title: A Shift Registers in Willingness to Pay for Internet Content
description: More Internet users are showing a willingness to pay for content online -- subscribing to news sites, for example, or paying fees to send e-greeting cards -- suggesting a shift in consumers' expectations that online services should be free, according to a survey of cyberspending patterns released yesterday.

description: UIJONGBU, South Korea:  On a concrete wall surrounding Camp Red Cloud, a small U.S. Army post here, an identification photograph of Sergeant Mark Walker stares blankly from dozens of posters proclaiming him "wanted" for the "crime of murder."

description: People in the skating community had heard rumors and stories over the years that judges had traded votes or been pressured by their federations to mark a skater ahead of another. But until a Russian accused of being a mobster was charged yesterday with conspiring to fix competitions during the Salt Lake Games, skating officials said that they had not heard of any connections between the sport and organized crime.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PAY PACKAGE IS ENDORSED Vodafone claimed a victory in a battle with minority shareholders on the compensation of the chief executive, Sir Christopher Gent. It said almost 85 percent of investors had approved his pay, despite the Vodafone Group's record loss last year of 16.15 billion ($25.43 billion at current rates) and a one-third decline in its share price. The company said Sir Christopher received the equivalent of $3.8 million in pay, shares and pension benefits in the year to March.

title: Great Idea For Trash, If It Works, Most Say
description: The beauty of the idea is its simplicity. Take the old city trash docks and the scuffed-up and dented city fleet of trash barges. And instead of sending trash to the Fresh Kills landfill each day, as these barges once did, deliver the smelly stuff in sealed containers to local railyards or shipyards that can move it to landfills anywhere east of the Mississippi.

A successor to Ms. Hill in San Francisco is being sought, the agency said. Hill, Holliday is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Drama as a DMZ in Israel; Arab and Jewish Actors Share the Stage as Partners in Provocative Works
description: One Friday night in October 2000, several bloody weeks into the Palestinian uprising called the Aksa intifada, the Arab-Hebrew Theater here presented an open-mike night. It went by the title ''In Jaffa, We Talk,'' and it was meant to reinforce in wrenching times the theater's commitment to partnership between the Jewish and Arab citizens of Israel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Both parties will pay a steep price at the polls.''

title: TV Magic, Made More Magical Still
description: IMAGINE a magic box that gives you an extra half-hour of free time every day. Imagine that it could also shift any TV show so that it comes on just as you sit down to watch. Imagine a gizmo so amazing that everyone who bought it turned into an evangelical fanatic, extolling its virtues to anyone within earshot.

title: They Propped It Up. Then It Fell Down. Perfect, They Said.
description: The Weald and Downland Open Air Museum, an hour's drive from London in West Sussex, England, is a kind of retirement home for medieval barns and other traditional farm buildings. The Downland Gridshell is the museum's first contemporary building. While it adapts one of the world's oldest vernacular building techniques -- latticework construction -- to form a large-span structure, it is a high-tech building in disguise.

title: Rise in Mortgage Requests
description: An index measuring applications for mortgages rose last week to the highest level in eight months, bolstered by a surge in refinancing, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: A Big Homer Lifts Burnitz and the Mets
description: Jeromy Burnitz has smashed helmets, dropped his head in disgust and discarded his bat at home plate as if allergic to it. But he has never lost his drive. So when Burnitz hit a 3-2 pitch from the Astros' Dave Mlicki in the first inning at Shea Stadium last night, he sped out of the batter's box.

title: A Fee-Friendly Bank? First, Map the A.T.M.'s
description: LITTLE did I know when I married Mr. Rockefeller that he had what some people might describe as an addiction to off-brand automated teller machines.

title: What the Senator Did Not Say
description: For violating ethics rules, Senator Robert Torricelli of New Jersey faced the music this week but proved he doesn't really know the tune. Even as he said he agreed with the findings of the Senate Ethics Committee, he continued to deny that he had done anything wrong.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Arrow Exterminators, Roswell, Ga., a termite and pest control company, named Match, Atlanta, as the first agency to handle its account, with billings estimated at less than $1 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Orthodox Church Berates Vatican
description: The Russian Orthodox Church said that the Roman Catholic Church is proselytizing in Russia, and that this activity dooms any dialogue. The Vatican has denied it is seeking to convert Orthodox believers. There have been angry exchanges between the two churches since February, when the Roman church formed four dioceses in Russia. Soon after, an Italian priest and a Polish bishop were denied Russian visas. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: How Spingold Was Defended
description: In 72 years, successful defense of the Spingold Knockout team title has been very rare. Before the string of successes by the Nick Nickell team in the past decade, only the Canadians Eric Murray, Sami Kehela, Bruce Elliott and Shorty Sheardown ever managed it. But George Jacobs and Ralph Katz added their names to this list at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Washington. With them again were four Italians, Giorgio Duboin, Norberto Bocchi, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace, whose many international successes include the European Team title in their homeland in June.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Dispute On Prisons
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove says he is likely to call state legislators into another special session soon to clear up a dispute over financing of the state's five privately run prisons. Lawmakers adjourned a special session on Tuesday after rejecting the governor's plan to resolve the dispute. Mr. Musgrove previously vetoed part of the state's prison budget for the privately run sites, and renegotiated contracts with their operators. He plans to shut one of the prisons, saying it is not needed.

title: Representatives Ask I.N.S. to Add Workers to New York Office
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, unloved and much criticized in its present form, may soon pass into history. But before many of its jobs are transferred to a new government agency, immigration officials in New York are lobbying for a fresh infusion of staff members and equipment.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: PRICELINE REPORTS SURGE IN EARNINGS Second-quarter earnings more than doubled at Priceline.com Inc. , a seller of discounted travel services on the Internet, as the company cut costs. Net income rose to $6.31 million, or 3 cents a share, from $2.82 million, or 1 cent a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue fell 16 percent, to $304.5 million from $364.8 million, Priceline.com said in a statement. Shares of Priceline rose 1 cent, to $1.85. (Bloomberg News)

title: Maxfeld Parrish Murals Stolen From Gallery
description: By cutting a hole in the ceiling of a West Hollywood art gallery and disabling its alarm system, one or more burglars were able to make off over night Sunday with a pair of Maxfield Parrish murals valued at $1.7 million to $2.5 million each.

title: Rare Place For Jews And Arabs To Meet
description: For schnitzel or a cup of coffee or just for conversation, the Frank Sinatra, as students called the student center whose cafeteria was bombed today, drew the range of Hebrew University's visiting and full-time students: Italians, Americans, South Koreans, and Israeli Jews and Arabs.

title: Promoters Try to Fill a Void By Finding Interesting Sites
description: ''My cummerbund is too tight'' and ''There's not enough vermouth in my martini'' are not usually heard at boxing matches. But if promoters have their way, such comments could become the norm as the sport tries to fill the void of competitive sizzle with upscale cachet.

title: Safety Steps for the Tyke Brigade
description: IT is impossible to be too careful where a child is concerned, whether it is in the baby's room, near a swimming pool or merely in a bathtub. While nothing takes the place of adult supervision, there are products that can help make areas around the house safer.

A masterful photographer, he enjoyed documenting everything around him with an eye for whimsy & beauty. We will miss loving him. Bereavement visits are on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Dr. David M. Maurice, 80, Eye Specialist and Professor
description: Dr. David M. Maurice, a pioneering eye specialist and researcher who invented a device that is commonly used to examine the cornea, died on July 20 in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Hard Life in Gaza, Through 13-Year-Old Eyes
description: Like most news reports and television images coming out of the Middle East these days, ''Gaza Strip,'' an unsparing new documentary by James Longley, offers little reason for optimism. The film, which opens today at the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village, was shot in the winter and spring of 2001, and it provides a grim, upsetting glimpse at the lives of some of the 1.2 million Palestinians who live in the crowded cities and refugee camps of Gaza.

description: WHEN riders were given a voice at the board table of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for the first time in 1995, Beverly Dolinsky plopped eagerly into the seat. She's a veteran complainer, and looked forward to kvetching on riders' behalf.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Cameras At Judge's Plea
description: A state appeals court in Brooklyn refused yesterday to bar cameras from a court proceeding on Monday at which a State Supreme Court justice is expected to plead guilty to charges that he took an $18,000 bribe to fix a civil case. The justice, Victor I. Barron, had argued that allowing still and television cameras at the plea would cause him ''irreparable harm.'' In an appeal he filed in July, he asked the appeals court to overrule a decision by the judge in his case, Nicholas Colabella. The judge ruled in February that a state law barring cameras in court was unconstitutional. In a technical decision yesterday, a panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court said that state law required an appeal from such an order within four months and that Justice Barron had waited too long. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Hindsight Makes Actors The Butt of the Jokes
description: There are reasons lame old sitcoms thrive in reruns: we watch to laugh at them, not with them. That's the premise of ''The Rerun Show'' on NBC, in which actors recreate scenes from creaky old series, word for word, with wickedly comic intent. They add a subtext here (the foster father on ''Diff'rent Strokes'' likes his sons a little too much) or a layer from real life there (the photos on the walls are mug shots of Todd Bridges and Dana Plato, actors from that series who ran into trouble with the law). Creating satiric sketches in the style of ''Saturday Night Live'' or ''Mad TV,'' this new series is just as uneven as those shows and occasionally just as funny.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Berlin Official Quits
description: Gregor Gysi, municipal economy minister in Berlin and a prominent member of the reform Communists, the Party of Democratic Socialism, resigned, just two days after admitting he had made personal use of bonus air miles from official flights during his time as a member of Parliament. He became a minister in Berlin when his party formed a coalition with Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's Social Democrats earlier this year. Mr. Gysi said he would voluntarily pay the equivalent of the flights to a human rights group. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Bolstering Faith of Indians, Pope Gives Mexico a Saint
description: During a lavishly staged Mass that mingled flourishes from the ancient Aztecs with traditional hymns, Pope John Paul II made an emphatic appeal today to the indigenous people who have abandoned the Roman Catholic Church and presented them with a saint they could call their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUADRACCI, HARRY
description: QUADRACCI - Harry. J.S. Eliezer Associates, Inc. wishes to extend its deepest sympathies to Betty Quadracci, her family and all of the employees of Quad/Graphics, Inc. for the passing of Harry Quadracci, our friend and an industry activist. Our association with Harry Quadracci spans nearly 30 years, both personally and professionally. He was the consummate, innovative businessman, with that special insight into how to make individuals work together to create the largest private printing firm in the world. In addition, he was a tireless philanthropist who supported many worthwhile causes, in Wisconsin and throughout the country. We will miss him dearly, in our everyday working environment and in our hearts.

description: Martin Ebner, the financier who spent the 1990's shaking up Switzerland's clubby corporations and coaxing the famously thrifty Swiss to invest in stocks, yielded today to a slumping market and gave up control of four main investment funds.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the signing of a peace accord by Rwanda and Congo to end the four-year war in Congo misstated the year that president Laurent Kabila of Congo died in office. He was killed in January 2001, not 2000, and was succeeded by his son, Joseph, who signed the agreement yesterday.

title: A Few Pinpricks, and Voil
description: ELLEN CAREY had always admired the vintage pinpricked lampshades she saw at the Paris flea markets. The technique is called picotage, the art of adding tiny holes to a lampshade to let the light shine through. "You have to find a pattern  it can be anything, dancing birds, florals, cherubs, ABC's  that is big enough that light will come through," she said. She liked a beaded floral pattern from a Megan Park scarf, so she photocopied it onto vellum, taped that to the shade and poked a pin through until she got the desired effect. "It took me five nights, after work," she said. "Most people would do it in one night."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDICOTT, YVONNE JANET (BLOSSOM)
description: ENDICOTT-Yvonne Janet (Blossom). Beloved wife of John Edward Endicott for over thirty years, passed away peacefully and without pain with family and holding hands with her husband at UCLA Medical Center, Saturday morning, July 27, 2002. Yvonne was born in Gawler, South Australia. Yvonne is survived by her sisters, brother, cousins, aunts, nieces and nephews in New Zealand and Australia. Yvonne fought with grace and dignity a long and courageous fight against brain stem tumors. Yvonne was a beautiful lady, loved by all who met her and will be deeply missed by all who knew her, none greater than her husband. Yvonne is now in a better place. Funeral services will be held Friday, August 2, at 2PM at Brentwood Presbyterian Church, 12000 San Vicente Blvd., L.A., CA 90049 (phone 310-826-5656). Light refreshments will follow at the church. The family will provide flowers at the church, and those who wish may make a donation in the name of ''The Yvonne Endicott Memorial Fund'' to The UCLA Neuro-Oncology Program, 710 Westwood Plaza, Suite 1-230, L.A., CA 90095. Pierce Brothers Westwood Village Mortuary (800 966-5113.

title: VERSICOR TO BUY BIOSEARCH FOR $261 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Versicor, a California-based biotechnology company, agreed to buy an Italian partner, Biosearch Italia, for $261 million in newly issued stock to expand its line of antibiotic drugs. Versicor will exchange 1.77 of its shares for each Biosearch share, the company said. That values Biosearch, which has a joint venture with Versicor, at $21.43 a share, about a third more than its closing share price on Tuesday of 16.14 euros ($15.77). After the acquisition, Versicor shareholders will own 55 percent of the company, with Biosearch's investors owning the rest.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Bias Suit
description: The State Supreme Court ruled 4 to 3 that a Detroit police lieutenant who claimed she was discriminated against because she is a lesbian had no right to sue the city. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Young Killer Denied Parole
description: A young woman who admitted helping cut the throat of a drinking companion and then helping disembowel the body before dumping it in a Central Park lake was denied parole yesterday for the second time. The woman, Daphne Abdela, was denied release, according to a parole hearing transcript, because of continued behavioral issues and a ''total disregard for human life.'' She pleaded guilty to manslaughter in 1998, when she was 15. She said that in 1997 she helped kill Michael McMorrow, a man she and a friend had been drinking with in Central Park. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Drug Coverage Failure
description: One-third of the elderly in this country have no prescription drug insurance at all, and many of the rest are poorly covered. Yet despite repeated promises stretching back to the 2000 election campaign, the 100 members of the United States Senate could not muster the will to pass even a stripped-down version of a drug bill that would have helped millions of America's neediest citizens. It was only modestly consoling that the Senate then approved the underlying bill to which the drug benefit had been attached -- a useful proposal to ease access to cheaper generic drugs.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Systems Lowers Forecasts
description: Adobe Systems Inc., the largest maker of software for publishing and graphic design, lowered its forecasts for third-quarter sales and profit as customers cut back on advertising-related spending. Sales in the current quarter will be $270 million to $290 million with profit of 18 cents to 23 cents a share, excluding certain costs, Adobe said in a statement. A year earlier, Adobe had sales of $292.1 million and profit of 28 cents on that basis. The third quarter will be the fifth consecutive quarter of declining sales for the software maker. Adobe last month said third-quarter sales would be $300 million to $320 million, less than the $328.2 million average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The company said third-quarter profit would be 24 cents to 27 cents a share. The stock has fallen 34 percent since then. Shares of Adobe fell 98 cents, to $23.96 yesterday in regular trading before the announcement.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Alters McAfee Bid
description: Network Associates Inc. yesterday extended its $131.2 million offer for the rest of McAfee.com after less than 5 percent of the shareholders of the computer-security software company accepted the bid. Network Associates, whose software guards against computer viruses, is offering 0.90 share for each McAfee.com Class A share. The offer, worth $18.46 a share when a takeover was first proposed in March, values McAfee.com at $10.94 a share, $2.15 less than its closing price yesterday of $13.09. Network Associates owns 75 percent of McAfee.com. Network Associates shares have lost more than half their value this year, as the software maker disclosed that it was the subject of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and forecast yearly sales that disappointed some investors. McAfee.com said the offer, accepted by only 4 percent of its shareholders, has weighed on its stock price. Network Associates, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., first bid 0.675 share in March, then raised it to 0.90 after the value of Network Associates shares declined. The offer, which was set to expire last night, was extended to Aug. 13. McAfee.com sells antivirus software through a subscription service over its Web site. Network Associates, maker of McAfee brand software, first sold shares of McAfee.com to investors in 1999, taking advantage of the high values given to Internet companies at the time. Shares of Network Associates fell 3 cents, to $12.15 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HARRAH'S TO BUY REMAINING STAKE IN JCC FOR $54 MILLION
description: Harrah's Entertainment Inc. said it agreed to buy the part of the JCC Holding Company it does not already own for $54 million in stock, ending a fight with the company, which manages Harrah's New Orleans Casino. Harrah's will exchange stock worth $10.54 for each share of JCC for a total of $54 million and assume or retire all of JCC's $27 million of debt, a Harrah's spokesman, Gary Thompson, said. The purchase price is a 17 percent premium to JCC's closing price of $9 Tuesday. The purchase will end litigation between the two companies, Harrah's said. Harrah's has said that JCC was blocking its nominations to the JCC board, and JCC said Harrah's failed to market the casino as it promised under the management agreement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Movers Plead Guilty To Fraud
description: The owners of five unlicensed moving companies have pleaded guilty to defrauding their customers by giving unrealistically low cost estimates and then holding customers' belongings hostage in return for large cash payments, Richard A. Brown, above, the Queens district attorney, announced yesterday. The belongings were stored in warehouses as far away as Nevada and Texas. The owners of the moving companies, Daniel and Ronit Mantoza and Morad Alfar, all from Queens, agreed to reimburse 120 clients whom they defrauded and return their property. Ms. Mantoza and Mr. Alfar will be sentenced to three months in jail and Mr. Mantoza will be sentenced to two months. All will be barred from the moving business, Mr. Brown said. The companies are Allstate Moving and Storage, On Budget Van Lines, Eilid Moving and Storage, Online Moving and Storage and In & Out Moving and Storage. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NORTEL SELLS CALIFORNIA OFFICES The Nortel Networks Corporation sold an office building in California's Silicon Valley to the South Bay Development Company for about $23 million, the lowest price per square foot in the area since the mid-1990's. South Bay and its partner Pacific Coast Capital Partners paid about $65 a square foot for Nortel's vacant 359,000-square-foot building in Santa Clara, said Mark Regoli, executive vice president of the real estate developer company, which is based in Campbell, Calif. Silicon Valley's office vacancy rate has risen to 32 percent from 3.5 percent since the late 1990's Internet boom faded, and rents have fallen to an average of $33 a square foot from a high of $100. Nortel, North America's second-biggest maker of telephone gear, spent about $40 million renovating the building and had it on the market earlier for $50 million, Mr. Regoli said. The sale by Nortel at the lowest per-square-foot price since at least 1996 is unlikely to lead to more transactions, said Bradley Martin, a director with Cushman & Wakefield.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPPER, DAVID, MD
description: TAPPER-David, MD, 57, died July 23 after a courageous battle with kidney cancer. He joined Children's Hospital and Regional Medical Center in Seattle, WA, in 1983 as their first surgeon-in-chief and professor and vice-chairman of Surgery at the University of Washington Medical School. Dr. Tapper recently concluded his presidency of the American Pediatric Surgical Association. Dr. Tapper graduated Magna Cum Laude in 1970 from the University of Maryland Medical School and began his surgical training at the University of California in San Francisco. Dr. Tapper completed a research fellowship at Boston Children's Hospital, and after completing his surgical residency in San Francisco in 1977, he returned to Boston for training in Pediatric Surgery at Boston Children's. He stayed on the faculty of the Harvard Medical School and was an attending surgeon at Boston Children's. Devoted to his family, he is survived by his loving wife of 34 years, Susan; their four children, JoEllen, Erica, Jacalyn, and Aaron; mother, Sylvia; sister, Martha (Jerry) Benesch, and brother, Jeffrey (Barbara). He was preceded in death by his father, Herman. In lieu of flowers, his family requests contributions be made to: The David Tapper Residents Fund, C/O UW Foundation, 1325 Fourth Ave. Suite 2000, Seattle, WA. 98101.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Part Of Manhattan Bridge To Close
description: Part of the Manhattan Bridge will be closed for a year beginning early this morning. The upper deck on the north side of the bridge will be closed so that its roadway can be rebuilt as part of a $500 million renovation, city transportation officials said. The upper deck is expected to reopen July 31 of next year. Until then, drivers will have the use of three Manhattan-bound lanes and two Brooklyn-bound lanes in the mornings, on the lower deck and the south upper deck. In the evening, the pattern will reverse, with three lanes going to Brooklyn and two open in the other direction. All traffic entering Manhattan will be able to reach westbound Canal Street and the northbound Bowery, but not eastbound Canal Street or Chrystie Street. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

description: An article on Friday about the Senate Ethics Committee's inquiry into charges that Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey improperly accepted gifts and cash from a political contributor, David Chang, misstated the timing of two checks that Mr. Torricelli gave him after receiving a television set for which Mr. Chang paid $1,877.90. According to a government official who has reviewed a summary of Mr. Torricelli's spending, the first check, for $800, was delivered within a week -- not six months -- after Mr. Torricelli received the television, in November 1998. The second check was delivered about a month later.

title: TRANSKARYOTIC WINS AN APPEAL ON DRUG PATENT RULING
description: Transkaryotic Therapies won a British appeals-court reversal of a ruling that the biotechnology company's anemia drug infringed on a patent for Amgen's $2 billion Epogen treatment. The patent dispute has blocked Transkaryotic and its partner, Aventis, from marketing Dynepo, which won European approval last year. Courts in the United States and Britain ruled last year that Transkaryotic, which makes drugs based on human proteins, and Aventis infringed on Amgen's patents, preventing Dynepo from cutting into Epogen's sales. In the United States, the Court of Appeals for the federal circuit in Washington heard arguments on the case in May, with a decision expected next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit For B Sky B
description: British Sky Broadcasting, the satellite TV company controlled by the News Corporation, reported its first quarterly profit. Net income in the fourth quarter was 1.7 million ($2.7 million), in contrast to a loss of 167 million in 2001. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bank's Profit Rises
description: Allied Irish Banks reported an after-tax profit of 537 million euros ($526 million) for the six months ended in June, an increase of nearly 4 percent from the 2001 period. Profit from domestic operations increased 8 percent, to 307 million euros before taxes. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Russian Man Is Arrested in Italy In a Plot to Fix Olympics Skating
description: A Russian accused of being in organized crime was arrested in Italy yesterday on an American complaint that he conspired to fix the pairs figure skating and ice dancing competitions at the recent Salt Lake Winter Olympics, which were dominated by the sport's judging scandals.

title: Uruguay Closes All Banks After Currency Falls by Half
description: Uruguay said today that it would keep its fragile banking system closed at least through Friday, despite the prospect of fresh aid.

title: Edison Reaches Contract on Philadelphia Schools
description: Edison Schools Inc., the nation's largest commercial manager of public schools, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to manage 20 elementary and middle schools in Philadelphia for five years.

title: Bush Is 'Furious' at American Toll in Latest Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 - President Bush reacted with outrage today to the deaths of five Americans in a bombing in Jerusalem on Wednesday, telling reporters that he was ``furious'' as he met with King Abdullah of Jordan at the White House in an attempt to nudge the Middle East toward peace.

title: Teaching Machines to Hear Your Prose and Your Pain
description: SINCE Sept. 11, United States intelligence agencies have been listening attentively for security threats. They have not been getting much help, though, from their electronic stenographers: the computer programs that automatically convert intercepted conversations and broadcasts into transcripts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBER, LACI, M.D.
description: TAUBER-Laci, M.D. Our friendship began in 1966. You left us Tuesday. Our daily telephone calls, for many years, were followed by visits with each other to learn more about our private lives. Our friendship, after you married Diana, became closer. We will remember all, Shalom Chaver. Vera and Imre

title: Last of 42nd Street's Peep Shows Closes
description: The formal closing yesterday of the last peep palace on 42nd Street, Peep-O-Rama, was a coda in the rebirth of Times Square as a kinder, gentler place. The sex shops and naughty tape stores have been wiped clean from the famed street.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Electronics Makers
description: Three of Japan's big consumer electronics manufacturers had profits in the April-June quarter, thanks to strong sales of flat-panel television sets, digital video recorders and other high-technology goods. Matsushita Electric Industrial, Sharp and Sanyo Electric reported profits. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mob Kills 2 After Truck Hits Women On a Stoop
description: Crumbling stone, dried blood and a man's silver watch band were among the remnants of the night of horror here.

title: Plans for the Neglected East River Shoreline
description: EVEN if more innovative plans are drawn up for the World Trade Center site, only a fraction of Lower Manhattan will be directly affected. Redevelopment of ground zero alone will not shape downtown's future nor solve some of its chronic problems.

title: CHUBB GETS INDIAN APPROVAL FOR INSURANCE VENTURE
description: The Chubb Corporation, a leading business insurer, won approval from the Indian government to buy 26 percent of a nonlife insurance venture with the Housing Development Finance Corporation, India's largest mortgage lender. Chubb will pay 737.6 million rupees ($15.1 million) for the stake, a statement by the commerce and industry ministry said. India's Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority, allows foreign insurance companies to hold no more than a 26 percent stake in local insurance companies. Chubb's Indian venture, called HDFC Chubb General Insurance Ltd., would focus on automobile, accident and household insurance policies.

title: One Man Can't Fix New York's Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's choice of Joel I. Klein as the next schools chancellor may have been surprising to many New Yorkers. But Mr. Klein is not the only manager with an unconventional background to take control of an urban school system; other cities have handed over their beleaguered systems to nontraditional (read non-educator) types. This collection of retired generals, corporate executives and former elected officials who have assumed overall responsibility for underperforming schools throughout the nation has a very mixed track record.

title: Jersey City Man, Captured at Canadian Border, Is Arrested in Slayings of Wife and 2 In-Laws
description: A Jersey City man suspected of killing his pregnant wife and two in-laws was arrested Tuesday night at the Canadian border, the authorities said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Brokerage Accused Of Fraud
description: A stock brokerage firm that federal regulators said used high-pressure sales tactics to cheat investors out of more than $1.5 million has had its assets frozen by a federal judge. The judge granted the request of the regulators, the Securities and Exchange Commission, to issue a temporary restraining order against the brokerage, Platinum Investment Corporation. Platinum's lawyer, Carl F. Schoeppl of Boca Raton, said that the company is going to ''vindicate itself through the court process.'' The S.E.C. charged that the brokerage used ''boiler-room'' tactics to sell shares in a related company and in a hedge fund. The S.E.C. said in federal court that the brokerage used ''patently false'' misrepresentations to defraud at least 56 investors. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Progress in Labor Talks
description: Putting aside the thorny issue of revenue sharing for a day, negotiators for baseball's club owners and the players spent their brief meeting yesterday on the subjects of minimum salary and the benefits plan. The owners presented counterproposals on both issues, and both sides pronounced the movement positive.

title: Senate Passes Broad Trade Powers for President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 - The Senate agreed today not to interfere in trade deals negotiated by the White House, giving final approval to an accord requested by two presidents over eight years. Bush administration officials said they would immediately use the long-sought authority to accelerate trade talks stalled for years by partisan differences.

title: Bringing Congo's Great War to an End
description: For the past four years, a conflict has raged in the Democratic Republic of Congo that has amounted to an African world war. At various times it has drawn soldiers from seven nations into a country the size of Western Europe. It has killed more than two million people, either directly or through disease and starvation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Sex Abuse Of 2 Girls Reported
description: A man sexually abused two girls, 6 and 8 years old, on the rooftop of an apartment building in Bronx Park South on Tuesday night, the police said yesterday. The man, whom the girls did not know, met them as they were playing in the first-floor hallway of the building just before 9 p.m. and asked one girl where her grandmother was, said Deputy Chief Joseph Reznick, commander of the Bronx detectives. The man then asked the girls to take him to the rooftop of the five-story building, on Southern Boulevard between 178th and 179th Streets, where he asked them to take off their clothes and then abused them, Chief Reznick said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: No-Parent Households
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: 'Regrets' By Pakistani
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan wrapped up a three-day visit with expression of ''regrets'' for the behavior of Pakistani soldiers during the civil war in 1971 that led to the formation of Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan. An estimated 3 million people died. But he did not address the fate of 250,000 Pakistanis who have been stranded in Bangladesh ever since. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: An Adman Whose Fantasy Was Hardly the Hamptons
description: NEIL KRAFT is the man who put Marky Mark and Kate Moss on ad posters, showing off their Calvin Klein underwear. His advertising firm, KraftWorks, makes Playtex bras look desirable by putting them on unapproachable blondes in wheat fields.

He was Robert Trout, lawyer for the Merrill investment banker Schuyler Tilney -- not G. Kelly Martin, president of Merrill's international private client division.

title: Any Painting Is Improved By a Colorful Background
description: It not only holds art, but also looks like art. For young children, there is a new easel designed by Alla Kaznovsky, an architect in Los Angeles, who teaches children about architecture. The colorful plastic easel has translucent sliding drawers for supplies, as well as trays, a storage area for paper and pads and a holder with a 100-foot roll of paper. The height is adjustable. The easel will be available in September for $175 at the MOMA Design Stores at 44 West 53rd Street and 81 Spring Street (Crosby Street); (800) 793-3167, or www.momastore.org. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan To Make More Cars
description: The Nissan Motor Company says it will increase production up to 20 percent in Japan as it expands its new car lineup and tries to increase market share. Nissan Motor said it planned to make an additional 300,000 cars in Japan by 2005. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Poll Shows Race Narrowing
description: Gov. John G. Rowland's lead over his Democratic challenger has shrunk to 17 percentage points, and Mr. Rowland's approval rating is the lowest in six years, according to a new Quinnipiac University poll. The survey showed Mr. Rowland, a two-term Republican, leading Democrat William E. Curry Jr., above, by 51 to 34 percent, a narrowing of the 55-to-27-percent lead the governor registered in the university's May poll. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: A Guardhouse to Make Deep Thinkers Think Twice
description: A pentagonal guardhouse with a canopy on tilted stilts, far right, has been added to the geometry of Rockefeller University, which also has a hemispherical auditorium and a parabolic atrium. Designed by Henry Smith-Miller and Laurie Hawkinson, right, the metal guardhouse hugs the filigree fencing at York Avenue and 66th Street. When completed, it will replace a wooden hut that is hard for visitors to find, said Cathy Yarbrough, a university spokeswoman. The structure, she said, ''suits the gestalt of this place -- it's part of the culture here to have surroundings that encourage people to think.'' The design was based on a 1930's fantasy by Iacov Chernikov, a Russian constructivist. Mr. Smith-Miller called the house a ''wonderful, outrageous, spectacular, energetic event,'' while conceding that it may be New York's smallest building. EVE M. KAHN

title: Loral Space Narrows Loss
description: Loral Space and Communications said today that its second-quarter loss narrowed as satellite-manufacturing and technology sales rose.

description: Two former executives of WorldCom Inc. were arrested in Manhattan today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a variety of charges, including securities fraud, in connection with billions of dollars in accounting irregularities at the telecommunications company.

title: Experts Warn of High Risk for American Invasion of Iraq
description: In the first public hearings on the administration's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein from the Iraqi presidency, an array of experts warned a Senate committee today that an invasion of Iraq would carry significant risks ranging from more terrorist attacks against American targets to higher oil prices.

title: Snakebite Advice Is Close to Snake Oil
description: Most people know how to treat a snakebite: Apply a tourniquet above the site, cut the skin, suck out the poison, spit it out and remember to be more careful in the future.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TALK WITH NORTH KOREA Japan and North Korea agreed during ministerial talks to make "serious efforts" to normalize relations. The meeting between Foreign Minister Yoriko Kawaguchi and her North Korean counterpart, Paek Nam Sun, during regional security talks in Brunei was the first ministerial contact in two years. Divisive issues include the apparent abduction of 11 Japanese by North Korea during the 1970's and 80's, reportedly to train North Korean spies in Japanese customs.    (Agence France-Presse)

description: WHEN it comes to the futuristic, nostalgia can be a complicated business.

title: Parcells to Join ESPN's N.F.L. Team
description: After signing a multiyear, multimillion-dollar contract yesterday to become one of the guys on ESPN's ''Sunday N.F.L. Countdown,'' Bill Parcells said, ''This is the end of it,'' when asked about the constant rumors that he would return to coaching.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Postal Blues
description: Profit for 2002 at Deutsche Post World Net is expected to be down at least 10 to 15 percent from last year's $1.6 billion. In the first half, profit fell to $152.4 million from $1.03 billion in the period a year earlier. Victor Homola (NYT)

Services Thursday, 11AM, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th and Madison.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; G.E. Joining Move Toward New Way To Count Options
description: General Electric, the nation's biggest company by stock market value, yesterday joined a small but growing group of companies that are changing how they account for stock options. G.E. went even further by saying that top executives would no longer be allowed to take profits immediately after cashing in options.

title: Weyerhaeuser to Cut 142 Jobs in Kentucky
description: FEDERAL WAY, Wash., July 31 (Bloomberg News)  The Weyerhaeuser Company , the lumber and paper producer, said today that it will close a cardboard-corrugating machine in Kentucky and eliminate 142 jobs, or less than 1 percent of its work force, as a result of its purchase of Willamette Industries.

title: U.S. Trade Bill Could Hurt Philippine Tuna Industry, Officials Will Tell Powell in Manila
description: A last-minute compromise by Congress on tuna tariffs has done little to appease officials in the Philippines, who are likely to protest to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell when he visits Manila this weekend.

title: Delays Seen in Superfund Cleanup Projects
description: The inspector general of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that insufficient financing within the Superfund program was delaying the cleanup of toxic waste sites and preventing ''important work needed to protect human health and the environment.''

title: A Small Theater Nurturing Big Ideas (and a Big Broadway Hit)
description: Every day James C. Nicola walks from his East Village apartment to his office at 79 East Fourth Street. As he said in a recent interview: ''There's never a morning that I don't think, 'I'm going to work and I love what I am doing.' I'm one of the very fortunate people.''

Terms were not disclosed. Gatorade has been an NBA partner since 1984.

description: This is what a curfew declared by the Israeli Army looked like here today: taxis jammed downtown streets, vendors hawked fruits and vegetables at the central market and thousands of townspeople shopped in stores and strolled the sidewalks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DR. EDMUND R.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Jobless Rate Rises
description: French unemployment rose by 17,000 people in June, to 2.41 million, or 9 percent of the work force. It was the highest level since October 2000. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Guerrilla Group Asserts Itself
description: A month after the police cracked the guerrilla group known as November 17, the band has re-emerged with a proclamation that it is considering hostage-taking as a means of defending more than a dozen members awaiting trial. Published in the Athens daily Eleftherotypia, the tract also reasserted the group's anti-Americanism. The Public Order Ministry called the group's assertions lies. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Deutsche Bank Board Defends Chief on Mannesmann Payouts
description: With the threat of a criminal case hanging over its chief executive, Deutsche Bank issued a strongly worded statement today defending the executive, Josef Ackermann, and dismissing potential charges against him as ''arbitrary and incomprehensible.''

title: Busy Time For Baffert: A Wedding And a Race
description: With his shock of white hair, his ever-present shades and his glib mannerisms, the trainer Bob Baffert exudes California cool. He seems intent on keeping his existence simple, laid-back and carefree, but sometimes even he is a bit overwhelmed.

title: Bush Criticized by Lawmakers on Corporate Governance
description: Less than 24 hours after a grand display of bipartisanship at a White House ceremony celebrating President Bush's signature on a major corporate-fraud bill, lawmakers today criticized Mr. Bush for what they called an abrupt watering down of the legislation. The Democrats also raised questions about an offshore subsidiary of the Harken Energy Corporation formed when Mr. Bush was on the company's board.

title: Lahore Journal; Cybercafe Crackdown May Trip Up Leering Boys
description: Shahid Masood is a bit down on the Internet these days. But he has never seen anyone who looks like a terrorist at the cybercafe he owns here.

title: U.S. Initiates Investigation Of Accounting At AOL Unit
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that the Justice Department had begun an investigation into accounting practices at its AOL division, after the initiation last week of an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: The Fragile Recovery
description: The latest raft of economic data released yesterday was cause for more heartburn. The weaker-than-expected growth for the second quarter of this year -- an annual rate of 1.1 percent, half of what had been predicted -- calls into question the solidity of the recovery and gives more credence to warnings by some analysts that the economy could be in for a possible ''double-dip'' recession.

title: Tiny Digital Camera With a Tiny Price And Many Features
description: Shrinking size is nothing new in a digital camera, with many wafer-thin pocket-size models now on the market, but a rock-bottom price is unusual. The StyleCam Blink from SiPix -- which measures less than 2 inches wide by 2 inches high and fits easily in a shirt pocket -- comes in at a penny less than $40.

title: SENATE KILLS PLAN FOR DRUG BENEFITS THROUGH MEDICARE
description: The Senate today killed legislation to provide prescription drug benefits promised to the elderly by politicians of both parties. But it overwhelmingly passed a bill intended to give all Americans greater access to low-cost generic versions of brand-name medicines.

title: Russia Defers $714 Million Oil Stock Sale
description: Russia postponed a $714 million sale of Lukoil shares today because of slumping stock markets. It would have been the country's largest stock offering.

title: In an Ancient Game, Computing's Future
description: EARLY in the film ''A Beautiful Mind,'' the mathematician John Nash is seen sitting in a Princeton courtyard, hunched over a playing board covered with small black and white pieces that look like pebbles. He was playing Go, an ancient Asian game. Frustration at losing that game inspired the real Mr. Nash to pursue the mathematics of game theory, research for which he eventually won a Nobel Prize.

title: Hearst-Argyle's Net More Than Triples
description: Hearst-Argyle Television Inc., the owner of 24 television stations, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit more than tripled.

description: A federal judge in Manhattan indicated yesterday that he might be ready to consider the constitutionality of the Bush administration's decision to place Jose Padilla, the former Chicago gang member accused of plotting to explode a radioactive bomb in the United States, into military custody.

title: After Easy Victories, Brooklyn State Senator Faces a Tough Primary Battle
description: In the 10 years since she was first elected to the State Senate, Nellie Santiago has never faced an election without a Democratic primary challenge. Still, Ms. Santiago, who represents Bushwick and Cypress Hills in Brooklyn, has typically won easily with wide margins over little-known opponents.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: New Music Service Is Planned
description: Pressplay, the online music service owned by Universal Music Group and Sony Music Entertainment, plans to introduce a new version of the service today that provides consumers more flexibility at lower prices than any of the fee-based services have offered so far. For $9.95 a month, customers can listen to and download as many songs as they want, although the downloads will disappear if they stop paying the monthly fee. The company will also sell packages of 5, 10 and 20 tracks for about $1 a track, which consumers can keep forever, burn to CD's and transfer to the most popular portable devices, with the exception of the Apple Ipod. The service is limited to the catalogs of three of the five major record labels. Amy Harmon (NYT)

description: When Yankees Manager Joe Torre collected All-Star ballots from opposing managers a few weeks ago, Mike Mussina was mentioned often. With a standout career and a spiffy record this season, Mussina's reputation preceded him.

description: BRITAIN: A ROYAL GESTURE Queen Elizabeth II became Britain's first reigning monarch to visit a British mosque, as part of a nationwide tour celebrating her 50 years on the throne. As a gesture of respect, the queen slipped off her shoes as she entered the prayer room of the Scunthorpe Islamic Center in northern England. A spokesman for the mosque said the visit was a tribute to Great Britain's 3.5 million Muslims. Royal aides are eager to include all of Britain's major faiths in the celebrations for the queen's golden jubilee. Today, she is due to visit a Sikh temple.    (Agence France-Presse)

title: Corrections

It took place in 1950, not 1951.

title: Can't Sleep on the Red-Eye? Burn a Bunch of CD's Instead
description: For those seeking a way to burn CD's on the go, Archos Technology has introduced the Cesar CDRW/MPM, a portable CD writer powered directly by a notebook or desktop computer.

title: Judge Faces Charges Of D.W.I.
description: A State Supreme Court justice who the police said rammed her car into another car and a pickup truck in the parking lot of a Bronx department store last week has been arrested on drunken driving charges, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Panel Finds No Major Flaws in Nuclear Treaty
description: None of the major technical issues raised by opponents of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty posed a serious problem, a panel of experts reported yesterday. The treaty was defeated in the Senate in 1999.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Sells California Offices
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation sold an office building in California's Silicon Valley to the South Bay Development Company for about $23 million, the lowest price per square foot in the area since the mid-1990's. South Bay and its partner Pacific Coast Capital Partners paid about $65 a square foot for Nortel's vacant 359,000-square-foot building in Santa Clara, said Mark Regoli, executive vice president of the real estate developer company, which is based in Campbell, Calif. Silicon Valley's office vacancy rate has risen to 32 percent from 3.5 percent since the late 1990's Internet boom faded, and rents have fallen to an average of $33 a square foot from a high of $100. Nortel, North America's second-biggest maker of telephone gear, spent about $40 million renovating the building and had it on the market earlier for $50 million, Mr. Regoli said. The sale by Nortel at the lowest per-square-foot price since at least 1996 is unlikely to lead to more transactions, said Bradley Martin, a director with Cushman & Wakefield.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARPS, RUTH
description: ARPS-Ruth. The partners, associates and support staff of the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP and Affiliates mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Ruth Arps. Mrs. Arps, the widow of one of the firm's founding partners, Leslie H. Arps, will be fondly remembered for her caring nature, unwavering good cheer and invaluable contributions to the culture and success of the firm and for her tireless work on behalf of the Legal Aid Society and other charities. She will be deeply missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with her family. A memorial service will be held today, August 1, 2002, from 2 to 4PM in Heritage Hall at Seabury Retirement Community, 200 Seabury Dr in Bloomfield, CT.

title: Solace in the Stars
description: In the face of horror it is natural to avert our eyes. Like so many people, I hid my eyes on Sept. 11. That day, which was supposed to be like any other, was shattered first by the sound of a low-flying airplane, a sound so loud I thought it would hit my home. From the corner of my street in Tribeca I witnessed the nightmare that followed. Days, weeks and months went by and I continued to hide my eyes from the scenes of sadness and terror around me. My neighbors and I went about life as best we could, hoping that in time we would absorb what had happened, understand it and go on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMILTON, T. STEWART, M.D.
description: HAMILTON-T. Stewart, M.D. retired President and Executive Director of Hartford Hospital, died peacefully on July 29, 2002, with his family at his side. He was 91. Dr. Hamilton began his career in hospital administration in 1941 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. After the war he moved to Hartford, Connecticut, where he assumed the leadership of Hartford Hospital, a position he was to hold until his retirement in 1976. Dr. Hamilton was instrumental in the development of Medicare and Medicaid in the 1960s. His testimony before Congress helped ensure the passage of Medicare legislation, and he was present at the signing in the Oval Office. The first Medicare reimbursement check in the country was issued to Hartford Hospital in 1966. Dr. Hamilton was predeceased by his wife of 65 years, Amy, in 2000. He is survived by three daughters, Ann H. Brainerd (Mrs. Lyman Brainerd) of Sedona, Arizona, Barbara H. Almy (Mrs. David Almy) of Manchester - By - The - Sea, Massa chusetts, and Jeanne C. Hamilton of Avon, Connecticut. He is also survived by five grandchildren, six greatgrandchildren, five stepgrandchildren and three nieces. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hartford Hospital, 80 Seymour Street, Hartford, Connecticut 06102; Mystic Seaport, Mystic, Connecticut; or to Duncaster, 80 Loeffler Road, Bloomfield, Connecticut 06002. A memorial service will be held in the Education and Resource Center at Hartford Hospital, 560 Hudson Street, on Saturday, August 10 at 1:00 PM.

The officer, Hernando Olaya, 31, had begun to unload his 9-millimeter pistol shortly before 9:15 p.m. on Wednesday while his son Jonathan was still in the room, the police said. Moments later, the gun fired, sending a bullet through the boy's right forearm and passing into his chest, they said. The boy died of his injuries at 12:05 a.m. at North Shore University Hospital. title: 36 Hours | Portland, Me.

You'll still find lobster boats and lighthouses here, but Portland, the state's largest city, with 230,000 year-round inhabitants in its metropolitan area, is also home to the University of Maine School of Law, a major teaching hospital (the Maine Medical Center) and even a minor-league baseball team, the Portland Sea Dogs. Portland also has a growing number of immigrants, particularly from African and Asian countries. Enjoy the diverse culture and tradition here, but don't leave the city without trying a lobster roll. title: Technology Briefing | Software: Quantum Names New Chief Executive
description: The Quantum Corporation said yesterday that it had hired the former Microsoft president and chief operating officer, Rick Belluzzo, as chief executive , succeeding Michael Brown, 43, who will remain as chairman. Mr. Belluzzo's appointment as head of the maker of computer data-storage devices is effective Sept. 3, Quantum said. Mr. Belluzzo, 48, quit Microsoft on May 1 in a reorganization giving Steve Ballmer and other top executives more control of the world's biggest software maker. Quantum, whose fiscal 2002 sales fell 29 percent from 2001, has struggled with declining sales as customers like Hewlett-Packard and Dell Computer resold fewer Quantum machines in a slowdown in computer-technology spending. Before Microsoft, Mr. Belluzzo was responsible for all of Hewlett-Packard's computer systems and storage products, Quantum said. Shares of Quantum rose 24 cents, or 11.5 percent, to $2.32. They had fallen 79 percent this year. Quantum is based in Milpitas, Calif.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: ADC To Sell Or Close A Business
description: ADC Telecommunications yesterday said that it would sell or close its optical components business, and that it planned additional job cuts on top of the 3,300 positions it has eliminated since last November. ADC provides network equipment, fiber optics, software and systems integration services used to deliver high-speed Internet, data, video and voice services. It has operations in nearly 100 countries. ADC said it expected to decide the fate of the unit by the end of its fiscal year on Oct. 31. Its products include lasers used in telecommunications equipment. ADC has retained Lehman Brothers to help seek a buyer. The optical components business has operations in Canberra, Australia; Jarfalla, Sweden; and Vadnais Heights and Shakopee in Minnesota. It employs 350 people worldwide, an ADC spokesman said. ADC said it had also discontinued its Avidia DSL Access Multiplexer and plans to focus its on its next-generation DSL access platform -- devices that deliver high-speed communications over the ''last mile'' between customers and providers. Since November, ADC has closed 41 facilities worldwide and plans additional closings and consolidations the next three months. Mr. Clark said the company had not determined how many or which operations might be affected. Shares of ADC fell 18 cents, or 10 percent, to $1.62.

Mr. McCall said the administration had failed to adopt many of the recommendations he made in a 1999 audit that found widespread problems in oversight of the homes. Mr. McCall noted that the state still had not adopted systems to track inspections and complaints. "There is just no excuse for the administration's lack of progress on situations that threaten peoples' health and well-being," said Mr. McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor. It said his findings were out of date, asserting that it had taken numerous steps in recent months to improve oversight. Clifford J. Levy (NYT)

title: The Evolution of Alfred Stieglitz, Ever the Perfectionist
description: In the last decades of his life, Alfred Stieglitz (1864-1946) spent many hours destroying and reprinting his old photographs. In 1929 he told the painter Arthur Dove that he was ''burning up books and papers -- negatives and prints,'' especially snapshots, manipulated prints and photographs taken before 1900. In the early 1930's he told his wife and muse, Georgia O'Keeffe, that this editing was ''self-torture.''

title: Golf Group Withdraws Plan For Resort Near San Antonio
description: The Professional Golfers Association today pulled out of a plan to build a golf resort atop the Edwards Aquifer, the main source of drinking water for San Antonio, after opponents gathered enough petitions to force a citywide referendum on the proposal in November.

title: No Longer Vandals at Gate, but a City Wrecking Crew
description: Hetty A. Fox does not want anyone to know it, but she has started to limp. The cartilage in her left hip is gone, worn away by too much basketball, too much dancing and too many hot afternoons spent walking door to door in the South Bronx asking for help in keeping her block -- and its children -- from disappearing.

Joe Mathebula, who is close to clinching a $50 million mining deal, swivels and swings and his nearly perfect shot whistles through the thorn trees as his colleagues hoot and his caddie scrambles.

title: Solidarity Helps Ensure Security

Rescue crews used sophisticated machinery to pump out freezing water and pump in warm air to keep the men alive. They relied on huge drills to dig deep below the surface, and on medical helicopters to transport the rescued men to the hospital.

His conviction was in the way he attacked one guitar after another at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night: windmilling through power chords, wrenching out sustained notes and then slicing them off, machine-gunning harsh tremolos and then speeding and squiggling with manic insistence. The Who had something to prove, and he knew it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, HOWARD F., M.D.
description: STOCK-Howard F., M.D., 65. Died August 1 after a courageous five-year battle with multiple myeloma. He was president of the Westchester Psychiatric Society, president of the Westchester Medical Society, and a fellow of the American Psychiatric Association. For eight years he was chair of the department of psychiatry of White Plains Hospital and continued on its staff until his retirement in 1998 due to his illness. He began his private practice in New York City, moving it to Scarsdale in 1972. In 2000, he was honored by the Westchester Consumer Empowerment Center in New Rochelle. A native of Pittsburgh, PA, he earned a BS from Washington and Jefferson College, an MD from Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and later served as a psychiatrist in the Army during the Vietnam War. He was a member of the Scarsdale Non-Partisan Nominating Committee, a Village Advisory Committee, and coached sports teams for his children. After retiring, he volunteered for Scarsdale Meals on Wheels. An advocate for medicine and for the rights of patients, he recognized the benefits of medical savings accounts several years ago and lobbied passionately for their adoption. In addition, he loved golf, computers, and cars. He leaves his loving wife of 38 years, Evelyn; their two caring daughters, Elisabeth Stock and Andrea Spaar; their sons-in-law, Benjamin Austin and Richard Spaar; his mother, Selma Stock; his devoted sisters, Barbara Merwitzer and Elaine Krasnick (Donald); his sister-in-law, Rachel Levy (Donald), and numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held at noon on Sunday, August 4th, at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, NY. Memorial contributions can be made in his name to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, New Canaan, CT., and to the International Myeloma Foundation of North Hollywood, CA.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: Disabled Device Led To Elevator Deaths
description: A piece of tape over a safety mechanism allowed the elevator at a Colts Neck estate to ascend with its gate open on Wednesday, killing two little girls who were inside the car, the authorities said today. Their heads were caught between the car and the floor above. The mechanism was designed to prevent the elevator from moving without the gate being closed, the Monmouth County prosecutor, John Kaye, said. But for reasons he cannot explain, he said, it was taped over, closing a switch to signal that the gate was closed and allow the elevator to move. Nanci and Areli Franco, 6 and 7, were killed in the accident. The children were the daughters of the caretaker of the house and 10-acre estate. There is no evidence of criminal wrongdoing, the prosecutor said. Iver Peterson (NYT)

Torricelli's campaign, called "Fighter," comes two days after the Senate Ethics Committee released a letter that "severely admonished" Mr. Torricelli for using his office to do favors for a contributor who gave him improper gifts. It began running yesterday on stations in New York and Philadelphia and is the first television commercial in the race since the Republican primary in June. It will also improve training and report to the state on the quality of care.

Much of the increase reflected the sale of one million shares to SK Telecom as KT completed a government-mandated privatization program. Profits were also higher on sales of broadband Internet service to another 256,469 subscribers, bringing the number of South Koreans subscribing to the service to 4.3 million, a market share that represents nearly 50 percent. The foundation works with community resources and government in New York City to provide affordable housing for low-income families and seniors. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Officer Charged In Theft From Suspect
description: A New York City police detective was charged yesterday with taking a credit card from someone he had arrested and using it to buy an electric toothbrush and a telephone answering system, the authorities said. The detective, Edgardo Rodriguez, 38, faces charges of grand larceny and official misconduct, the Queens district attorney's office said. Detective Rodriguez, a member of the detective squad in the 106th Precinct in Queens, took the credit card on July 23 and used it to buy $370 worth of goods soon after, said Betsy Herzog, a spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. When he tried to use the card again he was denied, and the card was confiscated, she said. He has been suspended from the force, a police spokesman said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Judging on Thin Ice
description: It's hard to imagine two human activities apparently further removed from each other than organized crime and figure skating. And it's hard to understand just how a Russian mob figure, born in Uzbekistan and now living in Italy, might have found it worth his while to meddle, long distance, in ice dancing of all sports. The whole thing sounds like a particularly dark-humored episode of ''The Sopranos,'' in which heavily muscled fixers come a cropper when they try tangling with well-conditioned women in rhinestone-studded body stockings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULTER, JANIS
description: COULTER-Janis. Died July 31, 2002 in a heinous terrorist attack on the Mount Scopus campus of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem. American Friends of The Hebrew University and the Office of Academic Affairs for the Rothberg International School mourn the profound loss of Janis Coulter, a friend, colleague and mentor to scores of young people pursuing higher education. Janis served as the Assistant Director of the Office of Academic Affairs for the Rothberg International School at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem. In this important role, she supervised the admissions of American graduate students to the full array of Rothberg International School graduate programs. A consummate professional, Janis supervised the marketing of the Rothberg International School in the United States and administered the Anna Sobol Levy Fellowship Program. Janis was known for her creative vision and also an indefatigable researcher who devoted much of her own time to advancing the educational mission of the Rothberg International School. She helped overseas exchange students and their families with kindness and good humor, qualities that endeared her to co-workers and friends. An honors student, Janis earned her B.A. from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. She obtained her M.A. from the University of Denver and studied at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem from 1996-1997, focusing on the field of Jewish Civilization. We deeply mourn the passing of Janis Coulter and extend our sympathies to her entire family. She touched the lives of many people in positive, lifeaffirming ways and she will truly be missed and remembered. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Peter Willner, Executive Vice President The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Prof. Menachem Magidor, President Prof. Haim Rabinowitch, Rector Prof. Menahem Milson, Provost Rothberg International School

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: INTEREST RATES ARE UNCHANGED For the ninth consecutive month, the Bank of England and the European Central Bank left their benchmark interest rates unchanged. The Bank of England kept its rate at 4 percent, suggesting that an expected recovery is not yet strong enough to accelerate inflation. The rates are the lowest in almost four decades, spurring a surge in borrowing that has helped push house prices up 21 percent the last year, one lender said. The European bank kept its rate, unchanged since Nov. 8, at 3.25 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: In the Dells, Where Youth And Nostalgia Ski Side by Side
description: THE alarm goes off. It's 11:45 on a Friday morning in late July. Dan Laughlin, 22, having gotten to bed around 3:30 a.m. -- an early night, for a change -- wakes up in the place he's calling home this summer: a 14-by-58-foot trailer decorated with blue-tinted lights, 25 empty Captain Morgan rum bottles lined up along the living room wall and leopard-print curtains sewn by the girlfriend of one of his two roommates. He scrambles out of bed, pulls on a pair of red bathing trunks, puts in his contact lenses, dons a pair of silver wraparound sunglasses and heads off to work.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: 13 BODIES FOUND ON BEACH The police in Tarifa found the bodies of 13 Africans on the beach. They had apparently been trying to get to Europe illegally. A helicopter patrolling the Strait of Gibraltar had earlier spotted people in a boat. The police believe the skipper forced his passengers overboard to make his getaway. Shortly after the bodies were found, the police arrested eight Africans nearby who may have been on the boat. A Moroccan immigrant group says 4,000 people have died or disappeared since 1997 in the strait and in the Atlantic between Africa and the Canary Islands, which belong to Spain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: McCall Criticizes Oversight Of Adult Homes
description: The state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, yesterday stepped up his criticism of the Pataki administration's regulation of adult homes for the mentally ill. Mr. McCall said the administration had failed to adopt many of the recommendations he made in a 1999 audit that found widespread problems in oversight of the homes. Mr. McCall noted that the state still had not adopted systems to track inspections and complaints. ''There is just no excuse for the administration's lack of progress on situations that threaten peoples' health and well-being,'' said Mr. McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor. In response, the administration accused Mr. McCall of ''unnecessarily scaring vulnerable New Yorkers to further his personal political ambitions.'' It said his findings were out of date, asserting that it had taken numerous steps in recent months to improve oversight. Clifford J. Levy (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Ewing: Mayor's Firm Plans 2nd Jersey Office
description: As mayor of New York, Michael R. Bloomberg likes to chastise businesses that build outside the city. But Bloomberg L.P., the financial information company that Mr. Bloomberg founded and ran until he stepped down to run New York City, is planning to build a new office complex in Ewing, N.J. Christine Taylor, a spokeswoman for the firm, said that no jobs from the city would be relocated to the proposed site, which would be used to house some of the operations that no longer fit in its offices in Princeton, N.J. She said the company's plans to build a new headquarters in Manhattan at Lexington Avenue and 58th Street were still on schedule. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: ADC TO SELL OR CLOSE A BUSINESS ADC Telecommunications yesterday said that it would sell or close its optical components business, and that it planned additional job cuts on top of the 3,300 positions it has eliminated since last November. ADC provides network equipment, fiber optics, software and systems integration services used to deliver high-speed Internet, data, video and voice services. It has operations in nearly 100 countries. ADC said it expected to decide the fate of the unit by the end of its fiscal year on Oct. 31. Its products include lasers used in telecommunications equipment. ADC has retained Lehman Brothers to help seek a buyer. The optical components business has operations in Canberra, Australia; Jarfalla, Sweden; and Vadnais Heights and Shakopee in Minnesota. It employs 350 people worldwide, an ADC spokesman said. ADC said it had also discontinued its Avidia DSL Access Multiplexer and plans to focus its on its next-generation DSL access platform  devices that deliver high-speed communications over the "last mile" between customers and providers. Since November, ADC has closed 41 facilities worldwide and plans additional closings and consolidations the next three months. Mr. Clark said the company had not determined how many or which operations might be affected. Shares of ADC fell 18 cents, or 10 percent, to $1.62.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: CenturyTel Completes Sale Of Wireless Unit
description: CenturyTel Inc., which sells telephone service in 22 states, yesterday completed the sale of its mobile-phone business to its rival, the Alltel Corporation, for $1.65 billion. The sale lets CenturyTel focus on selling local and Internet services, the company said in a statement. Alltel will bill customers under the CenturyTel name until it completes a billing system conversion later this year. CenturyTel agreed in March to sell the business to Alltel after spurning its $9.2 billion offer for all of CenturyTel. Alltel yesterday also completed the purchase of 600,000 local phone lines in Kentucky from Verizon Communications, the largest American local-phone company, for $1.9 billion. The acquisition increases the Alltel's local-phone lines to more than three million, the company said. Shares of CenturyTel fell 30 cents, to $26.30. They had fallen 19 percent this year. Alltel dropped 32 cents, to $40.20.

title: Struggling to End Africa's World War
description: The signing this week by the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda of a treaty to end the savage war that has devastated central Africa must be viewed with skepticism. The warring parties have already gone through several pacts and cease-fires, and this may prove to be just one more.

title: WILLIAMS SAYS IT HAS RAISED $3.4 BILLION
description: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it had raised $3.4 billion from asset sales and new loans to help stave off bankruptcy. The loans, provided in part by Lehman Brothers Holdings and Warren E. Buffett, will be backed by assets that include natural gas fields in Colorado and Wyoming. The money allowed Williams to meet $650 million in bond payments this week and will be enough for $1.2 billion of debts due through Dec. 31. Williams also cut dividends and sold some pipeline and refinery assets. More asset sales are likely, it said.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: FREEHOLD: DISABLED DEVICE LED TO ELEVATOR DEATHS A piece of tape over a safety mechanism allowed the elevator at a Colts Neck estate to ascend with its gate open on Wednesday, killing two little girls who were inside the car, the authorities said today. Their heads were caught between the car and the floor above. The mechanism was designed to prevent the elevator from moving without the gate being closed, the Monmouth County prosecutor, John Kaye, said. But for reasons he cannot explain, he said, it was taped over, closing a switch to signal that the gate was closed and allow the elevator to move. Nanci and Areli Franco, 6 and 7, were killed in the accident. The children were the daughters of the caretaker of the house and 10-acre estate. There is no evidence of criminal wrongdoing, the prosecutor said.

title: Finding Faith, or Something, in a Cornfield

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Reduces Forecast
description: National Semiconductor said yesterday that its first-quarter sales would rise less than forecast on reduced orders for chips used in personal computers and related peripherals. Shares fell in extended trading. Sales in the quarter ending Aug. 25 will be about the same as the fourth quarter's $419.5 million, the company said in a statement. The company said in June that first-quarter sales would increase from 6 percent to 8 percent from the previous quarter. In the first quarter a year ago, the company reported sales of $339.3 million. National Semiconductor's chips are used in a wide range of electronic devices, from PC's and cellphones to so-called Internet appliances that can use the Web. Consumers have cut purchases of such products on growing concern that the economy may not soon improve. ''With everything else we're seeing in technology, it doesn't shock me,'' said James McBride, a fund manager at Kornitzer Capital Management, which has $2.5 billion under management including 399,305 National Semiconductor shares. ''They were doing well and now'' the economy and declining corporate and consumer spending on computers have caught up with them, he said. Shares of the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell as low as $15.97 in after-hours trading. They dropped 98 cents, or 5.4 percent, to $17.13 during regular trading.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Harassment Suit Settled
description: A man who sued the city for what he considered harassment after he complained on television in 1997 about a traffic-ticket trap near the Bronx Zoo has settled the case for $290,000. The man, James E. Schillaci, was later arrested that year on a 13-year-old warrant for traffic violations. In his suit, Mr. Schillaci, now 55 and an unemployed limousine driver, contended that the arrest was city harassment and violated his civil rights. A federal judge has not yet filed the final dismissal order, said Michael L. Spiegel, Mr. Schillaci's lawyer. A city spokeswoman said the city admitted no wrongdoing but determined that settlement was in the city's best interest. Al Baker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Promising Bank Results

But the bank's net income fell 76 percent, to 204 million euros, or $200 million, as it struggled with a loss of investment banking fees and the bankruptcies some of its borrowers, including WorldCom. Deutsche Bank's new chief executive, Josef Ackermann, dismissed as ''absurd'' a potential criminal indictment against him for awarding lucrative severance deals to executives of Mannesmann while he was a member of its board.
