description: Steven Soderbergh's last three movies -- ''Erin Brockovich,'' ''Traffic'' and ''Ocean's 11'' -- each grossed more than $100 million. The first two earned him simultaneous Oscar nominations for best director and won a handful of awards in other categories. Admirers of Mr. Soderbergh's recent work who find themselves mystified by ''Full Frontal,'' his fractured, abstruse new movie, might recall that six years ago, before he became one of the most successful filmmakers in Hollywood, he made a fractured, abstruse picture called ''Schizopolis,'' a Godardian essay in displaced chronology, psychological irrealism and plain incomprehensibility.

title: Israeli Forces Enter Nablus in Reprisal Raid
description: NABLUS, West Bank, Aug. 2  Penning the old city of Nablus with scores of tanks, bulldozers and armored vehicles, Israel sent soldiers house to house today in pursuit of explosives laboratories and suspected extremists, acting against what it called a possible source of the bomb that killed seven people, including five Americans, at Hebrew University on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a New Jersey man who won a $165 million lottery jackpot misstated his surname in some copies. He is Sundel Judson, not Jackson.

title: Buy a Yacht, Without Going Overboard
description: THE ripples of the yacht's reflection gleam white in the water. Its silhouette is sleek and streamlined. Inside, the quarters are the size of a modest apartment, with three bedrooms, three bathrooms and accommodations for the captain. Amenities include flat-screen television sets and bone china. And it can be had for $186,500 upfront. Just not all the time.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Rejects Jenin Claims

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, DAVID
description: DANIELS-David. Of New York City, died July 30, 2002 at New York Cornell Presbyterian Hospital of complications from a long illness. Born April 10, 1927, St. Paul, MN. Son of Thomas L. and Frances H. Daniels. A graduate of Curtis Institute, Mr. Daniels was a baritone who performed opera and musical comedy throughout the United States and Europe. Highlights of a long career as a singer/actor were ''Plain and Fancy'' on Broadway, ''Boys in the Band'', off Broadway, and the national company of ''Call Me Madam'' with Elaine Stritch. He was a passionate collector of paintings, drawings and sculpture, and significant benefactor to the Minneapolis Institute of Art and an active member of the Drawing Society. He is survived by his brother John H. Daniels of Camden, S.C., and numerous nephews and nieces. A memorial service is planned for the Fall of this year.

title: Bush 'Furious' Over U.S. Toll In Hamas Blast
description: President Bush reacted with outrage today to the deaths of five Americans in a bombing in Jerusalem on Wednesday, telling reporters that he was ''furious'' as he met with King Abdullah of Jordan at the White House in an attempt to nudge the Middle East toward peace.

title: The Days of Terror in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBER, DR. LASZLO
description: TAUBER-Dr. Laszlo. The American Hungarian Foundation, its Board of Directors and Officers mourn the loss of a dear and esteemed friend, whose vision and counsel uplifted many. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the Tauber family. Dr. Zsolt Harsanyi, Chairman Prof. August J. Molnar, Pres.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: A Little Guy With Whiskers And His Feathery Lady Love

title: MBNA ACQUIRES CARD BUSINESS OF ALLIANCE & LEICESTER
description: The MBNA Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the credit card business of Alliance & Leicester, the British bank, for 225 million ($349 million). The deal will give MBNA, the second-largest credit-card issuer in the world, 1.3 million new customers.

title: Pataki Rival Files for Spot in Conservative Primary
description: B. Thomas Golisano, a billionaire making his third minor-party run for governor, filed petitions yesterday in his bid to enter the Conservative Party primary against Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Corporate executives who cheat investors, steal savings and squander pensions will meet the judgment they fear and the punishment they deserve.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ELLIOTT A.
description: COHEN-Elliott A. On July 31, at his home in Santa Barbara, CA. Beloved husband of Liane. Brother of Roslyn Hart Goldstein, Sidney Cohen and Janice Epstein. Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GESNER, CLARK
description: GESNER-Clark. We mourn the loss of our esteemed and cherished member. He brought wit, kindness and music to our clubhouse. He will be sorely missed. The Players

title: Hillary Clinton's 'Real World'
description: Campaign money is like quicksilver -- it will squirt through any opening you give it. No one knows that better than the troglodytes on the Federal Election Commission who would love to poke all sorts of crippling loopholes in the nation's brand new campaign finance law. Unfortunately, some of the Senate Democrats who supported reform are now wavering over whether to let the commission get away with this high-handed maneuver. Among the tremulous lawmakers is Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has not decided whether to join in overturning the commission's most recent regulations. Mrs. Clinton voted for the McCain-Feingold ''soft money'' ban and notes that she disavowed soft money in her Senate campaign in 2000. But her record will be seriously tarnished if she does not block the election commission's attempt to use the rule-making process to eviscerate the law.

title: Through the Eyes of a Child
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Heat Wave
description: As three surfer chicks up against the guys in "Blue Crush," Michelle Rodriguez, Kate Bosworth and Sanoe Lake are hoping to make a splash. (Their clothes already have.)

title: Beliefs; In this postmodern world, what religious thinkers may need is a scholarly new postcolonial posting.
description: Is it time for those who study religion and those who preach it to take advantage of an ordinary four-letter word with extraordinary impact? A word that declares something new by declaring something old? A word that conjures up groundbreaking developments in ideas and sensibilities?

title: Russia Says It May Reconsider Its Nuclear Plant Deal With Iran
description: Russia, under pressure from the Bush administration, indicated today for the first time that it was prepared to reconsider plans to continue building nuclear reactors in Iran that American officials fear could be used in a covert program to build nuclear weapons.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Protests And Fighting
description: Thousands of people in Khost, in the southeast, protested the new Afghan government for the fourth day. Khost is one of the nation's least secure areas, where the United States military continues operations to hunt Al Qaeda and Taliban members. The protesters are supporters of the powerful local warlord Bacha Khan Zadran, who is demanding that he be consulted on appointments of governors in the region. In the west, outside Herat, as many as 70 people were reported killed in fighting among ethnic Tajik and Pashtun soldiers. The Pashtuns appealed for help from the central government. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Moves to Strengthen His Grip on Military Intelligence
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is moving to strengthen his control over the military's intelligence apparatus, and his first step has been to propose a civilian post reporting directly to him to manage the vast and expensive operation.

title: North and South Korea Ease Into Discussions on Reconciliation
description: North Korea intensified its diplomatic offensive today, surprising the American command here with a request for the first meeting in 20 months between a North Korean and an American general, to talk about the skirmish in the Yellow Sea between North and South Korea on June 29.

title: Unthinkable in Baghdad
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Headscarves Banned From ID Photos
description: A court in Tatarstan turned down a lawsuit by three Muslim women seeking the right to wear headscarves in their photos for the internal passports that all Russian citizens are required to carry. The region is a historic center of Islam in Russia, where Muslim ethnic Tatars make up just over half the population and predominate in its government. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Drug Agency Is Studying Ear Implants' Links to Meningitis
description: The Food and Drug Administration is investigating what appears to be an increase in meningitis among deaf patients who have had tiny devices called cochlear implants surgically inserted deep inside their ears to help them hear.

title: Even a Billionaire Mayor Can't Buy a Cool Subway Ride
description: It is enough to make you think that fate has singled you out for suffering: walking from the unbearable heat of a summer subway platform into the truly unbearable heat of a subway car with no air-conditioning.

title: A Folk Festival's Idol Returns
description: To create the kind of music festival that would truly represent the folk world, I knew in 1962 that I needed someone who had the respect of traditional musicians as well as contemporary performers. In other words, I needed Pete Seeger. In the autumn of that year, my wife Joyce and I drove to the Seegers' home in Beacon, N.Y. There, we discussed the future of the Newport Folk Festival, and that was how the nonprofit, musician-run folk festival was conceived.

title: Most Bets Lie On a Decline In Fed Rates
description: With the economy looking less healthy than before, Wall Street is beginning to expect that the Federal Reserve Board will cut interest rates again within the next few months in an effort to stave off a double-dip recession.

title: DNA Evidence Ties 2 Brothers To Woman's Death in 1999
description: The Queens district attorney said yesterday that two brothers had been charged in connection with the disappearance and death of Haqiqi Samiya, a law student who vanished almost three years ago.

title: Smithsonian Is Planning 9/11 Exhibit
description: When two co-workers rescued Jerry Henson from under a pile of rubble at the Pentagon on Sept. 11, his khaki slacks were transformed into a piece of history.

title: No Headline
description: Msgr. James M. Ryan, a Roman Catholic missionary from Chicago who was one of the central figures of religious and civic life in the Amazon for more than half a century, died in Chicago on July 12. He was 89 and had lived in Santarm, Brazil, since 1943.

title: City Proposes a Land Swap To Control Trade Center Site
description: New York City officials have proposed a swap in which the city would take over the World Trade Center site in exchange for giving the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey the land beneath La Guardia and Kennedy Airports, an official involved in the rebuilding effort said yesterday.

title: Improving Testaverde Is to Play in Preseason Opener
description: Vinny Testaverde pulled his right hand from his pocket for a moment, and much of it was purple, a large black and blue mark spread from palm to fingers. Testaverde practiced today for the first time since he sprained his thumb on Tuesday, and Coach Herman Edwards said Testaverde would play in the Jets' preseason opener against Pittsburgh on Thursday.

title: Master Storyteller or Master Deceiver?
description: HE was a spellbinding storyteller, a figure of mesmerizing charm. The South African-born writer Sir Laurens van der Post, who died in 1996 at 90, sold millions of copies of his novels and nonfiction books, including ''The Lost World of the Kalahari,'' about the plight of the South African Bushmen, which became a popular BBC television series.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about options under discussion within the Bush administration for toppling President Saddam Hussein of Iraq misstated the year of a Korean War action, the amphibious landing at Inchon, that Pentagon officials are using as a model for surprise maneuvers. It took place in 1950, not 1951.

title: 7 Arrested in Chicago In Beating Death of 2
description: Seven people have been arrested in the fatal beating of two men who were dragged from their van on Tuesday after it crashed into a porch, injuring three women, the police said today.

title: 'Soft Star That Shines at Night'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Soft Star That Shines at Night'
description: To the Editor:

title: Arena League Player Finds Much to Be Happy About
description: For most of his arena football career, Otis Moore, a New Jersey Gladiators lineman, would be looking for work by this time of year.

title: Backing Bush All the Way, Up to but Not Into Iraq
description: A lifelong Republican, Tom Meaker worked on Barry Goldwater's presidential campaign in 1964, served as a Marine officer in Vietnam and now owns a small printing company. His vote helped George W. Bush carry Arizona in 2000.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition Delayed
description: E.ON's planned 10.7 billion euro ($10.5 billion) acquisition of Ruhrgas, Germany's largest natural-gas company, may face months of delay after a court upheld an injunction against the transaction. The higher regional court in Dsseldorf ordered that a full case be opened into the way E.ON, Germany's largest utility, received government approval to buy Ruhrgas, the country's dominant natural-gas company. The regional court froze the purchase on July 13 after Ampere and three other German energy companies lodged appeals, saying Germany's government made procedural errors during its final assessment of the transaction and that the European Commission and not Germany should have made the decision.

title: Kazmir Experiences a Taste of the Major Leagues
description: Early yesterday afternoon, when the senior members of his new organization were stretching before batting practice at Shea Stadium, Scott Kazmir was in the Mets' bullpen in right field. Between pops of the catcher's glove, Kazmir would turn to his left and stare at the No. 7 train.

title: National Briefing | Health And Science: Mother Earth's Midriff Bulge
description: Over the last four years Earth has been getting fatter around the middle, NASA researchers are reporting in the journal Science. Earth is wider around its Equator than a perfect sphere, but recently it has become even more oblate or pumpkinlike, researchers said. Before 1998, the researchers said, observations from space suggested that the reverse was occurring as Earth's mantle, which had bounced up after the end of the last Ice Age, sank back again. Now, though, the researchers say, a redistribution of water in the oceans is counteracting the gravitational effects of the rebound, leading to the bulge in Earth's midsection. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 25 about the expulsion of James A. Traficant Jr. from the House misstated a word in a comment from Representative Kenny Hulshof, Republican of Missouri, who reminded his colleagues that in recent years they had reprimanded the House speaker, Newt Gingrich, and had voted to impeach President Bill Clinton. He said, ''Here we are again tonight with the lens of history trained upon us'' -- not ''the winds of history.''

title: An Election Law That Bars Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: TRW TO SELL NOVASENSOR UNIT TO GENERAL ELECTRIC
description: The General Electric Company agreed to buy the NovaSensor unit of TRW to increase sales of sensors for the manufacturing, medical and automotive industries. Terms were not disclosed. NovaSensor, which is based in Fremont, Calif., will become part of the measurement and sensing business within the GE Industrial Systems unit. GE Industrial Systems, based in Plainville, Conn., provided about $4.4 billion of General Electric's $125.7 billion in sales last year. General Electric is based in Fairfield, Conn. TRW, based in Cleveland, agreed last month to be acquired by the Northrop Grumman Corporation, of Los Angeles, which has said it will sell or spin off some of TRW's businesses.

title: Former Justice Said to Have Deal On Bribery Plea and Jail Term
description: Victor I. Barron, the former Brooklyn Supreme Court justice who was charged with accepting a bribe in January, has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty and spend at least three years in prison, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Nevada ballot initiative to legalize marijuana omitted attribution for a comment on restrictions in the proposal, including prohibitions against advertising or selling marijuana in public places like schools and parks. It was Billy Rogers, campaign manager for the effort, who said: ''This allows law enforcement to go after people who truly act irresponsibly. People who smoke marijuana are otherwise law-abiding citizens who shouldn't be arrested. They are not endangering society.''

title: Boston's Cardinal Defends Abandoning Abuse Accord
description: After eight months of accusations that he mishandled cases of sexual abuse involving Roman Catholic priests, Boston's archbishop, Cardinal Bernard F. Law, found himself on the witness stand today.

title: Semiconductor Sales Point to Slow Recovery
description: Anemic growth figures from the semiconductor industry and a warning on earnings from National Semiconductor yesterday offered further proof that an economic recovery is not imminent.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CZECH REPUBLIC: POLICE FOIL EXPLOSIVES SALE The Czech police said they arrested five men in Prague who were trying to sell nearly 110 pounds of the plastic explosive Semtex, a notorious substance favored by guerrilla groups because it is reliable and hard to detect. Semtex is believed to have been used in the 1988 bombing of a PanAm jet over Lockerbie in Scotland that killed 270 people. An explosives expert said the amount seized was enough to bring down dozens of aircraft. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANKEL, SAMUEL
description: TANKEL-Samuel on August 2, at age 90. Loving husband and father and cherished grandfather. A strong memorable figure who we will miss dearly. Services Sunday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Shiva will be held Monday at the New York apartment.

title: 9/11 Trauma Referrals
description: To the Editor:

title: Expanded Trade Powers for Bush May Help Singapore
description: Few people have more reason to be pleased about President Bush winning expanded powers on trade than George Yeo, Singapore's minister of trade and industry.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Gunman Fit To Stand Trial
description: Maxime Brunerie, the French neo-Nazi who fired a shot at President Jacques Chirac on Bastille Day, was formally placed under investigation for attempted assassination after psychiatrists decided he was fit to stand trial. A lawyer for Mr. Brunerie, 25, said the man had recognized what he had done, but had insisted that ''he never acted for political reasons.'' If prosecutors pursue the case, the next stage will be Mr. Brunerie's formal indictment. Alan Riding (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Loans to Units of Enron Draw Regulators' Attention

title: HANOVER COMPRESSOR DISMISSES 2 EXECUTIVES
description: The Hanover Compressor Company, a pipeline equipment maker faced with a federal accounting inquiry and a falling stock price, ousted its chief executive, Michael J. McGhan, and chief operating officer, Charles D. Erwin, yesterday. The chairman, Victor E. Grijalva, was appointed interim chief executive and pledged in an interview to restore investor confidence. Hanover, based in Houston, restated 2000 and 2001 earnings in February, saying it had improperly accounted for revenue from a Nigerian natural-gas plant that was not operational and $12 million of gas pumps sold to a pipeline controlled by Enron. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the transactions.

title: A Mideast 'Parallel'?
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE ORDERS U.S. TO RELEASE NAMES OF 9/11 DETAINEES
description: A federal judge ruled today that the Bush administration had no right to conceal the identities of hundreds of people arrested after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, and she ordered that most of their names be released within 15 days.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits on Thursday about the xD-Picture Card, a removable memory device for digital cameras developed by Olympus and Fujifilm, misstated its thickness. It is about one-sixteenth of an inch, not two-thirds of an inch.

title: Stephen G. Cary Dies at 86; Long a Leading Quaker
description: Stephen G. Cary, who ran public-service work camps filled with fellow conscientious objectors during World War II and later became the leader of the American Friends Service Committee, the national Quaker humanitarian organization, died on Tuesday at his summer home in Chatham, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 86 and lived in Haverford, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: An illustrated timeline in The Arts on Wednesday, with an article about the evolution of the United Artists film studio, included one film erroneously among those made by United Artists. Although the Web site of United Artists and its parent, MGM, claims ''Silence of the Lambs'' (1991), that movie was made by Orion Pictures, now defunct; its film library was acquired by MGM.

title: Giants Show Depth at Receiver for a Change
description: Improving the wide receiving corps is an annual goal of Giants training camp, a summer rite since at least 1968, when the Giants last had a Pro Bowl wide receiver. They have drafted 39 wide receivers in those 34 years, including Tim Carter of Auburn and Daryl Jones of Miami last spring.

title: AOL Chief Faces Two Choices; Each Is Worse Than the Other
description: In the next few weeks, Richard D. Parsons faces his first pivotal test as chief executive of AOL Time Warner: coming up with as much as $9 billion, beginning with an initial downpayment of at least $1 billion in cash.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Falls
description: The French bank Socit Gnrale posted a 41 percent decline in second-quarter profit from a year earlier, falling short of analysts' predictions. Net income fell to 376 million euros ($370 million) from 641 million euros in 2001. The bank, which is based in Paris, booked charges of 265 million euros in the second quarter to cover losses on its industrial equity portfolio, including provisions totaling 33 million euros for Argentina, and 68 million euros for telecom investments. Like its rival, BNP Paribas, Socit Gnrale is a primary lender to Vivendi Universal, which may not be able to repay its increasing debt. Socit Gnrale's investment banking unit was surprisingly strong, posting a 14 percent increase. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPERT, A. ELLIOT
description: ALPERT-A. Elliot. My Sweet AEA-one year today. Forever a part of me. Love, AEA

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Betting Shops To Be Sold
description: Morgan Grenfell Private Equity said it had agreed to sell Coral Eurobet, Britain's third-largest chain of betting shops, to Charterhouse Development, a rival private equity firm, for 860 million ($1.34 billion). Coral Eurobet has a national network of 870 betting shops. The price was more than double the 390 million Morgan Grenfell paid to buy Coral from the Ladbroke Group in 1999. Morgan is a unit of Deutsche Bank. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Birdie Run Gives Irwin Sore Back and the Lead
description: They have their aches and pains; they take their aspirin; they stretch their 50-something muscles and joints -- and there are days they manage, as they did today, to destroy par on the Senior PGA Tour.

title: Torricelli Asks Constituents To Forgive His 'Mistakes'
description: In his first campaign appearance since being reprimanded by a Congressional committee for improperly accepting gifts from a donor, Senator Robert G. Torricelli today apologized to constituents for his actions, conceding that he had made ''mistakes.''

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PROFIT AT AIRLINE In a better-than-ex- pected recovery, British Airways said second-quarter net profit rose by almost 54 percent, to 40 million ($62 million), after costs were cut by 15 percent. But the airline warned that full-year sales would fall because of "considerable global and political uncertainty." The company's shares fell by as much as 7 percent. The chief executive, Rod Eddington, above, declined to say whether the airline expected a full-year profit. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 18 about Navy divers' preparations to salvage the revolving gun turret of the Monitor, the sunken Civil War ironclad, misstated the number of patents awarded in the construction of the ship. Historians say it had 250 patentable innovations, not 280 patents.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: A Predator Fish Spreads
description: Two fishermen said they each caught a snakehead fish in a lake off the Catawba River, the first time the voracious predator from China that can walk across land has been reported in the state. Officials in Maryland plan to poison a pond where snakeheads were found to keep them from disrupting the local ecosystem, but North Carolina officials said that was not an option. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Mexico Drops Planned Airport After Protests From Peasants
description: President Vicente Fox has canceled plans to build an airport on a sprawling stretch of communal farmland just outside the northeast edge of the capital, after violent protests by machete-wielding peasants who refused to cede it.

title: Frolicking in a Hydrant's Spray Is Fun, and Illegal
description: It is an archetypal summer-in-the-city tableau: children seeking relief from sun-baked streets in the cool spray of an illegally opened fire hydrant. It is also an archetypal summer headache for those who manage the city's water supply and fight fires, particularly this year, as the city struggles with its worst drought since 1989.

title: Sports of The Times; Clouds Gather Over Baseball's Pristine Scene
description: TWO major league superstars were sitting in the grass at Miller Park in Milwaukee watching the All-Star Game festivities last month and talking about everything they saw. There was baseball in front of them, the sun was shining, and laughter completed the picturesque scene. The only things missing were a picnic basket and a blanket.

title: Budget Office Error
description: To the Editor:

title: A Microcosm of Terror In a Torn Kurdish City
description: More than a decade after Saddam Hussein's warplanes dropped poison gas canisters here, killing perhaps 5,000 people in one of the worst such attacks since World War I, this city was still struggling to get back on its feet.

title: INSIDE
description: Proposal for Trade Center

title: 'Soft Star That Shines at Night'
description: To the Editor:

title: The City Life; The Laments of Commuting
description: It's hard to make commuters happy. So much is working against us. Virtually no subway platforms have air-conditioning. Express lines suddenly go local. And it's a long-distance hike through the underground pedestrian connection between the ACE and the NRQWS1237 trains.

title: Down One Wins the Board. Making a Slam Is Good Too.
description: The Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League traditionally ends with the Mixed Team Championship, a board-a-match event which attracts many of the world's best. The winners in Washington Sunday were Richard Schwartz, Margie Gwozdzinsky, Lisa Berkowitz, Debbie and Michael Rosenberg, all from the New York metropolitan area; and Larry Cohen, a former New Yorker now living in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Fire Dept. to Raise the Rates For Its Ambulance Services
description: New Yorkers, who already pay some of the highest prices in the nation for ambulance service, will soon be paying even more.

title: A Breezy Midsummer Night's Music
description: The New York Philharmonic played the second of its two programs this summer at the Great Lawn in Central Park on Thursday night. Some 85,000 listeners and picnickers turned up for the performance and the Grucci fireworks afterward on what turned out to be a comfortably breezy evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMBUSH, WILLIAM
description: WIMBUSH-William. On July 31, 2002. Beloved brother of John Wimbush. He leaves behind a host of nieces, nephews and friends. He served in the U.S. Army and was an active member of the Duplicate Bridge Club of Mt. Vernon, NY. He was a teacher in the New York City School system for 37 years until his retirement in 1987. Visitation Sunday 6-8 P.M. Services Monday, 10 A.M., at Nesbitt Funeral Home, 165 Madison Ave., Elizabeth, New Jersey.

title: With Huge Gift, the Whitney Is No Longer a Poor Cousin
description: In what is believed to be the largest donation of postwar American art to any museum, the trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art have joined forces to give it a trove of 86 paintings, sculptures and prints that experts value at $200 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Samsung Share Buyback
description: Samsung Electronics plans to buy back $850 million of its own shares to curb the downward slide of its share price on the Korea Stock Exchange. The company said the buyback would include 2.66 million ordinary and 400,000 preferred shares. Samsung's directors reached the decision after the price slipped to 319,500 won from a peak of 420,000 won on April 24. At the same time, the directors said the company, hard hit by the uncertainties of the American market for semiconductors and other electronic products, could not afford new or improved facilities beyond approximately $1.4 billion already committed for that purpose. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: War Resisters: 'We Won't Go' To 'We Won't Pay'
description: You could hardly find a more problematic time for pacifists who do not want their taxes spent on the military. But the recent wave of patriotic fervor has only reinvigorated the efforts of one tiny, determined group.

title: Congress's Mixed Handiwork
description: Americans who have grown accustomed to bad news may be surprised to find that Congress, now off for summer vacation, actually racked up some real accomplishments this year. On Thursday, for instance, the Senate gave final passage to a bill authorizing President Bush to engage in new global trade talks. No president has had such authority since it expired in 1994. A sweeping corporate responsibility law has also been enacted. The list of unfinished business is long, but voter impatience could force more action in the fall.

title: Judge Rules Capitol Gunman Can Be Forced to Take Medicine
description: The government can force Russell E. Weston Jr., who is accused of killing two Capitol Police officers in 1998, to continue taking antipsychotic medication while officials monitor his condition, a federal judge said today.

title: Israelis Clamp Down on Nablus, Hunting Suspects
description: Penning the old city of Nablus with scores of tanks, bulldozers and armored vehicles, Israel sent soldiers house to house today in pursuit of explosives laboratories and suspected militants, acting against what it called a possible source of the bomb that killed seven people, including five Americans, at Hebrew University on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUPAK, LEO
description: SCHUPAK - Leo. Beloved father of Leslie and Robert, grandfather to Adam, Jonathan and Jarrett. Father-inlaw of Dianne and Michelle, & husband to the late Thelma and to Henrietta. Services will be held Sunday, August 4 at 9AM at Weinstein-Flynn, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Leo's memory to the MGA Foundation, 49 Knollwood Road, Elmsford, New York 10523, or to a local chapter of the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Op-Art
World Briefing | Americas: 4 Nations In Education Pact
description: In a step toward a common educational system, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, the founding members of Mercosur, the South American common market, have agreed to recognize each other's university degrees in medicine, agronomy and engineering. The objective is to have universities adhere to common standards so professionals from one country can work in the others. Chile and Bolivia, associate members of Mercosur, have agreed to take part in the experiment. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Haitians Are Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about a Senate vote against coverage of prescription drugs for some Medicare patients misstated the 10-year cost of the Senate Democrats' initial plan to cover all 40 million of them. The amount was $594 billion, not million.

title: Judge's Finding Is Music To Mister Softee's Ears
description: City lawyers have found themselves on the losing end of a legal battle with an ice cream truck.

title: Diplomats' Cars Will Be Towed If Illegally Parked, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned diplomats yesterday that starting next Friday, the city would tow their illegally parked cars and require them to pay any outstanding fines to get them back.

title: Andover Hall the Favorite For the 77th Hambletonian
description: The ineligibility of Kadabra has opened the gate for several challengers in Saturday's $1 million Hambletonian at the Meadowlands.

title: KERR-MCGEE RESTATES EARNINGS TO REFLECT CLEANUP
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation restated its second-quarter earnings, showing a wider loss after including costs to clean up former oil, gas and chemical sites. With the costs, Kerr-McGee had a net loss of $58 million, or 58 cents a share, rather than the net loss of $7.6 million, or 8 cents, reported July 24. The items came to light in an ''ongoing analysis'' of liabilities, a spokeswoman, Debbie Schramm, said. Kerr-McGee, based in Oklahoma City, incurred a noncash cost of $48.9 million in the quarter related to the remediation of former plant sites, it said. The company also will have $1.5 million in additional exploration expenses after drilling failed at two locations.

title: Prosecutor to Remain For 4th Louima Trial
description: Alan Vinegrad, the chief prosecutor in the federal case against Charles Schwarz, the former police officer charged with taking part in the assault of Abner Louima, said yesterday that he would lead the prosecution team in a retrial scheduled for September.

title: Washington Talk; Merry Month of Going Fishing and Looking Busy
description: This was getaway day, when the Senate and the president left town, following the House and the vice president who beat them to it.

title: Strong Outing By Pettitte Gives Yanks A Needed Lift
description: The Yankees like to say that all six of their starting pitchers are aces, and to some extent, they are right. At one point in their careers, every member of the rotation could have been considered a No. 1 starter.

title: City and Federal Agency in Dispute Over Security Downtown
description: An attempt to improve security at federal buildings in Lower Manhattan has turned into a dispute that has the federal government threatening to condemn blocks of city streets around 26 Federal Plaza and 290 Broadway.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EPIQ SYSTEMS INC., Kansas City, Kan., a maker of software used by bankruptcy trustees, said it would buy Trumbull Bankruptcy Services, a provider of case management software to companies in Chapter 11, from Hartford Financial Services Group, Hartford, for $31 million.

title: Stranded on the Cape
description: The sight of 55 pilot whales stranded on a Cape Cod beach this week was both sad and frustrating. Although 46 of the whales were successfully pushed back to sea, the next day they came ashore some 25 miles north of where they had originally landed. Despite repeated attempts to return the whales to sea, all eventually died. From a scientific perspective, this stranding wasn't entirely unexpected. For reasons we have yet to fully understand, more pilot whales strand on Cape Cod than anywhere else in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, DR. JEAN, JACQUES
description: SIMON - Dr. Jean - Jacques, died Friday, August 2, 2002. Devoted husband of Francine. Beloved father of Dr. Jean - Pascal, Anne - Valerie and Jean-Francois. Cherished grandfather of Michel. Services Tuesday, August 6, 11:30 AM at Cimetiere de Montparnasse, Paris, France

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit At Airline
description: In a better-than-expected recovery, British Airways said second-quarter net profit rose by almost 54 percent, to 40 million ($62 million), after costs were cut by 15 percent. But the airline warned that full-year sales would fall because of ''considerable global and political uncertainty.'' The company's shares fell by as much as 7 percent. The chief executive, Rod Eddington, above, declined to say whether the airline expected a full-year profit. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Is Posting Statement Dates
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, trying to avoid confusion about the deadline for executive certifications of company financial statements, posted due dates for each company on its Web site today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Layoffs At Siemens
description: Siemens, Germany's biggest employer, plans to cut at least 5,000 more positions at its telecommunications businesses as a slump in demand deepens, said an IG Metall labor union representative, Wolfgang Mller. Siemens, whose 13 businesses also include power plants and light bulbs, may cut 4,000 jobs in the phone networks unit and 1,000 in mobile phones, Mr. Mller said. A Siemens spokeswoman, Sabine Metzner, said the company was exploring cuts. She gave no numbers. The latest eliminations would bring the total announced in the last two years to 42,000, or 9 percent of Siemens's work force. The chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said last month that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings would fall after orders declined.

title: Bottled Water Is Still Pure, But It's Not Simple Anymore
description: For water, pure is no longer enough. Now it has to be bulked up.

title: FIAT TO SELL ALUMINUM ENGINE PARTS UNIT TO BUYOUT GROUP
description: Fiat, Italy's biggest manufacturer, agreed to sell its aluminum engine parts business to a J. P. Morgan Chase & Company acquisition partnership and a United States buyout group for about 460 million euros ($454 million) to reduce debt. J. P. Morgan Partners, Questor Partners and Private Equity Partners will buy the Teksid Aluminum unit of Fiat. The sale will lower Fiat's net debt by 290 million euros, the company said. Fiat is selling 11 subsidiaries to cut the carmaker's debt to 3.6 billion euros, from 6.6 billion euros.

title: Four Are Killed in Big Outbreak Of West Nile Virus on Gulf Coast
description: Federal and state health officials said yesterday that 58 Louisianians had become ill from the West Nile virus in recent days and that four had died. The outbreak of the virus is the largest since it was first detected in the United States, in New York City in 1999.

title: Rogge Won't Rule Out Revising Skating Results
description: Dr. Jacques Rogge, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said yesterday that he would not rule out recalculating the results of the pairs skating and ice dancing competitions at the Salt Lake Winter Games if a federal investigation ultimately showed that the judging was tainted.

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: RADIOACTIVE SHIPMENTS BEGIN The federal government has begun shipping tons of weapons-grade plutonium to South Carolina from Colorado despite a lawsuit by opponents who fear that the fuel will be permanently stored in the state. Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina lost a federal court fight intended to block the shipments and was rebuked by a judge when he tried to ban shipments from the state after the ruling. He is waiting for a ruling on the issue by the United States Court of Appeal for the Fourth Circuit. (AP)

title: FIRE DEPT. LAPSES ON 9/11 ARE CITED
description: The Fire Department's response to the Sept. 11 attack at the World Trade Center, while brave and aggressive, was plagued by problems in radio communication, lapses in discipline and a lack of coordinated efforts with the Police Department, according to a draft report by an independent consultant.

title: In Cincinnati, Art Bows to the Privacy of Death
description: For Thomas Condon, a 30-year-old professional photographer, it all began one day two years ago when he walked into the coroner's office here to make a film of an autopsy to be used for training.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Monday about options under discussion within the Bush administration for toppling President Saddam Hussein of Iraq misstated the year of a Korean War action, the amphibious landing at Inchon, that Pentagon officials are using as a model for surprise maneuvers. It took place in 1950, not 1951.

title: Lightning Kills Man as Violent Storm Hits Region
description: A 25-year-old man was struck by lightning and killed last night when he went up to the roof of a building in Lower Manhattan to watch a spectacular thunderstorm that swept through the region, the authorities said.

title: Bush Will Travel to the 3 Sites To Commemorate Sept. 11
description: President Bush will travel to New York, Pennsylvania and the Pentagon on Sept. 11 to commemorate the anniversary of the terrorist attacks, the White House announced today.

title: MASSEY ENERGY ORDERED TO PAY $50 MILLION IN DAMAGES
description: The Massey Energy Company, a coal producer, was ordered by a West Virginia jury to pay $50 million in damages to the closely held Harman Mining Corporation. Harman's owner, Hugh Caperton, accused Massey of driving his company out of business by supplying coal to the Wellmore Coal Corporation, according to a Massey spokeswoman, Katharine Kenny. The impact of the jury verdict, handed down on Thursday, ''depends on our appeal,'' said Donald Blankenship, the chief executive of Massey, which is based in Richmond, Va. Robert Berthold Jr., a Harman lawyer, said, ''Massey kept us in protracted litigation for an extended period of time and we feel the jury entered a very fair and adequate award.''

title: Bausch Loses Bid To Lift Ban on Lens
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. failed in its bid to lift a court order so it could keep selling its PureVision line of contact lenses in the United States while it appeals a ruling that found the lenses infringed on a patent owned by a unit of Novartis.

title: 'Soft Star That Shines at Night'
description: To the Editor:

title: Shuttle Repairs Will Be Quick, NASA Says
description: The nation's space shuttle fleet, grounded since mid-June because of minuscule fuel-line cracks, should be flying again by the end of next month, NASA officials said today.

title: Mostly Mozart Settles, But Concerts Are Lost
description: A strike by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Lincoln Center ended yesterday when the two sides reached a tentative agreement on a new contract, but the ensemble's 20 canceled concerts would not be rescheduled, Lincoln Center officials said.

title: Official Sues Over Melee
description: After the brawl between Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis on the stage of the Hudson Theater in January, Jos Sulaimn, the president of the World Boxing Council, sat woozily backstage, recovering from having his head knocked on a table.

title: Schwarzenegger's Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: California Examines Ways to Manage Energy
description: Two years after electricity shortages sent prices soaring and blackouts rolling across the state, California, the standard-bearer for power deregulation gone wrong, is just beginning to figure out how its power market will operate beyond the next few months.

title: Cigna Profit Drops on Investment Losses
description: The Cigna Corporation, a leading health insurer, said today that its profit fell 15 percent in the second quarter as investment losses doubled.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Cuts Back
description: Gerling Reinsurance, the world's sixth-largest reinsurer, said it would stop writing new business in the United States. The company, owned by Rolf Gerling and Deutsche Bank, said that it wanted to concentrate on its European property and casualty business and on worldwide life reinsurance markets. Gerling decided to scale back the reinsurance business in the United States after it lost $575 million last year after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, analysts say. Its United States subsidiary, the Gerling Global Reinsurance Corporation of America, will continue the administration of existing policies, keeping about 100 of its 220 employees. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Meet the Flavors Of the Month; After Making Bachelors List, Brothers in Queens Get Calls
description: It's not easy being a bachelor in New York City. Sure, the urban singles scene might sound exciting to someone from Idaho, but it can be a dog-eat-dog world of broken hearts, melted dreams and blind dates from hell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARRON, EDWARD M.
description: McCARRON-Edward M. Of Cedarhurst, L.I. on August 1, 2002 at age 65. Professional architect. Beloved father of Colleen (James) Young of London, England and Owen (Sharla) McCarron, MD, of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Adored grandfather of six: Emily, Ryan and Kevin Young, and Sean, Kyle and Owen McCarron. Fond brother of John and Eugene McCarron. Will repose Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Meserole Funeral Home, 143 Lord Ave, Inwood Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 9:30 AM at St. Joachim R.C. Church, Cedarhurst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, HERBERT
description: GROSSMAN - Herbert. On August 2nd, 2002 at age 96. Loving brother of the late Flora Grossman. Beloved uncle & great uncle. Services Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Sunday 10 AM. Interment to follow Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In a very competitive business market, it's one way to try to make your product stand out from the others with very little cost involved and without having to prove that your product is any better than your competitors'.''

title: U.S. to Resume Aid to Train Indonesia's Military Forces
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell announced on Friday that the Bush administration would resume direct military training aid to Indonesia for the first time in a decade, in a move aimed at bolstering the efforts against terrorism in the world's most populous Muslim nation.

title: UAL SAYS IT RETAINED BANKRUPTCY LAWYERS
description: UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that it had retained bankruptcy lawyers after the Sept. 11 attacks and that it was still working with those lawyers. Its statements confirm a report on Business Week's Web site that said UAL had hired such lawyers. UAL lost more than $2.1 billion last year, an industry record, and reported a loss of $341 million in the second quarter, more than any carrier. It has applied for a federal loan guarantee of $1.8 billion on a $2 billion loan. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Baffert to Donate Half of Appearance Fee
description: War Emblem will run in the Haskell Invitational and Bob Baffert will accept a $50,000 appearance fee for signing autographs at Monmouth Park on Sunday. But after a brouhaha over the arrangement, Baffert announced today that $25,000 of the fee would be donated to the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation in memory of Prince Ahmed bin Salman, War Emblem's owner before his death July 22.

title: Los Angeles Radio's Noisy Newsmakers
description: When Gov. Gray Davis of California signed legislation regulating automotive greenhouse gas emissions, the phone lines in his office lit up and the press office shut down.

title: Musical Chairs On Tax Havens: Now It's Ireland
description: Efforts by American companies to save on taxes by reincorporating in Bermuda and other offshore tax havens are nearly dead. But United States corporations are still bristling at the way they are taxed, and another island, Ireland, may soon emerge as the next battleground.

title: Puerto Rico, Up to Date
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Want to Know the Unknowable on Iraq, and Time Is Running Out
description: When will Iraq have biological or nuclear weapons?

description: BASEBALL

title: Liberty Gets Some Revenge Against Road-Weary Team
description: In the Women's National Basketball Association, the schedule is sometimes the enemy.

title: The Best Medicine?
description: To the Editor:

title: Silverstein Properties Places Its Trade Center Losses at $8.2 Billion
description: Silverstein Properties, the real estate company that controls the lease on the World Trade Center site, said yesterday that its losses related to the Sept. 11 attack on the trade center totaled $8.2 billion.

title: Stock Gauges Fall 2% or More On Jobs Report
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday on reports that employers added few jobs in July and on weak outlooks from Disney and other companies. The three major market gauges were down 2 percent or more on the day and gave up all or most of their gains for the week.

title: Florida's Jim Crow Law
description: To the Editor:

title: The Immigrant Culture, Written in Harsh Light
description: NEIL BISSOONDATH dedicated his new novel, ''Doing the Heart Good,'' to his uncle and mentor, V. S. Naipaul, who wrote him a letter when he was a teenager advising him to migrate to Canada from their native Trinidad and to pursue his ambition of becoming a writer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCAULIFFE, VIRGINIA
description: McAULIFFE-Virginia. 78. On August 1, 2002 of complications from burn injuries. Artist, beloved wife, mother and grandmother. Memorial event to be announced.

title: A Time for Candor on Iraq
description: With all their talk about forcing a regime change in Iraq, President Bush and his aides are creating the 2002 equivalent of the 1939 ''phony war'' in Europe -- the period following the German invasion of Poland when everyone knew war was coming but the guns remained silent. The anticipation of war stirs uncertainty and puts people on edge, which is the way the country, already shaken by Sept. 11, is feeling these days. It is time for Mr. Bush to level with the nation about his intentions and to talk candidly about why he feels military action against Iraq may soon be necessary, and what the goals, costs and potential consequences of a war would be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGER, BEULAH
description: KLINGER-Beulah. Age 81, of Hollis Hills, Queens. Esteemed Music Teacher at the High School of Music and Art in New York City. Predeceased by her beloved husband Emanuel. Survived by her daughters Beth Agin, Arlene Romoff and Carole Rothman. Sister of Maureen Lerner & William Rabinowitz. Grandmother of six loving grandchildren. Services are Sunday, 11:30 AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: The Mysterious Meme, A Seductive Metaphor
description: Metaphors are dangerous things. They easily take on a life of their own, determining how we think, what questions we ask and what comparisons we make. Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? Sure, though as Shakespeare knew, that loving image shouldn't be pressed too intemperately.

title: 2 Candidates For Governor Need Listeners For a Debate
description: After a week of intense campaigning and long-distance sniping, the two Democratic candidates for governor of New York were ready to sit across from each other Monday and discuss their differences.

title: Jobless Data Exposes Cracks in Recovery
description: The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.9 percent in July, and the nation's employers -- determined to hold down costs in a weak economy -- reduced hours, cut overtime and limited hiring to a bare minimum. The latest data raised fresh questions about the faltering recovery, suggesting that growth will be modest at best.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, REV. EZRA
description: GOLDMAN-Rev. Ezra. Our temple family deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend. He served our temple as Ritual Director for more than 25 years. We were blessed to have him share with us his mastery of synagogue Nusach and rituals, gained from years of study in the Yeshivot of prewar Poland. We shall sorely miss his sense of humor, his store of anecdotes, his sweet disposition and gentle manner. We extend our deepest condolences to his son Lloyd and brother Manny. Funeral services will be held on Sunday morning August 4, at 10:15 A.M. at Temple Gates of Prayer, 3820 Parsons Blvd, Flushing. Temple Gates of Prayer Albert Thaler, Rabbi Susan E. Smith, President

title: Annan Weighs Reply to Iraq On Invitation To Inspectors
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan yesterday welcomed an offer by Iraq to begin talks in Baghdad on United Nations arms inspections, but indicated that President Saddam Hussein was still far from complying with Security Council requirements for lifting sanctions against Iraq.

title: MARKET UNCERTAINTY QUASHES AQUILA'S BID FOR COGENTRIX
description: The $415 million purchase of Cogentrix Energy Inc. by Aquila Inc. has been canceled because of uncertainty in the electric power market, the companies said. Aquila, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., and is one of the nation's largest utility company owners, agreed in April to buy Cogentrix for $415 million in cash and the assumption of $1.13 billion in debt. The transaction had been in jeopardy because of the risk that Dynegy Inc. might default on power purchases from Cogentrix, a closely held power-plant operator based in Charlotte, N.C., Aquila said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the effect of a management shake-up on the American divisions of the German media company Bertelsmann misstated the headquarters location of the Brown Printing Company. It is based in Waseca, Minn., not in Wisconsin.

title: Employment Data Raise Questions About Economic Recovery
description: Determined to hold down labor costs in a weak and uncertain economy, the nation's employers slashed hours in July, cut overtime and limited hiring to a bare minimum, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Tilling Community Gardens and Keeping Builders at Bay
description: Junior Sotero, who is battling cancer, has spent the summer in his hammock in the Volky Garden's casita on Hornaday Place in the Bronx.

title: L.I.R.R. Will Erect Fence Along Tracks Where a Boy Died
description: The Long Island Rail Road announced today that it would erect an eight-foot fence along a mile-long section of tracks where a 10-year-old boy died last month.

title: Park Is Set to Go After Dusting Himself Off
description: Steve Park was back in a fast yellow stock car today, turning laps at nearly 180 miles an hour. He was delighted to say that his courage was intact five days after an accident that frightened everyone -- except him, apparently.

title: Two Subsidiaries of Enron Face Scrutiny Over Loans
description: By taking out loans and transferring the money to Enron in an attempt to save the company from bankruptcy, two of Enron's most valuable subsidiaries may have run afoul of federal regulations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Gerhard Wessel, 88, German Espionage Chief
description: Gerhard Wessel, a spy for Nazi Germany who went on to head West Germany's espionage agency, died on July 28 at his home in Pullach, a suburb of Munich. He was 88.

title: Hawks Gain a Scorer In Trade for Robinson
description: Six weeks after guaranteeing fans that they will make the playoffs, the Atlanta Hawks took a major step in that direction yesterday, acquiring the All-Star small forward Glenn Robinson from the Milwaukee Bucks for Toni Kukoc, Leon Smith and a first-round draft pick in 2003.

title: Administration Approves Stiff Penalties for Diesel Engine Emissions, Angering Industry
description: Over the fierce objections of the long-haul trucking industry and Republican lawmakers, including Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, the Bush administration has approved hefty new penalties for the makers of diesel engines that do not reduce their emission pollutants by October.

title: Optimistic Owners Hope To Head Off Strike Date
description: Citing progress on various issues, including the critical issue of revenue sharing, the owners' chief labor lawyer yesterday continued to lobby against the need for the players union to set a strike date.

title: Notes From Washington; A Mayor Who's Good at Government but Not at Politics
description: In his 1998 campaign for mayor, Anthony A. Williams fought back a field of opponents who termed him a short-timer. Although admired as an effective manager -- before he was elected mayor, he was the city's chief financial officer -- the aspiring mayor had voted in only one Washington election since moving to the city almost a decade ago. Everywhere Mr. Williams went, he was challenged on topics of local authenticity; at one point, he was even quizzed on the location of a few of the city's 100-plus neighborhoods.

title: Louis Owens, 54, American Indian Novelist and Literary Critic
description: Louis Owens, a prizewinning American Indian novelist and scholar, died on July 26 at the University of New Mexico Hospital in Albuquerque. He was 54.

title: Hirschfeld Suspected of Ordering Deaths of 7 More, the Police Say
description: Abraham Hirschfeld, the real estate developer who was released from prison last week after serving time for trying to have a business associate killed, is suspected of ordering the deaths of seven more people, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly confirmed yesterday.

title: 'Soft Star That Shines at Night'
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Luxury Auto Planned
description: The German car manufacturer DaimlerChrysler expects to sell 150 limousines from its new luxury make Maybach in 2002, the company said. The Maybach will be built in Sindelfingen, where the company makes the Mercedes-Benz S-Class. Sales are planned to start in October 2002 in Germany and at the beginning of 2003 in the United States. The price for the Maybach 57 is $303,000, and the Maybach 62 will cost $352,000. In 2003, DaimlerChrysler plans to sell 1,000 limousines, 40 percent of which are to be sold in the United States. The car will compete with Volkswagen's Bentley and BMW's Rolls-Royce, which will be introduced next year. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Kashmir Elections Set
description: Elections to the state assembly of Jammu and Kashmir, which is claimed by both India and Pakistan, will be held in four phases beginning Sept. 16, India's election commission said. The votes will be counted on Oct. 12. India reiterated its opposition to allowing international observers, which Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had said last weekend would help ensure free, fair elections in light of a history of rigged elections in the state. A Pakistan-based militant group, Jamiat-ul-Mujahedeen, warned that it would attack anyone participating in the elections. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Yanks Quickly Go From Homer to Heartbreak
description: Orlando Hernndez bounced up and down in the Yankees' dugout, nodding his head and smiling broadly. Bernie Williams had just done the unthinkable, crushing a three-run, game-tying homer off the Angels' indomitable closer, Troy Percival, in the eighth inning. Hernndez would not lose this game, and the Yankees seemed poised to win.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Secret Subway

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALAJIAN, BERGE
description: KALAJIAN-Berge. William Wordsworth wrote in his Lyrical Ballads: ''The Poet binds together by passion and knowledge the vast empire of human society!'' And so did Berge Kalajian, whose passing we mark today with a supreme sense of loss, capture the high ground of rediscovery for anguished parents of Daytop over these 40 years. He restored to the art of parenting its good name, providing the tools to heal and strengthen as Founder of the Daytop Family Association. May a loving God embrace him as he arrives on Heaven's shore. (Msgr). William B. O'Brien President, Daytop Village Inc

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, BEN
description: KAPLAN-Ben. On June 26, 2002, at the age of 88 after a long life of adventure and public service. A great athlete in his youth, superb golfer, he served in the US Army 1942-1945. Landed at Omaha Beach June 6, 1944, and survived the Battle of the Bulge. In postwar Europe he served with UNRRA, AJDC, and the US Displaced Persons Commission Dept. of State. Subsequently he joined the United Nations Congolese Mission and the World ORT in Mali. From 1968-1990, he was Director of Administration and Assistant Treasurer of the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged in New York. His wife Betty predeceased him. He is survived by his nieces Sharon Hutner Brown and Joan Hutner Marsteller, nephews Dennis and Robert Freeman, stepdaughter Margaret Fishman Erickson, stepson Robert Fishman, brother-in-law Mike Gladstone. He leaves a wide circle of friends and colleagues. Memorial service Sunday, August 11, 2:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLIN, ALFRED E.
description: ORLIN-Alfred E. On July 30, 2002. A valiant man who fought a myriad of illnesses. Beloved husband of the late Thelma. Devoted and special father of Linda.

title: Modified Track May Add Some Excitement to the Brickyard 400
description: The Indianapolis Motor Speedway may be a famous old racetrack, but it is also a flat old racetrack. Stock cars do not tend to go as fast on flat tracks, no matter how famous.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Death of Sweet Mister, by Daniel Woodrell. (Plume, $13.) Set deep in the harsh backcountry of the Ozarks, this violent, even pulpish, novel features an unattractive 13-year-old narrator named Shuggie, who can barely tamp down his incestuous jealousy of his mother and his fury at his father and at a courtly stranger who turns up to compete for her attention. The result is a ''stunningly accomplished'' tale that achieves ''near mastery of style: language, plot, characterization and theme mesh with a seamless power,'' Michael Anderson wrote here in 2001.

title: Blackboard: Q&A; For Every Child, Success in Learning
description: In recent years, researchers have used advances in understanding how the brain works as a catalyst for understanding how children learn or, sometimes, do not learn. In the current bestseller ''A Mind at a Time'' (Simon & Schuster), the author, Dr. Mel Levine, surmises that each child's brain is ''wired'' differently, with its own set of strengths and weaknesses in learning. A child with a flaw in her sequential ordering system, for example, may have trouble remembering the steps in a chemical reaction or the order of digits in a phone number. As a professor of pediatrics at the University of North Carolina, Dr. Levine works with children to help them learn to bypass those weaknesses. JULIE FLAHERTY

title: Rock Alternatives: A Music Scene Migrates to Brooklyn
description: It's not quite the end of the city's rock world as we know it, but Manhattan's downtown music scene is shrinking again, even as Brooklyn's expands.

title: Stacey Seslowe, Daniel Philips
description: Stacey Lyn Seslowe, a daughter of Marsha and Jerry Seslowe of Manhasset, N.Y., was married last evening to Daniel Evan Philips, the son of Ann Philips and Dr. Steven Philips of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated at the Plaza.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Container-Ship Hub Proposed for Site Near Turnpike
description: WHAT do you do with a 300-acre garbage dump along the Rahway River? Consider it a golden opportunity, say developers who are marketing a plan for a container-shipping warehouse and distribution center in Carteret off Exit 12 of the New Jersey Turnpike.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Hambletonian Is Surprise As Favorite Breaks Stride
description: The Hambletonian became more of a wide-open race just moments after it got under way this afternoon. Along with the absence of the ineligible Kadabra, considered the best three-year-old trotter, the favored Andover Hall went off stride around the first turn in the bright sunshine at the Meadowlands.

title: Holy Warrior
description: Q: In your new book, ''My Jihad,'' you describe your conversion to Islam and experiences as an American Muslim, who in 1993, at 19, began training with the mujahedeen in Afghanistan.

title: Security Agency, Yes, But Whose Version?
description: If all had gone according to plan, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman would have successfully shepherded the Homeland Security Department bill through the Senate before the recess this weekend and could then have enjoyed the glow of a solid accomplishment on the Sunday talk shows.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Sylvia Vinall, Brendan Walsh
description: Sylvia Ann Vinall, the daughter of Maria Vinall of Tempe, Ariz., and Dr. Sidney Vinall of Boulder, Colo., was married yesterday to Brendan Francis Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Walsh of Woodhaven, Queens. The Rev. Robert O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Manhattan.

title: INVESTING WITH -- David H. Ellison; FBR Small Cap Financial Fund
description: BANK stocks have been battered lately, but David H. Ellison, manager of the $450 million FBR Small Cap Financial fund, has managed to find some gold with his investments in small, regional savings institutions that make loans very carefully.

title: Youths Explore the Environment, and Change It
description: NEW HAVEN, July 31  For years, people from the Brookside public housing complex had trouble reaching the two schools and the small park just across Belden Brook. They could take footbridges over the brook itself, but to get there they had to cross a low-lying area that was often a foot-soaking mess.

title: In the Berkshires, Wharton's House Revisited
description: Seven interior designers are celebrating the centennial of The Mount, Edith Wharton's residence in the Berkshires, with interpretations of her distinctive neo-Classical style.

title: Stars & Stripes Narrowly Averts Disaster
description: When the America's Cup helmsman Ken Read heard what he called ''the big bang'' while steering the Cup challenger Stars & Stripes on a training sail off the coast of Southern California on July 23, he had his first inkling that it might not be a terrific day.

title: Keeping Home Safe and Sound
description: SOME people, when planning a vacation, focus so completely on getting away that they neglect to attend to the place they are leaving behind. But nothing will deflate holiday euphoria faster than a home that's been robbed or flooded in the owners' absence.

title: Jennifer Gosselin, Reed Maltzman
description: Jennifer Nelson Gosselin, a daughter of Elizabeth and John N. Gosselin of Greens Farms, Conn., was married yesterday to Reed Evan Maltzman, a son of Charlene and Richard D. Maltzman of San Francisco. Rabbi Stephen S. Pearce officiated at the California Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco. The Rev. He got a B.A. at Cornell University in 1948 and spent his lifelong career with Johns Manville Co. in marketing positions. In his later years, he courageously struggled with post polio syndrome, for which there is unfortunately no medical research.

She is a former tour manager for the band Third Eye Blind and now owns Dernier Cri, a clothing boutique in Manhattan's meatpacking district. Ms. Valle's shop mixes vintage Rolling Stone magazines with off-the-beaten-track clothing, an inventory that mirrors the contents of her closet. ''My style is erratic,'' she said. title: July 28 - Aug. 3
description: ADEADLY WEEK The violence of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict continues unabated. Last Sunday Jewish settlers at the funeral of one of four Israelis killed at a roadside ambush went on a rampage in Hebron, shooting a 14-year-old Palestinian girl dead. Tuesday a teenager blew himself up at a falafel stand, injuring five, and a backpack exploded in a Hebrew University cafeteria Wednesday, killing seven, five of them Americans. President Bush told reporters he was furious over the killings, which the militant Muslim group Hamas said was retaliation for the killing of its military leader, Salah Shehada, in Gaza last week by a bomb that left 14 others dead, including 9 children.

title: Bake at 95 Degrees. Then Buy an Air-Conditioner.
description: Sales of air-conditioners are heating up around the country this year, thanks in part to above-normal temperatures this summer and strong demand for new housing in some regions. Through the end of June, manufacturers shipped 3.9 million central air-conditioning units, a 5 percent increase from the same period in 2001, according to the Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute. In June alone, shipments rose 11 percent from last year, the trade group said. Sales of smaller room-sized units are also picking up, a sign that some people were surprised by the hot weather. In June, those sales were $208 million, up from $156 million the year before. MACAULAY CAMPBELL

description: Federal judges have ruled both for and against the Bush Aministration's war on terrorism. On Friday, Judge Gladys Kessler ruled that the administration could not conceal the identities of hundreds of people arrested after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. She ordered that their names be released within 15 days. Earlier in the week, Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly ruled that the administration may use the naval base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to hold most enemy fighters captured in Afghanistan. Because the base is controlled by the U.S. military under a lease agreement with Cuba, the judge said, it is not really part of the United States. As a result, the more than 560 detainees there had none of the constitutional rights that even foreigners have once they enter the country. Neil A. Lewis

For this sanguinary tale of pride and obsession, Vine insinuates herself into the orderly (and narrow) mind of Martin Nanther, a hereditary peer deep in research for a biography of his great-grandfather Henry Nanther, a physician to Queen Victoria, an expert on hemophilia and a man bewitched by the medical and metaphysical properties of blood. ''Red is my favorite color. . . . To me a splash of blood is beautiful,'' Henry wrote, in one of the 52 leatherbound diaries that hold everything but the guilty secret Martin is determined to uncover. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Mountain Man With Camera
description: Anne Hammond, a former co-editor of the journal History of Photography, argues in ANSEL ADAMS: Divine Performance (Yale University, $46) that Adams's aesthetic relationship with the high Sierras developed nothing less than ''a new consciousness.'' As Hammond explores the relationship of American mountain worship to American transcendentalism and American pragmatism, she discusses Adams and absolutism, Adams and vitalism, Adams and primitivism, monism, pantheism, Zen Buddhism, post-Cubist abstraction and psychoanalysis. Only in this country does wilderness so stubbornly refuse to remain wilderness; it must be allegory or epic, microcosm and macrocosm all at the same time. And it's hard to stay on the level of ''the organic interconnectedness of all things'' for more than a paragraph, much less for an entire book. Hammond's scholarship does present at least one sublime truth: great pretension can make for great art. The fact that Alfred Stieglitz, Edward Weston, Minor White and Ansel Adams were in all seriousness vying for visionary status may now seem quaint, but their utter lack of irony about their work has made it endure. At her best, Hammond anchors Adams in the historically ambivalent contexts of American cultural radicalism. Frederick Kaufman
