Solomon and Jerome S. Solomon of Ridgewood, N.J. Rabbi Howard Hoffman is to officiate at Elk Mountain Lodge in Aspen, Colo.

title: Man's Best Friend
description: We are not sports fanatics because women won't go out with us, despite your caricature of a goggle-eyed loser watching sports by himself. We're sports fanatics because it's the only way to get a break from women. Most of us have wives or girlfriends. When they moved into our apartments, they made us take down our Springsteen posters and beer signs; they dragged us to French films and macrobiotic restaurants.

title: Word for Word/Biting Words; In Slaying Terrorism, It's Good to Be Better Than Buffy
description: IT has been foretold that into each generation a Slayer is born, and since 1997, that Slayer has been Buffy. What she slays are vampires -- usually on Tuesday evenings as part of U.P.N.'s primetime lineup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINFRANK, AARON R.
description: EINFRANK-Aaron R., 69. Died in Rosenheim, Germany on July 11, 2002 of complications due to a fall. An award winning journalist Aaron Robert Einfrank began his career at the New York Herald Tribune while still in college. After graduating from Washington Square College, New York University in 1955, he served in the U.S. Army as a linguist and staff writer for Stars and Stripes. In 1957 he returned to the Tribune as Wire Editor for its news service. In 1960, he was named United Nations Bureau Chief by the Toronto Telegram. His work earned him a Sigma Delta Chi award for distinguished UN reporting. In 1963 he took a sabbatical to become a Ford Fellow at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. In 1967 he became the Telegram's Moscow Bureau Chief. His hard-hitting, no holds barred reporting on the Soviet system led to his expulsion in 1969. After Moscow, he became the paper's Washington, D.C. Bureau Chief, where he remained until the Telegram ceased publication in 1971. He was later employed by Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty as a foreign affairs editor based in Munich, Germany. He held a variety of positions including Islamabad Bureau Chief. From Pakistan, he reported on the 1979 War in Afghanistan. He retired from the Corporation in 1991. Before his illness, he was planning a book on radical Islam. His professional affiliations included the National Press Club, The Overseas Press Club, the Columbia and Williams Clubs of New York. He is survived by his sister, Eileen Einfrank of Manhattan. On Monday, September 30 at 5:10PM a Memorial Mass will be said at the Church of Our Saviour, 38th Street and Park Avenue.

title: The Super Bowl
description: Imagine a job that requires an Army officer's leadership skills, a C.E.O.'s management expertise, a lawyer's negotiating talents and an educator's understanding of how to teach children. That's what it takes to be a school superintendent in the 21st century.

title: Petersburg on the Hudson
description: Stravinsky and Balanchine

title: July 28-Aug. 3: NATIONAL; FRAUD FIGHT
description: President Bush signed a major corporate fraud bill on Tuesday, just three weeks after the White House had opposed central provisions of the legislation. But the business scandals have shaken the administration, and the president has recently cast himself as the protector of the worker and small investor. Elisabeth Bumiller

title: Defying China, Taiwan Leader Backs a Vote On Sovereignty
description: President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan said today that separate countries now exist on either side of the Taiwan Strait and voiced support for legislation authorizing a referendum to declare Taiwan independent of China, positions that are certain to anger Beijing.

title: The Nation: Surveillance 101; Privacy vs. Security on Campus
description: WHEN the news broke a week ago that a Princeton admissions officer had used the Social Security numbers of applicants to his school to view Yale University's Web site for admissions, privacy advocates were aghast not only at his act, but also at the Yale site's lack of security.

title: Into the Woods
description: July 27: The guests at the annual benefit for the Watermill Center on its grounds in the Hamptons village of Water Mill, N.Y., were asked to dress in red for their walk entering the grounds through the surrounding woods, which are dotted with large stones. The stones, slip-covered in white paper for the party and painted with scarlet faces, looked otherworldly. So did wandering performers dressed like the stones. The woods were filled with the haunting Persian songs of Sussan Deyhim. Andrey Bartenev, the Russian artist, created this magical installation. He also conceived a performance, which took place on a lacquered red stage in a clearing between the center's buildings. There were 34 performers wearing costumes that recalled Russian Constructivism. They were made of white cardboard and paper painted with red patterns. At one point, three performers painted themselves red with crimson paint jetting from under their wide collars. Afterward, there was dinner and dancing under a huge tent. The evening, which included an auction of donated artworks, was attended by 550 and raised $600,000. The event was underwritten by Louis Vuitton. The center, founded by Robert Wilson and the Byrd Hoffman Water Mill Foundation, is a summer art school. It has 108 students from 30 countries, including the United States, and they made the costumes and props.

title: At N.F.L. Training Camps, An Exercise in Caution
description: It is 7 p.m. and the day has still refused to cool. The heat and intense humidity combine to make it feel over 90 degrees, covering the Carolina Panthers players like a layer of wool as they lumber onto the practice field of Wofford College for their second session of the day. ''Somebody microwaved the world,'' fullback Brad Hoover jokes to his teammates. ''This is crazy.''

title: Nicole Kamine, Eric Wilhelm
description: Nicole Clare Kamine, the daughter of Grace and Arthur Kamine of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric Gregory Wilhelm, a son of Susan Gregory Carr and John Lenhart Wilhelm, both of Washington. The Rev. Jude Murphy performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Pompton Lakes, N.J.

title: Believe It or Not, 2 1/2 Years Is Not the Long Term
description: BUY-AND-HOLD investing does not deserve to be any less popular today than it was several years ago. In fact, recent criticism of the strategy can be traced to a basic misunderstanding of the concept.

title: GOVERNOR'S HELICOPTER USE
description: Governor McGreevey came under criticism last week for using State Police helicopters in 45 trips during the first seven months of his term, costing taxpayers more than $13,850 in fuel alone. The governor's office said that it was important for the governor to visit as many parts of the state as possible and that the helicopters were only used for state business. Jo Piazza

description: MARGE AND TONY GARGIULE were headed for their summer house in Sea Isle City on the old Lincoln Highway when they saw a statue in a field just before Central Avenue in this Atlantic County farm town.

title: Suzuki Beefs Up Its Car Warranties
description: THE automakers' warranty wars escalated last week, with Suzuki firing the latest volley. Saying it now offers ''America's best warranty'' -- a claim that other automakers dispute -- Suzuki said its 2002 and 2003 vehicles would be covered, as of Thursday, by a powertrain warranty of seven years or 100,000 miles, whichever comes first.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: NICK BROOMFIELD ran into trouble when he tried to screen his documentary KURT AND COURTNEY (1998) at the Sundance Film Festival. Courtney Love's lawyers wanted the film suppressed, possibly because it seems to suggest that she had something to do with the death of her husband, Kurt Cobain, the young king of grunge rock. Cobain died in 1994, apparently from a self-inflicted shotgun wound, but this film finds several people (including Ms. Love's father) who aren't convinced it was suicide. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin called the film ''a memorable group portrait.'' Needless to say, Ms. Love did not cooperate with the filmmakers, but Mr. Broomfield does finally track her down, confront-ing her as she's receiving an award from the American Civil Liberties Union - Monday at 12:55 and 10:25 p.m. on Sundance.

title: The Soprano of 'The Sopranos'
description: WHEN Jamie-Lynn Sigler was 16 and heard there was a role for someone her age in a new television show called ''The Sopranos,'' she figured she had a shot at it. After all, she said recently, ''I sing soprano.''

description: Despite the shaky economy, new restaurants continue to open around the city. Here are a few that have opened this year.

description: OVER his 25-year career, the director Hector Babenco has shown an affinity for film adaptations of prestigious but difficult books. His 1985 version of Manuel Puig's ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' won William Hurt an Academy Award for best actor, and he was also called upon to translate William Kennedy's ''Ironweed'' and Peter Matthiessen's ''At Play in the Fields of the Lord'' into film.

description: After all these years, after all those tens of thousands of putts, some of the best players on the Senior PGA Tour still cannot explain why some go in and some drive them nuts.

Shah of Great Neck. Pandit Krishna Pratap Dixit performed a Hindu ceremony at Leonard's of Great Neck, a caterer.

title: In a Finicky Age, He Just Sings
description: The Siberian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky gives new meaning to the term ''heavy breathing.'' No, not just because he has been one of the opera world's hottest pinups virtually since 1990, the start of his international career. The term also applies to his singing. Few singers have such great breath control. In practice, Mr. Hvorostovsky's involves a sometimes rough inhalation followed by a long arc of warm sound.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; After the Din of the Bronx, a Suburban World of Quiet
description: From his third-floor apartment in the Bronx, 10-year-old Davon Ashley says, he sees and hears people on the street at all hours. They hang out, drinking or listening to radios and watching the cars go by. Davon, who lives with his mother and four brothers and sisters, says the noise keeps him from sleeping well at night, so he watches TV, as he does throughout most of the day. During the summer, he says, there is not much to do in the housing projects.

description: Classical/Opera

Students are not widgets, the argument goes; the artistry of teaching cannot be summed up by a score. States mandate, teachers revolt. Eager competitors stand ready to prove they can do things better.

He operates CrosComm Inc. of White Plains, which does advertising and merchandising, as well as marketing; his title is president.

description: BUSY watching stock market bulls morph into bears, I almost overlooked the arrival of Cos Cob Grill in Cos Cob, which had done a morphing job of its own in emerging out of the short-lived Sevilla restaurant.

title: In the Twilight, Unaffected And Indirect
description: The key lines in ''Mount Washington,'' a song from Beth Orton's new album, ''Daybreaker,'' are: ''May there never be a time that I don't love you/ may there never be a time that you don't pull through.'' Pop singer-songwriters don't usually express themselves so indirectly, but one way or another Ms. Orton does again and again. She wishes for the best in relationships -- sometimes they don't even sound like her own, yet they're meant to be -- and hopes that providence will right things.

My brother and I loved to stand in the back of our house and watch steam engines transporting coal to a power station in the distance. We even had names for them. Years later, when the Thomas the Tank Engine toys came out, they really resonated with me.

And the account of Mary Jo Copeland's fight for her controversial orphanage drew mail calling her more a C.E.O. than a saint.

description: MY father likes the smell of mildew because it reminds him of camp. Mom still knows every word of her old color-war songs and will gladly sing them with gusto. So they never could fathom why their daughter was not a happy camper.

title: Mideast Terror Brought Home
description: Last Wednesday was a day of celebration for many in Gaza City. They handed out sweets and thousands danced in the streets. The cause: seven Jews, five of them American, had been massacred by a remote-control bomb at Jerusalem's Hebrew University. Soon, Israeli armored vehicles were tearing through the West Bank city of Nablus and Israeli troops were blowing up homes of refugee relatives of suicide bombers.

title: Turks May Face Long Road to the European Union
description: Even if Turkey truly resolves two deeply controversial issues abolishing the death penalty and expanding the civil rights of a restive Kurdish population -- it may be misleading to think that membership in the European Union is just around the corner.

title: July 28-Aug. 3: INTERNATIONAL; A DEADLY WEEK
description: The violence of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict continues unabated. Last Sunday Jewish settlers at the funeral of one of four Israelis killed at a roadside ambush went on a rampage in Hebron, shooting a 14-year-old Palestinian girl dead. Tuesday a teenager blew himself up at a falafel stand, injuring five, and a backpack exploded in a Hebrew University cafeteria Wednesday, killing seven, five of them Americans. President Bush told reporters he was furious over the killings, which the militant Muslim group Hamas said was retaliation for the killing of its military leader, Salah Shehada, in Gaza last week by a bomb that left 14 others dead, including 9 children.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Woodwinds and Wood Blocks

title: Taking a Seat Inside a Culture
description: THE instant our bus pulled out of the Istanbul station, a smiling attendant rose from his jump seat near the driver and walked down the aisle with a large squeeze bottle. Passengers cupped their hands to receive a spritz of lotion; following their lead, we rubbed the lemony cologne on our hands and faces, and ended with a refreshing sniff. Nestled in our roomy, plush seats, my husband and I exchanged a thumbs-up. A bus steward to tend our comfort? Our guidebooks had been right to call Turkey's bus system a marvel. Rental cars don't have stewards.

description: Kevin Clement, Rathel Gincig and Dan Gincig, Aurora, Colo., June 16, 2002

To them, and to her town, she is the Nut Lady, the quirky woman who has run a museum featuring nuts (jewelry made out of walnuts, paintings with a nut theme) in her home.

title: 'You Cannot Be Serious'
description: I HATE ALARM CLOCKS.  That incessant ticking drives me nuts. And so September 11, 2001, began like any other morning in the McEnroe household, with my seven A.M. call from 540-WAKE. I quickly hung up the phone, let my wife Patty sleep, and dragged myself out of bed to go rouse five of my six children—Ava, the baby of the family at two, was still too young to be part of this daily ritual.

title: Yellowing Journalism: A Search for Old Newspapers
description: In a basement office in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, a dark-haired librarian named Laura Zelasnic carefully measured the dimensions of a recent copy of Hati Progrs, the 60,000-circulation weekly that serves the city's Haitians and runs articles in English, French and Creole.

title: July 28-Aug. 3: INTERNATIONAL; PLUGGING THE SIEVE
description: The Bush administration has sprung a leak. In recent weeks, details about preliminary plans for invading Iraq from three directions, conflicts within the Pentagon over containment policies and a proposal to begin an assault on Iraq from Baghdad have seeped into the media. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has ordered an investigation, and the F.B.I. has begun interviewing members of Congress and their aides about the release of classified intelligence intercepts relating to the Sept. 11 attack. James Dao

description: To the Editor:

title: 'A Matter of Degrees'
description: Ninety-eight point six. It is extraordinary how alike we are; a thermometer under the tongue of an Inuit on an Arctic ice floe, a pygmy in the Ituri forest, or a stockbroker on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange gives the same reading. Yellow, black, brown, or white, tall or short, fat or thin, old or young, male or female, it's still 98.6. For a one-month-old baby, a twenty-year-old athlete, and a centenarian, body temperature is still the same. Muscles bulge or atrophy, teeth erupt or fall out, vision is acute or clouded by cataracts, heart rates double under stress, breathing fluctuates wildly, you shiver uncontrollably or sweat buckets, but temperature stays the same. And you feel sick if it varies by the merest 2 percent. If it rises or falls by much more than 5 percent, you should consider heading for the emergency room. The resemblance of one human to another in this respect is truly remarkable. Respiration, perspiration, excretion, and other bodily functions have huge swings, keyed to maintaining a constant body temperature.

title: Ever-Improving Jeter Eyes Gold Glove
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 3  Last week in Cleveland, Derek Jeter tapped a ground ball to shortstop. The Indians' Omar Vizquel took a couple of steps in, ready to gobble the ball and flip to first. But Vizquel booted it, and almost before Jeter crossed the base, the call went up in the press box: base hit.

description: The ballot blues just won't go away in Florida.

description: To the Editor:

description: At the ferry terminal in Weehawken one recent day, an elderly gentleman -- nattily dressed in a tropical tan suit and a necktie -- kept asking to sip the various coffees.

description: Sarah Courtney Gough, the daughter of Nancy and Peter J. Gough of London, was married yesterday to Timothy DeVries Schwarz, a son of Anita and John A. Schwarz III of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Mark J. Pruitt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. George's School in Newport, R.I., where the bride graduated.

description: A proposal that would give New York City and New York State control of the rebuilding process in Lower Manhattan deserves serious consideration, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

description: Dr. Herodotus Damianos's choice of Duck Walk as the name of his South Fork winery in 1994 suggested that pomposity could not attach to its wines. The winery's image of seriousness derives instead from the Normandy-style chateau architecture that houses it.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: HUCK FINN, CONTINENTAL STYLE -- Peter Deilmann Cruises is trimming up to $565 per person on European river-cruise fares this fall aboard 10 vessels, ranging in capacity from 58 to 204 passengers. Seven-night trips on the Po River on the Casanova start at $1,555 a person, based on double occupancy (a saving of $340 from high season), Oct. 19 through Nov. 9. The trip starts in Venice and visits Cremona, Bologna, Ferrara, Verona and Murano, among other places. On Oct. 13, 20 and 27, the Mozart departs Passau, Germany, to sail the Danube. Stops include Vienna, Bratislava and Budapest. Rates per person, double, are $1,745 and $2,445, a saving of up to $565 over summer rates. Prices include all meals and transfers from gateway cities. Alcoholic beverages, sightseeing and port charges are extra. Information: (800) 348-8287 or www.deilmann-cruises.com.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on July 7, about Corsica, misstated the period of the Corsican nationalist movement led by Pascal Paoli and mistranslated a phrase of graffiti. Paoli's nationalist efforts were in the mid-1700's, not the 1800's. In addition, the slogan ''Corte Nazione,'' which the author saw, means ''Nation of Corte'' (a town on the island), not ''Corsican Nation.''

title: Jennifer Landry, Khoa Le
description: Jennifer Bolten Landry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Kevin Landry of Lincoln, Mass., was married yesterday to Khoa Pham Dang Le, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Co K. Le of Lakeside, Calif. The Rev. Edwin L. Holt, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Palace Hotel in San Francisco.

description: IS it true that the New York Stock Exchange, which has been in the city since 1792, might be coming to Westchester? Before you go and bake a pie for the new neighbor, let's examine the whole situation.

title: July 28-Aug. 3: NATIONAL; SMALL COIN, BIG MONEY
description: The 1933 double eagle, the only $20 gold piece of its kind, was auctioned at Sotheby's for $7.59 million, nearly double the previous price for any coin sold at auction. The anonymous buyer of the coin, which was once stolen from the U.S. Mint, was believed to be a collector living in the U.S. Glenn Collins

title: Uganda's Terror Crackdown Multiplies the Suffering
description: This town in the remote reaches of northern Uganda has experienced many miseries over the years, from ethnic clashes to a deadly Ebola outbreak. Now fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States is bringing even more ill fortune.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: The majority of shareholders of the Garden City Company and a federal bankruptcy judge have approved a Manhattan real estate investor's bid to buy control of the company, one of Long Island's oldest and largest real estate concerns.

title: July 28-Aug. 3; COMING UP
description: President Bush will travel on Monday from his family home in Kennebunkport, Me., to Pittsburgh, Pa. to meet with coal miners and their families. On Tuesday, Mr. Bush will undergo his annual physical at the Bethesda Naval Hospital near Washington, before returning to his ranch in Crawford, Tex. Congress is on its summer recess until September.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about gifts given to the president and other members of the federal government by foreign dignitaries misspelled the name of a style of jacket given to President Bush by Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair. It was a Barbour Thornproof, Classic Beaufort, not Thomproof.

title: Hawaiian Dance Groups Welcome a New Island
description: Two dance companies will join in performing a new work, ''Hanau Ka Moku: An Island is Born,'' on Aug. 23 and 24 at the Maui Arts and Cultural Center. Halau O Kekuhi, led by the hula masters Pualani Kanakaole Kanahele and Nalani Kanakaole, and Peter Rockford Espiritu's Tau Dance Theater will depict the formation of Loihi, a new island below the surface of the ocean 15 miles from the Big Island of Hawaii.

title: Samantha Davidson, Jordan Green
description: Samantha Jane Davidson, a daughter of Judith Reeve Davidson-Baker of Hanover, N.H., and Richard Davidson of Hebron, Me., is to be married today to Jordan Casey Green, the son of Susan B. Green and Dr. Ronald L. Green of Norwich, Vt. Cantor Elliott Hurvitz is to officiate at Dexter's Inn in Sunapee, N.H.

title: Corrections

Ferries serving Hoboken number roughly 16 an hour at peak times, not 20 a day. The article also misspelled the name of one of the city's major employers. It is St. Mary Hospital, not St. Mary's.

description: ELVIS IN JERUSALEM

title: Showing Promise, Sehorn Pursues a Career in Television
description: The most recent scouting report on Jason Sehorn is that he's very quick. Makes adjustments on the fly; a great freelancer. Tends to rush a bit, but responds under pressure. Tremendous teammate. Much promise.

title: Co-op Board to Buyer: Information Please
description: ''IT is one of the most personally invasive experiences in most people's adult lives,'' said Douglas Wagner, president of Benjamin James Real Estate, a Manhattan brokerage firm, referring to the ''board package'' that prospective buyers submit when they want to buy an apartment in a co-op building.

title: Rolls-Royce of Garage Sales
description: The stylish Hamptons held their annual designer garage sale in Water Mill, N.Y., last weekend. Over 100 leading designers from Seventh Avenue and a few from Europe set up booths of donated wares on a broad meadow. The grounds also included a carnival for children and a circus-size tent for entertainment. Tickets went for $350 and $500. The event was attended by 2,000 and raised more than $1 million for ovarian cancer research. Donna Karan, left, is the guiding force behind it all, assisted by an army of fashion house volunteers. Above left, Kelly Klein tries on a dress over her own. After 4:30, many of the booths reduced their prices, some to $10, and the racks were stripped in minutes.

title: More Cruise Ships Are Calling in Alaska
description: CRUISE lines moved a record number of ships to Alaska for this summer season after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, anticipating less demand for Mediterranean itineraries. But local merchants in Alaska are wondering if the influx of passengers will translate into profits for them.

title: Choosing A Slow Pace In Japan
description: WE were a couple of hours outside of Tokyo when Mount Fuji appeared. The train trundled out of a tunnel, and there it was -- glowing pink and purple in the late-afternoon light, wearing a halo of mist. The vision was so gorgeous it distracted us, for a moment, from our boxed lunch.

title: How to Keep Mosquitoes From Biting
description: WITH West Nile virus having been detected in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and 30 other states and, as of last month, in all five boroughs of New York City, health officials are urging residents to ratchet up their precautions against mosquitoes.

title: Tall Ships Are Visiting Five West Coast Ports
description: A fleet of tall sailing ships will visit the West Coast this month and next, participating in festivals at five ports of call. The event, called the Tall Ships Challenge Race Series, brings together about 7 to 10 vessels for races from Seattle to San Francisco, and from San Francisco to Los Angeles.

title: American Airlines: No More Paper Tickets
description: As many airlines take steps to discourage the use of paper tickets, American Airlines has announced that it will soon stop issuing them altogether. By March 2003 the airline will issue only electronic tickets for domestic flights; international flights will have until December 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CHARLES E.
description: MURPHY-Charles E. Age 84 of Manchester Township, NJ, formerly of Forest Hills, NY, died Thursday, August 1, 2002. He was a partner at KornFerry International, New York City, NY, for twenty years before retiring in 1990 as Executive Search. He was a longtime member of the Civil War Round Table, New York City, and the Jersey Shore Civil War Round Table. He is survived by his devoted wife of 55 years, Ottlie J. Fredericks Murphy. Beloved father of Charles Eugene Murphy Jr. of Atlanta, GA, Frederick Tyrone Murphy of Hightstown, NJ, and Mary Margaret Hammid of Las Angeles, CA; three brothers, Terrence, Edward and Vincent; five grandchildren, Patrick, Christopher, Mary Margaret, Bendan and Evelyn. Visitation Wednesday, 11 AM, at DeGraff Lakehurst Funeral Home, 119 Union Ave, Lakehurst, NJ. Interment to follow at Brig. Gen. William C. Doyle Veterans Cemetery, Arneytown, NJ.

title: Exercising Their Cares Away
description: Obesity and couch-potatodom may be on the rise in this country, but so is health club attendance. Club members made it to their gyms an average of 93 days last year -- up 29 percent since 1987, and a record -- according to the Health Club Trend Report. The number of hard-core fitness buffs -- those who show up faithfully at least 100 days a year -- rose to a record 13.9 million, up 48 percent in the last five years alone. Perhaps they're trying to deal with life's many stresses, like corporate layoffs, falling stock prices and global unrest.

title: Calvert to Manage College Plan
description: The District of Columbia has selected the Calvert Group, which runs socially screened mutual funds, to manage its college saving plan, known as a 529 plan.

title: The Upper Crust of Crullers
description: Doughnut lovers cannot live on Krispy Kremes alone. So high-end restaurants around New York are offering homemade versions for those who crave the finer fried things in life. At Avenue on Columbus Avenue at 85th Street, the dessert menu includes a $6 homemade yeast doughnut, right, stuffed with strawberry jam and garnished with red currants. Fiamma Osteria, an Italian bote at 206 Spring Street in SoHo, serves crocchette (doughnut holes) along with blueberry compote, lemon curd and chocolate sauce ($9). Craft, at 43 East 19th Street, offers three kinds of doughnuts as well as doughnut holes: chocolate, cinnamon and brioche, all of which come with hot chocolate sauce on the side ($7). Glazed doughnuts served warm are the treat of choice at Tabla, 11 Madison Avenue, at 25th Street ($7). And Harrison in TriBeCa, 355 Greenwich Street, offers its signature beignets, chocolate-filled doughnut holes ($7) served with espresso sauce for extra dipping pleasure. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Outfitter to the Suspicious
description: ON the busy stretch of Huguenot Street here, the Chevrolet dealership and Pizza Hut mix easily with the New Roc City entertainment complex and a sprinkling of office buildings. It is the unlikely home for headquarters to one of the world's leading spy supply companies. CCS International, Ltd., the parent company of the Counter Spy Shops, has its showrooms, a factory, a training center and corporate offices there.

title: Dance Listings
description: BALLET TECH  Summer preview season. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Ave. at 19th St. (212-242-0800) Mon.-Sat., 8.

title: Hoang-Yen Haduong, Richard Tesler
description: Hoang-Yen T. Haduong, a daughter of Nhan T. Ha and Dr. Cu D. Ha of Morganville, N.J., was married last evening to Richard Jon Tesler, a son of Ellen and Marc S. Tesler of Ship Bottom, N.J. Rabbi Stewart Berman officiated at Pier 60 at Chelsea Piers in New York. A Vietnamese Buddhist ceremony was held earlier at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Business Is Better; the Bartender's Drinking
description: Some New York bar and restaurant owners say they knew the economic climate was getting dire when their waiters, waitresses and bartenders vanished during their off hours. For a time after Sept. 11, tips fell so sharply that employees could not afford to spend their time on the drinking side of the bar, where half their drinks were often free.

title: The Stripes and (Nearly) Nothing but the Stripes
description: THE surprising career of the French artist Daniel Buren springs from extraordinarily austere beginnings making broad, pale stripes akin to those found on restaurant marquees. Mr. Buren, who actually patented the exact width of the stripes (8.7 centimeters or 3.4251968503937 inches) admitted then (some 30 years ago) that they were devoid of any intrinsic merit as visual objects. They were presented in a variety of places, with or without permission, indoors and out (on billboards, on flags atop buildings, even in art galleries and museums, on walls, behind other paintings), their significance being then argued by him in the dreariest, most unreadable, authoritarian, indeed ''terrorist'' (in the French sense of ''intimidating'') and totalitarian commentary, by which Mr. Buren claimed sole control over the interpretation of his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILGRIM, JAMES F.
description: PILGRIM-James F. The Trustees and Staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with deep sadness the passing of our respected colleague, Jim Pilgrim. Over 17 years at the Museum, from 1971 to 1988-first in the Department of American Painting and Sculpture and afterward in various administrative capacities, culminating in that of deputy director for curatorial affairs-he demonstrated a long standing and steadfast commitment to the highest standards of professional excellence. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, our treasured colleague Katharine Baetjer, and to the entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENEFF, CARL
description: DENEFF-Carl. 92 died August 1, 2002. Retired physician and doctor on duty during the Japanese Attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. The bravery and strength in which you used to save your fellow americans is the model you used for the rest of your life. Loving husband to the late Gertrude. Beloved father to Marla, Lewis and Steven. Grandfather to Charles, Jack and Michael. Dedicated physician for over 50 years in Brooklyn, NY. Love by all who had the pleasure of knowing him. You will be greatly missed by your family.

title: SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION
description: Governor McGreevey announced last week the creation of a New Jersey Schools Corporation, intended to make it easier for school districts to apply for state aid for repair, renovations and construction. The Legislature allocated $8.6 billion in state and local funds almost two years ago to finance school construction as part of the Educational Facilities Construction and Financing Act. John Holl

title: Civil War Relics Draw Visitors, and Con Artists
description: One hundred and thirty-nine years after the climactic charge at the Battle of Gettysburg, Gen. George Pickett's Confederate cap rests here north of the Mason-Dixon line, a prime historic relic that has seen better but hardly richer days.

title: Teaching Children the Realities of Employment
description: THE letter that reached Collin James, the purchasing manager and mentor coordinator for the Wyandanch School District, was handwritten and sent by an 8-year-old student. The letter writer, whose name was James, thanked Mr. James for arranging for him to attend the Take Your Children to Work Day at the Adecco Corporation in Melville.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNEDDON, KRISTINE
description: SNEDDON - Kristine. Our heartfelt sympathy to David and family on the loss of his wife. Iris and Sally Goodgold

title: Lesley Bonney, James Fitzgerald IV
description: Lesley Suzanne Bonney, a daughter of Jean C. Bonney of Concord, Mass., and the late Russell N. Bonney Jr., was married yesterday to James J. Fitzgerald IV, a son of Judge and Mrs. Fitzgerald III of Philadelphia. Judge Marjorie O. Rendell of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, officiated at the Algonquin Club in Boston.

title: Correction
description: The Close Reader column on July 14, about the relation between daily life and intellectual life in Israel at present, referred erroneously to protests against the award of the Israel Prize to an Israeli Arab, Emile Habibi. The award, and the protests, occurred in 1992, not ''recently''; the Israel Prize is given for a life of achievement, not any particular accomplishment. The novel ''Arabesques'' was misattributed; it was written not by Habibi but by Anton Shammas, also an Israeli Arab, in Hebrew, not Arabic.

title: Once More With Feeling: Buy American. Please!
description: The math couldn't be simpler. If you pay Americans $10 an hour to make shirts, they'll end up more expensive than if you pay a fraction of that to overseas workers. Of course, you can try to skew the math by appealing to customers to ignore the price and "buy American," but most shoppers typically stop waving flags the moment they pull out their wallets.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Arrow Electronics Posts $6 Million Quarterly Loss

title: Left Bank Ties Record in Winning the Whitney
description: Angel Cordero Jr., the retired Hall of Fame jockey now hustling rides as an agent for John Velazquez, calls the skittish chestnut Lefty. The trainer Todd Pletcher thinks the horse that has been in his barn for three years is something of a goofball, but a lovable one.

title: Jets' Moss Exudes Health and Maturity
description: It was on a routine route, maybe a crossing pattern Santana Moss had run in the Miami heat a thousand times, that the breakthrough finally came. After a rookie season beset by injury, sprinkled with frustration and studded with the disappointment of friendships lost, Moss sprinted, planted and was gone. Same as it ever was.

title: Bringing Cartoon Shorts Back to the Head of the Bill
description: CARTOONS before the main attraction were once as much a part of movie-going as popcorn. But in today's multiplexes, time once devoted to the art of animation is now taken up with trailers, pitches for concession-stand snacks and even plugs for local merchants.

title: Surf's Up, Dude. Hang On to Your Couch.
description: POP culture in the United States often seems to vacillate between East and West Coast dominance. And right now, thanks in part to the popularity of sports like skateboarding and surfing, Southern California is back in the spotlight with a vengeance. On MTV, acts like Incubus and Sheryl Crow try to show off their surfing moves in videos. In theaters, the documentary ''Dogtown and Z-Boys,'' about Los Angeles surf and skateboard culture, just finished a well-reviewed run, only to be replaced by ''Blue Crush,'' a feature about women who surf that is said to be the biggest-budget surf movie in history. And ''Girl in the Curl,'' intended to appeal to teenyboppers, is in the works at Paramount. Meanwhile, the surf clothing industry continues to grow, taking in some $2.4 billion a year.

title: Rebecca Schaefer and Joshua Cypess
description: Rebecca Lynn Schaefer, a daughter of Dr. Roberta Rubel Schaefer and Dr. David L. Schaefer of Worcester, Mass., is to be married today to Joshua Neil Cypess, a son of Dr. Sandra Messinger Cypess and Dr. Raymond H. Cypess of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York.

title: Brut Taste, Bire Budget
description: Domaine Collin's nonvintage Blanquette de Limoux brut, a sparkling wine from southwestern France that resembles pricey Champagne, offers a boon to budget-minded hosts. It's as light as meringue, spare, dry and yeasty in flavor. The importer is Jeroboam, owned by Daniel Johnnes, Montrachet's wine director. Beekman, 500 Lexington Avenue (47th Street), Manhattan, asks $13. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: It's Never Too Late To Be a Virgin
description: WITH three months to go before her wedding, Nicole Ratliff, 24, is deep into her prenuptial regime. She exercises with a personal trainer so her arms will look buffed in a strapless gown. She works on her tan to get rid of the swimsuit lines across her shoulders. She exfoliates her face and guzzles 124 ounces of water daily to hydrate her skin. And since July 26, three months to the day before she will say, ''I do,'' she has been abstaining from sex with her live-in fianc, David Crawford, and plans to continue until after they are married.

title: July 28-Aug. 3: ECONOMY; PERP WALK
description: Another week, another corporate perp walk. Two former WorldCom executives were led by government agents to federal court in Manhattan, where they face charges related to that company's misstatement of billions in expenses.

title: In Capitol, Last Names Link Some Leaders and Lobbyists
description: With a pierced tongue, a goatee and previous employment as the owner of a record store and label called Seven Dead Arson, the young man is not a typical buttoned-down Washington lobbyist. But Joshua Hastert, 27, does have something increasingly common in lobbying circles -- family ties to a Congressional leader.

title: Amanda Claremon, Fritz Umbach
description: Amanda Judith Claremon and Dr. Gregory Holcomb Umbach were married last evening by Rabbi Charles J. Davidson at the Glenmere Mansion in Chester, N.Y.

title: U.S.-Mideast Connection: The News Becomes Less Foreign
description: Americans got a shocking reminder this week that their connection to the conflict here is not just strategic but personal, even intimate.

title: Bol Brings Message To American Youth
description: Chris Mullin and Allan Houston have had wonderful basketball experiences. Mullin can talk about playing on the ultimate Dream Team, running alongside Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and Michael Jordan to win Olympic gold in 1992. Houston, who has also won a gold medal, can speak about the thrill of hitting the game-winning, series-clinching shot against Miami during the Knicks' run to the 1999 N.B.A. finals, or even about what it is like to have a $100 million contract.

title: Catherine Olson, Scott Schirmeier
description: Catherine Kelly Olson, the daughter of Nora and Robert Olson of West Nyack, N.Y., was married last evening to Scott Alan Schirmeier, the son of Fredrica M. Sloan of Williamstown, Mass., and Peter T. Schirmeier of Westbrook, Conn. The Rev. James Covington, a Unitarian minister, officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSKY, DR. HOWARD F.
description: WATSKY-Dr. Howard F. ''Poppy'' of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Lawrence, LI on July 24, 2002. Beloved husband of Rhoda and now joins the late Francine to whom he was married 50 years; Loving father of Dr. Steven (Sharon) and Claude Watsky; Cherished grandfather of six and great-grandfather of one; Dear brother-in-law of Muriel and Max Switkes. Services private. Information ''Gutterman's'' 800-992-9262.

title: Traveling Diplomat of the Parlor Set
description: IN the nearly three decades that Peggy Elliott has worked as a hairdresser she has picked up a blow-dryer roughly as often as Hugh Heffner sets and clears a dinner table. It is not that Ms. Elliott, 60, considers blow-drying beneath her. ''I really wasn't trained in blow-drying,'' she explained one afternoon recently. ''I find it so boring standing there for a half-hour without being able to talk.''

title: BackTalk; Some Woods Supporters Are Aware Of His Flaws
description: Golf pros are the corporate world's geishas. They are sweet-talking stroker-jokers. They ease the lives of stock rockers who need to network outdoors where it's hard to wiretap their insider-trade conversations. Teaching pros hustle the hustlers (''Just a few hundred more lessons, C.E.O. Billy, and you'll be ready for the Sing Sing Open, heh-heh.''), make them feel manly and give them socially acceptable reasons to be out of the office and away from their families on those lush lawns where you can mix with your own kind.

title: Malia Simonds, Elliot Kirschner
description: Malia Gates Simonds, the daughter of Kitty and John Simonds of Honolulu, is to be married today to Elliot Charles Kirschner, a son of Dr. Phyllis Kirschner and Dr. Marc Kirschner of Newton, Mass. Boyd P. Mossman, a retired judge of the Second Circuit Court of Hawaii, is to officiate on Makena Beach, in Maui.

title: The Art of Weaving The Imagination, Too
description: DO not come expecting to see conventional baskets. In the exhibition ''Other Materials Other Forms: Exploring Contemporary Basketry,'' at the Brookfield Craft Center, artists take the basket form and adapt it to glass, ceramic, leather, paper and wire.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LETTERS TO A YOUNG NOVELIST

title: To the Point
description: 'Montauk Point!'' Walt Whitman exclaimed in an 1861 article in The Brooklyn Standard. ''How few Americans there are who have not heard of thee -- although there are equally few who have seen thee with their bodily eyes.'' Stuck on Main Street in August in a traffic jam, witnessing crowds of people spilling out of Mr. John's Pancake House, anyone can see that things have changed a lot in the 141 years since Whitman wrote his love letter to the place, but other things, like the topography, have not. ''To a mineralogist,'' Whitman wrote, ''I fancy Montauk Point must be a perpetual feast . . . earths of all colors, and stones of every conceivable shape, hue, and destiny.'' It is these rocks and reefs that have helped make Montauk such a mecca for surfers on the East Coast.

title: A Hotel Helps Ease Racial Tensions
description: In slick travel magazine ads, big-budget movies and hip-hop videos, this sun-drenched city is billed as an oceanfront oasis with an international flavor that offers something for everyone. To some, though, Miami Beach has never fully lived up to its reputation.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ANSEL ADAMS

title: Hudson a Source Of Pleasure for Years
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH SENTENCE REPRIEVE
description: Leslie Ann Nelson, the only woman on death row in the state, won a second reprieve last week when the State Supreme Court overturned her sentence. Ms. Nelson killed a police officer and an investigator from the Camden County prosecutor's office during a standoff at her house in 1995. The Supreme Court's 5-to-0 decision said the jury might have been confused by instructions on its verdict sheet, but two of the five justices wrote that they would also find Ms. Nelson's execution unconstitutional because of her history of severe emotional problems. Ms. Nelson, now 44, underwent sex-change surgery in 1992 and was pursuing a career as an exotic dancer when the confrontation with police occurred. Her first death sentence for the shooting of a Haddon Heights patrolman was overturned on the ground that the prosecution had failed to disclose important evidence, but she was sentenced to death by a second jury last year. Ms. Nelson is serving a life sentence for killing the second man. Laura Mansnerus

title: July 28-Aug. 3: INTERNATIONAL; PEACE NOW
description: The four-year war between Rwanda and Congo, which killed hundreds of thousands, may soon end. Presidents Joseph Kabila of Congo and Paul Kagame of Rwanda signed a treaty in Pretoria, South Africa, committing Rwanda to withdraw its troops from Congo, and Congo to disarm Rwandan Hutu militias it harbors that took part in the 1994 Rwandan genocide. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Kristin Lucas, James Robillard
description: Kristin Lawrence Lucas, a daughter of Virginia L. Lucas and Jerome D. Lucas of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Andrew Robillard, a son of Rosanne E. Robillard of Wayzata, Minn., and the late Gregory L. Robillard Jr. Msgr. Austin P. Bennett performed the ceremony at St. Dominic Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, DOROTHY PRESSMAN
description: ROSENTHAL - Dorothy Pressman. 88, died peacefully at home on July 30, 2002. She was born in Baltimore and was educated there and in Waterbury, CT, and Brooklyn, where she graduated from Girls Commercial High School and attended City College. She worked as a bookkeeper for many years and had two children, Robert, of Manhattan, and Nancy (Mrs. Paul Rosendahl), of Great Neck. Also surviving are a brother, Jeffrey Pressman, of Delray Beach, FL, several nieces and nephews, and her longtime caregivers, Yvonne and Alida Cooman. There will be a memorial service at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, on Sunday, August 11, at 2 PM. Donations in her memory may be made to BFFY Alzheimer's Adult Care, 157-16 65th Ave, Flushing, NY 11367; or Forest Hills Community House, 108-25 62nd Dr, Forest Hills, NY 11375.

title: Waging a Mission to Save a Family Heirloom
description: On Tuesday evening, under the baton of Derrick Inouye, the Naumburg Orchestra will perform works by Haydn, Stravinsky and Elgar under the Naumburg Band Shell on the mall in Central Park. The concert will be the last of the summer series.

title: Pour It On
description: Read this slowly. Prolong the vowels. It's hot out. Words will salve.

title: Facial Hair Is Fine, but Only Above the Lip
description: AS municipal disputes go, this one in Fairfield between the town's Police Commission and the police union doesn't have the drama of most labor conflicts. No work stoppages. No angry citizens waving placards of protest. No calls for cooler heads to prevail.

title: The Rise of the Perma-Temp
description: In a beige classroom so spare that there isn't a poster or a bookcase to warm it, Elaine Bobrove passes out her last reading assignment of the semester -- Langston Hughes's ''Theme for English B.'' It's a clear enough poem, about a black student trying to relate to his white instructor, a perfect assignment for a rainy spring day when Ms. Bobrove's Camden County College students are through with finals and ready to put her remedial reading course behind them.

title: BackTalk; A Cyclist Finds There Are Many Ways to Be Like Lance
description: When I told my two daughters that I planned to shave my legs to Be Like Lance, they said, ''Uh!'' When I told my wife, she said, ''Grow up.''

title: 'The Real World' Gets a Script and Gets Unreal
description: FANS of MTV's ''Real World'' are a devoted bunch. In September the show enters its 12th season, set in Las Vegas, on the heels of ''The Real World: Chicago,'' whose July finale garnered more viewers than any episode in the history of the series.

title: Penobscot Bay
description: A safe conversation starter along the western shore of Penobscot Bay in Maine these days is to ask, ''Can you believe what's happened to . . .'' and then insert the name of Belfast or Rockland or any other town in the area.

title: The Dillon Legacy For Fire Island
description: On the surface, Superintendent Constantine Dillon's decision [''A Changing of the Guard, and of Policy, on Fire Island,'' July 28] to let 17 small communities renourish the fragile beach via dredge and fill, and also scrape sand into the dunes and then plant grass there, all at their own expense, seems a nice gesture. But it is a hollow one.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAPLAN, ALAN H.
description: KAPLAN-Alan H. April 26, '30-August 2, '01. On the first anniversary of Alan's death, his wife, children and grandchildren remember him with love. He was a devoted son, brother, mentor and friend. We miss his intellect, sweetness and humor. He is in our thoughts every day.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about horse and wagon trips from Jackson Hole, Wyo., misstated the type of wagon used. It is a replica of a prairie schooner, not of a Conestoga. The article also misstated the area in which the original Conestogas were used. It was as far west as Ohio and Indiana, not on the Oregon Trail.

title: A Story of Pain and Endurance
description: THE little ladybug has a downcast look, her blue eyes nearly teary, her pencil-thin mouth in deep frown.

title: South Rim Savings
description: From Aug. 11 to Sept. 12, the 358-room Yavapai East Lodge, within walking distance of the South Rim of the Grand Canyon, is offering a Grand American Getaway package with a room, breakfast and a bus tour of the South Rim for $79 plus tax for two. Each additional person in the room is $9. The regular price for the components would be about $170. The narrated tour takes a half day, starting in Grand Canyon Village with numerous stops along the South Rim to the Desert View Watchtower. Mention code GETPR when reserving, at (888) 297-2757.

title: FOREIGN INVESTORS TURNING CAUTIOUS ON SPENDING IN U.S.
description: Foreign investors, who once joined with confident Americans in a wave of spectacular acquisitions and business spending that helped power the 1990's economic boom, are now turning cautious about the United States economy. That is compounding the current weakness and making it harder to achieve a robust recovery from last year's recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIMM, CHARLES H.
description: GRIMM-Charles H. Of New York, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, on July 27, 2002. Husband of Ruth. Father of Donald and brother of the late Sydelle G. Carleton & the late Dorothea Robinson. On his retirement, Mr. Grimm was senior vice president and chief flavor chemist of International Flavors and Fragrances (IFFUS). He continued to serve the company as a consultant. Mr. Grimm joined IFF in 1953, was named vice president in 1966, and was actively engaged in the industry for over 50 years. He was a longtime member of the American Chemical Society, American Institute of Chemists, Institute for Food Technology, American Society of Enologists, a member of the Technical Committee of the Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association, the Scientfiic Committee of the Essential Oil Association, a long-standing member of the Food Protection Committee, Industry Panel of the National Academy of Sciences, National Research Council, a founder and charter member of the Society for Flavor Chemists. He lectured before the American Chemical Society, American Association of Cereal Chemists, Columbia University, M.I.T., N.Y.U., and other organizations on flavor creation, essential oils and aroma chemistry. He authored many papers published in scientific and technical journals and holds several patents. He is listed in ''American Men and Women in Science.'' Mr. Grimm was a graduate of New York University and did graduate work and research at the graduate schools of New York University and Columbia University. Funeral arrangements were private.

title: Trying to Measure An Entrepreneurial Itch
description: About one in five Americans runs his or her own business, but a new survey shows that many more people yearn to don the entrepreneurial cap.

title: High-Yield Opportunity, High-Risk Possibilities
description: STRESS-TESTED investors looking for opportunities may want to explore the market for high-yield, or junk, bonds.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RESSNER, MICHAEL
description: RESSNER-Michael. August 4, 1999 ''Something Wonderful.'' All who loved him

title: Demand for Electricity Sets a Record for LIPA
description: Electric usage on Long Island soared last Monday to a record 5,059 megawatts. The Long Island Power Authority said that demand was growing at a rate of 4 to 5 percent annually, about three times the state average.

title: Business; Round Up the Usual Suspects. Lawyers, Too?
description: AS investors, politicians and prosecutors search for people to blame for the lengthening list of corporate scandals and bankruptcies, they have set their sights on a new group: lawyers.

title: Frank Inn, Who Trained Lassie and Benji, Is Dead at 86
description: Frank Inn, who helped train Lassie and Rhubarb the cat, and on his own discovered and made actors of Arnold the pig on ''Green Acres,'' the 500 or so animals on ''The Beverly Hillbillies'' and his greatest star, Benji, the cuddly movie dog, died on July 27 in Sylmar, Calif. He was 86.

title: She Walks Through Walls
description: My 14 siblings and I were all reared in various orphanages, in Ireland, by Catholic religious orders. Not one of us escaped from those institutions without enduring some form of abuse, be it sexual, physical, emotional or psychological.

title: Corrections
description: Money & Business

title: Man's Best Friend
description: De Jonge's take on sportscasters was entertaining. His larger claim -- that there is a nation of lonely guys out there taking refuge in viewing sports shows -- may be true, but he never grounds that assessment in anything more than his own musings. (I seem to recall an NBC honcho saying the opposite was true when that network passed on the N.B.A. contract.)

title: Shake It Up, Baby
description: Jonathan Reynolds's Food column (July 21) was a joy to read. It brought back memories of delicious malteds at candy stores in Brooklyn. I've tried to make them at home using Carnation malted mix in a glass blender. But I think part of the pleasure of those candy-store malteds was that after the counterman poured a glassful from the stainless-steel blender, he then left it on the counter so that at least another half glass remained to savor.

title: She's Funny, but Can TV Find a Spot for Her?
description: SARAH SILVERMAN is the main reason some of us stay up late to watch television. Glimpses of Ms. Silverman, a bewitching 31-year-old comedian who's as babelicious as she is wickedly daring, are highly prized by her band of admirers.

title: Rise, Shine And Root
description: More pathetic even than the couch potato is the mattress potato. My wife usually gets up before I do, and on the way back from the shower, she flicks on the bedroom television to help rouse me into sentience. In June, though, she found me propped up in bed with the tube already on. She looked at the screen and then back at me. ''You're watching soccer?'' she said. A couple of weeks later, during the final of the British Open, she pointed out that I was still in my pajamas at lunchtime.

title: 30th Annual World Open Lives Up to Its Name
description: The 30th annual World Open Tournament at the Adam's Mark Hotel in Philadelphia, June 29 to July 7, ended in a nine-way tie for first place.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: A Manager's Streak Is in Danger, or Is It?
description: If Bill Miller is afraid that his unmatched streak of beating the market will end this year, his fear is not showing.

title: Business; To Start a Men's Line, A Pitch to Women
description: ARNOLD B. ZETCHER, the president and chief executive of Talbots, has had a good time opening his mail. A woman in California sent him family portraits of herself, her children and her mother all dressed in Talbots clothing. Another woman sent him a photograph of her closet door, which she had painted red after the Talbots signature storefront. Then there was the customer who mailed him blue pajamas she had ordered through the catalog. She did not like the color and asked him for the pink ones.

title: Librarians in Demand, Away From the Books
description: AT 40, Elaine Cummings-young, is returning to the corporate world after leaving her job at Merrill Lynch nearly two years ago. But as she takes her final classes at Queens College, where she has studied database management and Web programming, Ms. Cummings-Young of Massapequa Park, N.Y., is not looking for a job in computer development. She would rather use her master's in library science degree to be a business librarian.

title: Attack of the Summer Interns
description: KENDRA GLEN marvels at the worldliness of the interns who work for her in the publicity and special events department at Henri Bendel, the Manhattan fashion emporium. One, a high school senior who worked at the store in May, asked Ms. Glen for the name of a good nightclub.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STABILE, VINCENT A.
description: STABILE-Vincent A. Engineer and philanthropist, formerly of Verona, NJ, died at his home in Naples, FL on July 13. A funeral mass was held in Naples on July 17th. Burial will be August 7, 2002, at 1:30 P.M. in the St. Gertrude Cemetery, 53 Inman Avenue, Colonia, New Jersey.

title: She Walks Through Walls
description: So here's another brash, strong-willed executive telling people what to do (Dennis Cass, July 21). The only difference is that Mary Jo Copeland is not a corporate C.E.O. commanding an obscene salary and pocketing profits for herself. She draws no salary and helps orphans and the poor.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Arthur Benson, a utilities magnate (and the developer of Bensonhurst, in Brooklyn), bought virtually all of Montauk in 1879 for $151,000. After he ''relocated'' what was left of the Montaukett Indian tribe, he set about turning the ruggedly beautiful tip of Long Island into a playground for his wealthy friends. (At one point, he even tried to introduce fox hunting.) Benson, who died before realizing most of his grandiose plans for the area, did leave one important mark: he commissioned McKim, Mead & White in 1882 to design seven shingle-style summer cottages on a bluff overlooking the Atlantic. Six of the original ''Seven Sisters'' still survive.

title: Who's That Girl?
description: Amanda Latona has a voice, but she needs a sound. It is January, and she is standing in a small, closetlike recording booth in Midtown Manhattan, where she is recording part of her first album for J Records. Her handlers are still trying to decide what kind of platinum-selling pop sensation she should be. Originally, the idea was that Latona, who is 23, should be Britney Spears. Latona admires Spears, and they almost performed together in Innosense, a girl group from the home of teen pop, Orlando, Fla. Innosense was designed to be an American version of the Spice Girls, but Britney left to pursue her solo career. Lately, Spears's star has fallen; her last record sold disappointingly, and her HBO special revealed that she can't sing live. With 'N Sync and the Backstreet Boys dismantling and Christina Aguilera still recording the follow-up to her 1999 debut, the teen-pop phenomenon seems to have fizzled.

title: July 28-Aug. 3: SCIENCE; MAYBE YES, MAYBE NO

They observed the way billions of rare particles called muons whirled in a powerful magnetic field, and found that the rate of their microscopic jig did not match the predictions of accepted theories. Their conclusion: either a new form of matter was flitting through space and affecting the motion, or theorists have not yet solved a series of math mistakes they have made in working out the predictions of the known theory. James Glanz

In bright prints with voluminous cuts, the skirts play off last season's peasant look: stiff linings, crinkly underskirts and generously gathered waists. Club Monaco's bright yellow and white garden skirt, right ($89), comes in polished cotton with a retro 1950's circle cut that hits right below the knee. Chetta B's Mexican-like polka-dot skirt is trimmed with rickrack ($415 at Saks Fifth Avenue), while a petticoat skirt by Banana Republic hugs the hips and then explodes in a cascade of eyelet and ruffles ($128). A pink cotton Gypsy skirt by Vanessa Bruno ($172 at www.netaporter.com) has a ruched, drawstring waist and lace hem, while J. Crew's printed poet skirt sits low on the hips and is lined in cotton batiste ($68). And Cynthia Rowley's cream silk taffeta number with a rose floral print ($240) allows party princesses to flounce around the room straight through autumn.

title: 'I'll Be Short'
description: It is far too early to know what historians will see when they look back on the years 2000 to 2002 from their perches in the future, but it's likely they will chronicle a profound change in America. The years leading up featured almost breathless excitement about getting rich quick in dot-coms, irrational exuberance in the stock market, and boundless confidence about the nation's power and place in the world. Then, in rapid succession, the dot-com bubble burst, the economy drifted into recession, and terrorists attacked with a deadliness and ferocity never known or even imagined before. Then one of our most successful corporations suddenly imploded, revealing a sham of accounting gimmicks and regulatory lapses; investors and employees lost big while top executives walked off with fortunes.

But in the last 30 years, the leadership of the schools has been removed from education and immersed in politics.

It's a clear enough poem, about a black student trying to relate to his white instructor, a perfect assignment for a rainy spring day when Ms. Bobrove's Camden County College students are through with finals and ready to put her remedial reading course behind them.

description: BERKLEY-Sandra DeJur. Of New York City, passed away on August 1, 2002. Devoted daughter of the late Frances and Ralph DeJur. Beloved and cherished wife of Allen Berkley. Loving mother of John, Elizabeth and son-inlaw Stephen. Proud grandmother of Alexander. Dear sister of Jacqueline and her husband Steven. Aunt of David, James and Mark. She was deeply loved and will be missed. Sandra possessed a gifted artist's eye for beauty and perfection. She had a passion for family and travel. We will remember her courage, strength and grace. Services Monday, August 5, 9:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment to follow at Old Montefiore Cemetery, at St. Albans, New York.

First there's the surly soldier who has been ordered to guard her; while he's busy with election day duties, he complains, ''the crooks are having a party.'' Then there are the islanders. One man, fearing she has come to arrest him, flees; another man tries to commandeer the votes of all the women in his village. A wacky scientist proclaims that God is his only candidate; an ancient matriarch, who governs her farm like an absolute ruler, finds the whole democratic process irrelevant.
