description: Ernest Hemingway drove an ambulance in wartime Italy, safaried in Africa and lived for years in a finca outside Havana. F. Scott Fitzgerald cut a wild swath across Europe, touching down in places like Paris and Cap d'Antibes. But William Faulkner, who came of age in the same Lost Generation era, was content to live most of his life in the sleepy town of Oxford, Miss. -- the ''postage stamp'' of land he famously transformed, in 15 novels and numerous short stories, into Yoknapatawpha County, ''William Faulkner, Sole Owner & Proprietor.''

title: After Sept. 11, a Legal Battle On the Limits of Civil Liberty
description: In the fearful aftermath of Sept. 11, Attorney General John Ashcroft vowed to use the full might of the federal government and ''every available statute'' to hunt down and punish ''the terrorists among us.''

title: On Writers and Writing; Who's a Robot Now?
description: I CAME upon ''Portraits of Robots,'' a small art book by Thomas Zummer, just as I began an effort to upgrade my scientific awareness by reading Chris Hables Gray's ''Cyborg Citizens: Politics in the Posthuman Age.'' Gray's book is hearteningly lucid about such things as prostheses, genetic engineering, cryonics and biochemical weapons. Zummer's drawings are spectrally exact, and very beautiful. He has drawn copies of actual photographs of robots built between 1930 and 1987 and equipped for various tasks, among them walking, talking, counting, distinguishing red from green, administering exams and smoking.

title: History of Hatred
description: Racism

title: Marilyn In Manhattan
description: FEW people write about Marilyn Monroe in New York, despite her strong and visible presence in the city where she lived on and off from 1949 until just before her death four decades ago tomorrow.

title: Courtney Pulitzer, Paul Kaihla
description: Courtney Jane Pulitzer, a daughter of Charlene Atkinson of Washington and Arthur B. Pulitzer of Utica, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul A. Kaihla, the son of T. H. Elizabeth Kaihla of Toronto and the late Mauno O. Kaihla. The Rev. J. Barrington Bates, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Ascension in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ELLA (ESTHER)
description: WEISS-Ella (Esther). On August 2, 2002, at the age of 95 years young. Widow of husband Edward E. Deutsch, deceased 1948. Loving mother of Harvey Deutsch and dear mother-in-law of Jeanine. Loving mother of Martin Deutsch and dear mother-inlaw of Michelle and the late Rita. Beloved grandmother of Allan Deutsch, Colette Ebert, Bruce Deutsch, Marc Deutsch, Jerome Deutsch. Grandmother-in-law of Susan Deutsch, Debbie Deutsch and Robert Ebert. Great-grandmother of Nicole, Michelle, Lindsay and Jeffrey Ebert, Joshua, Remy, Beryl & Jessie Deutsch, Noah Deutsch. Dear sister of Edward Stallman and the late Louis, Charles and Benjamin. Widow of Alfred Jacoby. Widow of Barrie Weiss. Hadassah PastPresident of New York National Hadassah. Founder and generous contributor. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ANTHRAX CLEANUP
description: A postal facility in Hamilton Township closed since October when it was found that anthrax-contaminated letters were processed there, will reopen no earlier than next spring, according to the Postal Service. Equipment being used to decontaminate a postal center in Washington, D.C., will be moved to Hamilton once work in the capital is finished. Decontamination and renovations at the Hamilton complex should be completed by spring. The employees who worked at the Hamilton office have been relocated to nearby offices, and mail is being processed in three other postal facilities nearby. Another building in Monroe Township, Middlesex County, was leased last week to process mail. Karen DeMasters

title: Eternal Squeeze
description: CEMETERIES make many people uncomfortable. They can be disturbing, even a bit creepy. They inspire small children to hold their breath while passing. But a well-maintained cemetery can be lovely and luxuriant and it can be a source of family pride.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Desire for Home Offices, but They Are Hard to Find
description: A SIX-BLOCK area in Williston Park once called ''doctor's row,'' which lies along Mineola Boulevard between Hillside Avenue and Jericho Turnpike, is lined with trees and neat homes with wide lawns.

title: The World: Death Throes; Remembering How Africa's First World War Began
description: THE leaders of Congo and Rwanda signed a peace agreement last week, four years after war broke out in Central Africa and drew in half a dozen other nations in what was sometimes called the continent's first world war. Only the combatants will decide whether this pact ends up in the wastebasket with the war's other failed truces or becomes a milestone in Africa's history, like the war.

title: Kidnapped
description: THE WHITE

title: A Breather For Parents And Kids
description: FOR the past six years, my husband, Ken, our two children and I have spent a week each summer at the Tyler Place Family Resort in Highgate Springs, Vt., on Lake Champlain. We had not previously been resort-inclined, and tended to smile at people who were, viewing them as less imaginative and self-reliant than those of us who improvised their own vacations. But when my older daughter was a toddler and my younger was a baby, I was so beside myself that I routinely forgot to turn on the oven, turn off the toaster, hang up the phone, or close the car windows in the rain. The baby was teething; the toddler was having tantrums. Ken once walked into traffic without looking and then refused to say it was an accident. In other words, imagination and self-reliance were no longer of interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNANT, EDMUND
description: PENNANT-Edmund. Poet, died July 23, age 85, in New York City.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sparkill, N.Y.; Hamlet That Prizes a Small-Town Feeling
description: SPARKILL, a tiny, verdant Rockland County hamlet surrounded by the tonier enclaves of Piermont and Palisades, is blessed with a rich history and a tendency among its residents to stay put.

title: DataBank; Weak Economic Signs Stop the Market Rally
description: Last week ended poorly for stocks, as a recent rally from five-year lows stalled in the face of sour economic news. Second-quarter economic growth was anemic, the manufacturing sector slowed significantly in July and job creation was surprisingly weak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HERMAN I.
description: LEVINE-Herman I. Of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Woodmere, NY, passed away August 3, 2002. Survived by his belvoed wife Eleanor (nee Klugman), four children, a sister and six grandchildren.

title: Corrections
description: A column last Sunday about varieties of Judaism that coexist at a Y camp in Clifton misstated the most common English rendition of the Yiddish word for pray, or bless. It is bentsh, not bench.

title: The Cake Eater
description: VERSAILLES

title: Maybe They Should Make Camden an Olympic Village
description: If you build it, they will come. Really.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about disputes in the venture capital industry misstated a ruling in a lawsuit brought last month by Benchmark Capital against the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Juniper Financial, a start-up company that Benchmark helped finance. A Delaware judge denied Benchmark's request for a preliminary injunction to stop Juniper from getting new financing from the Canadian bank, a move that would dilute Benchmark's stake. The judge did not throw out Benchmark's suit.

title: POSTINGS: Riverside in Detail; Long Map for a Long Park
description: A bit more than a yard long but folded to the size of a small paperback book, a new two-sided map unfolds the offerings of Riverside Park and its adjoining byways. The 37 1/2-inch long color strip maps the park from 67th to 156th Streets, covering nine blocks on each of its panels and including details down to the telephone number shown under the diagram of 10 tennis courts at 119th Street.

title: Attacks on Peace Corps Volunteers Found Rising
description: Reported assaults on Peace Corps volunteers abroad more than doubled over the last decade, and organizational problems in the agency may be limiting its ability to ensure volunteers' safety, a study by the General Accounting Office has found.

title: Hoping for a City Full of Farms on Rooftops
description: NEW YORKERS and other city people may be used to seeing tomatoes and peppers in big pots on the roof, but what about a little farm growing right out of the tar beach?

title: Leaf's Pro Career: Short and Unhappy
description: It was just over four years ago that the Indianapolis Colts' president, Bill Polian, held the golden ticket inside the Willy Wonka chocolate bar -- the first pick in the 1998 N.F.L. draft. Used wisely, it would unlock the doors to a future of playoff possibilities. A poor choice, however, might hamstring the franchise for years, jarring its salary cap and demoralizing its fan base.

title: U.N. Agency In Afghanistan Is the Target Of a Grenade
description: Two men hurled a hand grenade at a building housing a United Nations agency in the southern city of Kandahar on Thursday, the first attack on the United Nations since it returned to Afghanistan seven months ago, a spokesman said today.

title: Getting Asian-Americans Into the Picture
description: CORKY LEE has a day job. He works in sales and customer service at Expedi Printing in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the company that prints India Abroad, News Tibet, Dog News, Dan's Paper, The New York Sun, The New York Law Journal and Bamboo Girl zine. When he gets off work, though, he straps on a camera and becomes, in his words, ''the Undisputed Unofficial Asian-American Photographer Laureate.''

title: The Bottom Line At Local Hospitals
description: DR. JACK GREEN didn't know what to expect when Essent Healthcare took over Sharon Hospital last spring. After all, no for-profit hospital had ever operated in the state.

title: 'Gums'
description: WITH apologies to Peter, Paul and Mary, where have all the sharks gone?

title: Stanley Works Decides to Stay Put After All
description: THE workers who gathered in New Britain last Monday to rally against a plan by Stanley Works to reincorporate in Bermuda said they had seen too much work sent overseas and opened too many Christmas bonuses only to find a grocery-store gift certificate to believe the plan would have benefited anyone other than company executives.

title: College Prep; Premeditations
description: An awful lot of the best and brightest 17-year-olds want to be doctors. Despite the constraints of H.M.O.'s and the costs of malpractice insurance, the letters M.D. continue to bring prestige and prosperity to the names that are attached to them. That's why in the nation's elite colleges of arts and sciences -- including the University of Chicago, Cornell University and the University of Virginia -- 20 to 30 percent of first-year students identify themselves as pre-med.

title: Fair Trials in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFF, ROSE (NEE HOCHMAN)
description: HOFF-Rose (nee Hochman). Age 97. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Ralph Hoff, loving daughter, dedicated sister, proud mother of Herbert (Evelyn) and Claire Greenfogel (Maurice), grandmother of Michael, Patricia, Terry, Stephen and Vivian, greatgrandmother of Aaron, Alana, Benjamin, Matthew, Mark, Samuel, Caroline and Meryl Rose. She met every challenge of the tumultuous century her life mirrored and excelled as legal secretary, wife and mother, corporate officer, art student and accomplished painter. Our memory of her compassionate and unqualified friendship and love will endure as her legacy to all whose life she touched.

title: Koreans Protest U.S. Military's Handling of a Fatal Accident
description: The two schoolgirls were on their way to a birthday party on the morning of June 13, walking along a rural road about 20 miles north of here, when an armored vehicle operated by two American army sergeants crushed them to death beneath its tracks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, ROBERT V.
description: SULLIVAN-Robert V. Deceased July 27, 2002, at the age of 90. Resided in Palm Beach, Florida, and Fort Lee, New Jersey. Prominent New York jeweler. Executive Vice President with Van Cleef & Arpels from 1972 until 1984. Survived by Arax, his beloved wife of 65 years, sons Dennis and Shawn, three grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren.

title: Surrounded
description: Each July brings the announcement of the winners of the annual Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest. Named after the fellow whom Snoopy the dog was plagiarizing whenever he typed ''It was a dark and stormy night,'' the contest seeks ''the opening sentence to the worst of all possible novels.'' And the recently proclaimed grand-prize sentence for 2002, penned by Ms. Rephah Berg, of Oakland, Calif., is: ''On reflection, Angela perceived that her relationship with Tom had always been rocky, not quite a roller-coaster ride but more like when the toilet-paper roll gets a little squashed so it hangs crooked and every time you pull some off you can hear the rest going bumpity-bumpity in its holder until you go nuts and push it back into shape, a degree of annoyance that Angela had now almost attained.''

title: July 28-Aug. 3: NATIONAL; JOY TURNED TO GRIEF
description: A day after volunteers and tourists saved 46 pilot whales stranded on a Cape Cod beach, the whales ran aground again. This time, the whales refused to head out to sea and were all euthanized by veterinarians. Pam Belluck

title: Anxiety Felt in Louisiana After 4 West Nile Deaths
description: The doctors who have tried to explain to Becky Hunt why her husband died this week from a mosquito bite cannot tell her precisely how and when he was stricken, but she believes she knows. Her husband, Earnest, was a lawyer, always dressed in suit and tie, his pinstripe armor, except on the Fourth of July.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; Vacancies Up in Fairfield, but So Are Building Prices
description: COMMERCIAL real estate in Fairfield County is going through a tumultuous time. Office vacancies have doubled from 6 and 7 percent two years ago to 13 to 16.5 percent, depending on which brokerage company is compiling the statistics. and asking rental rates keep dropping.

title: In Predawn Hours, Bronx Man, 65, Is Slain on Way to Work
description: A 65-year-old Bronx man who brought his family to New York from a small farm in Mexico was stabbed to death just before dawn yesterday after he left his home for his job as a cleaner at a City Island restaurant, the police said.

title: An Uplifting Voice From CD or Pulpit
description: LIKE a rock star, Donnie McClurkin strolled onto the stage in Freeport, grabbed the microphone and started to sing. The crowd, dressed in their Sunday finery, was already on their feet, dancing in front of their folding chairs as they joined the tall, suave vocalist in a rollicking rendition of ''You Are the Living Word.''

title: Cloth That's Wrapped In Spiritual Power
description: IN 1886, Queen Ranavalona III of Madagascar sent two stunning togalike silk wraps called lambas to the new American president, Grover Cleveland. The diplomatic gifts were made to mark Madagascar's 50-year alliance with the United States and, more pressingly, to seek continued American support in the fight to remain independent. At the time, Madagascar, the island nation off the southeast coast of Africa, was fending off French and British attempts to colonize it.

title: Coastal Village Preserves Its Nature
description: If California is the land of self-reinvention, Caspar could be the unofficial capital.

description: School (skool) n. (Middle English scole < Old English scol < Latin schola < Greek schole; leisure, discussion, philosophy)

title: Sex, Lies And Bad Lighting
description: It's hip to mix high and low.

title: Personal Business; Term Insurance Turns Long Term
description: TERM life insurance started as a type of coverage that people bought year to year. Then it gradually became a long-range proposition, with 20-year policies the most popular. Four years ago, insurers began extending the term to 30 years in many parts of the country, and in the last two weeks such policies quietly became available in New York for the first time.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Tony Wilson; Sneak Preview
description: BEYOND his glasses, black Gaultier sarong and sandals, not to mention the reputation for high-voltage iconoclasm that has followed him since he was a lad back in Manchester, England -- or ''Madchester,'' as it was then known -- it's the frosted blue polish on Tony Wilson's toenails that seals it.

title: Shake It Up, Baby
description: Working in my family's ice-cream parlor when I was growing up, I learned that the secret of a thick shake was the temperature of the milk. It was kept semifrozen, which obviated the need for heaps of ice cream.

title: The Dillon Legacy For Fire Island
description: Superintendent Dillon's new announced sand-dredging and dune-building policy commits to issue National Park Service permits for properly designed, comprehensive and coordinated beach renourishment projects for the near-term and 2003-2006 period, if approved by the other responsible agencies, the Corps of Engineers and the state Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Lost Voices of Firefighters, Some on the 78th Floor
description: A lost tape of lost voices, ignored until recently by investigators studying the emergency response on Sept. 11, shows that firefighters climbed far higher into the south tower than practically anyone had realized. At least two men reached the crash zone on the 78th floor, where they went to the aid of grievously injured people trapped in a sprawl of destruction.

title: 'Camouflage'
description: My sister and I were often left alone together. She was younger than me, about eighteen months. I hardly had time to know her, although we were alone together for days on end, weekends included.

title: 'The Real McCoy'
description: Here was a champion before he closed his hand into a fist. The boy's gumption was like the full steam of a locomotive. Plus he was a born liar.

title: C.E.O. to Retire Over Dating Worker
description: Ashland Inc., the maker of Valvoline motor oil, said Friday that its chief executive, Paul W. Chellgren, will retire because he had violated a company policy on dating subordinates.

title: Iraqi Cleric in Iran Welcomes Plans to Oust Hussein
description: The ayatollah preached before nearly 70 Iraqi fighters this week and told them that America had decided to topple Saddam Hussein, the very goal that he has coveted for years.

title: Design That Is Literally Accessible
description: MARLENE WEINER, an occupational therapist and one of the 29 interior designers participating in this year's Show House at the Shore, still becomes emotional when she thinks about how her work can help the elderly and the disabled to do something as simple as take a shower alone for the first time.

description: WHEN a giant falls, the noise is loud and the collateral damage wide. Fear of such a prospect is gripping Latin America.

title: Loveseats And Beds Shape A Meadow
description: WHIMSY, historical symbolism, river lore and spiritualism are taking shape in marble and limestone here, as a group of artists works to finish a touchable, climbable ''sculpture meadow'' here by the Hudson River.

title: A Rsum From Beyond the Job Market
description: A FRIEND is thinking of leaving her job in order to spend the next few years caring for her two young children. She has all but decided to do this, but is hesitating over one nagging concern. Not finances, although she certainly worries about that. Not the strain of being with two preschoolers all day long, although she frets about that too. ''I spent years building my rsum,'' she says. ''Now there'll be this empty space when the time comes to return to work.''

title: Patricia Amorosi, David Muccia
description: Patricia Irene Amorosi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Amorosi of New York, and David Carrol Muccia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carrol A. Muccia of Rye, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Edward F. Maloney performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Allison Kampel, Marc Singer
description: Allison Michelle Kampel, a daughter of Susan and Stewart Kampel of East Northport, N.Y., is to be married today to Marc Lawrence Singer, the son of Susan Singer and Edmund Singer, both of Great Kills, Staten Island. Cantor Ralph P. Nussbaum will officiate at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Reading Lessons Wrapped in Rhymes and Covered With Fur
description: IMAGINE a land where nothing is quite as it seems -- where lion statues guarding library entrances twitch as you walk by, and inside, books literally take on lives of their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, NORMAN J.
description: ROSEN-Norman J. Leaves behind his wife Terry and his sons Richard and Robert. Survived by his sister Carla and his nephews Dr. Lewis Jassey, Adam Jassey and Jonathan Jassey. Former Executive Assistant District Attorney for Kings and Queens County. Partner in the law firm of Farber, Rosen and Kaufman, PC. Funeral services Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Was Gordon Gekko Right About Greed?
description: IN a Tolstoy story titled ''How Much Land Does a Man Need?'' a peasant named Pahom who longs for loam is granted his wish by the devil. First he gets 40 acres, then 125. Finally, in his acquisitive hunger, he accepts an offer of as much fertile territory as he can encircle in a day on foot. His cost will be just 1,000 rubles.

title: A Firm Resolve to Halt Abuse
description: A TRAGEDY of huge proportions has struck at the heart and life of the Catholic Church. We have had to face the sad fact that for more than three decades, a few priests have abused their positions of authority and betrayed a precious trust by preying on the innocence of children and teenagers through acts that are criminal, immoral and sinful.

description: Opening This Week

title: Beauty Parlance
description: After reading William Safire's On Language column (July 21) about beauty parlors, salons and spas, I discovered that I have some issues with the words used to describe the place where most of us go to get our hair cut off.

description: Tiger Woods's recent comment that Augusta National was entitled to ''set up their own rules the way they want them'' and exclude women led to a minor firestorm.

description: Steve Spurrier's first N.F.L. exhibition game had a Florida-type result.

title: Once More With Feeling: Buy American. Please!
description: The math couldn't be simpler. If you pay Americans $10 an hour to make shirts, they'll end up more expensive than if you pay a fraction of that to overseas workers. Of course, you can try to skew the math by appealing to customers to ignore the price and ''buy American,'' but most shoppers typically stop waving flags the moment they pull out their wallets.

title: Suozzi's Budget Shows A $4.6 Million Surplus
description: Thomas R. Suozzi, Nassau's county executive, said last week that the county budget showed a $4.6 million surplus for the year.

title: A New Schools Chancellor Draws Advice, Optimism and Crossed Fingers
description: With the shift to mayoral control, and a host of unresolved governance questions, Joel I. Klein, the incoming chancellor, will be navigating New York City's schools into new territory at a time when the faltering economy is forcing big budget cuts.

title: QUICK BITE/North Arlington; Serving Hot Dogs With Plenty of Company
description: I could easily have driven past the nondescript rectangular building on the Belleville Turnpike. That is, if it weren't for the enormous red awning draped over the white brick proclaiming, ''You never SAUSAGE a thing!'' Puns and buns? I pulled into Jimmy Buff's lot without another thought. Rutt's Hut in Clifton seems to get the ink in roundups on hot dog joints, deservedly. But any comprehensive look at this dog-eat-dog business should include Jimmy Buff's, which claims to be the inventor of the Italian hot dog, in Newark, in 1932. The Newark dog combines the deep-fried goodness of Rutt's with the piled-high philosophy of a Chicago-style concoction. A ''double'' ($5.57) consists of a half-moon of fresh, soft pizza bread (picture a pita on steroids), filled with two hot dogs fried in soybean oil, topped with grilled onions, peppers, fried potato slices, mustard and ketchup. The same treatment can also be applied to sausage, cheese steaks, hamburgers, chicken, potato and vegetables and potatoes and eggs, all in single and double servings. For the less adventurous, there are fish and chips, shrimp, chicken tenders, roast beef and meatball sandwiches, French fries, and onion rings. The North Arlington location has a charming and simple look, with its black-and-white checkerboard tile floor, old-fashioned bar stools, and a large crescent-shaped wooden counter. This year is the 70th anniversary of Jimmy Buff's, and throughout this month, a single hot dog will cost you the 1932 price of a nickel, with the purchase of any other sandwich of at least $2.90. If you go to Buff's every day this month, though, it will be tough to be buff. Jack Silbert

title: Sending Candy to Campers? Shhh!
description: WHEN Lauren Garfield of Larchmont got ready for sleepaway camp this summer, her mother knew not to hide any food among the duffel bags. Lauren's camp, Merriwood in New Hampshire, prohibits any snacks in the bunks. Not surprisingly, some children nonetheless sneak some candy in while packing and parents often turn a blind eye toward the contraband. Lauren's mother, Leslie, says, ''I have a 'don't ask, don't tell' policy.''

title: The World; Albert Einstein, Political Pawn
description: CHINESE and Israeli relations stumbled last week after Chinese authorities asked Israel to remove statements that Albert Einstein was Jewish and supported the creation of a Jewish state from an exhibition on the physicist's life that had been scheduled to tour China.

title: Bhutto Plans to Return to Pakistan, and Politics
description: Benazir Bhutto, one of two former prime ministers of Pakistan who are living in exile, said today that she would return to her homeland to run for office in the elections scheduled for October and that she would face being jailed by the country's military dictator.

title: Long Island Has Its Own Tall Ship Again
description: SQUINTING into a northeast wind, Mary Helen Gunn stood on the Greenport ferry dock on July 26, watching a three-masted tall ship maneuver through a churning sea of whitecaps. As program director of the Ernestina, a 108-year-old two-masted wooden schooner, Ms. Gunn knew from personal experience that bringing an old wooden ship into safe harbor was no easy task.

title: A Ladies' Man, but Not One for Night Life
description: There aren't many eligible roosters strutting around Park Slope. That may be why the one that appeared this spring in an enclosed green area off Grand Army Plaza seems to have acquired not one girlfriend, but two.

title: 'Some Memories of a Long Life, 1854-1911'
description: One day during the late summer of 1853 in Evansville, Indiana, a small but growing town in the Southwestern part of the State—a young girl of fifteen, suffering from some slight affection of the eyes, had been confined by the physician's orders to a darkened room.

title: Unexpected Pairings Via Britain and Mali
description: IT should come as no surprise that Damon Albarn voyaged to Mali, in West Africa, to record his new album. Although Mr. Albarn, 34, helped define the British rock sound of the 1990's with his postpunk band Blur, he has recently reinvented himself as a champion of eclectic sounds. With his side project, the Gorillaz, he collaborated with everyone from the Cuban singer Ibrahim Ferrer to the New Jersey rapper Redman, and Blur is going to Morocco to work on its seventh album.

title: On the Diamond or the Court, Dance Can Run Up the Score
description: THE choreographer Peter Pucci, a track and football star in his hometown of Baltimore, had almost completed a degree in physical education when he took a dance improvisation class in college. ''I liked the creative freedom of dance so much better than the strict regimen of athletics,'' Mr. Pucci, 44, said recently.

title: He Liked the Words But He Didn't Stay to Dance
description: As Jimmy Durante used to say, everybody wants to get into the act.

title: She's Brazilian, Tempered By a Bit of Everything Else
description: JAZZ isn't multicultural -- it's omnicultural. No other music has been so open to ethnic cross-pollination, and no other art form has successfully assimilated so wide a range of influences without compromising its own essential identity. Still, it's hard not to be startled by the exuberant polystylism of Luciana Souza, the Brazilian singer who begins a weeklong engagement on Tuesday at the Jazz Standard in Manhattan. title: Latvia Struggles to Include People of Its Soviet Past
description: Aleksandra C. Matrosova first arrived here in 1944 as an 18-year-old nurse in the Latvian Brigade of the Soviet Army. Now 76, she is still not a citizen in the place where she has lived most of her life. She speaks little of the new state language, Latvian, and is prohibited by law from using her native one, Russian, in any official way.

title: Man's Best Friend
description: Well done, Peter de Jonge (July 21). While I am not the junkie I was when I was younger, I'm still in recovery.

title: Out of the City and Deep in the Woods: Dread Visits a Campsite
description: WE'VE been trying to get out of the city as many weekends as possible this summer, so when a friend lent us a car for three weeks, we decided to run wild.

title: A Stoppard Panorama of Russian Idealism
description: TOM STOPPARD is the dramatist who debated the nature of God and good in his ''Jumpers,'' brought Lenin and James Joyce onstage in ''Travesties,'' and somehow made chaos theory, landscape gardening, Byron scholarship and Romanticism his joint subjects in ''Arcadia''; but even he admits he has written nothing more ambitious than the trilogy opening at the Royal National Theater this weekend.

title: The Baby Bias
description: When Marcia Inhorn had her first child, she took a paid leave from the anthropology department at Emory University and, on return, took on extra classes to make up the teaching she had missed. But as her hours as a mom started to compete with her hours as a professor, her relations with the department soured.

description: Nine Pennsylvania coal miners who were trapped underground for more than three days and whose rescue enthralled the nation have sold the television and book rights to their tale to the Walt Disney Company, a Disney representative said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENSKY, ARNOLD
description: PRENSKY-Arnold, 81. Of Florida, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of Felice and the late Estelle. Devoted father of David, Carol and Janet. Dear father-inlaw of Lois and Burt and stepfather of Joseph, Susan and Jane. Loving grandfather of Shelly, Bennett, Evan, Namir and Ariel. Dear friend of many. Prominent Great Neck resident and retailer. President of Great Neck Chamber of Commerce, President of New York State Council of Retail Merchants and founding member of Temple Emanuel. Donations to: Great Neck Student Aid Fund or American Cancer Society.

description: To the Editor:

description: (Pre)view From the Train

title: She Walks Through Walls
description: The article on Mary Jo Copeland was disturbing. While she turned to religion to cope with her abusive family environment, this solution must not be viewed as the best strategy to help neglected children cope with such traumatic experiences. What these children need are nurturing, stable family relationships. Copeland's plan to return to the traditional orphanage model denies troubled children this opportunity.

title: Who Declares a War?
description: Last week's Senate hearings on military action against Iraq mark a welcome step toward maintaining constitutional government in a time of national emergency. But this process will be incomplete if Congress shirks the two fundamental questions it must ultimately face: Can the Bush administration unilaterally decide when to go to war against Iraq without seeking the assent of Congress? And can a Congress in which each party narrowly controls one house effectively discharge its constitutional duties?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARROW, BERNIE
description: BARROW-Bernie. Gone nine long years, but always in our hearts. Joan and the children.

title: 'Stravinsky and Balanchine'
description: In reviewing the 1972 Stravinsky Festival of the New York City Ballet, Andrew Porter wrote in the New Yorker that ballets like Stravinsky Violin Concerto, Orpheus , and Agon seemed "almost to flow from a single mind; an entity called Stravinsky-Balanchine." No conjoining of two artists' names was ever more appropriate. Beginning with their initial meeting in 1926, a binding covenant quickly developed, a union that would connect them personally and professionally for the rest of their lives. In Balanchine's eyes, Stravinsky was a colossus, the "Orpheus of the twentieth century." Along with Mozart and Tchaikovsky, no composer inspired him more. Even as a young ballet student at the Imperial Theater School in Petersburg, Georgi Balanchivadze was immediately drawn to Stravinsky's vibrant music. By the time of his death in 1983, he had choreographed many of the composer's most important works. The powerful pulse of Stravinsky's music flowed relentlessly forward, begging to be placed into physical motion, to be visualized, to be danced. Even through those electrically charged Stravinskyan moments of silence that so powerfully jolt the music's continuity, "life goes on," Balanchine remarked. No matter what the piece, the genre, the instrumentation, the choreographer declared that "every measure Eagerfeodorovitch ever wrote is good for dancing."

title: July 28-Aug. 3: ECONOMY; THE DEAL GETS DONE
description: I.B.M. announced that it would buy the management consulting arm of accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers for $3.5 billion, evidence both of Big Blue's view that services, not hardware, are the key to future growth in the computer industry, and of the fall in value of the consulting arms of the big accounting firms. In 2000, Hewlett-Packard almost bought the same business for $18 billion. Jonathan D. Glater

title: Elizabeth Wiedenmayer, Shep Rogers
description: Elizabeth Iselin Wiedenmayer and Edward James Rogers were married yesterday by the Rev. Matthew Engleby, an Episcopal priest, at the Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: She Walks Through Walls
description: The ball fields, the $2 a week and even the hugs will not counteract the regimentation that impairs all institutional care for children. Copeland says: ''I never really was a part of this world. . . . Belonging to the world didn't mean anything to me.'' That is her personal tragedy. Children, on the other hand, very much want to be part of this world. Copeland and her generous donors should not keep them away from it.

title: Saving a Butterfly's Berth in the Ark
description: ON the southwestern edge of the Pine Barrens, under a broiling summer sun, Joseph M. Patt was demonstrating the delicate art of administering a butterfly tattoo. Not etching a butterfly onto someone's arm, mind you, but actually tattooing a butterfly.

title: Francine Ross, Jonathan Margolis
description: Francine Merle Ross, the daughter of Shelli Ross of Alexandria, Va., and the late Marc Ross, was married last evening to Jonathan David Margolis, the son of Andrea and Ira Margolis of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Arnold G. Fink officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Washington.

description: BASEBALL

description: JOSEPH B. QUINN talks about pockets of opportunity in New York City and its environs.

title: Phillip Oesterman, 64, Producer And Director of Broadway Shows
description: Phillip Oesterman, a Broadway producer and director who worked extensively with Tommy Tune and whose bawdy musical ''Let My People Come'' was a long-running hit in the 1970's, died on Tuesday at his home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 64.

title: Private Sector; The Ballad of Bernie Ebbers: Sorry, Wrong Number
description: It was only a matter of time before Wall Street had its fun with the accounting-fraud scandal that has enveloped WorldCom and its founder and former chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers. An e-mail message making the rounds of traders in New York, Boston and Latin America features a parody song, to the tune of Don McLean's 70's ballad, ''American Pie.'' (An MP3 file of the music is conveniently attached to the e-mail message for the karaoke-inclined.) A sampling:

title: Sharing a Vacation, Straining a Friendship
description: SHARING a beach house with your friends seemed a good idea in the dead of winter. It was cold then. You had a glass of cabernet sauvignon in your hand and warm feelings in your heart. You thought togetherness would not only make a beachside vacation affordable -- it would also be fun!

title: A Hamptons Favorite Moves Up a Notch
description: I JUST received the annual call from friends in New Jersey asking for a list of this year's hot new Hamptons spots. In a few weeks, after their East End vacation, there will be a report card on how well I did, along with their usual sign-off, ''And of course we went to Nick & Toni's, which is still our favorite.''

title: The Classiest Of the Classics, True to Itself
description: ''SWAN LAKE'' is too much with us. Once the very model of the classical ballet, it has evolved into something even grander: an icon of the Romantic imagination, casting its long shadow across the landscape of our culture, no longer the sole property of the balletomane.

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Sunday about government-issued comic books in Mexico used a misspelled given name in some copies for the Mexican president, who sponsored their publication. He is Vicente Fox, not Vincente.

title: Knee Injury To Abraham Unsettles Jets' Defense
description: The cheering from the boisterous crowd that had gathered for a mock game at the Jets' training camp today ended abruptly. Just three plays into the practice, on a handoff at the goal line, the defensive coordinator Ted Cottrell barked out, ''Somebody is hurt,'' and John Abraham, the Jets' best defensive player and one of the leading pass rushers in the National Football League, was lying on the ground, grabbing his left knee.

title: Nassau Beach Park To Undergo Facelift
description: A SIGN that hangs outside the East Terrace at Nassau Beach Park, a summer clubhouse that once bustled with activity, says it all: ''Terrace Closed. No Services Provided.'' Beachgoers now have to walk around the boarded-up building and along cracked walks to get to the beach. But county officials have high hopes for Nassau Beach, and they intend to restore the dilapidated park in Lido Beach to the charm and popularity it once had.

title: Armstrong Manages to Fit New York Into Schedule
description: When Lance Armstrong won the three-week, 2,036-mile Tour de France last Sunday, his fourth straight victory in bicycle racing's greatest test, he reinforced his dominance in a sport with huge physical demands. If he could prevail against the world's best riders over endless mountain climbs, surely he could destroy less-gifted opposition today in BMC Software's New York City Cycling Classic.

title: Investing; Hospitals Strut in a Lurching Market
description: IN a stock market starved for good news, Triad Hospitals has had something to celebrate. Last week, the company announced another quarter of strong results, ahead of Wall Street's estimates. Its shares have gained 33 percent so far this year, compared with a decline of 25 percent for the broader market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUNES, ADEMAR PADRON
description: NUNES-Ademar Padron. On July 23, 2002 in Brazil. Father, husband, poet, dreamer, thinker, banker, inspired student of the human condition, playwright, actor, director, singer (and not only in the shower). Dema left us, but he will live forever in our hearts. He is survived by his wife Marta, and his daughter Georgia.

title: Title Wave
description: Any West Point cadet can explain the difference between a lieutenant colonel and a colonel. Rank, after all, is important stuff. But a freshman at Berkeley might not fare so well explaining the difference between a visiting professor and an adjunct. Despite its reputation for hierarchy, the Army has far fewer titles to classify soldiers (24, from private through general) than a typical research university has to classify teachers (40, from teaching fellow to professor emeritus, at Harvard).

title: BEST SELLERS: August 4, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Tentative Deal Is Reached That Would End 7-Week Bus Strike in Queens
description: The union representing 1,500 striking workers at three private bus lines in Queens reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday with the city and the bus companies that would end a seven-week walkout, union and company officials said.

description: I'LL BE SHORT

description: THE New York International Fringe Festival has always been home to oddball drama students, avant-garde performance artists and inspired exhibitionists, but this year audiences will be looking for something else: a Broadway hit.

description: You Cannot Be Serious

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DORSEN, RANDI BETH
description: DORSEN-Randi Beth. Randi, your physical presence is greatly missed, but you live in my heart and are constantly in my thoughts. You are always with us. We miss and love you. Happy birthday. Love, Mother, Marc and David

title: I.P.O. Plums For Titans Of Telecom
description: THE regulators investigating Wall Street firms' allocation of hot initial public offerings are likely to discover some juicy material. As they examine the records, they will find that many top executives of telecommunications companies, including Bernard J. Ebbers, founder of WorldCom, and Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications, received I.P.O. shares of upstart companies -- like Juniper Networks -- that had won, or later would win, contracts to sell equipment or services to the big telecom concerns.

title: July 28-Aug. 3: NATIONAL; I'M SORRY, BUT NOT WRONG
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat, insisted he had never taken improper gifts from David Chang, a businessman. The Senate Ethics Committee found otherwise and ''severely admonished'' Mr. Torricelli, saying he had broken Senate rules by accepting a projection television set and a compact-disc player, among other gifts. Tim Golden

description: SOME MEMORIES OF

title: The World; An Ugly Rumor Or an Ugly Truth?
description: THE day after the deadly Palestinian attack on Hebrew University in Jerusalem, The Guardian, the left-leaning British newspaper, published an editorial criticizing Israel for what the paper called ''random, vengeful acts of terror'' against Palestinian civilians during its reoccupation of the West Bank town of Jenin last spring. This after a United Nations report dismissed Palestinian claims that Israel had massacred civilians there.

title: For Different Tastes, Four New Furniture Stores
description: North State Road in Briarcliff Manor is becoming a Decorators' Row: four very different furniture stores have opened there in recent months. Mobelex Furniture Designs, at 515 North State Road, offers contemporary chairs, computer carts and stationery items imported from Spain and Italy and ideal for small spaces and home offices. Jonathan Rosen, its owner, described his merchandise as ''a cross between Ikea and Crate & Barrel.''

title: Haltingly, Layers Of Clothing Fall Away
description: IN a messy midtown rehearsal studio last month, Edie Falco and Stanley Tucci were at an impasse, and it involved skin. Ms. Falco, 39, is best known as the manicured mob wife Carmela in the HBO series ''The Sopranos.'' Mr. Tucci, 41, is an accomplished character actor seen currently in the gangster movie ''Road to Perdition.''

title: Endpaper; Cracking the Code
description: HIGH SCHOOL seniors preparing to apply to selective private colleges can be reasonably assured that their submissions will be read by at least two admissions officers at each institution. In most cases, those readers will reach consensus on whether to accept or reject an applicant. But for instances of sharp disagreement, the dean will most likely convene the entire admissions committee, with the vote of the majority deciding.

title: Some Breathe Easier With Plant's Last Gasp
description: For most New Yorkers, the debate over the city's decision to stop recycling glass and plastic on July 1 is abstract, turning on environmental and budget issues. But on Casanova Street in industrial Hunts Point, the consequences of the change are painfully concrete.

title: New Museum Explores Yellowstone Ecosystem
description: The relationship of humans to the natural environment is the subject of the new Draper Museum of Natural History, which opened June 4 in Cody, Wyo. The Draper, dedicated to exploring the greater Yellowstone ecosystem and surrounding area, is the fifth museum in the Buffalo Bill Historical Center complex, about 50 miles from Yellowstone National Park.

title: Italian Fare With an American Twist
description: ON my first visit to Luna, a warehouse-size trattoria in a small shopping mall on Main Street here, I felt as if I had walked in on a Tuscan tailgate party. On a sweltering summer evening, the place was jammed. A wood-stoked fire blazed in the open kitchen, joyous noise reverberated off the industrial ceiling and plates heaped with rustic Mediterranean fare passed by on the raised arms of waiters. A football game beamed from the television at the bar (yes, in July), and guys in shorts leaned back in their chairs, nursing their beers and beepers. Luna speaks passable Italian, but with an unmistakable American twang.

title: Open a Book, Then Dare to Open That 401(k) Envelope
description: IF you're contemplating retirement, or are already there, chances are you're steamed over the corporate chicanery that has helped to shrink the assets in your 401(k) plan or your stock portfolio.

title: Private Sector; Keeper of the Blue Suede Shoes
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, Elvis Presley left the building. Today, in a manner of speaking, Elvis is the building. Actually, many buildings.

title: Powder River Showdown
description: The Powder River Basin in Wyoming and Montana may appear unprepossessing to people whose idea of the West is the peaks of Grand Teton National Park. It is a windswept, grassy landscape, pure ranch country, with a subtle beauty all its own. The basin now finds itself at the epicenter of a larger national struggle between the country's energy needs and its environmental values, between a Bush administration that is determined to drill for oil and gas and the conservationists and ranchers who are equally determined to protect their vulnerable and increasingly threatened landscape.

title: July 28-Aug. 3: ECONOMY; ENRON YET AGAIN
description: Lawmakers probing the collapse of Enron charged this week that Merrill Lynch, one of the nation's largest brokerage firms, improperly helped to burnish Enron's finances. This included the purchase of a Nigerian barge operation from Enron that artificially increased Enron's profits by $12 million, and the ouster of a Merrill research analyst whose skepticism of Enron had cost Merrill investment-banking business.

title: How'm I Doin'? A survey for sizing up a college.
description: The National Survey of Student Engagement, an annual poll of freshmen and seniors, was initially trumpeted as an alternative to the carefully scrutinized U.S. News & World Report rankings, which are based on indicators like admissions test scores and alumni donations. Nessie, as the student survey is known, had a different story to tell: like, do you have to write a 20-page paper?

title: Violence in the Mideast
Rooted in Technique But Free and Airborne
description: Most professional dance academy graduation programs are worthy events, attended dutifully. But the American Ballet Theater Summer Intensive Final Performance 2002, presented on Friday afternoon at La Guardia High School was first-rate entertainment. All six of the commissioned ballets were accomplished and enjoyable. And they and the classics on the program were performed by a large group of promising young dancers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLASKEWICZ, GLORIA
description: BLASKEWICZ-Gloria. Died on July 30 at the age of 72. Former registered nurse. Beloved aunt of Tom, George, Ralph, Christine & Deborah.

title: Haven for Workers in Bronx Evolves for Their Retirement
description: The singalong was not his speed, so Harold Silvers passed the morning in the day care center. The week's events were listed on a poster tacked to the door: a dance class with M. Kramer, Stretching for Seniors with Nettie, Arts and Crafts with Iris Cordero -- not to mention a canasta game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, JOSEPH MALCOLM
description: MARCUS-Joseph Malcolm. Died peacefully at home in Golden Beach, FL, on August 1, 2002, at age 101. Predeceased by Augusta (nee Hittleman), his beloved wife for 71 years. Formerly from Mt. Vernon, NY, and Lido Beach, LI. Loving father of Helen, Bernard (Dolores), Irene (Bernard) Feuerstein and Carl. Also survived by eight grandchildren, 12 great grandchildren and sister Melva. Formerly owned Treemark Shoe Stores in NYC.

title: Government Asked to Act On Teenagers' Job Safety
description: With nearly four million teenagers at work across the nation this summer, many health safety experts say it is time for the government to revise its 60-year-old list of jobs barred to young people because they are too dangerous.

title: 3 Die in Gunfight at East Jerusalem Market
description: A midday gun battle was played out today in an always crowded market area of Arab East Jerusalem across the street from the Damascus Gate, one of the most picturesque parts of the crenellated limestone wall built by Suleiman the Magnificent around the Old City. By the time the battle was over, 3 people were dead and 14 were wounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCKIE, PATRICK J.
description: LUCKIE-Patrick J. Of Hackensack, NJ, formerly of Hillsdale, NJ, on Friday, August 2, 2002. Father of Patricia Cerbo, Anne Marie Coumbe, Rosemarie La Forge and the late Patrick J. Luckie, Jr. Brother of John Luckie and the late Vincent Luckie. Grandfather of Cassidy and Jamie La Forge and Bridget Coumbe. Former husband of Rosalyn Luckie. Funeral liturgy, Church of St. John the Baptist, Hillsdale, NJ, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Becker Funeral Home, Westwood, NJ.

title: Death Ends a Longstanding Partnership
description: The oldest and most prestigious regional pair championship in North America is the Goldman Pairs, played annually in Manhattan since 1929. Very few pairs have won this title twice, and in that select group are Gene Prosnitz, who died on Wednesday at 70, and Ira Ewen. They were successful in 1988 and 1991, and had one of the world's longest-lived partnerships. It began in 1958, when they were graduate students, and was still active this year when Prosnitz was already ill. In February they won a Grand National match by 54 imps against a team of stars who have won national and international titles.

title: A Time of Flux For City's Core Of Greek Life; Others Discover Astoria As Longtime Citizens Exit
description: For half a century, Astoria has been the nucleus of New York City's Greek life. It has been a neighborhood of cafes where dark-haired men sip strong coffee while talking late into the night. It is a place of quiet sidewalks lined with tenderly fussed-over brick houses, where a solitary widow in black can be glimpsed scurrying homeward as if she were on Rhodes.

title: Elliott Takes Advantage of Wallace's Mistake
description: Rusty Wallace, a driver who has had a lot of bad luck at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, permitted himself to think that he had a race won here. Bill Elliott had the only car faster than Wallace's today, but for seven laps Elliott remained plastered on Wallace's rear bumper, unable to sweep past him.

title: Brazil's Eye on the Amazon
description: Last month, Brazil inaugurated a high-tech radar system to keep watch on its two million square miles of Amazon jungle. The American-financed $1.4 billion Amazon Vigilance System will help catch drug smugglers and detect incursions by Colombia's guerrillas. But it was originally conceived and designed for environmental protection, and can still be a key tool in combating deforestation and illegal mining. The system, however, is only as good as Brazil's willingness to use the information it provides -- and there the record is worrisome.

description: Papa loves mambo.

title: China Fumes At Taipei Chief Over Vote Plan
description: The Chinese government angrily condemned today as ''a brazen provocation'' a speech on Saturday by President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan, who said that Taiwan and China were two separate countries and endorsed legislation to allow a referendum on Taiwanese independence.

title: A 2nd Hot Day Without Power For Thousands
description: More than 86,000 residents of central New Jersey sweltered through another scorching day without power yesterday as utility crews struggled around the clock to restore lines downed by lightning-studded thunderstorms that marched across the New York metropolitan area Friday night.

title: Medaglia d'Oro Takes Inside Track to a Romp
description: The paddock conference between the golden duo was brief: Jerry Bailey told the trainer Bobby Frankel that the track was lightning fast and that the inside path could make a colt three lengths faster. Frankel, no dummy, agreed. ''It's a jet stream out there,'' he said.

title: Bronfman Joins The Board Of Fandango
description: Edgar Bronfman Jr., who helped carry out the ouster of the chief executive of Vivendi Universal, Jean-Marie Messier, after watching the Bronfman family fortune in Vivendi stock plummet, has joined the board of the online movie ticket company Fandango.

title: Can't Stand The Heat? Wait a Day. Honest.
description: Just one more day, the weatherman says.

title: Hearing Voices of History and the Heart
description: ''Can you hear the voices from the edge of the world?'' Robin Holcomb sang as she began her set at Joe's Pub on Tuesday night. Ms. Holcomb hears them, as she hears voices from history, voices from the backwoods and voices from within. In a set drawn largely from her new album, ''The Big Time'' (Nonesuch), her songs were restless, mysterious reveries about love and memory, and they were both punctilious and strange.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the arrests of two brothers in the killing of a law student who vanished three years ago reversed the victim's names. She was Samiya Haqiqi, not Haqiqi Samiya.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: PENNSAUKEN: WOMAN DIES IN BOATING ACCIDENT A Pennsylvania woman speedboating with her family on the Delaware River near Philadelphia was killed last night when the 23-foot craft hit a buoy and she was hurled overboard, the police in Pennsauken, N.J., said. The boat, driven by her husband and carrying the couple's three young children, struck the woman at 7:30 p.m., but it was unclear if she was killed by the impact or drowned, said a police spokesman, Lt. Marco Anthony. Her husband brought her ashore at Pennsauken, north of Camden, where police and paramedics tried to revive her. The lieutenant said her death was being listed as an accident, pending further investigation by the New Jersey State police, and the names of the victim and her husband were not released. The husband was given blood tests for drugs and alcohol at Cooper Hospital-University Medical Center in Camden, the lieutenant said.   Robert D. McFadden (NYT)

title: Lifeguard, 18, Is Charged In Sex Abuse At Public Pool
description: Two teenage girls were sexually abused in a public pool in Brooklyn last week, the police said, and a lifeguard responsible for their safety was arrested on Saturday and charged in the attack.

title: Policing Wall Street
description: The White House and Congress have done an abrupt about-face about corporate malfeasance this summer, belatedly recognizing the need to crack down on financial chicanery in the executive suite. Whether the rush to reform is translated into a new era of stricter law enforcement now depends largely on whether the Securities and Exchange Commission can snap out of the coma it fell into during the first year of the Bush administration.

title: Smith Looks for Break in Clouds
description: The Bengals players were granted yesterday morning off from their training camp in Georgetown, Ky., which is only an hour or so by car from here. So, Akili Smith came home to handle some business and regroup. This young quarterback is carrying a barrel of burdens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAPP, JEANNE T.
description: CLAPP-Jeanne T. On August 3, at home in Bethesda, MD. Graduated Smith College 1938, where she was a member of the diving team and co-founder of the Smiffenpoofs. Married 59 years to Edwin J. Clapp. Survived by husband, sons Peter, John, and Nelson, granddaughters Rebecca, Mary, and Elizabeth, and brother Philip H. Thayer, Jr.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, introduced a unit to focus on multicultural advertising, marketing and diversity to be called the AAF Center on Multiculturalism. Two of the initial programs led by the center will be the Mosaic Awards and the Multicultural Resources Expo. Representatives Carolyn Cheeks Kilpatrick, Democrat of Michigan and Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, are honorary chairwoman and chairman of these events.

title: Market Place; Talk of a buyout at Martha Stewart Living appears to be unrealistic.
description: WITH the rest of the Dow crumpling last Friday, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia proved to be a bright spot: the stock rose 59 cents to close at $8.51, up 7 percent from the previous day's close.

title: Bernard Haldane, 91, an Author And Innovator in Job Counseling
description: Bernard Haldane, who founded a pioneering career counseling firm and wrote 14 books about changing jobs and looking for work, died on July 21 in Seattle. He was 91 and had lived in Seattle since 1977.

title: Upstate, When the Living Was Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: For Armstrong, Just Another Sunday Ride
description: When a bike racer like Lance Armstrong wins the sport's biggest challenge, the Tour de France, even once, let alone four straight years after surgery and intense chemotherapy for life-threatening cancer, the expectations become huge.

title: Credit Offerings During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, a four-week bill being auctioned tomorrow and 5-year and 10-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday, respectively.

title: Turkish Tremors
description: In 1999, an earthquake ripped through northwestern Turkey. 20,000 people died; thousands more lost homes, businesses, schools. But this disaster could just be the latest in a deadly cycle. By combining technology - and a bit of history - it might be possible to forecast the next big earthquake. And the news is not good. The next quake could strike the commercial and cultural center of modern Turkey.

title: MediaTalk; Words and Mascara In a Marketing Deal
description: Putting a new magazine into the hands of the consumer has become so difficult that publishers almost need to go door to door to get some attention. So it is not surprising that Latina magazine, a 230,000-circulation monthly magazine for bilingual Hispanic women, has joined with Avon Products to sell subscriptions. This fall, up to 80,000 Avon sales representatives catering to a Hispanic customers will begin selling subscriptions to Latina for $10.99 a year.

title: Affleck and Damon Find Real-Life Obstacles to Their Media Venture
description: There is a moment in the movie ''The Sum of All Fears,'' this summer's Tom Clancy spy thriller starring Ben Affleck, when Mr. Affleck's character, a nave agent, realizes that an unforeseen disaster has changed his world, altering his outlook and making him wary.

title: A Firebrand, Toned Down, Seeks to Take On Rangel
description: His hair is now flecked with gray and the fiery diatribes of his youth seem to have given way to slower, more measured remarks. And that is but the beginning of the changes that have come to Conrad Muhammad.

title: Amid Bioterrorism Concerns, Smallpox Scare Tests Hospital
description: A 200-bed community hospital in Brooklyn was temporarily closed yesterday after a man who exhibited symptoms similar to those of smallpox walked into its emergency room in midafternoon, the authorities said.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADIGAN, LAURENCE M.
description: MADIGAN-Laurence M. Age 77. Catholic church activist. Husband of Mary. Wake at The Abbey, 1076 Madison, Monday, 6-7 pm, and Tuesday, 3-7 pm. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola Wed., 10 am.

description: THE SEXIEST MAN ALIVE

title: Ex-Executive Says Dynegy Asked His Help To Cook Books
description: A former senior executive at the Dynegy Corporation says in a lawsuit that Dynegy fired him last year after he refused to go along with a plan to manipulate the company's profits and losses in the summer of 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAIMITZ, JAKOB
description: KLAIMITZ-Jakob. At the age of 89 on August 2, 2002. Beloved father of Heidi and Leni, father-in-law of Mitchell Berg and grandfather of Alexander and Madeline. Cherished brother of Abe of Miami. He was a man of integrity, intellect and kindness and we will miss him deeply.

title: Over at Grand Central, Questions, Questions
description: Much talk and little action characterize the enigmatic French play ''In the Solitude of Cotton Fields.''

title: BURST OF ATTACKS FROM PALESTINIANS CAUSES 14 DEATHS
description: A powerful bomb ripped apart an Israeli commuter bus in northern Galilee early Sunday morning, igniting a fireball that left 9 people dead and wounded 45, beginning a burst of widespread Palestinian violence that defied Israel's tough crackdown.

title: Editorial Observer; School Vouchers: A Small Tool for a Very Big Problem
description: The Supreme Court decision upholding the school voucher program in Cleveland has generated a burst of hyperbole among hard-core voucher advocates, the most ideological of whom view the ruling as the first step toward dismantling public education as we know it today. Hijacking the language of civil rights, many advocates are portraying the Cleveland case as the second coming of Brown v. Board of Education, suggesting that vouchers will somehow rescue millions of black and Latino children who are trapped in failing schools all across the United States.

title: Democrats, Hear Us
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Killed at Christian School in Pakistan
description: JHIKA GALI, Pakistan, Aug. 5  Four gunmen dressed in Western clothes shot their way into an isolated Christian missionary school complex here today, methodically gunned down six Pakistanis and tried to force their way into buildings where more than 100 Australian, European and American schoolchildren were cowering inside.

title: Patents; A tracking device that can be fitted in a child's backpack or a ball cap.
description: When Samantha Runion, Danielle van Dam and Elizabeth Short were snatched from their homes, parents everywhere shared the dread and sense of helplessness of the girls' families. How do you find a child who has simply vanished at the hands of a stranger?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Toddler's Death Ruled Homicide
description: The death of a 3-year-old boy who suffered a severe bacterial infection has been ruled a homicide, the authorities said yesterday. Ellen S. Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city's medical examiner, said, ''This child died of neglect, essentially.'' The boy, Alexander Louis-Jacques, died in June of sepsis, a bacterial infection of the blood that was caused by severe infections of his kidneys and lungs that ''were not treated in a timely basis,'' Ms. Borakove said. No criminal charges have been filed, the police said. A man who identified himself as the boy's father said, ''I didn't hear anything about the report, so I don't know what to say. It's not a good moment for me.'' Al Baker (NYT)

title: Compressed Data; Hey, Getcha Cellphone! At Stadiums, Dial a Hot Dog
description: Want a hot dog at the ballgame? Why wait for the hawker to come by when you can whip out your cellphone and call the concession stand for a direct delivery?

title: Loving a Sport, Despite Its Big Flaw

title: Battling Failing Health, in Her Own Words

The federal appeal, filed Friday, says the conviction of Mr. Lasaga, 52, was flawed because the images were created by computer, and were not pictures of actual children, and that making the videotape did not fall under federal jurisdiction. The appeal will not affect the state conviction for which Mr. Lasaga was sentenced to 20 years to be served concurrently with the federal sentence. (NYT)

The lieutenant said her death was being listed as an accident, pending further investigation by the New Jersey State police, and the names of the victim and her husband were not released. description: A Pennsylvania judge allowed a woman yesterday to end her pregnancy after a week's delay during which he had considered her ex-boyfriend's objections.

description: John McEnroe and Boris Becker, two of tennis's more colorful characters, did not cross paths often enough during their illustrious careers to establish a bona fide rivalry. Becker was 8-2 against McEnroe in head-to-head competition but they never met at the United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVOREN, MARY
description: DAVOREN-Mary. Of NYC, a guest at the Marian Convent, died Thursday afteroon at the Marian Convent, Scranton, following an illness. Born in NYC, she was the daughter of the late John M. and Hanna K. Higgins Davoren. Miss Davoren was a graduate of the College of Sixty, Fordham University, NY, and was employed as a personal administrator for the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. Miss Davoren was a member of St. Paul the Apostle Church in Manhattan, and a volunteer in the church's soup kitchen. She was also a member of the Ladies of Charity, Diocese of New York. Survivng are a sister, Sister Andre Davoren, I.H.M. Center, Scranton, PA, three nephews, and a sisterin-law. She was preceded in death by a brother John M. Davoren. Mass of Christian burial was held. Interment Tuesday, at 11 AM, Calvary Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Memorial contributions can be made to the I.H.M. Retirement Fund, C/O the I.H.M. Center, 2300 Adams Avenue, Scranton, PA. 18509.

title: Tone Precedes Content, And Heart Equals Brain
description: Kenneth Kvarnstrom's ''Fragile,'' an hourlong work presented by K. Kvarnstrom & Co. in its American debut at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Saturday night, is an intriguing piece. But its fascination lies less in the accomplished choreography than in the dancers' presence, the movement style and the ways in which both affected the audience at this summer festival in the Berkshires.

title: Justice Dept. Details Its Loss Of Weapons and Computers
description: The F.B.I. and other federal law enforcement agencies have lost hundreds of guns and other weapons in recent years, along with more than 400 laptop computers that, in some cases, may have contained classified national security information, according to an internal Justice Department report made public today.

title: Microsoft Promises More Disclosures
description: Microsoft will disclose more technical information than it ever has before about its Windows operating system to comply with the proposed antitrust settlement it reached last fall with the Justice Department, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THERON, JACOBUS J. (KNOWN AS ''JOHAN'')
description: THERON-Jacobus J. (known as ''Johan''), on August 3, after a long illness. He was 78. Born and educated in South Africa, Theron came to the United States in 1952 as a member of his country's diplomatic mission. He resigned in 1956 because of South Africa's racial policies and joined the United Nations Secretariat. He was a senior officer in the budget division for a number of years and was then appointed Chief Editor of the United Nations & Deputy to the Under Secretary General for the Department of Conference Services. In retirement he translated from Dutch into English, including the study ''Extremes'' by A.J. Dunning, and was a passionate gardener. He is survived by his companion, John Ferrone.

title: Illegal Immigrant Death Rate Rises Sharply in Barren Areas

The victims, young men ages 19 and 20, had made their way from Chiapas, in southernmost Mexico, before drowning in the canal's churning currents just 35 yards from United States land.

title: Taiwan's Market Falls as Ties With Beijing Worsen
description: Taiwan's stock market fell sharply today in response to deteriorating relations with China, but the dispute is unlikely to affect either side's economy or American companies and consumers unless it becomes much more serious, corporate executives and economists said here today.

description: Padsha Khan Zadran, a warlord as volatile as the region he rules over, is again making trouble for the new central government in Afghanistan -- and this time the government is hinting that it might hit back with force.

description: BASS-Philip E. On August 5, 2002, at the age of 84 of complications from a stroke. Resided in Boca Raton, Florida. Formerly of Forest Hills, New York. Adoring husband of the late Beatrice (Zarkower) for fifty years. Loving father and greatest supporter of Judith (Jack Levy) and Marcy (Scott Fisher). Devoted and proud grandfather of Jenna Bass Levy, and Jeffrey and Michael Fisher. Co-owner of City Typographic Service. A unique and unforgettable man. Storyteller, lover of fine food, gourmet cook, tennis player, Knicks fan. Typographer and salesman par excellence. Believed only in himself and never took no for an answer. Life will never be the same without him. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, New York City, on August 6, 2002, at 1:30 PM.

description: Winston Smith, the protagonist of George Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-Four,'' was a rewrite man. His job was to destroy documents that could undermine the government's pretense of infallibility, and replace them with altered versions.

description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., Aug. 5 (Bloomberg News)  Cephalon Inc. , a maker of neurological treatments, said today that it had a profit in the second quarter as it sold more medicines for narcolepsy, cancer pain and epilepsy.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Fuel-Cell Legislation
description: A state senator yesterday introduced a series of bills intended to promote cars using cleaner-burning fuel cells, whose only emissions are water vapor. The senator, Peter A. Inverso, Republican of Mercer, said the legislation calls for a business tax credit for the purchase of fuel-cell-powered cars, a fuel research center at Rutgers University and a fuel-research commission. It also calls for consideration of other fuel-cell-powered equipment, such as lawn mowers. Senator Inverso said automotive plants in New Jersey that are being closed or scaled back could be retooled to manufacture fuel-cell cars.

title: Surgeons Begin Delicate Work of Parting Joined Twins
description: After a year of desperation, two Guatemalan parents could only wait as a team of surgeons huddled today over their baby girls, delicately prying apart the bone, veins and brain tissue that has kept their heads fused.

description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, among the world's largest advertising agency concerns, said yesterday that it would postpone the release of its second-quarter earnings report by a week, sending the company's stock tumbling nearly 24 percent.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Investment In Cornell Center Increased
description: Dell Computer, Intel and Microsoft will add $60 million to their investment in a Cornell University center that will promote the companies' chips, software and hardware for supercomputers. Cornell's not-for-profit Cornell Theory Center, which already receives free products from the companies, will double the size of an existing Cornell supercomputer and add five staff members to help promote the companies' wares as it consults with business, government and academic clients, a Cornell spokeswoman, Margaret Corbit, said yesterday. The $60 million in added resources will be spread over four years. The companies say they gain research expertise and a partner close to New York-based customers. Cornell sells advice to its clients on how to use the companies' products to solve specific problems, Ms. Corbit said. Cornell will showcase its systems in the financial district of Manhattan. Cornell's 50-employee center, based in Ithaca, N.Y., provides computing resources for basic research at the university, including studies of materials, proteins and engineering problems, the center's director, Tom Coleman, said on a conference call.

title: To Become a Lawyer, He's Suing; Retiree, 80, Wages Long War Over Law School Rejection

title: For Cooper-Hewitt, a Defining Moment
description: When the news came out last month that a previously unknown Michelangelo drawing of a candelabrum had been discovered in a box at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, more than one reasonably aware museumgoer no doubt asked: ''Where is that place? And what is it?''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Citizens Communications Posts Wider Net Loss
description: The Citizens Communications Company, a seller of telephone and Internet services in 24 states, yesterday reported a wider second-quarter net loss on higher costs for moves like job cuts. The loss widened $41.6 million, or 15 cents a share, from $13.3 million, or 5 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter, the company said. Sales rose 31 percent, to $662.4 million from $505.7 million. Citizens is selling its water, electricity and natural-gas units to focus on the telecommunications business. In the latest quarter, the company said it had revamping and other costs of $18.3 million, compared with none a year earlier. The company pared 500 jobs, or 7 percent of its work force, in the first quarter and said in May it planned to trim more in the second quarter. Shares of Citizens, which is based in Stamford, Conn., fell 22 cents, to $6.04. They have declined 43 percent this year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Female ''Priests'' Excommunicated
description: The Vatican announced that it had excommunicated seven women who have been calling themselves priests since an ordination ceremony in late June that the Vatican branded illegitimate. After the ceremony, the Vatican ordered the women -- from Austria, Germany and the United States -- to renounce any claims to being ordained and confess error in their actions by July 22. The women did not obey. Pope John Paul II has repeatedly made clear his opposition to opening the priesthood to women. The ceremony in which the seven dissidents took part was conducted aboard a ship on the Danube by an Argentine who claims to be an archbishop but is also at odds with the Vatican. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Industrial Slowdown
description: British manufacturing had its worst decline in more than 22 years in June. The Office of National Statistics said the 5.3 percent decline may have been caused in part by factory closings during the lengthy celebrations in honor of the Golden Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth. But economists said the demand for British goods may have been reduced in a faltering global economy. The slowdown may increase the pressure on the Bank of England to keep interest rates at a 38-year low. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 6 - President Bush signed a bill this morning in Washington giving him the authority to negotiate trade deals with foreign countries without interference from Congress, then left less than 20 minutes later for a monthlong ``working vacation'' at his 1,600-acre ranch here.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: U.S. Appeals Ruling
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have appealed a judge's ruling that could limit what the government calls an important investigative tool against terrorism. In April, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin ruled that the government may not use a law that allows detention of material witnesses to hold people for grand jury investigations. The government had held a Jordanian student, Osama Awadallah, above, as a material witness and later indicted him on charges of lying before a grand jury. Judge Scheindlin ruled that Mr. Awadallah was detained illegally, and, therefore, his grand jury testimony must be suppressed and the charges dismissed. In a 139-page brief filed July 31, prosecutors said Judge Scheindlin's conclusions disregarded legislative history and Supreme Court precedent. Last month, another judge of the same court, Chief Judge Michael B. Mukasey, ruled that prosecutors may detain material witnesses for grand juries. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Did You Get the Check I Sent?
description: It's hard not to open an e-mail with a subject header like ''Come to dad's retirement party.'' But a warm feeling of anticipation can quickly turn to disgust when the text of the e-mail, sent by one ''Harrdog86,'' turns out to be about a dubious money-making scheme. ''Did you hear what happened,'' floating tantalizingly on an e-mail subject line, sounds like a friend offering up some good gossip. But then it turns out to be yet another cheesy commercial come-on.

title: Ending Secret Detentions
description: One of the most disturbing elements of the Bush administration's post-Sept.-11 policies has been its detention of hundreds of people whose identities have not been revealed. Judge Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court in Washington was right to declare last week that such secret arrests are ''odious to a democratic society,'' and to order the government to release the names of those it has detained since the terrorist attacks.
