title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Housing Cases Decided
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court decided two cases yesterday that bolstered its recent ruling that municipalities must provide housing for low- and moderate-income families. In one decision, the New Jersey high court said that Cherry Hill must require a developer to build such housing on the old Garden State Park racetrack property. The township, the court ruled, could not simply request the developer to pay $4.25 million into a municipal fund to develop housing in another town. The court ruled similarly in a case involving High Bridge. Last week, the court affirmed a 1983 ruling known as the Mount Laurel decision that directs the state's 566 municipalities to provide opportunities for such housing. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Shipments Of Handheld Computers Decline
description: Second-quarter worldwide shipments of handheld computers fell 3.5 percent from a year ago as a lack of new models from market leaders Palm Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company hampered sales, Gartner Dataquest said yesterday. Shipments declined to 2.71 million from 2.80 million a year ago, the market-research firm said. Total sales rose to $901.6 million from $888.5 million. Hewlett-Packard, which acquired Compaq Computer this year and sells more expensive models, overtook Palm as the market leader in sales of personal digital assistants. Palm retained the lead in number of units shipped. ''Palm and H.-P. did not ship in volume any new models during the quarter,'' a Gartner Dataquest analyst, Todd Kort, said. He blamed economic conditions and high prices for the drop in shipments of Hewlett-Packard's Jornada and iPAQ models. New models from Sony and Toshiba helped bolster global revenue 1.5 percent. Palm was the market leader in shipments, with a 30 percent share, followed by Hewlett-Packard with 16 percent and Sony with 10 percent. In sales, Hewlett-Packard edged Palm 24.4 percent to 24.1 percent. Sony had 9.7 percent share, Toshiba 4.9 percent and Handspring Inc. 4.5 percent.

title: Cigarette Tax, Highest in Nation, Cuts Sales by Half
description: The number of cigarettes sold in New York City has been cut almost in half since the city began charging the highest cigarette tax in the nation last month, driving the price of many cigarettes to $7.50 a pack, according to figures released yesterday.

It also found only a very slight correlation between cancer rates and exposure to other pollutants, like car exhaust and cigarette smoke.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Nuclear-Plant Petition
description: A citizens group said yesterday that it had gathered more than 2,500 signatures on petitions seeking the immediate closing of the Indian Point nuclear power plant for what critics call inadequate emergency plans in case of accident or terrorist attack. The petitions were presented to the Westchester County Board of Legislators, which is considering a bill to close Indian Point. The citizens group, the Westchester Citizen Awareness Network, said it gathered the signatures in June, mainly from people receiving potassium iodine pills for treatment in case of a radiation leak.

title: A Distracted China Issues Censure of Taiwan Chief's Remarks
description: Distracted by back-room maneuvering over leadership changes here, China has offered little more than a boilerplate response to aggressive statements on relations with Taiwan by its president, Chen Shui-bian, and has suggested that his own constituents may provide the strongest censure of his remarks.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: SHIPMENTS OF HANDHELD COMPUTERS DECLINE Second-quarter worldwide shipments of handheld computers fell 3.5 percent from a year ago as a lack of new models from market leaders Palm Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company hampered sales, Gartner Dataquest said yesterday. Shipments declined to 2.71 million from 2.80 million a year ago, the market-research firm said. Total sales rose to $901.6 million from $888.5 million. Hewlett-Packard, which acquired Compaq Computer this year and sells more expensive models, overtook Palm as the market leader in sales of personal digital assistants. Palm retained the lead in number of units shipped. "Palm and H.-P. did not ship in volume any new models during the quarter," a Gartner Dataquest analyst, Todd Kort, said. He blamed economic conditions and high prices for the drop in shipments of Hewlett-Packard's Jornada and iPAQ models. New models from Sony and Toshiba helped bolster global revenue 1.5 percent. Palm was the market leader in shipments, with a 30 percent share, followed by Hewlett-Packard with 16 percent and Sony with 10 percent. In sales, Hewlett-Packard edged Palm 24.4 percent to 24.1 percent. Sony had 9.7 percent share, Toshiba 4.9 percent and Handspring Inc. 4.5 percent.

title: POLYMEDICA'S CO-FOUNDER RETIRES AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The PolyMedica Corporation, the nation's biggest maker of diabetes test kits, said a co-founder, Steven Lee, had retired as chief executive. PolyMedica shares fell $5.30, to $24.54. Mr. Lee, 55, will continue as chairman through the end of 2002 and will help the board find a successor for the chief executive post, PolyMedica said. The company, based in Woburn, Mass., said Samuel Shanaman, 61, a director since November 2001, will be interim chief executive until a successor is named. The Securities and Exchange Commission in April ended an investigation of PolyMedica's accounting, financial reports, sales of securities and other matters. The company remains the subject of a separate investigation by the Justice Department into accusations that it overbilled Medicare.

description: A judge in Tallahassee ruled today that Florida's school voucher program is unconstitutional and barred students in public schools from using vouchers to attend private schools.

title: When It's Better to Do It Yourself
description: A study of the ''white coat effect'' -- the idea that patients' nervousness at seeing a doctor increases blood pressure readings -- found that the phenomenon was not only real, but was so significant that doctors were better off basing decisions on readings taken by nurses or by patients themselves.

title: Smoking: Hazardous to Your Cat
description: Cats whose owners smoke are up to three times as likely to develop lymphoma, a form of cancer, as cats living with nonsmokers, a new study has found.

title: The Port Authority's Role in the World Trade Center
description: The debate about rebuilding on the site of the World Trade Center has taken a new turn since the design options presented two weeks ago were greeted with disappointment. State and local officials said the plans were just a starting point. But the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- which built the World Trade Center, owns the site, and has a decisive voice in what happens -- has insisted that the redevelopment of the site generate revenues comparable to those produced by the World Trade Center. Now, proposals are emerging that would remove the Port Authority and its financial requirements from the process altogether -- by trading La Guardia and Kennedy airports, which are owned by the city, to the authority in exchange for the World Trade Center site -- with redevelopment reassigned, perhaps, to new city-state agency.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wal-Mart Unit Expands
description: The Asda Group, part of Wal-Mart Stores, said it planned to spend 114 million ($178 million) to open two stores, renovate eight, expand one and relocate another in London and on its outskirts over the next year. The chain opened a 17,500 square-foot store in Walthamstow, northeast of London, its 256th British outlet. The store will focus on food and take-out meals, Asda said. Asda, Britain's third-largest supermarket chain, is expanding and adding space for general merchandise like television sets and DVD players to keep up with competitors like Tesco, the largest chain in Britain.

title: G.M.'S SALARIED WORKERS TO GET MERIT RAISES OF 3.5%
description: The General Motors Corporation will award merit raises of about 3.5 percent on average to salaried workers this month after delaying the pay increases by two months to cut costs. The average raise is the same as last year and is for 53,000 employees in the United States and Canada, a spokesman, Tom Wickham, said. General Motors, the Ford Motor Company and DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler Group delayed merit raises and cut or eliminated 401(k) matching programs this year to save money as price wars eroded revenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Line Rejects Meeting Offer
description: P & O Princess Cruises rejected a request from the Carnival Corporation for a meeting to discuss antitrust issues relating to Carnival's hostile bid for P & O Princess. P & O Princess, which has agreed to merge with Royal Caribbean Cruises, said any meeting with Carnival would violate that agreement. Both deals are facing antitrust scrutiny from regulators in the United States, though the European Union recently approved the combination of Carnival and P & O Princess. The merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises did not require approval on a European level because the combination of the two businesses would not create a material presence there. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

Next season, jewelers will be catering to this hypothetical woman. A creature fond of contradictions -- the polished and the rough, the precious and the plain -- she has inspired much of the jewelry expected to brighten fall wardrobes.

The bomb ripped through a police barracks, wounding 45 people. The dead were identified as a policeman's daughter, 6, and a 57-year-old civilian.    (Reuters)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Avocent To Buy 2C Computing For $22.8 Million
description: The Avocent Corporation, which sells equipment for managing multiple computer networks, agreed to buy closely held 2C Computing Inc. for $22.8 million in cash to sell its products to the desktop-computer market. 2C's digital extension technology permits users to operate a computer keyboard, monitor and mouse in a location, separate from the computer, through fiber optic cable to save space, reduce heat near the workstation and improve security, Avocent said. 2C, which is based in Huntsville, Ala., began shipping its newest product in April. Avocent will create a digital desktop division to develop and sell 2C's products, the company said. Avocent said the transaction will help the company increase sales in the desktop-computer industry, which is larger than the server market it currently serves. The acquisition should be completed by Aug. 20, the company said.

They eventually began to make inconsequential contact, which did not stop them from serving as pawns in the latest masterpiece by Johnson, an imposing left-hander.

title: ROHM & HAAS TO BUY POWDER-COATINGS BUSINESS
description: The Rohm & Haas Company, the biggest North American maker of powder coatings for industrial markets, agreed to buy Ferro's European powder-coatings business for about $60 million. The purchase will increase Rohm & Haas's powder-coatings sales to about $300 million from $210 million in 2001, the company said. The purchase includes operations in Britain, Germany and Spain. The unit makes materials used on products including car wheels, home appliances and window frames. Rohm & Haas is based in Philadelphia.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: More Ballot Trouble
description: The state's Democratic Party filed a lawsuit seeking to change the wording of the Sept. 10 primary ballot for governor, which it says may be confusing. The ballot instructs voters to ''Vote for One Pair,'' meaning they should choose an entry for governor and lieutenant governor. Pointing out that none of their candidates for governor had yet chosen running mates, Democrats said the wording could lead some people to make two choices for governor, which would void their ballot. The party and state officials reached an agreement on absentee ballots, which are to be mailed this week. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: INDUSTRIAL SLOWDOWN British manufacturing had its worst decline in more than 22 years in June. The Office of National Statistics said the 5.3 percent decline may have been caused in part by factory closings during the lengthy celebrations in honor of the Golden Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth. But economists said the demand for British goods may have been reduced in a faltering global economy. The slowdown may increase the pressure on the Bank of England to keep interest rates at a 38-year low.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Lehman Takes Real Estate Stake

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SPRINT AND EBAY IN CALLING-CARD VENTURE The Sprint Corporation will sell prepaid calling cards on eBay, the two companies said yesterday. An increasingly popular payment method for long-distance calls, prepaid telephone cards represent one of the few growth areas in telecommunications. Sprint will offer 120-minute and 480-minute cards for 4.5 cents a domestic minute and a 25-pack of 480-minute cards for 4.2 cents a domestic minute, the company, which is based in Overland Park, Kan., said. Sprint began the promotion with the donation of a million prepaid domestic minutes that will be given to a camp for children with chronic or life-threatening illnesses. Late last year, the two companies announced that eBay would use Sprint technology to expand Ebay's Web hosting facilities. Shares in Sprint, which reported earnings last month that were slightly below Wall Street expectations, ended the day lower, falling 11 cents, to $6.39. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: Cablevision Systems said yesterday that it would retire shares that track the company's interests in a television group that includes Bravo and the Independent Film Channel.

title: South America's Troubled Economies
description: For a group that came into office pledging to make ties with Latin America a priority, the Bush administration has managed to convey the opposite impression in recent months, just as the region's economic plight has worsened. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill, who has contributed to the bruised relations, can help repair some of the damage this week as he travels through South America.

title: Roddick, 19, Breaks Top 10
description: For the first time in more than a decade, an American teenager cracked the top 10 on the ATP Tour when 19-year-old Andy Roddick settled in at No. 9 in the ranking released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, BERNHARD LYON KOHN, SR.
description: KOHN-Bernhard Lyon Kohn, Sr. of Bloomfield, CT and Naples, FL retired tobacco executive and philanthropist, died peacefully at home on Saturday, August 3. Born in Hartford on December 31, 1920, the son of the late Delphine Lyon Kohn and the late Solomon J. Kohn. He was a graduate of Cheshire Academy and attended Lafayette College. He served with the First Marine Division in the South Pacific. In 1944, he married the former Joan Joseloff of West Hartford. He joined his family's business, Kohn Brothers Tobacco Co. In 1953 he sold Kohn Brothers to Cullman Brothers Tobacco Co., which later bought General Cigar Co. and eventually became Culbro Corporation. He was the first non family director of the Cullman Brothers Tobacco Co., served as Executive Vice President of General Cigar Co. through 1973 and as a Board member until 1996. In 1973 Mr. Kohn became president of the Sycamore Properties and the Kohn - Joseloff Foundation. He was a member of the West Hartford Auxiliary Board of The Hartford National Bank, a member of the Board of The Westminster School, the Hartford Jewish Federation, and a Corporator of St. Francis Hospital. He was a member of the Hartford Golf Club, The Hartford Club, Audubon Country Club, and a former member of The Century Country Club. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Joan; his son, Bernhard Lyon Kohn Jr. and his wife, Carol; his daughter, Kathryn Rieger and her husband Charles; his four grandchildren, Ben and Elizabeth Kohn, Kimberly and Michael Masius. There will be a private burial. A memorial service will be held on Friday, August 9, 2002 at 12:00 Noon at Congregation Beth Israel, 701 Farmington Avenue, West Hartford followed by a reception at the Hartford Golf Club in West Hartford. There will be no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Center, 85 Retreat Avenue, Hartford 06106. For information the Weinstein Mortuary, Hartford, CT.

title: At Rutgers, Foes of Sports As a Priority Win a Round
description: A maverick alumni group has won another round in its effort to get Rutgers University to focus less on athletics and more on academics.

title: Madden's Night a 'Boom' and a Boon
description: In John Madden's first game as Al Michaels's new boothmate on ''Monday Night Football,'' controversy immediately erupted when Madden said ''boom'' for the first time on ABC's air.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Official Joins Princeton
description: Anthony E. Shorris, a top deputy to Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, is resigning to become a visiting professor at Princeton University. Mr. Shorris has served as the school system's chief operating officer since January 2001, troubleshooting and overseeing management and policy for Mr. Levy. At Princeton, he will be a public-affairs professor at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs for the 2002-03 school year. Another of Mr. Levy's deputies, Judith A. Rizzo, left in June to become the director of a new education institute in Chapel Hill, N.C. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Quecreek Journal; Caught in the Spotlight, Miners Quickly Adjust
description: Other idled coal miners are wondering when it will be pronounced safe to go back down. But Eric Brant is already working as a misplaced miner of sorts, absorbing a vivid sunburn in politely herding the increasing flow of tourists who approach the rescue pasture as if it were Lourdes.

title: Stocks Plummet on Renewed Fears of Recession
description: Stocks tumbled again yesterday as investors digested another report showing that the economy was slowing sharply, or even falling back into recession.

title: Hotel Lore From Female Travelers
description: A LOT of women think hotels have a lot to learn about female business travelers.

title: Scandal in Olympics Could Boost Ratings
description: In eight years, figure skating scandals have changed from the sports television equivalent of ''F Troop'' (the knee-whacking of Nancy Kerrigan by confederates of Tonya Harding) to ''Rocky and Bullwinkle'' (accusations that Russian gangsters fixed the pairs and ice dancing events at the Salt Lake Olympics).

title: Would-Be Math Teacher Ended Up Educating a Computer Revolution
description: Frances E. Allen had intended to be a math teacher, but she was introduced to computing and got sidetracked, 45 years ago.

title: Turnaround Is No Surprise to the Liberty
description: A month ago, the Liberty was a .500 team heading in the wrong direction.

title: ICAP WILL BUY BROKERTEC'S BOND BUSINESS
description: ICAP agreed to buy BrokerTec Global's bond business for as much as $240 million in stock, making it the largest electronic broker of government debt after Cantor Fitzgerald. The purchase is ICAP's third acquisition in nine months as it tries to raise its share of the $400 billion-a-day market in United States Treasury issues. The addition of BrokerTec's electronic trading system gives ICAP the same combination that helped make Cantor the biggest Treasury broker -- voice and electronic trading. ICAP, based in London, is the product of a merger in 1999 of Garban and Intercapital. BrokerTec, which started operating two years ago, is owned by 14 of Wall Street's largest bond-trading banks.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES TO SELL EUROPEAN LIGHTING BUSINESS
description: U.S. Industries, the maker of Jacuzzi hot tubs, agreed to sell its European lighting business to J. P. Morgan Chase for about 120 million euros ($118.4 million) to help it pay down debt. U.S. Industries will sell its SiTeco unit to JPMorgan Partners, the private equity arm of J. P. Morgan, the company said. The sale is expected to close by the end of the month. The unit, which makes household lighting systems, is based in Traunreut, Germany. U.S. Industries is based in Iselin, N.J.

title: How the States Are Run
description: To the Editor:

title: For All Sides, A Land Swap Offers Much To Consider
description: The really surprising thing about the Bloomberg administration's proposal to swap the city-owned land under two big airports for the World Trade Center site is that nobody, so far, seems to be against it.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Creates Chip For Medical Devices
description: Texas Instruments Inc., whose semiconductors run twothirds of the world's cellular telephones, built a processor that uses circuitry from the most-advanced phones to allow new uses in medical devices and cars. The chip, based on a design called OMAP that rivals Intel's XScale, is being evaluated by customers. Products using the processor will go on sale next year, Mark Tiernan, who heads the Texas Instruments project, said in an interview yesterday. Customers including Nokia of Finland, the world's biggest cellphone maker, use current OMAP products in phones that handle both voice and data. Texas Instruments wants to expand into emerging markets like telematics devices that send navigation services and entertainment to cars, and handheld devices that provide patient information to doctors.

title: NEW ISRAELI RULES ADOPTED IN WAKE OF MORE ATTACKS
description: After three Palestinian attacks on Sunday and early today killed 13 people, the Israeli government banned Palestinian travel through the northern West Bank, further tightening already stringent restrictions.

title: Chick Hearn, 85, the Voice Of the Los Angeles Lakers
description: Chick Hearn, the radio and television voice of the Los Angeles Lakers for 42 seasons, whose vivid broadcast phrases were credited with adding ''slam dunk'' and ''air ball'' to the lexicon of professional basketball, died last night at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: M.R.I. Reveals Partial Tear In Abraham's Left Knee
description: Good fortune graced the Jets last week, when a thumb injury on Vinny Testaverde's throwing hand kept him off the field for only two days. But John Abraham was not so lucky today when a magnetic resonance imaging exam revealed a partial tear of the medial collateral ligament in his left knee.

title: A Synthetic Day at the Beach, Synthesized Sound Included
description: On Saturday afternoon the courtyard at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, was filled with young people pretending to be at the beach. There were plenty of props -- the museum has filled the space with an installation called ''Playa Urbana/Urban Beach'' by William E. Massie, a maze of undulating walls and brightly colored wading pools. But at this beach party the loudest applause was reserved for the crudest toy: a roll of toilet paper, thrown back and forth over the crowd.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Indians Sue Over Voting
description: Members of the Lakota and Sioux tribes filed what their lawyers called the largest voting rights lawsuit ever. The lawsuit accuses South Dakota state and county officials of violating federal election laws more than 600 times in three decades. It says state officials have ignored a legal obligation to submit changes in election laws to the United States attorney general for approval. The state's secretary of state, Joyce Hazeltine, said the suit was unnecessary in light of a state submission to the attorney general last week. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: A Peril Of the Veil Of Botox
description: The woman fantasized about having a face-lift for years, but had an insurmountable fear of the knife. So when Botox was approved in April for cosmetic use by the Food and Drug Administration, she jumped at the opportunity.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: INTERNET PROFIT Netease.com , a Chinese Internet company that is listed on Nasdaq, had a profit of $4,600 for the second quarter. It is the first of the three such Chinese companies listed in the United States to report a profit. Netease.com, which lost $2.1 million in the quarter last year, said sales of pictures from the World Cup raised revenue. Craig Smith (NYT)

title: Immigration Cut Into Income In New York, Census Finds
description: The surprising drop in median income in New York City that has puzzled demographers studying the results of the 2000 census appears to be traceable in large part to immigration, according to new census data that show income declines concentrated heavily in neighborhoods in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens that have become magnets for new arrivals.

title: Buying Group For Hospitals Changes Ways
description: Under pressure from Congress, a private company that helps about a quarter of the nation's hospitals buy billions of dollars in drugs, medical devices and other supplies has agreed to sweeping changes in how it does business.

title: Meredith Baylis, 72, Dancer Who Taught at Joffrey School
description: Meredith Baylis, a prominent teacher at the Joffrey Ballet School in New York for 15 years and a former member of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, died on July 26 in Burbank, Calif. She was 72 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Anthem Reports Rise in Profit
description: Anthem Inc., which owns Blue Cross and Blue Shield health plans in nine states, reported today that its second-quarter profit increased 47 percent as it added customers and increased premiums.

title: Lie Back, New York, and Tell Him Why It Hurts
description: DR. LLOYD I. SEDERER, 57, discovered Sigmund Freud in medical school and, as much as he loved chemistry and anatomy, he was hooked. The old texts helped him as he was ''searching to understand my own confusion,'' and he began a career studying the vagaries and twists of the human mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTENFELD, MATHILDA
description: DISTENFELD-Mathilda. Loving wife of Joseph, devoted mother of Fred and Rita, adoring grandmother of Michael and Claire. She will always be remembered for her elegance, dignity and courage. Funeral services today, 2 PM at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, RENA
description: FRANKLIN-Rena. The Horace Mann Parents Association extends deepest sympathies to Ian, Alan, and the family of Rena Franklin.

title: Turkish Tremors
description: In 1999, an earthquake ripped through northwestern Turkey. 20,000 people died; thousands more lost homes, businesses, schools. But this disaster could just be the latest in a deadly cycle. By combining technology - and a bit of history - it might be possible to forecast the next big earthquake. And the news is not good. The next quake could strike the commercial and cultural center of modern Turkey.

title: Giants' Shockey Immediately Makes An Impression
description: Jeremy Shockey shrugged off the first tackler tonight as if he were shedding an overcoat. He turned upfield, and looked for someone to hit in the first steps of a play that will probably be remembered for years if the tight end is as good as the Giants believe he is, if he is as good as he thinks he can be.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Software Outlook
description: The Irish security software developer Baltimore Technologies will meet its earnings forecasts for the first half of the year when it reports figures in September, with total revenue of 21.5 million and 22.5 million ($33.6 million and $35.2 million), the company said. The chief executive, Bijan Khezri, said that job cuts and other measures had reduced capital requirements. The company had about 23 million ($36 million) in cash reserves on June 30. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: SHELL TO PAY $28 MILLION TOWARD GROUNDWATER CLEANUP
description: Royal Dutch/Shell agreed yesterday to pay $28 million to help clean up groundwater near Lake Tahoe that was contaminated by a gasoline additive, a lawyer for a utility district said. The settlement in San Francisco ends a 10-month trial in which a jury said oil companies maliciously failed to warn a local utility district of the dangers of methyl tertiary-butyl ether. The additive leaked from underground gasoline tanks near the lake on the California-Nevada border and the utility sued. A spokesman said that other cases would be reviewed individually.

title: West Nile Outbreak Is a Warning, Not a Crisis, Officials Say
description: The largest outbreak of illness from West Nile virus since it was first detected in this country in 1999 is the latest warning against lowering the guard against this and other mosquito-borne diseases, federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, ARNOLD
description: KIMMEL-Arnold. The AIPAC Family mourn the passing of Arnold Kimmel, beloved brother of dedicated Executive Committee Members, Helen and Martin Kimmel. Our heartfelt sympathy to all the family. Amy Friedkin, President Howard Kohr, Executive Director

title: Teeth and Millstones
description: Q. When wheat was ground with millstones, did grit end up in the flour and damage the teeth?

title: Letters
description: Depression's False Cost

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Third Death In Chicago Accident
description: One of the three Chicago women struck by a van in an incident that ended in the beating deaths of two men died. The woman, Shauna Lawrence, 26, had a lacerated liver and other internal injuries. Six of the seven people charged with first-degree murder in beating deaths have been ordered held without bond. Court proceedings for the seventh will begin on Wednesday. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUTRUX, ELIZABETH ''LYNNE'' (LOFTING)
description: MUTRUX - Elizabeth ''Lynne'' (Lofting), 88. Died on August 4, 2002 in Glastonbury, CT. Born in New York City, she was the daughter of Flora Small and Hugh Lofting, author of the Dr. Dolitte books. She grew up in Connecticut and lived most of her adult life in Wilton. She studied art history in Vienna and was active in the New York fashion world, both as a photographer for Glamour Magazine and as a designer for Lilly Dache. She designed clothes for celebrities such as Helen Hayes and Rosalind Russell. In 1959 she joined Miss Thomas School for Girls in Rowayton where she taught art history and later became assistant head-mistress. In the 1970s she taught art history at Fairfield University, later donating to the University an extensive slide collection of art and architecture compiled during decades of world travel with her husband. (The collection is now known as the Mutrux Visual Resource Collection). She is the author of a children's book, ''Squawky and Bawky'', as well as several short stories for children. She will be remembered for her sense of humor, her love of animals, her creativity and her fabulous cooking. She is predeceased by her husband, Robert Henri Mutrux, as well as a brother, Colin Lofting of Pennsylvania. She is survived by a half brother, Christopher Lofting, as well as four daughters: Jennifer Lander of Boston, Massachusetts; Michele Witt of London, England; Brien Chelminski of Bourron Marlotte, France; and Robin Worley of Glastonbury, CT, also seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Protectors of Animals, P.O. Box 24, South Glastonbury, CT 06073.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGE, ANNA
description: GEORGE - Anna. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Devoted mother of Daniel Jr. and Carole. Also survived by five grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Reposing at Daniel George & Son Funeral Home, 1852 Bath Avenue, Brooklyn until Wednesday 10AM. Funeral mass 10:30am, St. Finbar Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Islamic Charity Banned
description: German authorities banned an Islamic charity group, Al Aksa, which is suspected of aiding Hamas and supporting the families of Palestinian suicide bombers. Interior Minister Otto Schily said investigators had seized $296,000 from accounts of the organization in Aachen and Cologne. The chairman of Al Aksa, Mahmoud Amr, said it was just helping needy people. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Houston Player Bruises His Spinal Cord
description: Houston safety Leomont Evans bruised his spinal cord in a head-on collision during a Giants punt play tonight in the second quarter of the Giants' 34-17 preseason victory at Fawcett Stadium.

title: Museum of the Medical Macabre Edges Into the Mainstream
description: Over its 140 years, the National Museum of Health and Medicine has been a destination for amateur Civil War historians, medical researchers and tourists with a penchant for the macabre.

title: HSBC Raises Loan Reserves As 6-Month Profit Falls 7%
description: HSBC, the large banking company based in Britain, said today that its first-half earnings fell 7 percent as it set aside more money to cover bad debts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint And Ebay In Calling-Card Venture
description: The Sprint Corporation will sell prepaid calling cards on eBay, the two companies said yesterday. An increasingly popular payment method for long-distance telephone calls, prepaid telephone cards represent one of the few growth areas in telecommunications. Sprint will offer 120-minute and 480-minute cards for 4.5 cents a domestic minute and a 25-pack of 480-minute cards for 4.2 cents a domestic minute, the company, which is based in Overland Park, Kan., said. Sprint began the calling card promotion with the donation of a million prepaid domestic minutes that will be given to a camp for children with chronic or life-threatening illnesses. Late last year, the two companies announced that eBay would use Sprint technology to expand Ebay's Web hosting facilities. Shares in Sprint, which reported earnings last month that were slightly below Wall Street expectations, ended the day lower, falling 11 cents, to $6.39. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: G.M. Seeks Agency For Ethnic Account
description: General Motors will begin a review for its advertising aimed at Asian-American consumers, which had been handled by Innovasia in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, LEONORE (STARK)
description: FOX-Leonore (Stark) of Boston, MA and Palm Beach, FL on Saturday, August 3. Wife of the late Franklin H. Fox. Mother of Wendy & Allan Williams, Priscilla & Stuart Albrecht & Elizabeth and Patrick Gerschel. Grandmother of seven, great-grandmother of 5. Sister of Roslyn Simon, Harriet Lewis, and the late Edna Stark and Irving Stark. Remembrances may be made to the Franklin H. and Leonore Fox Scholarship Fund, Brandeis University, Waltham, MA. 02454.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, BABETTE (NEE SCHMIDT)
description: MAYER - Babette (nee Schmidt). Of Larchmont, NY, died peacefully at home surrounded by family on August 4, 2002 at the age of 78. Beloved wife of the late Richard L. Mayer. Devoted mother of Virginia (Mark), Richard (Caryl) and the late Kenneth Mayer. Proud grandmother of Heather, Nolan, Rachel, Evan, Louis and Samuel. Her love of history & adventurous spirit will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Hood College, 401 Rosemont Ave., Fredrick, MD 21701. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 8, at 1:30 PM at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY.

title: SHAW WILL BUY POWER PLANT IT IS BUILDING IN MISSISSIPPI
description: The Shaw Group, a construction company that has been building a 1,200 megawatt power plant in Mississippi, said yesterday it would buy the plant from its owner, NRG Energy, because NRG is unable to make a scheduled payment on the plant. Shaw will pay $43 million and forgive $75 million in debt to acquire the plant, according to NRG, a subsidiary of Xcel Energy of Minneapolis. Shaw's stock fell $5.70, or 26 percent, to $16.06 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shaw is based in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Deadly or Dull? Uproar Over a Microbe
description: Pfiesteria piscicida, the microbe with a fearsome reputation for killing fish and endangering human health, may not be a villain after all, some researchers say.

title: If You Can't Stand the Heat, Get Out of the Suit
description: It is a little-known fact of social science that, above a certain temperature, the will to be fashionable fails. Experts are divided about the point on the thermometer where this phenomenon sets in, but after a string of days with temperatures in the 90's, even New York's hard-core fashionable tossed over their Edmundo Castillos last week for flip-flops and switched into clothes that made them look as if they were planning to mow the lawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MICHAEL
description: MILLER-Michael. The Congregation of The Community Synagogue of Port Washington, NY, notes with sorrow the passing of its member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Rabbi Jeffrey K. Salkin Laurence Tarica, President

title: A Camera-Toting Odysseus Looks Into the Face of Pain
description: In person the Brazilian documentary photographer Sebastio Salgado is genial and unassuming. He keeps himself trim and his head shaved. He delivers rapid-fire accented English, as if he can hardly contain his immense energies.

title: Unit of Omnicom Gets AARP Account
description: AARP in Washington, the organization for Americans 50 and older, selected GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account, including television, print and radio advertising. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Heard the One About the Expos' Trades?
description: The conspiracy theorists and the paranoia platoon simply can't leave the Montreal Expos alone. According to them, the Expos haven't done anything legitimately this year. Next thing, they will allege that other teams have been throwing games so the Expos can make the playoffs and enhance the team's value for a sale to a group from Washington or Northern Virginia.

title: Effort to Curb Tax Havens Could Be Costly For Consultant
description: With Congress on the verge of barring federal contracts to companies that acquired an offshore address simply to cut their American taxes, the world's largest consulting firm is at risk of losing hundreds of millions in revenue unless it can persuade lawmakers that it is different from other companies that recently established official headquarters in Bermuda and other tax havens.

title: Accounts
description: ABC Sports College Football, New York, part of the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company, to Dcode, New York, to handle broadcast advertising, which had been at the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe. Spending was estimated at less than $1 million.

title: Pastor Tells Why Abducted Girls Went on TV
description: A pastor advising the families of the two teenage girls kidnapped and assaulted last week in California said they had agreed to give a national television interview yesterday morning to the NBC program ''Today'' out of a conviction that their story could help other young women facing a similar traumatic experience.

title: New Rochelle Man Pleads Not Guilty in Hatchet Slaying of 6-Year-Old Boy
description: Marquise Newman had fallen asleep at his baby sitter's home on Saturday night when Samuel Calloway came by to visit his relatives. Not long afterward, Mr. Calloway locked the baby sitter out, fatally struck the 6-year-old boy in the head with a hatchet and set the house on fire, police and city officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, JAMES MONROE
description: MARX-James Monroe. Beloved husband of Helen. Cherished father of Douglas and Bradley and devoted grandfather of William. Loved brother to Katherine and son of the late Dorothy and Solomon. Honorary Consul General of the Republic of Finland. James was a generous, caring man of stature, loyalty and integrity who will forever will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services will be held 11:30AM Wednesday, August 7th at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club, 283 Lexington Ave, N.Y., N.Y. 10016 and the AmericanScandinavian Foundation, 58 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10016.

title: Mideast Peace Obstacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Plants Hang On In Concrete Jungle
description: Despite miles of skyscrapers and pavement in New York City, nature has not lost its foothold, at least not yet.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Man Sentenced For Army Threats
description: A New Jersey man has been sentenced to more than 17 years in federal prison after being found guilty of weapons charges in connection with threats to blow up Fort Monmouth, an Army base that focuses on research and development of military communications. The man, Robert B. Merrill, was sentenced last Thursday in Martinsburg, W.Va., on charges of unlawfully purchasing and transporting a weapon from West Virginia to New Jersey. After a search of Mr. Merrill's Long Branch home, the authorities found pipe bombs, a pistol and a falsely obtained West Virginia driver's license. Prosecutors also linked Mr. Merrill to threatening faxes sent to Fort Monmouth by comparing the font from the faxed threats with the font of documents in Mr. Merrill's home. Mr. Merrill's attorney argued that his client did not send the faxes and that the seized items were components for fireworks. Mr. Merrill still faces trial on other charges including making terroristic threats. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Leslie Slote, 78, a Spokesman For Wagner and for Rockefeller
description: Leslie Slote, former press secretary to Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, died on Friday at the hospice at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Good Deal for Lower Manhattan
description: The Bloomberg administration has informally proposed a swap in which New York City would trade its ownership of the land beneath La Guardia and Kennedy airports to the Port Authority in exchange for the World Trade Center site. This is the most creative idea to arise from the Lower Manhattan redevelopment process so far. It deserves prompt and serious consideration.

title: Eye Spy
description: Most of us believe we are unique. We can prove who we say we are simply by flashing a passport of knowing a secret code. But passports and codes can be stolen, faked, bought and sold. One thing that cant be faked is your biological identity.

title: Bush Meets Rescued Miners, Saying They Represent Spirit of America
description: President Bush celebrated nine coal miners this morning as representatives of the ''spirit of America'' eight days after they were trapped 24 stories underground, thinking they would die.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIST, BEATRICE K.
description: GEIST-Beatrice K. Died peacefully on August 4, 2002, at age 93. Beloved by family, friends and co-workers.

title: Brutality Cloaked as Tradition
description: How could a tribal council in the Pakistani village of Meerwala Jatoi decree that a young woman be raped in revenge for a crime allegedly committed by her brother? They were certain they could get away with it, of course. And they would have, except that the local imam spoke out against it during Friday prayers; a journalist in the mosque that day reported the case; the story was picked up nationwide, then worldwide. Absent this circumstantial chain, the rape would have gone unremarked.

title: Credit Union Says A.T.M. Users Stole Millions After 9/11
description: Fifteen million dollars was looted from the Municipal Credit Union in New York City by its own members -- including city employees, health care professionals and education workers -- when a computer failure caused by the collapse of the World Trade Center allowed virtually unlimited access to money in automated teller machines, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Collins & Aikman Loss Sends Stock Falling
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation, a maker of automotive carpet, posted a second-quarter loss today and lowered its full-year outlook, setting off a 49 percent decline in its share price.

title: Gunmen Kill 6 at a Christian School in Pakistan
description: Four men shot their way into a boarding school for the children of Christian missionaries today, gunned down six Pakistanis and tried to force their way into buildings where more than 100 Australian, European and American children were cowering inside.

title: Desperations Crossings
description: Deaths are reaching record rates in the most remote outposts along the U.S.-Mexican border as migrants continue to cross dangerous terrain in the heat.

title: Natures Superheroes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: New Ways to See Science
description: The photographer Felice Frankel collaborates with scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to produce images that illuminate and explain their research.

title: The Conjoined Twins
description: After a procedure lasting nearly a day, doctors successfully separated the conjoined Guatemalan twins.

title: What the Tooth Fairy Forgot: Dentists for Rural America
description: Dr. Donald E. Nemer does not like to make people in pain wait.

title: A Multimedia Declaration
description: Scholastic, the children's book publisher and distributor, is donating a multimedia curriculum on the Declaration of Independence to 525 New York City middle and high schools this fall. The curriculum is part of the Declaration of Independence Road Trip, a national tour of an original copy of the Declaration of Independence. NORMAN LEAR, the television producer and founder of People for the American Way, developed the project. SHELLEY WHITE, editorial director for the project, said the curriculum aims to encourage students ''to play a role in their communities and the nation.'' Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Hewitt Wins, but Faces A Fine From the ATP
description: The same combative nature that pumps air into Lleyton Hewitt's lungs during a match has apparently left him miscast in the role of No. 1 player in the world.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column of Circuits on July 25 about creating the online diaries known as Weblogs misstated the address of a Weblog information site maintained by UserLand Software. It is weblogs.com, not weblogs.org.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPLAN, MARILYN
description: CAPLAN - Marilyn. We mourn the loss of our dear, courageous, brave, loving friend, Marilyn, who set an example of all that is wonderful & good. We extend our deepest sympathy to Ron and his family. We have lost a gem. The heavens have gained a new star. Rest in peace, dearest Marilyn. Beverly and Ed Robbins and family

title: How Do You Drink Tea That Costs $33 an Ounce? Ceremoniously
description: HanGawi, a Korean vegetarian restaurant at 12 East 32nd Street, has introduced a line of fine teas, including Korean wild green teas, under the brand name Franchia. A three-ounce tin from the prized first picking of the wild tea is $100; a tin from the second picking is $50.

title: Mirroring Official 9/11 Observances
description: From private memorials at hospitals and firehouses to public displays of remembrance in storefront windows, the city's businesses and religious and cultural institutions will mirror the official ceremonies on the anniversary of the attack on the World Trade Center. And, like the official commemoration, the tone of the day will be understated symbolism.

title: FINANCIAL SERVICES COMPANY TO BUY INTERLINQ SOFTWARE
description: The John H. Harland Company, a financial services and check printing business, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Interlinq Software Corporation for $34 million to increase its mortgage offerings. Harland, based in Atlanta, said its Harland Financial Solutions unit would pay $6.25 a share for Interlinq Software, based in Seattle. The price is more than triple Interlinq's closing price on Monday. Interlinq sells mortgage-servicing software.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Stock Buyback
description: With its stock near a 52-week low, EarthLink said yesterday that it had adopted a so-called poison-pill defense plan to discourage hostile takeover bids. The Internet service provider also plans to spend as much as $25 million to repurchase company shares. EarthLink shares rose 84 cents, to $5.56. It hit an intraday 52-week low of $4.40 on July 26. Last week, in a conference call with company executives, several analysts suggested that EarthLink would be wise to put some of its $556 million in cash into a repurchase program. Under the shareholder rights plan, EarthLink will issue a dividend of one right for each outstanding common share that was owned by the close of business Monday.

title: Conservatives' Factions Vie in Georgia Primary
description: A race between two Georgia Republicans, Representatives John Linder and Bob Barr, who vote alike on issues like abortion, guns and taxes, might not seem a test of a major ideological divide within the Republican Party.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Far-Right Group Banned
description: The government has outlawed Radical Unity, the rightist group of the French neo-Nazi who tried to assassinate President Jacques Chirac on July 14. A government spokesman said the four-year-old group, which has about 2,000 members, was disbanded under a 1936 law banning groups that promote violence, racial discrimination or racial hatred. Fabrice Robert, a Radical Unity leader, said the group would rename itself and start over. ''You can ban an organization,'' he said, ''but not men and their ideas.'' Alan Riding (NYT)

title: New Masters of Sauvignon Blanc
description: MUCH of the wine-drinking world is gripped by chardonnay mania, never happier than when a spoon stands up in the glass and the taste is akin to licking an oak plank.

title: A Development in Security Software
description: A group of Bell Labs computer researchers will describe new network security software on Wednesday intended to protect personal digital information and increase security when connecting to remote computers and Web sites.

title: Haute Food for the Pampered Set
description: SLAP-THUMP-SLAP-THUMP. He was crawling down the hall. His razor-sharp ears had picked up the distinctive metallic shaking of a skillet atop a burner. He knew we were in the kitchen, and he knew exactly what we were doing. We cook supper and sit down to eat as a family nearly every night, and our youngest member was determined not to be left out.

title: Snags on the Homeland Front
description: The bipartisan drive to create a new Homeland Security Department has sputtered and stalled. Very few members of the public are going to get exercised about the disagreements creating the roadblock, over protections for federal workers in the new agency and how much latitude the president should have in spending money without lawmakers' approval. With the partisan climate growing nastier as the election approaches, everyone needs to cool off and negotiate a compromise.

title: Avista Reports Earnings Drop of 44%
description: The Avista Corporation, the owner of utilities in the Northwest, said today that second-quarter earnings fell 44 percent as energy trading and marketing declined.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Charter Reports Narrower Net Loss
description: Charter Communications, the cable-television company, said yesterday that an accounting change would help narrow its second-quarter net loss. The change will eliminate the quarterly write-off of good will, the accounting term for the difference of the purchase price in an acquisition and the assessed value of the acquired company's assets. Writing off good will in a one-time charge can be perfectly acceptable, even required, under accounting rules. But such a charge could also enable a company improperly to avoid a long-term drag on its earnings. Charter Communications, of St. Louis, reported a loss of $202 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with a loss of $273.9 million, or $1.07 a share, a year earlier. The company also said revenue increased about 25 percent to $1.16 billion from $928.5 million. Shares of Charter Communications closed at $2.97, up 33 cents, or 12.5 percent; the stock has fallen 82 percent this year.

title: Major Indicators of Health Show Rise in New York City
description: The homicide rate plunged, infant mortality dropped and the spread of infectious diseases diminished in New York City and its suburbs in the 90's, a new study has found. But the rate of babies being born underweight, while dropping in the city, rose by 22 percent in the suburbs.

title: A Prime Kettle of Fish
description: IT is made from bony, spotty, spiny little fish, each one uglier than the last, creatures that cooks in many places disdain as trash. It was originally a product of peasant thriftiness, created by fishermen as a cheap way to feed themselves and their families with the fish their customers would not buy. But one man's trash is another man's treasure, and the fish have become so expensive that today a carefully fashioned bouillabaisse can cost $40 or more.

title: Keeping the Lights On
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Still No Power After Storm
description: About 3,000 customers in central New Jersey remained without electricity yesterday, four days after a severe storm. Most of those without power were in Monmouth County, and officials of Jersey Central Power and Light said they hoped to have electricity restored to all customers by today. At its worst, the Friday night storm cut power to about 200,000 people in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. By Monday, power was restored to all but about 45,000 customers in central New Jersey. By midafternoon yesterday, that number had been cut by three-quarters. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Zimbabwe's Man-Made Famine
description: In the last two years Zimbabwe has been transformed into a state that increasingly resembles Cambodia under Pol Pot. The government seems set on adding famine to the list of oppressions visited on the nation. In May, a law was passed decreeing that any commercial farmer who continued to farm 45 days after being given notice to stop would face imprisonment.

title: PICKENS GROUP ENDS ATTEMPT TO ACQUIRE PENN VIRGINIA
description: The corporate raider T. Boone Pickens has called off efforts to acquire the Penn Virginia Corporation, an oil and gas company, more than a month after the company rejected a buyout offer from investment partnerships he controls. The Pickens group, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said pursuing the acquisition would not be feasible. In late June, BP Capital Energy partnerships controlled by Mr. Pickens offered to acquire the Penn Virginia shares they did not already own for $329.6 million, or $40 a share. Penn Virginia, based in Radnor, Pa., rejected the offer on June 26. BP Capital, based in Dallas, holds a 7.6 percent stake in Penn Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSSAVAR, RAHMANI SHAHIN
description: MOSSAVAR - RAHMANI Shahin. Much beloved son, brother, brother-in-law and uncle and a cherished friend to so many passed away on August 3, 2002 at the age of 48 of heart failure while jogging in Central Park. Following a career in journalism, he earned a Ph.D. in international relations from the University of Pennsylvania and became a founding member and principal of UAS Asset Management in New York City. A gentle soul, he was fiercely devoted to his family, friends, work and sports and gave generously of himself to all. A celebration of his life will be held Friday, August 9, 2002 at the Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, at 1:30 PM followed by burial services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODALE, PETER PERKINS
description: GOODALE-Peter Perkins, painter and sculptor, died at home on August 1, at the age of 46. The cause was pancreatic cancer. Peter was educated at the Middlesex School in Concord, Mass and at Harvard University. He was represented by the Jack Tilton Gallery in New York and had also shown at the Nielsen Gallery in Boston. He is survived by his wife Susan, his sons Thomas and Joseph, his mother Irene, his brothers Nathaniel and Wing, and his siters Kate, Olivia, and Ava.

title: Darrell Porter, 50, the Catcher Who Was Series M.V.P. in '82
description: Darrell Porter, the All-Star catcher who overcame drug and alcohol addiction to become the most valuable player of the 1982 World Series with the St. Louis Cardinals, was found dead Monday at a park outside Kansas City, Mo. He was 50.

title: The Disabled, After 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: For Burnitz and Rusch, Change Does Not Help
description: Jeromy Burnitz was resting between a round of interviews today, his chin leaning on his forearms, which were draped across a railing in front of the Mets dugout. The temperatures at Miller Park were in the 70's and Burnitz would hear cheers when he took batting practice. The sticky, uncomfortable and discouraging weekend in New York was behind him.

title: A Beef Gem in the Rough
description: JUDY RODGERS has a penchant for forthright simplicity. So a whole fillet of beef, a costly cut that is usually garnished and sauced in grand style, seems an odd choice for her.

title: Is It Criticism, or Is It Really Hate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, ARTHUR L.
description: BLOCK-Arthur L. August 5, 2002. Retired Principal of P.S. 87 New York, member of the Board of Examiners of the NYC Board of Education, and longtime Assistant Professor (Adjunct) of English at Baruch College. Husband of Adrienne Fried Block, father of Elizabeth & Ruth (daughters of the late Frances Bildersee Block), stepfather of Linda and Barbara Fried, father-inlaw of Joseph Margolick and Joseph Bankman, and grandfather of Jonathan, Alexander, Samuel and Gabriel. He will be greatly missed. A Memorial Gathering will be held on August 23 from 5-7 PM at the Graduate Center/CUNY, 365 Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers send contributions to Catherine Block Memorial Fund, University of Rochester Gift Office, Rochester, New York 14627.

title: Giants' Shockey: Not Your Average Rookie
description: For a good, solid week of training camp, the Giants tried to maintain the premise that Jeremy Shockey was just another rookie. They really tried. Talk of great expectations diminished, and they attempted to enforce tradition and traditional talk. Sing your song, Rook. Know your place, Rook. The Rook has got a lot to learn.

title: U.S. Fails To Produce Documents On Prisoner
description: The Justice Department has spurned a federal judge's order to produce documents to back its contention that an American citizen captured in Afghanistan is an enemy combatant and therefore not entitled to constitutional protections.

title: Mining Company to Offer H.I.V. Drugs to Employees
description: After more than a year of mixed signals, the mining company Anglo American P.L.C., which is confronted with a crushing AIDS burden in Africa, said today that it would begin supplying life-prolonging drugs to all its employees who are H.I.V. positive.

title: Bush Signs Trade Bill, Restoring Broad Presidential Authority
description: President Bush signed a bill this morning in Washington giving him the authority to negotiate trade deals with foreign countries without interference from Congress, then left less than 20 minutes later for a monthlong ''working vacation'' at his 1,600-acre ranch here.

title: After Pakistan Raid, 3 Mysterious Suicides
description: Three men blew themselves up with grenades tonight when the police stopped them 25 miles from a Christian missionary school attacked by gunmen on Monday morning, the Pakistani police said tonight. But it was not known whether the men were linked to the attack, which killed six Pakistanis.

title: Chick Hearn, 85, the Voice Of the Los Angeles Lakers
description: Chick Hearn, the radio and television voice of the Los Angeles Lakers for 42 seasons, whose vivid broadcast phrases were credited with adding ''slam dunk'' and ''air ball'' to the lexicon of professional baskeball, died Monday night at Northridge Hospital Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Jets Want Defense to Have Offensive Mentality
description: It has been 21 years since the Jets' defense became famous for sacking quarterbacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARISH, JOAN LOWTHER
description: PARISH-Joan Lowther. On July 30, 2002, in North Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of Richard L. Parish, Jr., devoted mother of George Lowther IV and mother-inlaw of Kathleen Burns Lowther, loving stepmother of Linda D. Parish, Winifred Parish Goss, Richard L. Parish III, James Preston Parish, and the late Ann Meredith Parish. Also survived by ten grandchildren, and five greatgrandchildren. She was predeceased by her first husband George Lowther III, and a brother, Berndhardt Reijmers. Funeral services 2 P.M. Friday, August 9th at Saint Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, CT. Interment is private. The family will receive friends from 5-8 P.M. Thursday, August 8 at The Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33047.

title: Don't Do Anything, Just Stand There
description: A torrent of heartfelt words pours from the stage at Theater 3, where ''Only the End of the World'' by the French playwright Jean-Luc Lagarce is having its United States premiere through Aug. 24. Filtering them all for meaning may be more than most audience members can manage; grabbing onto the occasional trenchant phrase may have to suffice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, THELMA J.
description: ROSEN-Thelma J. Passed away on Monday, August 5, 2002. She survived her husband of sixty-three years, Leonard, by eight months. Thelma is survived by her daughter, Gail, & a daughter in California, 5 grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren, and her sister, Ruth Beitman, of Connecticut. Thelma's memory will be cherished by her entire family and all of her friends. Services are at 12 P.M. Thursday, August 8, at Garlick's Memorial Chapel in New Rochelle, 914-235-5341. In lieu of flowers or baskets, contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: A Homeless Problem Is Back: Overnight in a City Office
description: The only city office where homeless families can go to apply for shelter has become so crowded that three times as many people as city fire codes allow are waiting there each day, leading a judge to suggest that the city reopen homeless services offices that it closed a decade ago.

title: Helen Robinson, Island Matriarch, Dies at 91; Preserved Native Culture on Niihau in Hawaii
description: Helen Matthew Robinson, the matriarch of the family that in 1864 bought the Hawaiian island of Niihau and then so zealously guarded its privacy that it is the only one of the islands where Hawaiian is still spoken as an everyday language, died on July 31 at her home in Makaweli, on the island of Kauai. She was 91.

title: Israeli Court Upholds Blowing Up Houses
description: Saying Israel is in the middle of a war, the Supreme Court today gave the army approval to destroy without notice the homes of 43 families related to suicide bombers, while fearful and frustrated Israelis struggled to find a way to end a new wave of Palestinian attacks.

title: 'Harlem Song': An A Train Through History
description: Time is music in ''Harlem Song,'' George C. Wolfe's adrenaline-laced valentine to a neighborhood. The sounds of rag, jazz, swing and funk that filter through this 90-minute revue aren't just signposts for moments in Harlem's history; they're the elemental forces that keep pushing the years forward. And time of course never stands still in Mr. Wolfe's Harlem: it cakewalks, shimmies, jitterbugs and frugs.

title: People
description: * Richard Rapp was named president at the Lord Group, New York, a subsidiary of Spier New York. He succeeds Roger Chiocchi, who left, the agency said, to pursue other interests. Mr. Rapp also continues as president at Altamira, Westport, Conn., which handles business-to-business clients.

title: Grape Juice With a Secret
description: It is not surprising to find a suggestion of balsamic vinegar in Purely Organic's Mosto d'Uva grape juice. Like many good balsamic vinegars, the juice is made in Modena, Italy, and cooked to concentrate the flavor. Unlike balsamic vinegar, it is not fermented.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: WebMD Posts Narrower 2nd-Quarter Loss
description: The WebMD Corporation, which makes management software for medical practices, said its second-quarter loss narrowed to $22.2 million, as expenses for acquisitions declined. The loss of 7 cents a share narrowed from $821.8 billion, or $2.30, a year earlier, the company said. Shares of the company, which also runs health Web sites, rose 28 cents, to $4.76.

title: Lessons From Sri Lanka
description: It's often forgotten that while suicide bombing started in the Middle East, the people who perfected suicide as a weapon of war were the Tamil Tigers militia here in Sri Lanka, the island-state off the southern tip of India. In the last decade, Tamil suicide bombers, many of them women, killed some 1,500 people, including an Indian prime minister and a Sri Lankan president. And in a bizarre twist, the Tigers filmed many of their suicide bombings to show and motivate their troops.

title: National Briefing | Labor: Settlement With Workers
description: More than 80 workers have accepted a $675,000 settlement with Quadrtech, a California jewelry maker whose plan to move operations to Mexico was barred as illegal retaliation for a vote to unionize, the workers union, the Communications Workers of America, said. National Labor Relations Board lawyers said the decision by an agency judge was the first time an American company had been prevented from leaving the country to keep out a union. The settlement will award workers an average of $4,600 in back pay and $3,400 in severance payments for workers the company plans to lay off this month. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, RODERICK
description: KENNEDY-Roderick. Of Bronxville on August 4, 2002. Husband of Marjorie Lynn Kennedy, father of Roderick Jr., Robert S., Nancy Jane and William B. Service and interment in Rainelle, West Virginia.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: DOCUMENTS UNSEALED IN GATOR CASE When the Gator Corpoartion's chief executive, Jeff McFadden, played down the impact of a preliminary injunction barring it from displaying pop-up ads on the Web sites of 10 publishers, Mr. McFadden was contradicting beliefs held by other senior executives. On July 8, eight days before the preliminary injunction was issued, Dennis Jang, Gator's corporate controller, filed sealed papers in Federal District Court in the Eastern District of Virginia, saying a preliminary injunction was "highly likely to have a severe impact" on Gator's business. The comments, made public late last month when the court ordered the documents unsealed, echoed those filed with the court by Scott VanDeVelde, Gator's vice president of sales. Noting the company expected $3.7 million in monthly revenues for the rest of this year, Mr. VanDeVelde said he conservatively estimated that 65 percent of this revenue would be lost in the two months after a preliminary injunction. Mr. McFadden, in a statement on Monday, said he was "pleased by our clients' and prospective customers' response to the court case and their continued support." Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, THOMAS F.
description: HUGHES-Thomas F. On August 4, 2002 of Bayside, NY. Beloved son of the late Mary and Thomas Hughes. Loving brother of the late Elizabeth, Anne, William, Henry and Margaret. Survived by seven nieces and nephews and 19 great nieces and nephews. Reposing at Elmont Funeral Home, 1529 Hempstead Tpke, Elmont, NY on Wednesday 24:30 and 7-9:30 P.M. Mass at St. Kevin RC Church on Thursday 9:45 AM. Interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Donations may be sent to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Avenue, NYC, N.Y. 11001.

title: 2 Major Airlines Reduce Business Fares by 20%
description: American Airlines and Northwest Airlines have lowered their business fares by 20 percent on most domestic routes where they compete, with other airlines matching the discounts to various degrees. The fare sale signals an attempt by the airlines to lure back business travelers who have abandoned them during the economic downturn.

title: South Africa May Bar AIDS Drug in Childbirth
description: South Africa's drug safety board is considering reversing a decision that would have allowed the AIDS drug nevirapine to be used to prevent the transmission of H.I.V. from mothers to newborn babies, a move that is stirring outrage among advocates for AIDS patients.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Documents Unsealed In Gator Case
description: When the Gator Corpoartion's chief executive, Jeff McFadden, played down the impact of a preliminary injunction barring it from displaying pop-up ads on the Web sites of 10 publishers, Mr. McFadden was contradicting beliefs held by other senior executives. On July 8, eight days before the preliminary injunction was issued, Dennis Jang, Gator's corporate controller, filed sealed papers in Federal District Court in the Eastern District of Virginia, saying a preliminary injunction was ''highly likely to have a severe impact'' on Gator's business. The comments, made public late last month when the court ordered the documents unsealed, echoed those filed with the court by Scott VanDeVelde, Gator's vice president of sales. Noting the company expected $3.7 million in monthly revenues for the rest of this year, Mr. VanDeVelde said he conservatively estimated that 65 percent of this revenue would be lost in the two months after a preliminary injunction. Mr. McFadden, in a statement on Monday, said he was ''pleased by our clients' and prospective customers' response to the court case and their continued support.'' Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: CUNY's Mr. Fixit, Moving to York From Queens
description: There is probably no place at Queens College that Russell K. Hotzler likes more than the new Welcome Center. When he arrived as acting president two years ago, it was a plain, windowless room with blank walls, far from the campus's main entrance. Now it is near the entrance and resembles the elegant reception area of a small, well-heeled college, with decorative wall moldings, big windows and a burgundy-and-blue rug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUMWASSER, MEYER
description: STRUMWASSER-Meyer. On August 5, 2002. Devoted husband of the late Shirley. Loving father of Jerry and Louise & Ronald and Sharon. Dear brother of Ruth Spitalnick. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather of Marni Strumwasser, Brett Strumwasser, Steven and Sharon Block, Robert and Iris Block and Emma and Sage Block. A caring friend to Sylvia Rosenblum & a life long friend to all he knew. Services 1PM today, Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (corner Avenue M).

title: Ruling by U.S. Widens Study Of Stem Cells
description: When President Bush opened the door to human embryonic stem cell research a year ago this week, he imposed strict limits on federal financing to discourage the destruction of embryos. But in a little-noticed ruling, the administration later told federally financed researchers they could go beyond the president's strictures -- as long as they did so with private money.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Utility's Credit Warning Dropped
description: More than three months after taking over Enron's former British subsidiary Wessex Water, the Malaysian utility YTL Power was removed from Standard & Poor's list of companies facing a possible ratings downgrade. S. & P. said it had determined that YTL Power's 1.24 billion ($1.5 billion) takeover of Wessex did not appear to threaten its creditworthiness after all. YTL Power borrowed 410 million to finance the deal and subsequently assumed 600 million of Wessex debt, leading to concerns the Malaysian company might be overextended. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Hey, It's the Subway. Don't Cheer Me Up.
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving a Secret Agency From a Madman's Monsters
description: Forget Vin Diesel. For my money the multicultural action-movie star of the moment is Alexa Vega, the 13-year-old actress who plays the tough and scrappy Carmen Cortez, heroine of the ''Spy Kids'' movies, the second of which opens today nationwide.

title: On Camera, Jobless Argentines Vie for a Livelihood
description: Other countries may have television programs that lure entrants with offers of a million dollars, a new car or a luxury vacation in a tropical clime. But in this nation of broken finances and shattered dreams, contestants on a popular new game show compete for a prize that is increasingly rare and precious: a paying job.

title: Is It Criticism, or Is It Really Hate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, JAMES M.
description: MARX-James M. The American - Scandinavian Foundation is saddened by the death of Trustee, James M. Marx, and extends sincere condolences to his family. His energy and commitment will be greatly missed. Kristjan T. Ragnarsson, Chairman Edward P. Gallagher, President

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: COURT CLEARS PLUTONIUM SHIPMENT

title: Bush, With Senate Absent, Fills a Top Agriculture Post
description: President Bush appointed an Iowa farmer to a top position at the Agriculture Department today, despite objections from members of Congress who said the man had made racially insensitive comments and had circumvented federal limits on farm subsidies.

title: A Yogurt of Substance on Sullivan Street
description: The rich Greek yogurt sold at Yoghurt Place II, 71 Sullivan Street (Spring Street), is thick enough to spread on bread. Naturally, Vea Kessissoglou, the owner of Yoghurt Place II, the new Manhattan branch of Kesso Foods in East Elmhurst, Queens, has other ideas. She suggests, for example, pairing it with sour cherry preserves, Greek honey or nuts. You can taste these combinations before buying a cup with a topping, $2.50 to $3.50. The yogurt is $4.25 a pint ($3.25 for low-fat).

title: New York to Observe Sept. 11 With Dawn-to-Dusk Tributes
description: From the beginning of the morning commute until the sun lowers over the Hudson River, New York City will be transformed into a state of perpetual commemoration on Sept. 11, with readings, concerts and odes to the dead, tributes that in many cases grew out of ideas from people around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALAY, SANFORD L.
description: PALAY-Sanford L. Of Concord, MA. On August 5. Father of Victoria L. and Rebecca L. Palay. Brother of Donald. Grandfather of two. Donations may be made to: Sanford L. Palay Foundation, C/O Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio 44704.

title: Long Hike and Yetis, Too? Abominable; Bhutan Official Seeks New York Sponsors for a Himalayan Walk
description: In the faraway kingdom of Bhutan, lost in the mists and mountains between India and China, the royal ministers know a thing or two about New Yorkers. One thing they know is that New Yorkers, and Americans in general, are very good at walking, running or cycling for a cause, or supporting others who do.

title: A campaign to tell restaurant owners that smoke-free environments don't hurt business.
description: STANTON A. GLANTZ wants to tell restaurants and bars to go smoke-free -- but he is having trouble getting the word out.

title: St. Alban's Guide to Populism
description: Rule No. 1: So let's say, old sport, that one summer night in a hotel ballroom you gather your favorite fat cats and they all sit on their checkbooks.

title: Rome Journal; The Trevi Fountain Was His Gold Mine
description: For countless tourists over two and a half centuries, the Trevi Fountain has been a source of awe and a wellspring of hope, promising another visit to the Eternal City, and a wish fulfilled, to anyone who tosses coins into its gurgling waters.

title: Is It Criticism, or Is It Really Hate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, NATHAN, M.D.
description: POLLACK-Nathan, M.D. August 6, 2002. Loving husband of Raie (nee Cook) of Mount Laurel, NJ. Formerly of West Hempstead, New York and Cranbury, NJ. Devoted father of Louis, Pam, and Lisa (Ed Sharp). Brother of Irving. Grandfather of Jonathan, Elsa, Tildi and Ian. Dr. Pollack was the founder of Mid Island Hospital in Bethpage, NY. Funeral services and interment are private. Platt Memorial Chapels.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Banker Steps Down
description: Cazenove, the secretive investment bank that caters to the upper echelon of British society, said its deputy chairman, David Verey, would step down. Mr. Verey, 51, the former head of the London office of Lazard, joined Cazenove a year ago and was widely expected to succeed David Mayhew as chairman. ''We had different expectations for each other, and we have agreed to go our separate ways,'' Mr. Mayhew said in a statement. Mr. Verey's departure comes amid increasing uncertainty over the future of Cazenove, one of Britain's last closely held investment banks that counts members of the royal family among its clients. Cazenove has said it intended to sell shares to the public, but volatile stock markets have cast doubt on such a plan. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Immigrants' Language
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP., Portland, Ore., a maker of building materials, said it would transfer ownership of four plywood mills in Texas and Louisiana to Georgia-Pacific Corp., Atlanta, a producer of lumber and building materials, in exchange for a mill in Maine and additional considerations.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Fox Plans Institute For Emigrants
description: President Vicente Fox said he would create an organization for the 22 million Mexicans living in the United States. The group, to be called the Institute for Mexicans Abroad, will operate from the Foreign Ministry to coordinate emigrant programs by nine cabinet agencies, and seek input from a council of emigrant advisers. An emigrant will head the institute, as well. But appointments have yet to be announced. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Dingell Holds Off Challenger to Win Primary in Michigan
description: John D. Dingell, the nation's longest-serving congressman, fended off the most serious challenge he has had since 1964 in a Democratic primary that pitted two incumbents against each other in a new district drawn by Republicans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDUNER, HARRIET
