description: CARDUNER-Harriet. After a short illness on August 6 at the age of 84. Devoted wife of the late Leonard Carduner and cherished by her sons Andrew and Stuart, her brother Ralph, sister-in-law Ann & grandson Jason. A woman of remarkable strength and courage, she met the challenges of life with a dignity and spirit that were an inspiration to all of us who had the good fortune to know and love her. She revered people of character, integrity and loyalty and practiced and taught those virtues throughout her life. For many years she had been active in New York and Long Island charities and was, along with her husband, a founder of North Shore Hospital and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. At her request, services will be private.

title: All Spicy Thai Rhythm and Sculpture
description: THE best Thai restaurants in New York are largely no-nonsense affairs. Places like Sripraphai in Woodside, Queens, and Pam Real Thai in Clinton resemble diners more than anything else, offering their spicy, pungent, emphatically flavored foods, simultaneously searing and soothing, in generic utilitarian rooms with few amenities.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Incumbent Leads Money Race
description: New campaign finance reports show Gov. Bob Taft with an overwhelming fund-raising advantage over his Democratic challenger, Timothy F. Hagan. Mr. Taft, a Republican, has more than $8 million, while Mr. Hagan has $375,000. Mr. Hagan has said he needs $2.5 million to $3 million to run an effective campaign.

title: The Temperature Falls And a City's Spirit Soars
description: The boys from Lafayette Gardens went sledding yesterday. While it was a cool day, it was hardly cold enough for snow, so they used another medium: the concrete steps at the obelisk at Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Greens On Ballot
description: The Green Party will field a candidate in the governor's race with the certification by state election officials of David Bacon. Mr. Bacon's party affiliation had been questioned by Secretary of State Rebecca Vigil-Giron, when a voter registration certificate could not be found. Mr. Bacon submitted an affidavit showing he had been affiliated with the Green Party since 1998 and complained that the secretary of state, a Democrat, was trying to keep his party off the ballot. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: New Colombian President Gets Jump on Country's Problems
description: lvaro Uribe Vlez wants to get his government off to a fast start.

title: Bush and Cheney Signal U.S. Resolve to Act Over Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  The Bush administration emphasized today that it has made no decision on whether to go to war against Iraq, but left no doubt that it is still considering a military campaign to remove President Saddam Hussein.

title: Audrey Cohen Looking Out for Students
description: Audrey Cohen College, whose Manhattan campus enrollment has grown to 1,700 from 1,000 in the last three years, has added two posts for student services. MARCIA Y. CANTARELLA, a former assistant dean at Princeton University, was named vice president of student affairs. PAUL LERMAN, former dean of the college of business administration at Fairleigh Dickinson University, was appointed executive vice president and provost. Dr. Cantarella will oversee enrollment management, marketing, advertising and institutional research. Dr. Lerman will head all academic affairs in addition to student affairs, the registrar's office and facilities. Jennifer Medina

title: Mussina Pounded By Royals For 14 Hits
description: These are disturbing times for Mike Mussina, the intelligent and confident pitcher who has looked bewildered and uncertain for the Yankees for far too long. The potential explanations about why Mussina is sputtering sound like lame excuses as Mussina muddles through the fifth month of an unsatisfying season.

title: Trial Begins on Increasing Fees For Lawyers Assigned to the Poor
description: A group representing lawyers who are assigned to handle cases for the poor argued yesterday that low payments for those lawyers' services effectively denies adequate legal representation to the indigent.

title: Palestinians Tentatively Accept West Bank Terms
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, Aug. 7 - Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority tentatively accepted Israeli terms today for withdrawing from parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, as Israeli forces pressed their offensive, killing at least five Palestinians in the occupied territories.

title: TV Programs Honored As 'Family Friendly'
description: The fourth annual Family Television Awards were presented last week by a coalition of advertisers interested in stimulating the production of prime-time programs intended to appeal to multigenerational audiences.

title: REGIONAL MARKET: Midtown South; More Leases, but Not a Surge of Activity
description: It did not take Raymond Crane long last winter to lease space for his engineering and consulting company at 6 East 32nd Street, an unassuming 1915 structure in the Midtown South office market area.

title: Rape by Decree: A Pakistani Horror
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Spraying For the Bronx
description: Ground-based spraying to kill mosquitoes is scheduled for residential and nonresidential areas of the Bronx tomorrow, from 8:30 p.m. to 2 a.m. The residential area is bounded by Pelham Bay Park South to the north; the Hutchinson River Parkway to the west; Middletown Road, Jarvis Avenue, and Country Club Road to the south, and Eastchester Bay to the East. The nonresidential areas are Pelham Bay Park North and Pelham Bay Park South, including Rodmans Neck Firing Range.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Medic Hurt In Collision
description: A man was charged with driving while intoxicated early yesterday morning after he rammed his car into the back of an ambulance, injuring an emergency worker who was helping a patient inside, the authorities said. The medic, Wolfd Louissant, 25, was in fair condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center, his left leg broken in several places, they said. The man charged, Jose Lopez, 33, of Woodside, crashed into the ambulance shortly before 2:30 a.m..

title: A Museum Learns Leverage
description: Before they could build a new 33-story office tower on Congress Avenue here, developers had to clear the block of the two-story buildings that housed small businesses -- always a delicate task. But the Mexic-Arte Museum, an 18-year-old home for Mexican art and a homage to Hispanic culture, would not be moved or destroyed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Cosmetics Outlook Falls
description: A French cosmetics maker, Clarins, said that operating profit for the first half of this year would be down 40 percent compared with a year ago, and warned that it expected the situation to worsen in the next few months. The company, which owns the Thierry Mugler brand and Azzaro perfume, said the decrease was caused by slow sales in skin creams and fragrances and that it expected sales to slow further around the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. The company will release full first-half results on Sept. 12. As recently as May, Clarins was predicting a 15 percent growth in full-year operating profit. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Making Stones Speak, So That People Remember
description: AS she sips lemonade in the air-conditioned hush of the Franklin Street loft that has been her art studio and think-pad for 20 years, Elyn Zimmerman's brow is so furrowed with worry that it resembles, in the abstract, the striations in her favorite working materials: granite, marble and limestone. Should an artist established enough to be represented by the chic Gagosian Gallery, remunerated enough to employ two assistants, and fortunate enough to be married to a man she half-jokingly identifies as ''the king of the art world,'' be this somber?

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: TRENTON: MURDER CONVICT'S LAWYERS URGE NEW TRIAL

title: Wanted in Los Angeles: Any Qualified Police Chief
description: So who will it be this time, an Anglo? Another African-American? Maybe a Hispanic for the first time? But from where, inside the department or outside? From the city's urban core or the valley? For a real change, how about a woman?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Yahoo Takes Wireless Stake
description: The Internet company Yahoo agreed to buy 15 percent of Zed, a content provider for mobile phones and other wireless devices that is owned by the Sonera Corporation, a Finnish mobile phone company. Yahoo has the right to increase its stake to 100 percent in the next two years, or withdraw from the investment completely. The full financial terms were not disclosed. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Theft At Versace
description: The police released a photograph yesterday of a man they say stole almost 200 pieces of jewelry worth $3.7 million from a Versace store in Midtown, where he worked as security director. All of the jewelry has since been recovered, the authorities said. The man, William Robinson, 33, of Brooklyn, disappeared after July 10 when the 196 pieces of jewelry were discovered missing from the store, the police said. Investigators said Mr. Robinson sold two diamonds that day for $10,000. The rest of the jewelry was found on July 14 at Mr. Robinson's rented storage locker the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Nets Get Mutombo From 76ers For Van Horn and MacCulloch
description: Dikembe Mutombo's numbers are receding as he ages. Yet, at 36, there is still something about putting him in the middle of a basketball key that makes young, athletic players cringe. It is that fear that made the Nets acquire the 7-foot-2, 265-pound center from the Philadelphia 76ers yesterday.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Cello Suddenly Closes

title: A Wine That Cries Out for Food
description: IN certain circles, sauvignon blanc has replaced chardonnay as the standard cocktail party wine. On one hand, this is a good thing. A very good thing, in fact, because chardonnay is often such an awful choice. If it's flabby and banal, then its successor comes off as clean and sharp. But if you wish to a put a fine point to it (which I do), then sauvignon blanc is really only slightly better than chardonnay. Many sauvignon blancs, as we discovered when tasting some from South Africa and New Zealand, are tough to drink alone. They can be sharp to the point of piercing and as acidic as apple juice.

title: For Once, Children Don't Want Balloons
description: A lobbying campaign by a class of Long Island third graders has triumphed over the forces of the nation's balloon industry.

title: An American Darts Ahead
description: David Krummenacker, America's latest hope in the mile, never realized how fast he could be until he started running backward.

title: Reactor Sales Are Said to Endanger Accident Payments
description: The sale of about two dozen nuclear power reactors around the country to a small number of companies has undermined the system Congress devised to ensure compensation for people hurt by a severe nuclear accident, according to an analysis commissioned by two antinuclear groups in New York.

title: Federal Hall Will Be Site For Congress To Convene
description: On Sept. 6, for the first time since the early days of the Republic, there will be a joint meeting of Congress in New York.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: 'MOSTLY MOZART' SETTLEMENT

title: AQUILA TO QUIT WHOLESALE ENERGY TRADING AND CUT JOBS
description: Aquila, the utility owner that was the country's fourth-largest power trader, said yesterday that it would quit wholesale trading and eliminate most of a subsidiary's 500 jobs to ease a cash shortage and reduce risk. The company, which owns utilities in Missouri and Kansas and employed 7,377 people at the end of 2001, has already cut 550 jobs in wholesale energy trading and marketing since May. It will exit the business by the end of next month, Aquila said. Aquila will stop all speculative trading as energy prices fall and credit tightens in the wake of the Enron Corporation's demise.

title: Bush Hears Options Including Baghdad Strike
description: President Bush and his national security team were briefed Monday on options for military action against Iraq that included first striking Baghdad and key command posts in hopes of forcing a quick disintegration of the government, administration and Pentagon officials said today.

title: The Colombian Vortex
description: Few people have ever willingly undertaken a task more punishing than the one lvaro Uribe is to assume today when he is sworn in as president of Colombia. The country's currency is plummeting, and poverty and foreign debt are swelling. Cocaine eradication is failing. Violence has driven two million people from their homes.

title: U.S. to Test for Contaminants In 250 Downtown Apartments
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency announced plans yesterday to test for dioxins and toxic metals in a sampling of Lower Manhattan apartments whose interiors were coated with ash and dust from the World Trade Center's collapse.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Man Wins Ritual Feathers
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver, has upheld a lower court ruling that the government must return eagle feathers to a man who wants to use them in American Indian religious practices. The appeals court agreed that the seizure of the feathers violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. The plaintiff, Joseluis Saenz is a descendant of the Chiricahua Apaches, a tribe not recognized by the government. Prosecutors said the feathers could be used only by federally recognized tribes. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: G.M. Plans to List Its Stock Options as Expenses
description: General Motors said today that it would start counting its stock options as an expense at the beginning of next year, becoming the first automaker to announce such a plan and joining a small number of companies, like General Electric and Coca-Cola, to do so.

title: INSIDE
description: Veteran Lawmaker Prevails

title: Recipe: Marinara Sauce
description: Adapted from Roxanne's

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Sheep Meadow Shire

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, LAWRENCE STERN
description: MYERS - Lawrence Stern. Age 63. Died on August 5, 2002 in Cincinnati, OH. Beloved husband of Barbara Myers. Devoted brother of Ronnie Eldridge. Loving son-in-law of Saul and Sue Schiffman. Brother-in-law of Carole Smargon, Jimmy Breslin, and Larry & Marianna Klaiman. Loving uncle of Adam, Daniel, Emily, Lucy and Chiara. Memorial service is at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York, Thursday, August 8, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to the March of Dimes.

title: Nestl Strikes $2.6 Billion Deal to Buy Chef America
description: Nestl said today that it would buy Chef America, which makes top-selling Hot Pockets and Toaster Pizza snacks for the microwave, for $2.6 billion as it steps up an aggressive expansion into the United States.

title: Buddy System
description: ATS Tours has cut more than $1,000 on companion prices for trips to Australia and New Zealand. Each itinerary features round-trip air fare from Los Angeles, first-class accommodations, ground transportation, 22 meals and some sightseeing. The New Zealand Scenic Explorer, with 12 nights' accommodations, includes the Waitomo Caves, Mount Cook National Park, Fjordland National Park and other natural attractions. Prices start at $3,228 for one person and $2,145 for the companion. Departures through Dec. 5. The Sydney, Reef and Islands trip, with 13 nights' accommodations, stops at islands along the Great Barrier Reef, the rain forests in Daintree National Park and Surfers Paradise on the Gold Coast. Rates start at $3,919 for the first person, $2,651 for the companion. Departures through Nov. 15. Some fees are extra; (800) 423-2880 or www.atstours.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Adidas Promotes Executive
description: Adidas-Salomon, one of the world's leading sporting goods makers, added the head of its North American business to the company's executive board, giving its second-largest region a direct voice in corporate strategy. The executive, Ross McMullin, 45, will join the board on Sept. 1. Mr. McMullin joined the company on July 1, 2000, as president of Adidas America, the company's North American subsidiary, based in Portland, Ore. He will remain in charge of all Adidas and Salomon operations in North America, which generates 30 percent of the company's sales. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: ABC Reverses TV Pattern And Schedules Cable Rerun
description: ABC announced yesterday that starting next week, it would begin broadcasting a rerun of the USA Network show, ''Monk,'' four days after the episode first appeared on USA. The deal reverses the usual order of television programming, where shows play first on a network and then on cable.

title: Mets Win One in August As Astacio Pitches Nine
description: Good things have rarely been predictable for the Mets this season, but one thing has been a given: Combine Pedro Astacio with the Brewers and even the Mets cannot lose.

title: Vacancy Rate Aside, a Tower Rises in Austin
description: Tim Hendricks, a Dallas native who fell in love with Austin after a brief job at the State Legislature and a series of real estate courses at the University of Texas, is pressing every connection he has made in half a lifetime of dinners and weekends.

title: Experts Consider How to Stop a Variant of Mad Cow Disease
description: Wildlife experts from the United States and Canada are meeting here to discuss strategies for containing the spread of chronic wasting disease, the variant of mad cow disease that kills deer and elk.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: MALAYSIA: UTILITY'S CREDIT WARNING DROPPED More than three months after taking over Enron's former British subsidiary Wessex Water, the Malaysian utility YTL Power was removed from Standard & Poor's list of companies facing a possible ratings downgrade. S. & P. said it had determined that YTL Power's 1.24 billion ($1.5 billion) takeover of Wessex did not appear to threaten its creditworthiness after all. YTL Power borrowed 410 million to finance the deal and subsequently assumed 600 million of Wessex debt, leading to concerns the Malaysian company might be overextended. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Retail Sales
description: Sales to consumers fell 7.7 percent in June in Hong Kong, led by a decline of 18.8 percent in sales of jewelry, watches, clocks and luxury gifts. Because prices are actually falling in Hong Kong, the overall drop adjusted for deflation was 6.9 percent. The government said the World Cup might have distracted some consumers from shopping. But Hong Kong is also having record unemployment, 7.8 percent and rising, while bankruptcies have quadrupled in the last year as the former British colony struggles with low-cost competition from cities on the Chinese mainland. For the first half of 2002, retail sales were down 4.7 percent, or 3.1 percent when adjusted for deflation. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: CITY'S FIRE DEPT. FACING AN EXODUS OF ITS SUPERVISORS
description: Scores of New York City's Fire Department supervisors, including some of its most senior surviving commanders, have retired since Sept. 11, and hundreds more have notified their union that they expect to leave in the next year. At the same time, the department's front-line firefighters are retiring at more than double the usual rate, according to fire officials.

title: AstraZeneca Reports Delay On a New Drug
description: AstraZeneca said yesterday that Crestor, its cholesterol-lowering drug, was unlikely to be approved in the United States until late next year because it must provide new data to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, BERNARD
description: POLLACK - Bernard. Our kind, caring, always-interested, ever-young uncle Bernie. We send our love to our dearest aunt Mary Jane and all of the family. David, Judith & Daniel Rivkin, & Marilyn, George & Jennifer

title: VeriSign's Marketing Is Subject of F.T.C. Investigation
description: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the marketing practices of VeriSign Inc., which registers Internet addresses, the company said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charter Reform
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Charter Revision Commission met for a second time yesterday and released a preliminary report on banning party primaries. It noted that supporters believed such a move would open the political process to more people and free candidates from having to tailor their positions to appeal to the party loyalists. Opponents fear that it could depress voter turnout and confuse voters who would no longer have a party label to help them judge candidates. The report ended with language on how the Charter could be amended to shift to nonpartisan elections. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Plenty to Say On the State Of Baseball
description: FAY VINCENT, the former baseball commissioner, was speaking about six months ago with Bud Selig, the current commissioner, about baseball's 1994 labor fight -- when players were fighting to become simply filthy rich, instead of obscenely so, as they are now. Vincent said he had asked Selig a simple question: What did he, and in effect, what did the owners get out of those ugly, bitter days?

title: Attire Purely Optional at Dress Rehearsal
description: This was the last day of practice for the USA Gymnastics championships. It was closed to the public, which was fine, because today some of the world's most polished athletes looked more like refugees from Somersaulting Karaoke Night.

title: Tasting Report: Northern Grape, Southern Hemisphere
description: Selaks Marlborough, N.Z. $13

title: Giants' Goal Is to Control the Point of Attack
description: While Michael Strahan was trekking toward the sack record last season, his peers along the line were often hobbled, hampered and flailing. Strahan took some prickly ribbing from the group.

title: Footlights
description: Meeting Mahler

title: A Boy's Essence Uploaded And Adrift in Cyberspace
description: MIND CATCHER

title: Editorial Observer; Learning to Make Popular Music From the World Trade Center Attack
description: Last week I turned on CMT -- Country Music Television -- just in time to see Toby Keith perform the controversial hit single from his new album, ''Unleashed.'' It took some talking before he was ready to play. In the grand tradition of country music, he explained that he was a simple man and that this was a simple song and that he didn't much care what the media made of it. The song, ''Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue,'' is both a paean to America's military men and women, including Mr. Keith's father, and a promise to kick the rear end of any enemy because ''It's the American way.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNEFSKY, PHYLLIS
description: DUNEFSKY - Phyllis. The staff of the Anti-Defamation League mourns the untimely passing of our colleague, Phyllis Dunefsky, Assistant Director, New York Campaign. Phyllis's professional skills and efforts to promote ADL's agenda were exceptional. We will miss her personal warmth. We extend our condolences to her brother, Jerry, sister-in-law, Joyce, nephews, Brian, Adam and Eric, and the entire family. Abraham H. Foxman, National Director Joel J. Levy, Director, New York Regional Office

title: Microsoft Faces Old Foe In New Role: Chancellor
description: In March 1998, with the Justice Department threatening the biggest antitrust suit of the century against Microsoft, the company's chairman, Bill Gates, made a visit to a New York City middle school. Accompanied by a gaggle of reporters and photographers to Mott Hall School in Washington Heights, Mr. Gates used the opportunity to burnish his battered image while drawing attention to a laptop-computer leasing program that Microsoft helped finance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLEY, MILDRED (NEE BROWN)
description: POLLEY - Mildred (nee Brown). 100 years young. Born in Brooklyn, New York, April 4, 1902. Died August 5, 2002. Devoted wife to the late Henry. Loving mother to Ruth Gundell & David Polley. Mother-in-law to Virginia and the late Peter. Proud grandmother to Andy and Carolyn, Jim and Ed, Jane, Douglas and Stacy, Diana, and Frank. Great-grandmother to Amanda and Ethan. She took great joy in nurturing and sustaining these relationships throughout her entire life. She will be dearly missed by us all. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hebrew Hospital Home in Valhalla, New York.

title: Pass the Vegetables, Please. Now!
description: This is the season when fresh vegetables both decide and dominate the menu. There is no need to call a halt to the harvest theme at dessert: you can serve realistic miniature garlic, onions, zucchini and carrots, all made of marzipan, or cut a slit in them and use them as place-card holders. The marzipan vegetables are made by Kalev, a confectionery established in 1806 in Estonia. They can now be found in Manhattan and Brooklyn at Garden of Eden stores for $17.99 a pound, or 15 to 17 veggie pieces.

title: Like A Cool Wind Blowing From Fuji
description: JUST about everyone over 30 grew up eating cold noodles in the form of macaroni salad. Then the pasta police declared cold pasta beneath people of good taste, and from then on cold pasta dared show its face only at bad salad bars. Of course, closet eaters of leftover pasta (I'm one) are probably still in the majority, but that would be difficult to prove.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing the steepest declines for the main stock gauges during bear markets misstated the most recent performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. It reached its low on July 23, not this Monday. And the low followed the most recent peak by 821 calendar days, not 834. At its low, the index was 47.8 percent below its peak, not 45.4 percent, making the decline the sixth worst among the major indexes, not the seventh.

title: Baruch Business School Gets a Windfall
description: BERNARD L. SCHWARTZ, chairman and chief executive of Loral Space and Communications, has pledged $5 million to Baruch College for recruiting and retaining faculty at its Zicklin School of Business. In 1996, Mr. Schwartz, a graduate of City College's downtown campus (now Baruch), gave Baruch $3 million for a communication institute to help students improve their writing and speaking. JOHN A. ELLIOTT, the business school dean, said the new gift was particularly useful now since the school is hiring 40 faculty members over the next two years. NED REGAN, Baruch's president, said that a shortage of Ph.D. candidates in business had restricted the pool for faculty positions. Karen W. Arenson

title: Harlem Has the Hits, but Is Beaten by Walks
description: Morris McWilliams didn't really mean it when he entered a postgame news conference tonight and said softly, ''There's no crying in baseball.''

title: Benefactor's Chair Filled at CUNY
description: When MINA S. REES died five years ago at the age of 95, she left $1.7 million to the City University of New York Graduate Center to create a chair in mathematics and pay for a fellowship. A mathematician, she was the university's first dean of graduate studies. She is shown above during her tenure as the first president of the CUNY Graduate School and University Center, where she served until her retirement in 1972. This week, the center celebrated her 100th birthday and announced that VICTOR A. KOLYVAGIN, a mathematics professor at Johns Hopkins University, would fill the chair. Dr. Kolyvagin received his Ph.D. from Moscow State University in 1981 and was awarded the U.S.S.R. Academy of Science's Chebyshev Prize in 1990. He will be a CUNY distinguished professor. Karen W. Arenson

title: Is It Criticism, or Is It Really Hate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Stanley Giving a Pep Talk To Stock Investors
description: The chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley, Philip J. Purcell, is taking his shot at restoring investor confidence in a videotaped discussion to be broadcast today to 100 brokerage offices.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column last Wednesday, about lawsuits planned against a number of food companies in connection with acrylamide, a potential human carcinogen, referred imprecisely at one point to the American Council on Science and Health, a nonprofit group that said it intended to sue. While the council is indeed financed in part by food companies, as the column noted, it also receives funds from other companies, private foundations, trade associations and individuals. It is not part of the industry.

title: Copies of a Vatican Masterpiece, Made in the U.S.A.
description: From wax models subjected to molten hot bronze, experienced artisans work with cutting torches, electric grinders and chemicals to finish one of the most cherished art pieces of all time, the bust of the Madonna from Michelangelo's ''Piet.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Trade for Van Exel Not Easy for Knicks
description: Unable to land Andre Miller or Baron Davis, the Knicks are turning their attention to the Dallas Mavericks' playmaker, Nick Van Exel. But even though Van Exel is available, some familiar obstacles could hinder the Knicks' ability to bring him to New York.

title: TV Programs Honored as `Family Friendly'
description: The fourth annual Family Television Awards were presented last week by a coalition of advertisers interested in stimulating the production of prime-time programs intended to appeal to multigenerational audiences.

title: 9 Hindus Die In Attack On Pilgrims In Kashmir
description: Nine Hindu pilgrims were killed and 29 wounded today in an attack on an annual religious pilgrimage to a cave that holds a naturally forming, phallic-shaped ice stalagmite regarded as the symbol of the Hindu god Lord Shiva.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Publisher Fined For American Book
description: A Turkish publisher, Abdullah Keskin, has been convicted on charges of promoting separatist propaganda for publishing a Turkish-language edition of ''After Such Knowledge, What Forgiveness? My Encounters in Kurdistan,'' by Jonathan C. Randal, a former Middle East correspondent for The Washington Post. A State Security Court in Istanbul sentenced Mr. Keskin last week to a six-month prison term, but then commuted it to a fine of the equivalent of around $500. Mr. Keskin's lawyer said he would appeal the verdict. Alan Riding (NYT)

title: Knoblauch Returns To Familiar Territory
description: Dozens of Yankees fans shouted to Chuck Knoblauch as he walked into Yankee Stadium yesterday as a Kansas City Royal for the first time. Once a Yankee, always good enough for an autograph. Knoblauch waved to them and said he would sign autographs on the field.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cuomo Goes To Israel
description: As he left yesterday on a trip to Israel, Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor, released a letter he sent to Secretary of State Colin Powell recommending that he add the Palestinian Authority to the United States list of terrorist groups. Mr. Cuomo applauded the Bush administration's insistence that Yasir Arafat leave office. Mr. Cuomo denied that his trip was intended to counter the expected boost in Jewish support that his opponent, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, will receive from a recent endorsement by Senator Charles Schumer. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Guest Ensembles Enjoy Center Stage at Mostly Mozart
description: After a week of traded accusations and canceled concerts due to a strike action by the musicians of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, what remains of the popular festival began on Sunday afternoon with an engrossing recital by the Austrian baritone Wolfgang Holzmair and the British pianist Imogen Cooper at Alice Tully Hall, followed on Monday night with a concert by the impressive Scottish Chamber Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall that featured Mr. Holzmair and Ms. Cooper as soloists.

title: Recipe: Blackberry and Vanilla Bean Custard Parfait
description: Adapted from Roxanne's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIH, DAPHNE BAYNE HELLMAN
description: SHIH-Daphne Bayne Hellman. Passed away peacefully on August 4, 2002, at age 86. Famed jazz harpist of Hellman's Angels. Beloved mother of Daisy Hellman Paradis, Digger St. John and the late Sandy Bull. Dear motherin-law of David Paradis, Mona St. John and Candy Bull. Cherished grandmother of Sasha and Alain Paradis, and Davina-Nicole, BrittanyKara and Bayne-Alexander St. John, and Cassandra, Jesse and Jackson Bull. Dear sister of the late Elizabeth Shields. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, August 8, 11:30 AM. Interment private.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BANKER STEPS DOWN Cazenove, the secretive investment bank that caters to the upper echelon of British society, said its deputy chairman, David Verey, would step down. Mr. Verey, 51, the former head of the London office of Lazard, joined Cazenove a year ago and was widely expected to succeed David Mayhew as chairman. "We had different expectations for each other, and we have agreed to go our separate ways," Mr. Mayhew said in a statement. Mr. Verey's departure comes amid increasing uncertainty over the future of Cazenove, one of Britain's last closely held investment banks that counts members of the royal family among its clients. Cazenove has said it intended to sell shares to the public, but volatile stock markets have cast doubt on such a plan.

title: New Jersey Plans to Sue Companies Over Losses to Pension Funds
description: New Jersey plans to sue several major companies now accused of corporate mismanagement, the state attorney general announced today, saying that misleading accounting practices and bad decisions by executives have cost the state's retirement system more than $1 billion.

title: Doctors Who Examine Bush Say He Is Exceptionally Fit
description: President Bush's second annual medical checkup since he took office found him in ''extraordinary health,'' his doctors said today, with his heart and lung function in the top 1 percent for men of his age, up from the top 2 percent a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LOUISE JOSEPHINE SCHLOSSER
description: SMITH - Louise Josephine Schlosser. On July 27, 2002 in Greenwich, CT. Aunt of Lynn Elise Friend and George Antony Friend. Memorial contributions: Lighthouse, 111 East 59th St, NY, NY 10022.

title: Embattled Analyst Donated to Democrats
description: Jack B. Grubman, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney who is under investigation for potential conflicts of interest, gave $100,000 to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in June, campaign finance reports show.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. August 7. . Many years...and the wonderful memories linger on. Children, grandchildren and Joyc

title: Cross the Border and Enter France
description: QUEBEC had always meant two things to me: Montreal and skiing. But over the last few years I've discovered how far and wide the province's culinary attributes extend -- even into summer.

title: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Approval of Hepatitis B Drug
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee unanimously recommended approval yesterday for the Gilead Sciences drug adefovir for hepatitis B, a viral infection for which there are few good treatments.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: New Wording For Ballot
description: The state Democratic Party reached a settlement with Secretary of State Jim Smith in a lawsuit it filed seeking to change the language of the Sept. 10 primary ballot for governor. Instead of reading ''Vote for One Pair,'' the ballot will read ''Vote for One'' when choosing a Democratic candidate for governor. None of the candidates has a running mate. Absentee voters will also receive supplemental instructions on how to fill out their ballots. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cisco Beats Earnings Estimate, Raising Hope for Technology
description: Cisco Systems offered investors hope today that the nation's technology sector was not continuing to deteriorate, posting stronger-than-expected earnings.

title: New Business and Takeovers Push Omnicom's Profit Up 24%
description: Second-quarter earnings for the Omnicom Group, the advertising company, increased 24 percent as sales were helped by a string of acquisitions and new accounts.

title: Flailing Mets Contend With Ownership Sideshow
description: Bobby Valentine was standing behind the batting cage Tuesday at Milwaukee's Miller Park, but something was obscuring the view of his hitters taking batting practice. In his hands was not a scouting report. Instead, Valentine held a photocopied fax of the long statement co-owner Fred Wilpon had released that afternoon after Nelson Doubleday's response earlier that day to a lawsuit filed by Wilpon to force Doubleday to accept a $391 million appraisal of the Mets. The Mets were about to hand that release to reporters traveling with the team and Valentine was given a sneak peek.

title: A Taste of Vietnam With a Little Flavor of Chinatown
description: WHEN you go to Pho Grand, a new Vietnamese restaurant on Grand Street, begin by ordering the avocado juice ($2.50). It is a phenomenal treat, a kind of avocado smoothie, thick and creamy but not heavy and only a bit sweet. You won't want it to start, but you may want it later. And if you order it the moment you arrive, it may be served before you leave.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the return of the author Elie Wiesel to his Romanian hometown, Sighet, to open a Jewish museum referred incorrectly to Marshal Ion Antonescu, whom he cited as a wartime figure not to be glorified. The marshal, whose troops carried out mass killings of Romania's Jews, was deposed by King Michael I of Romania in 1944, not by the Communists; it was the Communists who convicted him as a war criminal and executed him in 1946.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: FAR-RIGHT GROUP BANNED The government has outlawed Radical Unity, the rightist group of the French neo-Nazi who tried to assassinate President Jacques Chirac on July 14. A government spokesman said the four-year-old group, which has about 2,000 members, was disbanded under a 1936 law banning groups that promote violence, racial discrimination or racial hatred. Fabrice Robert, a Radical Unity leader, said the group would rename itself and start over. "You can ban an organization," he said, "but not men and their ideas." Alan Riding (NYT)

title: After Surgical Separation, Twins' Prognosis Is Good
description: Exhausted surgeons kept a wary eye today on the progress of year-old Guatemalan twins after managing to separate their heads in a 22-hour operation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 28 about the re-election of New Zealand's prime minister, Helen Clark, misstated the surname of the leader of the Green Party, which renewed its voting alliance with Ms. Clark's Labor Party. She is Jeanette Fitzsimons, not Fitzgerald.

title: Islanders' Parrish Gets a 2-Year Pact
description: The Islanders, who opened a lot of eyes around the National Hockey League last season by making the playoffs for the first time in eight years, agreed to terms yesterday with one of their chief eye-openers, Mark Parrish.

title: Telemarketers Bilked Investors Of $29 Million, Officials Say
description: A nationwide telemarketing network bilked more than 1,800 investors out of $29 million by selling worthless securities in bogus movie projects and other sham ventures, federal prosecutors on Long Island said yesterday as they announced charges against 53 people.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teacher Charged With Rape
description: A New York City school teacher was arrested yesterday and charged with having sexual relations with a 15-year-old girl who is a student at the school, the police said. The man charged, Garrett Harris, 27, of Gilmore Street in Queens, a teacher at Benjamin Cardozo High School, is accused of having sex with the student July 1 and 2. Board of Education officials did not immediately respond to messages left late last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: The Tweed Courthouse
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Rising at SUNY Schools
description: The State University of New York is raising tuition at many of its professional schools this year. Tuition for state residents will rise by $2,000 a year to $14,840 at medical schools, by $600 a year to $10,500 at its law school, and by $500 a year to $11,840 in its dental programs. Pharmacy students will pay $10,900 a year, a $1,000 increase. And students in the physical therapy doctoral programs will face the biggest jump  $2,300 a year  to $9,300. Undergraduate tuition for state residents at SUNY's four-year colleges remains $3,400 for the seventh consecutive year.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: MAN WINS RITUAL FEATHERS

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: PAYPAL TO BUILD COMPLEX IN NEBRASKA PayPal, the Internet payment services company, plans to build a customer service and operations installation in Nebraska that could hold up to 1,200 people. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., has 540 employees in Omaha who will be moved into the building from two sites. The single-story building will be completed in early 2003 as part of a new retail and business park in an Omaha suburb. The site has enough space for a second building of about the same size for future growth. PayPal said in April that it would add 100 employees to its Omaha work force. (AP)

title: Senate G.O.P. Courts Democrats Who Might Switch
description: The Republicans who control the State Senate tried to persuade two, and possibly three, Brooklyn Democrats to switch parties this year, and at least one is likely to make the jump, Senate officials in both parties say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIV, MOSHE (MUKI)
description: ZIV-Moshe (Muki). On August 2nd of lung cancer. Beloved husband of Nina Dansky Ziv. Loving father of Assaf and Avigail. Also survived by family in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, Israel.

title: U.S. Is Seeking Pledges to Shield Its Peacekeepers From Tribunal
description: The Bush administration, still wary of the new International Criminal Court, is trying to line up nations one by one to pledge not to extradite Americans for trial, administration officials said today.

title: Doubleday Allegations Looming Over Talks
description: Because of the threat of a $1 million fine, baseball owners have basically been silent during talks between negotiators for the clubs and the players. But yesterday, without opening his mouth, the Mets co-owner Nelson Doubleday tossed a bomb onto the bargaining table that management officials quickly tried to defuse by debunking his accusations.

title: John T. Edsall, 99, Biochemist Who Helped Explain Proteins
description: Dr. John T. Edsall, a Harvard biochemist known for his pioneering study of proteins, died on June 12 in Boston. He was 99 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Procter & Gamble Company, Cincinnati, selected the Creative Artists Agency, Beverly Hills, Calif., to integrate marketing initiatives for its Tremor youth marketing unit with Hollywood advertisers like entertainment companies. Terms were not disclosed.

title: From Down-Home to Upmarket: Sam Walton's Town Gets Sleeker
description: Old-timers here still arrive by pickup truck to have their coffee and biscuits at Marty's, a plain-looking restaurant that has been a fixture for decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, MARGARET S.
description: STANLEY-Margaret S. In North Branford, CT. August 4, 2002, Margaret S. Stanley of Evergreen Woods. Wife of the late Julian C. Stanley. Daughter of the late Henry & Helen Graeff Schniewind. Mother of Michael, Julian and Peter Stanley. Also survived by eight grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. See obit www.wsclancy.com

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Deutsch, New York, promoted two employees. Paula Fedoris, vice president for data strategy, was named senior vice president and director for customer and data strategy. And Daniel Mailliard, associate creative director, added the post of vice president. Deutsch is part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Ratified Contract Ends 7-Week Bus Strike
description: Workers at three private bus lines in Queens voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a new contract and return to work, ending a seven-week strike that cut bus service to more than 100,000 passengers a day.

description: Adapted from Roxanne's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLLER, DR. SAMUEL
description: DOLLER-Dr. Samuel. Optometrist. Passed away after a long illness with Parkinson's, surrounded by his family on August 5. Beloved husband of 50 years to Shirley Falk, sister to Leah Ozner, father to Shira Grosser and father-in-law to Dr. Mayer Grosser, all of Teaneck, NJ., and father to Benjamin Doller of NY., and grandfather to Eliana, Rachel, Shoshana and Josef. He will always be remembered for his kindness.

description: To the Editor:

title: Levy Leaving Slightly Earlier Than Planned
description: Harold O. Levy, the departing New York City schools chancellor, will leave his post on Aug. 16 and his successor, Joel I. Klein, will take over on Aug. 19, Mr. Levy said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Underage Worker Violations
description: PriceRiteSupermarkets was fined nearly $160,000 for violating child labor laws in 12 of its stores in four states, including Connecticut, the United States Department of Labor said. The department accused the supermarket chain of allowing employees younger than 18 to work more than the federally permitted number of hours: no more than three per day on school days and 18 hours a week during school weeks. Some also operated power machinery, which underage workers are banned from using, the department said. A spokeswoman for PriceRite's parent company, Wakefern Food Corporation, said the company was appealing.

title: How Do You Drink Tea That Costs $33 an Ounce? Ceremoniously
description: HanGawi, a Korean vegetarian restaurant at 12 East 32nd Street, has introduced a line of fine teas, including Korean wild green teas, under the brand name Franchia. A three-ounce tin from the prized first picking of the wild tea is $100; a tin from the second picking is $50.

title: Suing the Accountants: Vitriol and Paperwork
description: Who's to blame when a company runs into trouble because of concerns over its accounting?

title: Settlement Offers Are Due on Trade Center Losses
description: In the most significant moment yet in the insurance battle over the World Trade Center, lawyers for Larry A. Silverstein, the developer, and Swiss Re, the lead insurer, are to make settlement offers to a federal judge in Manhattan tomorrow.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Insulin Maker's Profit Climbs
description: The world's largest maker of insulin, Novo Nordisk, said its second-quarter profit rose 24 percent. Net income climbed to 1.1 billion kroner ($143 million), from 887 million kroner, a year ago, it said. Novo has been cutting costs after falling demand in the United States for the diabetes therapy Prandin and slower sales of the hemophilia drug NovoSeven prompted the company in April to cut profit forecasts for the first time in more than three years.

description: The State University of New York is raising tuition at many of its professional schools this year. Tuition for state residents will rise by $2,000 a year to $14,840 at medical schools, by $600 a year to $10,500 at its law school, and by $500 a year to $11,840 in its dental programs. Pharmacy students will pay $10,900 a year, a $1,000 increase. And students in the physical therapy doctoral programs will face the biggest jump -- $2,300 a year -- to $9,300. description: SCHOEM - Georgiana. Of Park Ridge, formerly of Glen Rock, NJ. She was a graduate of Rutgers University, PastPresident of Hadassah, founding member of the Glen Rock Jewish Center, and Past-President of its Sisterhood. Surviving are her husband Robert, loving mother of Marla and Gary, devoted sister of Adrienne, cherished grandmother of Alissa, Jordan, Jenna, Adam, Sarah, and Zach. Services are today 1:30 P.M. Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. #

title: Those Who Fight to Save Young Cardiac Patients
description: Does anyone really care that Dr. Jonathan Drummond-Webb participates in triathlons when he isn't performing cardiac surgery? Not at first, but that changes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by the consulting firm Accenture to be treated differently from other companies that set up shop in offshore tax havens misstated the financial situation of its former affiliate, Arthur Andersen. It has not sought bankruptcy protection.

title: More Records Are Demanded In Inquiry on Martha Stewart
description: Saying they had tried without success to interview Martha Stewart, members of Congress looking into her sale of shares in ImClone Systems demanded additional records yesterday, including e-mail messages from Ms. Stewart and various records of a business manager for her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia.

title: O'Neill, Upbeat in Uruguay, Faces Tough Talk in Argentina
description: After making efforts to prop up the ailing economies of Brazil and Uruguay earlier in the day, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill arrived late this afternoon in Argentina, the third, final and most contentious stop on his four-day tour of a financially troubled region that blames the Bush administration for making many of its problems worse.

title: When Generosity Is Medically Necessary
description: In Aldous Huxley's vision of a brave new world, the central hospital has an organ store in a basement where the shelves are well stocked with organs whose donors are anonymous and unimportant. Perhaps someday, when stem cells can grow into kidneys and hearts or when organs from ''nude pigs,'' stripped immunologically of their pigness, can be transplanted into humans and not be rejected, we will achieve that time of plenty.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Boat Crew Rescues Whales
description: The crew of a whale-watching boat came to the aid of a 65-foot humpback whale and her calf after they noticed the animals had become entwined in fishing gear. The crew of the Nautilus, which had been watching the two whales all summer, realized something was wrong when the mother and calf were not diving. They positioned the boat, which was full of sightseers, alongside the whales and removed more than 300 feet of rope and netting as passengers cheered. The whales stayed with the boat for more than an hour afterward. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Annan Reaffirms U.N. Role In Iraq Weapons Inspections
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan told Iraq formally in a letter yesterday that the United Nations Security Council, not the government of Saddam Hussein, would decide on what basis weapons inspectors would return to Iraq after a four-year break.

title: Our Towns; A Black Eye Is Sometimes Just a Bump
description: SCANDAL has proved simply divine for this former seminary student.

title: A Rack That's Wiry But Not So Wobbly
description: The wavy wire chromed wine rack at right looks as if it might wobble, but it can hold 16 bottles securely. The rack, 22 inches square and 7 inches deep, stands as comfortably on a shelf as on the floor. It was created by Hawke Design in Los Angeles and Toda, a design group in New York, and is best stocked from the bottom up for stability. It is $50 at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street). Other stores at the distributor's Web site, www.puredesignonline

title: Investors Capitalize on Bargains And Give Sagging Markets a Lift
description: After three days of sharp declines, stocks shot higher yesterday as bargain hunters stepped in to buy recently downtrodden shares.

title: Taylor's Ascendance Facing a Hurdle
description: Jermain Taylor had to grow up fast, but he is trying to be patient with his boxing career.

title: Little League Coach Tossed After Players Say He Told Them to Lose
description: Three weeks after a group of Little Leaguers here said their coach had told them to lose an all-star game intentionally, the coach has been suspended.

title: Liberty Wastes First Shot at Playoff Berth
description: The Liberty had a chance to clinch a Women's National Basketball Association playoff spot last night. All it had to do was win at home against the Minnesota Lynx, which entered the game at 9-19 and tied for last place in the Western Conference.

title: Russia Agrees to Work With OPEC on Pricing
description: Russia, the second-largest oil exporter, agreed today to help OPEC maintain oil prices but offered no new promises to reduce its exports.

title: N.F.L. Seminar Offers Latest on Rule Interpretations and Tie Knots
description: For CBS Sports, the preseason National Football League production seminar is a day to renew acquaintances, reflect on the 2001 season, listen to rules changes, chat with Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and hear the boss's pep talk. But there were no lessons in Telestrating or, surprisingly, the art of parsing replays in 20 seconds or less.

title: An Old-Line Executive For AOL's Online Unit
description: Even as he met repeatedly with senior executives at AOL Time Warner over the last several weeks, Jonathan F. Miller, who was named chief of the company's troubled America Online division yesterday, was sure he was not going to get the job.

title: The Catcher In the Texas Chain Store
description: Even the title of the new Miguel Arteta crooked comedy of manners, ''The Good Girl,'' is contrary and mocking. Like ''Chuck and Buck,'' this director's previous collaboration with the writer Mike White, ''Girl'' is about a perverse need to create romance. Here it's like a Bette Davis melodrama directed by Luis Buuel: ambition and heartache with a poisonous undercurrent of anti-bourgeois absurdity. And it's a winner, helped along by a no-frills performance by Jennifer Aniston as the soul-sick cashier Justine.

description: Nelson Doubleday alleged yesterday that he was the victim of a ''sham process'' orchestrated by Major League Baseball to undervalue the Mets in the sale of his half of the team to Fred Wilpon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTENFELD, MATILDA
description: DISTENFELD - Matilda. Young Israel Forest Hills mourns the passing of its founding member, Matilda Distenfeld. May the All Mighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Man Is Killed in Explosion While Loading Fireworks in Newburgh
description: A man was killed today when fireworks that he was trying to load into a truck exploded at a storage depot near Stewart International Airport here, the police said.

title: Profit Up 68% In 1st Quarter For Airline From Ireland
description: Ryanair, the Irish discount airline, reported remarkably robust results today, even as many of its rivals continue to struggle.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 'Mostly Mozart' Settlement
description: A musicians' union ratified a contract yesterday between the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and Lincoln Center. The contract provides for disputes over dismissals to be handled by a three-person panel of an arbitrator and representatives from the orchestra and Lincoln Center. Under the previous contract, disputes were settled by an arbitrator. The union and management also agreed to present two free concerts at Avery Fisher Hall on Aug. 20 and Aug. 21, although the rest of the season remains canceled. The orchestra had proposed that musicians be able to reverse a music director's decision to fire a musician. But Lincoln Center said that would hamper recruiting a top-flight music director. The post has been empty for a year. Robin Pogrebin (NYT)

title: Moral Choices in a Thriller Spanning 1,500 Years
description: The British author Iain Pears is very tall, very thin and has the hollow-cheeked look of someone who lives mainly in the realm of the mind. He was folded awkwardly in a chair in a restaurant in midtown Manhattan and describing trying to write his novel ''The Dream of Scipio,'' published in June by Riverhead Books.

title: Last Week's Storm Still Tests New Jerseyans
description: About 3,000 customers in central New Jersey remained without electricity yesterday, four days after a wind-whipped storm toppled trees, downed power lines and tested patience across the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, BERTHA MARGOLIS
description: JAFFE-Bertha Margolis. On August 4th in Palm Desert, CA in her 91st year. Beloved wife of the late Irving Jaffe and loving mother of Mark Jaffe and Beth Pressman; grandmother of Kimberly & Lauren Pressman; mother-inlaw of June Jaffe. Caring, charitable and courageous, she was a grammar school teacher in New Jersey as a young woman and returned to that career in mid life. With her husband she early recognized the potential development of Tribeca as a residential neighborhood and was active in the real estate business there. Services ''Schoem's Menorah Chapel'', Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey, at 10:15 A.M., on Friday, August 9, 201-843-9090. Family and friends are invited to a luncheon following.

title: Eckstein's On-Deck Routine
description: Ispotted David Eckstein in the Angels locker room doing what David Eckstein kind of guys do: opening his fan mail and signing the baseball cards inside. I was assigned a story on the surprising Angels, so I figured I'd talk to their sparkplug of a leadoff hitter.

title: Duncan Noble, 80, Dance Teacher And Member of Ballet Theater
description: Duncan Noble, a dance teacher at the North Carolina School of the Arts and a former member of Ballet Theater, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo and Valerie Bettis's modern dance group, died on Monday at a hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 80 and lived in Winston-Salem.

title: Accounts
description: * Papa Murphy's, Vancouver, Wash., a pizza chain, to David and Goliath, Los Angeles, to handle its account, which had been at the San Francisco office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group. Billings on the account were estimated at $15 million.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Aerial Spraying For Staten Island
description: Helicopter spraying to kill mosquitoes that may carry the West Nile virus is scheduled for nonresidential wetlands tomorrow, Friday, and Saturday, from 6:00 a.m. to 9 p.m., weather permitting. The places scheduled to be treated: the Saw Mill Marsh area between Chelsea and Bloomfield; the GATX Industrial Park in Gulfport; marshes south of the Staten Island Expressway, west of South Avenue, and north of the Staten Island Expressway; and areas adjacent to Richmond Creek in La Tourette Park.

title: Bite a Brioche, Find Gelato
description: AS Gino Cammarata said, the ice cream sandwich at Bussola in Greenwich Village has its roots in two aspects of Sicilian life: First, ''It's so hot in Sicily, in the summer people eat gelato for breakfast, lunch and dinner,'' and second, ''In Sicily, we eat everything with bread: watermelon, grapes, you name it.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our intent is to have a day of observances that are simple and powerful.''

title: McCall Seeks Hispanic Votes
description: This 30-second commercial, in Spanish, is the second in H. Carl McCall's campaign for the Democratic nomination for governor. Two Spanish-language television stations, Telemundo and Univision, began broadcasting the spot yesterday. A similar radio commercial is also on the air.

title: Taiwan Chief Eases Stand; Beijing Rattles Sabre
description: President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan, seeking to allay the concerns of local business leaders and of the United States, softened his position toward China on Tuesday, but the Chinese military threatened Taiwan today anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMLEY, FRANK J.
description: GORMLEY-Frank J. On August 5, 2002, retired from Citibank and Siemens, served aboard The USS Bennington. Dearest and truest friend, a sweet and lively companion, courageous and passionate about life & love, an adoring and forever adored husband. Frank loved the sea and ships, music, especially jazz, good food-especially mine, films and books about history and intrigue. Above all, he loved to talk and exchange ideas. As his illness robbed him of one and yet another of these earthly pleasures, he continued to accommodate each loss without complaint or bitterness. He remained independent and each day went through exhausting health rituals just to stay alive. Survived by his wife and soul mate, his caring and loving mother-in-law, Jennie Sini, and sisters-in-law, Evelyn and Yolanda Sini, and Peggy Gormley (widow of dear deceased brother, Jack), nieces, Betty and Kathleen, and nephew, John. My deepest gratitude to the entire Medical Staff at Victory Memorial. I could not ask for more or better. Thank you for touching me and Frank so gently. Visiting on Wednesday and Thursday, August 7th and 8th, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Friday August 9 at 10 A.M. Saint Anselm's Church, 82nd Street & Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Thank you with love from Frank and Eileen.

title: Junius Scales, Communist Sent to U.S. Prison, Dies at 82
description: Junius Scales, who in the postwar anti-Communist fervor was the only American sent to prison for being a member of the Communist Party, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82 and lived in Manhattan and Pine Bush, N.Y.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT MAKER TO CUT JOBS
description: Tut Systems, which makes telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that it would cut 39 percent of its jobs and close a design center in Bridgewater, N.J., to save $5 million to $6 million a year. The reductions, which will affect 56 people, will leave the company with 86 employees, a Tut Systems spokeswoman said. Ten of the 56 people work in the Bridgewater center, she said. Tut makes equipment that allows the delivery of high-speed Internet access over copper telephone lines. The move is expected to cost about $500,000 for severance benefits and as much as $1.1 million for closing the center in the third quarter, the company said.

title: Longtime Assemblyman Takes Challenger Seriously
description: Dawn had barely come yesterday, and Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. was already perched at the entrance to the Kingston Avenue subway station on Eastern Parkway. Impeccably dressed in a dark blue suit, Mr. Norman, the Democratic Party leader of Brooklyn and a 20-year incumbent, insisted that his re-election battle was a difficult one that demanded nearly 24-hour vigilance.

title: Schools Are Gaining Help In Getting Parents Involved
description: SOME students fail in school because their parents participate too little in their learning. Many educators strive to get parents involved, but the task may be beyond the capacity of schools acting alone.

title: UNIONBANCAL AGREES TO BUY VALENCIA BANK AND TRUST
description: The UnionBanCal Corporation, California's second-largest bank, said yesterday that it would buy Valencia Bank and Trust for $62 million in cash and stock to add branches in the Los Angeles area. UnionBanCal, parent of Union Bank of California, said it would pay $31 million in cash and $31 million in stock for Valencia. UnionBanCal valued the transaction at $34.13 a share, 11 percent higher than Valencia's closing price Monday. Valencia Bank, based in Santa Clarita, Calif., has 92 employees and five branches. Union Bank, headquartered in San Francisco, has 41 branches in Los Angeles County.

title: Chancellor Levy Exits
description: The job of New York City schools chancellor is a thankless one. In recent years the most a departing chancellor could hope for was to slip out in a barrage of chilly silence. The alternative was to be ridden out of town on a rail. That's one of the reasons that when there's a vacancy, top-flight candidates don't exactly line up at the door.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.S. Soldiers Kill 2
description: American soldiers shot and killed two men who fired on them while on a patrol on Monday in eastern Afghanistan, said Col. Roger King, an army spokesman. He said about 30 special operations soldiers came under fire from a hilltop north of Asadabad in Kunar Province. No Americans were hurt. In July, the military reported five attacks on Americans hunting for Al Qaeda and Taliban forces. Ian Fisher (NYT)

description: G.M. to Begin Counting Options as an Expense

title: You Hear About the Chef Who Doesn't Use a Stove?
description: IN the wrong setting, undercooked food can earn restaurants a demerit. At Roxanne's, about a half-hour's drive north of San Francisco, where the menu offers fare that is not just undercooked but raw and vegetarian, it's drawing improbable crowds. And despite raw food's sprouts-and-seaweed reputation, calls for reservations are coming from some of the most sophisticated names in the world of, well, cooking.

title: What Itzhak Perlman Learned at Camp; While Helping Students, His Wife Says, He Reinvented Himself
description: Seven years ago when Itzhak Perlman first led an orchestra of teenagers at his wife's summer music camp, then in East Hampton, N.Y., he guided them with a pencil. A pencil signified teacher, which was as much as he was ready to commit to, and even then only occasionally. A baton, he recently confided, would have made him a conductor, and he simply wasn't ready.

title: A Study Finds Children's Aid Goes to Adults
description: Congressional investigators said today that the Bush administration had improperly allowed some states to spend federal money intended for the Children's Health Insurance Program on childless adults instead.

title: Colombian Sticks to Plans Despite Shelling That Killed 19
description: VALLEDUPAR, Colombia, Aug. 8  Defiant a day after rebels launched mortars during his inauguration, Colombia's new president traveled to this lawless northern region today to help set up a controversial plan to undercut the guerrillas by recruiting thousands of civilian informers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARHI, CAROL RUSKIN
description: FARHI-Carol Ruskin, on August 7, 2002, at home. Beloved wife of Jean-Pierre; mother of Jacques, Paul and Jane. Service Friday, Aug. 9th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: PARIS:  CHALLENGES OF DEVELOPMENT

title: Leukemia Drug Side Effect: Color Returned to Gray Hair
description: In a puzzling and intriguing side effect, a new antileukemia drug has darkened the gray hair of some patients, French doctors reported yesterday.

title: Ford Heir Says Nation's Affair With the Car Has Lost Its Zip
description: William Clay Ford Jr. said today that a credibility gap on environmental issues had eroded America's love for cars. Mr. Ford, the chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, also said he wanted to ''lower the temperature'' of the industry's often contentious relationship with California regulators.

title: CALENDAR
description: Seen and Invisible

title: Bad Hair Day? She Can Blame the Hard Hat
description: SEXISM 101: Conjure up an image of the woman who is construction honcho at the first major rebuilding effort at ground zero. Wears that hard hat, yes? Chain-smokes Camels? Swears a blue streak? Screams a lot? Downs boilermakers while she issues arm-wrestling challenges to the guys?

title: Timely Entertainment
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Deaths Rose in 2001, But Rate for Miles Traveled Fell
description: The number of people killed in motor vehicle crashes rose to 42,116 last year, up 171 from the previous year. The Transportation Department said that the reason was growth in traffic, and that the death rate per 100 million miles traveled declined slightly.

title: On the Waterfront, at Least for Now; Hudson River Park Threatens Some Home-Grown Free Spirits
description: To many New Yorkers, the city waterfront is still -- as John Krevy, one wharf business owner, put it -- ''Marlon Brando, crime, corruption and, eeuuuww, disgusting.''

title: Ways to Remember a Tragic Day
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: No Toasting, Please
description: A new Miss Teen Texas 2002 has been crowned after the first winner resigned after her arrest on a public intoxication charge. The new title holder, Brittany Wellsfry, a senior at Wichita Falls High School, was first runner-up to Julia Anderson in July. But Ms. Anderson, 17, resigned on Saturday after the police, responding to a report that she had been drinking and was trying to drive away from a party, arrested her in a parking lot. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Hormone That Causes Full Feeling Is Found
description: Scientists have identified a hormone that causes the sensation every dieter craves: the feeling of fullness.

title: Turning Mysteries of E-Mail and Technology Into Theater
description: FOR many people, e-mail is simply a part of daily life. They send and receive messages with a few easy keystrokes. But few stop to ponder what happens to their message once they hit Send. ''In the Wire,'' a new play being presented this month as part of the New York International Fringe Festival, seeks to change that.

title: Special Financing Approved For Downtown Apartments
description: Special financing worth up to $340 million was approved yesterday for construction of three apartment buildings in Lower Manhattan, the first projects to be granted the special tax-exempt bonds created by Congress in response to the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Violence in Hebron
description: To the Editor:

title: For WorldCom, Acquisitions Were Behind Its Rise and Fall
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the onetime high school coach and Canadian milkman who rose to chief executive of WorldCom, stepped to the lectern at the National Press Club to applause from scores of Washington journalists. With delight he described how he had transformed an obscure long-distance phone company into one of the country's fastest growing corporations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, BERTHA MARGOLIS
description: JAFFE-Bertha Margolis. On August 4th in Palm Desert, CA in her 91st year. Beloved wife of the late Irving Jaffe and loving mother of Mark Jaffe and Beth Pressman; grandmother of Kimberly & Lauren Pressman; mother-inlaw of June Jaffe and sister of Theresa Hahn. Caring, charitable and courageous, she was a grammar school teacher in New Jersey as a young woman and returned to that career in mid life. With her husband she early recognized the potential development of Tribeca as a residential neighborhood and was active in the real estate business there. Services ''Schoem's Menorah Chapel'', Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey, at 10:15 A.M., on Friday, August 9, 201-843-9090. Family and friends are invited to a luncheon following.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about pacifists who do not want their tax dollars to go to the military misstated the percentage of the federal budget now spent on it. The Office of Management and Budget says that in the 2002 fiscal year, ending Sept. 30, the percentage is 16.37. The article's figure of about 50 percent came from antimilitary tax resisters, who generally include items like veterans' benefits and the portion of interest on the national debt that they say is related to military spending.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: MTI To Introduce New Fuel-Cell Design
description: MTI MicroFuel Cells plans to introduce today a simplified design for methane-powered fuel cells. It plans to shrink fuel cells by 2004 into devices small enough to supplement or replace lithium ion batteries in devices like cellphones and laptops. The prototype is half the size of MTI's first device, which it publicized last fall, but still twice as big as a commercial version will have to be, according to William Acker, chief executive of MTI, a subsidiary of Mechanical Technology. MTI is one of a number of companies racing to develop methane-powered micro fuel cells, which many energy experts expect to become the leading candidate to power future portable consumer electronics. Initially, though, they will probably be used to recharge or extend battery life. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Arms Sales Plummet

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Airline Posts A Profit
description: The Asian carrier Cathay Pacific Airways posted an unexpected rise in first-half profit on cost reductions after the Sept. 11 terror attacks and higher cargo demand. It had net income of $181 million, compared with $169 million, a year earlier. Cathay has fared better than most rivals in the air-travel slump partly because it was quick to cancel flights and ground planes in response to the terrorist attacks.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Police Investigate Suicide Raid
description: Investigators were examining the body of one of three men who blew themselves up with grenades when confronted by the police 25 miles from a missionary school attacked by gunmen on Monday. A deputy inspector general, Tariq Qayuum, said the men had told villagers they had carried out the attack. The bodies of the two other men washed down a river. Six Pakistanis were killed in the attack. David Rohde (NYT)

title: A Screen That Cuts The Cord
description: WHAT'S going on with computer design these days? Apple's recent machines have resembled Kleenex dispensers, gumdrops and sunflowers. Sony dabbled with computers that let you draw right on the screen. I.B.M. built a laptop whose screen rotates to face your audience. Computer makers must be desperate to revive the sagging PC market -- or maybe they're just bored.

title: Ways to Remember a Tragic Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Will Sell Computers To I.R.S.
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's second-largest computer maker, will provide more than 23,000 Compaq computers to the federal Internal Revenue Service in a five-year contract valued at about $35 million. Hewlett-Packard, which completed its acquisition of Compaq Computer in May, will sell more than 12,300 Evo D500 desktop computers and monitors and about 11,000 EVO N800 notebooks through PlanetGov, a reseller in Chantilly, Va., Hewlett-Packard said in a statement.

title: Privatize Public Diplomacy
description: Last week, President Bush announced the creation of an Office of Global Communications to help manage and shape America's image abroad. Mr. Bush is certainly right that public diplomacy must be practiced in harmony with traditional diplomacy. Precisely how to practice it is the critical question. Mr. Bush seems content to leave it to the White House and the State Department. But public diplomacy is much too important to leave to professional diplomats.

title: Hitler, It Seems, Loved Money and Died Rich
description: Hitler died wealthy.

title: In Twin Speeches, Bush and Cheney Vow to Fight Fraud
description: In a rare public appearance, Vice President Dick Cheney today defended the administration's stewardship of the faltering economy and vowed to punish corporate misconduct.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Lee Gallagher was named group media planning supervisor at Horizon Media, based in Los Angeles. She had been advertising director at Uniworld, Encino, Calif.

title: Nick Lowe With Guitar, His Smirk Long Gone
description: Was Nick Lowe ever just a joker? He got some laughs when he performed at Joe's Pub on Tuesday night, in the second of two shows that completed a rare United States tour. But playing solo, with just a guitar, and singing in a voice that has shed its youthful callowness, he revealed the melancholy within his songs, old and new.

title: Charmed by Six Feet of Circuitry
description: WITH her conference duties complete, Grace found a quiet spot in the wings of the busy auditorium where she had just delivered a detailed and fluid speech on her groundbreaking scientific advances.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: RCN Reports Bigger Loss Than Expected
description: The RCN Corporation, the cable television, phone and Internet provider backed by Paul G. Allen, said it would have a larger second-quarter loss than it had expected because of ''the severe slowdown in the telecommunications industry and the economy, and the limited available capital'' within the sector. The company said it had curtailed growth plans and had nearly $900 million in asset impairment and other costs. RCN, of Princeton, N.J., reported a net loss of $1.09 billion, or $10.46 a share, compared with a loss of $676.9 million, or $7.38 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 15 percent, to $128 million from $111 million. David C. McCourt, RCN's chief executive, said that the company added customers to its network during the quarter and that ''we continue to fine-tune our marketing and service delivery strategy.''

title: A Slightly Immodest Proposal
description: HENRY DAVID THOREAU never had plumbing at his famous shack. But if he did, he surely would have built an outdoor shower placed so that he could gaze in reverie at the reflections on Walden Pond while rinsing off the sweat of his labors.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
