description: To the Editor:

title: Firing of former officer unfair, court rules : Whistleblower upheld in UN Bosnia police case
description: PARIS:  A British tribunal has ruled that a former member of the UN police force in Bosnia was unfairly fired after she reported to her superiors that colleagues in the police force used women and children as sex slaves in connivance with Balkan traffickers.

title: 4 Killed as Suspects in Afghan Border Area
description: American Special Forces patrolling near the Pakistan border shot and killed four men on Tuesday, the second day in a row in which American forces reported killing would-be assailants in that area.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Voters Reject Tax Increase
description: Voters rejected an increase in gas and sales taxes that would have generated $483 million a year for major roadway improvements. The state will now focus on repaving and fixing potholes. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 900 To Lose Jobs In Nokia Networks Unit
description: The Nokia Corporation, the world's biggest maker of handsets, said yesterday that it planned to lay off 900 employees in its networks business, or about 5 percent of the unit's work force, as demand for base stations, phone towers and switches faltered. The cuts will ''adjust the organization to the current business environment,'' said a Nokia spokeswoman, Riitta Maard. Earnings at the unit, which accounts for a fifth of total sales, fell 33 percent in the second quarter, Nokia said last month.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: MTI TO INTRODUCE NEW FUEL-CELL DESIGN MTI MicroFuel Cells plans to introduce today a simplified design for methane-powered fuel cells. It plans to shrink fuel cells by 2004 into devices small enough to supplement or replace lithium ion batteries in devices like cellphones and laptops. The prototype is half the size of MTI's first device, which it publicized last fall, but still twice as big as a commercial version will have to be, according to William Acker, chief executive of MTI, a subsidiary of Mechanical Technology . MTI is one of a number of companies racing to develop methane-powered micro fuel cells, which many energy experts expect to become the leading candidate to power future portable consumer electronics. Initially, though, they will probably be used to recharge or extend battery life. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about potential risks to the system that would compensate people hurt by a severe nuclear accident referred incorrectly to a problem at the Davis-Besse nuclear plant near Toledo, Ohio. An acid leak inside the plant ate a hole six inches deep into a steel cap that covers the plant's reactor vessel, federal inspectors said in March. No accident was reported.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BCE Sells New Shares
description: The Canadian communications group BCE said it had signed an agreement with an underwriting group to raise 2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion) through a public stock offering. The proceeds will be used mainly to finance BCE's proposed purchase of the 20 percent of the Bell Canada phone company that it does not already own from SBC Communications. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: HIGHER GOLD PRICES HELP NEWMONT MINING'S QUARTER
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation reported a second-quarter profit yesterday because of higher gold prices and the sale of a stake in a rival. Net income was $64.8 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $33.5 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 95 percent, to $712.3 million. Newmont benefited from gold prices that averaged nearly 20 percent higher than last year's and a $47.3 million profit on the sale of a stake in Lihir Gold.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Shoo, Elephants!
description: The governor of Bangkok is mounting a new effort to expel scores of domesticated elephants who wander the streets as beggars with their handlers. The governor, Samak Sundaravej, proposed building special camps at a cost of $7 million. Earlier plans to rid the city of begging elephants have failed because of the cost, the lack of available forest area and the pressure of poverty, which drives elephant handlers to seek a living on the streets. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Cool Buys In a Hot Month
description: AUGUST might seem like the right time to take a vacation, but this year it is a month for good buys on furniture and home accessories, especially downtown. Smart shoppers should keep an eye out for handwritten signs in store windows advertising sales.

title: In London, a Necklace of Water in Memory of Diana Makes Waves
description: What is a memorial without controversy? Tessa Jowell, England's culture secretary, has chosen a design for a $4.6 million fountain in memory of Diana, Princess of Wales. But, lacking gushing jets of water, it is less a fountain than a large raised oval channel of running water in Hyde Park, above, by the American landscape designer Kathryn Gustafson and her London-based partner, Neil Porter. Ms. Gustafson, highly regarded for her Arthur Ross Terrace at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, called the design ''complex but feminine'' and likened it to a necklace. But, predictably, British newspapers complained that it is too minimalist or not daring enough. The Guardian of London called it a stone moat and said it was bland and embarrassing. The London Evening Standard, attacking on another front, said that Ms. Gustafson's landscaping for the Crystal Palace Park in London, with its modern-looking restoration of an area containing 19th-century stone dinosaurs, right, now nearing completion, was ''out of kilter with its Victorian setting and period charm.''

title: ESPN Shifts N.H.L. Games To Make Way for the N.B.A.
description: ESPN will shift its marquee National Hockey League games from Wednesday to Thursday next season and reduce the number of its and ESPN2's hockey telecasts.

title: Patient Deaths Tied to Lack Of Nurses
description: Calling a shortage of nurses ''a prescription for danger,'' the national organization that accredits hospitals reported today that the lack contributed to nearly a quarter of the unanticipated problems that result in death or injury to hospital patients.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an operation that separated joined twin girls included an erroneous description from NBC for an observer of the surgery, Houman Hemmati, who commented on the ''Today'' show about the work of anesthesiologists. He is a medical student, not a medical doctor.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about primary elections in Michigan referred incorrectly to Representative David E. Bonior, who lost in the Democratic voting for governor. He is the former House minority whip, not the current majority whip.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: By the Sea

title: Ring! It's a Digital Snapshot, Taken and Sent by Cellphone
description: If you are looking to limit the number of gadgets in your bag, you may want to think about a new offering from AT&T Wireless. The service, mMode Pix, lets cellphone users shoot photos and instantly send them to friends via e-mail, using a wireless phone.

title: Players Union Proposes Tests for Illegal Steroids
description: In a major breakthrough, the union for major league baseball players proposed yesterday that players be tested for illegal steroids. The union's plan differs from the drug proposal that the club owners presented earlier in the year, but it is nevertheless the first time the players have agreed to any unannounced testing for illegal substances.

title: Promoting Our Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSSAVAR, RAHMANI SHAHIN
description: MOSSAVAR - RAHMANI Shahin. Much beloved son, brother, brother-in-law and uncle and a cherished friend to so many passed away on August 3, 2002 at the age of 48 of heart failure while jogging in Central Park. Following a career in journalism, he earned a Ph.D. in international relations from the University of Pennsylvania and became a founding member and principal of UAS Asset Management in New York City. A gentle soul, he was fiercely devoted to his family, friends, work and sports and gave generously of himself to all. A celebration of his life will be held Friday, August 9, 2002 at the Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, at 1:30 PM followed by burial services.

title: CNBC Official for Business News Resigns
description: Bruno Cohen, the CNBC executive vice president for business news and an important steward of the network's coverage of the stock market in the late 1990's, resigned yesterday.

title: Huck Finn, Continental Style
description: Peter Deilmann Cruises is trimming up to $565 per person on European river-cruise fares this fall aboard 10 vessels, ranging in capacity from 58 to 204 passengers. Seven-night trips on the Po River on the Casanova start at $1,555 a person, based on double occupancy (a saving of $340 from high season), Oct. 19 through Nov. 9. The trip starts in Venice and visits Cremona, Bologna, Ferrara, Verona and Murano, among other places. On Oct. 13, 20 and 27, the Mozart departs Passau, Germany, to sail the Danube. Stops include Vienna, Bratislava and Budapest. Rates per person, double, are $1,745 and $2,445, a saving of up to $565 over summer rates. Prices include all meals and transfers from gateway cities. Alcoholic beverages, sightseeing and port charges are extra. Information: (800) 348-8287 or www.deilmann-cruises.com .

title: Gyroscopes That Don't Spin Make It Easy to Hover
description: WHEN learning to fly a helicopter, either a full-size one or a radio-controlled model, one of the greatest challenges is keeping the craft hovering in one spot. But model fliers, at least, now have some assistance: digital circuitry that can help them develop the right touch in just a few hours.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Increased in July
description: The number of magazine advertising pages grew in July, the first monthly increase since December 2000, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: Strength and Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Cortlandt Parker, 80, Publisher Of 17 Weeklies in New Jersey
description: Cortlandt Parker, president and publisher of the Recorder Publishing Company in Bernardsville, N. J., died on Monday at Norwood Caritas Hospital in Norwood, Mass.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Fighting Spread Of Virus
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee said he would make $1 million in emergency money available to fight West Nile virus. Health officials said on Monday that the state's first suspected case of the virus in a human had been reported near the border with Louisiana, where numerous infections have been documented and five deaths attributed to the virus, which is spread by mosquitoes.

title: Family of 9/11 Victim Accepts $1.04 Million In U.S. Compensation
description: The family of a young financial services employee from New York City who died in the terror attacks on Sept. 11 has become the first to acknowledge accepting an award from the federal Victim Compensation Fund, a key moment for a program that is being closely scrutinized by thousands of relatives of victims and American taxpayers.

title: In Scenic Norway, a Death Scene of Addiction
description: It is a sunny morning, and the Oslo Fjord dances with reflections. Festive pennants flutter from a departing North Sea ferry, bicyclists pedal past the colonnade of the stock exchange building and sleek trams glide by, filled with downtown workers.

title: Piazza Simply Puts on the Mask in the Face of Criticism
description: A few months ago, Mike Piazza strolled through the players' clubhouse before a game wearing a royal blue Mets T-shirt while flipping through a magazine. Piazza passed shortstop Rey Ordez, who broke off a conversation with a reporter to tell him he needed to continue throwing the way he did the previous night, without effort. When he did that, Ordez said, his arm was like a rifle.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: UNITED ONLINE SHARES SOAR ON RESULTS Shares in United Online, the discount Internet service provider formed by the merger of NetZero and Juno, jumped yesterday after the company said that it had narrowed its losses and raised its expectations for the year. For the quarter ending on June 30, United Online reported a net loss of $2.7 million, or 7 cents a share, on revenue of $54.4 million. That compares with a $7.3 million loss, or 19 cents a share, on sales of $50.9 million in the previous quarter. The company says it has 20 million users and expects its paid subscriber base to grow by 25 percent to 28 percent in 2002. It had previously expected an increase of 20 percent to 24 percent. Shares rose $1.43, or 15.1 percent, to $10.90. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRAD TOURETZ, LILLIAN
description: CONRAD TOURETZ-Lillian. Died at home August 6, 2002, surrounded by her children and grandson, at peace with a beautiful smile. Psychotherapist, mother of David and Donna, grandmother of Zakary, sister of Gladys, Irene, Mae, beloved aunt, cherished member of lifelong community of friends. Predeceased by second husband Arthur, by parents Rose and Philip, friend to first husband Martin. First woman union president, led march for racial integration in '40's, decoded for Gen'l Grove on Manhattan Project. Great woman of pizzaz with brilliant mind, vital spirit, empathic heart, touched the depths of many. Service on Friday, August 9th, 11 AM, Riverside, 21 Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, 914-664-6800.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Boos and Benching Still Haunt Stewart
description: He came one victory short, a touchdown and a 2-point conversion shy of a trip to the Super Bowl in New Orleans, just a stone's throw from Marrero, La., where he grew up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEYDEN, ARTHUR F. JR
description: LEYDEN-Arthur F. Jr, 74. Of Little Egg Harbor Township, died Monday at home. He was born in Woodhaven, NY, resided in Wayne, NJ, moving to Little Egg Harbor in 1991. He graduated from Seton Hall University in 1950 with a BS in Chemistry. Mr. Leyden retired from Pfizer Inc, in 1991, after 40 years of service as an executive in various sales and business development positions. Mr. Leyden was a member of the 50th Armored Division (NJ) serving in the 102nd Armored Calvary Regiment, Newark. He was past president of The Immaculate Heart of Mary school board, Wayne, and its home and school association. Also a member of the Neumann Prep Parents Association. Mr. Leyden was a member of the Board of Directors of The Drug Chemical and Allied Trade Association and The Calorie Control Council. An accomplished singer, he was a member of the glee club of The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, NYC. He also served as president of the group which was founded by Victor Herbert. He was frequently a soloist when the glee club performed at Town Hall, Lincoln Center, Sheraton Center and elsewhere. He was a communicant of St. Theresa's RC Church, Tuckerton and congregational song leader at St. Michael's in Little Egg Harbor. He was a member of The Island Singers, Ship Bottom, NJ. Mr. Leyden was predeceased by his wife, Regina A. (Power) in 2000. He is survived by his sons, Arthur F. III, Esquire, of Toms River, NJ; Gregory P. of San Diego, CA; Stephen A. of Oak Ridge, NJ; daughters, Regina A. Jasinski, Whippany, NJ; Mary E. Garbarino, Cartaret, NJ; Cecilia A, NYC; and Therese M. Potter of Wayne, NJ; brothers, Thomas P. of Westport, CT; and Lawrence G. of Bridgeport, CT and 13 grandchildren. Friends may call Thursday August 8, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Wood Funeral Home, Tuckerton, NJ, and after 8:30 am, Friday. A funeral mass will be said at St. Theresa's Church, Tuckerton, 9:30 AM. Burial will be in St. Teresa's Cemetery, Summit, NJ. Memorial contributions to: St. Theresa's Building Fund or Island Singers, PO Box 251.

title: My Daughter in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about quarterly earnings for Cisco Systems referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing planned by the chief executive and the chief financial officer for complying with a new requirement that they certify the company's financial results. It is next month, not next week.

title: Lounging on a Jelly Bean, With a Little Bounce
description: SOFT gummy materials top the latest bar stools, chairs and loungers. Often they look and feel more like Jujubes than pieces of furniture. Even though the forms here are modern, they depart from the hard edges of midcentury modern design. ''I don't like molded plastic; it looks too machined,'' said Jeanne Scandura, an architect in Philadelphia who prefers softer surfaces. In that vein, Ms. Scandura has made polyurethane cube-shaped stools, which have the feel of a smooth rubber ball.

title: POTENTIAL OBSTACLE FOR AMERITRADE PURCHASE OF DATEK
description: NASD, which was formerly known as the National Association of Securities Dealers, ordered a unit of the Datek Online Holdings Corporation to halt day trading by some customers, raising a potential obstacle to the company's acquisition by the Ameritrade Holding Corporation. Ameritrade and Datek must obtain N.A.S.D. approval for a change in control at Datek. Ameritrade, the nation's fifth-largest Internet brokerage firm, offered to buy Datek for $1.3 billion in stock. The approval may be jeopardized because the association, which regulates brokers, has expressed concern that a Datek unit is permitting customers to engage in an illegal form of day trading known as free riding, the purchase of shares without the money to pay for them, according to a filing by Ameritrade with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Ameritrade and Datek say the unit, a business called IClearing that processes securities transactions, is not doing anything wrong.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Holocaust Victim Payments
description: The first payments to settle Holo caust victim claims arising from the Nazi seizure 60 years ago of two Austrian banks will be sent out this month, according to an agreement worked out in United States federal court. A three-member claims committee reviewed some 58,000 claims for the $40 million settlement agreed on by Creditanstalt and Bank Austria AG. About $30 million was set aside in a fund for survivors and their heirs, and the rest was divided into two other funds, including one to support a historians' commission to investigate and publish a report on Austrian banks' actions during the Nazi era -- just as Switzerland did to settle its Holocaust funds controversy. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: ID Cards, Not Ignition Keys, at Airports
description: SINCE Sept. 11, the most prominent efforts to bolster aviation security have focused on ways of searching passengers and baggage for weapons or bombs. But in coming months the new Transportation Security Agency will have to deal with other weak points, including airport ramp areas filled with fuel trucks, baggage tugs and catering trucks with keys left in the ignition -- all available to ram a plane or deliver a bomb or terrorists.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIH, DAPHNE BAYNE HELLMAN
description: SHIH-Daphne Bayne Hellman. Passed away peacefully on August 4, 2002, at age 86. Famed jazz harpist of Hellman's Angels. Beloved mother of Daisy Hellman Paradis, Digger St. John and the late Sandy Bull. Dear motherin-law of David Paradis, Mona St. John and Candy Bull. Cherished grandmother of Sasha and Alain Paradis, and Davina-Nicole, BrittanyKara and Bayne-Alexander St. John, and Cassandra, Jesse and Jackson Bull. Dear sister of the late Elizabeth Shields. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, August 8, 11:30 AM. Interment private.

title: Rivera Gives the Staff A Deft, Finished Touch
description: When the Yankees approached last week's trading deadline with their bullpen looking ragged, General Manager Brian Cashman held off from making trades. When the pitching staff is whole, Cashman said, there will be no room for another pitcher.

title: Doctor Pleased With Recovery Of Twins Separated by Surgery
description: The twins whose heads were separated in a marathon operation here are doing very well, the surgeon in charge of their case said today.

title: U.S. ADDS CHARGES AGAINST EX-CHIEF OF DRUG COMPANY
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems, was indicted yesterday on charges of insider trading, bank fraud, forging a signature and destroying records to obstruct a federal investigation.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: ACQUISITION OF PHONE ASSETS Telecom Italia Mobile, Italy's largest cellphone company, said it would buy some of Blu's assets, and rivals would divide up the rest. Telecom Italia Mobile will pay at least 18 million euros ($17.5 million) for 1,400 radio base stations and 830 sites where antennas are placed.

title: Don't Let This One Buy You A Drink
description: ''You're the world's coolest woman,'' says an aspiring gangster to Kei (Michelle Reis) in Takashi Miike's ''City of Lost Souls,'' an unseen film from 2000 that today opens a two-week tribute to Mr. Miike at Anthology Film Archives in the East Village.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Youth Center Reform Urged
description: Following the February beating and burning of a counselor at a center for troubled girls, a State Senate committee yesterday recommended reforms for youth centers but cautioned that new financing was unlikely. State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, above, Republican of Yonkers, said solutions would have to be more creative than just spending money. The investigations committee, which he leads, recommended more training for counselors, background checks for all employees and a cost-of-living adjustment for center workers. Jane Barowitz, a spokeswoman for the Pleasantville Cottage School, where the counselor was attacked, said inadequate financing and rapid staff turnover hindered treatment at the centers.

title: An Electric Drill So Quiet You Can Hear the Radio Over It. In Fact, in It.
description: It is always nice to find an inexpensive compact tool with all the bells and whistles. The Ryobi cordless drill, right, also comes with a radio built into the charger unit. All screws and hardware are included. The drill is powerful enough for most home drilling or screwdriving jobs, and the AM-FM radio is loud enough to hear over it. Two 9.6-volt batteries are included. They run three to six hours each when fully charged. The bits can be tightened without a key, and two double-ended screwdriver bits store in the drill. The Ryobi drill-radio is $49.97 at Home Depot, www.homedepot.com or (800) 430-3376 for stores. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Now on TV, Drug Dealers With Gravity of Mafia Dons
description: We like to denounce television's endless capacity for the banal. But daring television doesn't shed the banal, it injects the banal into the unexpected. It has to. Its shocks usually must be conveyed in just under 30 to 60 minutes. They cannot exceed the belief limits imposed by a familiar and intimate environment: our bedroom, our kitchen, your den. That's why some version of reality TV trickery has always been with us.

title: Mentally Ill Boy Kills Himself in Shelter Hotel
description: Everyone knew Jason-Eric Wilson was a boy with troubles and a troubled mind.

title: Liberty and Mystics Play 2
description: After missing an opportunity Tuesday to clinch a berth in the W.N.B.A. playoffs, the Liberty will have another chance tonight, against the Washington Mystics at Madison Square Garden.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Wilpon Issues a Response To Doubleday's Allegations
description: Fred Wilpon escalated the Mets' simmering ownership feud yesterday by rejecting Nelson Doubleday's allegations that he was the victim of an unfair process in the sale of his half-share of the team to Wilpon.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS TO PAY SOUTHERN UNION FOR MERGER CLAIM
description: The Southwest Gas Corporation, a natural-gas distributor that was the target of two failed takeovers, agreed to pay $17.5 million to settle claims by the Southern Union Company that its 1999 takeover bid was unjustly rejected. The settlement will cost 33 cents a share, Southwest Gas said. Southwest, which has 1.4 million customers in California, Arizona and Nevada, rejected a $1.02 billion offer from Southern Union. It then accepted an offer of $912 million from Oneok Inc., and Southern Union sued. Oneok terminated its deal in January 2000, citing Southern Union's suit and opposition by regulators.

title: Deal on Israeli Withdrawal Collapses After Early Hope
description: As Israeli military forces pressed their offensive on Wednesday, killing at least six Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority provisionally accepted Israel's conditions for a withdrawal from parts of the occupied territories.

title: Doubts Arise in Trade Center Land Swap
description: Nearly one week after word of the proposed trade of World Trade Center land for city-owned land beneath two airports first surfaced publicly, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged yesterday that ''nobody has sat down yet and talked about the money'' or the terms of the deal.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RELIANCE STEEL & ALUMINUM CO., Los Angeles, the U.S.'s fourth-largest metals distributor, said it would buy two distribution units, one in Portland, Ore., and the other in Milwaukee, from bankrupt Metals USA Inc., Houston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Judge Suspends Proceedings In Standoff on War Prisoner
description: In a standoff over the constitutional rights of prisoners captured during the war in Afghanistan, a federal judge in Virginia took the rare action today of suspending all proceedings in a case in which the government has classified a prisoner as an ''enemy combatant'' with almost no legal protections.

title: Cheney Doubts Weapons Inspectors Can End Baghdad's Threat
description: Iraq has so diligently concealed its effort to develop weapons of mass destruction in recent years that the return of international weapons inspectors might be insufficient to eliminate the threat, Vice President Dick Cheney said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Forever Archived

title: U.S. Backs Oil Giant On Lawsuit In Indonesia
description: The State Department is urging a United States court to dismiss a lawsuit brought by a human rights group against Exxon Mobil over its operations in a war-torn province of Indonesia. In response to a request by the corporation for an opinion, the department declared that pursuit of the case would harm Washington's campaign against terrorism.

title: Kangemi Journal; For Spellbinding Soccer, the Juju Man's on the Ball
description: ''Witch doctor,'' says the hand-painted sign on the door of Jackson Ambani's rundown shack. ''Treats all kinds of illnesses. Witchcraft victims. Drowsiness. Heart ailments. Syphilis. Chest problems.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rochester: E. Coli Illness Reported
description: A 3-year-old girl was hospitalized with E. coli O157, a spokeswoman for a children's hospital affiliated with the University of Rochester Medical Center said. The toddler, who was admitted Sunday after suffering from bloody diarrhea, was discharged Tuesday. Her illness was diagnosed as infection with a strain that could lead to kidney failure or death. Other E. coli can live harmlessly in animals and humans. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACGREGOR, JOHN
description: MacGREGOR - John. The Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd. is deeply saddened by the death of our colleague and dear friend on July 25. A devoted member of the Troupe since 1954 and President in 1976, John graced our productions with his sets, costumes, props and graphics, he served on innumerable committees and he will be gratefully remembered by Troupers to whom he was an unselfish and encouraging mentor. We miss him a lot. The BHT Board

title: Aides to Arafat Meet With Powell and National Security Adviser
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  In the highest-level contacts since President Bush made support for Palestinian statehood contingent on Yasir Arafat's removal, three senior Palestinian officials met today with senior officials at the White House and the State Department. They left saying they could make little progress toward peace unless Washington pressed Israel to withdraw from Palestinian areas.

title: G.E. in $1 Million Settlement on Product Safety Issue
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission plans to announce a $1 million settlement today with General Electric for what the agency said was the company's failure to report defects involving more than three million dishwashers made in the 1980's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Store Clerk Is Assaulted
description: A clerk at a Morningside Heights supermarket remained in critical condition yesterday after he struck his head when he confronted a shoplifter who punched him in the face, the police said. His assailant was later arrested, they said. The clerk, Otilio De La Cruz-Lora, 64, stopped the man at the door of C-Town Supermarket after he was seen shoplifting hot dogs at 11:39 a.m. Tuesday, the police said. William Kearney, 29, of the Bronx, has been charged with robbery and assault. Mr. De La Cruz-Lora was in intensive care yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, a hospital spokesman said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Serial Killings Bring Terror To Women of Baton Rouge
description: Some women, even the ones who hate guns, stand three-deep in lines at firing ranges waiting for their chance to shred a paper target that, in their minds, they have painted with the image of a cold-blooded predator.

title: Rusch and Brewers Outdo D'Amico and Mets
description: For the first half of tonight's game against the Brewers, the Mets' Jeff D'Amico appeared ready to take advantage of his old team. Sure, he was trailing by a run, but these are the lowly Brewers and must have been ready to give up the lead at any point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, BABETTE S.
description: MAYER-Babette S. The Board of Directors and members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Babette S. Mayer whose many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. Beth Z. Post, President Roger H. Tulcin, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFEDER, ODETTE FRIEDMAN
description: GOLDFEDER-Odette Friedman. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Manhattan, passed away suddenly on August 5. A graduate of Passaic NJ High School, she is survived by her son Eric Friedman and his wife Liz; her husband Herbert Goldfeder; stepdauthers Madeline I. Berger and Fern Stasiuk and their husbands; a granddaughter and siblings Robert Fiebach and Carol Greenberg and their spouses. Services today, 11:15 AM at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, Manhattan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''WorldCom wasn't operated at all, it was just on auto pilot, using bubble gum and Band-Aids as solutions to its problems.''

title: Global Arms Sales to Developing Nations Are Tumbling, Study Finds
description: International arms sales to the developing world tumbled steeply last year, reaching the lowest level in eight years, as those nations curtailed weapons purchases because of the global economic downturn, according to a new Congressional study.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Being Monitored
description: Martin Ebner's BZ Bank, part of his BZ Group Holding, has been ordered to report daily to Switzerland's Federal Banking Commission about its finances. Swiss regulators, who say they do not dispute that the bank is adequately capitalized, took the unusual step after reports emerged that a group of banks had given the Ebner group a one-year extension to repay its debts. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Schools That Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Suddenly, One House Isn't Enough
description: ''WHEN people lose faith in accountants, lose faith in the clergy and lose faith in the government, and start to trust real estate agents, it's scary,'' said Diane Saatchi, a real estate agent in the Hamptons.

title: A Nominee With Vigor Gives Michigan Democrats Hope
description: At the morning-after unity breakfast, the giants of the Michigan Democratic Party were quiet -- or absent. James J. Blanchard, the only Democratic governor in 40 years, hugged the winner and slipped away. Representative David E. Bonior, who has spent much of his 26 years in Congress in the House leadership, clasped a coffee mug off to the side, clapping politely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNHELL, SIDNEY
description: STERNHELL-Sidney. On August 2nd, 2002, at the age of 80. Adored and devoted husband of Claire (nee Weissbrod) for 58 marvelous years. Much loved and loving father of Carol and Emily. Proud grandpa of Daniel and Benjamin. Cherished fatherin-law of Scott Passeser. Obstinate little brother of the late Charles and the late Arthur (always asked to read the wicked son at family seders). Lifelong fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers, Adlai Stevenson, Cuban cigars, and Claire. A veteran of World War II, Sid built a successful career as a life insurance agency manager but always valued his family most of all. We will miss him!

title: Nicaragua President Demands Corruption Trial for Predecessor
description: President Enrique Bolaos accused his predecessor, Arnoldo Alemn, tonight of having stolen nearly $95 million from his impoverished country's coffers for personal enrichment and demanded that he be stripped of immunity and face trial.

title: Work Starts on North Korea's U.S.-Backed Nuclear Plant
description: With the first Bush administration envoy to visit North Korea joining in a rare ceremony, work began today on the foundation of a long-planned nuclear reactor, by far the largest Western aid project in this Communist nation and one on which its future cooperation with the outside world will hinge.

title: MetroStars and Power Falter on Defense
description: More breakdowns on defense tonight led to the MetroStars' elimination from the United States Open Cup with a 2-1 loss to the Columbus Crew.

title: Tough Keyboard for Hand-Helds Keeps Stains and Spills at Bay
description: Owners of digital organizers who would rather type than tap with a stylus are turning to lightweight keyboards that let them use their hand-helds as miniature laptop computers. A new one with some unusual materials changes the feel of the experience.

title: Officials Link Foreign Web Sites to Cheating on Graduate Admission Exams
description: An undetermined number of students in China, Taiwan and South Korea were able to raise their scores substantially last year on the verbal part of the most widely used entrance exam to American graduate schools by logging on to Web sites in those countries that post questions and answers memorized by previous test takers, test administrators said yesterday.

title: New Method Said to Solve Key Problem In Math
description: Three Indian computer scientists have solved a longstanding mathematics problem by devising a way for a computer to tell quickly and definitively whether a number is prime -- that is, whether it is evenly divisible only by itself and 1.

title: Bloomberg Announces a Revamped Fire Dept. Command Structure With More Chiefs
description: The Fire Department's top management will be expanded and reorganized, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday, moves he said would improve day-to-day operations and make better use of the force's most experienced people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, BLANCHE (NEE HAUPT)
description: SHAPIRO-Blanche (nee Haupt). On August 7, 2002. Wife of the late Saul J. Beloved mother of Ronald and Cornelia and the late Suzanne. Loving sister of Melville and the late Elliot. Loving sister-in-law of Gloria. Adored aunt to her nieces and nephews. She was a care giver extraordinaire. Service Friday, 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: United Online Shares Soar On Results
description: Shares in United Online, the discount Internet service provider formed by the merger of NetZero and Juno, jumped yesterday after the company said that it had narrowed its losses and raised its expectations for the year. For the quarter ending on June 30, United Online reported a net loss of $2.7 million, or 7 cents a share, on revenue of $54.4 million. That compares with a $7.3 million loss, or 19 cents a share, on sales of $50.9 million in the previous quarter. The company says it has 20 million users and expects its paid subscriber base to grow by 25 percent to 28 percent in 2002. It had previously expected an increase of 20 percent to 24 percent. Shares rose $1.43, or 15.1 percent, to $10.90. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GULKOW, ANNA
description: GULKOW-Anna. On August 7, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving sister of Hannah Sacks. Dear aunt of Stanley & Joyce Rabinowitz, Sandra and Stanley Levitt and Seymour Sacks. Services on Friday 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Economic Scene; Let's hear from those who feel government has a role in stabilizing the economy.
description: SO where are the economists?

title: The Pentium-Class Chip And Its Low-Cost Cousin
description: Q. When you are buying a computer for home use, does it matter if the machine has a Celeron or a Pentium processor? What's the difference?

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Mine Bid Extended
description: Placer Dome, the Canadian gold producer, said it had extended the deadline for its $852 million takeover offer for AurionGold until Aug. 16.

title: U.S. Envoy's New Role: Trying to End Indonesia Conflict
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 8  In a new role, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the Bush administration's envoy to the Middle East, met with Indonesian officials here today in an effort to find a solution to the long-running but little publicized guerrilla conflict in Aceh, the nation's resource rich northern province.

title: Daphne Hellman, Harpist With Eclectic Taste, Dies at 86
description: Daphne Bayne Hellman, the jazz harpist who performed around the world and for three decades at the Village Gate but who had a special affection for playing on subway platforms, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Manhattan. She was 86.

title: Wilson, Often Hurt, a Threat at Nationals
description: When the USA Gymnastics championships began today, Blaine Wilson of Columbus, Ohio, was ranked first in many categories.

title: Trash Agency Investigators Seize on Enron Revelations
description: Recent revelations that Enron arranged to receive loans disguised as energy transactions from two of the nation's largest investment banks have strengthened Connecticut investigators' suspicions that the company's $220 million deal with the state trash authority last year was a similarly disguised, but illegal loan.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When Volatile Is the Word, Traders Scramble for Footing
description: Todd Nagel, who trades stocks full time in downtown San Francisco, dismissed Wall Street's biggest event on Tuesday. He was so unconcerned about the news -- the earnings report from Cisco Systems, an ostensible market bellwether -- that shortly after the New York markets had closed, he turned off his computer and headed home for the day.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Acquisition Of Phone Assets
description: Telecom Italia Mobile, Italy's largest cellphone company, said it would buy some of Blu's assets, and rivals would divide up the rest. Telecom Italia Mobile will pay at least 18 million euros ($17.5 million) for 1,400 radio base stations and 830 sites where antennas are placed.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Going Ivy, Coyly

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Power Returns To Homes
description: Electrical service has been restored to virtually all the 200,000 customers in central New Jersey who lost power Friday night after a series of violent thunderstorms. Officials with Jersey Central Power and Light said that about 200 crews were working to re-establish service to the few hundred scattered homes and businesses still affected. State regulators have asked the power company for a report on why tens of thousands were still without electricity on Monday. Ron Morano, a spokesman for the power company, said it had experienced unprecedented damage from the storm. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume in September.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Two Dead In Fires
description: A 7-year-old boy in the Bronx and a man in Queens were killed late Tuesday night in home fires, the authorities said. Investigators have not determined the cause of either blaze. The boy, Jashawn Parker, went into cardiac arrest after inhaling smoke from the two-alarm fire that broke out around 11:30 p.m. in the first-floor apartment where he lived, the police said. Eight other residents and three police officers were treated for minor smoke inhalation, they said. In Queens, the man, 55, whose name was not disclosed, was found dead in his apartment around 10 p.m. after his kitchen erupted in flames, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRENNAN, JAMES A.
description: BRENNAN-James A. Dad, we continue to celebrate your life. All your many loved ones miss you.

title: New Members for a Remade School Board
description: The borough presidents of Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx yesterday announced their appointments to the city's new Panel for Educational Policy, including two former members of a citywide parent group and a retired school district superintendent.

title: Remembering Sept. 11 In a Personal Way, Or Maybe Ignoring It
description: Ask 20 New Yorkers how they plan to observe the anniversary of Sept. 11 and you get at least 10 different answers.

title: East River Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: Decoding North Korea
description: After years of delay, construction began yesterday on one of the two nuclear reactors that a Western consortium is building for North Korea, capping an encouraging few weeks in that country's erratic relations with the outside world. Although President Bush called Pyongyang part of an ''axis of evil'' in January, Washington has wisely decided to explore diplomatic avenues to the extent that the North's unpredictable behavior permits. North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, has sounded reasonable before only to reverse course and embarrass advocates of engagement in Seoul and Washington. The wisest American course for now is to keep open the lines of communication to learn more about Pyongyang's true intentions.

title: Japan Savers May Find They're Paying Banks
description: Racked by deflation and eager to stave off a bank crisis, Japan is considering pushing its rock-bottom interest rates on some bank accounts into uncharted territory: below zero.

title: Reviving an Old Technology for a New Kind of TV Screen
description: WHEN computer manufacturers were making the first laptops two decades ago, some of the flat-panel screens on those ostensibly portable machines glowed with a distinctive yellow light.

title: Iraqi Warns Against Attack in Speech Dismissed by U.S.
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warned today that anyone who attacked his country would be "digging their own graves," in a speech that was dismissed by the Bush Administration as "bluster from an internationally isolated dictator" and viewed with pessimism by the United Nations secretary general.

title: Why the West Is Burning
description: Every summer, we put thousands of young men and women in peril fighting forest fires in the West. This week they are putting their lives at risk in the pinelands of Idaho and Utah, in the chaparral of southern California and in the spruce-fir big woods of the Pacific Northwest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSLEY, HERBERT
description: PINSLEY - Herbert, D.D.S. We will always cherish fifty years of a wonderful friendship. Our deepest sympathy to Deanne, Jimmy, David and Alison. Brenda and Carlin Axelrod and family

title: Advance Puts Atom's Depths Within Range Of Microscope
description: Scientists at I.B.M. and the Nion Corporation have developed an advanced electron microscope optics system that makes possible the creation of the most precise images yet, with resolving power less than the radius of a single hydrogen atom.

title: Burst Bubble Memorial Stadium
description: The erosion of tradition and continuity in professional sports has gone too far. Not only have players and coaches become restless temps, but now even the names of the venues they play in have become transient. In this turbulent economy, in which yesterday's highest bidder may no longer be around today, the New England Patriots have become the third consecutive Super Bowl winners to be forced to change the name of their stadium.

title: Pitching Designs, Not Tents
description: ''I WAS trying to be creative, so I made it curvy,'' said Andrew Schock, describing his latest design, an acoustic batten, which Mr. Schock previewed for the press two weeks ago.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: No Second Helpings on Cukes

title: High School Group's Hazing Was Open Secret, Some Say
description: A day after the police announced that they had arrested 13 current and former members of a high school fraternity for assaulting three freshmen boys in a hazing incident almost two weeks ago, people here said the fraternity and its initiation rites had been an open secret for decades.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Forecast Cut
description: The Bank of England lowered its forecasts for growth and inflation, reducing prospects for an increase in interest rates. Mervyn King, the bank's deputy governor, said falling stock prices could slow both consumer spending and investment. The bank cut its growth forecast to 2.5 percent from 3 percent and said inflation would be below its 2.5 percent target for most of the next two years. Britain's benchmark interest rate has been at a 38-year low of 4 percent since last November and economists have gradually scaled back forecasts of an increase in the fall. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: From Springsteen, a Call to 'Rise Up'
description: Bruce Springsteen recently told an interviewer that he had no desire to be a senator, even though he is far and away the most revered public figure in New Jersey. ''That's a real job,'' he said, ''and a musician's life is spent avoiding hard work.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sporting Goods Profit
description: The sporting equipment and clothing maker Adidas-Salomon posted better results than expected for the second quarter, helped by a 10 percent increase in sales. The company said its profit rose to 25 million euros ($24.3 million) from 24 million euros last year. Sales were up 26 percent in Asia, helped by the World Cup, and 7.7 percent in North America. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: GLOBAL TRADE INCREASES Taiwan's exports and imports rose sharply in July as demand from Asia continued to drive the trade-dependent economy, the government said. Exports grew 14.9 percent, to 379.6 billion Taiwan dollars ($11.2 billion) from a year ago, according to a report from the Ministry of Finance. Imports grew 15.8 percent, to 359.3 billion Taiwan dollars ($10.6 billion), the report said. (Dow Jones/AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABAN, ALBERTO M.
description: SABAN-Alberto M. Age 42 of Tenafly, NJ. Surviving are his wife Claudia, his children Elias, and Shirley, a sister Celia Donzis, his parents Elias and Juana. Services are today 10 am. Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Route #

title: Luxury Car Sales in U.S. Lift Earnings At Toyota
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its profit more than doubled in the first fiscal quarter as a result of strong demand for its luxury models, a weak yen and strong dollar, and a one-time gain from its pension fund.

title: Ex-Executives Say Sham Deal Helped Enron
description: Desperate to meet a year-end profit target, the Enron Corporation struck a sham energy deal with Merrill Lynch that let Enron book a $60 million profit in the final days of December 1999, according to former Enron executives involved in the transaction.

title: Aon Reports U.S. Investigation of Its Accounting
description: Aon, the world's second largest insurance broker, delivered a triple helping of bad news yesterday, including a federal investigation of its accounting, which sent its shares plummeting 30 percent.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Police Group Backs Softer Marijuana Law
description: The state's largest law enforcement group, the Nevada Conference of Police and Sheriffs, endorsed a ballot initiative to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana, saying passage would give officers more time to investigate violent crime. ''Violent crime is on the rise and terrorism remains a real threat,'' the group's president, Andy Anderson, said. ''Our priorities have changed.'' Polls show that Nevadans are about evenly split on the issue, which would become law if it passed in November and again in 2004. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Top Clubs Visiting With Skills And Debts
description: Under a financial cloud, two teams are threatened with elimination. A top league official says the growing gap between rich and poor teams is ruining the sport. As the start of a new season approaches, only a handful of teams have a chance to contend for a championship. The best, big-money players gravitate to the richest teams.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Global Trade Increases
description: Taiwan's exports and imports rose sharply in July as demand from Asia continued to drive the trade-dependent economy, the government said. Exports grew 14.9 percent, to 379.6 billion Taiwan dollars ($11.2 billion) from a year ago, according to a report from the Ministry of Finance. Imports grew 15.8 percent, to 359.3 billion Taiwan dollars ($10.6 billion), the report said.

title: Senior Editor Named For Staff Recruiting, Times Announces
description: Neil Amdur, sports editor of The New York Times since 1990, has been appointed senior editor for staffing/ national recruiting.

title: Knicks Said to Let Deal for Mutombo Slip Away
description: The Knicks spent yesterday completing a deal with the reserve center Michael Doleac. But two high-ranking Eastern Conference officials said the Knicks could have spent the day introducing the eight-time All-Star center Dikembe Mutombo as their newest player.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Amber Alert Expanded
description: The state police and the Department of Transportation are planning to use all the state's flashing highway signs to display news when a child has been abducted, a state police spokesman said. The plan will become part of Connecticut's Amber Alert System, named for Amber Hagerman, above, a Texas girl who was kidnapped and killed in 1996. The system is credited with last week's rescue of two teenage girls in California whose abductor was found after a tip prompted by the system. The alert system, used in 13 other states, notifies television and radio stations, which then broadcast the message. The Connecticut system, almost 10 months old, has not yet been used. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFERS TO BUY REST OF EXCO RESOURCES
description: Exco Resources Inc., which explores for oil and natural gas in the United States and Canada, said its chief executive, Douglas H. Miller, offered to buy the company's stock he does not own for about $206 million in cash plus assumed debt. Including $84.9 million of debt at June 30, the offer is worth $291 million, Exco's president, Ted Eubank, said. Each outstanding share of Exco would be exchanged for $17, a 14 percent premium over Tuesday's closing price of $14.90. Mr. Miller already owns about 8.2 percent of Exco's common shares and 1.8 percent of its preferred stock. A committee of independent directors will be named next week to review the offer.

title: Sports of The Times; Paper Season Comes to End For the Jets
description: TODAY is the first day of the Jets' new life. They open a new season against the Steelers this evening in a preseason game in Pittsburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAKSON, WILLIAM S.
description: SAKSON-William S. On August 6th, 2002, after a long illness. Devoted son of the late Anna and Milton. Loving nephew of the late Frances Finston. A former professor of Business Administration at NYU and Hunter College, who served in the army overseas in World War II. He will be missed by his family and friends. Service today, August 8, 10:30 A.M. at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: A Pop Singer Goes Live, Online
description: In the country's first live Internet interview, a popular singer, Tran Thu Ha, answered questions from fans for two hours. Ms. Ha, 25, has attracted attention for the racy lyrics of some of her songs. Among the 298 online questions she answered was: ''What do you think when some people say you only sing sick and weird songs?'' Ms. Ha answered, ''I think the sickness and weirdness is in the minds of those people, not my songs.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: China Issues New Warning To Taiwan, Just in English
description: China's major English-language news media, meant primarily for foreign consumption, threatened Taiwan today with military action if the island's president, Chen Shui-bian, continued with what Beijing called ''radical pro-independence moves.''

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: POLICE INVESTIGATE SUICIDE RAID Investigators were examining the body of one of three men who blew themselves up with grenades when confronted by the police 25 miles from a missionary school attacked by gunmen on Monday. A deputy inspector general, Tariq Qayuum, said the men had told villagers they had carried out the attack. The bodies of the two other men washed down a river. Six Pakistanis were killed in the attack.

title: Qwest in Switch To Foote, Cone
description: Just four months after selecting the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide to handle its consolidated account, Qwest Communications International has unexpectedly shifted the account to the New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Curbs Urged For Terror Groups
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor, said that if he won election he would push for a state law placing immigration and business restrictions on people associated with a State Department list of terrorist organizations. Mr. Cuomo spoke to reporters in Manhattan by telephone from Israel, where he is traveling. He stopped short of saying Yasir Arafat should be barred from the United States, saying it was for the secretary of state to decide. Mr. Cuomo had earlier called the Palestinian Authority a terrorist organization. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: EXPLOSIONS RATTLE COLOMBIAN CAPITAL DURING INAUGURAL
description: At least 14 people were killed and 40 wounded today by mortar shells in the center of this capital as lvaro Uribe Vlez was sworn in as president. He was elected on a pledge to crack down on Colombia's leftist guerrillas.

title: Forever Archived
description: To the Editor:

title: Forsaking Sanity for the Joys of Candy-Colored Madness
description: ETERNAL DARKNESS: SANITY'S REQUIEM

title: Ecologically Sensitive? Here Are Offices Designed to Soothe You
description: Aveda, an ecological-minded cosmetics company, has commissioned Maya Lin, far left, the architect who designed the Vietnam War Memorial, to turn honeysuckle vines into grass-cloth wallcoverings and sunflower seed shells into burled tabletops for its new 11,000-square-foot penthouse offices. The atrium walls, left, are covered in a rosy paint, which is low in volatile organic compounds. The tables and benches in the atrium, from Jamson Whyte furniture importers in SoHo, are handmade from environmentally sensitive Indian sheesham wood.

title: GTECH APPOINTS TURNER AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE AND PRESIDENT
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation, an operator of lottery games and systems, said W. Bruce Turner had stepped down as chairman to become chief executive and president, replacing Howard Cohen, who resigned. Mr. Turner, 42, was acting chief executive from July 2000 to March 2001 while the company reorganized management, a spokesman, Robert Vincent, said. Mr. Turner was named chairman in July 2000 and has been on Gtech's board since 1999. Mr. Cohen, 55, who became chief executive last year, left to pursue personal and business interests. Gtech is based in West Greenwich, R.I.

title: Observations From the DVR Frontier
description: What I learned from the e-mail reactions to my column last week about the ad-skipping features of TiVo and ReplayTV: First, Americans are fed up with the current state of television. Second, the readers of this e-mail newsletter are a thoughtful and articulate bunch. Here are a few excerpts from your messages:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, JAMES
description: MARX-James. The Finnish American Chamber of Commerce mourns the death of Board Member and friend James M. Marx. As Honorary Counsel of Finland for the State of New Jersey, Jim's passionate work in developing and advancing the business relations between Finland and the United States will be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jim's loving wife Helen and sons Bradley and Douglas. In lieu of Flowers please make donations to the Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club, 283 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10016 and the AmericanScandinavian Foundation, 58 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10016. Christopher Franco President

title: New Jersey D.M.V. Report Finds Fault, and Offers Solutions
description: A commission created to revamp the State Division of Motor Vehicles -- an agency under fire for poor customer service and security lapses -- released an interim report today calling for additional hiring, a faster move to digitized driver's licenses and tighter surveillance of D.M.V. offices after the terror attacks of last September.

title: Bringing Diversity To the Suburbs
description: Advocates for the poor proclaimed a rare victory last week in their long campaign for more affordable housing in the suburbs. They hailed the latest court decision upholding New Jersey's so-called Mount Laurel doctrine, a set of rules designed to open suburbia to low-income families. But if past is prologue, the ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court will mainly benefit builders of mid-priced and luxury homes.

title: Gun in Lawmaker's Hands Claims One Victim: A Door
description: Unlike many candidates in tough primaries, Representative Bob Barr of Georgia did not shoot himself in the foot on Friday.

title: Join the Fight, Mr. Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME WITH/The Carter Family; High on a Hilltop With Music All Around
description: FROM Janette Carter's modest clapboard house in the foothills of Clinch Mountain, the view is down toward a wooden shell marked Neal's Store, once the hub of this rugged community. Ms. Carter, 79, remembers bartering eggs for groceries as a girl, because no one had any money. In those days, Neal's was post office, railroad depot and meeting spot.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: MINE BID EXTENDED Placer Dome , the Canadian gold producer, said it had extended the deadline for its $852 million takeover offer for AurionGold until Aug. 16. (Bloomberg News)

title: SANOFI WINS NEW UNITED STATES PATENT FOR PLAVIX
description: Sanofi-Synthlabo, France's second-biggest drug maker, won a new patent in the United States for the heart treatment Plavix, its No. 2 medicine. The patent covers an improved form of the active ingredient in Plavix, known as clopidogrel bisulfate, and expires in 2019. Plavix is one of Sanofi's fastest-growing products, and studies show it can help reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke and death caused by cardiovascular complications. The French company, which markets Plavix with the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, is trying to protect the drug against competition and plans to ask the Food and Drug Administration to add the latest patent to the list of those it recognizes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORETZ, SELMA B.
description: KORETZ-Selma B. Died on August 7, 2002 at age 80. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Cherished mother to Eileen Koretz Giampaolo and James Koretz. Loved mother-in-law to Jodie Koretz and Joseph Giampaolo. Loving grandmother of Lauren and Casey Angelo and Jonathan, Jeremy and Jesse Koretz. Sister of Arthur Bernholtz and sister-in-law of Beverly Bernholtz. The funeral service was private. Shiva will be at her daughter's home the evening of August 8th and August 9 until sundown. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Society for PSP at www.psp.org or at the Woodholme Medical Building Suite 515, 1838 Greene Tree Rd. Baltimore, MD 21208. For additional information contact Zion Memorial Chapel of Westchester, 914-381-1809.

title: Where Warriors and Ogres Lock Arms Instead of Swords
description: ''NICE ears!'' the young man with the bow and arrow shouted through the crowd to the corseted woman. Her ears were pointy and Vulcanlike. ''I'm guessing, druid?''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Japanese Prisoners' Remains Found
description: The authorities have exhumed the remains of 342 Japanese prisoners of war in Siberia and pledged to return them to Japan, the news agency Interfax reported. The latest discovery of remains was made in a mass grave outside the village of Kvitok, in the Irkutsk region. After World War II, thousands of Japanese prisoners were forced to work as slave laborers in the former Soviet Union. For the last decade, officials have been slowly excavating what are believed to be more than 80 P.O.W. grave sites in the region. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Modern Master Of the Early Piano, Sharing Secrets
description: ''I am a Steinway artist, and proudly so,'' proclaimed the ever-ebullient Robert Levin. This was a little surprising, since Mr. Levin is probably the most famous and admired present-day performer on the fortepiano, meaning the various precursors of the modern-day piano -- like the Steinway.

title: Emotions Beneath the Sondheim Chill
description: The soldier has the shucked, wondering look of a man who is just realizing that he has shed his old skin. Something has happened to Giorgio, the kind of thing that means he will never again see life in the same terms. When his mistress tells him solemnly, ''You've changed,'' the simple words crack like thunder.

title: Citigroup Chief Makes Changes In How Bank Does Business
description: The chief executive of Citigroup, taking the offensive after weeks of negative publicity regarding the company's role in financing Enron and WorldCom, outlined to employees yesterday several changes in the way it does business.

title: News Corp. May Walk Away From Italian Pay TV Deal
description: The News Corporation has become increasingly frustrated at the pace of its negotiations to acquire an Italian pay-television provider from Vivendi Universal of France and could walk away from the deal, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Football Countdown
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums  from Judy Battista's analysis of the Jets' preseason to diverging opinions on Bruce Springsteen's "The Rising."

title: Deftly Dodging the Bullets To Make an Unlikely Slam
description: Anyone who can combine great luck and great skill will do well at bridge, or almost any other activity. The diagramed deal from the final of the Spingold Knockout Teams in Washington a week ago illustrates the point.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: 900 TO LOSE JOBS IN NOKIA NETWORKS UNIT The Nokia Corporation, the world's biggest maker of handsets, said yesterday that it planned to lay off 900 employees in its networks business, or about 5 percent of the unit's work force, as demand for base stations, phone towers and switches faltered. The cuts will "adjust the organization to the current business environment," said a Nokia spokeswoman, Riitta Maard. Earnings at the unit, which accounts for a fifth of total sales, fell 33 percent in the second quarter, Nokia said last month. (Bloomberg News)

title: What's a Parent to Do? Fix the PC, for Starters
description: WAY back in 1995, researchers gave computer and Internet access to 93 families in Pittsburgh and watched what happened. What they found was that teenagers ruled: the researchers coined the term ''teen guru'' to describe youngsters whose digital skills enabled them to usurp the traditional adult role of master of the machinery, bailing out poor old Mom and Dad when they couldn't get the darned PC to work.

title: New England Passion
description: To the Editor:

title: Unlimited Presidential Powers
description: The Justice Department all but told a federal judge this week to take his legitimate concerns about civil liberties and stuff them in the garbage pail. The Bush administration seems to believe, on no good legal authority, that if it calls citizens combatants in the war on terrorism, it can imprison them indefinitely and deprive them of lawyers. It took this misguided position to a ludicrous extreme on Tuesday, insisting that the federal courts could not review its determinations.

title: Getting There, the Old-Fashioned Way
description: ASTRONAUTS preparing for a touchdown on the moon could not have been more alert than my husband and I were the other day as our car neared Exit 17 on the interstate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAVIN, MARJORIE A. (NEE RICE)
description: CLAVIN-Marjorie A. (nee Rice). On August 6, 2002. Beloved wife of the late James R. Loving mother of Marjorie & Daniel McClean, Jean & Donald Cole, Philip & Elizabeth Clavin and Peter & Mary Clavin. Devoted sister of Joan Hastings, Patricia Giordano and Barbara Huggard. Proud grandmother of Carrie Vanderstar (Andrew), Brendan McClean, Lauren Brennan (James), Philip, Michael, Joseph, Matthew, Stephen and Amy Clavin. Also survived by many fond nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews, great friends and neighbors. Lady of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and member of the first graduating class of Fontbonne Hall Academy, 1941. Former active member of the Dr. White, Angel Guardian and the Bay Ridge Garden Club. Visiting Friday, 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Bklyn. A Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10 A.M. at St. Anselm's R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to Juvenile Diabetes Foundation would be greatly appreciated.

title: Federal Appeals Panel Upholds Vermont Limits on Campaign Spending
description: A federal appeals court panel upheld a Vermont campaign-spending law today in a ruling that lawyers said could reverberate far beyond the Green Mountain State and propel the issue of political spending back to the Supreme Court.

title: All Eyes on Pennington For the First Exhibition
description: Vinny Testaverde will come and go, play a series or two, chip off the rust and check the health of his thumb in the Jets' preseason opener Thursday night against the Pittsburgh Steelers. Then the real show will start.

title: A Portable MP3 Player That Plays in a Tape Deck, Too
description: Digisette's Duo-DX E-Cassette is a portable MP3 player and recorder that looks like a souped-up cassette tape. It comes with 96 megabytes of built-in memory, enough to hold about two and a half hours' worth of music, and flash memory cards can bulk it up to 160 megabytes. The player, which measures 2.5 by 4 by 0.45 inches and weighs just a little more than a cassette tape, can also be inserted into a tape deck to play MP3 files through a conventional audio system.

title: Big Screens Ready To Show Pictures On Memory Sticks
description: Getting on television may soon become much simpler. Many of the larger televisions to be introduced by Sony this summer and fall have a slot on the control panel that allows viewers to insert a Memory Stick -- Sony's small removable storage card -- and look at digital photographs right there on the big screen. Using the remote control, a viewer can scan pictures stored on a Memory Stick card individually, as an index or as a slide show.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Miner's Profit Falls
description: BHP Billiton, the world's biggest mining company, said profit fell 12 percent in its fiscal year because of lower prices for products from oil to copper. Profit fell to $1.93 billion, or 32 cents a share, in the year ended June 30 from $2.19 billion, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier, excluding one-time items.

title: Rib Strain Will Keep Barber Out 7 to 10 Days
description: The walkways between practice fields here are covered with gravel, and whenever the golf cart that carried Tiki Barber to the locker room rolled over a small mound of stones, Barber winced in pain, holding his right side.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Pilot Error Cited In Crash
description: The two pilots of an SU-27 fighter jet that crashed at an air show in Lviv, Ukraine, on July 27 deviated from their flight plan and flew too close to spectators, a senior Ukrainian official investigating the crash said. Yevhen Marchuk, chairman of the National Security and Defense Council, ascribed the crash to errors by the pilots, who were trying an unauthorized acrobatic stunt, as well as the poor organization of the air show. Both pilots survived and face prosecution. Another injured spectator died on Monday, raising the death toll to 85. More than 200 people were injured. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Can't Find the TV Remote? It Can Be Right in Your Palmtop
description: The days of pulling out a hand-held computer every 20 minutes to check the value of your investment portfolio may be over, but it's not too late to use a palmtop as a clever remote control. A new software service called ConnectedTV lets users see complete program guides on their Palm OS-based organizers and tap on the listing to tune in a show on a TV.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an operation that separated joined twin girls included an erroneous description from NBC for an observer of the surgery, Houman Hemmati, who commented on the "Today" show about the work of anesthesiologists. He is a medical student, not a medical doctor.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Posts Gain
description: Outpacing its British rivals, the Royal Bank of Scotland said first-half net income rose to 1.34 billion ($2 billion) from 1.1 billion a year ago, while revenues rose by one-fifth to 8.18 billion, helped by acquisitions in Britain and the United States. But, like its competitors, Royal Bank increased its provisions for potential bad debts, reflecting exposure to companies including WorldCom. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: As Chancellor Gerhard Schrder wages an uphill battle for re-election, new economic numbers released today show that Germany's economy, the largest in Europe, is faltering.

title: Newspaper Chain Weighs Stock Offering
description: The board of Freedom Communications, which owns newspapers like The Orange County Register, is reviewing options for restructuring the closely held enterprise, with the emphasis on an initial public offering, people briefed on board discussions say. The move comes as some of Freedom's family owners have been chafing at their inability to cash out their holdings.

title: Railroaded in Texas
description: The malicious intent of the law enforcement authorities in Tulia, Tex., was almost immediately evident as police officers fanned out early on the morning of July 23, 1999. They weren't just going to arrest dozens of the town's black residents for alleged drug trafficking, they were going to publicly humiliate them.

title: F.C.C. to Require Digital Tuners in Most New TVs by 2007
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  Complaining that market forces alone had not assured the transition to digital television, the Federal Communications Commission voted 3-1 today to require television manufacturers to include digital tuners in most every television sold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUNDLICH, ROZA (NEE LOBATTO)
description: FREUNDLICH - Roza (nee Lobatto). Passed away on August 2, 2002 at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was born in Amsterdam on June 25, 1907 and was predeceased by her husband Fred Freundlich and a sister in Holland. She is survived by her brother Fred Lobatto of New York City and her nieces Suzanne Neulander of Wheeling, Illinois and Barbara Taylor of Hamburg, New York. She is also survived by several other nieces and nephews. Her kind and devoted friends Bobbie and Dave Abrahams of New Rochelle and her many friends.

title: First Night Back, and Clemens Is Strong
description: Roger Clemens needed one more strike to end his night on his terms, without exceeding his pitch count. With two out in the seventh inning, the Kansas City Royals' Brent Mayne fouled off three two-strike pitches before Clemens buzzed a fastball too far inside. Ball four, his first walk of the night.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Delaware: Overtime Suit Is Settled
description: Perdue Farms and lawyers representing 60,000 chicken processing workers reached a $10 million settlement over the company's failure to pay workers for time spent putting on and removing clothes and protective gear, estimated at eight minutes a day. James M. Finberg, a lawyer for the workers, said they would each receive about $525 in back wages and that this unpaid time would be added to each worker's pension calculations. This settlement comes three months after the Labor Department and Perdue reached a separate $10 million settlement over identical accusations. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: So who needs leagues? AMF wants you and your family.
description: BOWLING may be more readily associated with vintage lace shoes and league shirts than with contemporary culture. But AMF Bowling Worldwide, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in March, is looking to put bowling back on the family weekend circuit as it begins its first national television commercials in four years.

title: Norman J. Rosen, 73, Deputy To Two District Attorneys
description: Norman J. Rosen, a lawyer who was the top deputy to district attorneys in both Brooklyn and Queens, died Saturday morning at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 73 and lived in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: I.M.F. Agrees to Loan Of $30 Billion for Brazil
description: Confronted with the prospect of another financial meltdown in Latin America, the International Monetary Fund agreed today to a $30 billion rescue loan for Brazil. At the same time, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill was urging Argentina to move quickly to reach a similar accord, saying that the United States will not bail out the government and believes that additional reforms of the Argentine economy are needed.

title: Leukemia Drug Side Effect: Color Returned to Gray Hair
description: In a puzzling and intriguing side effect, a new antileukemia drug has darkened the gray hair of some patients, French doctors reported yesterday.

title: You've Seen the Building, Now Read the Blueprint
description: Images of classic New York structures are now available to architecture buffs and fans of New York. These are reproduction blueprints from J. Pocker & Son, a custom framer and art print dealer, which was established in 1926. Available are the Statue of Liberty (above, 24 inches tall by 16 inches wide), the Chrysler Building, Grand Central Terminal, the New York Stock Exchange and the Empire State Building.

title: Just the Burrow For Your Little Hobbit
description: Do you know a young prince or princess? If so, there is a seven-and-a-half-foot canvas tent playhouse just right for their royal highnesses. It hangs from a branch or hook and comes from England. Amanda Allfrey and Vanessa Birell make it in pink or purple with white stars, above, or in pink, green or light-blue gingham ($275). Delivery can take four weeks; from Fleur, 84 Lexington Avenue, Mount Kisco, N.Y, or (866) 397-3300. Tent castles and cottages also available. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Royalty Rates Will Be Appealed
description: The Recording Industry Association of America and a coalition of Internet radio stations both announced plans yesterday to appeal the royalty rates set by the Librarian of Congress in June for playing songs over the Internet. Both groups said they would file briefs on the contentious issue before the United States Court of Appeals in Washington later this year. The recording industry argues that the rates set by the Librarian are too low and based on erroneous information about the market for Webcasting services. The radio stations say the rates will force many smaller stations out of business before they have a chance to generate revenue from advertising or other sources. On June 20, the Librarian cut the rate proposed by an arbitration panel in half, ruling that Internet radio companies must pay record labels 0.07 cents a song for each listener playing the music online. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Long Island Starts Bragging About Its Tourist Attractions
description: The economic slump and fears of terrorism have crippled tourism at many destinations, but not on Long Island. Now local officials are starting local and national campaigns to expand the island's healthy tourist trade.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Suit Advances
description: A federal civil rights suit brought by black and Hispanic officers against the New York Police Department has been granted class-action status. Without ruling on the suit's merits, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan ruled on Tuesday that it would be inefficient to hold separate trials for individual officers' claims. The suit, filed in 1999 by the Latino Officers Association, accuses the department of creating a hostile work environment for its 6,000 Hispanic and 5,000 black officers. The suit charges that black and Hispanic officers are disciplined more severely and that officers who complain suffer retaliation. The suit asks for unspecified damages, an end to discrimination and for changes in the disciplinary system. The city denies the allegations. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

description: OSLO, Aug. 2  It is a sunny morning, and the Oslo Fjord dances with reflections. Festive pennants flutter from a departing North Sea ferry, bicyclists pedal past the colonnade of the stock exchange building and sleek trams glide by, filled with downtown workers.
