description: Outdoor public sculpture shoots up in New York during the summer, as if in a growth spurt triggered by long days, lazy weather and relaxed expectations.

description: The Hill District, a Pittsburgh neighborhood that has suffered through years of blight and decay, is being rejuvenated by black professionals.

description: These outdoor showers show houses everywhere how to dress down.

title: A Black Enclave in Pittsburgh Is Revived
description: PITTSBURGH  Most people look puzzled when Steven Radney talks about moving from a quiet town south of Pittsburgh into the Hill District, one of the poorest, most beleaguered areas of the city. When they ask gingerly what he hopes to gain from the move, Mr. Radney answers, "an experience."

title: CHAIRMAN IS NAMED AT BARCLAYS GLOBAL INVESTORS
description: Barclays P.L.C. appointed Bob Diamond chairman of Barclays Global Investors yesterday. Mr. Diamond, who will remain chief executive of Barclays Capital, the bank's securities operations, is succeeding Mathew Barrett as the head of Barclays Global, which oversees more than $790 billion, making it the second-biggest manager of institutional investor funds in the world. Mr. Diamond said he hoped to help improve the integration of Barclays Global, based in San Francisco, into the company. Barclays acquired what is now the Barclays Global unit from Wells Fargo and Nikko Securities in 1995 and has since tripled its assets under management. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: A Villager Bicycles Back in Time, Alla Romana
description: It began in Rome, as so many memorable things in my life have, and with a command. ''You must have a bicycle,'' declared my friend Wendy Artin, a longtime Romana and a painter who travels by bicycle to do her shopping, meet her models and set up her drawing board in front of the ruins and crumbs of antiquity. ''It is the best way to unravel this city, and to master it. Movement changes everything. You'll see.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Bank Acquisition
description: The Fubon Financial Holding Company, a Taiwanese financial services conglomerate with life insurance, property insurance, brokerage and banking units, said it had agreed to acquire the Taipeibank Company for $2.4 billion in stock. The acquisition makes Fubon the sixth-largest owner of banks in Taiwan, with $33 billion in assets. The company said it planned to run its Fubon Commercial Bank and Taipeibank separately for at least two years. Citigroup bought a 15-percent stake in Fubon in 2000 that will be diluted to 10 percent if Fubon and Taipeibank shareholders approve the share swap. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Sharon Calls Palestinians 'Corrupt Terrorists'
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 8  Rallying support in a nationally televised speech scheduled at the last minute, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel called Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority "a gang of corrupt terrorists and assassins" tonight and said, "The people will prevail."

title: A House Divided: Perils of Co-Ownership
description: WHEN Peter Gumpel and his wife, Marcia Previti, both Manhattan architects, began looking at weekend homes in East Hampton, it quickly became clear that they couldn't assume the financial burden alone. Fortunately, they had friends in a similar situation. Seventeen years ago, the two couples bought a three-bedroom post-and-beam cedar bungalow, taking out a mortgage on the $132,500 property on East Hampton's Lion Head Beach.

title: Pride in a Flag And Outrage Over Its Theft
description: A CLOTH flag of the United States draped Joseph V. Daly's coffin when he was returned to the American earth.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UST INC., Greenwich, Conn., a maker of smokeless tobacco, said it would resume a stock repurchase plan halted by court order two years ago and buy back up to $500 million worth of its common shares.

title: Taliban Threatens F.B.I. 'Spy' List
description: Letters signed by the ''Taliban Islamic government'' threatening to kill anyone who cooperated with the United States were left at 20 homes on Tuesday night in an area where Pakistani soldiers recently clashed with suspected members of Al Qaeda, officials said.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: 2 MORE REFORMIST NEWSPAPERS BANNED The judiciary shut down two pro-reform newspapers, Rouz-e No and Ayeneh Jonoub, and jailed an activist, Hashem Aghajeri, on charges of insulting the Prophet Muhammad in a speech last month. A lawyer, Nasser Zarafshan, who represents the family of two dissidents slain in 1998 by "rogue" staff members of the Ministry of Information, was also jailed. An appeals court had upheld a five-year jail term and 50 lashes for Mr. Zarafshan for owning weapons and having alcoholic drinks at his home.    Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Returner Aims to Receive
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8  On paper, there seems little way that Chad Morton could find himself a sliver of playing time in the Jets' offense. After all, while he is versatile as a running back, kick returner and wide receiver, he plays on a team that already has the top four receiver spots locked up. And, to add to Morton's disadvantage, all four of those players are taller than he is.

description: If the war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic was supposed to force Serbs to confront their collective guilt for atrocities committed during the 1990's, it has so far failed dismally.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Rogue F.B.I. Worker Sentenced
description: A federal judge yesterday sentenced a former security analyst for the Federal Bureau of Investigation to six years in prison for selling hundreds of confidential federal records to criminals, lawyers and grand jury targets. The former analyst, James J. Hill, pleaded guilty last fall to stealing F.B.I. records, obstructing justice and conspiracy while working in the agency's Las Vegas office. Many of the records involved investigations in New York City and Long Island. The judge, Denis R. Hurley of United States District Court, also required Mr. Hill to be supervised for three years after his release. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: John M. Allen -- Magazine Executive, 75
description: John M. Allen, a retired Reader's Digest executive and former official of the philanthropy set up by the magazine's founders, died on July 31 at his home in Pawling, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Downsizing the Imperial C.E.O.
description: Next Wednesday is D-Day on Wall Street, the deadline for bosses at most major corporations to pledge allegiance to their own companies' financial reports. Wall Street is hoping this requirement will reassure jittery markets, even as legal experts debate the real significance of the exercise. There is some ''to the best of my knowledge'' wiggle room in the certification that the Securities and Exchange Commission has instructed chief executives to sign, and much confusion about the penalties for failing to do so.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Wants Say Over Airports
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that a potential swap of the World Trade Center site for the land owned by the city at its two airports ''would not just be a land-for-land deal,'' because the city ''has to have a say in how the airports are run.'' City officials said previously that they would seek financial compensation for turning over the land to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center property. But skeptics of a swap have suggested the Port Authority would expand Newark Airport at the expense of La Guardia and Kennedy Airports. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Forget About Retirement, There's a Killer to Catch
description: In ''Blood Work,'' Clint Eastwood (who also directed and produced) plays a maverick law-enforcement professional locked into a creepy, codependent relationship with a monstrous serial killer. At this moment, you may be tempted to glance at the top of the page to make sure you are reading today's paper. Haven't we seen this movie already, at least half a dozen times in the last three decades?

title: Quarterly Loss at Qwest Is $1.14 Billion
description: The heavily indebted Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it had met its goal of generating more cash than it spent in the second quarter. Qwest also said it was negotiating new loans and a relaxation of the terms of some existing loans.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: 2 MORE REFORMIST NEWSPAPERS BANNED The judiciary shut down two pro-reform newspapers, Rouz-e No and Ayeneh Jonoub, and jailed an activist, Hashem Aghajeri, on charges of insulting the Prophet Muhammad in a speech last month. A lawyer, Nasser Zarafshan, who represents the family of two dissidents slain in 1998 by "rogue" staff members of the Ministry of Information, was also jailed. An appeals court had upheld a five-year jail term and 50 lashes for Mr. Zarafshan for owning weapons and having alcoholic drinks at his home. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Pension Woes Bring Business Wealth Effect
description: GENERAL MOTORS has a problem. It has promised its workers big pensions and generous health care benefits when they retire. Paying for those promises will not be easy.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Delaware: State Cancels Lotto Show
description: For more than 24 years, Delaware residents have been able to watch their state lottery drawings on television, but that will end today. Lottery officials said a survey had found that only 7 percent of players watched the drawings. Most get the winning numbers from newspapers, and an increasing number rely on the Internet. The lottery broadcasts cost the state $400,000 a year. Indiana did away with its televised lottery drawings last year.

title: Europeans' Fluid Game Is a Treat in New Jersey
description: Two top European teams brought their mesmerizing world-class skills to Giants Stadium and 70,635 fans tonight. Hundreds of their fans may have arrived late, caught in traffic and slowed outside by security checks, but the lure of players like Zinedine Zidane, Roberto Carlos, Luis Figo and Gabriel Batistuta proved irresistible.

title: Sharing a Boat? Forget Fair-Weather Friends
description: THINK buying a second home with your best friends is fraught with pitfalls? Try going in on a boat together.

title: If There's a 'Leipzig Sound,' This Is It
description: It's hard to quantify the characteristics of a given orchestral sound objectively. But if there is a ''Leipzig sound,'' the dark, warm, full-bodied string tone ascribed to the Gewandhaus Orchestra, the Leipzig String Quartet has it. In a concert late Tuesday afternoon, the quartet seemed perfectly suited to its setting at the Frick Collection: like much of the art on the walls, it presented rich, mellow, unadulterated beauty.

title: Delta Promises New Service to Compete With Low-Cost Rivals
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it was developing a new product to compete with low-cost carriers, particularly AirTran Airways, which has been gnawing at Delta's market share on the East Coast.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chemical Maker's Profit Is Up
description: The world's leading chemicals company, BASF, reported an unexpectedly strong performance, with profit rising to 502 million euros ($484 million) from 11 million euros ($10.6 million) a year earlier. The year-earlier period included charges related to restructuring costs. The company said its operating profit, which excludes one-time items, rose to 822 million euros ($794 million) from 751 million euros ($725 million) a year earlier. Sales were steady at 8.4 billion euros ($8.1 billion). Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Bush's Forum on Economy Is to Feature G.O.P. Donors
description: The speakers at a White House economic forum next week near President's Bush ranch will include major corporate donors to the Republican Party and a labor leader whom the administration is courting for support in the 2004 presidential campaign.

title: What Do Iraqis Think About Life After Saddam?
description: Newspapers are making public possible war plans should the United States decide to attack Iraq while Bush administration strategists consider timing. Aid workers, academics and experts debate what comes after a war. Last week, witnesses testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee estimated that rebuilding a stable Iraq could take a 20-year commitment and cost American taxpayers billions of dollars. In all the debate, however, one thing is forgotten: What the Iraqis themselves say about their post-Saddam Hussein future.

title: The City's Hunger Crisis
description: Long hidden by the puffed-up image of abundance, a crisis of hunger in New York City has been worsened by rising unemployment and underemployment since Sept. 11. According to the New York City Coalition Against Hunger, more than one million city residents depend on hard-pressed food pantries and soup kitchens for their basic needs. One-quarter of them are from households with one or more members who have jobs but not enough income to survive. They have turned to charity because all else has failed them.

title: Legroom, More or Less
description: Designing a car that's the right size for every driver is an elusive goal. Automakers have added levers and gizmos to push seats forward and back, up and down. They struggle with headroom. But another issue is the position of the brake and accelerator pedals. A driver with long legs may find the pedals annoyingly close. But for shorter drivers, safety, not just comfort, is involved.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeal Of Kosher-Law Ruling
description: Gov. George E. Pataki plans to appeal the overturning of a state kosher-food law, in which state inspectors help certify food standards, to the Supreme Court. Meanwhile, he has asked a federal appeals court to permit the state to continue enforcing the law, which was overturned in 2000. Last week, the appeals court for the Second Circuit refused to review the ruling and on Wednesday, the state asked the appeals court for permission to continue enforcement. State inspectors help enforce standards defining kosher food as ''prepared in accordance with Orthodox Hebrew religious requirements.'' In August 2000, a judge ruled that the law improperly advanced religion. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Pension Officials to Weigh Influence on Wall St. Ethics
description: On Monday, officials who control pension investments in 12 states and 3 cities will meet in New York to consider how they can force changes in the way Wall Street firms do business, H. Carl McCall, the New York State comptroller, said yesterday.

title: Harlem Survives Protests And Reaches Semifinals
description: The New York state champions from Harlem survived two protests from opposing teams off the field today and a close call from their opponent on the field to continue a drive toward the Little League World Series.

title: With Lewis and Clark on a Trip to the Moon
description: Beautiful and dutiful, ''Lewis & Clark: Great Journey West,'' opening today on the huge screen in the Loews Imax Theater at Lincoln Square in Manhattan, arrays visual spectacle, historical research and sociological sensitivity in a 42-minute retelling of the extraordinary expedition that blazed a trail across early America to its Manifest Destiny at the shores of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Cablevision Will Retrench by Shedding Jobs and Stores
description: Trying to avoid running out of cash next year, Cablevision Systems, the biggest cable television company in the New York City area, outlined a retrenchment plan yesterday that includes cutting jobs, reducing spending, selling movie theaters and closing electronics stores.

title: Union Prepared to Set Strike Date on Monday
description: Nothing short of a deal will deter the executive board of baseball's players union from setting a strike date Monday, people familiar with the union's thinking said yesterday.

title: Neediest Schools Receive Less Money, Report Finds
description: As schools enter a new era of tough federal demands to raise achievement among poor and minority students, a report released here today shows that in most states, school districts with the neediest students receive far less state and local tax money -- an average of just under $1,000 per student -- than schools with the fewest poor children.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: RIGHTIST WEB SITE CLOSED Two days after the government moved to outlaw a neo-Nazi group called Radical Unity, a French judge ordered the group's Web site closed down, noting that it displayed anti-Semitic material in violation of a law prohibiting promotion of hatred and racial violence. Radical Unity, a shadowy group with some 2,000 followers, gained notoriety last month after a member, Maxime Brunerie, tried to kill President Jacques Chirac on Bastille Day. Fabrice Robert, a Radical Unity leader, said the ruling proved that France was a democratic dictatorship.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: CHEMICAL MAKER'S PROFIT IS UP The world's leading chemicals company, BASF , reported an unexpectedly strong performance, with profit rising to 502 million euros ($484 million) from 11 million euros ($10.6 million) a year earlier. The year-earlier period included charges related to restructuring costs. The company said its operating profit, which excludes one-time items, rose to 822 million euros ($794 million) from 751 million euros ($725 million) a year earlier. Sales were steady at 8.4 billion euros ($8.1 billion). Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Mahler and the Lesser Known Stars in His Universe
description: You may have missed a recent item in The International Herald Tribune: ''Maureen Cummins was so captivated the first time she heard something by the composer Joseph Joachim Raff that she ironed several thousand shirts to raise money to help finance a performance of one of his symphonies in London.'' Happily, Ms. Cummins, a housekeeper for a lord and lady, and other Londoners got to hear the fruit of her labors in June at the Chelsea Festival.

title: No Growls, and the Audience Still Purrs
description: Innocence on the verge was the subject of the Scream Tour II, which came to Madison Square Garden on Wednesday and was named for the screams of the teenage girls who nearly filled the arena. It was a rare hip-hop and rhythm-and-blues show with no profanity from the performers, who don't want to alienate the parents of their main audience.

title: Examining Why People Go From Here to There
description: THE ART OF TRAVEL

title: From Jerusalem, A Dream of Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Gymnast Is Also Training as Skater
description: In her spare time, Tabitha Yim likes to surf the Internet. In her spare time, she also likes to play with her two dogs.

title: More Human Remains Found in the Monitor's Gun Turret
description: More human bones have been found inside the gun turret of the sunken Civil War ironclad Monitor, raising the number of recovered victims from one to as many as three, the naval archaeologist who administers the site of the ship's wreckage said yesterday.

title: $1.14 Billion Loss at Qwest
description: Qwest Communications reported a $1.14 billion loss in the second quarter, but it also said that it had met its goal of generating more cash than it spent. Business Day, Page C3.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CITY WANTS SAY OVER AIRPORTS

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Bandujo Donker & Brothers Advertising and Design, Summit, N.J., hired three employees. Todd Goodman was named vice president for marketing; he had been director for marketing at Westwood One, New York. Carrie Dennis was named junior art director; she had been a student. And Amanda Maltese was named an account executive; she had been an assistant account exectuive at MPRM Public Relations, New York.

title: Fumio Yoshimura, Painstaking Sculptor, Dies at 76
description: Fumio Yoshimura, a sculptor known for his highly detailed wooden replicas of plants, machines and a variety of everyday objects, died on July 23 in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESCHER, ALFRED JOSEPH
description: ESCHER-Alfred Joseph. 91 passed on August 8, 2002. Retired New York City Firefighter. Beloved husband of 66 years to recently departed Madeleine Harwood Escher. Devoted father to David, Daniel and Douglas. Loving grandfather to Paul, Jonathan, Suzanne and James. Masonic Services 2 P.M. Friday, August 9 at Aumans Funeral Home, West Redding, PA.

title: In the Pit, As Porsches Rush Past At 140 m.p.h.
description: I STOOD on a low wall near the edge of the racetrack in Watkins Glen, N.Y., one rainy day earlier this summer, watching Porsches fly by at 130 miles per hour, trailed by rooster tails of spray. One car was emitting smoke. I knew what it was from -- a failing gasket that had been patched with epoxy earlier that day. Along with the other members of his pit crew, I hoped that the driver, David Lloyd, would make it through the race.

title: Australia Wins 25-Year Deal to Supply Gas to China
description: China said today that it had chosen Australia to supply it with $11 billion to $13 billion of liquefied natural gas over the next 25 years. The Australian bid won the contract, one of the largest and most politically contested energy deals this year, over rival proposals from Indonesia and Qatar.

title: Buying Group For Hospitals Vows Change
description: The largest group in the country that helps hospitals buy products said yesterday that it would fundamentally change its policies to make it easier for new, lifesaving medical products to reach hospitals faster.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SPRINT COMPLETES A 3RD-GENERATION NETWORK Sprint announced the completion of its Third Generation network for wireless voice and data communications yesterday, making it the first United States carrier to get the long-awaited technology in place nationwide. Data speeds on the enhanced 3G 1X network are expected to be 50 to 70 kilobits per second on the average, with peak speeds of up to 144 kbps. Along with the improved network comes the introduction of Sprint PCS Vision, a new collection of products and combined voice and data service plans, which include Sprint-branded Handspring Treo 300 organizers and cards for laptop and hand-held computers for wireless Internet access over the Sprint network. New phones with color screens, games, screen savers, Web browsing, chat and e-mail capabilities  plus special applications for corporate users  are also part of Sprint PCS Vision.

title: Whistleblower wins ruling in UN Bosnia case
description: PARIS:  A British tribunal has ruled that a former member of the UN police force in Bosnia was unfairly fired after she reported to her superiors that colleagues in the police force used women and children as sex slaves in connivance with Balkan traffickers.

title: Raises Sought by the Police Appear Increasingly Remote
description: The city's 24,000 police officers and their union, outflanked by a worsening economy and the drain on city resources since the Sept. 11 attack, are facing the prospect that the large pay increases they have sought appear remote.

title: Teenager Slain Outside School In the Bronx
description: A young man on his way to classes at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx was stabbed to death yesterday morning by a fellow summer school student who worked as a youth counselor, the authorities said.

title: In Democratic Race for Governor, Tension at New Level
description: Tension among the Democratic candidates for governor reached a new level yesterday as Andrew M. Cuomo released a television commercial that State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's campaign called the race's first attack advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESFELD, SHIRLEY
description: GOTTESFELD-Shirley, on August 7, 2002. Beloved and devoted mother of Suzy and Steven. A gentle and courageous original. Our best friend-we will miss you.

title: If a Medium Loses Its Message, Is It Still a Medium?
description: The exhibition ''Visions From America: Photographs From the Whitney Museum of American Art, 1940-2001,'' tells the tale of how photography took over contemporary art. Along the way, though, it suggests that by the time photography rose to power, it was not quite feeling itself anymore.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: INTEL WON'T COUNT OPTIONS AS EXPENSE Defying the recent trend among companies to count stock option costs as a regular expense, the Intel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to continue accounting for employees' stock options the way it had been, which adds no cost to the company's bottom line. The company, the world's largest maker of computer chips, called the current debate over stock options misdirected. "We prefer the intrinsic value method because we think it provides a more accurate reflection of company operations," said Andy Bryant, Intel's chief financial and enterprise services officer, in a prepared statement. A number of companies, including General Electric and Coca-Cola , have agreed to count options as a regular expense, but most technology companies oppose the move, saying they rely more heavily on option grants as a key component of employee compensation. Shares in a number of chip makers surged yesterday. Intel shares rose 67 cents, or 3.8 percent, to $18.39.

title: Ex-Enron Unit Settles An Accounting Case
description: Northern Natural Gas, a pipeline company formerly owned by Enron, has settled a federal complaint about its borrowing and accounting practices. The company, now owned by Dynegy, will not be allowed to use rate increases to repay loans backed by its pipelines.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about a robot that fulfilled the requirements of a ''robot challenge'' at a conference in Edmonton, Alberta, misattributed a quotation about the mundane nature of the tasks completed by the device. It was Alan C. Schultz, a creator of the robot, not his colleague Reid Simmons, who said: ''It's true -- it's not the most exciting thing. But we wanted to see if we could get a robot to do something that normal humans do. This seemed like a good thing to try.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARHI, CAROL RUSKIN
description: FARHI-Carol Ruskin, on August 7, 2002, at home. Beloved wife of Jean-Pierre; mother of Jacques, Paul and Jane. Service Friday, Aug. 9th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: As Rivera Returns, So Does Normalcy
description: The Yankees already had the best record in the American League, and on each of the last two days, a future Hall of Famer has returned to their pitching staff. Roger Clemens came back Wednesday, Mariano Rivera yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEPICS, PAUL
description: KEPICS-Paul. The Board of Trustees of Town Hall, his colleagues and friends mourn the death of one of our dearest and most devoted employees. Paul Kepics was passionate in his work, vital to the organization and had the greatest appreciation for this New York City landmark that he served so well. He will be missed by everyone. Marvin Leffler, President Lawrence Zucker, Exec Dir

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Shares Drop After Removal From Index
description: Shares of Palm Inc. fell as much as 18 percent yesterday after Standard & Poor's said Palm, the hand-held computer maker, would be dropped from its index. Palm shares dropped 16 cents, or 16.3 percent, to 82 cents and traded as low as 78 cents. Shares of companies removed from the S.&. P. 500 often fall, and those added often rise, as managers of about $800 billion in funds seek to match the index's performance by adjusting their holdings. Palm's market capitalization has fallen by more than $52 billion, to $568 million. The value was once greater than Ford Motor's. Palm was replaced in the S.& P. 500 yesterday by the Monsanto Company, an agricultural chemicals maker being spun off by Pharmacia. Shares of Pharmacia rose $2.05, to $46.25. Palm's sales fell 38 percent last year, to $1.03 billion from $1.6 billion. The shares reached $165 on March 2, 2000, their first day of public trading.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about sexually active couples in the South who agree to a period of abstinence before marriage, largely out of religious concerns, misstated Roman Catholic practice. Sexual abstinence is not prescribed for married couples during Lent.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: There's a new captain at Oceana, the Midtown seafood specialist, where you can duck in for a light but delicious lunch and feel as if you've set off aboard an intimate, luxurious yacht. Michael Schenk took over the kitchen a couple of months ago for Rick Moonen, who, after eight years, left to open his own restaurant.

title: INSIDE
description: Hospitals' Buyer to Change

title: Palm Springs in August: The Ducks Use Sunblock
description: AS a vacation port of call, Southern California has got it all. It's like a giant geographic theme park. Want to lap up glistening waves and bury your feet in the sand? The beach beckons. How about thick forests with fir- and pine-covered mountains? The majestic Angeles National Forest is a quick drive from Los Angeles. I prefer to use Dante's ''Inferno'' as my Baedeker. Every summer, whenever I get the itch for a little rest and relaxation, I venture deep into the inner circle of hell -- otherwise known as Palm Springs.

description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9  Palestinian officials today accused Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel of trying to sabotage talks in Washington between their representatives and the Bush administration with a tough speech calling Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority "a gang of corrupt terrorists and assassins."

title: Mayor Wants Investigation Into Homeless Boy's Death
description: Calling the suicide of a teenager in a homeless shelter a tragedy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg asked commissioners to investigate several aspects of the case yesterday, including how long it took for an ambulance to arrive at the scene, and whether better coordination between the city's social service agencies could prevent similar incidents.

title: A Democrat Who Found a Home in Westchester
description: ANDREW J. SPANO, history teacher and son of a Bronx tavern owner, was house-hunting 40 years ago, looking for something a young husband and father could afford on a New York City Board of Education salary.

title: Bombay Journal; The Mobster and the Movie Star: A Melodrama
description: The enormous glass wall in the coffee shop at the J. W. Marriott Hotel here keeps the gray sky and sea out -- and simultaneously invites them in. In this hot spot of Bollywood's beau monde, the wall perfectly reflects the ambivalent relationship between the film crowd and the underworld dons who endlessly circle from abroad, menacing and enticing.

title: Settlement Offers Fail to End Trade Center Insurance Battle
description: Larry A. Silverstein, the developer, and Swiss Re, a major insurer of the World Trade Center, submitted settlement offers to a federal judge yesterday and then resumed their battle over insurance coverage of the trade center.

title: Lawyers for 9/11 Defendant Seek 2-Month Delay in Trial
description: Court-appointed lawyers for Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, called today for his trial to be delayed by at least two months because of the huge volume of prosecution evidence that they need to review before jury selection.

title: Wounded Party Ponders, Should It Be Gore in 2004?
description: Democratic Party leaders said today that Al Gore would have to overcome deep resentment over his 2000 campaign for president -- and catapult over a field of new faces running for the White House -- if he wanted his party's nomination in 2004.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Boot Camp Settlement
description: The state will pay almost $4.6 million to settle legal claims by youths who say they were abused at three state juvenile boot camps. Under the settlement, given final approval by the Board of Public Works, $2.1 million will go toward scholarships for college, trade school or remedial education for more than 300 juveniles who were held in the Western Maryland camps. Another $1.8 million will go to 61 people beaten by guards, and $680,000 will pay fees for lawyers who represented the youths. The Baltimore Sun revealed in 1999 that guards at the camps had routinely assaulted teenagers. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: For the Summer, at Least, an M.I.T. Education
description: There are no formal classes in this summer school, nor any teachers per se. There are instead 60 college students, and each instructs one or two youths.

title: Deciding Who Is to Be Protected Against Smallpox
description: Should Americans be allowed to make an informed choice to receive the smallpox vaccine? I believe they should and that individual choice should become the central component of a new national policy aimed at protecting us from the possible use of smallpox as a weapon of mass destruction by terrorists.

title: Weekender | Milford, Pa.
description: AT the far edge of daily commuting distance from Manhattan lies Milford, a fortunate town that is both historic and scenic, and that has become a popular spot for second homes. The small town center still looks rustic and Victorian, and residents are at pains to keep it that way. But the part timers, along with the occasional hardy commuter who accepts the two-hour trek to New York, have hastened the addition of quaint shops, chamber music, a film festival and the sort of restaurant that needs a sommelier.

title: Roaring Into Town and Saying, 'Excuse Me'
description: THE man who called himself Texas Heartbreaker was 6 feet 3 inches and 260 pounds, with hands the size of Texas steaks. Even at 55, he was one of the fiercest-looking bikers at a rest stop on Interstate 90 last Sunday, taking a break on the way across South Dakota.

description: WHO -- Lena Gieseke, a photographer, and Charles Guimont, a construction coordinator and a writer.

title: HONEYWELL TO BUY ULTRAK'S CLOSED-CIRCUIT TV UNIT
description: Honeywell International plans to buy Ultrak's closed-circuit television business for $36 million in cash plus trade liabilities to expand the security controls and sensors it offers. Ultrak will receive $30.6 million at closing, and the rest in three installments over 18 months, the companies said. The transaction is expected to close in about two to three months.

title: Officials to Tour Federal Plaza For Street-Level Look at Security
description: The debate over bolstering security around Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan moves from the conference room to the streets this morning, as city and federal agencies tour the blocks around Duane and Reade Streets, seeking to balance safety and accessibility.

title: Is the Staff Really Rude Or Just Being, Well, French?
description: Jesse Peretz's video feature ''The Chateau'' presents the latest installment of the continuing drama that is French-American relations. The premise is familiar from old comic horror films: two nave Americans inherit a castle in the European countryside, and when they arrive to claim their prize, they find a decaying Gothic nightmare, loaded with debt and in drastic need of repair.

title: A Reply to Perceived Attacks
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the former secretary of housing and a Democratic candidate for governor in the Sept. 10 primary, released a 30-second advertisement that will be shown today on New York City stations and run for about 10 days, his campaign aides said.

title: In Democratic Race for Governor, Tension at New Level
description: Tension among the Democratic candidates for governor reached a new level yesterday as Andrew M. Cuomo released a television commercial that State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's campaign called the race's first attack advertising.

title: British Insurer Falls 21% After Talk of New Share Issue
description: The Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group of Britain lost more than one-fifth of its market value today, sending its stock to a 14-year low, after the company said it might try to raise cash by issuing new shares next year.

description: Aidan Fontana is a 6-year-old boy whose father died at the World Trade Center.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 19 and July 31 about Barry and Judith Smiley, who were sentenced last month in the kidnapping of an infant whom they raised as their son, misstated their legal connection to him. The Smileys had not adopted the child, whom they raised under the name Matthew Propp; he had been placed in their custody and they were trying to adopt him. Custody was awarded to his biological parents in 1979.

title: WORLDCOM FINDS $3.3 BILLION MORE IN IRREGULARITIES
description: WorldCom, which sought bankruptcy protection last month after disclosing that it had improperly accounted for $3.8 billion in recent expenses, said last night that it had uncovered $3.3 billion in additional accounting irregularities stretching back to 1999.

description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation's $11.8 billion takeover of TRW Inc. has no ''showstopper'' antitrust issues, even as other military contractors worry they might lose access to products the two companies produce, the Pentagon's top acquisition official said.

description: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, concerned about rising medical costs, said yesterday that his agency planned to step up scrutiny of past hospital mergers and groups of doctors to make sure they had not joined forces simply to fix prices.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Indonesian Workers Depart
description: More than 400,000 Indonesians who had worked in Malaysia for years without valid documents have fled in the past month. A new law sets penalties for illegal entry of a mandatory six months in jail and whipping. An Immigration Department spokesman said thousands of Indonesians had been arrested last weekend. Workers from Myanmar, Nepal, Cambodia, Vietnam and Central Asia were expected to fill some of the jobs being vacated by Indonesians. Baradan Kuppusamy (NYT)

title: Martha Stewart May Receive A Subpoena From Congress
description: A day after the founder of ImClone Systems was indicted on charges of insider trading and bank fraud, the spokesman for a Congressional committee looking into Martha Stewart's sale of ImClone shares said the panel might subpoena her to testify.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on Sunday about the difficulty of seeking tenure while rearing children misspelled the surname of a researcher with the American Association of University Women who cited the notion of collegiality as a criterion for tenure decisions. She is Pamela Haag, not Haig.

title: TV Weekend; For a Secret Service Agent, Work Outranks Marriage
description: If those warehouse megastores sold television movies alongside the cases of cola and kegs of ketchup, you might find ''First Shot'' inside a shrink-wrapped plastic Tub o' TV. This drama is professionally made, predictable and inoffensive, with clearly distinguishable good guys and bad guys. No ambiguity or subtlety intrudes upon the storytelling.

title: Simon Frost -- 'Ukhamba'
description: Peter Blum

title: Johnson Appeals Disqualification
description: Kirk Johnson, a heavyweight who was disqualified from the July 27 World Boxing Association title fight against John Ruiz in Las Vegas for landing low blows, wants the decision overturned because the referee was biased, Johnson's promoter said yesterday.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a $1 million settlement between General Electric and the Consumer Product Safety Commission involving defective switches in dishwashers made in the 1980's misstated the period in which the company received 49 complaints. It was over six years, not all in 1992.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You might say they've left Pluto and reached Mars. This sounds like very central change, and not tinkering at the margins, but it is still a long ways to Earth.''

title: Nets Leave Cablevision and Join YES
description: The Nets signed a 10-year deal yesterday to join the Yankees on the YES Network, ending a long relationship with Cablevision's Fox Sports New York channel.

title: Punishment Weighed in Fraternity Hazing
description: Officials are considering how to punish the group of high school students accused of beating three freshmen so hard with a paddle in a hazing incident last month that they were treated at a hospital, the schools superintendent said today.

title: Bottom Feeding From Her Place at the Top
description: ''Do you think Italian cinema is dying?'' someone asks Anna Battista, the Italian movie star whose tawdry travails are the subject of Asia Argento's ''Scarlet Diva,'' which opens today in Manhattan. Probably not, but this operatically sleazy study in sexual abandon and druggy desperation, in which Ms. Argento also stars, shows symptoms of a decadence that might well be terminal. It is, by conventional standards, a fairly terrible movie -- crudely shot on digital video, indifferently acted (in three languages) and chaotically written (by Ms. Argento) -- but it is also weirdly fascinating, a ready-made Eurotrash cult object. It is also, at times, curiously moving.

title: Alberta Struggles to Balance Water Needs and Oil
description: Alberta's oil companies use nearly half as much water as the entire city of Calgary, the province's commercial center, which has a population of almost a million. So it is hardly surprising, with much of western Canada still in the grip of its worst drought in decades, that the oil industry's water consumption has become a bone of contention.

title: British Court Frees Muslim Accused of Recruiting Terrorists
description: LONDON, Aug. 9  A British court today freed a 44-year-old Muslim who was arrested after the Sept. 11 attacks last year and accused of recruiting Islamic terrorists on an Internet site that offered the "ultimate jihad experience" of live-fire military training.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGMAN, MARTIN
description: WAGMAN-Martin. On August 8th, 2002. Beloved husband of Adela. Devoted father of Franklin and Paige, Julie and Chip Logan, Remy Wagman & Jessica Mindick. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Tyler and Max. Services Today, 1:30 PM at 98-60 Queens Boulevard. (at 66th Avenue) Forest Hills, 718896-5252. Interment to follow at Mount Hebron Cemetery. Gutterman Inc. Directors.

title: Don't Know the Nominee? Please Just Vote, Anyway
description: A lighthearted, whimsical comedy about the blossoming of democracy in Iran must necessarily be either incredibly calculating or incredibly nave. But ''Secret Ballot,'' a new Iranian feature from Babak Payami (whose ''One More Day'' made the festival rounds a couple of years ago), is never clearly one or the other.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORROW, JAMES P. (JIMMY)
description: MORROW-James P. (Jimmy). August 9, 2001. With remembrance. Love, Joan, Carol and Steven

title: Wholesale Prices And Jobless Claims Decrease Slightly
description: Wholesale prices of food, cars and computers fell in July, the third decline in four months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPER, SCOTT
description: KEMPER-Scott. October 9, 1946-August 3, 2002. A man of great dignity who leaves a family of friends worldwide. The reality of him will grow distant but not less powerful.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Rightist Web Site Closed
description: Two days after the government moved to outlaw a neo-Nazi group called Radical Unity, a French judge ordered the group's Web site closed down, noting that it displayed anti-Semitic material in violation of a law prohibiting promotion of hatred and racial violence. Radical Unity, a shadowy group with some 2,000 followers, gained notoriety last month after a member, Maxime Brunerie, tried to kill President Jacques Chirac on Bastille Day. Fabrice Robert, a Radical Unity leader, said the ruling proved that France was a democratic dictatorship. Alan Riding (NYT)

title: Colombian Flies to Rebel Territory and Issues Challenge
description: Resolute one day after a mortar attack by rebels during his inauguration, Colombia's new president, lvaro Uribe Vlez, traveled to this lawless northern region today to help set up a plan to combat the guerrillas by recruiting an army of civilian informers.

title: Editorial Observer; Feminists: More to Talk About Than Shoes and Lipstick
description: We keep arguing about lipstick. The 70's feminists think young women today wear too much of it and not enough ''Down With Patriarchy'' pins. Young feminists insist they have a right to equal pay, gender bending and use of their Barbie lunchboxes as makeup bags. This generation gap has been the way to talk about the women's rights movement for the past decade. It's let us skip over the deeper divides between women.

title: Analysis Shows That Williams Did Sign Note
description: A forensic analysis of a signed note, in which Ted Williams asked to be cryonically preserved upon his death, offered little doubt that the signature belonged to him.

title: Bankruptcy Bill Opponents Criticize Loan
description: In an effort to block a bill sought by credit card companies to overhaul the nation's bankruptcy laws, opponents are pressing for an investigation into the relationship between a major credit card issuer and an important House sponsor who received a $447,500 loan from the company on what appeared to be highly favorable terms.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sharon Calls Palestinians 'Corrupt Terrorists'
description: Rallying support in a nationally televised speech scheduled at the last minute, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel called Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority ''a gang of corrupt terrorists and assassins'' tonight and said, ''The people will prevail.''

title: Dead End for Cambodians Who Grew So American
description: On the basketball court, they seem like just a couple of young American guys in big sneakers and baggy shorts, part of a pickup game on the banks of the Mekong River.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Services Suit
description: A Russian oil concern, Yukos Oil, had a victory in an American court battle against Dardana, an investment company that says Yukos owes it $17 million. A federal judge on Wednesday refused to confirm Dardanas's claim that Yukos shirked payment for oil services in the mid-1990's in Russia and transferred the case to state court. Yukos, Russia's No. 2 oil producer, shipped a tanker of oil to Texas on July 3, but payment for the oil was frozen by the court. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Unions and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, BLANCHE (NEE HAUPT)
description: SHAPIRO-Blanche (nee Haupt). On August 7, 2002. Wife of the late Saul J. Beloved mother of Ronald and Cornelia and the late Suzanne. Loving sister of Melville and the late Elliot. Loving sister-in-law of Gloria. Adored aunt to her nieces and nephews. She was a care giver extraordinaire. Service Friday, 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Units on Rise Near City Hall
description: Until recently, there was no particular status attached to the perimeter of City Hall Park, but with the transformation of several office buildings into luxury dwellings and the restoration of the park, the neighborhood is becoming distinctly prestigious.

title: Can Workers Rescue the Market?
description: To the Editor:

title: Springsteen Issues a Call To 'Rise Up' After 9/11
description: Bruce Springsteen recently told an interviewer that he had no desire to be a senator, even though he is far and away the most revered public figure in New Jersey. ''That's a real job,'' he said, ''and a musician's life is spent avoiding hard work.''

title: National Briefing | West: Butterfly Wins Protection
description: A tiny butterfly that is found only in parts of Nevada and California has been given permanent protection under the Endangered Species Act. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service took temporary emergency action last year when the habitat of the butterfly, the Carson wandering skipper, was threatened by water projects and other development. Any development projects in the butterfly's habitat must now get approval from the government agency. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Palestinians, Meeting Powell, Urge Pullout
description: In the highest-level contacts since President Bush made support for Palestinian statehood contingent on Yasir Arafat's removal, three Palestinian officials appointed by Mr. Arafat met today with senior officials at the White House and State Department.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Share Limit Raised
description: A telephone company, the KT Corporation, plans to raise the limit on foreign ownership to 49 percent of the company from 37.2 percent. KT, which provides most of Korea's telephone service, decided to raise the limit largely as a result of demand overseas for its American depository receipts. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Officials Question Credibility of New Threats
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  New information warning of possible terrorist threats against bridges has been received by United States intelligence agencies, but officials played down its significance today, saying its credibility is uncertain.

title: Marcos Kurtycz
description: P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center

title: Everybody Who's Anybody Is Entering Connecticut Politics
description: So far, no dead people have registered to run for governor, but give them some time. A federal judge on Monday opened up Connecticut's September primaries to any of the state's two million registered voters, and he did not explicitly exclude those without a pulse.

title: Bloomberg Seeks to Ban Smoking In Every City Restaurant and Bar
description: The Bloomberg administration will ask the City Council to amend New York City's antismoking law to include all restaurants and bars, making it one of the toughest in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOWLING, STEVEN PAUL
description: NOWLING-Steven Paul. November 23, 1950 to August 3, 2002. The family, friends, and co-workers of Steve Nowling mourn his unexpected death. He was much loved for his vibrant spirit, generosity, and wry wit. Steve's life was dedicated to those in need: as an intern in Louisville KY at the Catholic Worker, as an RN and nurse practitioner at St. Vincent, Manhattan with AIDS patients and the AIDS clinical trials unit at Beth Israel Medical Center. He is survived by his daughter Amber, father Jack, sisters Margaret, Judith, Mary, Carolyn; brothers Michael and Christopher. We invite his friends and co-workers to join us in celebration of his life on Sunday, August 11 at the Church of the Ascension, 221 West 107 Street (betw B'way and Amsterdam). Mass 3:30 PM, reception 5:00-6:30 PM.

title: I.M.F. Loan To Brazil Also Shields U.S. Interests
description: To hear the Bush administration tell the story, there is one main reason that Brazil should be rescued with a $30 billion loan while Argentina should get nothing: Brazil has been good; Argentina has been bad.

title: Shostakovich, or Shooting the Rapids?
description: IT'S around 3 on a Sunday afternoon in early August. Hundreds of people are stretched out on blankets that cover acres of rolling hillside, picnic baskets unpacked, wine bottles opened and the strands of Bruch's Violin Concerto No. 1 wafting over the crowd. It's another perfect day at the Tanglewood music festival in Lenox, Mass.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: NIXON DAUGHTERS END DISPUTE

title: G.I. Hit on Afghan Patrol In a Third Day of Attacks
description: An American soldier was wounded by a sniper's bullet while on patrol in southeastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, the third day in a row American troops had come under attack while searching for members of Al Qaeda and the Taliban.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Completes A 3rd-Generation Network
description: Sprint announced the completion of its Third Generation network for wireless voice and data communications yesterday, making it the first United States carrier to get the long-awaited technology in place nationwide. Data speeds on the enhanced 3G 1X network are expected to be 50 to 70 kilobits per second on the average, with peak speeds of up to 144 kbps. Along with the improved network comes the introduction of Sprint PCS Vision, a new collection of products and combined voice and data service plans, which include Sprint-branded Handspring Treo 300 organizers and cards for laptop and hand-held computers for wireless Internet access over the Sprint network. New phones with color screens, games, screen savers, Web browsing, chat and e-mail capabilities -- plus special applications for corporate users -- are also part of Sprint PCS Vision. J. D. Biersdorfer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, ELLA
description: SCHAEFFER-Ella. Beloved mother of Dr. Alice Nadelman and Dr. Nancy Braman, (sons-in-law Manny and Stuart). Devoted wife of 59 years of the late Lou Schaeffer. Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Joel, Jonathan and Daniel. Caring sister of Kay Raab. Services today 11:15am ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Rain or Shine, Residing Outdoors
description: PUBLIC sculpture in New York is a summertime thing. New work suddenly shoots up outdoors around the city as if in a growth spurt triggered by long days, lazy weather and relaxed expectations. Certain arrivals are solid and polished; they could easily outlast the season, and a few are meant to do so. Others are made quickly, on the cheap, and have a decorative, accidental, disposable air. (The architect James Wines once coined the cruel phrase ''plop art'' to describe them.)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Officials Agree To Voting Changes
description: Miami-Dade County has agreed to make changes in its voting practices to settle a lawsuit that said ballot problems disenfranchised black voters in the 2000 presidential election. The proposed settlement came less than three weeks before the scheduled start of a trial on the lawsuit, filed by the N.A.A.C.P. and other civil rights groups. The agreement must be approved by Judge Alan Gold of Federal District Court. Under the agreement, election officials will modify voter registration, voter-roll maintenance and polling practices.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Father Sentenced In Death
description: A man who was convicted last month on two counts of second-degree murder in the starvation death of his 4-year-old daughter was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison, the maximum term. The child, Nadine Lockwood, died in 1996 just before her fifth birthday, weighing only 15 1/2 pounds. The man, Leroy Dickerson of the Bronx, protested his innocence until minutes before Justice Michael J. Obus declared him ''the farthest thing from a responsible father.''

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Exhibition

title: This Skateboard Uses High Octane
description: ''Think PlayStation,'' bellows Xander Cage (Vin Diesel) during a key action sequence in the director Rob Cohen's ''XXX.'' This is perhaps the silliest movie ever to certify the arrival of a major star since, well, ''The Fast and the Furious,'' the last Cohen-Diesel collaboration. They've become the Kurosawa-Mifune of the Mountain Dew Generation, which is half a compliment -- but only half.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEAGLE, RHODA WALKER
description: TEAGLE-Rhoda Walker. August 9, 2001. In loving memory from your family. We miss you very much

title: AOL Time Warner Near Deal on a Unit, Again
description: AOL Time Warner, AT&T and Comcast are nearing a deal to dissolve the Time Warner Entertainment venture and could announce an agreement as soon as early next week, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Adding Up the Stats Makes Pettitte No. 1
description: There were so many times this year when a worried Andy Pettitte wondered whether he would ever pitch as effectively as he had the last seven seasons. Pettitte first experienced pain in his left elbow in March and went on the disabled list two weeks into the season, when everything in baseball is supposed to be serene. His orderly world became muddled after that.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Won't Count Options As Expense
description: Defying the recent trend among companies to count stock option costs as a regular expense, the Intel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to continue accounting for employees' stock options the way it had been, which adds no cost to the company's bottom line. The company, the world's largest maker of computer chips, called the current debate over stock options misdirected. ''We prefer the intrinsic value method because we think it provides a more accurate reflection of company operations,'' said Andy Bryant, Intel's chief financial and enterprise services officer, in a prepared statement. A number of companies, including General Electric and Coca-Cola, have agreed to count options as a regular expense, but most technology companies oppose the move, saying they rely more heavily on option grants as a key component of employee compensation. Shares in a number of chip makers surged yesterday. Intel shares rose 67 cents, or 3.8 percent, to $18.39. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; One Family Still at Home In Zimbabwe
description: WHEN Don Black died, when his long tennis life was over, his wife and children were left with no specific directive on what to do with his ashes. Without much debate or fanfare, the family gathered to spread the remains around its lush compound in sub-Saharan splendor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, BERTHA MARGOLIS
description: JAFFE-Bertha Margolis. On August 4th in Palm Desert, CA in her 91st year. Beloved wife of the late Irving Jaffe and loving mother of Mark Jaffe and Beth Pressman; grandmother of Kimberly & Lauren Pressman; mother-inlaw of June Jaffe and sister of Theresa Hahn. Caring, charitable and courageous, she was a grammar school teacher in New Jersey as a young woman and returned to that career in mid life. With her husband she early recognized the potential development of Tribeca as a residential neighborhood and was active in the real estate business there. Services ''Schoem's Menorah Chapel'', Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey, at 10:15 A.M., on Friday, August 9, 201-843-9090. Family and friends are invited to a luncheon following.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor Signs Animal Cruelty Law
description: A year after two Cahokia teenagers sold copies of a videotape that showed them torturing a cat, Gov. George Ryan signed a law making it a class A misdemeanor to depict animal cruelty. The bill provides for up to a year in jail and mandatory counseling for juvenile offenders. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Mahler and His Universe
description: The music festival ''Mahler and His World'' is running this weekend and next at Bard College in Annandale-on Hudson, N.Y. It will feature music by and discussions about Gustav Mahler, left, and a constellation of variously gifted Germanic symphonists of the late 19th century, including Alexander Zemlinsky, right.

title: Farm Union Bill Holds Peril for California Leader
description: A union's chief role is to deliver better wages and benefits to its members, so it has been a huge frustration for the United Farm Workers that agricultural workers have not gotten a contract more than half the times they have voted to unionize.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: OPPOSITION GAINS IN LOCAL VOTING The main opposition party won a majority in the National Assembly in a landslide by-election victory, a rebuke for President Kim Dae Jung during his final months in office. Candidates from the conservative Grand National Party won 11 of the 13 contested seats. The party's leader, Lee Hoi Chang, left, who narrowly lost in 1997 to President Kim, is running again and leads his pro-government opponent, Roh Moo Hyun, in polls ahead of the Dec. 19 vote. Mr. Kim's five-year term ends in February, and the Constitution bars him from running again.    (AP)

description: NEWARK: MEN FATALLY SHOT

title: Visiting Indonesia, U.S. Envoy Seeks to End Rebel Conflict
description: Anthony C. Zinni, the retired American general who has worked as the Bush administration's envoy to the Middle East, met in a new role here today with Indonesian officials discussing a solution to the long-running but little publicized guerrilla conflict in the nation's northern province, Aceh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, EITAN YITZCHAK
description: SHAPIRO - Eitan Yitzchak. Our hearts are broken upon the untimely loss of our beloved son, brother, grandson, great-grandson, uncle, nephew, cousin and friend. He was our tower of strength and courage; our true hero. He will be sorely missed but never forgotten. The family

title: Paul Allen May Buy All Shares of Charter
description: Charter Communications's largest shareholder, the billionaire Paul G. Allen, confirmed today that he might buy the remaining shares he does not own and take the cable company private.

title: G.M. to Shed 5 Midsize Models
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to cut 5 of its 15 midsize car models in the United States by 2006 as it tries to trim manufacturing and development costs and spend marketing dollars on fewer brands.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  In the highest-level contacts since President Bush made support for Palestinian statehood contingent on Yasir Arafat's removal, three Palestinian officials appointed by Mr. Arafat met today with senior officials at the White House and State Department.

title: Jets' Offense Shows Signs of Life Mostly With the Passing Game
description: For all of their off-season maneuvers, the Jets left their offense almost entirely intact. That was not necessarily an endorsement, just an acknowledgment that it takes more than one season of learning a new, complicated offense to produce cohesion and explosiveness.

title: Phillips Is Taking Long Road to Majors
description: The roads into New York are almost always crowded, and ANDY PHILLIPS will certainly have a difficult time getting to the Bronx.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Boy Charged With Arson
description: An 11-year-old boy has been charged with setting the fire Monday night that destroyed a warehouse in Yonkers. The fire burned for more than 13 hours, destroying the building and injuring 26 firefighters, none seriously. Police Lt. Maureen Zadorozny said the boy, whose name was not released, was charged with the equivalent of second-degree arson and arraigned in Family Court. Police reports say the boy used gasoline he stole from a service station to set the fire, she said. Fire Commissioner Anthony Pagano said firefighters spotted the boy at the fire. The police say there may be other arrests.

title: Al Hirschfeld; Karl Mann; Simon Frost
description: Al Hirschfeld

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Posts Profit
description: Korean Air posted a net profit of 166.26 billion won ($138 million) for the second quarter of this year in contrast to a net loss of 115.1 billion a year earlier. The company's first-half net profit totaled 195 billion won ($162 million), up from a loss of 346 billion won ($287 million) in the first half of last year. The gains reflected in part the rising value of the won against the dollar, which has reduced the price of jet fuel and equipment. Other factors were rising passenger volume and rising air cargo traffic powered by Korea's expanding economy. The number of passengers rose 4 percent while air cargo rose 15 percent in the first half of this year from the first half of last year. Don Kirk (NYT)
