description: Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

title: When Watching TV Is Forbidden, Is It a Home or a Prison?
description: Judges can deprive convicted criminals of their freedom, their rights and even their fortunes.

title: Councilman Is Subpoenaed Over Finances For Campaign
description: Councilman James E. Davis has received subpoenas for the financial records of two organizations with which he has been affiliated, his lawyer confirmed yesterday.

title: AGREEMENT ON ASBESTOS CLAIMS LIFTS McDERMOTT
description: McDermott International, a builder of offshore oil-drilling platforms facing losses because of asbestos claims against its Babcock & Wilcox unit, said it reached a preliminary agreement with claimants. The company, which is based in New Orleans, announced the agreement after the close of trading on Wednesday, and yesterday its stock rose $2.35, to $5.35 a share. McDermott said in June that it would have losses this year as it writes off investments in the bankrupt Babcock & Wilcox unit. Babcock & Wilcox, which started in the 1800's making boilers for power plants, used asbestos as an insulator. The unit has settled more than 340,000 asbestos claims and sought Chapter 11 protection in February 2000 because it was the only way to resolve the claims, the company said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday about a plan by MTI MicroFuel Cells to introduce a simplified design for powering portable consumer electronic devices misstated the fuel to be used. It is methanol, not methane.

title: Megalomania as an Unembarrassed Art Form
description: New Order's album ''Power, Corruption and Lies'' would make just as fitting a title for the magnificent ode to Factory Records, ''24 Hour Party People,'' which tracks the rise and fall of that postpunk label.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 19 and July 31 about Barry and Judith Smiley, who were sentenced last month in the kidnapping of an infant whom they raised as their son, misstated their legal connection to him. The Smileys had not adopted the child, whom they raised under the name Matthew Propp; he had been placed in their custody and they were trying to adopt him. Custody was awarded to his biological parents in 1979.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit At BMW
description: The German carmaker BMW increased second-quarter sales by 8.9 percent, to 11.6 billion euros ($11.2 billion), and net profit by 11.9 percent, to 629 million euros ($607 million), compared with last year's second-quarter. Although the group reported a record volume of auto sales and better profit than have most of its European rivals, the results failed to impress analysts, and its stock fell 2.4 percent. BMW said sales in the United States rose 16 percent. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: L.I. Power Official Warns Of Dire Need for New Plants
description: Long Island, which is facing the tightest energy crunch in the New York region, used a record amount of electricity last month, with its consumption jumping more than a fifth over that of July 2001, utility officials said yesterday.

title: Earnhardt, in New York, Causes a Rock-Star Stir
description: A chorus of screams announced Dale Earnhardt Jr.'s entrance into the Herald Square Macy's, a common reaction now but one that still surprises him on some level. It took a pair of police officers and a half-dozen unarmed security people to shepherd him though his appearance there yesterday afternoon.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: 2 More Reformist Newspapers Banned
description: The judiciary shut down two pro-reform newspapers, Rouz-e No and Ayeneh Jonoub, and jailed an activist, Hashem Aghajeri, on charges of insulting the Prophet Muhammad in a speech last month. A lawyer, Nasser Zarafshan, who represents the family of two dissidents slain in 1998 by ''rogue'' staff members of the Ministry of Information, was also jailed. An appeals court had upheld a five-year jail term and 50 lashes for Mr. Zarafshan for owning weapons and having alcoholic drinks at his home. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Liberty Clinches Spot, but It's Holdsclaw's Night
description: Madison Square Garden was supposed to be enemy territory for Chamique Holdsclaw and the Washington Mystics last night. But thanks to a warm pregame greeting and what seemed like whole sections full of her friends and family, Holdsclaw felt right at home, which, of course, she was.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Charles P. Stetson Sr., 82
description: Charles P. Stetson Sr., a stockbroker, philanthropist and longtime board member of Outward Bound USA, died on Tuesday in Hanover, N.H. He was 82 and lived in Southport, Conn. He was the founding patron of Outward Bound South Africa, established in 1992. It works to improve the lives of young South Africans, black and white.

title: U.S. to Help Reduce Threat of Russian Arms
description: President Bush signed a temporary waiver on Wednesday that permits millions of dollars to be released to programs aimed at reducing the threat posed by Russian nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Machinery orders unexpectedly rose in June, the third consecutive monthly gain, but government forecasts suggest the rebound will be short-lived. Orders for machinery, a proxy for corporate capital spending, expanded 2.9 percent in June from May. The increase contributed to the first quarterly expansion in 18 months during the April-June period. The government, however, expects orders to decline 3.9 percent in the July-September quarter. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: No Indictment In Shooting Of Young Man In Suffolk Raid
description: A Suffolk County grand jury has declined to indict a police officer who fatally shot a man during a botched drug raid in April. But a lawyer for the dead man's family said yesterday that they would seek damages in a wrongful-death lawsuit.

title: BJ's MISSES FORECASTS, AND SHARES DECLINE
description: BJ's Wholesale Club, the warehouse-store chain, said second-quarter profit rose less than forecast and results this year would miss estimates, setting off an 18 percent decline in its share price. Per-share profit in the period ended Saturday was about 50 cents, compared with previous projections of 52 cents to 54 cents. July same-store sales rose 1.5 percent, the smallest monthly gain this year, as demand for apparel, frozen food and electronics declined. Profit this year will be $2.12 to $2.16, less than the $2.24 average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company, based in Natick, Mass., will report full second-quarter results on Aug. 20. Shares fell $5.99, to $27.46.

title: North Korea Adding a Pinch Of Capitalism to Its Economy
description: After a half-century of economic control so complete that even cash had fallen into disuse, North Korea has begun introducing the most significant liberalization measures since the start of Communist rule, diplomats here said.

title: Many Are Wondering if Eisner Can Reverse Course at Disney
description: To hear Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company tell it, recent talk of the company's sagging share price and discontent among a select group of board members is so much background noise in the marketplace.

title: The F.C.C. Has Voted: A Digital Tuner for Every TV
description: Complaining that market forces alone had not assured the transition to digital television, the Federal Communications Commission voted 3 to 1 today to require television manufacturers to include digital tuners in almost every television sold.

title: Count D. Gibson, 81, Leader In Bringing Medicine to Poor
description: Dr. Count D. Gibson, a leader in the movement to provide medical care and social services to low-income people and a founder of the country's first community health centers, died on July 23 in Hartford. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUDSON, WALTER A.
description: CHUDSON-Walter A. Age 88. Of Larchmont, New York. U.N. economist, Rhodes Scholar, music enthusiast. We mourn the loss of our very dear husband, father, grandfather and father-in-law. We will miss him very much. Tina, Paul, Lucy Alexandra, and Bill

title: Police Must Get Authorization In New Jersey Terrorism Cases
description: New Jersey's attorney general ordered yesterday that requests by local law enforcement agencies for search warrants in terrorism-related cases be authorized by liaisons that he would choose. The order came a week after the Passaic County Sheriff's Department made a failed attempt to arrest a man suspected of providing fake identifications to two of the Sept. 11 hijackers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Yankees Donate $250,000
description: The New York Yankees will give $250,000 to the Community Council, which gives aid to youth, recreation and education programs throughout the Bronx. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the gift with the all-star pitchers Roger Clemens, above, and David Wells and the Hall of Famers Whitey Ford and Yogi Berra yesterday in City Hall. The Yankees made eight earlier gifts to the Community Council, which since 1994 has provided funds to more than 100 community-based organizations and given about 150 grants to Little League programs in the Bronx. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: BANK ACQUISITION The Fubon Financial Holding Company, a Taiwanese financial services conglomerate with life insurance, property insurance, brokerage and banking units, said it had agreed to acquire the Taipeibank Company for $2.4 billion in stock. The acquisition makes Fubon the sixth-largest owner of banks in Taiwan, with $33 billion in assets. The company said it planned to run its Fubon Commercial Bank and Taipeibank separately for at least two years. Citigroup bought a 15-percent stake in Fubon in 2000 that will be diluted to 10 percent if Fubon and Taipeibank shareholders approve the share swap.

title: The Brand Is Called Rosie, But Its Future Looks Troubled
description: Whom exactly does a magazine named Rosie belong to? Is it the magazine's namesake, Rosie O'Donnell, the former talk show host and editorial director? Or Gruner & Jahr USA, the company that publishes the magazine?

title: A Reply to Perceived Attacks
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the former secretary of housing and a Democratic candidate for governor in the Sept. 10 primary, released a 30-second advertisement that will be shown today on New York City stations and run for about 10 days, his campaign aides said.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Meat Scandal
description: An official at Nippon Meat Packers, one of the country's biggest beef processors, admitted mislabeling meat to win state subsidies, the latest in a series of similar schemes. The official, who worked at the company's parent, Nippon Foods, said he ordered imported beef to be labeled as domestic beef to win financial compensation from the government. The agriculture ministry put the program in place in response to the mad cow disease scare that started last September. Another meat processing company, Snow Brand Foods, was accused of similar practices earlier this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACGREGOR, JOHN
description: MACGREGOR - John. The Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd. is deeply saddened by the death of our colleague and dear friend on July 25. A devoted member of the Troupe since 1954 and President in 1976, John graced our productions with his sets, costumes, props and graphics, he served on innumerable committees and he will be gratefully remembered by Troupers to whom he was an unselfish and encouraging mentor. We miss him a lot. The BHT Board

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WorldCom Adds $3.3 Billion To Accounting Troubles

title: Iraq Is Defiant as G.O.P. Leader Opposes Attack
description: The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey, warned today that an unprovoked attack against Iraq would violate international law and undermine world support for President Bush's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Gunman Found Incompetent
description: A failed student accused of killing three people in a gun rampage in January at the Appalachian School of Law has been found incompetent to stand trial. A judge in Grundy, Va., ordered medical treatment for the defendant, Peter Odighizuwa, 43. Two mental health experts, one selected by the defense and the other by the prosecution, agreed that Mr. Odighizuwa needed treatment. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: The Lost Continent
description: On Wednesday the Bush administration, which says that it is for free trade and against bailouts, once again put its money where its mouth isn't. Less than two weeks ago Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill created a diplomatic incident and sent Brazil's currency into free fall with his remark about assistance ending up in ''Swiss bank accounts.'' Now the International Monetary Fund, with Mr. O'Neill's blessing, has agreed to lend Brazil an unprecedented $30 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRIE, CATHERINE A.
description: CURRIE-Catherine A. In PA on August 6, 2002, formerly of Merrick. Devoted wife of the late Ross Struthers Currie. Devoted mother of Catherine J. Matteson and Ross A. Currie. Loving grandmother of Ross G. Currie. Visiting Tuesday, August 13, 2002, 11-1 at the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick. Funeral services immediately following visiting. Interment LI National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Disabled American Veterans, appreciated.

title: Grocer to Restate Earnings
description: Penn Traffic, an East Coast supermarket-chain operator, said yesterday that it would restate financial results for the last three fiscal years and the first quarter of this year because a former employee at its Penny Curtiss bakery unit had overstated inventory.

title: Youth and Experience Transforming a Town
description: The artist Jason Middlebrook took a look around Andover, a spacious, tree-hugged town that's home to the elite preparatory school Phillips Academy (founded in 1778) and as New England as it gets. He observed students, architecture, cars, clothing and other elements common to the area.

title: New York Is Seeking to Win Supporting Role in the Oscars
description: A group of New York entertainment executives, celebrities and government officials has begun working to persuade the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to move a significant part of the Academy Awards ceremony to New York next year to help the city in its effort to recover from the attacks of Sept. 11.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Ousts Head of the Internet Units
description: Gunter Thielen, the new chief executive of the media giant Bertelsmann, ousted the executive who oversaw most of its Internet businesses yesterday and eliminated the post of chief operating officer. Both moves signal a swift turn away from the drive toward centralized management and investment in the Internet that were among the main goals of Thomas Middelhoff, Bertelsmann's former chief executive.

title: Brazil's Markets Rally on News of Fresh Cash
description: Heartened by a $30 billion loan package from the International Monetary Fund that was much larger than expected, investors drove up sharply Brazil's flagging currency, stocks and bonds today.

title: Priest Indicted in Sex Abuse of Teenage Boy During the 80's
description: A Roman Catholic priest was indicted today on two counts of child rape, accused of paying a boy to have oral sex in the rectory of a Cambridge, Mass., church.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Eviction Deadline
description: Police officials said they were awaiting instructions from the government on how to deal with the nearly 3,000 white farmers who were ordered to leave their farms by midnight last night. Some farmers had vowed to defy the eviction order while others packed their bags. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Rightist Leader To Step Down
description: Mat Herben, left, who became leader of a Dutch anti-immigration party after its founder, Pim Fortuyn, was assassinated in May, has announced plans to step down after rank-and-file criticism of his leadership. Some party members complained that he made too many concessions in negotiating the inclusion of the party, known as the Pim Fortuyn List, in a Christian Democratic-led government coalition. The man accused of killing Mr. Fortuyn, Volkert van der Graaf, an environmental activist, is on a hunger strike to protest surveillance cameras in his cell. Alan Riding (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Woman In Court Case Miscarries
description: A woman who was ordered to put off having an abortion for a week while a judge considered her ex-boyfriend's objections had a miscarriage on Monday, hours after the judge ruled in her favor. The judge, Michael Conahan, had ruled that the ex-boyfriend, John Stachokus, had no right to interfere with Tanya Meyers's decision. ''Tanya said she would make the right decision when the time came,'' Ms. Meyers's mother, Tracey Curry, told The Associated Press. ''But God made the decision.'' Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUG, DOLORES
description: SCHUG-Dolores. On August 8, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Elizabeth and John Schug. Loving friend of William True. Reposing on Saturday and Sunday 2-4 & 79PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10AM at St. Gabriel's Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Suspect Identified
description: The police said one of three men who blew themselves up with grenades when confronted by officers on Tuesday has been identified by a witness as one of the masked gunmen who carried out an attack on a nearby missionary school. Six Pakistanis died in the attack. Local villagers said the men's accents suggested they were from Karachi, the southern port city that is a stronghold of Pakistani militant groups. It was unclear how the identification was made. The bodies of the two other men who killed themselves washed down a river and have not been found. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Intrepid Sisters Whose Lenses Traced Memories
description: Long before there was Sturbridge Village in Massachusetts, the Winterthur Museum in Delaware or Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, there was Deerfield, a small western Massachusetts farming town and early colonial outpost founded in the late 1600's. Summer visitors and tourists have flocked there for more than a century, many drawn by magazine photographs celebrating Deerfield's picturesque farms and its lone leafy street lined with fine 18th-century houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEHRE, EDWARD J., M.D.
description: HEHRE-Edward J., M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is saddened by the death of the founding chairman and professor emeritus of its Department of Microbiology and Immunology. A distinguished researcher, world-renowned for his outstanding work with carbohydrate enzymology, his colleagues and students remember him fondly as a gentle mentor and tireless academic scholar. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Hehre family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Hilliard Sees Big Picture Even If He Moves On
description: Ike Hilliard is running and he sees everything clearly, the darting eyes of the cornerback, the frantic movements of the linebackers. Chaos surrounds him and inevitably Hilliard turns in midsprint, his thighs twisting. He finds safe places, between the defensive backs, in front of them, behind him. Hilliard turns to take a pass.

title: 36 Hours | Washington, D.C.
description: THESE days, Washington has a serious case of split personality. Half seat of power, with all the attendant trappings (impressive monuments, world-class museums, plenty of landmarks), half a quirky, seductive place with its own particular charms, many of which are distinctly Southern (grits with breakfast, crab cakes of every shape and description). So the wise visitor hopscotches between the imperial city and the ''regular'' city, perhaps choosing a White House tour or an hour spent admiring the Capitol's architecture and stunning murals, then leaving the imperial city far behind to sit in a cafe in the rapidly gentrifying U Street neighborhood or to take in a piece of art-house esoterica at the Visions Cinema near Dupont Circle. ANNE GLUSKER

title: Trachsel Goes Distance as Mets Receive a Wake-Up Call
description: The Mets' bus from their downtown hotel had just pulled into Miller Park this morning when Bobby Valentine held a closed-door meeting in the clubhouse. The Mets had looked woeful in losing to the Brewers on Wednesday night, hardly resembling the playoff contenders they believe themselves to be, and Valentine wanted to refocus his disoriented team on the simple goal of playing solid baseball.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fewer Ineffective Teachers
description: The number of New York City teachers rated unsatisfactory dropped by 11 percent, to 837 this year from 944 last year, according to preliminary figures released yesterday. The school system has 80,000 teachers. Last year's number was unusually high, in part because Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy was pressuring principals to weed out ineffective teachers. Under the teachers' union contract, an unsatisfactory rating is the first step toward dismissing a teacher. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Van Horn Has Praise for Many Nets, With One Omission
description: Tucked into a tiny interview room just off the court at the First Union Center, Keith Van Horn made his first official appearance today as a member of the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAYARD, ANNETTE COLGATE
description: FAYARD-Annette Colgate. Died August 5, in Pt. Grimaud, France. Beloved wife of Michel; mother of 5 devoted children, and grandmother to 12 adoring grandchildren. Sister of Mimi Kirk of Greenwich, CT., and John K. Colgate Jr., of Mill Neck, NY. Annette graduated from Miss Porter's School and Bennett College, and lived her 45 years of married life in Paris. She will be missed on both continents.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 19 and July 31 about Barry and Judith Smiley, who were sentenced last month in the kidnapping of an infant whom they raised as their son, misstated their legal connection to him. The Smileys had not adopted the child, whom they raised under the name Matthew Propp; he had been placed in their custody and they were trying to adopt him. Custody was awarded to his biological parents in 1979.

description: Over his 29-year career, Pat Day has earned the nickname Patient Pat for his laid-back riding style.

Condolences also to William's wife, Gabriella, to children Eugene (and Rochelle) Major, Susie (and Jay) Spievak, & Debbie (and Daniel) Schwartz, and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Yeshiva University Board of Trustees Jay Schottenstein, Chairman Yeshiva College Board of Directors

description: The Inside Art column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: Woodrow Mann Dies at 85; Sought Troops in Little Rock
description: Woodrow Wilson Mann, who as mayor of Little Rock in 1957 asked President Dwight D. Eisenhower to send federal troops to prevent a mob from keeping black students out of a high school, died on Tuesday in Houston. He was 85.

title: 'In the Bedroom' Without Frills
description: With all the attention "In the Bedroom" had in theaters, not to mention its five Oscar nominations, its director, Todd Field, could be excused for some soul-baring in the form of a director's commentary or the like on the DVD, to be released Tuesday by Buena Vista. Instead there isn't an extra feature to be found  another smart move for a small, quiet film that tells its exceedingly powerful story in rich detail but totally without excess.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Colin Powell and Mayor Bloomberg Have a Little Chat About Parking
description: The city's fight over parking by diplomats reached the upper levels of the Bush administration yesterday with an 11th-hour phone call from Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Canyon Ranch Packages
description: Through Sept. 22, the Canyon Ranch Health Resort in Tucson, Ariz., has two packages that include accommodations, meals, use of the spa, fitness classes and hiking and biking programs. The four-night Summer Sampler is $1,560 a person, based on double occupancy; the seven-night version is $2,524 a person. The resort is in the foothills of the Santa Catalina Mountains. Information: (800) 742-9000 or www.canyonranch.com .

title: Stocks End Mixed in Best Week Since Last Fall
description: After surging sharply in each of the last three sessions, the stock market finished its best week since last fall today with stocks mixed but modestly higher.

title: BANKNORTH WILL BUY WARREN BANCORP FOR $122 MILLION
description: Banknorth Group agreed to buy Warren Bancorp for $122.6 million in cash and stock to add six banks in Massachusetts. Warren shareholders will get the right for their shares to be converted to $15.75 a share, which is 37 percent more than Wednesday's closing price, or a certain number of Banknorth shares determined by an average price as well as cash, the companies said. Banknorth, based in Portland, Me., has been expanding in New England by purchasing smaller rivals. Warren has $460 million in assets.

description: CUSACK - Helen R. We mourn the loss of a wonderful saint-like woman, kind, gentle and righteous. We'll miss her wonderful spirit. Fred, David, Bill and Earle Mack

description: GRAND-Mildred. On August 7, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Stewart Waltzer. Cherished grandmother of Sarah and Robert. Services Sunday, 11:15 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In 3 Plays, Jets Turn Weakness Into a Strength
description: Jerome Bettis was only steps away from the end zone in the second quarter when he lowered his shoulder into the first white jersey that came into view. It was an act of brute force that usually means curtains, but Jets cornerback Jamie Henderson grabbed Bettis, the Pittsburgh Steelers running back, by his meaty frame and dragged him down short of the goal line.

title: Bavaro Praises Shockey
description: Tight ends from different generations chatted briefly today, and Jeremy Shockey was pleasant and polite in his conversation with Mark Bavaro. But Bavaro sensed that Shockey had a lot on his mind in his first days in the National Football League.

title: Hollywood's Responsibility for Smoking Deaths
description: I've written 14 movies. My characters smoke in many of them, and they look cool and glamorous doing it. Smoking was an integral part of many of my screenplays because I was a militant smoker. It was part of a bad-boy image I'd cultivated for a long time -- smoking, drinking, partying, rock 'n' roll.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Brewer's Profit Falls
description: The Philippine beer and food conglomerate San Miguel said that its first-half profit fell 21 percent, to 3.01 billion pesos ($58 million), as it continued to digest the cost of an acquisition binge last year. San Miguel and Coca-Cola paid $1.24 billion in early 2001 to buy the local Coca-Cola bottler from Australia's Coca-Cola Amatil. San Miguel went on to buy a local hot dog maker and a rival soft drink company. Strong demand this year for San Miguel beer and Coke, helped increase first-half revenue 25 percent, to 66.11 billion pesos. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Jean Sauvagnargues, 87, Paris Diplomat, Dies
description: PARIS, Aug. 8 (AP)  Jean Sauvagnargues, a former foreign minister who helped shape France's European policy in the 1970's and advocated strong ties with Germany, has died at age 87.

title: Settling With F.T.C., Microsoft Agrees to Privacy Safeguards
description: Settling charges brought by the Federal Trade Commission, Microsoft acknowledged yesterday that it had not properly protected the privacy and security of people who provided personal information through the company's online identification services.

title: Music Makers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Choosing Her Battle
description: After 31 years with the same Gibson-girl hair, Judi Glassenberg wasn't going to wait for her bun to come out ''in globs all over everything'' after she was told in October that she had ovarian cancer.

title: Gallery: Softball
description: Late summer has always meant boys competing for championships on the dusty diamond. Now it's a girls' world too.

title: Scandinavian Home Style
description: In his all-American house by the sea, the artist Mats Gustafson takes Scandinavian style personally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MARY A.
description: KLEIN-Mary A. Loving sister, mother and doting grandmother, died on August 8th at Roosevelt Hospital at 73. A long time resident of Manhattan's upper West side, Mary instilled in her family a passion for life. Born in Michigan to Methodist minister William and Myrtle Morford, Mary was an avid traveler and adventurer who loved the theatre, fine arts, politics and enjoyed gardening. One of the first women to receive her pilot's license, Mary's strong and independent nature led her to travel the far corners of the world, a career in network programming at CBS Television and eventually into real estate, where she owned and managed properties and European style bed and breakfasts on Manhattan's upper West side. A generous woman with a heart of gold, Mary Klein now rests in peace with her son Christopher who died tragically in 1992, and her sister Laura who passed earlier this year. Survived by her sons Michael and Joshua, daughters in law Khairah and Mary, grandchildren Christopher, Adia and Emma, and her sister Lillian and brother in law Don, the can-do spirit and sense of adventure that Mary shared with all of us will be greatly missed. A memorial service was held on Friday, August 9th at The Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew United Methodist Church in Manhattan.

description: KOEHLER-Margarete. On August 8, 2002 in Worcester, MA. Born December 15, 1910 in Berlin, Germany, daughter of Hans and Emma Endress Koehler. A longtime resident of Greenwich Village, she is survived by one cousin Hermann Endress and his daughter Barbara Nazzaro. title: California G.O.P. Leaders Pessimistic on Top Race
description: Eager as they are to welcome President Bush to California later this month, some state Republican leaders are growing pessimistic that he will provide much help for Bill Simon Jr., the Republican challenging Gov. Gray Davis in a race that was tightening just a few weeks ago.

title: Turbulent Times for Airlines
description: Last fall's $15 billion aid package for the nation's airline industry was a bold move within days of the Sept. 11 attacks to shore up the nation's transportation system. The $5 billion in grants helped airlines weather their unprecedented grounding, and the $10 billion loan guarantee program, by its mere creation, served as a form of terrorism insurance that helped airlines tap capital markets in subsequent months.

title: The Ancient Art of Haranguing Has Moved To the Internet, Belligerent as Ever
description: ''The pamphlet is a one-man show,'' observed George Orwell approvingly. ''One has complete freedom of expression, including, if one chooses, the freedom to be scurrilous, abusive and seditious; or, on the other hand, to be more detailed, serious and 'highbrow' than is ever possible in a newspaper or in most kinds of periodical.''

title: We Love You, You're Perfect, Goodbye
description: Before it's too late, somebody Democrats listen to (which probably means somebody who can produce an obscene amount of money, if not the editorial writers of this paper) should take Al Gore aside and tell him: Stop. Don't run. You had your chance, you blew it, now get out of the way. An awful lot of influential Democrats are already saying this, but they seem to be saying it mostly to each other. Meanwhile Mr. Gore is half-heartedly engaged in the campaign foreplay of op-ed-writing, fence-mending, fund-hunting and weight loss. Will nobody step in front of this misbegotten bandwagon?

title: Supervisor Is Shot in City Car in Long Island City
description: A night supervisor with the Department of Environmental Protection was found shot in the head early yesterday in his city car on a desolate industrial street in Queens, the authorities said.
