title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Aidan Fontana, whose father, Dave Fontana, died in the World Trade Center attack, misidentified the man shown with the boy outside his father's memorial service. The man was Jason Kordelos, not Firefighter Sean Cummins.

title: Religion Journal; Buddhist Festivals Attract Many, but Fail to Help Maintain Membership Rolls
description: Marge and Jim Russell recently stood at the water's edge with their grandchildren and several hundred other people, ready to launch more than 1,000 paper lanterns on the receding tide, beacons to guide home ancestral spirits believed to have returned that night for a Japanese Buddhist ritual known as a bon dance.

title: The Power of Simplicity
description: The dance component of the free Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival opened on Thursday night with a near-perfect choice of program. The honors went to the Limn Dance Company and to Jos Limn himself.

title: Shares Close Out Vigorous Week In Quiet Fashion
description: After surging sharply in the previous three sessions, the stock market finished its best week since September yesterday with stocks mixed but modestly higher.

title: Are Politics Built Into Architecture?
description: The concept of building the State of Israel was long central to the Zionist dream. But after Israel's independence in 1948, the phrase took on a more literal meaning: Israel now also had to build the villages, towns and cities that would turn it into a modern, prosperous and secure land. As a result, urban planners and architects assumed a central role in defining the physical appearance of the new nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPER, SCOTT
description: KEMPER-Scott. October 9, 1946-August 3, 2002. A man of great dignity who leaves a family of friends worldwide. The reality of him will grow distant but not less powerful.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Claim Rejected In Jailed Brother's Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday rejected part of the claim for a new trial by Lamont Branch, a Brooklyn man who is serving 25 years to life in prison for a 1988 killing. Mr. Branch had asked for a new trial after his brother, Lorenzo Branch, testified this spring that he, not Lamont, was involved in the slaying. Justice James G. Starkey said that Lamont Branch had not provided ''newly discovered evidence'' as defined under the law, but he asked for arguments on whether Mr. Branch met a legal test of innocence and whether the prosecutors may have kept possibly helpful information from defense lawyers. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Productivity Rise Is Tied to Agility Of Employers In Rapid Layoffs
description: By cutting back the hours of workers without reducing the workload, employers pushed up the nation's annual growth rate of productivity by 1.1 percent in the second quarter, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILCOTT, T. GEORGE.
description: SILCOTT-T. George. Of Mt. Kisco, New York, passed away on Friday, August 9, 2002 at his residence in Mt. Kisco, NY. He was 71 years old. Mr. Silcott was born February 22, 1931, in Boston, Massachusetts to Joseph and Louise Williams Silcott. He was educated in Springfield, Mass, and graduated from Springfield College in 1952. He earned a B.S. degree in Group Work and Community Organization. He also earned an MSW at the University of Connecticut in 1961. On Oct. 28, 2000, he married Kathleen Duffy. He is survived by his wife Kathleen Duffy Silcott, his children: Julie Silcott Roberts, Tracey Del Duco, Brian T. Silcott, Larry Cain, Kurt S. Silcott, Ava M. Silcott, William J. Silcott, his brother James E. Silcott and his grandchildren Shawna Lee Del Duco, Adam and Andrew Roberts. Calling hours are Sunday 6-9 P.M. and Monday 10AM-12 Noon at the CassidyFlynn Funeral Home, 288 Main Street, Mt. Kisco, NY (914-666-4840). The funeral is Monday, Aug. 12, 12:30 PM at the funeral home. Interment will follow at the Oakwood Cemetery, Mount Kisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALTER, JANET
description: FALTER-Janet. Died on August 9 in her 83rd year. Wife of the late Stanley. Devoted sister to Phil. Loving mother of Joel and Richard. Beloved grandmother of Sarah and Hannah. She will be deeply missed and always remembered for her undefeatable spirit & unfailing will. Services are 2:30 Sunday, August 11, Schwartz Brothers FH, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Catholic Religious Orders Let Abusive Priests Stay
description: The Roman Catholic religious orders that include a third of the nation's priests will not expel sexual predators from their ranks, leaders of the orders said yesterday. But the leaders are debating ways to protect children from abusive priests and whether the priests should be allowed to wear religious habits as they continue their ministry.

title: A Return to Profitability; Big Recall Behind It, Tire Maker Regains Its Footing
description: Two years ago, Japan's major tire maker, the Bridgestone Corporation, was staggering from a huge, embarrassing recall of Firestone tires that threatened to crush its American subsidiary. Today, Bridgestone reported strong profits for the first half of the year, and said for the first time that it expected its American operations to turn a profit for the year.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: FINANCIER PLEADS GUILTY TO CONTEMPT

title: Go Ahead. Gossip May Be Virtuous.
description: If you're interested in the latest thinking about gossip, forget the self-serving plugs on Page Six, Entertainment Tonight and People and pick up the International Journal of Applied Philosophy. There, Emrys Westacott, an associate professor of philosophy at Alfred University in south central New York, tries to raise the subject to a higher plane with a moral defense of gossip.

title: Corrections
description: A credit in Weekend yesterday for two illustrations with an art review of the exhibition ''Al Hirschfeld: A Love Affair With Line,'' at the Morgan Library in Manhattan, misstated the medium. They were drawings, not photographs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, SEYMOUR
description: ROSENBERG-Seymour. Age 78, on August 9, 2002 in Norwalk, CT. Founder of Mevo'ot Betar in Israel. Leader of the American Betar and Director of Camp Betar. He was predeceased by his first wife Jacqueline in 1993 and is survived by his second wife, Judy Moore of Easton. Father of Meira Rosenberg of Stamford, grandfather of Benjamin, Marissa, & Joshua Friedman, stepfather of Lon Moore, Rachel Elan, Susan Moore and Harry Moore, brother of Enid Barnett of Kingston, Ontario and leaves his devoted and beloved friends. He was also predeceased by his beloved sisters, Helen Hoffman and Miriam Camhe. Service will be held Sunday, August 11, 2002, 11am at the Abraham L. Green & Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd., Fairfield, CT. Interment following Riverside Cemetery in Saddle Brook, NJ.

title: Leading the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Alfonzo Takes Turn On the D.L.
description: The Mets placed third baseman Edgardo Alfonzo on the disabled list tonight and recalled infielder Marco Scutaro from Class AAA Norfolk.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Is God Listening? Ask the Man Who Thinks So
description: Jack Chapman is not your everyday pimp. For one thing, he lives with his wife, Sara, and their daughter, Rivkele, in an apartment above his Lower East Side brothel. Jack also wants respect, and not just on the street. Jack wants a seat in the synagogue, the blessings of the rabbi and a husband for his 17-year-old Rivkele. But time is running short, so Jack is trying to buy his newfound piety by cutting a deal with God. Mazel tov.

title: Don't Bug Me: When E-Mail Is Junk Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Colombia Doomed to Repeat Its Past?
description: Walking in Bogot last Wednesday, the day of the presidential inauguration, was almost like walking through this city 15 years ago. As a journalist who covered the narcoterrorism war in the late 1980's and early 90's, I had flashbacks to the indiscriminate attacks directed by the drug lord Pablo Escobar. In those days, as on Wednesday, you had to follow the boom of explosions to know what was going on. Then you went and found the dismembered bodies, the panic and the fresh despair.

title: Pirro Criticized for Handling Of Youth's Death at Party
description: One month after a Westchester County grand jury chose not to return an indictment in the death of a Harrison teenager who was punched at an after-school drinking party, questions are still being raised about how the case was handled.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIDES, RUTH
description: WIDES-Ruth, August 10, 2001. Remembered for her love, beauty and sage counsel

title: Investigating the Investigators
description: One way to chill a Congressional investigation is to send a flock of F.B.I. agents to Capitol Hill to ask legislators to take polygraph tests and answer questions about their dealings with reporters. Unfortunately, that is precisely what is happening these days at the Senate and House Intelligence Committees as they review the government's response to terrorist threats in the years leading up to last Sept. 11.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: INDICTED LAWYER'S REQUEST DENIED

title: 2 Companies Agree to Buy Control of Global Crossing
description: Global Crossing and its creditors agreed yesterday to sell control of the company for $250 million to two Asian companies, three months after the creditors rejected a $750 million offer from the same bidders.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Track Worker Killed By Subway Train
description: A track worker accidentally stepped into the path of an A train in East New York and was killed early yesterday morning, the authorities said. The worker, Christopher Bonaparte, 50, had been flagging local northbound trains at the Liberty Avenue subway station around 3 a.m. as a crew worked on the tracks, when he stepped over to the express track, the authorities said. He was struck by a southbound train that had been rerouted onto the express track because of a sick person at a nearby station, they said. The incident was still being investigated. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Smoker No More, a Writer Repents
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about doubts by Vice President Dick Cheney that Iraqi development of weapons of mass destruction could be eliminated by inspections of the country's laboratories misstated the year that the United Nations imposed economic sanctions on the country. It was 1990, after Iraq invaded Kuwait -- not 1991, the year of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZBERG, DAVID
description: SALZBERG-David. On August 8, 2002. Beloved and cherished husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Barry and Janie Salzberg, Lani and Robert Hopp. Adoring grandfather of Mark, Karen, Dana and Jenna. A gentle person and a gentle man. Always anxious to share with others and spread beauty. Services Sunday 1 PM, Riverside Nassau North, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Drug Maker Drops Treatment
description: The French-German pharmaceutical company Aventis said it would stop developing an experimental drug to treat high blood pressure, raising fears about the company's potential for growth. The drug, which tests proved to be inefficient, was expected to generate from $500 million to $2 billion in sales; Aventis has already spent more than $100 million on its development. The company said it was working on a back-up compound for the treatment of hypertension and congestive heart failure. Aventis, which manufactures Allegra, Taxotere and Lovenox, is one of the world's fastest-growing drug companies. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after violence in Venezuela rekindled concern that supplies might be disrupted. In New York, crude oil for September delivery rose 19 cents, or 0.7 percent, to $26.86 a barrel.

title: U.S. Ties Military Aid to Peacekeepers' Immunity
description: The Bush administration, making use of a provision of the new antiterrorism law, warned foreign diplomats this week that their nations could lose all American military assistance if they became members of the International Criminal Court without pledging to protect Americans serving in their countries from its reach.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People choose a doctor according to the organ they think they have a problem with. But no one wants to think they have a mental problem.''

title: Grubman Attended 10 Board Meetings
description: Jack B. Grubman, the Salomon Smith Barney stock analyst who is under fire for his close ties to companies whose stocks he rated for investors, attended at least 10 corporate board meetings in four years, the firm has told a Congressional committee in a letter released yesterday.

title: Court Overturns a Ruling on Open Primaries
description: A federal appeals court yesterday overturned a lower court ruling that had opened Connecticut's primary ballot to any registered voter affiliated with a political party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISS, BENJAMIN
description: LISS-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Julia. Devoted father of Mark and Ileen, and fatherin-law of Charlotte and the late Mitchell Markowitz. Cherished grandfather of Andrew. Services on Sunday 11:30AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS COURT MUST DECIDE HERSHEY SALE
description: Pennsylvania's attorney general said a state court must approve any sale of the Hershey Foods Corporation by the charitable trust that controls the company. The attorney general, Michael Fisher, will ask the Dauphin County Orphan's Court, which oversees charitable trust activities, for a ruling that it has jurisdiction over any sale, according to a spokesman, Sean Connolly. Mr. Fisher met yesterday with members of the Hershey Trust Company, which operates the Milton Hershey School Trust, a trust spokesman said. On Tuesday, Mr. Fisher encouraged some board members to seek alternatives to a sale. A petition will be filed with the court by Monday, he said.

title: Talk of Ban Gives Smokers, Bars and Restaurants the Jitters
description: A few nights a week, Gene Scofield leaves his apartment near Lincoln Center and meets a few buddies at Rudy's Bar and Grill on Ninth Avenue near 45th Street for a drink or two. But since he found out that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wanted to keep him from smoking while he has a cocktail, he may just have to start drinking at home.

title: Hamm Ends Wilson's Bid to Win Sixth Title
description: A year ago, a broken ankle kept Paul Hamm out of the USA Gymnastics national championships and Sean Townsend won the national all-around title for the first time. Tonight, with Townsend unsteady and Blaine Wilson unable to navigate cleanly on a strained left knee and ankle, Hamm stayed steady and easily won his first national all-around title.

title: William R. Crawford -- U.S. Envoy and Mideast Specialist, 74
description: William R. Crawford, a retired American career diplomat and expert on the Middle East and Cyprus, died on Sunday at his home in Greensboro, Vt. He was 74 and also lived in Washington, D.C.

title: Shifting Colombia's Aid: U.S. Focuses on Rebels
description: Just as a new president, lvaro Uribe Vlez, begins his term determined to combat Colombia's leftist guerrillas, the Bush administration has delivered a powerful new tool: authorization to use nearly $1.7 billion in American military aid directly against the rebels.

title: Islam and Moderation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SUTTER, BEATRICE WEINBERGER
description: SUTTER-Beatrice Weinberger. August 10, 1992. Mother, sister, wife, friend, teacher to all: 10 years have not dimmed the memory of your grace and beauty, nor of your gifts of your time and artistry to others. Rest in peace. Larry and Betty

title: Invoking Corporate Greed
description: The campaign of Andrew M. Cuomo, the former housing secretary and a Democratic candidate for governor in the Sept. 10 primary, said it planned to broadcast a new commercial beginning today in the New York City region. Another commercial, a negative advertisement in response to what his campaign considers political attacks from his opponent, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, is also scheduled to be broadcast today.

title: Europeans Try Air Fares Without the Fine Print
description: The ads in the Underground are as subtle as the barking of a sideshow huckster. ''You won't believe your eyes,'' they scream. Then come the prices: the equivalent of $107 round-trip to Paris, $154 to Marseilles, $201 to Lisbon.

title: A Big Voice, With Nothing Held Back
description: Jazz singers these days seem more likely to find their useful information in the restraint and mystery of bossa nova than in the unapologetic splendor of, say, Sarah Vaughan. Maybe it's because they feel that reticent music implies modernity more quickly. If so, Dianne Reeves is their opposite: she's only lightly concerned with reticence. She has an enormous voice and an enormous talent, and she offers it up to stun her audience.

title: Yankees' Defeat Is a Long Time In the Making
description: A team cannot confidently look ahead to the postseason, Manager Joe Torre believes, until it is 30 games above .500. The Yankees tried desperately to get there last night. For six hours, they tried. They tried so much, they played the longest game -- six hours -- in the history of their opponent, the Oakland Athletics. They still lost.

title: SUN EXECUTIVES BORROWED MONEY FROM THE COMPANY
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. disclosed that five executives and a director of the computer maker had borrowed $6.3 million in personal loans that would be barred under a corporate-accountability law enacted last month. Sun made the loans from 1999 to 2002 to help the officials buy more Sun stock, purchase homes and meet margin loans, a Securities and Exchange Commission filing states. Sun made two of the loans totaling $3 million in June and July, just ahead of a law that went into effect July 30 that forbids the practice. The document put on record that the loans predated enactment of the law, which makes exceptions in certain cases, including home improvements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINGARTEN, ESTELLE
description: SCHEINGARTEN - Estelle. On August 9, 2002, the second day of Rosh Chodesh Elul. Reunited with her true love Louis, who departed 17 Elul 1981. Beloved mother of Anne (Irwin) Krasna, Carol (Hyam) Reichel and Susan (Norman) Ruttner. Cherished grandmother of 21 and great grandmother of 33. Devoted sister of David A. Levine and Alex A. Levine. Funeral Sunday 11 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Shiva at Reichel home.

title: Charles Poletti Dies at 99; Aided War-Ravaged Italy
description: Charles Poletti, a son of Italian immigrants who served as governor of New York in the final weeks of 1942, then played a major role in the United States Army's reconstruction of Italy after the fall of Fascism, died Thursday at his home in Marco Island, Fla. He was 99.

title: Smoker No More, a Writer Repents
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Profit Falls
description: Profits at McDonald's Holdings Company (Japan), fell 81 percent in the first six months of the year, and the company nearly halved its full-year targets. McDonald's, the biggest fast-food chain in Japan, earned 1.41 billion yen ($11.8 million) in the first half and expects to earn only 6.2 billion yen for the full year, 46 percent less than expected. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Steel Growth Possible
description: ThyssenKrupp Steel, the Duisburg-based steel unit of the German heavy industry company ThyssenKrupp, is considering a $180 million investment in the United States to help strengthen its foothold in America. A board member, Ulrich Jaronim, said in a newspaper interview that ThyssenKrupp Steel, the world's fifth-biggest producer of flat-rolled steel, was planning to build a hot-galvanizing plant in the United States, but no decision has yet been made regarding the site of the factory. ''Our aim is to be where our global clients are,'' Mr. Jaronim said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Saratoga Yearling Sales Fall 44 Percent From '01
description: With gross sales down 44 percent from last year's record figures, almost everyone involved in this week's Fasig-Tipton Saratoga Selected Yearlings Sale agreed that the market was depressed this year. Not everyone agreed on why.

title: Behind the Camera, A Former Firefighter; Documentary Shows 9/11 Anguish, But It Cannot Find a Spot on TV
description: Mike Lennon is fighting the clock. Only 33 days separate him and the anniversary of the attack on the World Trade Center. But his film, about the firefighters who answered the Sept. 11 alarms, is still not finished.

title: Don't Bug Me: When E-Mail Is Junk Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate for Lieutenant Governor Facing Scrutiny Over Business Dealings
description: H. Carl McCall's choice for lieutenant governor, Dennis Mehiel, has thrived at running companies on the brink, amassing considerable wealth in the process.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Privatization
description: Lone Star Funds of Dallas is offering $870 million in cash and profits in an effort to acquire SeoulBank, which was taken over by the government in December 1997. The equity fund revised its bid to top that of Hana Bank, which has offered more than $800 million in shares in hopes of a merger that would create Korea's third-largest commercial bank. Hana stated that Lone Star had no right to alter its bid and threatened to sue if Lone Star was chosen. The country's top financial regulator, Lee Keun-young, called for a review to determine the legality of the revision. Lone Star has been a major player in Korea since the economic crisis, buying more than $1 billion in bad loans. The government, which has spent $4 billion to keep SeoulBank alive, failed in 10 tries to sell it to foreigners before opening the bidding to Koreans. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Voices Concern on Merrill-Enron Tie
description: Merrill Lynch said in a filing released today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had ''expressed concerns'' about its role in the collapse of Enron.

title: Judge Lets Democrats Expel Bronx Senator From Rolls
description: A State Supreme Court judge ruled yesterday that the Bronx Democratic Party was within its rights to expel State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. from its rolls. And it ordered the New York City Board of Elections to cancel the Bronx senator's enrollment as a Democrat, which could doom his re-election bid this November.

title: DISNEY SAYS IT EMPLOYED RELATIVES OF 4 DIRECTORS
description: The Walt Disney Company said four of its independent board members had relatives who were employed by the company last year. Disney's practice, which was mentioned in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, runs counter to new standards of independence for corporate directors proposed by the New York Stock Exchange. With the changes, a director would not be considered independent if a relative worked at the company the last five years, a stock exchange spokesman, Ray Pellecchia said. The proposal would also require that a majority of a company's directors be independent of the company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Slow Economic Growth
description: Italy's economy barely grew in the second quarter after stagnating for a year, as manufacturing stalled and slumping stock markets hurt consumer demand. Italy's economy grew 0.2 percent in the second quarter, the government said, half the pace forecast by economists. The Italian statistics office Istat revised quarterly G.D.P. growth for the first quarter to 0.1 percent from the 0.2 percent gain originally reported and revised the annual gain to unchanged from 0.1 percent. Italy's economy grew 0.2 percent in the second quarter from the same quarter of 2001, Istat said. The report, the first on second-quarter growth from the nations using the euro, shows the region is struggling to rebound from last year's slowdown.

title: BUSH ROLLS BACK RULES ON PRIVACY OF MEDICAL DATA
description: The Bush administration today formally rolled back some major protections for the privacy of medical records adopted by President Bill Clinton. But at the same time, it also set new standards for the use of personal information to market prescription drugs and other health care products.

title: The Boys of Last Summer Are Back to Just Playing Ball
description: The kid with the killer fastball became famous when he pitched a perfect game for a team from the Bronx in the Little League World Series a year ago. It was the story of dreamers who wanted nothing more than to be big leaguers.

title: Anthrax Inquiry Draws Protest From Scientist's Lawyers
description: A lawyer representing Steven J. Hatfill, a germ weapons expert, has protested to the Justice Department that the government is violating his client's rights in its search for the culprit in the anthrax attacks that killed five people last fall.

title: South African Village, Fearing AIDS, Trusts God More Than Drugs
description: A shimmering blue Mercedes-Benz carries the holy man toward the sickly flock that is awaiting deliverance. The faithful believe that he is a prophet, a savior, a man of miracles who can stop the plague that is killing this poor, rural village.

title: Charlton Heston Reveals Disorder That May Be Alzheimer's Disease
description: ''Our revels now are ended,'' Charlton Heston, quoting Shakespeare, said as he revealed he might have Alzheimer's disease.

title: Defender Sets a Subtle Trap, But the Declarer Won't Bite
description: A familiar figure on the national bridge scene was center stage once again at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Washington two weeks ago.

title: Big Blast Kills 21 Afghans; Link to Terror Is Suspected
description: A huge explosion killed at least 21 people today near a road construction warehouse here, and investigators said that although its cause was unclear, they were treating it as a terror attack because the site was near a major hydroelectric dam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOVE, SONYA
description: SOKOLOVE-Sonya. Died on August 8th, 2002 in her 93rd year. Lucid and loving to the end. Predeceased by her husband, Abe, and son, Larry. Mother of Jane Alpern and Richard; grandmother of Aaron, Peter, Amanda, Maisie and Will; sister of Nat and Abe Gabriner and mother-inlaw of Karin & Lew. Services in North Adams, MA.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Suspension For Anti-Islam Graffiti
description: A Secret Service agent who admitted scrawling ''Islam is evil. Christ is king'' in the home of a man who federal prosecutors said had links to terrorism was suspended without pay for six months. The unidentified agent was also transferred out of the United States attorney's office for the Eastern District of Michigan and ordered to write a letter of apology to the family of Omar Shishani, a Jordanian-American whose Dearborn home he searched after Mr. Shishani was found with $12 million in counterfeit checks at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Couple Sentenced for Roles In Immigrant Smuggling Ring
description: A former immigration lawyer and his wife were each sentenced to just over eight years in prison yesterday for their roles in an immigrant-smuggling ring that federal prosecutors said brought thousands of Chinese into the United States illegally between 1993 and 2000.

title: Justice, Now With A's, Sees Another Side
description: David Justice stepped into the visiting clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, walking and talking, and made it only 50 feet before he hugged one of the Yankees' broadcasters. A few seconds later Justice wrapped his arm around a newspaper reporter's shoulder and gave half a hug. Five minutes later, still walking and still talking, Justice applied a bearhug to another broadcaster.

title: Golisano Spends Big For Campaign
description: Barraging the airwaves with ads, Tom Golisano, the billionaire making a third-party run for governor, reported today that his campaign spent $12 million in the last four weeks, a record pace for a statewide campaign.

title: Circus Truck Flips, but Elephants Just Walk Away
description: Paula, 35, and Kristy, 22, never saw the curve in the road that forced their tractor trailer to overturn yesterday on Route 9 in Rhinebeck, N.Y. They were in the back of the trailer, eating hay.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Rates On Hold
description: The Bank of Japan left its monetary policy unchanged yesterday. Though stock prices are near 18-year lows and the recovery is showing some signs of slowing, the central bank said it would continue to keep a surplus of as much as 15 trillion yen ($125 billion) in the money markets. The bank also promised to provide extra liquidity as needed. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Financier Pleads Guilty To Contempt
description: Robert E. Brennan, the former president of the defunct broker First Jersey Securities Inc., pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to criminal contempt charges for violating an asset-freeze order from the Securities and Exchange Commission. James B. Comey, the United States attorney for the Southern District, said that Mr. Brennan, above, violated the order by transferring $500,000 from the operations of a gambling cruise ship in which he had an undisclosed financial interest to his criminal defense attorney's bank account. At the time of the transfer, he was facing federal bankruptcy fraud charges and money laundering charges. Mr. Brennan agreed to a settlement of charges that he defrauded millions of investors with the cheap stocks he promoted in the 1980's. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Microcell in Danger of Default on Debt
description: Microcell Telecommunications, which sells wireless-phone service in Canada under the Fido brand, said today that it was in danger of defaulting on debt agreements and that lenders might force it out of business.

title: Problems At the Pound
description: If you can judge a society by how it treats its animals, New York is in sorry shape. The city's animal-welfare system, one of the worst in the country, is bound to get worse with this year's budget cuts.

title: The Love of Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: MyTravel to Start a Low-Cost Airline
description: Competition for European leisure air travelers, already fierce among established airlines and no-frills upstarts, became even more intense this week as the MyTravel Group of Britain disclosed plans for its own low-cost airline.

title: In New Flushing Assembly District, Asian-Americans Still Face Tough Campaign Fight
description: Nearly a year ago John C. Liu made history when he won a City Council seat in Flushing, Queens, one of the city's major centers of Asian-American life, and became the first New Yorker of Asian descent to win elective office.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN CLIMBS. The yen rose as expectations waned that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates to bolster the faltering U.S. economy. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.10 yen, down from 121.03 yen on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEL, MILTON
description: ABEL-Milton. August 7, 2002 in Lauder Hill, FL. Predeceased by his beloved first wife, Zelda Melz Abel and was the loving husband of Molly Cohen Abel. Cherished brother of Rose Abel Nelson, devoted father to Steven Abel and Carol Abel Jacoby. Survived by his daughter-inlaw Zara Abel, son-in-law, Raul Jacoby, four grandsons, one great - granddaughter, four step-children and 10 step-grandchildren. He was loved by many & succeeded in fulfilling his life purpose in helping others and making them happy. Funeral is at Gutterman's Inc, Rockville Centre, New York (516764-9400), Aug. 11, 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, PETER PATRICK
description: McGUIRE-Peter Patrick. Of Briarcliff, NY, died suddenly August 9th. He was a devoted educator and father. He is the son of Ethel & the late Peter McGuire and the brother of Maureen, Dorothy, John, Carol & Delores. Resting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Mass of Christian burial will be Monday 10 A.M., St. Theresa's Church, Briarcliff. In lieu of flowers donations in his name to The Scholarship Fund at St. Augustine School, 1176 Franklin Avenue, South Bronx, New York 10456, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Former Prosecutor Is Charged In Death of His Ailing Mother
description: A Westchester prosecutor who was fired in April as the police investigated the death of his mother has been charged with causing her death through neglect and ill treatment.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Opposition To Cleaning Plan
description: A group of scientists and residents in Lower Manhattan denounced the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday for what they called an inadequate plan to rid buildings of contaminants from the collapse of the World Trade Center. The E.P.A. had released a plan to clean homes south of Canal Street in May, asking residents to request a cleanup by Sept. 3. But critics who gathered outside the agency's office at 290 Broadway yesterday argued that the area covered was too small, the deadline too soon and the call for residents to request cleaning too lax. ''We know there was not a wall at Canal Street,'' said Dr. Marjorie J. Clarke, a scientist in residence at Lehman College in the Bronx. A spokesman for the E.P.A., Richard Stapleton, said the Canal Street boundary was not immobile. But, he added, ''We are not going to force people who don't want their apartments cleaned and lives disrupted to do that.'' Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: RATES ON HOLD The Bank of Japan left its monetary policy unchanged yesterday. Though stock prices are near 18-year lows and the recovery is showing some signs of slowing, the central bank said it would continue to keep a surplus of as much as 15 trillion yen ($125 billion) in the money markets. The bank also promised to provide extra liquidity as needed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo To Sell Bus Plant
description: Daewoo Motor plans to sell a bus plant that was not included in the acquisition by General Motors of Daewoo's Korean car-making units. A Korean company that makes sports hats has signed a preliminary agreement to buy Daewoo's bus factory in Pusan and a stake in its bus-making plant in China for $116 million. The Daewoo plant in Pusan, with a capacity of 8,000 buses a year, manufactured 7,564 buses in 2001. The hat company, Young An Hat, is not entirely new to the bus business. A subsidiary, Young An Development, owns a bus assembly plant in Costa Rica. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, RICHARD B.
description: ALPERT-Richard B., Attorney. Age 49. Died in NYC, August 9th, 2002 after a hard fought battle with pancreatic cancer. Beloved son of Erwin and Florence (Sterling) Alpert of Hamden, CT. Cherished brother of Daniel Alpert (Partner, Rabbi Eric Weiss) of San Francisco, CA. Devoted friend of Eduardo Sese of NYC. A graduate of Rutgers University and the New York Law School, Mr. Alpert was Deputy District Director of E.E.O.C., New York District Office. He was a valiant defender of human rights and social justice. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 11th, at 11:45 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NYC. Graveside service at Workmen's Circle Cemetery, Farwell St., W. Haven, CT, at 3:30 PM. Period of mourning will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Ave. at 16th St., NY, NY 10003, or to St. Vincent Supportive Care Program, St. Vincents Hospital, 153 W. 11th St., NY, NY 10011.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Nazi Criminal To Stay In Prison
description: A former Nazi mass murderer, Josef Schwammberger, 90, convicted in 1992 of killing hundreds of Jewish prisoners at several SS labor camps near Krakow, Poland, between 1942 and 1944, must serve 10 more years of his life sentence, a state court in Mannheim ruled. It said he cannot be considered for release because his ''particularly cruel'' crimes outweighed concern over his frailty. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Fumio Yoshimura, 76, Sculptor of Everyday
description: Fumio Yoshimura, a sculptor known for his highly detailed wooden replicas of plants, machines and a variety of everyday objects, died on July 23 in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 76.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Epidemic Threatens Harbor Seals
description: An epidemic that killed half the population of harbor seals of Northern Europe, has appeared again this summer and has already killed about 2,500 of the sea mammals. The so-called phocine distemper virus leaves the seals coughing and wheezing and brings on a type of pneumonia that often kills them. A similar virulent epidemic in 1988 killed about 18,000 seals, half the region's population. Scientists are unsure what brought on the virus, which does not threaten humans, and they say there is nothing they can do to stop it. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: GOLDMAN SACHS MAY SEEK TO OFFER BANK SERVICES IN UTAH
description: Goldman Sachs Group may apply for a Utah state license to provide bank accounts and related services to wealthy individuals, a spokesman said. The spokesman, Simon Eaton, declined to comment further. Michael Jones, chief examiner of the Utah Department of Financial Institutions, said Goldman Sachs has indicated that it is working on an application for a banking license, according to a report in The Financial Times. Goldman Sachs and other investment banks are seeking ways to increase revenue as fees from underwriting stock sales and advising on mergers decline.

title: Smoker No More, a Writer Repents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, DORIS BILLINGS ''DABBIE''
description: DANIELS - Doris Billings ''Dabbie'', 73, died August 4, 2002 at her home in Tisbury, MA. Beloved wife of George ''Gus'' and loving mother of Katherine B. Daniels. A Graveside service will be held on August 14th, 2002 at 2PM in Oak Grove Cemetery, Tisbury. For information, call the Chapman Funeral Home, 508 - 693 - 1495 or visit www.ccgfuneralhome.com

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about efforts to bring part of the Academy Awards ceremony to New York next year misstated the ownership and construction cost of the Hollywood and Highland complex, which houses the Kodak Theater, current home of the Oscars. It was built by the TrizecHahn Company, not the Denver billionaire Phillip Anschutz; Mr. Anschutz's company, AEG, operates the theater. The complex cost $615 million, not $94 million.

title: Farmers in Zimbabwe
description: To the Editor:

title: Depression Simmers in Japan's Culture of Stoicism
description: When Eiko Imai thinks back to the dim and blurry stretch of years when she silently suffered from depression, she often wonders how she survived.

title: EMULEX SAYS SALES WILL FALL SHORT OF ESTIMATES
description: The Emulex Corporation, a maker of circuit cards for data-storage systems, said sales in its current fiscal year would fall short of analysts' estimates and its stock fell 35 percent. Sales will be $305 million to $325 million in the year, which began July 1, the chief financial officer, Michael Rockenbach, said in a conference call on Thursday. Emulex was forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call to have sales of $335.6 million. Stock in Emulex, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., fell $8.34, to $15.27 a share.

title: Park Service Is Seeking Big Increase in Money for Mass Transit
description: In an effort to reduce congestion and pollution in the national parks, the National Park Service is asking Congress to increase financing for public transportation in the parks when it reconvenes this fall, Park Service officials said this week.

title: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS HOLDINGS AGREES TO BUY WESTWOOD
description: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., a maker of military-communications networks and aircraft simulators, agreed to buy the Westwood Corporation for $22 million to increase sales of controls and other equipment for United States Navy ships. L-3 will pay $2.30 a share, an 81 percent premium to Westwood's closing price on Thursday. Westwood, based in Tulsa, Okla., specializes in power distribution and switching for ships. The acquisition, which includes an unspecified amount of assumed debt, will make L-3, based in New York, the top provider of switch gear for some Navy ships, L-3 said.

title: U.S. Seeks to Limit Environmental Law's Reach Over Coastal Waters
description: The Bush administration is arguing that a major environmental law does not apply to the vast majority of oceans under United States control, a move that environmentalists say could allow military maneuvers, oil and gas pipelines, commercial fishing, ocean dumping and scores of other activities to escape public environmental review.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose and the number of private-sector jobs fell in July, reinforcing recent indications that the economy is losing momentum. Statistics Canada said that the jobless rate climbed to 7.6 percent in July from 7.5 percent in June. The private sector lost 12,000 jobs, but that was offset by the creation of 35,000 government positions. Economists are divided whether the Bank of Canada will raise interest rates when it reviews monetary policy on Sept. 4. So far this year, the central bank has moved its main overnight rate up three times, from 2 percent, to 2.75 percent. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about doubts by Vice President Dick Cheney that Iraqi development of weapons of mass destruction could be eliminated by inspections of the country's laboratories misstated the year that the United Nations imposed economic sanctions on the country. It was 1990, after Iraq invaded Kuwait  not 1991, the year of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Sports of The Times; Rutgers Tries To Find Hope In Florida
description: FOR 15 years I've taken the drive down the New Jersey Turnpike to Rutgers and listened to enthusiastic promises of success from four of the university's football coaches: Frank Burns, Dick Anderson, Doug Graber and Terry Shea.

title: Political Memo; Bloomberg Finds Some of City's Woes Resist His Solutions
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg can fly his own helicopter to meetings in Albany. He can bring about vast changes to school governance. But he cannot get diplomats to pay their parking tickets.

title: Companies Use Ex-Lawmakers In Fight on Offshore Tax Break
description: It can feel like old home week on Capitol Hill, what with the armada of former lawmakers who are suddenly lobbying against efforts in Congress to crack down on companies that shift their addresses offshore to lower their tax bills.

title: Microsoft and Free Software At the Same Show? It's True
description: Peter Houston, a top software executive at Microsoft, is not planning to wear a flak vest as he plays host when the company has its first booth ever at the LinuxWorld Conference and Expo computer industry show that opens here on Monday.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS GIVE CONCESSIONS TO US AIRWAYS
description: Flight attendants at US Airways Group voted yesterday to give the company $75.8 million a year in concessions, moving the airline closer to winning a federal loan guarantee. About 72 percent of workers represented by the Association of Flight Attendants voted for the agreement, which covers about 7,600 employees, a company spokesman said. In return, the airline said it would not cut more flight attendant jobs if it filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: As Strike Date Looms, Talks Are Secretive and Sensitive
description: In their effort to hammer out an agreement and avert the setting of a strike date, negotiators for baseball's owners and players have gone into their secret-meeting mode. That development could be a good sign for the chances of their reaching agreement on a new contract, but it could also lead nowhere. The talks are at a sensitive stage.

title: Airlines Told to Watch for Uniformed Intruders
description: The government has issued a warning to airlines to watch for people in stolen uniforms who might try to gain access to airplanes, an aviation expert confirmed tonight.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Cigarette Taxes Help Preschools
description: A Los Angeles County commission established to oversee revenues from Proposition 10, which raised the tax on a pack of cigarettes by 50 cents, voted to spend $100 million over the next 18 months on steps to make preschool available to all children in the county. The initiative, one of the largest of its type in the country, could begin enrolling participants within 6 to 12 months. A study recently found that one parent in seven is unable to find an appropriate place for his children. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Patriots Hoping to Keep the Magic
description: Despite the recent death of Ted Williams, there is no shortage of living sports legends in New England. In a region where history matters, the royal figures include Bobby Orr and Bill Russell. Russell recently spoke to the Patriots at the invitation of Coach Bill Belichick.

title: WorldCom Chief Tries to Reassure Customers
description: WorldCom, seeking to minimize the fallout from Thursday's announcement of a $3.3 billion increase in the dimensions of its accounting scandal, said yesterday that the new disclosures did not reflect on its ability to serve customers and would not derail its efforts to emerge from bankruptcy.

title: National Briefing | Washington: No Spying For Letter Carriers
description: The Justice Department said it would not enlist postal workers or utility workers for a planned informant program known as TIPS, for Terror Information and Prevention System. It said no one would be enlisted to report suspicious activity ''whose work puts them in contact with homes and private property.'' The House of Representatives has voted to bar any version of the program. Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Education: Students Allowed To Cross Border
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service will permit part-time Mexican and Canadian students who commute to colleges in the United States to continue their studies through the end of the year. The service had previously said it would bar thousands of commuter students from the two countries from crossing the border in the coming academic year, potentially costing colleges and universities millions of dollars in lost revenue. The extension will allow the agency and Congress time to develop a permanent solution, like creating a new visa category for part-time students, said Danielle Sheahan, a spokeswoman for the agency. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: British Court Frees a Muslim Arrested After 9/11
description: A British court today freed a Muslim who was arrested after the Sept. 11 attacks last year and accused of recruiting Islamic terrorists on a Web site that offered the ''ultimate jihad experience'' of live-fire military training.

title: Putting Preseason Games to Good Use
description: Bill Belichick ended years of debate last season when he smiled, but he is still viewed around the league as a polar example of eccentricity. A perception around the National Football League is that he might be the only coach who actually creates a game plan for preseason games.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Egypt's Justice System
description: To the Editor:

title: Leiter Gets Big Out, Then the Victory
description: Al Leiter makes his living by busting his cut fastball into right-handed batters and away from left-handers, and he had used that sequence plus a sharp curveball to survive for much of the game tonight against the St. Louis Cardinals. But Fernando Via had given him fits in a seventh-inning at-bat, extending it to 10 pitches by fouling off three two-strike pitches.

title: Conseco Recovery Efforts Fail; A Bankruptcy Filing Is Possible
description: Conseco, the big financial services company whose woes two years ago were in many ways a preview of the current corporate scandals, said yesterday that its turnaround efforts had failed, and analysts warned that the company might seek bankruptcy protection.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Clean Skies For Denver
description: Christie Whitman, director of the Environmental Protection Agency, officially declared Denver the first major city in the country to achieve full compliance with the Clean Air Act by meeting nearly all of the agency's standards for eliminating air pollution. New auto inspection laws, limits on wood burning and cutbacks in the use of sand on icy roads helped the city achieve the distinction. For decades, Denver was ridiculed for its poor air quality. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about efforts by Yankee magazine to attract a younger, more affluent audience referred imprecisely to the magazine's profitability. While Yankee is privately owned and does not disclose profit figures, Jamie Trowbridge, the president of Yankee Publishing, says the magazine has been profitable for the last 20 years, but only marginally so in the last few years -- not ''marginally profitable'' during the entire period.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Apple Dumping Duties
description: Mexico's economic minister, Luis Ernesto Derbez, said the government would impose a 40 percent tariff on fresh apples imported from the United States because American growers were selling the fruit at unfairly low prices, hurting Mexican growers. Consuming $118 million worth a year, Mexico accounts for about 30 percent of American exports of fresh apples. Mr. Derbez also said that he would ask Congress to pass a law that would give President Vicente Fox a kind of fast-track authority to impose antidumping duties on other products. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Edsger Dijkstra, 72, Physicist Who Shaped Computer Era
description: Edsger Wybe Dijkstra, whose contributions to the mathematical logic that underlies computer programs and operating systems make him one of the intellectual giants of the field, died on Monday at his home in Nuenen, the Netherlands. He was 72.

title: Early Reviews Show Thomas Will Be a Hit
description: Defensive end Bryan Thomas is unassuming enough to admit that he was nervous before his professional football debut Thursday night in the Jets' preseason opener against the Pittsburgh Steelers. So a smile of relief spread across Thomas's face after the game when he was asked about the play that made the game something special.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an increase in the number of people killed in motor vehicle crashes last year -- including an increase in those with alcohol as a factor -- misstated the measure used for blood alcohol levels. It is grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood, not milligrams per 100 milliliters.

title: Smoker No More, a Writer Repents
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ex-Foreign Minister Leaves Parliament
description: Makiko Tanaka, the outspoken former foreign minister whose firing in January from that post led to a plunge in opinion polls for Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, has resigned her seat in Parliament. Ms. Tanaka, the first Japanese woman to serve as foreign minister, resigned apparently over lingering accusations that she had used office funds to pay for employees who were not on her official payroll. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Editorial Notebook; The Globalization of the Family Cow
description: It's been a long, long time since the idea of the family cow had any currency in the United States. But there was once a time, lingering mainly in the childhood memories of an older generation, when the only way to keep milk fresh was to keep it inside the cow and when it took no imagination at all to figure out what to do with those daily gallons of milk and cream. Some of it went into homemade cheese, some into butter. Some went into the kids and the rest into the pigs.

title: RAIDS IN PAKISTAN RAISE NEW FEARS
description: Raising fears of a resurgence of Islamic militancy, a bomb attack on a Christian hospital here this morning killed 3 Pakistani nurses and wounded 23 people as they left a chapel after prayer services.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: STEEL GROWTH POSSIBLE Thys senKrupp Steel, the Duisburg-based steel unit of the German heavy industry company ThyssenKrupp, is considering a $180 million investment in the United States to help strengthen its foothold in America. A board member, Ulrich Jaronim, said in a newspaper interview that ThyssenKrupp Steel, the world's fifth-biggest producer of flat-rolled steel, was planning to build a hot-galvanizing plant in the United States, but no decision has yet been made regarding the site of the factory. "Our aim is to be where our global clients are," Mr. Jaronim said.

title: Victim-Support Group Banned From Churches
description: Members of Voice of the Faithful, a lay group of Roman Catholics that organized in response to the sexual abuse scandal in the church, have been meeting in church basements across the Northeast. But they will no longer be doing so on Long Island.

title: U.S. AGREES TO GIVE $4.5 BILLION TO LINK SUBWAY AND PATH
description: The federal government will contribute $4.5 billion in disaster relief money to build a transit center linking the subway and PATH systems around the former World Trade Center site, and possibly other transportation projects, state and federal officials said yesterday.

title: Mayor Says Pay Toilets Would Help City's Budget
description: In the Bloomberg administration, many things old are new again, including the first recent official step yesterday toward bringing public toilets to the streets of New York.

title: BUREAU VERITAS TO ACQUIRE U.S. LABORATORIES
description: Bureau Veritas will buy U.S. Laboratories Inc. for about $83 million in cash to add to the company's international consulting and training services and enter the United States construction consulting market. Bureau Veritas will pay $14.50 a share, a 48 percent premium to Thursday's closing price for U.S. Laboratories. U.S. Laboratories, which is based in San Diego, provides engineering and inspection services to architects, contractors, municipalities and public agencies. They expect the acquisition to close late next month. Bureau Veritas is based in Courbevoie, France.

title: Hey, That's Not an Aria, It's 'O Sole Mio'
description: When the Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky was growing up in Krasnoyarsk, a gritty, industrial city in the lowlands of Siberia, surely he could never in his wildest dreams have imagined someday singing ''O Sole Mio,'' of all things, for adoring throngs at Lincoln Center. But there he was at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, winning cheers for his heartfelt renditions of that Italian chestnut as well as for five other lushly lyrical Neapolitan songs. This was the second half of a program with the impressive Moscow Chamber Orchestra, another visitor to the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Johnson Out With Bruised Wrist
description: Joe Torre admitted that he had not spoken to Nick Johnson about Johnson's injured left wrist. "Even when he plays every day, I never see him," said Torre, the Yankees' manager.

title: Smoker No More, a Writer Repents
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: JOBLESS RATE RISES Canada's unemployment rate rose and the number of private-sector jobs fell in July, reinforcing recent indications that the economy is losing momentum. Statistics Canada said that the jobless rate climbed to 7.6 percent in July from 7.5 percent in June. The private sector lost 12,000 jobs, but that was offset by the creation of 35,000 government positions. Economists are divided whether the Bank of Canada will raise interest rates when it reviews monetary policy on Sept. 4. So far this year, the central bank has moved its main overnight rate up three times, from 2 percent, to 2.75 percent.

title: Misplaced Fear of a Viral Epidemic
description: The emergence and spread of any new disease is something to take seriously, but the reaction to the West Nile virus has been characterized not by seriousness but by hysteria. There has been no rational discussion of the threat and no information given about the likely future course of the disease -- even though there is a pattern that the disease will most likely follow.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Mayor Must Give Up Contributions
description: Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. of Providence must forfeit at least $250,000 in campaign contributions because they were collected through racketeering, a federal judge has ruled. The figure is close to the amount of money donated to Mr. Cianci's campaign fund by the Providence City Tow Association between 1991 and 1999. Mr. Cianci and two associates were acquitted on charges of soliciting contributions from the tow company's employees in exchange for a monopoly on police department towing. Mr. Cianci was convicted of racketeering conspiracy in June. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Palestinians Say Sharon Is Trying to Undercut U.S. Talks
description: Palestinian officials today accused Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of trying to sabotage their talks in Washington with a tough speech on Thursday in which he called the Palestinian Authority ''a gang of corrupt terrorists and assassins.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARKER, SIDNEY
description: PARKER-Sidney. Ten long years, but love is forever.

title: Harlem Team's Coach Takes Exception to Allegations
description: Morris McWilliams bristled when asked whether he had gone out of his way to ensure that none of the Harlem Little League All-Stars he manages were too old to be eligible to play.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRITISH NUCLEAR FUELS PLC., Risley, England, said its Westinghouse Electric unit had won a $350 million contract to make equipment for four nuclear power plants to be built in South Korea over the next eight years for Korea Electric Power Corporation, Seoul, South Korea.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: CLEAN SKIES FOR DENVER

title: INSIDE
description: No. 600 for Bonds

title: Gardens vs. Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Assassination Trial Opens
description: Prosecutors told a court that the man accused of assassinating a far right politician, Pim Fortuyn, had been arrested carrying a gun speckled with blood that matched the DNA of the victim. At a hearing in Amsterdam on the continued detention of the accused, Volkert van der Graaf, prosecutors said that the gun appeared to have been used in an earlier crime and that an investigation was under way on whether Mr. Fortuyn's killer acted alone. Mr. Van der Graaf was not required to appear in court but his lawyer, Stijn Franken, complained that ''nobody seems to doubt anymore that Volkert committed the murder of Fortuyn.'' Alan Riding (NYT)

title: Iraqi Opposition Groups Meet Bush Aides
description: Leaders of the Iraqi opposition met with senior Bush administration officials today and vowed to work together to establish a democratic government if Saddam Hussein was removed from power.

title: A Different Kind of Brezhnev in the Making
description: THE political career of Andrei Y. Brezhnev, grandson of the late Soviet Communist leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, could hardly be called auspicious thus far.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, CHARLES R.
description: RUBIN-Charles R. Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died peacefully at 95 after a wonderful life filled with all God's blessings. He will be loved and remembered always by his beloved wife of 73 years Pauline, adoring children Alan and Sandra Rubin, and Arline and Howard Herman. He is the cherished grandfather of eight and treasured great grandfather of four, and leaves a sister, Sylvia Ray. A man of honor and integrity with a brilliant mind and a joyful and generous heart. His life was a blessing for all who knew him. Services Sunday 11:30 AM at Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted in The Arts on July 29 for a mural shown with an article about efforts to enliven the displays about George Washington at Mount Vernon, his estate in Virginia. The painting, showing Washington as a surveyor, is by Byron Peck.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Indicted Lawyer's Request Denied
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has rejected a request that prosecutors be ordered to disclose whether they are covertly monitoring the conversations of Lynne F. Stewart, a prominent lawyer charged with supporting terrorism. Lawyers for Ms. Stewart, who is free on bond, argued that the prospect of such monitoring was hampering her ability to discuss pretrial strategy with them. But Judge John G. Koeltl of United States District Court said that mechanisms were in place to ensure that privileged communications would not be used against her, and he asked how prosecutors could engage in ''covert investigations'' if they were ''required to disclose any such investigations in advance.'' Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Don't Bug Me: When E-Mail Is Junk Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Turnpike Accident Kills Delaware Trooper
description: A Delaware state trooper was killed yesterday in a traffic accident on the New Jersey Turnpike after he took off his seat belt to attend to his 9-month-old daughter, according to the New Jersey State Police.

title: Reflective Mood Stills Breezy Summer Days
description: Martin Olivieri, a chemistry teacher, frets that America could be on the verge of war with Iraq. His brother-in-law, Ken Ricci, a computer consultant, nervously follows the stock market and wonders if he will find himself out of work when a contract ends in a few months.

title: August 4-10: SCIENCE/HEALTH; CAUTIOUS HOPE
description: Year-old twin girls from Guatemala, joined at the head, were separated in a 22-hour operation at Mattel Children's Hospital at the University of California at Los Angeles. Previous attempts by other teams to separate twins joined at the head often killed one or both children or caused brain damage. Doctors at U.C.L.A. said they were ''cautiously pleased'' by the progress of the twins, Mara Teresa and Mara de Jess Quiej lvarez. Mara de Jess opened her eyes on Thursday, a major milestone, doctors said. Denise Grady

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Erin Dodd, Richard Baumert
description: Erin Elizabeth Dodd, the daughter of Katherine and Allyn Dodd of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Keith Baumert, the son of Mary and Rodney Baumert of Reading, Pa. Msgr. Edward R. Surwilo performed the ceremony at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church.

title: Anne Jennings, Edward Staebler
description: Anne Steeger Jennings, a daughter of the Rev. Nancy S. Jennings and Richard B. Jennings of New York, was married yesterday to Edward Bradley Staebler, the son of Sally W. Schwartz of Bloomfield, Mich., and Michael Staebler of Ann Arbor, Mich. The Rev. Charles Cary performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Francesca Russello, Peter Ammon
description: Francesca Barbara Russello, a daughter of Antoinette and Christopher Russello of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Helmut Ammon, a son of Dr. Sandra Ammon and Dr. Helmut Ammon of Mequon, Wis. Louis Russello, a Roman Catholic deacon and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Monmouth, N.J.

title: Both Collins And Toomer Are On Target In Victory
description: Before the pass reached its destination tonight, Giants quarterback Kerry Collins began moving toward the sideline. He apparently had no doubt in his mind that he had thrown the ball beyond New England safety Victor Green and into the hands of Amani Toomer in the end zone.

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: THE BOY WHO DREW CATS. By Margaret Hodges. Illustrated by Aki Sogabe. Holiday House. $16.95. (Ages 5 to 8) This version of the tale of a talented young artist with an obsession for drawing cats, all kinds of cats, is adapted from Lafcadio Hearn's fairy tale about the ink drawings of Sesshu Toyo, a 15th-century Japanese artist. Noble lineage aside, it's a wonderful ghost story, and these handsome, stylized illustrations encourage artists young and old to try to draw cats.

title: Snail Mail for AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Fish, Christopher Martin
description: Jennifer Katherine Fish and Christopher Edward Martin were married last evening at the Thayer Hotel in West Point, N.Y. Cantor Daniel Neiden performed the ceremony.

title: Streetscapes/165 West 57th Street; A School for Dance Built by a Russian Immigrant
description: THE Russian immigrant Louis Chalif, who built a dance school in 1916 at 165 West 57th Street, once said that dance in the United States was often just ''a cannibalistic orgy.'' Chalif held on to his building for less than a generation, but he retained his outspoken views.

title: Now Ashore, Surfer Makeup
description: As the summer months ebb, shoppers can catch the wave of new surfing-inspired beauty products without ever getting their feet wet.

title: Gazeteer
description: 2-bedroom, 2-bath co-op at 1056 Fifth Avenue, at 87th Street, $1.2 million.

title: French Connection
description: GOING to a restaurant for the first time is a little like a first date, with the thrill of excitement beforehand and the same questions at the end of the evening: Did he talk too much? Was he interested in me? Is he a man of substance? Can I relax with him? Did he smell good? Or would I rather have been home with a good book?

title: Finding Forester in Transition
description: TESTED: 2003 Subaru Forester

title: Add a Dash of Comedy and a Pinch of Tragedy. Stir Well
description: MARTHA, the heroine of Sandra Nettelbeck's sparkling film ''Mostly Martha,'' is the head chef of a chic French restaurant in Hamburg, Germany. Statuesque in her kitchen whites, she slaves over her bubbling saucepans, turning out edible works of art. But this culinary high priestess, played by Martina Gedeck, has no gift for people: headstrong and shy, she has a solitary existence outside the kitchen.

title: Men's Jeans Snuggle In
description: High-end low-rider jeans have invaded the men's department. Stores are stocking up on low-rise, tight-fitting jeans in all shades of denim for men who have the slim physique to stand up to them. Seven Jeans has reconfigured its boot-leg hip-huggers for male customers and has changed its jeans label from plain Seven to 7 for All Mankind ($128 at Barneys New York, available by waiting list only until mid-September). Levi's offers two low-rise styles: the Offender, an ultra-low straight-legged dungaree ($125), and the Skinner, an equally low boot-leg cut ($110). At Saks Fifth Avenue, hipsters can choose Buckler jeans with detail stitching ($138) as well as an ink-dyed version by Paper Denim Cloth ($138). American Eagle Outfitters weighs in with slim-cut boot-legs or a vintage-look Whisker Wash ($44 to $48 at www.ae.com). And at Bergdorf Goodman, there's a Dolce & Gabbana pair for $265, while Roberto Cavalli's embroidered model goes for $780. It seems rather fitting that Levi Strauss invented bluejeans for prospectors panning for gold.

title: Jenny Diamond, Edward Cheng
description: Jenny Ann Diamond, the daughter of Ethel and Peter Diamond of Plainfield, N.J., was married in Basking Ridge, N.J., yesterday to Edward K. Cheng, a son of Emy and Stanley Cheng of Wayne, N.J. The Rev. Gary Hubert, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Basking Ridge Country Club.

title: A Tale of the Seasons, Worth Telling Well
description: ONE of the trickiest aspects of critical thinking is negotiating standards, especially when a theater company seems to be doing the right thing at the right price, but it turns out wrong.

title: Family Scene With Basic Home Cooking
description: THE Kitchen at Greenport specializes in Sunday-after-church cooking. Its meatloaf, pot roast, fried chicken, ribs and roast beef hark back to the simple fare of the farmers and fishermen who first settled the North Fork. This new spot, at 74825 Route 25 (631-477-8309), never pretends to be more than it is: a modestly priced, cash-only, family-oriented restaurant.

title: Children's Books
description: GIGGLE, GIGGLE, QUACK

title: Hatred, Reawakened
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rare Screen Test For Philip Roth
description: THE conventional wisdom about Philip Roth is that he's something of a recluse, holed up in his Connecticut home where, in the last decade, he has produced masterpiece after masterpiece with a dedication that makes just about every other writer seem like a slacker. But over Memorial Day weekend, Mr. Roth was lured to the campus of Williams College in a bucolic corner of the Berkshires to watch Anthony Hopkins, Nicole Kidman and Gary Sinise recreate his 2000 novel, ''The Human Stain.''

title: August 4-10: NATIONAL; PRIVACY ROLLBACK
description: The Bush administration rolled back protections for the privacy of medical records adopted by President Bill Clinton and set new standards that will no longer require health care providers to get written consent from patients before using or disclosing personal medical information for treatment or the payment of claims. Instead, they will have to provide notice of their privacy practices and procedures.

title: Schumer Wants Part of 9/11 Aid for Police and Firefighter Raises
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer yesterday called on President Bush to allow New York to use about $500 million in federal disaster aid to give police officers and firefighters raises comparable to the 22 percent received by city teachers.

title: Religious Orders Approve Plans to Curb Abuse
description: Leaders of Roman Catholic religious orders today called for moves to curb sexual abuse by their members, including the establishment of independent review boards to monitor how the orders handle abusers.

title: August 4-10: INTERNATIONAL; KILLING IN COLUMBIA
description: Security was tight, but leftist rebels still managed to launch several homemade mortars toward the Congress building Wednesday, where Alvaro Uribe Velez was about to be sworn in as president. Mr. Uribe, a former governor who won the presidency by promising to crack down on guerrillas, went ahead with the inauguration as if nothing had happened. But the country was rattled by the fierce attack, which killed 19 people and left more than 60 wounded. Juan Forero

title: Mary Ditzel and David Griffin

Monday evenings at Mortons usually attract some big industry players but on this particular Monday—March 28, 1994— it was as if the entire Hollywood A-list had decided to assemble on the corner of Melrose and Robertson. title: Editorial Observer; If the Big One Hits the Big Easy, the Good Times May Be Over Forever
description: Dot Wilson knows how bad the Big One could be. When Hurricane Betsy hit New Orleans in 1965 with 125 m.p.h. winds, leaving 75 dead in Louisiana and South Florida, she walked more than a mile in chest-high water, holding her infant daughter overhead. But when Ms. Wilson held a hurricane-preparedness teach-in recently at the community center she heads, attendance was sparse. ''A lot of people don't see storms as serious,'' she said with a sigh. But people who have been around for a while know better, she said, adding, ''We saw the bodies.''

title: Music of the Moment
description: Bruce Springsteen's new album, ''The Rising,'' which sold more than half a million copies in its first week, has been hailed as the first significant cultural response to Sept. 11. Mr. Springsteen may in fact be one of the few popular rock musicians -- perhaps the only popular rock musician -- who can credibly take on the task. (Neil Young and Paul McCartney have already tried and failed.) ''I help people hold on to their own humanity, if I'm doing my job right,'' Mr. Springsteen once said. ''The Rising'' is perhaps the ultimate test of his deeply held belief in the redemptive power of rock 'n' roll.

title: 'Essential Cowell'
description: Moscow is musically conservative. My music is usually considered radical, on account of its innovating a new and fulsome kind of piano resonance, and some new modes of piano technique. This tale is an account of the unheard-of ups and downs I encountered in playing concerts of my own music in Moscow, on the invitation of the Soviet government through its vehicle, the Society for Cultural Relations.

His vision of Montauk was different: a beach resort in the grand style, a Tudor village by the sea, a sporting gentleman's paradise with yachting, fishing, tennis, golf, shooting and polo. It was Fisher who wanted the Gatsby crowd to think, ''Miami Beach in the winter, Montauk in the summer.'' He owned both.

title: Oversize, Under Age
description: Adolescent estrangement drives the stories in SUICIDE'S GIRLFRIEND (Perennial/HarperCollins, paper, $11.95), a troubling, addictive collection by the author of the novel ''Carter Clay.'' Even when Elizabeth Evans's characters are adults, they're usually adults remembering their youth -- in a slangy, slippery, first-person style that instantly establishes each narrator's voice. ''Thieves'' uses a precocious 14-year-old to observe teenage flirtation rites; ''Ransom'' handles child abuse in a similar manner. Traffic accidents provide the drama in ''Blood and Gore,'' ''Voodoo Girls on Ice'' and ''A New Life,'' stories that otherwise have little in common. The narrators include a self-justifying coward, a haunted girl and a recently ditched boyfriend. Evans makes each of them convincingly distinctive, even if ''Blood and Gore'' is so condensed that it borders on the trite. Evans lives in Tucson, where she sets the novella that ends the book and provides its startling title. It refers to the surviving girlfriend of a young man who tells her ''Wake up, I have something to show you,'' just before he blows his brains out. The suicide is reconstructed from the viewpoint of a casual acquaintance who has flirted with self-destruction herself. As she does through much of the book, Evans makes this oblique approach to trauma seem natural and valid. John Hartl

title: The Hip-Hop Generation Grabs a Guitar
description: IT'S near midnight at Joe's Pub in the East Village and the movement is in full effect. A roomful of twentyish and thirtyish black folk for whom hip-hop has been like a religion most of their lives are cheering as Mos Def, an esteemed rapper, roars through a set of hard rock songs, singing over the crunch of heavy guitars. He launches into a song called ''Ghetto Rock.'' The chorus goes: ''Yes, we are so ghetto! Yes, we are rock 'n' roll!'' The song ends, and Mos says, ''Y'all want some more rock 'n' roll?'' The crowd screams for more. He tells them: ''It's a whole movement, like Fela with Afrobeat. They laughed at the Wright Brothers. Noah, too.''

title: August 4-10: SCIENCE/HEALTH; HEAD SCRATCHERS
description: Two new-found skulls may cause major revisions in current ideas of human genealogy. One, from central Africa, is about 7 million years old, close to the time human and chimpanzee ancestors went separate ways. Perplexingly, the skull looks less primitive than it should. The other, from the republic of Georgia, is only 1.75 million years old but looks more primitive than expected for a Homo erectus, the species long assumed to have been the human relative to leave Africa. So what were the physical, mental and cultural attributes of these intercontinental travelers? John Noble Wilford

title: Memorial Through Education
description: Temple B'Nai Shalom, a Reform synagogue in East Brunswick with a congregation of 650 families, will honor Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter killed while working in Pakistan, by naming its synagogue school after him. The Daniel Pearl Education Center will be formally dedicated Oct. 20 with members of Mr. Pearl's family in attendance, said Linda Scherzer, a spokeswoman for the congregation. Mr. Pearl disappeared Jan. 23 while researching links between Pakistani extremists and Richard C. Reid, who was arrested for smuggling explosives in his shoe onto an airplane. Mr. Pearl was born in Princeton and lived with his family in New Brunswick when Mr. Pearl was a young child; his father worked for RCA Laboratories in Princeton before moving to California. In addition to the naming of the school, a Daniel Pearl Memorial Lecture will be delivered, and classes will be devoted to tolerance and music to honor Mr. Pearl, who was also a violinist. title: Nation-Building Lite
description: Michael Ignatieff (July 28) has done a fine job of describing the difficulties that confront the United States in its attempt to reconstruct war-torn Afghanistan. His decision to place United States actions in the conceptual and rhetorical parameters of ''imperialism,'' however, is problematic. The purpose of our military presence in Afghanistan is to overthrow a despotic regime, destroy the terrorist network it harbored and establish political order in a lawless region. Ignatieff's use of phrases like ''grand imperial planning'' and ''colonialism'' suggest something quite different: economic exploitation, the scramble for superpower prestige and the violation of political sovereignty. Such language seems at odds with reality. What kind of imperial project would permit a variety of international organizations to implement vital social projects or seek to re-establish a sovereign nation-state?
