title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNIZZARO, RUSSELL
description: CANNIZZARO-Russell. Playbill Incorporated mourns the loss of Russell Cannizzaro, our beloved Secretary and Treasurer who died on Wednesday at the South Nassau Community Hospital after a short battle with cancer. He was 73 and lived in Baldwin, L.I. with his wife Trudy. Mr. Cannizzaro joined Playbill in June 1944 as an assistant bookkeeper, and enjoyed explaining that when he began his career, the accountants were still wearing garters on their sleeves and making their ledger entries with feathered pens. At the time of his death, he was still an integral part of the Playbill family and was as adept at using modern computer programs as those half his age. Mr. Cannizzaro worked with various Playbill publishers throughout his career, and in 1973 he helped form Playbill Incorporated, which became the leading theatrical publication in the country. Arthur Birsh, Chairman of Playbill, friend and co-worker with Mr. Cannizzaro for more than 40 years, said, ''I have lost a dear friend. Russ was truly a great man. His impact on the Playbill we know today was profound, and he will be missed not only for his unending conscientiousness and devotion to Playbill, but also for his great spirit and joy he brought to everyone who knew him.'' Mr. Cannizzaro's accounting staff refer to him as a ''true gentleman,'' ''an unfailing rock of support,'' ''a devoted husband, father and son'' and note his ''kindness'' and ''affection for his family and friends.'' An avid gardener, Mr. Cannizzaro often brought in bags of cherry tomatoes and zucchini to share with his co-workers. Mr. Cannizzaro is survived by his wife Trudy; his son Russell, Jr., his daughter-in-law Diane and their two children; his sisters, Jane and Theresa; his brother Carl; and his father James.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDBLUM, PROFESSOR RABBI MAYER SIMCHA
description: FELDBLUM-Professor Rabbi Mayer Simcha. Noted Talmudic scholar, died on August 8, 2002, in Petach Tikvah, Israel, of pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Ayala Levy Feldblum, his children, Dr. Avi Feldblum, Sholom Feldblum, Professor Chai Feldblum, Dr. Miriam Feldblum and 13 grandchildren. Dr. Feldblum was born in Lithuania and came to the U.S. following WWII. He received both rabbinical ordination and a Ph.D. from Yeshiva University, where he continued teaching for over 20 years. He then made Aliyah to Israel and taught at Bar Ilan University for over 18 years. Dr. Feldblum was the author of two books on Talmudic research, as well as numerous articles and presentations. A funeral service took place at Bar Ilan University in Israel on August 8, and the burial followed immediately at the Beit Shemesh Cemetery in Israel. His wife Ayala, and daughters Chai and Miriam will be sitting Shiva at the family home in Petach Tikvah, in Israel. His sons, Avi and Sholom, will be sitting Shiva in Allentown, PA.

We listen in silence. ‘This our brother's way is a way that has left us without words in our mouths. This little brother was our own child, and his death is more painful because it is of our own creation. It is not the first time that we bury little children. We bury them every day. title: Lend Me an Ear

This gentle ridge, called by geologists a terminal moraine, lifts Scuttlehole Road above the rich farmland that slopes southward to the sea. Part of a 100-mile spine marking the glacier's terminal extension, the ridge runs from Brooklyn to Amagansett at the far end of Long Island's South Fork and enters the sea where it may once have formed a third fork, long since eroded. This glacier, aided in its progress by the broad river valley that would later become Long Island Sound, shaped the hundred-mile sandbar known as Long Island.

title: Mets in Trouble, From the Starter to the Bitter End
description: Marco Scutaro was down the row of lockers from Steve Reed, dressing as he stared into his locker. Scutaro flew in from Charlotte, N.C., before today's game, and Reed knew little about his new Mets teammate.

title: An Online Revolution That Isn't Happening
description: IN 1998, the managers of the major American orchestras and opera companies and representatives of the musicians' union convened an Electronic Media Forum to discuss the ramifications of putting performances on the Internet. All the participants agreed that the World Wide Web offered tremendous potential for classical music, particularly as radio and recording outlets were dwindling. At issue was how the music might be offered -- as ephemeral, broadcastlike events (''streaming'') or in forms that listeners could download and preserve -- and how the musicians would be paid.

title: Turkmen Leader, Wishing to Be August, Settles for January
description: In the Central Asian republic of Turkmenistan, a personality cult envelops the country's first and only leader, President Saparmurat Niyazov, or as he is better known there, Akbar Turkmenbashi, the Great Leader of All Turkmen.

title: A Family Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: The Kiss-In Point
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Intimidating Father, A Tardy Brother
description: MANHATTAN MONOLOGUES

title: Carroll's Artistry And Our Obsessions
description: THE man who wrote ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking-Glass'' was an equally brilliant photographer. But in modern times Lewis Carroll's achievements have been overshadowed by the widely held conviction that his primary inspiration, literary and artistic, was an unsavory obsession with little girls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, LEON HILLEL, DR.
description: GERBER-Leon Hillel, Dr. Wonderful husband to Louise Jacobs Craig, and loving father to Robert Mark of Bedford Hills, NY, and Merrell Eve and Edie Mackenzie of Vancover, Canada, died peacefully at his home in Laguna Hills, CA, on Friday, August 9. Born on March 21, 1920, Leon graduated from high school at age 15 and college at age 18. A graduate of Case Western Reserve School of Dentistry, he had his own practice in New York City. Before moving to Laguna Hills in 1998, he lived in Mount Kisco, NY. A brilliant and gentle dentist and craftsman, an original and an idiosyncratic thinker, a passionate humanist, a lover of Shakespeare's sonnets and much, much more, he leaves behind many who love him dearly.

title: The Nonpaying Audience Withholds Its Applause
description: Florence Daniels, 83, knows her noises. More specifically, Ms. Daniels says she can easily discern which city sounds are too booming to be acceptable. (For training, she cites years spent working in tool-and-die factories as one of the city's first female manufacturing engineers.)

title: Options Do Not Raise Performance, Study Finds
description: THE downside to stock options has become spectacularly evident in the last year or so. They can give executives an incentive to inflate their company's earnings or make irresponsibly optimistic forecasts to keep their stock prices high and their paychecks lavish.

title: The Nation: Civil Liberties; Behind the Legal and Private Worlds of the Veil
description: SULTAANA FREEMAN, an American-born Muslim woman, had no trouble getting a Florida driver's license last year even though she insisted on being photographed in a veil that reveals only her eyes.

title: Westchester Offers A Library Science Program
description: To the Editor:

title: August 4-10: SCIENCE/HEALTH; HUNGRY HORMONE
description: Scientists have identified a hormone, made in the gut, that makes people feel full after eating. The hormone, Peptide YY3-36, or PYY, switches off the hunger signal in the brain. People given PYY before a meal consume a third fewer calories than they normally would. Researchers said they hoped the hormone itself, a drug based on it or a diet that stimulates the body to make more PYY, could eventually be used to help people lose weight. Denise Grady

title: John G. Zimmerman, 74, Leader Of Action Sports Photography
description: John G. Zimmerman, an innovative sports photographer who was among the first to use remote-controlled cameras to give the public the view from the hockey net, the basketball hoop and the bottom of the swimming pool, died Aug. 3 in Monterey, Calif. He was 74 and lived in nearby Pebble Beach.

title: The Digital Boneyard: Trying to Make It Safe
description: Come on. Admit it. You've got a nonfunctioning four-year-old computer sitting in the spare room, and a real dinosaur -- a seven-year-old hulk -- in the attic. But you're far from alone: it's hard for anyone to admit how alarmingly quickly a $3,000 highest-of-high-technology toy becomes trash that no one even wants as a donation.

title: Reading Offense Is Key for Griffin
description: Cornelius Griffin took about 500 snaps in his rookie season of 2000 and of those, about 400 were on passing situations and the Giants defensive tackle could launch himself up the field without restraint. When he played full time last year, however, it was a different matter  Griffin had to determine whether he was seeing a pass or a run, and at times, he lost the advantage because of indecisiveness.

title: Tabletopping Exuberance
description: The investment banker got up on a table to dance Wednesday night at Baraonda, an intimate restaurant on the Upper East Side. As soon as he did, he became a seductive satyr, a cross between Tom Jones and Zorba. He was good.

title: Day Rides Past the Field, And the Earnings Record
description: Over his 29-year riding career, Pat Day has established a well-earned reputation for impeccable timing.

title: Robyn Moo-Young, David Saye
description: Robyn Ann Moo-Young and David Benjamin Herren Saye, recent law school graduates, are to be married today by the Rev. Niko Leota at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Ocho Rios, Jamaica.

title: AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: In two decisions last week, the State Supreme Court refined what the court meant by its affordable housing requirements in the 1983 Mount Laurel decision, saying that developers couldn't get out of the requirement by simply paying fees into a fund to build housing for low and moderate income families somewhere else. The court rejected a Cherry Hill development on the old Garden State Park racetrack property that contained no affordable housing and ruled that High Bridge in Hunterdon County was right to reject a sewer hook-up for a development of luxury houses just over its border. In both cases, the developers wanted to pay fees rather than build the affordable housing. Maria Newman

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: KIM BASINGER walks into a liquor store. Russell Crowe likes what he sees, although there's a disturbing reason she looks so much like Veronica Lake. The elements of Curtis Hanson's hard-hitting film noir L.A. CONFIDENTIAL (1997), set in the 1950's, include cops, corruption, call girls, cosmetic surgery and numerous murders. The film is, after all, based on a James Ellroy novel. A mere five years ago, Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, was able to describe the film's cast as ''anything-but-A-list stars (yet).'' She was talking about Mr. Crowe, Kevin Spacey, Guy Pearce and Ms. Basinger, who won the Oscar for best supporting actress - Saturday at 3:30 and 10 p.m. on TBS.

title: The View From/Redding; The Ties That Bind A Man and a Town
description: THE library in Redding that Mark Twain helped to found, and which bears his name, this week will play host to the 42nd Annual Mark Twain Library Book Fair, one of the oldest book fairs in this part of the country. It began sporadically in 1911.

title: Restoring County's First Park
description: MATT LEON of Yonkers has been walking around the Bronxville Lake on the Bronx River Reservation at least once a week for five years.

title: Taming a Jiggling Whir
description: TODAY, Shaken and Stirred will temporarily be Stirred and Set.

title: A Delayed Surrender To an Irresistible Art
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM is feeling nostalgic (or at least his historians and fundraisers are), so I might as well, too, about him. His company is celebrating its 50 years of existence with programs in this country and abroad, including two late last month at the Lincoln Center Festival. I have been watching that company dance for some 35 years. In the course of those years my reactions have changed, and are no doubt changing still. How much of that has been me, and my slow but growing appreciation of what it is that Merce (everyone calls him Merce) does, and how much subtler changes in his own style, I'm not quite sure.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Fleeting Romance of the American Road
description: AMERICANS are falling out of love with cars.

title: 'A Thread Across the Ocean'
description: Thomas Nightingale had prospered in South Carolina almost from the day he had arrived as a young man from his native Yorkshire in the 1720s. He got his start operating a cow pen on the frontier but soon branched into numerous other activities, including building Newmarket Race Track in Charleston and importing some of the first thoroughbred horses to the North American colonies.

title: 'The Man Who Rode Ampersand'
description: Dan was my father's keeper. That was not how it seemed at first glance. They were an unlikely couple. My father affronted the street, the weather, the other pedestrians; he sniffed cold air like a connoisseur called in to describe its bouquet, he bore into the rain as stoic as a lifeboat skipper, inspected passers-by with friendly but lingering gaze. When he stopped to look into a shop window or to wait for the traffic from a side street, an invisible regiment stamped to a halt behind him. He seemed all exuberance and will.

title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 8-11-02: ON LANGUAGE
description: We had virtually finished our book on e-mail and other virtual writing before we gave much thought to the origins of the word virtual. In its latest incarnation (used like digital, e- and cyber- to describe something existing in the electronic ether), virtual is even more ubiquitous than Elvis memorabilia on eBay.

title: Investing; Bond Funds for Wary and Bold Investors
description: AS stocks struggle to find terra firma, one type of bond mutual fund offers a very conservative haven to the wary -- or a wild ride to those who may still have the stomach to speculate.

title: Lonelyhearts' Club
description: DRASTIC

title: Ann Sharfstein, Daniel Mielcarz
description: Ann Miriam Sharfstein, a daughter of Jill and Howard Sharfstein of New York, was married last evening to Daniel William Mielcarz, the son of Elaine and Robert Mielcarz of Concord, N.H. Judge Marjorie O. Rendell of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia and a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Rollins Chapel at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H.

title: Opening That Beat Morphy Makes a Modern Comeback
description: Today's opening strategies are freer from prejudice than at any other period in chess history. One powerful cause of this situation is the chess database, such as ChessBase, which can present more than a million games, cataloged under openings. It drastically cuts the work that used to be done by thumbing through books, and its effectiveness is heightened by downloading current games from The Week in Chess in London.

title: Home, Swede Home
description: Does art imitate life, or is it the other way around? In an artist's house, it's often impossible to tell. At what point does daily existence blur surreptitiously into creation? When does everyday household object become subject? In the Long Island house that the artist and illustrator Mats Gustafson shares with his partner, Ted Muehling, a jewelry designer, work, home and landscape are so intimately intertwined that visual echoes ricochet back and forth. The sense of dj vu as you find yourself sitting in a still life or walking through trees familiar from a watercolor is a bit like stepping into a hall of mirrors.

title: POSTINGS: An Exhibit of Drawings; 'Perfect Acts Of Architecture'
description: A display of architectural drawings notable for their innovative ideas for structures and cities that were never built will open on Thursday at the AXA Gallery in the atrium lobby of Equitable Tower, 787 Seventh Avenue at 51st Street. The free exhibition, in association with the Museum of Modern Art, is open 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Monday through Friday, and Saturday from noon to 5 p.m. It runs through Oct. 19.

title: Across the Ocean, Powered by Steam
description: FROM the late 19th century until the United States entered into World War I, the piers of Hoboken were the destination and departure point for two German steamship companies, the Hamburg-American Line and the North German Lloyd line. An exhibit at the Hoboken Historical Museum brings those days to life with artifacts from the ocean liners' heyday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DWYER, JAMES E. JR.
description: O'DWYER-James E. Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James E. O'Dwyer Jr., associated with The Times from 1960 until retiring in 1994.

title: The 150-Second Sell, Take 34
description: Just as we are recovering from the overinflated price of admission and settling into our seats, we are blasted by seven or eight ear-shattering ads for upcoming films. All the money, expertise and effort put into the making of movie trailers ignores the irritating fact that the message of each promo is lost in the din of so many. As we sit with our hands over our ears for yet another ''150-second sell,'' can we recognize a good film from a bad one? And, by that time, do we really care?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOLEY, E. MASON
description: COOLEY-E. Mason. Friends, colleagues and family mourn the loss on July 25 of Mason Cooley, noted teacher (College of Staten Island, Columbia University), author, aphorist, member of the Society of Senior Scholars at Columbia University, and great friend. Survived by his cousin, Ann Cooley Sangine of Reston, Virginia. Donations in Mason's name can be made to the College of Staten Island Library, 2800 Victory Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10314. A memorial is planned for the fall.

title: The Shock of the New
description: The Heart of Redness

title: Pakistani Who Died in Deadly Attack on Christian Hospital Is Identified
description: The Pakistani police said today that they had identified one of the three attackers who killed three nurses and injured 23 people during a raid on a Christian hospital near Islamabad on Friday morning.

title: Investing; Japan May Be Worth a Second Look
description: OF all the surprises to hit investors of late, one of the most curious is that Japan is home to the best-performing major stock market this year. While America's benchmark index, the Dow Jones industrial average, has plunged nearly 13 percent, its Japanese counterpart, the Nikkei 225, has held up relatively well, growing 3.9 percent in dollar terms this year. Though slender and partly inflated by the yen's rise against the dollar, these gains suggest that Japan is worth a second look for those willing to venture overseas to broaden their portfolios.

title: Stephanie Benig, Jonas Katz
description: Stephanie Erin Benig, the daughter of Barbara and Irving Benig of Granite Springs, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jonas Caliban Katz, a son of Perii Skolnick of Weston, Conn., and Michael Katz of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Robert Weiner officiated at the home of the bridegroom's maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Clark, in Great Barrington, Mass.

title: The World: Setting Sun?; Japan Anxiously Looks Ahead
description: YEAR in and year out since Japan's financial bubble burst in 1990, American presidents have needled and cajoled the country's leaders to fix their economy and restore Japan to its rightful place in the world.

title: Till the Cow Comes Home
description: LIFE is a constant revelation. For instance, who besides Maxwell Smart would have thought of hiding a bomb in a shoe? Or, who would have thought that an unintelligible heavy metal rocker named Ozzie would become the voice of parental reason? And, who would have thought that plastic cows are sacred in Highland Park?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENEMAN, JOHN
description: KOENEMAN-John. On August 7, 2002. Beloved companion of Lou Bilka. Dear brother of Victor Koeneman and Ann Ford. Cherished friend of Henry Elfering. He will be deeply missed by many and especially by his colleagues at amFAR. Service Friday, August 23, 3PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODOFF, MARILYN
description: BRODOFF-Marilyn. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted mother of Ilene, Bruce and Steven. Loving mother-in-law of Louis Harrison. Cherished grandmother of Barbara and Michelle Harrison. Loving aunt, cousin, niece and friend. Services were held on Tuesday 10 A.M. ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY (opposite Kings Plaza).

description: Museums/Institutions

title: The Name E-ZPass Is an Oxymoron
description: To the Editor:

title: Equal-Opportunity Pastime
description: Look at all that space out there in right field. An inviting target -- if the batter can get the ball there. Most likely the four outfielders have shifted left because they know their opponent and trust their skills -- the coming pitch certainly won't be a lob, and check out the coiled player in short right center -- to bail them out if they overplay the batter.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME, by Maud Casey. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) This first novel's heroine, bounced from her job in San Francisco, returns to her desolate Midwestern hometown, where she tries to keep her angst at bay while working as a ''mystery shopper,'' assuming new identities to spy on faceless mall and town-house developments. ''Casey is a stand-up philosopher posing the most vexing questions about human existence while satirizing the materialistic ways we find to hold our despair at a distance,'' Valerie Sayers wrote here last year.

title: 'The Ringer'
description: Don't flush too early. He always had to remind himself. At least make it seem like you're taking a piss.

title: Homicides Rise Again, Threatening Oakland's Renaissance
description: Killing No. 69 of 2002, a shooting, took place on Thursday night just three blocks from a neighborhood rally to stop the violence in the streets. Killing No. 68, another shooting, happened on Tuesday while 2,000 Oaklanders were rallying all over the city as part of a ''National Night Out'' against crime.

title: 'The Gatekeeper'
description: The convent was a squat, ramshackle building, its roof more corrugated iron than Gothic pinnacle. It was set among high walls spiked with shards of glass, forbidding enough to repel voyeurs, religious obsessives, nun-stalkers, sex offenders, militant Protestants, enraged atheists. But the walls were also there to keep the occupants in. For this was a convent of enclosed Carmelite nuns, who once the gate had slammed behind them would see nobody but their fellow nuns and a few priests and altar boys for the rest of their lives.

title: Birth of a Genre: The Black Hero Who Talks Back
description: IN the beginning, there was ''Sweetback.'' As Melvin Van Peebles explains in ''Baadasssss Cinema,'' Isaac Julien's definitive new documentary about the history of blaxploitation films, the idea for ''Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song'' rose up in him out of a long-festering sense of frustration over what he was seeing on the screen.

title: Steps Before War
description: When it comes to fighting foreign wars, American presidents have been most successful when they adhered to a set of democratic principles: act with the consent of Congress, fight in alliance with other nations and exhaust diplomatic measures before going to war. As President Bush edges closer to a decision on whether to take up arms against Saddam Hussein, he sometimes acts as though these are trivial concerns that he can ignore in a rush to drive Mr. Hussein from power. That would be a terrible mistake that could cripple a military campaign before the first shot was fired and undermine American interests abroad.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: LAUGH TRACK

title: Ex-New Yorker Takes Senate Hopes to Idaho
description: From Pocatello to Bonners Ferry, people in Idaho say you are more likely to find a river running uphill than a Democrat with a real chance of being elected United States senator in what by some measures is the most Republican state in the nation.

title: Ousted Members Say Jehovah's Witnesses' Policy on Abuse Hides Offenses
description: William Bowen always considered himself a devout Jehovah's Witness. As a child, he felt it was his duty to go door to door passing out the church's magazine, The Watchtower. Later, as an elder in his Kentucky congregation, he said he saw it as his duty to inform church officials that a fellow elder had abused a child.

title: Brazilians Find Political Cost for Help From I.M.F.
description: Brazil and other Latin American governments have followed Washington down the free-market path, only to find they are now losing control over their economies.

title: The Right Of Refusal In Condos
description: MOST present and future apartment-owners are acutely aware that it is easier to buy or sell a condominium than a co-op because transferring ownership of a co-op usually needs the consent of the building's board while the transfer of a condo usually does not.

title: Mr. Nice Guy With the State's Toughest Job
description: HERE, as in most political centers, you can eventually find someone with something bad to say about almost anyone. The more visible the person, the easier it is to find detractors. John E. McCormac, the state treasurer, might be the exception.

title: Letters
description: The pictures of grade-school girls sporting couture outfits in our Style pages provoked a torrent of outraged mail. Issues of excess aside (that $1,920 shearling coat), many readers said the poses were more provocative than playful and designed to appeal to the very deviants who prey on children.

title: Sports of The Times; Players' Steroid Proposal Is Lacking In Muscle
description: TO understand how glacial Major League Baseball is when movement forward is the matter, consider this: years behind the sports industry in acknowledging that steroids so much as exist, baseball's players have proposed to tackle a possible plague with what amounts to a poll.

description: To the Editor:

title: Heartfelt Advice, Hefty Fees
description: IN a rare interview, Lauren Bacall appeared on the NBC ''Today'' program in March, telling Matt Lauer about a good friend who had gone blind from an eye disease and urging the audience to see their doctors to be tested for it.

description: To the Editor:

Wed., Thur., 8; Sat., 2: "Les Sylphides," "Pas de Deux and Trois," "La Trovatiara" and "Paquita." Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Ave. at 19th St. (212-242-0800) Through Aug. 24.

description: STARS IN THE DARKNESS

title: August 4-10: SCIENCE/HEALTH; FLYING COLORS
description: George W. Bush, 56, passed his second annual medical checkup as president with flying colors and a prediction from the eight examining doctors that he would remain in good health for the rest of his term. After Mr. Bush ran on a treadmill and underwent other tests, the doctors said that he had no evidence of heart disease. Lawrence K. Altman

title: Workers of the World, Unite and Theorize!
description: THE GATEKEEPER

title: AMBER ALERT SYSTEM
description: An Amber alert system that will provide information about abducted children on highway signs and on television and radio should be in place in New Jersey by the end of next month, according to the State Police. Descriptions of the child and the suspected abductor will be broadcast on message signs on highways, which usually transmit traffic information. The information also will be broadcast on the bottom of television screens and on radio. The information will be broadcast every 15 minutes for the first three hours, the most crucial time for finding a kidnapped child alive, and every half-hour for the next three hours. Amber alert recently helped the police apprehend a man who kidnapped two teenage girls in California. Four or five children are abducted by strangers each year in New Jersey. Karen DeMasters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGELSTEIN, BARRIE ELOISE (GOTTESMAN)
description: SEGELSTEIN-Barrie Eloise (Gottesman). On August 7, in Boynton Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of Morris, loving mother of Michael and Shani Segelstein, and Karen and Jay Daitchman; adored grandmother of Eli, Ezra, Gavriel, Doniel, Akiva Daitchman, and Bryna, Rafi, and Ariella Segelstein. Cherished sister of Israel Gottesman, Miriam Ellis, and the late Ethel Roitman; devoted daughter of the late Michael and Frances Gottesman.

title: Short Memory a Great Help to Young Cornerback
description: Young cornerbacks know that embarrassment is inevitable in the National Football League, that moments will come when the opposing quarterback seems intent on meting out a night's worth of punishment. Will Peterson, a second-year cornerback for the Giants, had barely squatted into a crouch on the first play of tonight's preseason game against New England before he was on the business end of a 62-yard connection between Patriots quarterback Tom Brady and receiver Deion Branch.

title: Claiming Their Patches of Sand
description: A century ago, Jacob A. Riis opened New Yorkers eyes to the squalor of the slums with his compelling photographs and reporting in The New York Sun. It was a fitting tribute to a man who wrote of cramped, airless spaces that a mile-long stretch of Rockaway beachfront became Jacob Riis Park.

title: Gifts From the Dead to the Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Decade After Health Care Crisis, Soaring Costs Bring New Strains
description: Ten years after a health care crisis threw American politics into turmoil, many experts see another one on the horizon.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Native American Art

title: A Fitness Room of Your Own
description: EMILY HART, a 30-year-old real estate consultant from Brookline, Mass., was riding in the elevator of the Rihga Royal Hotel in Midtown Manhattan a few weeks ago when a fellow passenger asked how she was enjoying her stay. As it happened, she was ready to vent: she told him she was frustrated that the hotel was renovating its fitness center and sending guests who wanted to work out to a nearby gym.

title: Camp Lesson Learned: No Visit Without Candy
description: To the Editor:

title: So You've Got Your HDTV. Now What's There to See?
description: AFTER years as little more than a showpiece at electronics trade conventions, high-definition television is finally becoming practical. HDTV sets still don't qualify as basic appliances, but with prices as low as $1,000, they're now within the realm of possibility for many consumers.

title: The World: War Games; For Each Audience, Another Secret Plan to Attack Iraq
description: FOR all its reputation as a taciturn crowd, the Bush administration is downright chatty when it comes to Iraq. Officials who were tight-lipped about energy strategy and homeland security have taken to analyzing in detail a battle that the president insists he has not decided on. They have begun tallying up its costs before a single shot has been fired.

title: Ideas & Trends: Proof; What Causes Cancer: Can Science Find the Missing Link?
description: DR. DEBORAH WINN has had breast cancer herself, so when she speaks to women who have just received the dread diagnosis, she understands the nagging question: Why did this happen to me? Many people suspect environmental pollutants like pesticides, for instance, or car exhaust. But Dr. Winn, head of the extramural epidemiology program at the National Cancer Institute, which conducts studies to look for environmental causes of cancer, does not tell women that pollutants are the cause.

title: Labor Talks Hit a Snag Over Drug Policy
description: Talks aimed at getting a new labor agreement for baseball before the players union's executive board can set a strike date tomorrow suffered a setback over drug policy yesterday. One negotiator said the setback was not irreversible, but a confrontation over the drug proposals of the players and the club owners delayed discussion about a luxury tax on payrolls.

title: Corrections
description: The Deals and Discounts column last Sunday misstated the telephone number for Vineyards and Kitchens in France, a tour operator based in Brattleboro, Vt. It is (866) 200-8394.

title: Men in White: The Nurse May Be a 'He'
description: JIM CHAMBERLAIN is not your typical nurse. For one thing, he is a former New York City firefighter; for another, he is a man.

title: Tax Bill Exceeds Award To Officer in Sex Bias Suit
description: A police officer in Chicago who won a sex discrimination and harassment lawsuit against her employer may face a tax bill larger than her award.

title: Sonia Robertson, Matthew Garner
description: Sonia Lee Robertson, the daughter of Sharon L. Knab of Springwater, N.Y., and the late Donald G. Robertson was married yesterday to Matthew Liam Garner, the son of Bonnie and Jack Garner of Rochester. Ralph W. Gould, a town court justice of Hector, N.Y., officiated at the Lawrence Chapel in Alpine, N.Y.

title: Political Wit and Wisdom From Two Men With Both
description: There were several years back then, after he was defeated for a second term as governor, that Jim Florio played a cagey game about his ambitions. If a reporter ran into him at a political event and asked about his plans, Mr. Florio would say, ''Call me -- we'll talk.'' And the former governor would talk about this or that urgent need in terms that made it clear he thought he was the person to meet them.

title: Melanie Patrick, Nathan Neely
description: Melanie Janeen Patrick, a lawyer, and Nathan LeShawn Neely, a special education coordinator, were married yesterday. The Rev. James King, a Southern Baptist minister, officiated at the Idlewild Country Club in Flossmoor, Ill.

title: QUICK BITE/East Brunswick; Tuna Salad, and Grits and Gravy
description: On Saturdays and Sundays, customers crowd into Nora's Cafe to sample what Mohamed Mahmoud, the owner and chef, calls the house's breakfast specialty: a pork roll, egg, cheese and potato sandwich. It is just one offering at Mr. Mahmoud's eight-year-old luncheonette in East Brunswick, near the borders of Spotswood, Sayreville, South River and Old Bridge. While most of the service is to go, the place seats 38. Mr. Manmoud and his wife, Katherine, offer the usual assortment of breakfast dishes and hot and cold sandwiches, plus a catering menu that includes hot or cold buffet, appetizers and minisandwiches. But some of the other dishes Mr. Mahmoud prepares have a distinctly South-of-Jersey flavor -- offerings like grits, biscuits and gravy. These are tastes of home for his regulars who have come from Louisiana, Texas, Georgia and Virginia to work down the street in yearlong cigarette-paper-making stints at Schweitzer-Maudit International, a paper supplier. Mr. Mahmoud and his wife had operated a similar luncheonette several years ago in North Plainfield. Mr. Mahmoud, who immigrated to the United States from Egypt 22 years ago -- named this place for his mother. He is particularly proud that he knows the names of most of his customers, which number a couple of hundred a day. As a pair of women walked in about 8:30 one Wednesday, Mr. Mahmoud walked out of the kitchen. With no hesitation, he said, ''Hi, Maggie. Hi, Marge.'' Norm Oshrin

title: Ready for Takeoff
description: Most of the work you've done in transportation, before last fall, involved ground transportation, most recently for the National Transportation Safety Board. Now you have been selected to take over as the new head of the Federal Aviation Administration. Do you like to fly?

title: Elder Care Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: Heidi Snow and Arthur Cinader Jr.
description: DR. SUSAN SNOW, a physician who is the granddaughter of the founder of the Maine chowder-making company, F. H. Snow's, says lobsters know when to let go. Smithson ruled the legislation that allowed the governor and mayor each to appoint three school board members and gave the governor veto power over the school board's decisions was unconstitutional because it was special legislation applying only to Camden. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANOFF, N. HENRY
description: GRANOFF-N. Henry. 90 years old, died on August 10, 2002. Loving husband for 67 years to his high school sweetheart Jeannette. Loving father of Paul, Dan and Gary. Loving father-in-law to Leslie and Suzanne. Survived by his brother Herbert, sisters-in-law Sally and Shirley, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Resident of Palm Beach, FL, and formerly of Great Neck, NY. Born in 1912 to immigrant parents. Graduate of St. John's University. Founded Henry Products Company, a defense contractor, and served as president from 1950 until 1968, when he sold his business to become a private investor. From 1980 to 1996 he was Chairman of the Board of Elk Associates Funding Corporation, a Small Business Investment Co. A life member and former treasurer of Hillcrest Jewish Center. He also served on the boards of Queens College Speech and Hearing Center, The International Synogogue and the Palm Beach Opera. He influenced the lives of many people through his work, charitable activities and friendships. He loved music, opera, ballet and art, but most of all he loved Jeannette and his family. He will be remembered as a man of character, intellect and passion. Funeral services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to Parker Jewish Insitutute Hospice Program, New Hyde Park, NY 11040.

title: It's a Joy Ride, And the Kids Are Driving
description: AS I piled my children into the station wagon for a trip to the movies last Saturday -- it was going to be either ''Stuart Little 2'' or ''Like Mike'' -- I thought about delivering, for the first time ever, a standard parental lecture. No doubt you've heard it, or recited it yourself -- the one about how lucky you kids are today and how tough we had it back in our day. When I was a boy, I almost said, there were no DVD's or even VCR's -- there was barely even cable. That's right. No Nickelodeon, no Cartoon Network, only a few sugar-coated network hours on Saturday morning to offset the granola of public television. And movies? Sure, there were movies -- and they only cost a nickel! (Well, not really. I'm conflating the speech I was rehearsing with the one I used to hear.) But back then, if you can imagine, the really good movies were made for grown-ups. What we kids got was a bunch of junk: cheap, live-action pictures from Disney, most of them starring Fred MacMurray. And we didn't complain. We were grateful.

title: Private Sector; Walton Endowment Intrigue

It was the largest gift on record to a public university and the fifth largest to any institution of higher learning. While others celebrated, The Arkansas Times, an alternative weekly newspaper in Little Rock, grew curious: were there conditions attached to the donation? When the university declined to reveal how it would spend the gift, The Times filed suit in May under the Arkansas Freedom of Information Act to obtain documents that would answer the question.

Yet I never heard of turpentine beetles until they invaded us. The mysterious plague first appeared in the late 1970's on the Island's eastern tip, killing the majestic trees that had seemed so suited to the sandy soil and windy coastal climate. The scourge has since marched steadily westward, sweeping through Nassau County.

title: Brit Wit
description: The hero of ''I'm Alan Partridge,'' an extremely popular comedy series in Britain, has all the personal attributes you expect in a sitcom protagonist -- with the exception of good looks, intelligence and the faintest trace of kindness. Alan Partridge is the antithesis of his American cousins; he lacks the charm of a Jerry Seinfeld, and unlike Raymond, everybody does not love him. Yet Steve Coogan, the actor who plays the churlish, self-absorbed character, is revered in his home country as a comic genius. The BBC series mercilessly chronicles the decline of this rather horrid media personality, with his smarmy wig and sickly smile. Once a successful London talk-show host (with a ludicrous catch phrase, ''Ahaaa!''), the character has been exiled to the graveyard shift of Radio Norwich, and he takes it out on everyone he meets. In one episode, when an acquaintance irks Partridge with condolences on the fact that unsold copies of his (failed) autobiography have been scheduled for incineration, the host bites back: ''The book's not being incinerated. It's being pulped. My book might well end up becoming a trestle table in a battered women's center! I'm giving something back!''

title: Rustic Romance

One is affiliated with the Pacifica community-radio network, its musical playlist devoted mainly to the earnest sounds of the latter-day folk revival. The other, broadcasting along the coast from Belfast to Mount Desert, features the confident suavity of pre-rock 'n' roll American pop music -- Nat King Cole and Frank Sinatra, Bing Crosby and Peggy Lee. The stations would seem to occupy opposite cultural poles, the one presided over by the spirit of Ralph Nader, the other by the ghost of Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: India, Pakistan And G.E.
description: Two months ago India and Pakistan appeared headed for a nuclear war. Colin Powell, the U.S. secretary of state and a former general, played a key role in talking the two parties back from the brink. But here in India, I've discovered that there was another new, and fascinating, set of pressures that restrained the Indian government and made nuclear war, from its side, unthinkable. Quite simply, India's huge software and information technology industry, which has emerged over the last decade and made India the back-room and research hub of many of the world's largest corporations, essentially told the nationalist Indian government to cool it. And the government here got the message and has sought to de-escalate ever since. That's right -- in the crunch, it was the influence of General Electric, not General Powell, that did the trick.

And like half the people I know in New York and a quarter of the people I know who live everyplace else, I have roughly 3 percent of my cranium constantly at work -- sifting through scenes, filing away impressions -- on a magnum opus that I'll probably never write.

Paper licenses are easily counterfeited, and several of the Sept. 11 hijackers used fake licenses as identification, officials say. The commission also called for increased security at D.M.V. offices. James P. Fox, the transportation commissioner, said that state troopers would be posted at offices and security cameras installed and that the division would look into offering online services.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: TESTING BEGINS ON NEW FIRE RADIOS Over the next few weeks, the Fire Department will be testing new hand-held radios designed to penetrate deep into high-rise buildings like the World Trade Center. The city had pulled the radios from service in March 2001 and resumed using older equipment after a firefighter's call for help during a Queens fire went unheard. But the performance of the older radios on Sept. 11 has been criticized by some fire officers who say communication problems contributed to the deaths of 343 firefighters. Tests began in the Bronx on Saturday, and firefighters in Staten Island will get the radios on Aug. 26 during an eight-week pilot program. If all goes well, the radios will be distributed citywide in the fall. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: True Brotherhood, The Bruce Willis Way

He'll make some big Hollywood clunker like his last, ''Hart's War,'' and almost erase the memory of his subtlety in serious films like ''Nobody's Fool'' or even hits like ''The Sixth Sense.''

Meyer, a founder and for almost three decades president and winemaker at Silver Oak Cellars, one of California's most prestigious wineries, died on Tuesday while vacationing with his wife in the Sierra Nevada mountains, near Lake Tahoe. title: College Savings Plans Are a Growing Draw
description: Despite the plummeting stock market, millions of Americans are opening college savings accounts. They are drawn by new federal tax breaks, a growing array of options and an uneasy awareness of the ever-higher cost of college.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, IRA BENJAMIN V.
description: WHEELER-Ira Benjamin V. On August 10, 2002, in New York City, where he lived, at the age of 81. He was the husband of Mary T. Wheeler, father of Dorothy W. Bacon and Timothy M. Wheeler. He had two granddaughters, Katharine D. Bacon and Sarah H. Bacon. He was the stepfather of Fletcher H. Bardsley, William Walker Bardsley, and Clymer D. Bardsley and step-grandfather of Austin Miller Bardsley. Four of his children by his first wife, Grace Tufts Wheeler, pre-deceased him: Ira B. Wheeler VI, Timothy D. Wheeler, Ann D. Wheeler, and Mark W. Wheeler. He also had three stepchildren from his second marriage to Elizabeth Strong Wheeler: Lawrence A. Serre, Alison E. Serre and Elizabeth Clark Logan. He graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1938 and Princeton University in 1942. He served as a lieutenant in the Coast Guard during World War II and was executive officer on an LST in the Pacific. He spent much of his working life at Celanese Corporation, where he was a Corporate Vice President when he retired in 1982. After retiring, he began two new careers. He became a consultant for numerous non-profit organizations through the National Executive Service Corps (NESC), and was recently named to its board of directors. One of his longtime clients was Literacy Partners, where he later served on the board. He also became an actor, with parts in 24 movies including The Killing Fields, Hannah and Her Sisters, and Analyze This. He sang with the Canterbury Choral Society and was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe. He was treasurer of the Princeton class of 1942. He was a strong and remarkable man who will be missed terribly by his family and his many friends. There will be a family burial service and a memorial celebration with music in the Fall. Contributions in his memory may be made to Princeton University and the Canterbury Choral Society, 2 East 90th St, NY, NY 10128.

description: Scientists reported yesterday that they had produced cloned calves that made human antibodies in their blood. The achievement could eventually pave the way to using cattle as a source for a disease treatment that is now derived from human blood but is in short supply.

The highlight of the evening was a world premiere by New York's own Stephen Petronio, commissioned by the festival. description: Jeremy Scott of the United States and Allegheny Community College of Pennsylvania set a meet record of 18 feet 2inches yesterday while winning the men's pole vault at the North American, Central American and Caribbean Under-25 Championships in San Antonio.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Testing Begins On New Fire Radios
description: Over the next few weeks, the Fire Department will be testing new hand-held radios designed to penetrate deep into high-rise buildings like the World Trade Center. The city had pulled the radios from service in March 2001 and resumed using older equipment after a firefighter's call for help during a Queens fire went unheard. But the performance of the older radios on Sept. 11 has been criticized by some fire officers who say communication problems contributed to the deaths of 343 firefighters. Tests began in the Bronx on Saturday, and firefighters in Staten Island will get the radios on Aug. 26 during an eight-week pilot program. If all goes well, the radios will be distributed citywide in the fall. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, RABBI MORDECAI
description: WAXMAN-Rabbi Mordecai. Temple Israel of Great Neck with profound sadness announces the passing of its beloved senior Rabbi, Mordecai Waxman. Rabbi Waxman served the Congregation for the past 55 years with distinction and influenced the lives of generations of people. He was also a major world figure in Conservative Judaism, and was particularly noted for his historical accomplishments in interfaith relations. Most important, he was a warm, welcoming figure who every member of the congregation and colleague, past and present, will remember with love and respect. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Waxman family. The funeral will take place 10 AM, Tuesday, August 13, Temple Israel of Great Neck, 108 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY. Interment will be at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. The family asks that contributions in Rabbi Waxman's memory be directed to the ''Ruth and Mordecai Waxman Memorial Fund'' at Temple Israel of Great Neck. Steven Markowitz, President

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Port Authority Reports Crime Drop
description: Reported crime fell 40 percent at Port Authority of New York and New Jersey facilities during the first four months of 2002, its executive director, Joseph J. Seymour, said last week. The authority operates bus terminals, ports, bridges, tunnels, trains and the area's three major airports, Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark. This year, there was a 46 percent drop in reported crime at PATH stations, and a 42 percent drop at the airports. Mr. Seymour attributed the decline to more officers and more efforts to prevent crimes against property and people. Crime fell 19 percent in Port Authority facilities in 2001. Tina Kelley (NYT)

In the song a tropical bird is captured and taken to a new place, where it only longs to go home. But when it does, it no longer belongs there either, because its song has changed. At that point, the narrator tells the bird, ''Don't cry -- come with me.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Swimmer Vanishes Off Rockaways
description: A 61-year-old man disappeared while swimming off the Rockaways on Saturday evening, the police said. The man, Harold Dickerson, of Jamaica, Queens, went swimming with his son-in-law near Beach 19th Street in Far Rockaway about 6:43 p.m., the police said, when he was pulled under the water and not seen again. Lifeguards had ended their tours at 6 p.m., the police said. Police scuba divers searched for Mr. Dickerson until about 9 p.m.; police helicopters and the Coast Guard continued the search through yesterday. Al Baker (NYT)

title: A Difficult but Hopeful Journey
description: There is a curfew in effect in my town in Palestine. But he does not always accompany me. In June I made it from Tulkarm to Toledo, Spain, to spend a month with my colleagues from throughout the Middle East, including Israelis, to talk about the future of civil society and governance in our region.

While most of the workers in these establishments and their nonsmoking customers breathe a sigh of relief, smokers find their universe shrinking yet again. The law, if passed by the City Council, will put the city alongside California and Delaware as the nation's most unaccommodating places for smoking.

Environment Minister Joseph Kamotho and Fred Gumo, an assistant minister in the president's office, were ''relieved of their duties,'' the president's office said. Neither has backed Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of the Kenya's first president and Mr. Moi's handpicked successor. She's also a composer and arranger of considerable gifts, and there's a lot going on in her music; characterizing it from one piece to the next becomes difficult. Some 20 miles west of the ballpark, the major league players' representatives met at the O'Hare Hilton with their union officials and decided in midafternoon not to set a strike date. So the Cubs and the Astros went about their business with, as Houston catcher Brad Ausmus said, ''cautious optimism'' about the labor negotiations.

description: North and South Korea started their first cabinet-level talks since November, discussing construction of an across-the-border rail line and the renewal of reunions for families separated half a century ago by the Korean War. Part of a flurry of diplomatic activity by North Korea, the three-day meeting began on a positive note. ''You may think optimistically,'' Kim Ryong Song, leader of the 29-member North Korean delegation, said after the first day of talks ended. He added, ''There are prospects that the fruit can grow bigger and bigger.'' James Brooke (NYT)

title: What a Good Marriage Can't Do
description: President Bush and Congress appear headed for a battle over marriage. Before it left for recess, the Senate approved $100 million, a third less than the president had proposed, for programs that promote marriage. The issue is sure to be revisited in the fall, but unfortunately the terms of the debate are skewed: people don't need to be convinced of the value of marriage so much as they need support to make it work.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises
description: The surplus in Japan's current account, the broadest measure of goods and services going in and out of the country, nearly doubled in June, mostly because of an increase in exports. At 1.5 trillion yen ($12.6 billion), the surplus grew 90.3 percent in June from a year ago, the ninth consecutive monthly gain. Exports rose 8.7 percent but imports declined 4.6 percent because of Japan's weak domestic economy. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GASNER, ALAN. A PRINCE
description: GASNER-Alan. A prince. Love to Beverly, Stewart, Rosie, and Nelly! Max, Naomi, Lisa, Jonathon, and Norman

title: WAL-MART SAYS WEEKLY SALES ARE IN LINE WITH ESTIMATES
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said last week's increase in sales at its discount stores open at least a year were within the company's expectations. Sales for the total company are in line with its forecast for a gain of 4 percent to 6 percent this month, Wal-Mart said. Demand was strong for back-to-school supplies, a spokesman, Tom Williams, said. The discount retailer said last week that it expected to meet or beat its forecast for profit of 44 cents to 45 cents a share.

title: Overwrought on the Criminal Court
description: Any mention of the new International Criminal Court in Washington these days seems to guarantee an ugly overreaction. The Bush administration and Congress have rushed to outdo each other in bullying the 77 countries that have already agreed to take part in the court, including some of America's closest allies. Forgotten in this frenzy is the court's desirable goal of bringing international war criminals to justice and its substantial protections against abusive prosecutions. Ignoring these realities, Washington prefers to brandish its military and economic power to coerce other countries into exempting all Americans, in advance, from the court's jurisdiction.

title: Court Upholds School Policy On Drug Tests In New Jersey
description: A New Jersey appeals court ruled yesterday that a Hunterdon County high school can randomly conduct drug tests on students who participate in teams and clubs or who park their cars in the school parking lot.

title: Returning on a Shoestring
description: Has it been two years since the name Pegasus was bandied about as the next luxury fashion conglomerate? That promise turned out to be woefully overstated. Not only did Pegasus fail to become a player of any kind, but most of its designers, Daryl Kerrigan, Pamela Dennis and Miguel Adrover, dropped from view, too. The most promising, Mr. Adrover, staged his last show on Sept. 9, last year, and reviews of the collection, which seemed a commentary on the limits of Western dress, appeared on the morning of Sept. 11. After that, nobody was talking about fashion except as a frivolous pursuit, and Mr. Adrover was soon out of business.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility's Profit Rises
description: The utilities group RWE posted a 9 percent increase in operating profit to 2.17 billion euros ($2.12 billion) in the first half, helped by cost reductions and higher electricity rates. The company's power division, its core operating unit, had a 46 percent increase in operating profit, which offset losses at noncore operations that the company plans to sell by the end of 2003. Sales rose 3.5 percent, to 27.7 billion euros ($27 billion), and net profit was 818 million euros ($800 million), up 11 percent from a year earlier. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Others Failed, but This Bankruptcy Is Given a Chance
description: Several airlines have filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, never to return. But US Airways, which filed on Sunday, has some factors working in its favor and could benefit from the process, bankruptcy experts said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Novellus To Acquire SpeedFam-IPEC
description: A semiconductor equipment maker, Novellus Systems, said yesterday that it would buy SpeedFam-IPEC for about $220 million in stock and assumed debt. SpeedFam-IPEC will become a new product group for Novellus, company officials said, providing ''a key building block for addressing the new challenges in the manufacture of advanced devices.'' SpeedFam-IPEC, based in Chandler, Ariz., develops systems used in advanced semiconductor devices and other precision surface-processing applications. Novellus, based in San Jose, Calif., said it would assume $115 million of convertible bonds due in 2004 and exchange 0.1818 Novellus share for each SpeedFam-IPEC share. The arrangement has been approved by the boards of both companies and is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of this year, after approval from shareholders of SpeedFam-IPEC. Novellus shareholders' approval is not required, the company said.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Dell To Offer Oracle Server Software
description: The Oracle Corporation, the world's third-biggest software maker, said yesterday that Dell Computer would offer Oracle9i Application Server software to Dell customers. The companies, which have similar marketing accords for other products, announced the agreement in a statement. Servers handle corporate networks, processing transactions and taking care of functions like databases, Internet sites and printers. Dell, the world's second-largest maker of personal computers, also sells small servers. Shares of Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., dropped 8 cents, to $9.73. Dell, based in Austin, Tex., fell 30 cents, to $25.90.

title: A New Editorial Writer Joins The Times
description: The appointment of Carolyn Curiel as an editorial writer for The New York Times was announced yesterday by Gail Collins, editor of the editorial page. Ms. Curiel, a former United States ambassador to Belize and a speechwriter for President Bill Clinton, has served as a visiting fellow on The Times's editorial board this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ELEANOR (NEE FRIED)
description: HELLER - Eleanor (nee Fried). Age 96. Died August 10, 2002 at her home in Florida. She is survived by her daughter, Mary Silk, her son Herbert Heller, five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Services private.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 7 about stem-cell research misstated the name of the employer of Tony Mazzaschi, an associate vice president for research who said universities had been skittish about conducting such projects. It is the Association of American Medical Colleges, not the American Association of Medical Colleges.

title: Dockside, the War on Terrorism May Hone Rivalry
description: The 790-foot container ship Norasia Sharjah sat dissected on Christopher Ong's computer screen, sliced into virtual sections. Inside each slice were colored boxes representing the nearly 3,500 containers on board and their destinations: Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Egypt, Malta, Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMKIN, LAWRENCE
description: SOMKIN - Lawrence. New mark & Company Real Estate, Inc., is deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague Larry Somkin. He was a kind, honorable man who was a pleasure to work with and whose dedication, wisdom and integrity elevated those around him. We will mourn his passing and remember him with reverence. Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc.

title: Ruling Allows Quarterback to Play
description: Marc Taylor, considered to be one of New Jersey's top quarterbacks by several Division I colleges, will be able to play in his senior year at Asbury Park High School, thanks to an appeal to the New Jersey State Commissioner of Education.

title: At the Apollo, Harlem's New Look
description: These days there are lines outside the Apollo Theater on 125th Street in Harlem, made up of people buying tickets to George Wolfe's show ''Harlem Song.'' This is good news for Harlem: The show will attract diverse, well-to-do crowds to the neighborhood. This is also bad news for Harlem, or at least news to provoke ambivalence: The same crowds, added to the area's accelerating economic development, may in their own way pose a serious threat to Harlem's hard-won cultural identity.

title: President of Iran Says U.S. Creates 'War-Like' Tension
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 13  President Mohammed Khatami of Iran struck out at President Bush and other senior American officials today during a visit to Afghanistan, saying they had "mis-used" the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States "to create an atmosphere of violence and war."

title: Lofty Suitors, and a Determined Bellhop
description: There is so much edgy delight in the battle of the sexes in ''The Mistress of the Inn'' (''La Posadera'') that it is sad to see the sun set on it. The Puerto Rican Traveling Theater sets a high standard in its 35th season of free outdoor summer performances in the city's five boroughs and several locations in New Jersey with Carlo Goldoni's 18th-century rustic comedy; this is very sophisticated alfresco theater.

title: Child-Smuggling Ring Broken Up By the U.S. Immigration Agency
description: Federal officials said today that they had broken up a huge child-smuggling ring that preyed on illegal immigrants desperate to be reunited with their children.

title: UNIT OF J.P. MORGAN TO BUY BRAND SERVICES
description: The private-equity division of J. P. Morgan Chase, J. P. Morgan Partners, agreed to buy Brand Services Inc. from DLJ Merchant Banking for about $500 million. Brand Services, which is based in St. Louis, provides scaffolding services to refineries, and chemical and power plants, the company said. The purchase is consistent with J. P. Morgan Partners' plan to invest in companies with strong management teams and cash flow, the company said. J. P. Morgan Partners has more than $30 billion in total capital under management. DLJ Merchant Banking, the private-equity unit of the Credit Suisse Group's Credit Suisse First Boston unit, bought Brand Services from Waste Management Inc. in 1996, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, IRA BENJAMIN V.
description: WHEELER-Ira Benjamin V. On August 10, 2002, in New York City, where he lived, at the age of 81. He was the husband of Mary T. Wheeler, father of Dorothy W. Bacon and Timothy M. Wheeler. He had two granddaughters, Katharine D. Bacon and Sarah H. Bacon. He was the stepfather of Fletcher H. Bardsley, William Walker Bardsley, and Clymer D. Bardsley and step-grandfather of Austin Miller Bardsley. Four of his children by his first wife, Grace Tufts Wheeler, pre-deceased him: Ira B. Wheeler VI, Timothy D. Wheeler, Ann D. Wheeler, and Mark W. Wheeler. He also had three stepchildren from his second marriage to Elizabeth Strong Wheeler: Lawrence A. Serre, Alison E. Serre and Elizabeth Clark Logan. He graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1938 and Princeton University in 1942. He served as a lieutenant in the Coast Guard during World War II and was executive officer on an LST in the Pacific. He spent much of his working life at Celanese Corporation, where he was a Corporate Vice President when he retired in 1982. After retiring, he began two new careers. He became a consultant for numerous non-profit organizations through the National Executive Service Corps (NESC), and was recently named to its board of directors. One of his longtime clients was Literacy Partners, where he later served on the board. He also became an actor, with parts in 24 movies including The Killing Fields, Hannah and Her Sisters, and Analyze This. He sang with the Canterbury Choral Society and was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe. He was treasurer of the Princeton class of 1942. He was a strong and remarkable man who will be missed terribly by his family and his many friends. There will be a family burial service and a memorial celebration with music in the Fall. Contributions in his memory may be made to Princeton University and the Canterbury Choral Society, 2 East 90th St, NY, NY 10128.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Won't Treat Options As Expense
description: PeopleSoft, whose software manages accounting and human resources, joined the Intel Corporation yesterday in saying that it would not change the way it treats stock options on its financial statements, arguing that making them a compensation expense would stifle innovation. Responding to recent accounting scandals, companies like Coca-Cola and General Electric have pledged to treat employee stock options as an expense. But Kevin Parker, PeopleSoft's chief financial officer, said that he and Craig Conway, the chief executive, had discussed the issue with the board and audit committee and decided against making a change. ''We don't believe it's a traditional expense,'' he said in an interview. ''It's a reallocation of stockholder equity.'' Mr. Parker said that 80 percent of PeopleSoft's employees had received options and that the options had ''helped align their interest and energy'' with stockholders'. PeopleSoft's senior management holds less than 12 percent of total stock options. Shares in PeopleSoft fell 7 cents, to $16.83. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: SCHOOL TAX LAWSUIT ADVANCES The Connecticut Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday that a group of taxpayers from Canaan could challenge the state formula for levying school taxes in regional school districts. A lower court judge had dismissed the case, saying it presented a political and not a judicial question. Without ruling on the suit's merits, the Supreme Court said the group's lawsuit had challenged the formula's constitutionality and could be reviewed. The taxpayers assert that towns with a smaller property tax base pay an unfairly high portion of school taxes.   David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: UKRAINE: MORE BLAMED IN AIR DISASTER Yevhen Marchuk, the official investigating the crash that killed 85 people at a military air show near Lviv last month, told President Leonid D. Kuchma that "numerous violations and shortcomings by the show's organizers, servicemen, city officials and the pilots' deviation from the flight plan" had caused the disaster. Earlier the blame had focused on the two pilots  who ejected just before their SU-27 fighter jet crashed into spectators  and military officials. In a television interview on Friday, one of the pilots attributed the crash to technical problems and orders "to fly where people were." Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Clothes That Whisper, I Belong to the Club
description: It is now conventional wisdom that during the 1990's, design underwent a process of democratization in the United States. Refined taste became a preoccupation of the masses. Suddenly men and women who 10 years earlier might not have known that a baguette referred to a loaf of bread could tell you that a baguette is also a $1,600 shoulder purse produced by the house of Fendi, which happens to be based in Rome. What the culture expected of women who could not afford Prada skirts was that they buy some reasonably priced facsimile at the Gap. There was no justifiable reason why anyone would ever again look like Dixie Carter in ''Designing Women.''

title: Europe for Thanksgiving

Starting rates from other cities include: Chicago, $618 to London, $611 to Paris; Los Angeles or San Francisco, $638 to London, $697 to Paris. These prices include round-trip air fare, three nights' hotel accommodations, daily Continental breakfast, and all hotel taxes and service charges. At the base prices, the hotel in London is the 534-room Posthouse Kensington, with an indoor pool and health club a short walk from Kensington High Street . In Paris, the 31-room De Lausanne in the Ninth Arrondissement is the base-price hotel. Airline departure taxes as well as weekend surcharges are extra; subject to availability and restrictions. Information: (800) 927-3876 or on the Web at www.europeexpress.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, RABBI MORDECAI
description: WAXMAN-Rabbi Mordecai. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Rabbi Mordecai Waxman. He served with distinction and honor as spiritual leader of Temple Israel in Great Neck for more than half a century. Considered a giant for his national and international communal leadership, Rabbi Waxman assumed significant roles in numerous organizations, where his contributions to world Jewry were enormous. He was a strong supporter and loving critic of UJA-Federation. A major world Jewish figure, he was a pioneer in interfaith relations and egalitarianism for women in Judaism. A scholar, author, and renowned community advocate, Rabbi Waxman influenced the lives of generations. We extend our deepest condolences to his three sons, Rabbi Jonathan, David, Hillel, and his sister Naomi Perlman, and to their spouses and children. May his memory be a blessing. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. and CEO Erika Witover, LI Chair Stuart Tauber, LI Director

title: Kiss and Tell
description: The one shocking thing about ''No Lifeguard on Duty: The Accidental Life of the World's First Supermodel'' (ReganBooks/HarperCollins), a remember-that-Wednesday-is-recycling-day memoir by Janice Dickinson, is not that the 47-year-old former model was a victim of childhood sexual abuse. It is not that she has ingested at least her own body weight in quaaludes and cocaine. It is not that, in pursuit of fame, fortune and the cover of Mexican Vogue, she has enjoyed carnal knowledge of Mick Jagger, Warren Beatty, Sylvester Stallone and Liam Neeson. It is not that Ms. Dickinson has produced her own rather vivid addition to the already considerable store of published metaphors characterizing Mr. Neeson's anatomy. No, the most remarkable feature of this Page Six-style story of sin and redemption is this: it has an index.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: PEOPLESOFT WON'T TREAT OPTIONS AS EXPENSE PeopleSoft, whose software manages accounting and human resources, joined the Intel Corporation yesterday in saying that it would not change the way it treats stock options on its financial statements, arguing that making them a compensation expense would stifle innovation. Responding to recent accounting scandals, companies like Coca-Cola and General Electric have pledged to treat employee stock options as an expense. But Kevin Parker, PeopleSoft's chief financial officer, said that he and Craig Conway, the chief executive, had discussed the issue with the board and audit committee and decided against making a change. "We don't believe it's a traditional expense," he said in an interview. "It's a reallocation of stockholder equity." Mr. Parker said that 80 percent of PeopleSoft's employees had received options and that the options had "helped align their interest and energy" with stockholders'. PeopleSoft's senior management holds less than 12 percent of total stock options. Shares in PeopleSoft fell 7 cents, to $16.83. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SUDAN: NEW BID FOR PEACE Rebels and government officials met in Kenya for the start of talks widely viewed as the best chance yet of ending a 19-year war that has killed two million people. The negotiations, scheduled to last around five weeks, follow a round of talks in July that raised hopes for a comprehensive cease-fire. The rebels want southern Sudan, which is mainly animist with a small percentage of Christians and Muslims, to have more autonomy from the mainly Muslim north and want exemption from Islamic law, which has been applied countrywide. The government agreed to those demands last month, signing a framework deal that will allow southerners to opt for secession after a six-year period of administrative autonomy. (Reuters)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Target To Use Amazon Retail Services
description: The Target Corporation and Amazon.com deepened what was already a close online relationship yesterday when they announced that Target's three store chains -- Mervyn's, Marshall Field's and Target -- were now using Amazon's online retail services. Mervyn's and Marshall Field's online customers are redirected to the Target.com site. Once there, customers may buy merchandise from each of the stores within the Target chain and may also purchase books, music and videos from Amazon. While Target continues to handle shipping and warehousing for Mervyn's and Marshall Field's online orders, Amazon operates the site on behalf of all the stores, using technology similar to that offered on Amazon.com. Amazon executes all shipping and handling for products from the Target brand store. The specific terms of the deal, which was initially announced in September and is now going into effect, were not disclosed, but Amazon will earn sales commissions and a flat annual fee. Amazon has had a Target store within the Amazon.com Web site since October. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)
