He is survived by his wife of 38 years, Gretchen Steinthal Coleman; a son and daughter-in-law, Peter J. Jr. and Bennett Coleman; a daughter and son-in-law, Gretchen and Douglas O'Hare, and daughter, Heidi Coleman; two grandchildren, Riley O'Hare and Caroline Coleman; a brother, Robert Coleman, and a sister, Carole Buckner. Visitation Tuesday at John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ, (732) 747-0332, 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday at the Church of the Nativity, Fair Haven, NJ, at 10 am. Interment to follow at Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Court Asked to Block Adelphia Bank Payments
description: Lawyers for a group of bondholders and other creditors of Adelphia Communications asked a bankruptcy court yesterday to block payments of $300 million that had been designated for Adelphia's banks.

title: Medical Privacy, Fading Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, STAN
description: DAVIS-Stan, fine arts photographer with works in many shows and in permanent collections of several museums died in Sarasota, FL, August 7, 2002 at age 96. Formerly of Weston, CT and NYC, he was also a longtime musician, composer and singer. He began his career in early radio on the ''Capitol Family Hour.'' In his 1935 NBC network show, he was known as ''The Rolling Stone,'' and shortly thereafter, began singing the themes for several daily radio shows. After his WWII service, CBS hired him to work with Edward R. Murrow, after which he turned to producing and directing. In 1959, NBC's ''Monitor'' weekend show tapped him to sing the news as ''The Monitor Balladier.'' Walt Disney asked him to write the theme for an early ''Daniel Boone'' TV show. In the mid 60's, he was music director on NBC's ''Exploring.'' A long career followed with the ''Captain Kangaroo'' show, for which he wrote and produced over 150 songs and films. He was a member of ASCAP and AFTRA. He is survived by his wife of 34 years, Joan, and children from previous marriages, Carol Preston, Santa Barbara, CA, Diane Davis, York, PA, and two grandchildren. A son, Richard, predeceased him in 1990. At his request, there were no services. A celebration of his life is planned for the fall. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Saugatuck Nursery School, 245 Post Road East, Westport, CT 06880.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Governor To Ease Access To Records
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey plans to withdraw many of the restrictions he had imposed on New Jersey's new open-records law, officials said yesterday. He is scheduled to sign an executive order and detail his plans today. Last month, a new law widened public access to government records, but several days before it took effect, Mr. McGreevey exempted many records, citing privacy concerns and the risk that terrorists might gain useful information. After negotiating with the New Jersey Press Association and lawyers for the state's major newspapers, Mr. McGreevey has agreed to drop many of the 483 exemptions. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

title: Ailey's Young International Graduates Show How to Sizzle
description: The Ailey School's ''Summer Sizzler 2002,'' presented on Friday night at the Ailey headquarters on West 61st Street in Manhattan, was a festive, informal program of new pieces performed by graduates of the school's international summer intensive program, ages 12 to 23. The dances, most created by Ailey teachers or associates, covered a wide range.

title: CENDANT'S REAL ESTATE DIVISION BUYS DEWOLFE
description: The NRT unit of the Cendant Corporation will buy the DeWolfe Companies in Massachusetts for $149 million to expand there, the nation's third most expensive market. NRT is a leading owner of residential brokerage firms. NRT, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., will pay $19 a share, according to Jennifer Reese, an NRT spokeswoman. The price is about double DeWolfe's closing price Friday of $9.11. NRT has been adding brokerage firms as part of Cendant's strategy to cross-sell its other services, like mortgages and vacation packages, to homebuyers. Buying DeWolfe, which is based in Lexington, Mass., will more than double NRT's offices in the Boston area, which ranks behind San Francisco and Anaheim, Calif., among the nation's most expensive markets, according to the National Association of Realtors.

title: Union Puts Off Strike Date to Pursue Talks
description: On the eighth anniversary of the start of the longest strike in sports history, the baseball players union gave fans hope today that history would not repeat itself. In an unexpected development, the union's executive board opted not to set a strike date but to continue negotiating until at least Friday before taking that step.

title: The Cheney Factor
description: As President Bush and his economic team interrupt their vacations today to gather in Texas for an economic conference, Vice President Dick Cheney may have trouble playing his customary role as elder statesman. The problem is not primarily Mr. Cheney's weak heart, though that has impeded him, or his disappearances to unidentified secure locations, which have been the subject of much mirth on late-night television shows. Mr. Cheney's big problem is that he's associated with a company, Halliburton, that is under investigation for possibly improper accounting practices. That makes him less than the ideal front man for an administration trying to restore confidence in a sputtering economy spooked by corporate malfeasance.

title: MAYTAG LOWERS PROFIT ESTIMATE, AND SHARES FALL
description: Shares of the Maytag Corporation fell 5 percent after the appliance maker said third-quarter profit would be hurt by slower production to clear excess inventory and laid off 400 workers. Shares fell $1.56, to $29.81. The job cuts occurred this month at two refrigerator plants after retailers cut June orders, a spokesman, Jim Powell, said.

title: Palms Return to an Island (Manhattan); A Major Replanting as the Winter Garden Prepares to Reopen
description: Palm trees stood tall in the Winter Garden once again yesterday. And for the first time in 11 months, it seemed that life itself had returned to the celebrated 10-story glass dome.

title: U.S. Received Tip on Qaeda Threats Against Landmarks
description: High-ranking Bush administration officials said yesterday that the administration received a report from a foreign government in recent weeks about potential threats against such targets as the Brooklyn Bridge, the Golden Gate Bridge and a major landmark in Chicago.

title: C.I.A. Chief Skeptical About a New Palestinian Security Force
description: Despite pressure from the Bush administration for the rapid organization of a new Palestinian security force, George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, remains skeptical about the prospects, administration officials said today.

title: New Knees May Be in Order When Other Options Fail
description: When lesser measures can no longer control the pain and disability of arthritic knees, surgery to reconstruct or replace them then becomes a consideration. But only a consideration.

title: New Promise For Treating A Crippler
description: ''Conquering Rheumatoid Arthritis,'' by Dr. Thomas F. Lee, Prometheus Books, $20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISLER, SOPHIE
description: EISLER-Sophie. Age 100. Beloved mother, cherished friend to many. Donations in her memory to The Lighthouse or Andrew Heiskell Library.

title: Phelps Sets Record In 200-Meter Medley
description: At 15 years old, Michael Phelps was the youngest swimmer on the United States' 2000 Olympic team. He first became known as a butterfly specialist, but that has turned out to be a bit misleading, showing only a glimmer of Phelps's world-class potential.

title: Colon Cancer: Care, Not Biology
description: It is well established that black people with colon cancer are more likely to die of it than white people are, but researchers have been unable to explain why. A new study offers evidence that, its authors say, refutes theories that biological differences between the races may play a role.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: INSURER'S PROFIT FALLS The South African insurer Old Mutual said first-half profit fell 16 percent because the value of the rand declined. Pretax earnings, excluding short-term gains and losses on investments, slumped to 381 million ($583 million), from 455 million ($690 million) a year earlier. Old Mutual makes about three-quarters of its profit in South Africa, where the rand weakened 28 percent against the pound in the year to June 30. The company, which was founded in Cape Town but moved its headquarters to London in 1999, said it earned 291 million ($440 million), down 26 percent, in South Africa.

title: A Dance for the City, Complete With Traffic and Muggings
description: Cities can be puzzling or even dangerous. That was made clear in ''One -- (the Other),'' which Perpetual Motion Theater, a London-based company, presented Sunday afternoon at the Theater for the New City as part of the New York International Fringe Festival.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Prisoner Escapes, Briefly
description: A woman imprisoned on a drug charge escaped police custody briefly yesterday afternoon when an officer opened a door of a police van that was stopped at Willoughby Street and Nostrand Avenue and she burst out and ran, the authorities said. Officers quickly recaptured the woman, Robin McAllister, 33, of Brooklyn. As they did so, an officer's gun accidentally fired a round, but no one was injured, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: California County Ponders Resuming Ties With Merrill
description: Orange County, which blamed Merrill Lynch & Company for contributing to its municipal bankruptcy in 1994, is talking about working with the investment firm again. But at least one county supervisor opposes the idea.

title: Sweet but Deadly Addiction Is Seizing the Young in India
description: Promoted by a slick and many-tentacled advertising campaign, gutka, an indigenous form of smokeless tobacco, has become a fixture in the mouths of millions of Indians over the last two decades. It has spread through the subcontinent, and even to South Asians in England.

title: Tunnel Vision; The Light at the Top of the Subway Stairs
description: Nonverbal communication has always been widespread in the subway.

title: Factions Meet, but Fail To Achieve Arafat's Goal
description: Pressed by Yasir Arafat, a wide range of Palestinian factions including Hamas have drawn up a draft unity platform that could be interpreted as implying that attacks on civilians within Israel might end.

title: ICAHN'S HIGH RIVER RAISES ITS OFFER FOR XO DEBTS
description: Carl C. Icahn's High River Limited Partnership raised its offer to buy as much as $331 million of the senior secured loans of XO Communications Inc., a telephone and Internet service provider that filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year. High River will pay 70 cents on the dollar for the loans, an offer that expires Friday, the partnership said in a statement. XO, which was founded by Craig McCaw, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June. On July 30, the partnership said lenders could choose to receive 50 cents on the dollar for the loans or 45 cents plus other rights if a reorganization plan by the buyout company Forstmann Little and the Mexican phone company Telfonos de Mexico was completed. On July 10, Mr. Icahn offered 40 cents on the dollarin an effort to gain more of a voice in XO's bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Seeing Long Trading Slump, Schwab Sets More Cutbacks
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that it would shut one of its five customer call centers, eliminate 375 jobs and look for ways to save an additional $200 million a year as it braces for an extended slump in trading by individual investors.

title: Rockabilly? It's Alive And Kicking, Daddy-O
description: Survivors from the rockabilly era and their next-generation disciples gathered for the Red Hot Rockabilly Party at Damrosch Park on Sunday afternoon to show that their music can still kick. From the 1950's came Narvel Felts and Jack Scott, two singers who had not performed in New York City for decades, along with two more frequent visitors, Wanda Jackson and Billy Lee Riley. They shared the four-hour Lincoln Center Out of Doors concert, with Rosie Flores, the Persuasions, Lee Rocker (formerly of the Stray Cats) and Rocky and Billy Burnette, the sons (respectively) of the rockabilly pioneers Johnny and Dorsey Burnette.

title: Diet Company's Profit Up
description: Weight Watchers International, the weight-loss counseling company that went public in November, raised its 2002 forecast after its second-quarter profit rose 58 percent from a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VERNAY, JEAN, PIERRE
description: VERNAY-Jean-Pierre. December 5, 1938-August 13, 1988. Remembered with love every day. Bill and Lenn

title: Lawyers for Spider-Man win a fight over Times Square.
description: LOOKS as if Spider-Man has spun himself out of another sticky situation.

title: Officials of 14 States Pledge Protection of Pension Assets
description: Treasurers and other state officials with influence over more than $1 trillion of public pension assets said yesterday that they would work together to foster integrity in corporate America in the wake of the scandals that have cost these pension plans tens of billions of dollars.

title: West Nile and Its Lessons for Doctors
description: As West Nile fever spreads through the country, it is giving scientists a rare picture of how a virus carves a new ecological niche in a hemisphere where it has never been seen.

title: From Eakins's Canvas, 1800's Version of Medical Docudrama
description: The barrage of images and stories depicting doctors battling death have become standard fare today. Even the doors of the operating room, once the exclusive domain of surgeons, have been thrown wide open. Every day, millions watch lifesaving operations on television, both dramatic representations and actual procedures.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about an accord to end Congo's war against Rwanda and Uganda misidentified one of three countries aligned with the Congolese. It was Namibia, (along with Angola and Zimbabwe). Zambia sent troops to Congo only as part of a peacekeeping mission and did not support the war effort.

title: Poll Backs Lower Manhattan Cultural Sites
description: Most people who live and work in Lower Manhattan say they would be likely to go to any new museums and other cultural and entertainment attractions in the area, according to a new poll.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Assassin Suspect Said To Confess
description: A man accused of belonging to the guerrilla group November 17 has confessed to killing a British brigadier, Stephen Saunders, in Athens two years ago, the police said. They said Savas Xiros had also confessed to shooting nine other people, including an American military officer and a Turkish diplomat. Sixteen suspected members of the group -- which grew out of the popular struggle against the American-backed military dictatorship of 1967-74 -- have been taken into police custody since late June. Mr. Xiros was wounded at that time in a bungled bombing attempt at the country's biggest port, Piraeus. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Business Woes Add Scrutiny To Campaigns
description: George E. Pataki returned campaign cash from WorldCom, but not Adelphia Communications, Tyco International or Global Crossing. H. Carl McCall gave up ImClone Systems money, but not Global Crossing money. Andrew M. Cuomo hedged on Enron, returning some but keeping most.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Sun Microsystems' introduction of computers that run the Linux operating system misstated the company's experience with Linux. Sun already sells a Linux-based system, under the Cobalt brand; the new computers are not the first.

title: Turning the Lowly Parking Lot Into a Vibrant Brand
description: EVER since they paved paradise to put one up, in that Joni Mitchell song that was one of the merely incidental annoyances of 1970, the parking lot has been a pretty tough sell.

title: Sampras Searching for Perfect Sunset
description: All those years, Pete Sampras ambled around the court with his head in a full-blown droop, staring down at the gritty surface in the kind of solitude reserved for beachcombers.

title: Santa Cruz, City of Colorful Street Life, Resolves to Be Somewhat Less So
description: Early in the morning well before the tourists started straggling out of their motel rooms or the teenage cliques, baby strollers, street clowns and musicians turned the streets into a summer Sunday's parade -- you could see the yellow-chalk messages on the sidewalks of downtown Pacific Avenue quite clearly.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Maker Offers Options
description: The world's second-largest supplier of made-to-order computer chips, the United Microelectronics Corporation, will for the first time give employees stock options to keep up with rivals that offer better compensation. The company will allocate one billion options that can be converted into the equivalent of 6.4 percent of its outstanding stock. Half of those shares, worth about 29 billion Taiwan dollars ($856 million) at their current price, can be purchased within two years and half within four years, the company said. United Microelectronics, which is based in Hsinchu, Taiwan, is trying to provide more incentives to employees to keep them from being hired away by rivals.

title: Voyagers Reap a Bounty of Beauty and Discovery
description: Twenty-five years ago, in the late summer of 1977, two identical spacecraft took off on missions of exploration deep into the outer solar system. No drum rolls accompanied their launchings, no bloated language of cold war victories to be won or Odysseyan adventures ahead. In a departure from an earlier practice, the spacecraft were not given fanciful names from mythology, like Mercury or Gemini or Apollo. They were called simply the Voyagers.

title: FORD TO SELL KWIK-FIT TO CVC CAPITAL FOR $505 MILLION
description: The Ford Motor Company will sell Kwik-Fit Holding, a European car repair chain, to CVC Capital Partners for 330 million ($505 million), a third of what Ford paid for it three years ago. Ford said in January that it would sell the business as well as two others in the United States to help raise $1 billion to stem losses and focus on automaking. Ford bought Kwik-Fit for 1.01 billion in 1999 as the former chief executive, Jacques Nasser, expanded into car service businesses. Ford, which is based in Dearborn, Mich., said it would have third-quarter costs of about $500 million from the Kwik-Fit sale. Ford will keep a 19 percent stake in Kwik-Fit, which had sales last year of 762 million.

title: Younger Generation Will Seek Ways to Buy Newspaper Chain
description: A committee of fourth-generation family shareholders of the privately held Freedom Communications, which owns newspapers like The Orange County Register, began yesterday to discuss how to raise the capital to buy out those relatives who want to sell, according to two members of the group.

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the National Briefing column on Thursday about the number of doctors who make house calls referred incorrectly to effects of a 1998 increase in Medicare payments for home visits. The number of house calls paid for by Medicare fell to 1.5 million in 2001 from 1.6 million in 1996. It did not rise to 1.5 million from 195,700.

title: Colorectal Cancer Drug Wins Quick Approval From F.D.A.
description: After a review of only seven weeks, the shortest ever for a cancer drug, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a new drug for last-ditch use by patients with colorectal cancer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Couple's Bodies Discovered In Apartment
description: The police are investigating the shooting deaths of a man and a woman whose bodies were discovered yesterday in their Kingsbridge Heights apartment. A gun was recovered at the scene. The woman, Frenia Roa, 22, and the man, Apollinar Collado, 34, were married a week and a half ago. Tina Kelley

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO., New York, , said it bought Dynamic Ideas, Cambridge, Mass., a mutual fund analysis and investment company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: More Blamed In Air Disaster
description: Yevhen Marchuk, the official investigating the crash that killed 85 people at a military air show near Lviv last month, told President Leonid D. Kuchma that ''numerous violations and shortcomings by the show's organizers, servicemen, city officials and the pilots' deviation from the flight plan'' had caused the disaster. Earlier the blame had focused on the two pilots -- who ejected just before their SU-27 fighter jet crashed into spectators -- and military officials. In a television interview on Friday, one of the pilots attributed the crash to technical problems and orders ''to fly where people were.'' Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: A Court's Interference
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Around the World

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHR, KARL HOWELL
description: BEHR-Karl Howell. 88, died peacefully at home in East Hampton, NY, on August 10 from pneumonia. He was the son of Karl H. Behr and Helen Newsom, miraculous survivors of the Titanic. Born and raised in NYC, Karl graduated from Lawrenceville School in 1933 and Yale University in 1937. In World War II he served in the Navy as a Lt. Commander from 1941 to 1946 in the Pacific. A philanthropic businessman, he founded Converters Inc. Company in 1952. A resident of Mountain Lake, Lake Wales, FL, and East Hampton, Karl is survived by four daughters, Susan Travers, Princeton, NJ, Sally Ogden, Greenwich, CT, Helen Sanford, Princeton, NJ, and Elaine King, Dover, MA, as well as ten grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, BARBARA
description: MILLER-Barbara. Of Pleasantville. Died August 10, 2002. Loving mother of Paul, Bruce, Eric and Adam. Grandmother of Luke, Max, Hannah, Alex and Emily. Mother-in-law of Deborah, Sharon, Cheryl and June. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, 5:15 PM, at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville NY.

title: Prosecutors in Sept. 11 Trial Ask Court to Deny More Delay
description: Federal prosecutors urged a trial judge today to deny defense requests to delay the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui and suggested that Mr. Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, was to blame for many of the delays so far.

title: Cost of Revamping Lowers Profit at May
description: May Department Stores, the owner of Lord & Taylor and Filene's, said here today that profit fell 38 percent in the second fiscal quarter, the sixth straight quarterly decline, because of restructuring costs in combining four chains into two divisions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Edsger Wybe Dijkstra, whose contributions to mathematical logic underlie modern computer programming, misstated the day of his death. It was last Tuesday, not the previous day.

title: MEMO PAD
description: A Bright Side To US Airways Tale

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a deadline for retailers to convert to 13-digit bar codes misstated the ownership of Cognizant Technology Solutions, which was hired by Ace Hardware to overhaul its systems. Cognizant is now independent, no longer a division of Dun & Bradstreet.

title: Awesome Humor Shows She Can Set a Pace, Too
description: Nobody was more surprised than Pat Day this afternoon when he found himself racing on the lead with his mount, Awesome Humor, in the 87th running of the Grade II Adirondack Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, SANFORD H.
description: HARTMAN-Sanford H. Died in Lenox, MA on August 12th, 2002 at 94. Beloved husband of the late Henrietta Hartman. Cherished companion of Helen Finkel. Adored father of Dana Freyer and Jim Hartman, father-in-law of Bruce Freyer and Evelyn Hartman. Beloved Poppy of Tyana, Daria, Joe, Jakey, Alisa and Benji. He lived life to the fullest and left a rich legacy of love of family, compassion, integrity, and generosity. May his beautiful life ever inspire and guide us. Memorial service Wednesday, August 14th, 11 AM, Congregation Emanuel of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 3rd Ave., NY NY 10017.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about an accord to end Congo's war against Rwanda and Uganda misidentified one of three countries aligned with the Congolese. It was Namibia, (along with Angola and Zimbabwe). Zambia sent troops to Congo only as part of a peacekeeping mission and did not support the war effort.

title: Israel Apologizes To Journalist
description: Defense Minister Benjamin Ben-Eliezer offered a personal apology today to a prominent Israeli journalist who was fired upon on Sunday by an Israeli soldier as the journalist entered a West Bank military zone with army permission.

title: American Airlines to Cut 7,000 Jobs and Ground Some Aircraft
description: American Airlines announced today that it would eliminate 7,000 jobs over the next seven months and ground a fleet of 74 medium-range aircraft in a bid to return the company to profitability following record losses since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Scouts in the Solar System
description: Space near Earth swarms with hundreds of satellites like bees around a hive, tracking the weather, routing phone calls and beaming ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' to homes everywhere. Others ply the same altitudes with loftier missions: the Hubble Space Telescope looks for light nearly as old as time itself.

title: Cause of Fire Is Under Study in Forced Landing at Kennedy
description: The cause of an engine fire that forced an Iberia Airlines 747 to make an emergency landing on Sunday at Kennedy International Airport remained under investigation yesterday. Meanwhile, two passengers were still hospitalized after they were injured in an evacuation that was described as chaotic.

title: In a Work Stoppage, Some TV Money Would Evaporate
description: Although the baseball players union chose not to set a strike date yesterday, a walkout is still possible, one that could erase the playoffs and the World Series. If a strike occurs and it is not resolved in time to salvage the postseason, Major League Baseball could end up owing Fox Sports at least $500 million.

title: Papa John's Selects Austin Kelley
description: Papa John's International in Louisville, Ky., the pizza chain, selected Austin Kelley Advertising in Atlanta to handle its strategic and creative account. Spending was estimated at $40 million to $45 million.

title: Technology on Docks: Fears Despite Promises
description: As a bus packed with longshoremen headed to a giant Korean ship at Berth 36, Wendell Womack lashed out at management's contract proposal, saying it would be terrible for longshoremen and for the people of Oakland.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In San Diego; Hot Economy and Mild Temperatures
description: Don't tell San Diego that the country recently suffered a recession.

title: Injured Alfonzo Watches And Waits
description: Edgardo Alfonzo was changing by his locker late Sunday night, having removed the Mets' uniform that now serves merely as a workout outfit. The Mets had just lost again, their deficit in the standing looming larger with the shortening season. Alfonzo was asked how much he thought the Mets missed him and he smiled.

title: Williams Having Another Season Not to Be Taken for Granted
description: When Robin Ventura was kneed in the head in April, he reported that his mind had gone foggy, and that now he knew how it felt to be Bernie Williams.

title: Connecting the Dots Downtown
description: It has always been clear that the foundation of Lower Manhattan's revival would be a new and improved transportation system. It's important, of course, to build new office space and housing, no less important to create a stirring memorial. Yet first-class transportation is essential to restoring the area's vitality. The federal government's decision to contribute $4.55 billion in disaster relief funds to underwrite a new system linking PATH commuter trains with downtown subway lines -- until now a distant dream -- is thus very good news. It was not just the money, though that is welcome. It was also the fact that it came largely without strings.

title: The Only Game in Town
description: Major League Baseball's players union postponed setting a strike date at their meeting yesterday, saying they would continue negotiations with owners. Some fans, meanwhile, have already adopted their own labor strategy. Instead of waiting for a strike to ruin the season, they've decided to ruin their enjoyment of baseball. Bashing the game has become a popular national pastime of its own. The games are too slow, the players are on steroids, players and owners care only about money. And besides, with so many other happy diversions, who needs baseball anyway?

title: Preparing a Corps of Women For Corporate Responsibility
description: Headhunters say it has been hard, ever since Enron, to find people willing to serve as corporate directors; no one wants to be shamed or sued for sleepwalking through the next meltdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, TESSIE
description: FELDMAN-Tessie. The Congregation of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, records with profound sorrow the passing of the mother of past president, Stephen J. Feldman. We express our deepest sympathy to the family. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: 'Heat Island' Tokyo Is in Global Warming's Vanguard
description: With the temperature 96 degrees in the shade, veterans of this concrete jungle braced themselves recently as they opened a door to an apartment building roof. But instead of confronting a wall of dry heat, they felt their faces cooled by moist air, carrying a light scent of soil and fresh grass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDEFELD, JOHN JULIUS
description: GRANDEFELD-John Julius. Of Pelham, NY, died August 11, 2002, at the age of 93. Born on September 21, 1908 and active up until the time of his death, Mr. Grandefeld was a practicing attorney with Cusack and Stiles, NYC. Mr. Grandefeld married the love of his life, Muriel Trigge, on May 21, 1938 and she predeceased him. A graduate of Stuyvesant HS, NYU and Brooklyn Law, he was the oldest practicing alumnus of Brooklyn Law. He was a member of the New York and America Bar Associations, a Free Mason, the Wyoming Lodge, Huguenot Memorial Church, the Skytop Club and Pelham Country Club. Devoted to his family, Mr. Grandefeld is survived by his children, Merry Kormann, Joan Hurst and John Grandfeld. He is also survived by his eight loving grandchildren. Visitors may call at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY on Tuesday 7-9 & Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9. The funeral will be at Huguenot Memorial Church Thursday 10 AM.

title: McCall Puts Workers on an Ally's Payroll
description: Reports to the state show that much of H. Carl McCall's campaign staff recently went on the payroll of his choice for lieutenant governor, Dennis Mehiel, a highly unusual cost-sharing that is saving Mr. McCall's gubernatorial campaign thousands of dollars.

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: AIDS Coverage
description: Following the lead of Anglo American, which announced a similar program last week, De Beers, the world's biggest diamond company, said that it would begin supplying AIDS drugs at 10 percent of the cost to H.I.V.-positive employees. Like Anglo, its biggest corporate shareholder, De Beers has thousands of employees in southern Africa, which has the world's highest rates of H.I.V. infection. The costs of the epidemic have been mounting, and companies across the region have been grappling with how best to combat it. Many governments in the region say they cannot afford to pay for the drugs for the millions who would need them. ''This is essentially a strong humanitarian and moral statement by this company,'' the managing director, Gary M. Ralfe, said. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economic Growth
description: Singapore said its economy grew 3.9 percent in the second quarter of the year, the first year-on-year increase in five quarters, as a surge in pharmaceutical production offset a sluggish recovery in electronics exports. New drug production helped send output by chemical companies up 87 percent. Electronics, on the other hand, increased 1.8 percent on higher production. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Fictional Sex, Real Lawsuit

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHMAN, MICHAEL
description: FISHMAN-Michael. Aug. 19, 1963-Aug. 13, 1995. Until we meet again, lovingly remembered, family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORIE, PETER
description: BORIE-Peter. Retired attorney, 88, on August 10, 2002. Son of the Philadelphia painter Adolphe Borie, he attended Episcopal Academy and graduated from St. Paul's School, Yale University and Columbia Law School. He served as a Lt. Commander in the Navy during WWII. After practicing law as a partner with the New York firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, he joined the legal department of Pepsi Cola in 1951 and was named a Vice-President, retiring in 1971. He served on the board of trustees of the Nightingale -Bamford School and on the board of Interfaith Neighbors in New York City. In 1990, he and his second wife, Mary, moved back to Philadelphia. He is survived by a daughter, Edith Borie; three step-daughters, Valerie Takai, Molly Hoffman Mazzone and Helen Davies; and two grandchildren, Giorgio Mazzone and Elena Mazzone. Service will be held in Philadelphia at St. Peter's Church, 3rd & Pine Sts., Wednesday, August 14 at 4:00 PM. title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Mosquito Spraying In Queens
description: Ground spraying to kill mosquitoes that may carry the West Nile virus is scheduled for College Point, Bay Terrace and Bayside tomorrow from 8:30 p.m. to 2 a.m., weather permitting. The area to be sprayed in College Point is bounded by 11th Avenue to the south, 135th Street to the east and College Place to the west. In Bay Terrace and Bayside, the areas to be sprayed are bounded by the Long Island Expressway to the south (including Queensborough Community College), Bell Boulevard to 35th Avenue to Francis Lewis Boulevard to Utopia Parkway to the west, and the Cross Island Parkway to the north (including Fort Totten) and east (including Crocheron Park, Clearview Park and Golf Course and northern Alley Pond Park).

title: Federal Reserve Board Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  The Federal Reserve left its benchmark short-term interest rate unchanged at a four-decade low today, but it gave an unmistakable signal that it was willing to cut rates even further if the economy continues to flag.

title: Prince Charles the Clothier
description: The news that Prince Charles will have his own line of country clothing by next year sounds as mysterious as crop circles. On Sunday, a report in The Times of London said that the prince plans to produce clothing under the Duchy Originals label. The garments are expected to be made by craftsmen from organically raised sheep, and profits will go to charities that help British farmers.

title: DOZENS ARE DEAD AS FLOODS SWEEP THROUGH EUROPE
description: Parts of the historic center of Prague were under water tonight and 50,000 residents were ordered evacuated as rivers swollen by more than a week of near constant rain etched ribbons of destruction across Central Europe and southern Russia.

title: Money for Just Some of a Transit Wish List
description: Federal, state and city officials gathered at the rim of ground zero yesterday to celebrate their cooperation in securing $4.55 billion in federal money to overhaul and update the tangle of subway stations, commuter terminals and other transportation outlets in Lower Manhattan.

title: Of Babies, Salt and Hypertension
description: Researchers have found that some newborns partial to the taste of salt already have blood pressure higher than normal, a discovery that may offer doctors a tool to identify those at risk for hypertension.

title: New Tactic To Prevent AIDS Spread
description: The idea that people with H.I.V. should take steps to prevent passing along the infection may seem self-evident. But health officials have long understood that a host of factors -- stress, a craving for intimacy, fear of rejection, drug and alcohol abuse -- can cause lapses in judgment and self-restraint that lead people to have unsafe sex.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer's Profit Falls
description: The South African insurer Old Mutual said first-half profit fell 16 percent because the value of the rand declined. Pretax earnings, excluding short-term gains and losses on investments, slumped to 381 million ($583 million), from 455 million ($690 million) a year earlier. Old Mutual makes about three-quarters of its profit in South Africa, where the rand weakened 28 percent against the pound in the year to June 30. The company, which was founded in Cape Town but moved its headquarters to London in 1999, said it earned 291 million ($440 million), down 26 percent, in South Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUGHRAN, JOHN F.
description: LOUGHRAN-John F. Of New City, NY, died peacefully on July 19, 2002, at his home. After his return to America from Japan in 1998 Mr. Loughran resided in New City, NY. He had been the Senior Officer of J.P. Morgan Bank in Japan and the Far East since the 1960s. His sister Patricia Comerford lives in Stony Point, NY. He has two brothers, James of England and William of Denver, CO. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews in Connecticut, Denver, Hong Kong and London. Mr. Loughran was a graduate of Fordham Preperatory School, Fordham and Yale Universities. title: SIX FLAGS SHARES FALL 57% ON EARNINGS AND FORECAST
description: Six Flags, the owner of 38 amusement parks in North America and Europe, earned less than expected in the second quarter and said its 2002 profit would miss forecasts, setting off a 57 percent decline in its stock price. Rainy, cool weekends in April, May and June kept people away from amusement parks in the Northeast and Midwest, the chief executive, Kieran Burke, said when the company released its results late on Monday. Six Flags said park attendance dropped in July, and park sales fell 6 percent. Shares of Six Flags, based in Oklahoma City, fell $6.80, to $5.06. Second-quarter profit from operations fell 7.8 percent, to $12.6 million, or 8 cents a share, from $13.6 million, or 9 cents, a year earlier.

title: Energy Pricing Suspicious, Report Says
description: Federal energy regulators, struggling to get to the bottom of the California energy crisis of 2000-01, said for the first time today that there was evidence that natural gas prices might have been manipulated, helping to drive up power prices.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Officer Accused Of Grand Larceny
description: A probationary police officer was arrested yesterday on charges that she fraudulently received $115,000 in welfare benefits over the past two years, the authorities said. The officer, Esther Cornielle, 38, a mother of four, joined the department in March 2000 but continued to claim that she was a beautician making about $9,300 a year, they said. Ms. Cornielle also used the name and Social Security number of a woman renting a room in her Queens apartment to claim more public assistance, said Capt. Patrick DeSarlo of the Internal Affairs Bureau. Officer Cornielle, who was suspended, has been charged with grand larceny and other crimes and faces 15 years in prison, if convicted. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: In Diplomacy With North Korea, Some Progress, and a Setback
description: In a zigzag of diplomatic activity today, North and South Korean ministers made progress in talks here over uniting divided families and divided railroads, a North Korean general met with an American general to discuss avoiding armed conflicts, and North Korea threatened to pull out of a nuclear agreement with the United States.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWEDEN: SURVIVING A TELECOM SLUMP Ericsson said the 30 billion kronor ($3.2 billion) it is raising in a share sale will be enough to help it survive the current slump in demand for telephone equipment. "We'll get through this with the 30 billion," the chief executive, Kurt Hellstroem, said at a news conference. "We haven't seen a turnaround yet, but this market will rebound." Ericsson is selling new shares to existing investors at 3.80 kronor to pay back debt and pay for severance packages. It expects the market for mobile networks to fall by more than 15 percent this year. (Bloomberg News)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Surviving A Telecom Slump
description: Ericsson said the 30 billion kronor ($3.2 billion) it is raising in a share sale will be enough to help it survive the current slump in demand for telephone equipment. ''We'll get through this with the 30 billion,'' the chief executive, Kurt Hellstroem, said at a news conference. ''We haven't seen a turnaround yet, but this market will rebound.'' title: Talking the Talk, Even With Strangers; An Inquiring Couple With a Sign Are Just Looking for a Nice Story
description: Liz Barry and Bill Wetzel sit on sidewalks around the city, not asking for money, or sociological survey data, or dates, or even a shower, though that would help after weeks of camping in parks and on rooftops. They just want to hear stories.

title: ANDRX SHARES FALL AFTER IT REPORTS OVERSTATEMENT
description: Shares of the Andrx Corporation, a maker of generic drugs, declined 12 percent yesterday after it said that it had inadvertently overstated some results. An employee altered accounting records, leading the company to overstate its accounts receivable, Andrx said late on Monday. The company said it might have overstated its accounts receivable by $15 million since January 1999. Andrx reported $103.6 million in receivables from that date to June 30. The employee wanted ''to make his handling of past-due accounts appear better,'' said the chief financial officer, Angelo Malahias. Shares of Andrx fell $2.78, to $20.54 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, KEVIN T.
description: O'Neill-Kevin T. A New York Times pressman for 35 years, died on August 3, 2002. He is survived by his daughters Karen Fanning, Barbara Gerardi and Margaret O'Neill, his sons-in-law, Thomas Fanning Sr and James Gerardi Sr, his grandchildren Michael, Kelly, Megan and Thomas Fanning Jr, Ashley and Danielle Riggi, Kyle and Samantha McLoughlin and James Gerardi Jr, brothers Robert O'Neill Sr., Gerard O'Neill, sisters Pamela O'Neill, Laurie O'Neill, Kathryn Ritondo and the late Jeanne Marie McCloud, many nieces and nephews. Burial took place at Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Airport Gets New Federal Screeners
description: The first crew of 150 federal X-ray screeners began work yesterday at Newark International Airport, Newark's first wave in a nationwide transition from private sector airport security to federal security personnel. Newark, one of 32 airports that now have federal screeners, is scheduled to add almost 900 more before Nov. 19, the deadline the Transportation Security Administration set to replace all private screeners. Danise Daville, above, and the other screeners were placed in Terminal A, the facility that United Flight 93 left before being hijacked by terrorists on Sept. 11 and then crashing in a Pennsylvania field. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Mixed Economic Messages
description: President Bush's stage-managed economic forum in Texas yesterday was billed as a chance for average Americans to express their views on the economy. Much was made of the wisdom of ordinary people, as opposed to Washington. It was thus striking that the Federal Reserve Board seemed to capture much better the American anxiety about the economy right now. The Fed did not lower interest rates, but it did suggest that the economy was not gathering strength -- a change from recent pronouncements. Understandably, the markets, which fell again, seemed to be paying more attention to the Fed than to Texas.

title: The Beats, at Work, at Play and in Court
description: The Beats go on. Half a century after a bunch of college kids from Columbia University moved to San Francisco and redefined the nation's culture, a revival of interest in the Beat Generation attests to their enduring place in American letters. In ''Beat,'' a captivating celebration of Allen Ginsberg, the group's poet laureate and arguably its greatest voice, Kelly Groves has captured the spirit of a literary movement for which there has never been a satisfactory definition.

title: Air Bags May Be Missing From Used Cars, Industry Group Warns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 - Vehicles with air bags that have been deployed are often refurbished with false or faulty replacements and resold to unsuspecting customers, an industry group said today.

title: Cracks Cause Amtrak to Halt High-Speed Northeast Trains
description: Amtrak today suspended its new high-speed Acela, the pride of the struggling railroad's fleet, a few hours after finding cracks in a part designed to keep the locomotives from swaying. Most of the trains seem likely to be out of service for days or weeks.

title: U.S. BANCORP BUYS TRUST DIVISION FROM STATE STREET
description: U.S. Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the State Street Corporation's corporate trust business for $725 million to expand in New England. The division, which acts as a trustee for corporate and municipal bondholders, will add 20,000 clients and $689 billion in assets under management, a U.S. Bancorp spokesman, Steve Dale, said. U.S. Bancorp, based in Minneapolis, has made four acquisitions since the Firstar Corporation bought U.S. Bancorp in February 2001 and adopted its name. State Street, which is based in Boston, said the sale would not affect its 2003 results.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: DEFLATION CONTINUES The National Bureau of Statistics said that consumer prices in July were 0.9 percent lower than in July of last year. That was a slightly greater drop than in June, when prices were 0.8 percent less than a year earlier, but a lesser drop than in May, when prices were down 1.1 percent from May 2001. Growth in factory capacity and continued migration of workers from impoverished inland provinces to the coast have kept prices low, while many Chinese appear to be saving more instead of spending. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Trachsel Takes Beating As Mets Fail to Gain
description: Steve Trachsel pitched a five-hit shutout in his last outing. But Trachsel pitches for the Mets, who seldom perform good things twice in a row. As an example, Trachsel caught one blistering line drive last night, then had another liner carom off his chest for a hit.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cellphone Ban Urged At Theaters
description: City Councilman Philip Reed, fighting those who take cellphone calls during public performances, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation this week to outlaw such behavior except in emergencies. Under the proposal, warning signs would be posted in theaters and other places, and violators could be fined up to $50. ''I know virtually nobody in New York,'' he said, ''who has not felt themselves and their quality of life abused by being in either a movie theater or concert hall or stadium and listening, annoyingly, to a telephone ring out there while they're trying to enjoy entertainment.'' During his news conference, an aide's cellphone interrupted Mr. Reed's remarks. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Rebels Release Kidnap Victims
description: A rebel group has released 4 aid workers and nearly 100 women and children who were kidnapped in the north of the country. The aid workers were abducted last week when the Lord's Resistance Army attacked a refugee camp, killing at least 38 people. The women and children were kidnapped from their villages earlier. The rebels, trying to topple the government of President Yoweri Museveni, call refugee camps fair game for attacks, saying the army recruits soldiers from them. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: A Second Chance for Brazil and the I.M.F.
description: The world is waiting to see how the market will judge Brazil and whether the International Monetary Fund's rescue package, announced over the weekend, will bring the country back from the brink. It would be foolish to try to predict the movements of a global market that has demonstrated a proclivity for excessive pessimism. Yet those who have looked closely at the numbers and the politics are almost unanimous: there is no reason for Brazil to collapse. The United States has every reason to hope that it doesn't.

title: Vivendi Posts Big Losses and Will Unload Many Acquisitions
