title: A Chef Beats the Drum, Loudly, for Farmers' Markets
description: AS farmers' markets have spread like pea shoots across the country over the last 25 years, so has the perception that shopping at them is elitist. A good many Americans still do not understand why a sweet little basket of locally grown, hand-picked strawberries costs $3 when the woody California travelers are 99 cents down at Shop 'n Save.

title: Judge Questions Detention Of American in War Case
description: The government's decision to hold war captives indefinitely without charges, without bail and without access to lawyers was on trial here today in a squat concrete courthouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HARRY J.
description: LEVINE-Harry J. On August 13, 2002, at the age of 102. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of Richard and Andrew, and father-in-law of Judith. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, David and Adam. Devoted brother of Florence Wishnow, Beatrice Flagler, Dr. Arnold E. Leeds and the late Dr. Meyer R. Levine, Arthur M. Levine and D. George Levine. He left a lasting impression on all who knew him. His love and devotion to family and community will be a source of joy and strength all the days of our lives. Services today, 10AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave (Ave J), Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: California County Will Avoid Merrill
description: The Orange County, Calif., board of supervisors adopted a proposal today that will effectively prevent Merrill Lynch from gaining business with the county.

title: New Intel Chip Promises to Do More With Less
description: The Intel Corporation said today that its next personal computer chip would pack in twice as many transistors as the company's best-selling Pentium 4, use less power and have some of the tiniest parts ever made in high-volume chip manufacturing.

title: Retail Sales Increase for a Second Month
description: Retail sales rose for a second consecutive month in July, the Commerce Department reported today, citing zero-interest financing for cars and an increase in gasoline prices. Excluding cars and fuel, spending was unchanged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, SIDNEY
description: BLOOM-Sidney. 80. Died peacefully at home in Palm Beach, FL, on August 11. Beloved husband of Sheila. Devoted father of Andrea, Peter (Challis), and Edward (Debbie). Loving grandfather of Scott, Lainy, Amanda, Michelle and Adam. He was a bright, vibrant, witty and feisty man of high principles who had a great love for children. He was a passionate advocate of liberal causes. He fought valiantly in the Normandy invasion in World War II. His passing leaves a huge gap in our family and in the world. Contributions may be sent to Friends of Abused Children of West Palm Beach or Hospice of Palm Beach County. Services Wednesday, August 14, 2PM at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, MORDECAI
description: WAXMAN-Mordecai. The International Jewish Committee on Interreligious Consultations (IJCIC) mourns the passing of its past chairman, Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, a pioneer in the field of interreligious dialogue. May his memory be a blessing. Rabbi Israel Singer, Chairman Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Chairman of the Board Rabbi Leon Feldman, Executive Secretary American Jewish Committee Anti-Defamation League, B'nai B'rith International, Central Conference of American Rabbis, Israel Jewish Council on Interreligious Relations, Rabbinical Assembly, Rabbinical Council of America, Union of American Hebrew Hebrew Congregations, Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism, World Jewish Congress

title: Citing Economy, Bush Won't Spend $5.1 Billion Approved for Security and Other Uses
description: President Bush said today that he would not spend $5.1 billion approved by Congress last month for domestic security, the military and a variety of other initiatives, saying reduced spending would help stabilize the economy.

title: Recipe: Salmon, Arugula and Avocado Maki
description: Time: 2 hours

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: APPLE SHIFTS DESKTOP SYSTEMS Apple Computer said yesterday that it was shifting its entire professional desktop line of computers to dual microprocessor configurations. The systems will be available with twin 867 Mhz, 1 Ghz and 1.25 Ghz G4 PowerPC microprocessors and range in price from $1,699 to $3,299. The new machines, available today, will come with Apple's newest Jaguar 10.2 version of its Macintosh OS X operating system, that is scheduled to ship commercially on Aug. 24. The computer maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., also said it was reducing the price of two of the models of its flat-panel iMac line by $100 each, to $1,299 and $1,499 each. John Markoff (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: U.S. Cultural Center Closes
description: American officials announced that the American cultural center in downtown Islamabad had been closed because of security concerns, Reuters reported. A guard reached at the center by telephone said it had been closed indefinitely. The closing of the center, just off one of the capital's main roads, came a day after the United States re-issued a warning to Americans to avoid traveling in Pakistan because of the risk of terrorist attacks. Pakistani newspapers reported that a nurse wounded in an attack on a Christian hospital near Islamabad on Friday had died, bringing the number of women killed to five. David Rohde (NYT)

title: In Bronx, Battle of the Up and Coming
description: Mardy Fish knows both sides of professional tennis, the glamorous and the unglamorous. He has played on the United States Davis Cup team in front of a rabid crowd. He has taken a seeded player to five sets in the first round of the United States Open, prompting the Stadium Court crowd to chant ''Fish! Fish!'' as he fought for the upset.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN GAINS. Corn prices hit a four-and-a-half-year high after a forecast of the smallest harvest since the mid-1990's. In Chicago, corn for December delivery rose 7.25 cents a bushel, or 2.7 percent, to $27.95.

title: Timing and Luck Are Cited in a Boston Project
description: There is an argument that real estate is not about location at all, no matter what the wise clich makers say. It is about timing, this argument goes, and some people say it is also about luck.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Charter Review Meeting Disrupted
description: The first public hearing of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Charter Revision Commission was disrupted last night by protesters, and two men were arrested. Opponents of the mayor's plan to establish nonpartisan elections burst into the Fire Department's headquarters in Brooklyn, where the hearing was held, and chanted, ''Change the mayor, not the charter.'' Two men, Daniel Cantor, 47, of Brooklyn, and Arron Schildkrout, 22, of Watertown, Mass., were arrested and charged with assaulting Rabbi Moses Weiser, the police department's liason to northern Brooklyn, when they tried to enter the hearing. The demonstration was organized by the Working Families Party, which has protested city budget cuts, and Acorn, one of its largest affiliated groups. The meeting resumed after the chief fire marshal, Louis Garcia, restored order. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: The Secret Behind A Burger Cult
description: THE 166th In-N-Out Burger restaurant opened quietly last Tuesday morning on Century Boulevard, hard by the Hollywood Park racetrack. There were no ''Grand Opening'' banners flapping in the breeze, no food giveaways and no advertisements promoting the event.

title: Jets' Role for Chrebet Remains in Question
description: It was the conversation that may have salvaged the season. When Wayne Chrebet and Vinny Testaverde spoke to the Jets' offensive coordinator, Paul Hackett, midway through last season, they implored him to mix in a few plays to throw the ball downfield.

title: OBITUARY : John Callcott, 64, foreign correspondent
description: GENEVA:  John Callcott, 64, a veteran United Press International foreign correspondent, died of cancer Monday in Geneva.

title: Aged Four Years in New Zealand, Then a Little Longer on the Trip
description: New Zealand has made Cheddar for a long time, which is no surprise, considering the country's English heritage. One of its largest producers, Kapiti, is now sending the cheese to American shops. It is deep ivory and aged four years, and it has a mild but richly complex flavor, with a firm, slightly crumbly texture. The cheese is not shipped in wheels, but in one-pound wedges coated in wax, above left. Another Kapiti cheese is a triple-cream blue, above right, a tangy, mouth-filling, gently flavored cow's milk cheese that comes in a fat cylinder. The Cheddar is $9.95 a wedge at Ideal Cheese. Barefoot Contessa in East Hampton, N.Y. and Market Basket in Franklin Lakes, N.J. sell it for $11.99 a pound. The blue is $12.95 a pound at Ideal Cheese, $15.99 at Market Basket and $12.99 at Barefoot Contessa.

title: Wary About a Ban on Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Nostalgia Is Baseball's Best Friend
description: UNTIL further notice, baseball's best days are in the past. There doesn't seem much point in taking this business seriously until the jokers settle their labor problems.

title: Militants Reject Policy on Attacks in Israel
description: Islamic militants today rejected an effort by other Palestinian factions to declare a unified policy of ending suicide bombings and other attacks on civilians within Israel.

title: BUFFETT'S COMPANY SUES I.R.S. OVER $16 MILLION IN TAXES
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company headed by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, says in a lawsuit that it was mistakenly ordered to pay the Internal Revenue Service $16.3 million in taxes and interest. The lawsuit, filed last week in United States District Court in Omaha, said the I.R.S. improperly classified $750 million the company borrowed in the late 1980's. The loans were intended to help the company keep money on hand for investments or acquisitions and were not earmarked for dividend-paying securities as the I.R.S. ruled, the lawsuit says. The I.R.S. denied tax deductions for interest owed on the debt, reasoning that the money was borrowed to buy investments that pay dividends, the lawsuit says.

title: McGreevey Changes Mind On Access To Records
description: After weeks of negotiations with public advocacy groups and New Jersey media organizations, Gov. James E. McGreevey signed an executive order today rescinding most of the restrictions he imposed last month on the state's new public records act.

title: Inner Circle of Bloomberg Aides Put Homeless Shelter in Old Jail
description: The Bloomberg administration, which frequently makes high-profile decisions among a few key aides, used a similar strategy when deciding to place homeless families in a former jail, people involved in the discussions said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Disciplining A Lawyer
description: An Urbana lawyer was suspended for 30 days for writing offensive letters. A disciplinary commission of the Illinois Supreme Court found that the lawyer, Marvin Gerstein, used insulting and abusive terms in his correspondence. Mr. Gerstein conceded that he referred to adversaries and others as ''fool,'' ''idiot,'' and ''babycakes'' and that he made liberal use of vulgarities and anatomical suggestions. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Return Visit For Gore
description: Last week, the chairwoman of the Iowa Democratic Party tartly noted that Al Gore, the Democratic candidate for president in 2000, had repeatedly been invited to return to the state this year but had not responded. Now Mr. Gore has. A spokesman said Mr. Gore would visit in October. The spokesman, Jano Cabrera, said that no date would be set, but that Mr. Gore would campaign alongside Democratic candidates. Adam Nagourney (NYT)

title: For Chicago's 'Town Crier,' the Stories Linger
description: Kup still has the stories; just the names have slipped away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EMMY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Emmy. Yeshivat Sha'alvim extends heartfelt condolences to Dr. Allen Goldstein, distinguished member of its Board of Governors on the passing of his dear mother. Hamakom Yenachemchem.

title: Giants Must Try the 'Musical Chairs' Offensive Line
description: If Giants Coach Jim Fassel produced injury reports in training camp, center Dusty Zeigler would have been downgraded twice in the last three weeks. Fassel believed in July that Zeigler -- the only starting offensive lineman returning to the position he played last year -- would be back in time for the Sept. 5 opener against the San Francisco 49ers. Since then, Zeigler has gone from definite to probable to questionable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BETTY MALOY
description: BROWN-Betty Maloy. Born December 19, 1919, died at Somers Manor Nursing Home on August 13, 2002. Betty is survived by her children Susan Bauman of Somers, NY, Carol Gismondi of Yonkers, NY, and Paul Brown of Syracuse, NY. Predeceased by her husband, Lyle, and her son Gary. Also survived by nine grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Utility Bidder Named
description: Germany's largest utility, E.ON, said the Polish Treasury chose it as the preferred bidder for stakes in eight Polish power companies, known as G-8, which control 17 percent of the Polish energy market. Together, the companies have $980 million in sales and serve 2.5 million customers. Talks with E.ON will begin Monday. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Juilliard Sets Bachelor's in Jazz Studies
description: The Juilliard School, in collaboration with Jazz at Lincoln Center, has announced that it will offer a bachelor's degree in jazz studies starting next fall, with auditions in late March. The four-year program will include weekly private lessons and courses in ear training and keyboard skills, jazz improvisation, composition and arranging, and the liberal arts. The program is to be headed by VICTOR L. GOINES, artistic director of jazz studies. Students will perform in the New York area, on tour with the Juilliard Jazz Orchestra and in master classes with guest artists like WYNTON MARSALIS. Juilliard first introduced jazz to its curriculum last year with the creation of the Juilliard Institute for Jazz Studies. Sol Hurwitz

title: Companies Certify Data Today; Some Seem Quite Confused
description: Top executives at nearly half the companies required to do so have certified their financial statements ahead of today's deadline. But many companies remained confused last night about their responsibilities and potential penalties.

title: Wary About a Ban on Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolling Their Own
description: ON a back porch in Iowa City, on the eve of the Iowa State Fair, 10 friends gathered last Wednesday to make sushi. The hosts, Thisbe Nissen, a fiction writer, and Sarah Townsend, a graduate student, had assembled all the materials from three stores: sushi rice, pickled ginger, and seaweed paper from the local Asian market; Sapporo beer and sake from the Hy-Vee supermarket; and a glistening array of fresh mahi-mahi, tuna and two kinds of salmon from the cooperative grocery. Guests set to making inside-out sushi rolls sprinkled with black and white sesame seeds and took turns shooing Fernanda the cat away from the fish.

title: An Orchard Street Bistro With Genuine French Accents
description: AS I sliced into a piece of tender duck confit at picerie Caf Charbon, it occurred to me that it had been a long time since I'd been to a new French bistro in New York. For the last few years, bistros have been left to wilt, while large, loud brasseries opened by the dozen. But here I was in the hippest neighborhood in Manhattan, the Lower East Side, in a brand new bistro with style as declarative as the French accents of its waiters.

title: Many Voices, but One Call To Change Building Codes
description: One after another, they lined up to speak yesterday -- structural engineers, retired firefighters and city building officials, advocates for the disabled and relatives of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. And again and again, they offered essentially the same message: the more than 2,500 lives lost within the World Trade Center are more than enough evidence that city building codes need substantial revision.

title: Decision Due From Nasdaq On Dropping Japan Unit
description: The global downturn in equity markets is threatening to claim as its next victim Nasdaq's stock trading venture in Japan. Nasdaq is considering killing the venture because it has made little headway against a host of regulatory hurdles, persistent economic weakness and a deep aversion to change in the country's rigid financial system.

title: O.K., You've Rejected Just About Everything. Now What?
description: At the end of ''Almost Obscene,'' Joe Raiola, having fallen off a chair he had been straddling backward, and raising himself hesitantly from his sprawl, says, ''I'm in a mess, and honestly I don't know the way out.'' Having listened to him work himself ever tighter into a logical impasse for almost an hour, you have to admit he is right about his situation.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CELLPHONE BAN URGED AT THEATERS

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: REVIVAL OF GAYS' LAWSUIT

title: As India Goes . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Upbeat, but Luxury Tax Is Still a Roadblock
description: Given a reprieve from the weight of a strike date on their shoulders, negotiators in baseball's labor dispute plunged into their work on the critical luxury-tax issue yesterday. If the two sides did not make instant progress on the issue, they at least maintained the positive feeling that emerged from the union's executive board meeting on Monday.

title: Before It Was Hip to Be Hip, There Was Greenwich Village
description: REPUBLIC OF DREAMS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DACOSTA, BEVERLY
description: DaCOSTA-Beverly. Age 57, passed away on Friday, August 9, 2002 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. She spent most of her professional career with the NYC Board of Education. She is survived by her husband, Gaston; her son, Dennis; her daughter, Karen; her mother, Avis; brother, Barrington. Viewing will be held on Friday, August 16 from 4-9 PM at McCall's Bronxwood Funeral Home, 4035 Bronxwood Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466. Services at funeral home on Saturday, August 17 at 11 AM. Interment will be held at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Palestinian Leader Indicted on Terror Charges
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 14  Marwan Barghouti, the most prominent Palestinian leader to be brought before a civil Israeli court, made clear at his indictment on terrorism charges today that he intends to turn his public trial into a political duel with Israel.

title: Corrections
description: An Aug. 8 Op-Ed article mistakenly said that the federal Section 8 voucher program enabled 1.4 million families to move into better housing in 2000. The program served 1.4 million families in 2000; not all of them moved in that year.

title: Where Freedom Reigns
description: The more time you spend in India the more you realize that this teeming, multiethnic, multireligious, multilingual country is one of the world's great wonders -- a miracle with message. And the message is that democracy matters.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Politician Accused
description: Prosecutors have charged a leading ethnic Albanian politician and former guerrilla commander, Ramush Haradinaj, with endangering the safety of others in a shootout with supporters of a rival political faction in 2000. United Nations officials who have run the Serbian province since 1999 are eager to show they will punish former Kosovo Liberation Army guerrillas who commit crimes, even though they fought alongside NATO forces against Serbia. On Sunday, United Nations police officers arrested Rustem Mustafa, a former guerrilla commander, on charges of murder, torture and illegal detention of at least five people. His supporters in northern Kosovo protested the arrest yesterday. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Wines of the Week
description: If stranded on a deserted island which type of wine would you take along?

title: Markets Rebound as Big Companies Stand Behind Earnings Reports
description: Aday after registering their disappointment over the Federal Reserve's decision not to cut interest rates, investors sent stocks sharply higher late today.

title: France's Southwest, Worth a Detour
description: A FEW years ago I had lunch with an 83-year-old winemaker in Collioure, a onetime fishing village turned tourist haven on the French Mediterranean coast, not far from Spain.

title: Bush, Campaigning in Midwest, Presses His Economic Message
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14  President Bush traveled to the Midwest today to campaign for Republican candidates and to defend his stewardship of an economy that he said would remain strong with the help of fiscal restraint, low taxes and the hard work of millions of Americans.

title: Bally Fitness Selects Foote, Cone
description: The Bally Total Fitness Corporation is expected to announce today that it has selected the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle marketing and advertising. Total ad spending was estimated at $50 million.

title: Girls Link Their Use of Family Planning Clinics to Keeping Parents in the Dark
description: Most girls under 18 would stop or limit their use of sexual health services at family planning clinics if their parents had to be told they were seeking prescribed contraceptives, a new survey shows.

title: Citigroup Is Subpoenaed in I.P.O. Inquiry
description: A House committee issued a subpoena today to Citigroup, asking for documents on any role that the analyst Jack B. Grubman might have played in allocating potentially lucrative stock to WorldCom executives.

title: Schoolchildren's Visions of Sept. 11 . . .
description: Some New York City students drew stacks of plaintive pictures to express how they felt about the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. Others wrote poems  some disconsolate, some determinedly optimistic. Now, the New York school system has compiled dozens of these artistic responses in a book, "Messages to Ground Zero: Children Respond to Sept. 11, 2001." SHELLEY HARWAYNE, the superintendent of District 2 in Manhattan, collected drawings, poems, journal entries and essays from students citywide for the book, published by Heinemann and scheduled for release on Sept. 11. Also included are touching letters sent by children across the United States.

title: Ice and Tape Keep Posada Going
description: When Jorge Posada plays with his son, Jorge IV, he sits on the floor with ice packs attached to both knees. Whether they are pushing toy trucks, throwing a ball or punching the control buttons for video games, Posada feels better with some ice soothing his aching knees.

title: In Texas Race, Leader Struggles for Footing
description: Nearly 20 months ago, Rick Perry was handed the job of Texas governor from George W. Bush, along with a political landscape in which every statewide office was held by a Republican. Mr. Perry seemed to have inherited the equivalent of a royal flush.

title: Donors to McCall Profit in Cases State Pursues Against Corporate Wrongdoers
description: H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller who is running for governor, is campaigning on his record of pursuing corporate wrongdoers, highlighting his lawsuits on shareholders' behalf.

title: Food Stamps for Needy
description: To the Editor:

title: American Airlines to Cut Jobs, Planes and Flights
description: Acknowledging that the economics of its business are fundamentally flawed, American Airlines, the world's biggest airline, said yesterday that it would lay off 7,000 workers, retire inefficient jets, retool its hub schedules and cut back on flights going into the fall.

title: Filing on Financing Of Satellite Radio
description: Sirius Satellite Radio said yesterday that it might need to raise $600 million to stay in business until its satellite-radio service has enough customers. The shares fell 35 percent.

title: Brazil's Markets Fall on Economic Fear
description: Less than a week after Brazilian markets received a much-needed shot of confidence from a $30 billion International Monetary Fund loan package to the country, fears over Brazil's economic prospects dragged down stock and bond prices and the beleaguered real.

title: No Cut in Rates As Fed Lowers Its Assessment Of the Economy
description: The Federal Reserve left interest rates steady today but downgraded its view of the economy and signaled that it would consider cutting rates if the recovery from last year's recession continued to lose steam.

title: Galen Rowell, Mountaineer And Nature Photographer, 61
description: Galen Rowell, a photographer well known for sumptuous color pictures of the remotest corners of the earth, died on Sunday in the crash of a small plane as it approached the airport at Bishop, Calif. He was 61.

title: Fever Earns Playoffs And Faces The Liberty
description: The Indiana Fever gained its first W.N.B.A. playoff berth last night, defeating the Rockers in Cleveland, 60-56, on the final day of the regular season.

title: VERIDIAN BUYS SIGNAL AS SECURITY COMPANIES JOIN
description: The Veridian Corporation, which makes software the federal government uses to guard classified documents, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Signal Corporation for $227 million in cash and notes to increase domestic-security sales. The closely held Signal, which sells computer-network security systems to government agencies, will add as much as $70 million to sales in the fourth quarter, Veridian said. Separately, in its first income statement as a public company, Veridian said that its second-quarter loss widened to $62.2 million, or $4.73 a share, from $5.86 million, or 78 cents a share, a year earlier because of costs associated with restructuring its equity and debt after its initial public offering.

title: Far From Waco, Uninvited Scholars Ponder the Way to Recovery
description: The Bush administration invited only three economists to its seminar on economic recovery yesterday. If the room had been filled with economists instead of chief executives, the discussion would have been framed this way: Can consumers and business people generate enough demand to revive the sluggish economy? Or must government play a greater role to avoid another recession?

title: Cruise Debut
description: The 170-passenger Star Clipper will begin seven-day cruises among the cays and offshore islands along the Yucatan Peninsula, Belize, Guatemala and Honduras this fall. A $400 per person discount, double occupancy, and round-trip air fare from New York, Miami and other cities are available on departures Nov. 17 to Dec. 15. Information: (800) 442-0551 or www.starclippers.com .

title: UBS's Drop in Profit Is Less Than Forecast
description: Switzerland's largest bank, UBS, surprised investors and analysts today by posting a much smaller fall in profits for the second quarter than had been expected. The bank lived up to its cautious reputation by limiting credit losses and trimming costs.

title: Wal-Mart Earnings Rise
description: Wal-Mart Stores said here today that its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose more than 20 percent as consumers sought goods like summer clothing and patio furniture at discount prices.

title: Wary About a Ban on Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Chief Is Soaking Up Advice in San Diego
description: If New York City has learned anything about Joel I. Klein, the new schools chancellor, since his appointment on July 29, it is that he is conspicuously discreet.

title: Law Requiring Quick Jailing in Violent Crimes Is Overturned
description: Connecticut's highest court has struck down a law that required the immediate imprisonment of any defendant convicted of a violent crime. The law had also denied any possibility of bail to defendants trying to appeal convictions on charges involving the use or threat of physical force.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Girl Is Raped On Rooftop
description: The police continued their search yesterday for a man who they said forced a 14-year-old Harlem girl to the rooftop of her building and then raped her. Afterward, the police said, the rapist forced the girl down to her apartment where he sexually abused her 16-year-old sister before fleeing with jewelry and cash. Investigators said they believe the man followed the girl from a bus stop near Madison Avenue and East 117th Street at 11:30 a.m. on Monday. He apparently did not know the girl prior to the attack, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BREEN, DANIEL M., JR.
description: BREEN-Daniel M., Jr. January 31, 1959-August 14, 1998. Your Dad turned 70; Carter and Alexis are a year old; Tom made you a beautiful quilt. I'm with someone now who reminds me of youthanks. We all love and miss you more than ever. Always, Howard

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: A Pledge To Withdraw From Congo
description: President Robert Mugabe said he would withdraw his troops from Congo and end Zimbabwe's costly and unpopular participation in that nation's war. Zimbabwe has been supporting the Congolese government's battle against rebels in a war that has involved several African countries. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: A Shorter Revenue Shortfall
description: State officials who had predicted a revenue shortfall of about $475 million for the 2001-2 fiscal year got a pleasant surprise. The shortfall was only $390 million. As a result, the state will not have to draw as much money from its rainy day fund. In July, lawmakers approved $933 million in tax increases, raising the sales tax by 1 cent and increasing taxes on alcohol and tobacco, as well as some business taxes.

title: Every Blessed Crumb
description: ''BREAD is my favorite starch,'' Judy Rodgers said. ''I even thought about writing 'The Stale Bread Cookbook.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLANDER, GRACE (NEE SCHWARZSCHILD)
description: HOLLANDER-Grace (nee Schwarzschild). Of Israel. Wife of the late Herman. Mother of Julius, Peri, Shiri. Sister of Sara Kalman.

title: ECONOMIC OUTLOOK IS POSITIVE, BUSH TELLS TEXAS FORUM
description: President Bush said today that he was optimistic about the long-term health of the beleaguered American economy as he heard from a selection of 240 carefully chosen guests who praised his policies at an economic forum created to showcase his concerns.

title: Rumsfeld Denounces Iraq for Rejecting Further Arms Inspections
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld today dismissed an official Iraqi statement that weapons inspectors had completed their work, and said Baghdad's comments were ''a broken record'' of repeated acceptances followed by repeated rejections of United Nations monitors.

title: Rockette Regulars Lose Job Guarantees
description: The 41 Rockettes who regularly did the high kicks at Radio City Music Hall lost their job guarantees last night and were told they must audition along with any other dancers.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about the Texas Pacific Group, which is investing in US Airways, referred imprecisely to its goals. While it has endorsed concessions from unions in some earlier deals, Texas Pacific is not seeking concessions beyond those already being negotiated for US Airways.

title: Wary About a Ban on Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Leagues Gain a Measure of Relief From Privacy Laws
description: Buried deep in a 412-page document that will be published Wednesday in the Federal Register are a couple of paragraphs that could provide enormous relief to major sports leagues. Some players and coaches may not be so pleased, however.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUINNESS, GEORGE F.
description: McGUINNESS-George F. On August 12, 2002. Resident of Bronxville, NY. Member of New York Athletic Club and Friendly Sons of St. Patrick (Westchester). Reposing Hodder Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave., Yonkers, NY. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 10 AM, St. Joseph RC Church (Bronxville). Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Wary About a Ban on Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Weaver Adapts to Relief Role
description: Before games, Jeff Weaver wears a white T-shirt with a picture of a bobblehead doll on the front. The doll is not representing any team -- it was not clear exactly what it represented -- and when I asked Weaver about it last Friday, he sort of shrugged.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Deflation Continues
description: The National Bureau of Statistics said that consumer prices in July were 0.9 percent lower than in July of last year. That was a slightly greater drop than in June, when prices were 0.8 percent less than a year earlier, but a lesser drop than in May, when prices were down 1.1 percent from May 2001. Growth in factory capacity and continued migration of workers from impoverished inland provinces to the coast have kept prices low, while many Chinese appear to be saving more instead of spending. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Ceviche Without Fear
description: MOST people I know love ceviche, the Central and South American dish in which fish is ''cooked'' by marinating it in an acidic dressing. But they don't prepare it: they trust a chef to transform raw fish into something less fearsome by dousing it with lime juice. Whether this is rational, I don't know. While it could be argued that chefs have access to fresher fish than home cooks, it also could be argued that people have more control over their food when they make it themselves.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Carmaker Reports A Profit
description: The Ssangyong Motor Company, a motor vehicle manufacturer, reported a net profit of 120.4 billion won ($101 million) for the first six months of this year compared with 14.5 billion won in the period a year ago. Sales for the six months were 1.7 trillion won, up 53 percent from the first six months of 2001. Ssangyong, which specializes in sport utility vehicles, sold 81,741 vehicles from Jan. 1 through June 30, an increase of 27 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Facing Charges Again
description: A 69-year-old Chicago man returned to court this week to face charges that he molested, bludgeoned and strangled three boys in 1955 and dumped their bodies in the woods. The man, Kenneth Hansen, a stable hand at the time of the killings, was tried and convicted of the murders in 1995, but an appellate court overturned his conviction, saying the jury should not have been told he had molested boys before the killings. The case went dormant for years until the mid-1990's, when an informer named Mr. Hansen as the perpetrator. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | North America: Canada: Steel Merger
description: The Brazilian Steel maker Gerdau said that it had agreed to combine its North American steel operations with those of Co-Steel Inc. of Whitby, Ontario. Co-Steel will issue 146.6 million shares to Gerdau, giving the Brazilian group a 74 percent stake in the new company, which will be called Gerdau AmeriSteel. Co-Steel will own the remaining 26 percent. Gerdau AmeriSteel will operate 11 mills with annual production of 11.8 million tons of finished steel and revenue of about $1.7 billion. Co-Steel and Gerdau plan to integrate the mills with 29 processing and specialty product businesses. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Raises Bid For Rest Of McAfee
description: Network Associates raised its offer for the rest of the McAfee.com Corporation yesterday to $183.1 million in cash and stock, after most of the shareholders of McAfee, an antivirus software maker, rejected a previous offer. Network Associates, which owns 75 percent of McAfee .com, is offering 0.675 share and $8 in cash for each McAfee.com common share, or a total of $15.26 a share. That was 19 percent more than the closing price of McAfee.com shares on Monday. Since first proposing a takeover in March, Network Associates shares have lost more than half their value as the software maker discovered inaccuracies in its financial results and forecast sales that disappointed some investors. Network Associates, the maker of McAfee antivirus software, sold shares of McAfee.com, a computer-security service, to investors in 1999, when Internet stocks had higher values. The chief executive, George Samenuk, who took over in 2001, is seeking to acquire McAfee.com to clear up confusion about the companies, which sometimes approach the same customers. Network Associates in March first proposed swapping 0.675 share for each McAfee.com share, a bid that was rejected. In April, McAfee.com accepted a raised bid of 0.78 share, a value of $17.55 at the time, before withdrawing its support after Network Associates shares plunged over the next three months. A spokesman for McAfee.com could not be reached to comment on the latest offer. Shares of Network Associates fell 67 cents, to $10.34, on the New York Stock Exchange. McAfee.com shares rose $2.05, to $14.89 in Nasdaq trading.

description: Ansley Coale, whose distillery, Germain-Robin, produces fine Cognac-style brandies in Mendocino County, Calif., was tempted to try making vodka. So was Jorg Rupf, who distills eaux-de-vie and grappas in Alameda, Calif., under the name of St. George Spirits. Together, they came up with Hangar One vodka, made in a rented space at the former Alameda Naval Air Station. There are three unusual and delicious citrus varieties, made by infusing fruit, not just adding flavorings: Buddha's hand citron, which is a bit lemony-sharp; kaffir lime, with an intriguing citric flavor; and mandarin blossom, with honeyed, floral overtones. And if flavored vodka is not your drink, consider the plain version, which is silken, with exceptional lightness. Park Avenue Liquor Shop, 292 Madison Avenue (40th Street), has all three flavors, at $36 for 750 milliliters, and $30 for plain; Crossroads, 55 West 14th Street, has all but the citron for $37.99 a bottle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, SOLOMON SHALK
description: MANDELL-Solomon Shalk, was born in New York City in 1918. His mother came from Vilna and his father from Minsk. They immigrated to the United States in 1910 and settled in the Lower East Side. Mr. Mandell spent his pre-school years in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where his grandfather was a rabbi, and then attended public schools in the Bronx. He graduated from high school at age 16 and attended the College of the City of New York, majoring in accounting. In 1938 he began his studies at Harvard Law School where he was awarded a scholarship. After graduation in 1941, he worked at his father's deli as well as at the law firm Carroad & Carroad while studying for the bar, which he passed in 1941. He then went to work as a tax lawyer for an accounting firm and in 1943 took a position with the U.S. Treasury Department in the General Counsel's office in Washington, D.C. In 1944 he moved back to New York and helped J.K. Lasser write his income tax guide. In 1946 Mr. Mandell associated with the accounting firm Kalish & Rubinroit, where he worked independently as a tax specialist for most of his professional life. Mr. Mandell has written numerous articles on taxation which have been published in ''Taxes'', ''The Tax Magazine'' and ''The Journal of Accountancy''. He was lecturer at New York University's Institute of Federal Taxation. Mr. Mandell has been marrried since 1943 to Pauline Varon, with whom he has two grown daughters, two granddaughters and four grandsons. Sol's activities included daily calisthenics and a five mile walk (usually in Central Park) and occasional tennis matches. He regularly attended Lincoln Center concerts and film series, as well as films at the Museum of Modern Art and at theaters around Manhattan. He died August 10, 2002. We all loved him and will miss him deeply.

title: The Spirit of St. Louis
description: The Cardinals' clubhouse has been an inviting room for reporters the past few years and more so in the past few weeks. I covered Matt Morris when he was a star pitcher for Seton Hall before the Cardinals drafted him and, although he was not scheduled to face the Mets in a three-game series last weekend, I wanted to say hello. Morris, like many of his teammates, had been deeply affected by the death of starting pitcher Darryl Kile from a heart attack earlier this season. The depression carried over into his performances. Morris has a photograph of himself and Kile taped above his locker in the home clubhouse at Busch Stadium and he told me that things were slowly getting better.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Bluefly Reports $1.5 Million Loss
description: Bluefly.com, a discount fashion retailer, reported an operating loss of $1.5 million yesterday for the second quarter. The loss, of $1.27 a share, includes a one-time noncash charge of $10.2 million. Despite the loss, Bluefly said it had a good quarter because its $6.8 million in net sales were 29 percent better than in the period a year earlier, and its operating loss was 65 percent smaller. Its gross margin increased to its highest level, 35 percent. The company spent about $17 to acquire each new customer -- 77 percent less than last year, but nearly twice the amount it spent last quarter. The operating loss was about $500,000 more than last quarter. In addition, Bluefly said it had secured another round of financing from Soros Private Equity Partners, which is the venture capital firm of George Soros. The 2.1 million investment follows a $1.9 million round in June, completing a $4 million financing commitment made by Mr. Soros in March. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: CUNY Names Visiting Professors

Dr. Kripke won the Swedish Academy of Sciences' Schock Prize in Logic and Philosophy in 2001 and began teaching at CUNY last semester. Dr. Davies, the author of ''Meaning, Quantification, Necessity: Themes in Philosophical Logic'' (1981), will begin teaching in the spring.

description: The dissatisfaction with Michael D. Eisner by members of the Walt Disney Company's board may be broader than previously realized, but few in Hollywood think Mr. Eisner is in imminent danger of losing his job.

description: Because of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: U.S. CULTURAL CENTER CLOSES American officials announced that the American cultural center in downtown Islamabad had been closed because of security concerns, Reuters reported. A guard reached at the center by telephone said it had been closed indefinitely. The closing of the center, just off one of the capital's main roads, came a day after the United States re-issued a warning to Americans to avoid traveling in Pakistan because of the risk of terrorist attacks. Pakistani newspapers reported that a nurse wounded in an attack on a Christian hospital near Islamabad on Friday had died, bringing the number of women killed to five.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Deal With Rebels
description: A disagreement that threatened to scuttle planned peace talks was resolved when officials agreed to allow unarmed members of the rebel Tamil Tigers to move between rebel strongholds by boat. The government had objected to the movements, citing a rebel practice of ramming Sri Lankan Navy vessels with small boats loaded with explosives. Government officials flew to Norway yesterday for talks with the rebels' chief negotiator to clear the way for negotiations on ending the 19-year conflict, which has claimed an estimated 64,000 lives. David Rohde (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Revival Of Gays' Lawsuit
description: A federal appeals court in San Francisco reinstated a lawsuit brought by a gay couple who challenged the Arizona prison system's partial ban on gay kisses and hugs during visits with prisoners. Heterosexual couples are allowed such contact so long as it is not ''prolonged,'' but same-sex kisses and hugs are prohibited unless they involve relatives. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit rejected the state's argument that the prohibition protects prisoners from bias and abuse. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Progress Made at Korea Talks, but Setback on a Key Issue
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 14 — In North Korea's highest level meeting with South Korea in almost a year, the North agreed to discuss economic cooperation with the South and to allow another round of reunions of families divided by the Korean War, but balked at setting a date for key military talks that would allow construction of road and rail links across their highly militarized border.

title: CROWN CORK ALLOTS $283 MILLION FOR ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company, the maker of about one-fifth of the world's cans, has set aside $283 million to cover pending and future asbestos lawsuits, according to a regulatory filing. Executives of Crown Cork, based in Philadelphia, estimated that asbestos claims against the company could reach $516 million by 2012, according to the company's quarterly report filed June 30. Crown Cork's asbestos liability stems from its purchase of an insulation business.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Black Farmers' Grievances
description: The National Black Farmers Association met with civil rights officials at the Agriculture Department in an effort to resolve more than 400 outstanding cases from a 1999 class-action suit that charged discrimination against black farmers. While no agreement was reached, a department spokeswoman said the Bush administration was committed to speeding up the cases and deciding how much money was due the farmers. The group is asking the government to pay $1 billion to settle the cases and provide debt relief. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Posts Rise In Net Income
description: Applied Materials, the world's biggest maker of semiconductor-manufacturing equipment, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings were little changed as lower costs helped make up for a 7.4 percent sales drop. Net income rose to $115.2 million, or 7 cents a share, from $114.9 million, or 7 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the period ended July 28 fell to $1.46 billion. New orders rose 5 percent from the second quarter to $1.78 billion, less than analysts expected. The shares fell 4.3 percent after executives said orders in this period might drop 15 percent from the third quarter, adding to concerns that chip-industry sales might not rebound later this year. Last month, the No. 1 chip maker, Intel, pared its spending plans for 2002. Applied Materials shares fell 12 cents, to $13.46.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple Shifts Desktop Systems
description: Apple Computer said yesterday that it was shifting its entire professional desktop line of computers to dual microprocessor configurations. The systems will be available with twin 867-MHz, 1-GHz and 1.25-GHz G4 PowerPC microprocessors and range in price from $1,699 to $3,299. The new machines, available today, will come with Apple's newest Jaguar 10.2 version of its Macintosh OS X operating system, which is scheduled to be shipped commercially on Aug. 24. The computer maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., also said it was reducing the price of two of the models of its flat-panel iMac line by $100 each, to $1,299 and $1,499 each. John Markoff (NYT)

title: A High Roller Gets a Break From a Casino
description: The Muckleshoot Indians, who live near Seattle, are using some of the revenue from the casino they built in the mid-1990's to maintain a fishery for Western salmon. The fishery, along the Green and White rivers, which empty into Puget Sound, was virtually depleted in the 1930's and struggled for decades after. Cooperation between the Muckleshoots, who gained fishing rights in the 1970's, and Washington State has resulted in a carefully controlled conservation program, similar to those established by other tribes, and the fishery is now thriving: this year's catch is expected to be almost one million pounds. The brief season for lean, flavorful Muckleshoot sockeye salmon is winding down, but the rich and slightly sweeter king salmon is now available. It is the first wild salmon of the season from Washington. Fairway Markets sell it for $14.99 a pound; Citarella has it for $19.99 a pound. Rosedale has steaks for $15 a pound, fillets for $20 a pound.

title: . . . And Celebrity Decorations
description: DONALD J. TRUMP drew a skyscraper, WILLARD SCOTT fashioned a happy face and WILLIAM WEGMAN sketched a city street filled with his famous Weimaraners. About 1,000 celebrities, students, firefighters and the families of Sept. 11 victims have decorated children's building blocks as part of ''Rebuilding Hope,'' a project by the arts therapy department of the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan. The project is intended to help New Yorkers express their grief. The blocks will become part of a sculpture the department hopes to build in downtown Manhattan as a memorial. ''There is something inherently healing in the creative process,'' said JENNIFER DROWER, a coordinator in the department, which is expecting more than 2,000 blocks when the project is complete. Anyone who wants to paint a block can do so from noon to 2 p.m. on Aug. 22 at the School of Visual Arts, 132 West 21st Street.

A party of four could fight over the litchi, passion fruit, raspberry, orange, mango, banana, cassis and roasted lime. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Accounting Woes
description: The China Everbright Bank, China's sixth-largest commercial bank, acknowledged that a review by China's finance ministry last year and an internal audit had found accounting irregularities, but did not estimate the scale of the problem. The bank attributed the problems to its acquisition, at the insistence of regulators, of the ailing China Investment Bank in 1999 and a subsequent addition of capital to Everbright by one of its owners, China Everbright (Group) Holdings. A semiofficial Chinese newspaper, the 21st Century Business Herald, reported on Monday that the finance ministry found that the bank might have understated the extent of bad loans and evaded taxes. China Everbright Ltd. owns 21 percent of the bank, and its shares have lost more than a fifth of their value in the last two days. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Strindberg Stole His Thunder, Don't You Know?
description: It was the goose farm that gave it away. A news release for ''Resa Fantastiskt Mystisk'' recounts the story of this recently rediscovered masterwork by the great 19th-century Swedish playwright Lars Mattsun. But the mention of his family's struggling goose-breeding business and the references in the program to Mattsun's Fruit Period are definite hints that he may not exist. At the end of ''Resa,'' which is part of the New York International Fringe Festival, audiences will be glad that Matt Almos and his eight co-writers (including most of the cast) invented him.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Retires $733 Million In Debt
description: Nextel Communications Inc., the wireless-telephone company controlled by Craig McCaw, said yesterday that it had retired $733 million in debt and preferred securities since June 30, bringing the total exchanged this year to $1.83 billion. Nextel paid 33 million common shares and $205 million of cash in the latest swap, the company said in a statement. It will record a ''significant gain'' in the third quarter from the transaction, a regulatory filing said. Shares of Nextel had fallen 64 percent in the last year on concern about increasing competition, the cost of network upgrades and the company's ability to repay debt, which was $13.4 billion as of June 30. With the latest repurchase, long-term debt has declined to $12.7 billion at Nextel, which is based in Reston, Va. Shares of the company, whose phones also function as walkie-talkies, rose 54 cents, to $5.77.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loss At Chip Maker
description: Hynix Semiconductor, in the hands of the creditor institutions that took it over after its previous board rejected a $3 billion offer by Micron Technology, reported a net loss of $350 million for the April-June quarter. The loss reflected a downturn in the price of memory chips, which were again on sale on global markets for less than it cost to make them. Hynix, whose liabilities exceed $6 billion, appeared to have a chance of recovery earlier this year when the price of memory chips rose to a level several times that of last year's lows. Analysts say they believe that the company has fallen far behind Samsung Electronics and Micron in terms of research and development as chip prices plunge again. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Support For Governor's Resignation
description: A new poll shows that 61 percent of state residents think Gov. George Ryan, who has been mired in a corruption scandal involving his years as secretary of state, should resign before his term expires at the end of the year. Governor Ryan, left, a Republican who is not running for re-election, has not been directly implicated in the scandal, which has resulted in about 50 indictments. Attorney General Jim Ryan, the Republican who hopes to succeed the governor and who is not related to him, has also suggested that the governor step down. The poll, conducted by CBS 2/Survey USA, has a margin of error of three percentage points. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

description: Executives of Household International announced an earnings restatement yesterday and AOL Time Warner announced a review that might lead to one, while a handful of other companies said they would not vouch for their financial statements at all. But most big companies certified their earnings in time to meet a government deadline.

title: It's Gloves-Off Time for an Angry Arthur Miller
description: Arthur Miller has always held America, hopefully and critically, to a higher moral standard than it has ever achieved. So perhaps it's no surprise that now, at 86, he's getting fed up at last. His new play, ''Resurrection Blues,'' which is having its premiere production through Sept. 8 at the Guthrie Theater here, is a bitter comedy about the world that the American century wrought, and it essentially says that we have bollixed things up so badly that a Messiah has no chance; God has fled. That the deity in the play (who may or may not represent the Second Coming) keeps changing his name -- at one point it's Ralph, at another Frederico -- allows Mr. Miller to save his most meaningful yuk for the end.

title: Take the Gloves Off? Not Tua and Moorer
description: The tension was thin enough to cut with the plastic knives near the bagels. The bonhomie was as thick as David Tua's neck.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Abduction Suspect Identified
description: The police in Los Angeles have identified a 34-year-old woman who was taken into custody while they consider kidnapping charges against her in the abduction of Jessica Cortez, 4, from a park near downtown on Sunday. The woman, Patricia Cornejo, took the girl to a medical clinic for a checkup and staff members recognized her from news reports. Martin H. Pomeroy, the acting police chief, said detectives were still uncertain why Ms. Cornejo had taken the girl. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Schools Chief Hires Ex-Colleague
description: Joel I. Klein, the new schools chancellor, has hired a former colleague from Bertelsmann, the media conglomerate, to work for the school system. David Yarkin, who is in the executive management training program at Bertelsmann, where Mr. Klein was chairman and chief executive, will begin work on Monday, Mr. Klein's first day on the job, people who know Mr. Klein said. It was unclear yesterday what Mr. Yarkin's job would be. Reached at his Bertelsmann office, he declined comment. Mr. Yarkin, 28, is a former press secretary and chief of staff to Edward G. Rendell, the former mayor of Philadelphia and chairman of the Democratic National Committee. His wife, Courtney Carlson, works for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Musing on How to Define What Seems Undefinable
description: At the beginning of ''Perfect'' a cast member goes into the audience to ask people for their definitions of perfection. At a recent performance, people gave unsurprising answers about love, nature and the like. The one man who got a laugh said, ''Air-conditioning.'' Then an international cast of four proceeded to illustrate notions of perfection in a largely baffling one-hour multimedia presentation, heavy on the dance.

title: Multimillion-Dollar Awards Are Allowed in Futures Case
description: A New York judge yesterday upheld arbitration awards totaling $42 million against Refco, a large futures brokerage firm, stemming from a fraud carried out by Jay Goldinger, a Beverly Hills money manager.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 3 Boys Held In Rape
description: Three teenage boys were arrested late Tuesday on charges that they forced a 14-year-old girl into a stairwell of her apartment building in University Heights and took turns raping her, the authorities said yesterday. Investigators were still looking for a fourth boy who they believe was involved in the attack. The girl was returning from a grocery store around 10 p.m. when the four boys trapped her inside the elevator and offered to pay for sex, the police said. When the girl refused, they forced her into the stairwell, the police said. The boys -- ages 13, 14 and 15 -- who were arrested were held by neighbors until the police arrived. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ANN PACKER
description: LEVINE-Ann Packer. On August 14, 2002. Devoted wife of Irving Levine. Beloved wife of the late Mac Packer. Loving mother of Jack and Ilene Packer, and Arlene and Dr. Scott Baden; and her precious jewels, her grandchildren Steven and Allison Packer, and Shaun and Jamie Baden. She was State Committee Woman and Co-Leader of the High-Way Democratic Club. This year's recipient of the Lifetime Achievement Award and Woman of the Year. Services Friday 12 Noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave. (Ave. J), Bklyn.

title: Georgia Hearing Heavy Footsteps From Russia's War in Chechnya
description: Russia's war in Chechnya is spilling into the steep green gorges and snow-flecked mountains across its border with Georgia, worsening already tense relations between the two countries.

title: Speech Recognition Follies
description: Afew weeks ago, I wrote, in this e-mail column, about the futility of trying to predict the future of technology. I focused on the limits of miniaturization: After a certain point, computers will never be any smaller, because we still need a screen and some way to input information.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit Down At Carmaker
description: Hyundai Motor said that its second-quarter profit fell 8.3 percent from the year-earlier period, to $256 million, hurt by strikes in June and costs incurred in meeting new standards for cars exported to Europe. For the first half of the year, the company earned $745 million, up 46 percent from the first six months of last year on a small increase in sales. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Device Helps Make Arithmetic Appealing to the Game-Inclined
description: If you suspect that all those electronic gadgets for children are only good for wasting time with games, check out the FlashMaster, a digital alternative to flashcards that helps teach basic math skills.

title: Indonesia Convicts an Ex-Governor in East Timor Killing Frenzy
description: An Indonesian court found the former governor of East Timor, Abilio Soares, guilty of crimes against humanity today, and sentenced him to three years in jail for failing to stop the rampage by army-backed militia after the territory voted for independence in 1999.

description: CALIFORNIA: NO-STANDING ZONE FOR GANG MEMBERS

description: No, that's not an iPod.

description: BY next year, it will not matter very much whether companies choose to report the value of stock options as an expense. Investors will be in a good position to decide for themselves whether the figure is important.

title: Exploring the West
description: The bicentennial of the Lewis and Clark expedition is next year, and for those who want to get a head start, Lindblad Expeditions has a trip that follows their route in the Pacific Northwest. In the Wake of Lewis and Clark is a one-week voyage aboard the 70-passenger Sea Lion or Sea Bird, along the Columbia and Snake Rivers. The trips begin in Portland, Ore., and include a stop in Astoria, Ore., with its reproduction of the explorers' winter headquarters at Fort Clatsop. The ships go 450 miles upriver to Idaho, and trips are led by historians and naturalists, with a number of excursions by Zodiac. A discount of 25 percent is available on the Nov. 6 departure, with fares beginning at $1,793 a person, based on double occupancy, including all excursions and sightseeing, admission fees and use of kayaks. Air fare and alcoholic drinks are extra. (800) 397-3348 or www.expeditions.com .

description: SO now it is an annual event, investigating the living arrangements and birth certificates and school registrations of juveniles. How totally unappealing is this?

description: Marching to Many Beats

title: Evangelist Says Muslims Haven't Adequately Apologized for Sept. 11 Attacks
description: Nine months after calling Islam ''a very evil and wicked religion,'' the evangelist Franklin Graham said yesterday that Muslims had not sufficiently apologized for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and that they should help compensate victims' families.

title: When Princeton Snoops on Yale
description: It seemed somehow emblematic of our age: jockeying for admission to the best colleges has spiraled so out of control that one of the most sought-after schools, Princeton, was discovered spying on another, Yale.

description: * The Hollister Company, Santa Monica, Calif., a clothing brand for high-school-age boys and girls that is owned by Abercrombie & Fitch, selected the Creative Artists Agency, Beverly Hills, Calif., to handle marketing tie-ins with movies, music and television. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Pope, Again, Heads Home And, Again, Rumors Fly
description: There are simple, sensible explanations for the trip Pope John Paul II has scheduled to Poland this weekend. It gives him another glimpse of his homeland, and allows him to dedicate a new sanctuary outside Cracow that he holds dear.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, FRED
description: FRIEDMAN - Fred. Dear Fred, all that I wanted then is forgotten now, but you. Love Linda, Erik and Ada

title: MBNA SAYS IT MIGHT HAVE TO CREATE LARGE RESERVE FUND
description: The MBNA Corporation, a leading issuer of credit cards, said proposed federal rules would force it to set aside $300 million for unpaid fees and interest payments, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Federal regulators have proposed guidelines aimed at helping credit card companies weather rising loan losses. The issuers have until Sept. 23 to comment on proposed changes before the rules become final. The government's scrutiny was prompted by profit declines at credit card companies because of a rise in unpaid bills. MBNA, based in Wilmington, Del., said last month that it was reviewing the rule recommending that issuers set up a reserve for anticipated unpaid fees and finance charges. The company currently accrues interest and fee income on loans until they are written off.

title: National Briefing | West: California: No-Standing Zone For Gang Members
description: Hoping to stifle one of the most violent gangs in Los Angeles, prosecutors have obtained a permanent order preventing members of the 18th Street Gang from meeting in an area that covers about three-quarters of a square mile in the heart of their territory. The order, granted on Tuesday by Judge Haley J. Fromholz of Superior Court, bans gang members from standing, sitting, driving or gathering in the area, unless they are in school or church. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

description: NEXT month Clara Degallier, 5, will go to kindergarten. There will be 25 children in her class, but she will not be joining them for circle time, recess or any other activities.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker's Income Slips
description: The Swiss drug maker Roche Holding, said that its first-half profit declined 28 percent as its tax rate increased and its investment income declined. Net income dropped to 1.8 billion Swiss francs ($1.2 billion) from 2.5 billion francs a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent, to 14.7 billion francs. The chief executive, Franz Humer, had already warned investors that falling equity markets would reduce Roche's investment income this year. But the company's growth could top the industry average next year if a new drug, Pegasys, a potential 1.5-billion-franc-a-year treatment for hepatitis C, is approved in the United States.

title: Packing a Digital Bag On a Student Budget
description: THIS week a report from the InsightExpress research firm shed some fascinating light on the high-tech buying habits of the college-bound. These days, parents aren't as involved as you might expect in helping their teenagers decide which computer, MP3 player, digital camera or palmtop to buy. Up to 76 percent of the time, students decide which models to buy without parental help (or parental interference, depending on how you look at it). And 40 percent of the time, the students even pay for the stuff themselves.

description: The most powerful Kurdish chieftain in northern Iraq, Massoud Barzani, refused the Bush administration's invitation to attend the meeting of Iraqi opposition figures at the White House last week, Kurdish and administration officials said today.

description: Long Island power officials asked federal regulators yesterday to take the unusual step of ordering the activation of a new transmission line running under Long Island Sound despite the strong objections of Connecticut lawmakers and environmental groups.

description: The courts of Madison County, Ill., are famously hospitable, in a Will Rogers sort of way. They have, their critics say, never met a class-action lawsuit they did not like.

Economists agree that the recession has ended, not continued. The Dow Jones industrial average rose the day of the speeches, by 182 points; it did not decline.

description: Conseco, the big financial services company that is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, said yesterday that its accounting was under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: The Democrats and the War
description: The subtext to the current debate over America's foreign policy is history -- in particular, the Democratic Party's history of international engagement. Republicans are dismissive of it; Democrats have forgotten it. Neither approach serves the country.

title: FOUR BOARD MEMBERS RESIGN FROM PRE-PAID LEGAL
description: Pre-Paid Legal Services said yesterday that more than $200 million in commission advances were not recorded on its balance sheet and that four members of its board had resigned. The company, which sells legal insurance, said it expected 70 percent of the advances to be recorded as a commission expense in the next five years. Pre-Paid Legal said it would discontinue loans made to the four board members. It has formed a compensation panel to review the salary of its chief executive, Harland Stonecipher.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Candidate Loses Campaign Funds
description: The state's Clean Elections Commission has stripped a State Senate candidate of $26,600 in campaign money for failing to attend a mandatory debate. The candidate, State Representative Wesley L. Marsh Jr., went to a legislative conference instead. To receive state campaign money, candidates must attend a predetermined primary election debate.

title: Police Union Posts Outside Jobs; Rally for Pay Raises Is Set Today
description: As the city's largest police union prepared for a rally today in Times Square to call for larger salary increases, it posted law enforcement job openings from across the nation on its Web site, highlighting the differences between officers' salaries in New York and those in places like Seattle and Champaign, Ill.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — Using the huge sculpted heads of four earlier presidents as a patriotic backdrop, President Bush campaigned in South Dakota today for his vision of a Homeland Security Department, and for the Republican in a crucial Senate race as well.

description: Tyco International said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was reviewing its latest financial statements and that its new chief executive, Edward D. Breen, had expanded the company's internal investigation into its accounting practices as far back as 1999.

title: Bloomberg Seeks Doubling of Recycling Fines
description: As a moratorium on issuing tickets for violating the city's new recycling rules comes to a close, the Bloomberg administration has been quietly urging a reluctant City Council to double the fines the city can impose.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Wounded City Worker Dies
description: A city employee who was shot in the head in Long Island City last week died from his injuries on Monday, the authorities said yesterday. No arrests have been made. The man, Eugene McMahon, 46, of Levittown, was a night supervisor with the Department of Environmental Protection. He was found at 5:10 a.m. on Friday slumped in the driver's seat of his city car, which was smashed into a warehouse wall. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Cable Companies Improve
description: Two European cable companies reported improved financial results and said they had made progress on reaching agreements with bondholders to reduce debt. United Pan-Europe Communications, controlled by Liberty Media, reported its first profit, as it benefited from gains on currency exchange rates and other one-time items. U.P.C., as the company is called, said it earned 567 million euros ($554 million) in the second quarter, in contrast to a loss of 914 million euros during the period a year ago. The company said it did not expect to earn a profit for the full year. NTL, a British cable company that is run out of New York and filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States earlier this year, narrowed its second-quarter loss to $594 million from $1.1 billion. Both companies overspent during an acquisition spree at the height of the telecommunications boom and have since been negotiating with bondholders to exchange debt for fresh equity. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Washington Mayor Fined $277,700 Over Petition Fraud
description: The District of Columbia Board of Elections and Ethics fined the campaign to re-elect Mayor Anthony A. Williams $277,700 today for submitting thousands of fraudulent signatures on nominating petitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEVANS, MARGARET S., M.D.
description: BEVANS-Margaret S., M.D. A longtime resident of New York City and seasonal resident of Naples, FL and Centerville, MA. Died August 3, 2002 at Cape Cod Hospital at the age of 91. Dr. Bevans was born October 24, 1910 in Flushing, NY. She graduated from Flushing High School, from Trinity College in Washington, DC with a BA and from the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University in 1935 with an M.D. specializing in Pathology. Dr. Bevans was highly respected by her peers in New York's medical profession during her four decades of service. She served her internship at Bellevue Hospital, followed by posts at New York University (Assistant in Pathology), Goldwater Memorial Hospital (Pathologist), Columbia University (Assistant and Associate Professor of Pathology), Research Fellow, Public Health Research Institute, City of New York, and Director of Laboratories at Midtown Hospital, the New York Infirmary and Beekman Downtown Hospital to name a few. Dr. Bevans was a Fellow of the College of American Pathologists and a member of the American Medical Association, the New York State and County Medical Societies, the International Academy of Pathology, the New York Academy of Medicine, the New York Pathological Society. From 1942-1960 she co-authored and published over 40 research studies related principally to the effects of medication on arteriosclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis in animals. Dr. Bevans was formerly married to the late Dr. David Lyall from whom she was divorced. Dr. Bevans held a lifelong interest in tennis and was formerly an active participant at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, NY, and at the time of her death, she was a Fifty-Year Honorary Member of the Club. She was also an Associate Member of the Hyannis Yacht Club. She was an accomplished bridge player and a world traveler. She particularly enjoyed crossword puzzles and her many, many close and adoring friends. She will be greatly missed. There are no immediate family survivors. The burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date, to be announced. Memorial donations may be made in her honor to the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University Medical Education Fund.

title: It's an Oven In the City, But the 'Burbs Aren't So Bad
description: The air was taking on the consistency of gauze. Undulating, visible heat waves were beginning to rise off the griddle of a sidewalk. And the smell? Debbie James knew better than to stick around for that. Early this morning, Ms. James -- a resident of one of Manhattan's most citified addresses, Central Park North -- packed up her 3-year-old daughter, Raven, and headed for a decidedly uncitified destination: Westchester County.

title: Jail Closed as Shelter to Children After Report of Lead-Based Paint
description: Four days after opening a homeless shelter in an unused jail in the Bronx, city officials said last night that they would stop sending children younger than 6 there, at least for now, after advocates for the homeless said that large amounts of chipping and peeling lead-based paint had been found throughout the jail.

title: Downs and Ups of Jackson Melian
description: JACKSON MELIAN has gone from high-profile signing to Baseball America Top 100 prospect to major disappointment. All this by the ripe old age of 22. That can happen when the Yankees trot you out as a free-agent signing and you are only 16 years old.

title: Bad Taste Is Its Own Reward
description: IN his Greenwich Village apartment last week, John Waters was wearing a loopy T-shirt ensemble by Yohji Yamamoto and listening to Solomon Burke -- and if there is a more inviting way to spend a hot afternoon in New York City, it would be hard to imagine. He had a thin line of mustache, gum-ball-striped socks and a suntan.

title: Doubts Prompt Reviews of Hormone Therapy
description: Responding to growing doubts about the safety and value of hormone replacement therapy in women after menopause, two federal agencies are reviewing what is known about the drugs and what women and their doctors should be told about them.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: American Copters Crash
description: Two American helicopters crash-landed in separate operations in Afghanistan, military officials said. In the first incident, two crew members suffered minor injuries when an Army AH-64 attack helicopter was grounded about 20 miles south of Kabul. In the second, in southeastern Paktika Province, an air force HH-60 helicopter transporting a civilian injured in an ambush ''hit hard'' just after takeoff, an army spokesman said. Six people suffered minor injuries. Neither craft came under hostile fire, the military said. In recent days several helicopter missions have been scrapped because of dust storms. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Mattel Expands Role of WPP Division
description: Mattel in El Segundo, Calif., the toy company, said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, by selecting its office in Irvine, Calif., as the lead agency handling worldwide advertising for its boys and entertainment division, which includes brands like Hot Wheels, Matchbox and Uno. Spending was estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Aon and S.E.C. Resolve Questions Over Accounting Practices
description: Less than a week after disclosing a federal inquiry into its accounting, Aon, the world's second-largest insurance broker, said yesterday that it had resolved the questions by agreeing to restate its earnings for the final quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Town's Offices Reopen
description: Government offices in Lebanon, which have been closed since July 1, are open again after residents approved a $110,000 town budget this week. The shutdown, which left residents unable to register their cars or apply for fishing licenses, took effect after voters rejected a similar spending plan in June. This was the second time in 10 years the town of 5,083 in southwest Maine has shut its offices. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Marjorie G. Wyler -- Producer, 86
description: Marjorie Goldwasser Wyler, for many years the producer of ''Eternal Light,'' a weekly radio program on Jewish themes, died July 22 in Norwalk, Conn. She was 86 and lived in Westport, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: Credit Suisse Posts Loss And Will Cut Dividend
description: The Credit Suisse Group has had to devote so much cash to shoring up its flagging insurance unit that it said today that it was cutting back the dividend it pays shareholders, the first time it has done so in its 146-year history.

title: Affluence Aside, Many on L.I. Lack Health Coverage, Report Says
description: Nearly half a million Long Island residents rely on emergency rooms for their primary medical care, according to a report to be issued Thursday by the Long Island Coalition for a National Health Plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORVITZ, ANN BATTIE

Capital St. N.W., Washington, DC 20001.

description: Al Leiter loves to pitch after dark. When the sun goes down, he is as effective as almost anyone, compiling a league-low 1.97 earned run average in games played at night.
