description: IT erupts from Case Western Reserve University's campus in an explosion of rippling brick, warped glass and cascading shingles of stainless steel frozen between Ka and Boom. But there is much more than the strikingly unconventional appearance of its design, by Frank Gehry, that sets apart the newly completed $36 million home of the Weatherhead School of Management.

title: From Political Theatrics to Theatrical Narratives
description: HIS summer sublet is steps away on West 44th Street. But as the playwright Herman Daniel Farrell III, namesake of the New York State Democratic chairman, Herman D. Farrell Jr., surges up the steps of the New Dramatists club, he's a little late and a lot out of breath. He wears his cherubic 6-month-old daughter like a shoulder accessory; his mother, on baby-sitter duty because his wife is busy directing a rehearsal of his new play, pushes the stroller. His excuse for being tardy is so corny it must be true: it wasn't the oven-intensity Midtown heat that slowed him, but a celebrity sighting.

title: Party for Zora Neale Hurston, Obscure No More
description: On a day hot enough to send the knots in the trees crawling off to sit in the shade, Zora Neale Hurston, the protean folklorist and queen of the Harlem Renaissance, conjured an appearance on a Central Park stage Tuesday for a long-postponed party with 2,000 friends.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Law For Stranded Drivers
description: A bill requiring tow-truck operators to pick up stranded drivers even if they do not have cash to pay the towing fee was signed into law yesterday by Gov. James E. McGreevey. Under the law, tow-truck operators must accept credit cards, checks or money orders. If tow operators refuse service, they will face a $500 fine for the first offense. The law was prompted by the death of Debbe Miranda, who was hit by a car in 1994 after a tow-truck driver left her stranded on a highway because she did not have the $40 cash for his fee. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVLIN, WENDE (DOROTHY LOUISE)
description: DEVLIN - Wende (Dorothy Louise). Died August 13, 2002 at her home in Mountainside, NJ. Wende was a renowned author, painter and poet. Her portraits and still-lifes incorporate the beauty Wende saw in the world around her. Born on April 27, 1918, in Buffalo, NY, she attended Syracuse University, where she met her late husband, Harry Devlin. In 1977, they both received The Arents Medal, Syracuse University's highest honor bestowed on an alumnus for excellence in the field of their endeavour. Together Wende and Harry authored 28 childrens classics including ''How Fletcher Was Hatched,'' the acclaimed ''Cranberry Series'', and ''Old Black Witch'', later a movie. She is survived by her seven children, twenty grandchildren, and six great grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday August 16, 2002, at 12 noon at The Congregational Church in Westfield, NJ. For more information please call: 908-233-0081.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUINNESS, GEORGE F.
description: McGUINNESS-George F. On August 12, 2002. Resident of Bronxville, NY. Member of New York Athletic Club and Friendly Sons of St. Patrick (Westchester). Reposing Hodder Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave., Yonkers, NY. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 10 AM, St. Joseph RC Church (Bronxville). Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: As Gadgets Go to Class, Schools Try to Cope
description: IT was like the scene from the movie ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High,'' only for a wireless generation.

title: Hall Turns to the Ocean To Increase His Speed
description: With his 28th birthday coming next month, the two-time Olympic swimmer Gary Hall Jr. has thought of a novel way to stay competitive through the 2004 Games. To combat the monotony of training and to hold off the sport's young stars, Hall believes swimming in the ocean and underwater diving without a snorkel may just be the solution.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Arrested In Sunday Beating Death
description: Two men were arrested yesterday in the beating death of a man who accidentally walked into the middle of a neighborhood dispute, the police said. The two men -- Rafael Santos, 27, of the Bronx, and Hardy Marston, 18, of Queens -- were charged with murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. The victim, Mizanor Rahman, 37, was walking in Cypress Hills at 11:50 p.m. on Sunday when the two men confronted him, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: In and Around Harlem, Joy Fades as Anger Rises
description: Twelve hours earlier, Harlem -- its bars and its restaurants, its living rooms and its sidewalks -- crackled with sweet satisfaction. The neighborhood's baseball team had, in dramatic fashion and in extra innings, qualified for the Little League World Series for the first time.

title: U.S. Expands Hospital Supply Buying Inquiry
description: A group that helps a quarter of the nation's hospitals buy medical supplies has received a federal subpoena, along with three of its contractors in what appears to be a widening federal investigation into how hospitals buy drugs, medical devices and other products.

title: Emergency Rent Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Rogers Fills Nets' Long-Range Need
description: When Rodney Rogers signed on with the Nets yesterday, he became the final piece in a puzzle that the Nets hope pictures them one step farther than last season, when they fell short in the National Basketball Association finals.

title: A War Zone Downtown
description: To the Editor:

title: Franciscan Brother Is Charged With Molesting 4 Boston Boys
description: A Franciscan brother was arrested today on charges of sexually abusing four altar boys at a Roman Catholic church in the East Boston section of the city three decades ago.

title: Keyboard Weds Calculator And Begets Apps
description: The arrival this fall of the TI Keyboard, the latest accessory for graphing calculators made by Texas Instruments, signals an effort to break away from the confines of math and science. With the addition of the keyboard and related software, the calculators -- like the popular TI-83 Plus -- leave arithmetic and even trigonometry behind.

title: For a Closet (or Table), Just Unpack and Unfold
description: The designer Thorsten Franck had what he called the nomadic urban citizen in mind when he designed the Build in a Minute collection, which includes a collapsible dining table, a bookshelf and the Lockaway wardrobe closet (right). Build in a Minute also refers to the speedy, computer-controlled manufacturing process. The pieces come packed flat (which means they can be stored in a closet) and can be set up quickly without tools. The Lockaway wardrobe is made of solid ash plywood and comes in three wood veneers and four colors. It is approximately 66 inches tall by 27 1/2 inches wide and 13 inches deep when assembled; $465 (more for some veneers) from Oriac, (866) 466-7422. A pair of collapsible bases ($240) for a trestle table will be available at the end of the month at the MoMA Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, IRA B.
description: WHEELER-Ira B. The Board and staff of the National Executive Service Corps are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed colleague, friend and Board member, Ira B. Wheeler. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Mary and his family. A. Wright Elliott, Chair Robert N. Sellar, President

title: Further Designs Are Sought In Rebuilding of Downtown
description: The agency overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan announced yesterday that it would conduct ''a worldwide design competition'' to hire as many as five licensed architecture or planning firms to offer new ideas for the site of the World Trade Center.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: RealNetworks Names Executive
description: Merrill Brown, the former senior vice president and editor in chief of Msnbc.com, the online joint venture of Microsoft and NBC News, is joining RealNetworks Inc., as a senior vice president in charge of broadening subscription and advertising sales efforts. RealNetworks markets software to enable transmission and reception of audio and video files over the Internet. RealOne Services, the unit he will oversee, offers subscription services for online game players -- RealOne GamePass -- and its RealOne SuperPass gives subscribers access to extended information about everything from the CBS reality series ''Big Brother 3'' to the world of Nascar racing. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Brown said that ''if it's a good time for anything online, it may well be a very good time'' for ''figuring out the revenue game, figuring out how to make sense out of the content mess we're in.'' He added, ''It's largely going to be about developing new subscription strategies.'' Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: Patrick Chavis, 50, Affirmative Action Figure
description: Patrick Chavis, one of five black students whose admission to a medical school in California 30 years ago provoked a Supreme Court battle over affirmative action, died on July 23 in Hawthorne, Calif. He was 50.

title: Suddenly, Optimism Vanishes From Baseball Talks
description: Washing away all of the optimism that flowed from the union's decision Monday not to set a strike date, baseball's labor negotiators ran into a reef in their talks last night, almost ensuring that the union will set an Aug. 30 strike date tomorrow.

title: Well, the Hills Are Alive But the Tourists Aren't
description: Continuing the miniature retrospective devoted to the Japanese filmmaker Takashi Miike at the Anthology Film Archives, ''The Happiness of the Katakuris'' is a sour camp musical that trots out most of the standard signifiers of ''outrageousness'': graphic violence, kinky sex and parodies of Rodgers and Hammerstein.

title: Shares Rally, But Wall St. Shows No Sign Of Direction
description: A day after registering their disappointment over the Federal Reserve's decision not to cut interest rates, investors sent stocks sharply higher late yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, RON
description: PLOTKIN-Ron. On August 9, 2002. Beloved nephew of Ruth Ostwald, dear cousin of Susan Ostwald Barnes and Julie Lowy. Devoted friend of the late Arnold Ostwald.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Suspect Arrested In Immigrant's Death
description: Bronx detectives arrested a man yesterday in the killing of a Mexican immigrant. The police said the suspect, Harold Dudley, 43, has an arrest record dating back 25 years. Mr. Dudley was charged with second-degree murder in the killing of Miguel Carino, 65, who was on his way to his job as a cleaner at a City Island restaurant when he was slain. Chief Joseph J. Reznick said the detectives believed the motive was robbery, although Mr. Carino went to work each day with only bus fare in his pocket. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: A Reference Library On Disc or Online
description: A GENERATION or two ago, encyclopedia salesmen would scour neighborhoods, knocking on doors in search of parents willing to part with several months' pay to help ensure the educational success of their children. Their wares often became a fixture of family rooms, growing old, dusty and woefully out of date.

title: From Japan, Seating That Looks Simple, but Isn't
description: The designer Tokujin Yoshioka, right, says he designs the way the Japanese cook. ''Although the finished dish often appears extremely simple,'' he said, ''it requires a series of complex preparatory steps.'' His Honey-Pop chair, above right, is made from thin honeycombed sheets of paper. The chair, which is only inches thick when closed, opens like an accordion. Misting with water improves its shape and will increase its strength when dry. Sit in it, gather the sides around you and, voil, a custom-shaped chair. Signed and numbered, the chair is available from the designer for $580 plus shipping, but the shipping costs from Japan can be daunting. (You can order from www.tokujin.com; click on Information, then English.) The chair is already part of the Vitra Design Museum Collection.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: PROFIT DOWN AT CARMAKER Hyundai Motor said that its second-quarter profit fell 8.3 percent from the year-earlier period, to $256 million, hurt by strikes in June and costs incurred in meeting new standards for cars exported to Europe. For the first half of the year, the company earned $745 million, up 46 percent from the first six months of last year on a small increase in sales. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: United Warns of Bankruptcy Without Union Concessions

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Flextronics Will Lay Off 5,261 Workers
description: Flextronics International Ltd., the second-biggest builder of electronics for brand-name companies, said yesterday that 5,261 employees were being laid off under a plan announced in October to eliminate 10,000 workers. Flextronics said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that 856 employees were dismissed as of June 30, and 4,405 more had been notified they would lose their jobs. The Singapore-based company had said it would eliminate 10,000 jobs as it shifted to lower-cost production locations.

title: Washington Talk; Looking at the Books, The Government Way
description: Today was the deadline for hundreds of corporate chief executives to certify that they have not cooked their books, so Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who styles himself a crusader for fiscal responsibility in government, challenged the Bush administration to do what it is demanding of the private sector: sign an oath that its numbers are for real.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILIGMAN, SHIRLEY (NEE SPERANS)
description: HEILIGMAN-Shirley (nee Sperans), 75, on August 13, after a long heroic battle with cancer. Her warmth and enthusiasm will be remembered by a myriad of loyal friends. She was a devoted and beloved wife of Sol. Adoring mother of Andy & Tom, Randy & Nan. Grandmother of Michael and Zachary. Precious to her sister Phyllis Halpern. Adored by her nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends on Thursday 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services Friday 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to Community Access or Mary Mount Manhattan College.

title: Texas Executes Mexican for Murder Despite President Fox's Plea
description: In a case that has strained Mexico's relations with the United States, a Mexican citizen was executed in Texas tonight by lethal injection for the 1988 murder of an American undercover police officer.

title: A System to Offer Glee to the Bottom Flight
description: A major change in the last decade has been the virtual disappearance of flighted events in tournament play. Each field used to be divided into three groups, one for experts as measured by master points, one for the middle-level players and one for the less experienced. Everyone was competing with peers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've pretty much used up my advance, and now my editors are hoping that I'll outlive the pope.''

title: Playing Hooky? Can't Fool a Database
description: FOR years, the daily grind of a Boston Public Schools truant officer has been pretty much the same. Hit the streets, seek out wayward youths and check for their names on your trusty list of students. Trouble is, that list is a computer printout (usually out of date) of about 63,000 student names, making it thicker than several phone books. It is, to say the least, awkward.

description: Floods that have caused billions of dollars of damage across Central Europe and have shut down the Czech Republic's biggest tourist attractions also did something almost unheard of today -- they stopped the production of the Czechs' two most famous beers, Pilsner and the original Budweiser.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL STEEL GROUP, Cleveland, a producer of steel products, said it had agreed to buy the mill and other assets of the bankrupt Acme Metals, Riverdale. Ill., for $65 million.

title: RECALL IS ORDERED AT LARGE SUPPLIER OF IMPLANT TISSUE
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday shut down a substantial part of the CryoLife Corporation, the nation's largest processor of donated human tissue, saying the company could not adequately assure patients that its soft-tissue products were free of deadly bacteria and fungi.

description: James C. Thomson Jr., a Far Eastern specialist in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations who left government in 1966 because of his opposition to the United States' growing involvement in the Vietnam War, died on Sunday in Newton, Mass. He was 70 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

Beloved sister of Marilyn & Seymour Shimkowitz, Myrna JacobsRubin & Dr. L. Robert Rubin. Loved and adored by her grandsons Matthew, Adam and Joshua; nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. description: ALPER-Ethyl. On August 13, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sigfried Somers. Devoted mother of Owen Hill Alper & Harriet A. Otto. Cherished grandmother of David Hill Alper, Ellyn Schoen, Regan Otto Schroeder, Tiffany A. Otto and Dylan R. Otto and great-grandmother of Justine Bernhardt, Jason Schoen and Evan Alper. title: Mattel Expands Role Of WPP Division
description: Mattel in El Segundo, Calif., the toy company, said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, by selecting its office in Irvine, Calif., as the lead agency handling worldwide advertising for its boys and entertainment division, which includes brands like Hot Wheels, Matchbox and Uno. Spending was estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Larry Rivers, Who Shook Up American Art, Is Dead at 78
description: Larry Rivers, the irreverent proto-Pop painter and sculptor, jazz saxophonist, writer, poet, teacher and sometime actor and filmmaker, whose partly self-mocking bad-boy persona encapsulated the spirit of a restless era that shook up American art, died on Wednesday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Iran Will Force Many Afghan Refugees to Leave by Month's End
description: Iran has announced that it will require tens of thousands of refugees to return to Afghanistan as of Aug. 27, angering the United Nations refugee agency and human rights groups.

title: Bitter Circus Erupts as Israel Indicts a Top Fatah Figure
description: Marwan Barghouti, the most prominent Palestinian leader to be brought before a civilian Israeli court, made clear at his indictment on terrorism charges today that he intends to turn his public trial into a political duel with Israel.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: 12% Rise In Murders
description: Murders in the state increased 12 percent last year, and rapes rose 3.1 percent, but serious crime dropped 6 percent over all, state police reported. Robberies and thefts fell to the lowest levels since 1978, and motor vehicle thefts and burglaries were the lowest since the state police began compiling data in the mid-1970's.

title: Jailed Informer Seeks U.S. Aid To Help Family Flee Colombia
description: A jailed informer whose testimony helped convict the killers of a crusading antidrug journalist has complained that the United States government has failed to protect his family in Colombia, where, he says, five of his relatives have been killed in retaliation.

title: Technicians and Plant Operators at Animal Disease Laboratory Strike for More Pay
description: Workers at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, a laboratory off the North Fork of Long Island that conducts research on infectious diseases in animals, went on strike today.

title: U.S. CRACKS FIFA'S TOP 10
description: After making it to the final eight of the World Cup finals for the first time in 72 years, the United States men's national soccer team has again entered unchartered territory, cracking the top 10 of FIFA's latest world ranking.

title: They've Got Your Numbers
description: I WOULD love to meet the people who live in the pages of a new generation of ''shelter,'' or home design, magazines appearing this fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, MORDECAI
description: WAXMAN-Mordecai. The Center for Jewish Studies mourns the passing of its devoted Board member and early founder. His spiritual integrity, intellectual vigor, & passionate advocacy of the Jewish people give testimony to his inspired rabbinic and communal leadership. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Rabbi's bereaved sons and daughters-in-law, David and Eve, Hillel and Shohreh, Rabbi Jonathan and Judy; to his grandchildren, Jessye, Avir, Ariya, Amir Kia and Lailee, and to his sister, Naomi. Arthur Anderman, Chair Benny Kraut, Director

title: ImClone Sues Former Chief To Recover $7 Million
description: ImClone Systems filed suit yesterday against its indicted founder and former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, seeking to recover more than $7 million in severance and other compensation.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Talk About a Party

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: INSURER POSTS LOSS Europe's largest insurer, Allianz , said it lost $350 million in the second quarter as its banking sector, particularly Dresdner Bank , was hurt by higher-than-expected provisions for loan losses. Dresdner, the German bank that Allianz bought in April 2001, lost $898 million in the quarter and is expected to continue losing money for the rest of the year. While bank losses mounted, earnings on the insurance side improved, Allianz said. The insurer, which is based in Munich, said revenue from selling insurance policies rose 12 percent in the first half. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERSFELT, WILLIAM H. JR.
description: VERSFELT-William H. Jr. Of Greenwich, CT, died August 12, 2002, after a long illness. Mr. Versfelt was born in Brooklyn, NY, on November 11, 1925, the son of William H. Versfelt and Margaret Drown. He was educated in the Garden City, NY, public schools and received his B.S. degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1947. He served in the U.S. Army 99th Infantry Division during World War II and lost his right arm at the Battle of the Bulge in December, 1944. On August 29, 1946, he married Ruth Eileene Gerland, also of Garden City. Mr. Versfelt was associated with the St. Regis Paper Co. for 38 years, rising to the position of Vice President and General Manager of the Multi-wall Bag Division. He also served as President of the Paper Shipping Sack Manufacturing Association (PSSMA). As a resident of Irvington-on-Hudson, Mr. Versfelt was elected Trustee of the Village in 1960 and 1962. He was a member of the Ardsley Country Club, Ardsleyon-Hudson, for more than 30 years, as well as the Ardsley Curling Club. He taught and directed the Sunday School and served as an elder at the Irvington Presbyterian Church, where he was a member since 1956. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Ruth G. Versfelt; by two daughters, Gail V. Hay of Arlington, TX, and Claudia H. Versfelt of Indianapolis, IN, as well as one son, David S. Versfelt of Greenwich, CT, plus seven grandchildren, a stepmother, Evelyn Lewis of Sun City, AZ and a stepsister, Suzanne Graven of San Diego, CA. Funeral services are private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Irvington Presbyterian Church, 25 N. Broadway, Irvington-on-Hudson, NY 10533.

title: Mirant Finds at Least $1.1 Billion in Errors
description: Mirant, the biggest North American natural gas trader, said today that an accounting review had turned up mistakes that may have inflated figures on its balance sheet as much as $1.1 billion.

title: Amtrak Clears Another High-Speed Train
description: Amtrak said today that it had completed safety inspections on 16 of its 18 high-speed Acela trains, and had cleared three for service on Thursday, up from two on Wednesday.

title: Rules Are More Strict But Hard to Enforce
description: For more than a decade, the Little League regional playoffs and World Series have attracted nearly as much attention for scandal as for baseball. The problems have revolved around age (Are the players too old?) and residence (Do they actually live in the league's defined geographic area?).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALLMAN, MALCOLM B.
description: KALLMAN - Malcolm B., known as Matt, 73, died April 4, 2002, at home in Portland, Maine. A charming, tough and singularly complicated man, he loved politics, jazz and good conversation. His vibrant blue eyes, deep tan and wry humor sparked his enormous, ebullient presence. Born in Brighton Beach, he cherished New York. Starting as a buyer for Ohrbach's, he became general merchandise manager for the Boston Store, executive VP of Shillito's, president of Gimbels Pittsburgh, and president & chief executive for Gimbels New York. A memorial was held April 15 at Trinity Cemetery, NYC. Survived by daughter, Lisa; sons, Matthew H. & Dave, and four grandchildren. Donations may be made to the ACLU.

title: Doubles Team May Not Play in Open
description: When Amir Hadad of Israel and Aisam ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan turned into a symbol of international dtente as a doubles team at Wimbledon, they reveled in the attention that swirled around them. But neither is sure if they will team up for a repeat performance at the United States Open.

title: Vivendi Plans to Sell Assets; Goal Is to Raise $9.8 Billion
description: Vivendi Universal announced an unexpectedly large loss today and indicated that the company would begin unwinding the media empire assembled by its recently ousted chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, by selling the American educational book publisher Houghton Mifflin, among other assets, in a planned $9.8 billion sell-off.

title: Ames to Liquidate and Close Stores
description: Almost a year after filing for bankruptcy protection, Ames Department Stores, the regional discount chain, said yesterday that it would liquidate its assets and close its 327 stores.

title: Little League Is Back in Spotlight, Over Where Harlem Players Live
description: A year after one of its most profound embarrassments, when the discovery of an over-age player for a Bronx team led to a humiliating disqualification, Little League Baseball found itself today investigating the eligibility of players headed for its signature event, the Little League World Series.

title: M.L.S. DROPS SEPT. 11 PLANS
description: Major League Soccer dropped plans for a benefit soccer game on Sept. 11 between Brazil, the World Cup champion, and an international all-star team at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., saying it was not ''the right time for a celebratory match.''

title: A Midtown Skyscraper Quietly Adds Armor
description: Since Sept. 11, the owners of signature skyscrapers have been trying to find ways to calm jittery tenants and make the buildings more durable if catastrophe strikes.

title: After Prolonged Injuries, Cowart Is Ready to Play
description: Jets linebacker Sam Cowart will play little more than a dozen plays against the Baltimore Ravens on Thursday night, not that many fewer than he played in all of 2001.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Posts Loss
description: Europe's largest insurer, Allianz, said it lost $350 million in the second quarter as its banking sector, particularly Dresdner Bank, was hurt by higher-than-expected provisions for loan losses. Dresdner, the German bank that Allianz bought in April 2001, lost $898 million in the quarter and is expected to continue losing money for the rest of the year. While bank losses mounted, earnings on the insurance side improved, Allianz said. The insurer, which is based in Munich, said revenue from selling insurance policies rose 12 percent in the first half. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about technical challenges posed for retailers by plans to add a digit to the 12-digit bar code misstated the site of an Ace Hardware store. It is in Westcliffe, Colo., not Penrose.

title: Messages in Concrete: The Aesthetics of Safety
description: CENTRAL SYNAGOGUE did more than simply rebuild its fire-ravaged sanctuary last year. With meticulous care, the congregation reanimated the profuse Moorish Revival splendor of its landmark home in Midtown, conjuring once again the fearless pride expressed architecturally when the synagogue opened in 1872: this is a place of Jewish worship and we are part of the fabric of New York.

title: What Students Say; Study Finds That Teachers Fail to Grasp the Web's Potential
description: THE advent of the Internet, and the Web in particular, has upended a few traditional notions about who is educating whom. A study made public yesterday by the Pew Internet and American Life Project concluded that students tend to be far more adept than their teachers when it comes to finding creative educational uses for the Internet.

title: New Campaign For Pert Plus
description: This week, the Procter & Gamble Company began the first campaign in almost two years for its Pert Plus hair care line.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Industry Group Warns of Air Bag Fraud With Some Used Cars
description: Vehicles in which air bags have been deployed are sometimes refurbished with false or faulty replacements and resold to unsuspecting customers, the Automotive Occupant Restraints Council said today.

title: An Incestuous Attraction And a Mysterious Corpse
description: At the opening of ''Death of Frank,'' a play by Stephen Belber that is being staged as part of the New York International Fringe Festival, a dead man is lying center stage. There is a natural curiosity about who he is and how he came to be dead. But as one of the play's four characters delivers a monologue about his sister that drones into a childhood flashback about a maple tree oozing syrup, your interest even in a dead body begins to wane. The explanation doesn't come for nearly two hours, and by that time you can only feel a certain envy for the corpse.

title: Paying the Price in Losses Overseas For Replicating U.S. Online Service
description: At the same time that America Online's domestic service is faltering, the strains in its nine overseas operations are becoming more apparent, too.

title: A Lightweight Projector With Brightness to Spare
description: With the ability to handle everything from PowerPoint presentations to impromptu DVD screenings, liquid crystal display projectors are popping up everywhere from classrooms to conference rooms. At about five pounds, the new VPL-CX5 projector from Sony is light enough to be easily toted around. Yet it is one of the brightest projectors available, with a maximum brightness of 2,000 lumens of light, meaning that presentations are visible even with the lights on.

title: BANKRUPTCY HINT BY UNITED AIRLINES
description: United Airlines, burdened by debt and by tense relationships with its employees, who own more than half the company, said yesterday that it might file for bankruptcy protection by mid-November if it did not receive concessions from labor unions, suppliers and others within a month.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SCHOOLS CHIEF HIRES EX-COLLEAGUE

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Attorney General Names Liaison
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft announced that Guy Lewis, a former United States attorney for the Southern District of Florida in Miami, will become director of the Executive Office for United States Attorneys. Mr. Lewis will serve as the liaison between the 94 federal prosecutor's offices across the country and various divisions of the Justice Department as well as several other federal agencies. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: In Windows 2000 and XP, A Successor to ScanDisk
description: Q. I recently got a new computer with Windows XP installed, but now I can't find the ScanDisk utility program that came with some previous versions of Windows. Did they get rid of it?

title: KMART SEEKS AN ADDITIONAL $500 MILLION IN LOANS
description: The Kmart Corporation has asked a federal judge in Chicago for permission to borrow another $500 million so it can pay suppliers through the holiday season. As part of the request, the company wants creditors to adjust some of the terms governing its loan agreements, Kmart said. Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., has $400 million in cash available, the company said. ''We believe that seeking this increase will provide additional comfort to our suppliers,'' Al Koch, the chief financial officer, said in a statement. He said the increase would help ensure that the company succeeded during the ''critical holiday season.''

description: FRIEDMAN-Sally. Thinking of you on your birthday and everyday. You'd be so proud of your girls. Love, Ellen

title: In Albany, a Rainbow to the River
description: It has been more than 30 years since the residents of Albany could stroll over to the Hudson River without having to dodge speeding Buicks on Interstate 787, thanks to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's dropping the highway on its west bank. ''It really cut the city off from the river,'' said Virginia Bowers, the city historian.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Exploring Belarus Merger
description: In talks with his Belarussian counterpart, President Vladimir V. Putin proposed absorbing Belarus into Russia, adding 7 regions to Russia's 89. The Belarussian leader, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, objected to the plan once he got home from Moscow, saying he favored more equal terms. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Chief Offers To Resign As Varig Seeks Cash
description: Ozires Silva has offered his resignation as chief executive of Varig, just as the company, Brazil's prestigious but debt-laden airline, is negotiating with the government and creditors to secure a $300 million cash injection to keep flying, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Drapery, From the Theater to the Home
description: A company called Rose Brand, which supplies drapery fabrics, trim and hardware to theater and movie-set designers, is a source for well-priced home-curtain materials. It has a store in New York and one in Los Angeles, a Web site and an outlet on the Web site. The outlet offers unclaimed custom-made orders at deep discounts. This week, a black velour stage curtain, 21 feet high and 32 feet long, was $300. The regular stock is also well priced and includes lightweight China silk in 36 colors ($11.36 a yard for 45-inch width) and polyester voile in three colors (118 inches wide, $8.06 a yard). Tassels, rods and tracks are available, too. Rose Brand East, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), (800) 223-1624; Rose Brand West, 10856 Vanowen Street, North Hollywood (800) 360-5056, or www.rosebrand.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REITER, NORMAN A.
description: REITER-Norman A. Of Livingston, NJ. Beloved husband for 39 beautiful years of Diane Kronberg Reiter, devoted father of Stephen L. and Dr. Mitchel F. Reiter, adored father-in-law of Alyssa and Patricia, cherished brother of Marsha Martin and Sol Reiter, dear brotherin-law of Martin and Ilene Kronberg. Most precious grandfather of David Max and Samantha Riley. Funeral services at Bernheim-ApterKreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, Friday, August 16, 2002 at noon. For additional information please call at 1-800-938-6372.

title: Venezuela Supreme Court Clears 4 Military Officers in Uprising
description: The Supreme Court of Venezuela today dismissed the case against four military officers the government had accused of rebelling against President Hugo Chvez in April. The ruling set off violent protests by supporters of the president in the streets of the capital.

title: The Look of Age, Without the Wait
description: WHEN Jessica Dubner went shopping for flooring for a 1910 house on Long Island, she passed up linoleum, rubber, cork, vinyl and Pergo, opting for secondhand chestnut pried from a collapsing Normandy farmhouse. ''I like knowing that the material has history,'' she said.

title: Malfunctions And Bus Crash Make Bad Day For Commuting
description: A string of unrelated mishaps turned the morning commuting around New York into a long, hot and frustrating one yesterday for hundreds of thousands of people who were delayed by suspended subway lines, malfunctioning traffic lights and an accident that left the New York State Thruway backed up for miles.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Passaic Prosecutor Nominated
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey has nominated James Avigliano, a lawyer and former assistant prosecutor, as Passaic prosecutor. Mr. Avigliano, whose nomination is subject to Senate confirmation, would replace the acting prosecutor, Boris Moczula, who took office after Ronald Fava stepped down to run for sheriff. Mr. Avigliano, 62, started his career in 1972 as an assistant prosecutor in Passaic County. Since then, he has served as a municipal prosecutor in Wayne and a borough attorney for Haledon. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Booting Up Before Taps, Soldiers Pursue College Degrees
description: SGT. FIRST CLASS REINALDO VAILLANT, who grew up ''a block from Yankee Stadium'' and now lives in Watertown, N.Y., has decided to earn a degree in computer technology.

title: Bum a Smoke? At This Price?; Even Without a Ban, Some Rituals Are Changing
description: Valerie Lee was smoking down her drinks at the Bowery Bar. For each dry vodka martini, there was another Virginia Slim. But she said she was going to have to change her pace. ''I will probably go to one smoke for every other drink,'' she said. ''I just can't do $7.50 a pack.''

title: New Designs for a New Downtown
description: The people in charge of rebuilding Lower Manhattan have decided, literally, to go back to the drawing board. One month after six preliminary plans for a new World Trade Center site were unveiled to almost universal scorn, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation announced yesterday that it would extend the design competition three months and invite architects from around the world to submit plans. The corporation said it was seeking excitement, creativity and energy -- three qualities that were conspicuously missing from the original designs.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Timber Harvest Drops
description: The state's timber harvest in 2001 was the lowest in 12 years, the Department of Forestry said. The harvest of 3.44 billion board feet was down more than 400 million board feet from 2000. In the late 1980's, annual harvests exceeded 8 billion board feet for five straight years. Officials attribute some of the decline to environmental regulations that forced changes in logging practices.

title: Zavata Is the Leading 2-Year-Old
description: Patrick Biancone, the French-born trainer who handles Zavata for Michael Tabor, originally wanted to name the bay colt Houdini, as a sort of play on the sire's name, Phone Trick.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility's Profit Rises
description: Europe's second-largest utility, E.ON, said that first-half profit rose 42 percent after it made acquisitions in Sweden and Germany, cut costs and benefited from higher electricity and lower fuel prices. Pretax profit including interest income rose to 2.352 billion euros ($2.3 billion) from 1.66 billion in the period a year ago, E.ON said. Net income tripled on gains from asset sales.

title: News Corporation Posts a Loss, Mostly in Gemstar Mess
description: The News Corporation announced solid quarterly financial results yesterday, even as a worsening relationship with Gemstar-TV Guide International continued to obscure the strength of some of the company's core operations.

title: See You in September? Hoping, Coping
description: If the Giants cut fullback Darian Barnes, there is a post-apocalyptic place he will go. A city in Ohio, with vampires.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Senior Fire Official Named
description: Frank P. Cruthers was named the Fire Department's chief of department yesterday, a post he held briefly in 1996. Chief Cruthers will play a large role in the reorganization of the Fire Department, which includes the expansion of the top uniformed ranks and the creation of borough commands to decentralize the management of field operations. Chief Cruthers, a 34-year veteran of the department, most recently served as citywide tour commander. He is to start work on Sept. 9. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: The Path Not Chosen
description: To the Editor:

title: To Shower and Do Laundry at the Same Time
description: Whirlpool wanted to reshape thinking about laundry, so it showed some futuristic prototypes at the Milan furniture fair in April. A handful of design groups worked with Whirlpool's design team on the project. ''We wanted to blur the barrier between outside and internal design,'' said Charles Jones, the company's vice president for global consumer design.

title: Words for Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTHERLAND, DONALD J.
description: SUTHERLAND - Donald J. The Board of Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Professional Children's School in New York City deeply regret the death of Donald J. Sutherland, the beloved husband of our esteemed Board Chair, Denise Sutherland.

title: Designers United to Put South African Crafts in the Home
description: Creations by LOSA, a group established to market South African crafts, will be available beginning next month at the Terence Conran Shop. The products were conceived by designers, mostly based in London, who traveled to South Africa for inspiration. They were executed by South African artisans, who were paid for their work and will receive a percentage of the profit. The pieces were shown in the spring at Sotheby's in London.

title: Actors in Ellis Island Show Vote, 7 to 1, to Join Union
description: The 10 actors who take turns in ''Embracing Freedom,'' the play performed before visitors to Ellis Island, try their hardest to portray the oppression and poverty overseas that drove millions of immigrants to the United States.

title: Gov. Bush Is Said to Have Chosen New Head for Children's Agency
description: Gov. Jeb Bush is widely expected to announce as early as Thursday that he has chosen Jerry Regier, former secretary of health and human services in Oklahoma, to succeed Kathleen A. Kearney, people who have been told of the decision say.

title: One Building Approved for Special Financing
description: Approval of special Sept. 11-related financing for two residential buildings in Lower Manhattan was delayed yesterday for further discussion, while financing for a third was approved, according to a spokesman for Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.

title: ALKERMES DROPS PLAN TO BUY RELIANT PHARMACEUTICALS
description: Alkermes, which makes long-acting drugs, ended its agreement to buy the 81 percent of Reliant Pharmaceuticals that it does not already own after Alkermes shares plummeted. Alkermes agreed in March to pay $934 million in stock for Reliant. Shares of Alkermes have fallen 72 percent since the deal was announced, cutting the value of the transaction to $259.4 million. Alkermes, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., is shifting toward developing its own treatments and away from concentrating on ways to create long-acting versions of drugs from other companies. In December, Alkermes paid $100 million for a 19 percent stake in Reliant, a closely held company based in Liberty Corner, N.J.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: REGION BUFFETED BY LANDSLIDES AND FLOODING More than 800 people have been killed by floods and landslides in an unusually severe Chinese storm season. State officials in Yunnan said 13 people were killed Monday and 16 were still missing as rescuers dug through a landslide, according to China Central Television. Similar crises have befallen India, Bangladesh and Nepal, where landslides in a mountainous village northeast of Katmandu killed two, pushing South Asian monsoon-related death toll to almost 880, officials said. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, ROSLYN
description: ALEXANDER-Roslyn. Town and Village Synagogue/Tifereth Israel mourns the loss of its long standing member and extends heartfelt condolences to her husband Albert Alexander and son Howard Alexander and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Cantor Shayna Smith Dr. Roselyn Kolodny, Pres.

title: Babies Who Sign
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: The Economy, Rah, Rah! (Right?)
description: To the Editor:

title: Parental Tech Support
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Moves to Increase Control of Some Isuzu Units
description: General Motors said today that it planned to restructure its stake in Isuzu Motors by taking control of parts of the troubled Japanese automaker's diesel division and cutting its equity stake in the whole company to 12 percent from 49 percent now.

title: Holding Lawyers Accountable
description: Harvey Pitt put lawyers on notice this week. Addressing an American Bar Association gathering on Monday, Mr. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, admonished lawyers to play an active role in preventing further corporate scandals, or risk the ''fate visited upon the accounting industry.'' There was no need for him to mention Arthur Andersen, the dying auditing firm convicted of obstructing justice in the Enron scandal, to make his point.

title: Williams Moves Past Mattingly
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14  Don Mattingly did not realize Bernie Williams had passed him on the Yankees' career home run list until a reporter contacted him today for his reaction. Mattingly heard his name mentioned with Williams's homer on a highlight show this morning, but he said he was unsure of the connection.

title: It's Giants Versus Dorm Rooms, and the Giants Lose
description: RODNEY WILLIAMS has made two purchases to improve the living conditions at the New York Giants' training camp here. He bought one purple-flowered can of air freshener. Then, a week later, he bought another one.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC WILL SELL UNIT TO REDUCE DEBT
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 60 percent of its Unisource Worldwide distribution unit for $850 million to an investment company to reduce debt before spinning off its tissue and packaging business. The sale will be completed in the fourth quarter, Georgia-Pacific said late Tuesday. The unit is being bought by Bain Capital, which is based in Boston. Georgia-Pacific, which is based in Atlanta, is trying to reduce its $12.1 billion debt load, which caused Moody's Investors Service to cut its bond rating to junk status in May. Georgia-Pacific bought the distribution business for $1.51 billion in 1999. Unisource, which sells paper for copy machines and printers, had $48 million in profit last year on $6.2 billion in sales.

title: The Seductive Call Of School Supplies
description: IF I had to pinpoint the moment when I went wrong during the back-to-school season last year, I wouldn't necessarily say it was when I took my daughters to a local store so that they could pick out their own school supplies.

title: AOL's Challenges Now Have Global Reach
description: Racing against a Securities and Exchange Commission deadline, Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner, certified the company's financial results late yesterday afternoon with the disclosure that its AOL division might have inflated revenue by $49 million in a period from the fall of 2000 through the summer of 2002.

title: Genome Pioneer Will Start Center of His Own
description: J. Craig Venter, who raced government-financed researchers to decode the human genome then was ousted from the company he made famous, plans to create a huge laboratory that would rival efforts by his former company and his public competitors.

title: Following Custer's Photographer Into the Black Hills
description: In 1874, just two years before his forces were wiped out in the Battle of Little Bighorn, Lt. Col. George Armstrong Custer led the first expedition by white men into the Black Hills, the land of darkly forested granite peaks that was then the Dakota Territory's final frontier. On Aug. 1, 1874, Custer ordered his 1,000 weary men to set up camp in a broad valley near here.

title: West Bank Story
description: To the Editor:

title: The Road Back to School Is Paved With Style
description: IT isn't necessary to sacrifice style when furnishing a dorm room or starter apartment on a tight budget. Smart shoppers can find plenty of up-to-date designs in the current crop of low-priced furnishings for studying, lounging and storage. The new palette is bright, and the fabrics are soft.

title: Not Just Singing, but Soul-Baring, Too; The Hardest Thing Is to Be Yourself, Barbara Cook Tells Her Students
description: She walks onto the bare stage in black pants, a loose jacket, a gauzy scarf and oversize rose-colored sunglasses, carrying a big handbag and a small bottle of water. She surveys the grand piano, three chairs and two microphones, then turns to face the six singers in the front row who have come to listen, and learn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIBERG, HARRIET HALL
description: FREIBERG-Harriet Hall, 89. Of Greenwich, CT. on August 10. Beloved mother of Susan Lane Coolidge and Ann Hall Kaplan. Grandmother of Anne, Tommy, Amy and Kenneth. Great-grandmother of Charles and Alexander. In lieu of flowers contributions can be sent to Doctors Without Borders.

title: Political Ad and 9/11 Speech May Be an Unwelcome Mix
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg expressed concern yesterday about a plan by the New York State Democratic Party to offer its own rendition of the Gettysburg Address in a television ad honoring the Sept. 11 dead.

title: Bush Takes His Optimism on Economy to Iowa State Fair
description: President Bush today took his message of cheer about the gloomy American economy to the fertile political grounds of the Iowa State Fair, where he spoke between appearances by two of his potential 2004 Democratic competitors, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.

title: Smallpox Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: A Smoker's Lament
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about participants in President Bush's economic forum referred incorrectly in some copies to the company headed by Charles Schwab, who attended. It is the Charles Schwab Corporation, not Charles Schwab Inc.

title: An Adviser to McGreevey Resigns
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey's former adviser on domestic security, who was reassigned to another post in the governor's office because he was unable to obtain a security clearance, resigned from the administration today.

title: The Anger of Arab Youth
description: Throughout the Arab world, millions of young people resent America and the West. They cite specific grievances, including American support for Israel, the Bush administration's threats to attack Iraq and Washington's support for repressive Arab dictatorships. But their rage has much deeper roots. To a large degree it is the result of the sharply felt contrast between the past glories of Arab civilization and its current dismal prospects.

title: Neal Travis -- Columnist, 62
description: Neal Travis, a gossip columnist for The New York Post whose work appeared daily opposite the paper's Page Six celebrity page, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. He was 62 and lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a workshop for high school students at the University of Minnesota Design Institute misstated the name of a band whose CD ''White Blood Cells'' was playing behind a sofa that some of the students had made. It is the White Stripes, not White Stripe.

title: Inter-Korea Talks Offer Signs Of Progress, and Frustration
description: In the highest-level meeting between North and South Korea in almost a year, the North agreed today to discuss economic cooperation with the South and to allow another round of reunions of families divided by the Korean War, but it balked at setting a date for key military talks that would allow construction of road and rail links across the highly militarized border.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Middle Island: Camp Counselor Arrested
description: A 24-year-old camp counselor and bus driver was charged yesterday with sexually abusing a 3-year-old girl on her bus, the Suffolk County police said. The counselor, Jennifer Reiffert of Middle Island, works at Laurel Hill School in East Setauket, the police said. She was accused of abusing the girl July 22. Ms. Reiffert, who told the police she is a substitute teacher in the Riverhead School District, has been charged with first degree sexual abuse. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLOUGHLIN, JOHN R.
description: McLOUGHLIN-John R. On August 13th, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth Morgan. Loving father of Suzanne Battenfeld. Devoted grandfather of Morgan and Lance. Retired from General Cigar, 1988. Memorial Mass, St. John the Evangelist Church, Friday, August 16th, 9:30 AM. For information, please call Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 212-877-9700.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. To Build Supercomputer For Germany
description: I.B.M., which has built 5 of the 10 biggest supercomputers, won a contract yesterday for the world's fourth-largest version of the big machines for the Juelich Research Center of Germany. Terms were not disclosed. The device will comprise 37 I.B.M. eServer computers plus data-storage systems for faster simulations of physics, mathematics, chemistry and biology problems, said Peter Ungaro, vice president for high-performance computing at I.B.M., the world's biggest computer maker. Supercomputer sales by all vendors are growing as demand for other computers stagnates, Mr. Ungaro said. The I.B.M. machine, capable of peak performance at 5.8 trillion calculations a second, would be Europe's largest if operating today, according to a global ranking of supercomputers by United States and German university researchers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agere Systems Will Cut 4,000 Jobs
description: Agere Systems, the maker of communications chips that was spun off from Lucent Technologies, said yesterday that it would cut 4,000 jobs, or more than a third of its work force, as it left the optoelectronics sector to focus on its integrated circuits business. Optoelectronic components can be found in televisions, compact disc players, mobile telephones and other electronic products, but Agere's offerings are usually used in fiber optic cable networks, a sector that has been hard hit with the telecommunications slump. Shares in Agere rose 12 cents each, to close at $1.69. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Bugging Out on the Bayou
description: Louisianans are confronting the nation's worst outbreak of West Nile virus since it first appeared three years ago.

title: Calling Plans
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: At the Gipsy House
description: It is not just kids who year to go to Gipsy House, where Roald Dahl wrote "James and the Giant Peach," among other classics. Grown-up children do, too. People like the director Wes Anderson.

title: Police Rally for Pay Increases
description: Thousands of off-duty police officers and firefighters demonstrated in Times Square on Thursday for higher pay.

title: A Dream Car and Changing Dreams
description: In the small subset of automobiles that can properly be called American sports cars, the undisputed king is the Corvette.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Take a walk through TriBeCa on a warm summer evening, and if you disregard all the American flags and don't look up, it's possible to feel things are pretty much as they should be. Restaurants are bustling, couples are walking arm-in-arm and parents are pushing strollers. With a slight breeze keeping the temperature comfortable, it was hard to imagine a more pleasant place to be than having a drink on the outdoor terrace at Layla, the Middle Eastern restaurant that is part of the Drew Nieporent-Robert De Niro restaurant empire.

title: Residential Real Estate; Dowager Going Condo in Un-Trumplike Way
description: Monolithic glass towers are his skyline signature. But Donald J. Trump has an entirely different plan for the 73-year-old Hotel Delmonico at Park Avenue and 59th Street.

title: Comet-Exploring Spacecraft Has Disappeared, NASA Says
description: NASA is searching space for a comet-exploring spacecraft that disappeared today after it was supposed to fire its main rocket engine.

title: Recalling a Colorful Europe As It Turned Steel Gray
description: Matej Minac's ''All My Loved Ones'' begins with a black-and-white photograph blossoming into bright, pastel color, introducing the audience to the idyllic world of the Silberstein family, Jewish residents of Prague in the years just before World War II.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Soda Ads Deface Mountain
description: The cutthroat competition between local arms of Coca-Cola and PepsiCo landed them both in trouble with the Indian government after they covered a mountainside in the Himalayas with competing soft drink ads. The huge ads painted on the rock cliffs can be seen from a busy road in Himachal Pradesh Province, about 200 miles north of New Delhi. India's solicitor general, Harish Salve, said cleaning away the signs with chemicals might compound the environmental damage done by painting them. He has begun court proceedings against the companies and called for an investigation by a government research institute. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 30 about political fund-raising by Dick Armey, the House majority leader, referred imprecisely to his son Scott, who sought the Republican nomination to succeed his father in Congress. Scott Armey had been a county judge while he was seeking election, but then resigned to take a job with the federal government.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Doctor Suspended After Patient Dies
description: State officials have suspended the medical license of a surgeon after some of his patients suffered serious complications, including severe infections and perforated bowels, and a woman died during a routine procedure to remove fat from around her stomach last month. The state's Board of Medical Examiners voted Wednesday to suspend the license of the doctor, Jose A. Lopez, a cosmetic surgeon. Last month, Wendy Nunez, 28, died during an abdominoplasty, or tummy tuck. No precise cause of death was reported, but Ms. Nunez had received excessive amounts of the anesthetic lidocaine, the board said. A partly blocked artery may have also played a role. The board will re-examine Dr. Lopez's suspension at a hearing in October, when he may respond to the charges against him. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Fed Officials Were Confident Economy Was Improving in June
description: Federal Reserve policy makers were confident seven weeks ago that the economy was on the path to recovery, according to minutes of their discussions on June 25 and 26.

title: Chief Expands His Holding in Disney
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that Michael D. Eisner, the company's chairman and chief executive, bought 725,700 shares of Disney stock on Wednesday for about $10 million. The purchase, which was made at prices from $13.55 to $14.49 a share, makes Mr. Eisner the third-largest shareholder of Disney stock, after the Bass family and Roy Disney, the nephew of Walt Disney.

title: Judge Delays Moussaoui Case, Giving Defense More Time
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  The trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was delayed for more than three months today by a federal judge who said the defense needs more time to prepare its case.

title: Internet Bumbling in the Ivy League
description: To the Editor:

title: Suddenly, Raises for Congress Seem Less Certain
description: There is only one thing members of Congress hate more than voting on giving themselves a raise: voting on giving themselves a raise in an election year when a shaky economy is shrinking the retirement funds of many constituents.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Drops Sale Of Unit
description: The fourth-biggest German bank, Commerzbank, has decided not to sell the Jupiter International Group, its British asset management unit, because it could not get the price it wanted. It now intends to keep Jupiter within the Commerzbank Group for the long term, the bank said. Commerzbank reaffirmed its plans to sell Montgomery Asset Management, which is based in San Francisco. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: League's Founders Draw Wide Praise
description: Over the past 13 years, as the Harlem Little League grew into a national model for urban youth sports, the reputation of the founders, W. Dwight and Iris Raiford, soared. Dwight Raiford became a board member and, last November, the first African-American chairman of Little League Baseball.

title: Officials to Hold Competition For Design of 9/11 Memorial
description: An international competition to design a memorial to the victims of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 is expected to begin early next year, with a winning design to be selected by the second anniversary of the attack, rebuilding officials said yesterday.

title: London Journal; A Fence for the Orthodox Faces a Wall of Critics
description: To the world's arenas of colliding faith from Jerusalem to Jaffna, Belfast to Beirut -- add Golders Green, albeit without the bloodshed.

title: U.S. in Criminal Inquiry on Metabolife Product
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it was conducting a criminal investigation into Metabolife International, a leading manufacturer of the herbal stimulant ephedra, to determine whether executives lied about what they knew about the safety of the substance.

title: Dresden, Battered by Elbe, Fights to Preserve Its Heritage
description: Below the paintings by Raphael, Rubens, Rembrandt and other old masters that crowd the walls of the Zwinger Palace hundreds of other works by Renaissance and Baroque artists are now lined up on the floor, survivors of what might have been a cultural tragedy when the palace's underground storage rooms flooded on Tuesday.

title: TOP  REPUBLICANS BREAK  WITH  BUSH ON IRAQ STRATEGY
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Number Of Listed Sex Offenders  Rises
description: The number of registered sex offenders has risen nearly 55 percent over the last three years, a spokesman for the State Division of Criminal Justice said yesterday. Established in 1996 as part of the state's Sex Offender Registration Act, the registry listed 14,404 offenders in July, up from from 9,336 in July 1999. The rise is due in part to the addition in 1999 of eight sex offenses requiring registration. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas climbed after a report showed a smaller-than-expected rise in stockpiles. In New York, natural gas for September delivery rose 21.7 cents, or 7.5 percent, to $3.127 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: To Make River Boaters Breathe Easier
description: To the Editor:

title: Kyle Rote, a Top Receiver For the Giants, Dies at 73
description: Kyle Rote, an all-American back at Southern Methodist who became a star receiver with Giants teams that went to four N.F.L. championship games in the 1950's and early 60's, died yesterday at a hospital in Baltimore. Rote, who lived in St. Michaels, Md., was 73.

title: A Fire Born of Revolution
description: ALTHOUGH its title suggests a drowsy history textbook, ''The Epic of American Civilization,'' a mural by the Mexican painter Jos Clemente Orozco (1883-1949) in the Baker Library at Dartmouth College here, has a throbbing vitality that keeps viewers' eyes wide open. Punctuated by doors, windows and other architectural bits and pieces as it runs the 92-foot length of the basement reserve reading room, the 26-panel fresco is densely packed with symbolic figures and stagy events. A blend of myth, history and contemporary comment, much affected by premonitions of the pending World War II, it aptly conveys Orozco's dour, apocalyptic vision of human fate.

title: DOMINION RESOURCES SAYS AGREEMENT WILL END STRIKE
description: Dominion Resources, owner of Virginia's largest utility, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to raise workers' wages and improve their pensions, ending a 13-day strike. The tentative agreement includes a compounded wage increase of almost 15 percent over the next five years and improved health care benefits, Dominion said. If approved by workers, the new contract will succeed a three-year agreement ratified in 1995 and extended twice. It expired March 31. The company, which has maintained operations during the strike using salaried and contract workers, said 3,700 employees would return to work in the next few days.

title: Weekender | Madison, Conn.
description: AFTER Sept. 11, R. J. Julia Booksellers, which takes up 6,000 square feet in two buildings in Madison, a town of 16,000, became a kind of town square where people could share their shock. The store brought in authors like former Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, the Yale historian Paul Kennedy and Karen Armstrong, author of ''The History of God,'' for lectures and discussions that helped residents make sense of what had happened.

title: Funk Leads P.G.A. Championship
description: CHASKA, Minn., Aug. 16 - There was no doubt that Fred Funk basked in the limelight today. He smiled and waved at the gallery like a campaigning politician, tipping his cap more times than some players do in year. He hit terrific shots, avoiding the dangers at Hazeltine National Golf Club with precise play, smart course management and a rock-solid putting stroke.

title: With the Folk Being Globalized, What Is Folk Art?
description: ''Great Masters of Mexican Folk Art'' is a big, lavish, crowd pleaser of an exhibition at the National Museum of the American Indian. A colorful and entertaining selection of more than 500 works by 181 contemporary Mexican artisans, it includes sculpture, furniture, ceramics, weaving, toys, religious objects, glassware, bead work, leather work and much more. There are works of dazzling opulence, amazing technique and expressive vigor.

title: Computer Sciences Seeks Leaves
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the computer-services company, said today that it would ask its 66,000 workers to volunteer to take at least six months' leave with 20 percent pay.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Pension Fund Loses $419 Million
description: The state pension fund lost $419 million in the 2001-2002 fiscal year, newly released figures show. The fund's market value, which was almost $9 billion at the beginning of the year, fell to about $8 billion. In addition to investment losses, the fund paid $560 million in benefits. State officials said the losses of 5.08 percent were not as bad as those of many other state pension funds.

title: Mondesi's Home Run Rallies Yanks
description: An airplane flew over Kauffman Stadium before the game tonight carrying a sign that read: ''N.Y. Yankees. The Best Team Money Could Buy.'' If anyone missed the first reminder of the disparity of about $90 million in payrolls between the Yankees and the Kansas City Royals, the plane circled a few more times to emphasize it.

title: A Single-Minded Cook Who Wakes Up to Life
description: ''Mostly Martha'' is the latest addition -- and a quite adorable one -- to the cooking melo-comedy subgenre, where ''Big Night'' and ''Who Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe?'' reside. It's a German comedy about a workaholic chef who has to force herself out of her fixation and get a life. The movie succeeds because the writer and director, Sandra Nettelbeck, seems as obsessive as her titular heroine.

title: Long Live the King
description: For those too young to have experienced Elvis Presley in his prime, today's celebration of the 25th anniversary of his death must seem peculiar. All the talentless impersonators and appalling black velvet paintings on display can make him seem little more than a perverse and distant memory. But before Elvis was camp, he was its opposite: a genuine cultural force. He was, famously, the white boy from Tupelo, Miss., who sang like a black boy and who shocked refined sensibilities by moving, as Time magazine observed in 1956, ''as if he had swallowed a jackhammer.''

title: Smallpox Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Governor Chooses Running Mate
description: Gov. Bill Owens has named his running mate for the Nov. 5 election: Jane Norton, director of the state Department of Public Health and Environment. Governor Owens, a Republican, had said he would not run with Lt. Gov. Joe Rogers. On Tuesday, Mr. Rogers finished fourth in a four-way Congressional primary race. Governor Owens and Ms. Norton will face Rollie Heath, a Democrat, and his running mate, State Senator Bill Thiebaut. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Quick Escapes
description: San Francisco

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Zimbabwe Cracks Down on Whites Who Won't Quit Farms
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 16  After a week of tough talk and stern warnings, the government of Zimbabwe has begun to crack down on the hundreds of white farmers who have defied an official eviction order that requires them to abandon their properties.

title: Technology as a Muse, A Hazard and an Ally
description: Let's call it the New Hollowness. I mean the growing phenomenon of exhibitions in which there is no discernable there. The recent Whitney Biennial had this shell-like emptiness in many areas, and so does Documenta XI in Kassel, Germany. Such a void can be achieved in many different ways, but the current method of choice combines expertly used technology with an overemphasis on subject matter, as opposed to material and form.

title: Umpires Demand Arbitration
description: The World Umpires Association, which has already filed two grievances in its dispute with Major League Baseball over a computerized system that monitors balls and strikes, took another step in the dispute yesterday. It filed a demand for arbitration against the commissioner's office in its effort to obtain information about the system.

title: Chief of Hooters May Invest in Airline
description: The chairman of Hooters of America, Robert H. Brooks, may invest in or buy the troubled Vanguard Airlines and will provide the airline with financing for the next three weeks.

title: Surgeons Offer Reassurances on Implant Tissues
description: Orthopedic surgeons reassured patients yesterday that risks of infection from cadaver tissue are small and that there were several good sources of it besides a company whose shipments were ordered halted Wednesday by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Brick Houses: A Sturdy, Low-Maintenance Nest for the Long Haul
description: WHO -- Joseph D. Altavilla, 89, a retired mechanic, and Edie Altavilla, 87, a retired dressmaker.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Twins' Condition Improves
description: The Guatemalan twins who were separated last week in a 22-hour operation are doing well, and their condition has been upgraded to serious from critical, officials at Mattel Children's Hospital at the University of California at Los Angeles said. One of the year-old twins, Mara de Jess Quiej lvarez, is feeding from a bottle, while the other, Mara Teresa, remains slightly sedated. Both are breathing on their own. Nick Madigan (NYT)

title: Border Skirmishes of a Novice Gardener
description: FOR the last two summers, not coincidentally since the time my children learned to entertain themselves for 43 minutes at a stretch (I know; I've timed it), I have been out in the blazing sun, covered from brow to ankle in dirt and mosquito bites, increasing our property value. By which I mean to say I've been gardening.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Judge Says A Regulation On Park Fees Violates Law
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a regulation allowing the New York City Parks Department to charge commercially sponsored private groups higher fees than groups without for-profit sponsors for the use of city parks is unconstitutional.

title: Council Proposes Public Market on Site of Towers
description: If the City Council has its way, the World Trade Center site will become home to a public market, like Pike Place in Seattle, where organic produce vendors stand cheek by jowl with fishmongers, artisans and performers.

title: 'We Have to Put Our House in Order'
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with Cardinal Edward M. Egan, as recorded by The New York Times. More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 30 about political fund-raising by Dick Armey, the House majority leader, referred imprecisely to his son Scott, who sought the Republican nomination to succeed his father in Congress. Scott Armey had been a county judge while he was seeking election, but then resigned to take a job with the federal government.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Prison Workers Charged In Identity Theft
description: Two Miami-Dade County prison employees were accused of using children's Social Security numbers to obtain credit cards to pay for cosmetic surgery and other personal expenses, said Marcos Daniel Jimenez, the United States attorney for the Southern District in Miami. The employees, Della Savoury-Mayo and Xiomara Lobo, were charged with identity theft, which carries a sentence of up to 15 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: A Celebration to Remember Liberation Unites Koreans for a Day
description: Barely six weeks after North and South Korea fought a gun battle at sea, the largest delegation of North Korean civilians in memory joined South Koreans here today to celebrate the anniversary of the end of World War II and the end of Japanese colonial rule.

title: Riding the Perfect Wave Into a Hawaii Sunset
description: I must confess that there were times during ''Blue Crush,'' a late summer guilty-pleasure movie about surfing, when I would have been helped by English subtitles. Especially in the first 20 minutes or so, the jargon comes on so thick and fast that I had no idea what anyone was talking about: the prospect of something called ''perfect pipe'' just off the beaches of Oahu had a few folks pretty excited.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: New Leader For Social Services Agency
description: Gov. Jeb Bush announced the appointment of Jerry Regier, left, the former secretary of health and human services in Oklahoma, to succeed Kathleen A. Kearney as secretary of the Florida Department of Children and Families. Ms. Kearney resigned on Tuesday. The agency has been besieged by scandals, including a disclosure in April that it had lost a 4-year-old in its care and had not noticed the problem for more than a year. Dana Canedy (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Weighing Counsel of Republicans Cautious on Iraq
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 16  President Bush said today that he was "listening carefully" to a group of moderate Republicans who are warning him against going to war with Iraq, but he said that he would still make up his own mind based on the latest intelligence that is very tightly held within his administration.

title: Mets Trade Estes to Reds For 2 Now and 2 Later
description: Shawn Estes's disappointing stay with the Mets came to an end yesterday, when Estes, a left-handed starter who had pitched erratically this season, was traded to the Cincinnati Reds for two minor leaguers and two players to be determined later.

title: Through Kafka's Eyes
description: ''The City of K.: Franz Kafka and Prague,'' at the Jewish Museum, explores the writer's complex feelings about his native city. The show features manuscripts, ephemera, photographs and early editions that have been arranged into 12 Kafkaesque environments. In one part of the exhibition, called ''The Primal Scene,'' a viewer glimpses, mostly through photographs, the Prague of 1883, when Kafka was born. At that time it was a city where three cultures -- Czech, German and German-speaking Jewish -- coexisted in often anxious harmony. Among the literary works in the show is a copy of the first German edition of Kafka's ''Metamorphosis,'' published in 1915 (above).

title: Fox echoes world on the death penalty : Execution pits Mexico against U.S.
description: WASHINGTON:  The unexpected cancellation by the president of Mexico of his visit to President George W. Bush's Texas ranch  in a blunt objection to the execution of a Mexican national  has given Bush his highest-level indication yet of the breadth and depth of near-global opposition to the death penalty in America.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: TALKS ON BANK STAKE China's second-largest publicly traded lender, the Shanghai Pudong Development Bank Company, said it was in talks to sell a stake to Citibank N.A., joining rivals in seeking foreign capital and expertise to increase its competitiveness. Pudong Bank, which operates 261 branches nationwide, has a market capitalization of 40.8 billion yuan ($4.9 billion), and had 5,743 employees at the end of last year.

title: Firefighters And Police Hold Protest For Raises
description: About 10,000 firefighters and police officers crowded into Times Square yesterday to demand larger raises from the Bloomberg administration, which they said had forgotten the sacrifices they made rushing to fires, cutting crime and responding to the horrors of Sept. 11.

title: A body blow for Bates as Wendy's transfers its U.S. ad business.
description: BATES USA, already reeling from the defections of some crucial advertising clients, lost one of its largest accounts yesterday when Wendy's International announced that it was moving its United States advertising business to the McCann-Erickson World Group.
