title: Corrections
description: The What's Next column in Circuits yesterday, about technologies integrated into the new home of the Weatherhead School of Management at Case Western Reserve University, misstated the cost of the building. It is $61.7 million; $36 million is the amount contributed by the lead donor, Peter B. Lewis.

title: Players Union Is Ready to Set Aug. 30 as the Strike Date
description: In three days of talks since the union's executive board postponed its plan to set a baseball strike date, negotiators for the two sides have not made enough progress for the board to delay a second time. The board is scheduled to have a conference call at 10 a.m. today and is expected to approve Aug. 30 as the date the players will walk out if they do not have a new labor agreement.

title: A City Reimagined: The Metamorphosis of Kafka and His Context
description: ''Prague doesn't let go. Of either of us. This old crone has claws. One has to yield, or else.''

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: CONCERN OVER COASTAL FAULT An earthquake along a newly discovered fault off the southeastern coast of Japan could generate devastating waves, scientists report in the journal Science. The fault, a few dozen miles from land, lies near the boundary where the Philippine sea plate is pushed beneath the Eurasian plate. If the fault slipped, the resulting earthquake could give the seafloor a sudden shove, producing a tsunami that would hit shore within minutes. The scientists believe the fault may have played a role in a magnitude-8.1 earthquake in 1944.    Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: Stock Slide Adds to Fear On Liquidity Of Vivendi
description: Investors dumped Vivendi Universal stock for a second consecutive day today, apparently unconvinced by the announcement on Wednesday that management would try to ease a severe cash squeeze by shedding assets in a $9.8 billion sell-off.

title: Dell Profits Are Up 11% For Quarter
description: The Dell Computer Corporation, continuing its elbows-out assault on the rest of the computer market, announced yesterday that its second-quarter profits had improved and product shipments had increased at a time when other computer makers are suffering.

title: The Culture of Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Boat Reimbursement Ends
description: The Insignia Financial Group, New York's biggest property broker, will no longer reimburse its chief executive, Andrew Farkas, for the company's use of his personal boat, and will stop paying for a plane he co-owns by Sept. 30, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: It's All About Artifice (and Croons and Growls)
description: Mike Patton is, to use the rapper Rakim's phrase, a microphone fiend. With his band Tomahawk at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night, he was using four microphones, though there could have been more: two were freestanding; one was from a police-radio system; one was stuck through some sort of gas mask.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: GENUITY GETS EXTENSION TO RENEGOTIATE CREDIT LINE Genuity, a seller of high-speed Internet access that defaulted last month on $3 billion in loans, says lenders have given it 30 more days to renegotiate the credit line. As part of the "standstill" agreement, the second since July 29, Genuity will pay $50 million, according to a statement. The company also said it would no longer finance Integra , a manager of data for corporate Web sites that is 93 percent owned by Genuity. Last month, Verizon Communications chose not to buy a controlling stake in Genuity, causing a default under the company's credit agreement. The new accord gives Genuity time to renegotiate repayment of the loans. Genuity, based in Woburn, Mass., has drawn down $1.87 billion of a $2 billion credit line from banks, as well as a $1.15 billion loan from Verizon, a spokeswoman, Susan Kraus, said. Verizon had made $2 billion available, but it said last month that it would not extend the remaining $850 million, Ms. Kraus said. On July 29, Genuity said it had been given two weeks to renegotiate its credit line. Under that agreement, Genuity paid $100 million.

title: Diane Lipton, 57, Champion of the Disabled
description: Diane J. Lipton, who fought for the rights of her disabled daughter and went on to become a lawyer and prominent advocate for children with disabilities, died on Aug. 8 at her home in Richmond, Calif. She was 57.

title: An Execution in Texas Strains Ties With Mexico and Others
description: The decision by President Vicente Fox of Mexico to cancel a meeting with President Bush at his Texas ranch after the execution, in that state, of a Mexican citizen on Wednesday is the latest confrontation over the death penalty between the United States and some of its closest allies.

title: California's G.O.P. Candidate for Governor Cuts Staff and Hires Heavyweights
description: With his campaign for governor of California in desperate need of money, Bill Simon Jr. has dismissed almost a third of his staff and hired a pair of longtime political consultants to improve his chances against the Democratic incumbent, Gov. Gray Davis.

title: Judge Delays Order to Identify Detainees Until Appeals Ruling
description: Two weeks after a federal judge ordered the Justice Department to reveal the names of hundreds of people detained in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the same judge ruled today that the names did not have to be made public immediately.

description: EURO RISES. The dollar fell after a Federal Reserve report showed Philadelphia-area manufacturing contracted this month. In New York, the euro settled at 98.31 cents, up from 98.14 cents on Wednesday.

description: Events

title: Maybe It's Time to Call on the Rain Gods
description: The groundskeepers at Fox Hopyard Golf Club in East Haddam, Conn., have started praying -- only partly in jest -- to a wooden rain-god statue the club superintendent brought back from Mexico.

title: Through Hot Pink Glasses, a World That's Nice
description: IF life were everything it should be -- that is, if life were more like the endearing new musical called ''Hairspray'' that opened last night at the Neil Simon Theater -- your every waking thought would be footnoted by a chorus of backup singers of early 60's vintage. You know, the kind who always come up with helpful bons mots like ''ow-oot'' and ''bop-be-ba, ba-ba-ba-ba,'' whether the lead singer's heart is breaking or quaking.

title: Woods In Good Position
description: As erratic as Tiger Woods was with his driver, he was delighted to finish his first round just three strokes off the lead.

title: Downs and Ups Of a Top Prospect
description: JACKSON MELIAN has gone from high-profile signing to Baseball America Top 100 prospect to major disappointment. All this by the ripe old age of 22. That can happen when the Yankees trot you out as a free-agent signing when you are only 16.

title: Teardrops of Joy For Campers Who Don't Mind Small Spaces
description: MICHAEL CADY is 6 foot 8, but he learned long ago to tolerate small spaces. After he and his wife, Madeline, were married 22 years ago, they lived in a 525-square-foot efficiency apartment. Now they vacation in 32 square feet -- the living space in their teardrop trailer. And, he says, he loves it.

title: After the Bubble: Are Low Rates Enough?
description: ''While bubbles that burst are scarcely benign, the consequences need not be catastrophic for the economy. The bursting of the Japanese bubble a decade ago did not lead immediately to sharp contractions in output or a significant rise in unemployment. Arguably, it was the subsequent failure to address the damage to the financial system in a timely manner that caused Japan's current economic problems. Likewise, while the stock market crash of 1929 was destabilizing, most analysts attribute the Great Depression to ensuing failures of policy.'' Alan Greenspan, June 1999

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Same-Sex Partnership Advances
description: The city could soon formally recognize the domestic partnerships of gay couples who have legally registered in other locations, under a bill passed yesterday by the City Council. The measure, sponsored by Councilwoman Christine Quinn of Manhattan, right, passed after a contentious session by a vote of 34 to 7, with 4 abstentions. The Council also unanimously approved a bill that would regulate the number and placement of newspaper boxes on sidewalks. A third bill, drafted in response to the Father's Day 2001 explosion in Queens that killed three firefighters, was also unanimously approved. That bill would require merchants to install sprinklers where flammable materials are stored below ground. All three bills are expected to be signed into law by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Con Ed and Albany in Accord On Cleanup of Dozens of Sites
description: Consolidated Edison reached an agreement yesterday with state environmental regulators to clean up the sites of as many as 45 former fuel plants and storage facilities, including several that are now home to schools, hospitals, office towers and apartment buildings.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker To Build Factory In China
description: In a move that indicates a major expansion into Asian markets, the chip maker National Semiconductor said yesterday that it would build its first integrated circuit manufacturing factory in China, in Jiangsu Province, about 50 miles west of Shanghai. The company, which makes semiconductors for computers, cellphones and other electronic devices, said it had signed a memorandum of understanding to lease 36 acres in the Suzhou Industrial Park, a joint project of China and Singapore. Construction of the factory, which will eventually employ 500 people, is expected to begin in November and be completed in 2004. National Semiconductor, based in Santa Clara, Calif., expects to invest up to $200 million for the factory and personnel during the next five years. The company's shares rose 88 cents, to $17.70. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: NASD Suspends 2 Executives Of First Boston
description: Securities industry regulators said yesterday that they would fine and suspend two senior executives of Credit Suisse First Boston who directed the firm's collection of millions of dollars in inflated commissions from buyers of shares in sought-after new stock offerings.

description: Rumsfeld on Afghan Aid

title: For W.T.O.'s Next Chief, A Long List of Headaches
description: Supachai Panitchpakdi, a soft-spoken Thai economist, has been a passionate chess player since he took up the game as a teenager. Starting next month, he will give those tactical skills a good workout when he becomes director general of the World Trade Organization, a fractious lot of countries all pledged to the same end -- global free trade -- but always divided over how to achieve it.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Disparity In Broadcasting Salaries
description: Television and radio broadcasters on Spanish-language stations in Los Angeles are typically paid less than half the salary of those on English-speaking stations, a study at the University of California Los Angeles has found. The Center for the Study of Urban Poverty at the university said the median salary for broadcasters on Spanish television in Los Angeles is $60,000 a year, compared with $200,000 at English-language stations. The disparity is not as large at unionized stations, but few are. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

description: The stories are stirring testaments to the power of getting information out urgently, to mobilizing people across an entire state and beyond to help search for a kidnapped child.

title: What Awaits A Dream Car When Dreams Change?
description: IN the small subset of automobiles that can properly be called American sports cars, the undisputed king is the Corvette. The original two-seater Thunderbird, which had a good run but wasn't made after 1957, was not really a sports car; today's successor isn't either. The Dodge Viper, a challenger since 1991, has not reached Corvette-level appeal or sales. The AC Cobra, now a beloved collectors' car, flashed in and flamed out in the 60's. The Corvette endures -- 32,000 made every year, 32,000 sold every year. Those who love the Corvette love it fanatically.

description: An Indonesian human rights court today acquitted six military and police officials of crimes against humanity in East Timor after a pro-independence vote three years ago, a verdict that did not please the Bush administration as it seeks to rebuild military ties here.

title: Slumping Liberty Is Ready for Playoffs
description: This is not how the Liberty wanted to enter the playoffs: losing three consecutive games at home and four of its last six games of the regular season. Having played six games in nine days, the Liberty was a tired team, and it showed.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BEA Shares Rise On Strong Results
description: The shares of BEA Systems rose as much as 15 percent yesterday after the software maker's second-quarter results showed the company had held off its rival, I.B.M., analysts said. BEA shares rose 36 cents, to close at $6.12 in Nasdaq Stock Market trading, after rising as high as $6.64. They had fallen 63 percent this year. Contract awards indicated that BEA was not losing market share to I.B.M., the world's second-biggest software maker, as some investors had thought before BEA issued results yesterday for the quarter ended July 31, analysts said. BEA said about 210 customers chose its software over I.B.M. programs during the quarter, including 32 customers who replaced I.B.M. with BEA.

title: Grenada Resort
description: Laluna, a 16-cottage resort on the Caribbean island of Grenada, is offering seven nights for the price of six and 14 nights for the price of 12 through Sept. 30. Rates start at $270 a night (for two people) for one-bedroom cottages with private plunge pools, air-conditioning, VCR's and bathrooms that look out onto the sea. Meals are extra. Please refer to booking code 6/02 or 12/02. Information: (866) 452-5862 or www.laluna.com .

description: In ''Blue Crush,'' Kate Bosworth, above, stars as the best female surfer on Oahu as she tries to make a tournament comeback after a near-drowning. The film, directed by John Stockwell, opens today nationwide.

On Tuesday the best of his films, ''Pulp Fiction,'' and definitely not the best, ''Jackie Brown,'' are to be released in special editions by Miramax. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: An Insurer's Assuring Words
description: Swiss Life, Switzerland's largest insurer, reassured customers and investors -- for the second time in three weeks -- that it has enough money to cover claims and continue operations despite the ''current difficult environment.'' The company, which is based in Zurich, is also urging Swiss lawmakers to approve a 1 percent cut in the mandatory 4 percent return on pensions, citing weak market conditions. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Warning Shots on Iraq
description: Brent Scowcroft is a cautious, deliberate man accustomed to sharing his foreign policy views with Republican presidents in private, as he did as national security adviser to Gerald Ford and George H. W. Bush. That Mr. Scowcroft would publicly question the current president on a matter as sensitive as Iraq is an extraordinary challenge to the Bush administration as it weighs whether to go to war to oust Saddam Hussein from power. Mr. Scowcroft's concerns about attacking Iraq, aired yesterday in an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal, were the equivalent of a cannon shot across the White House lawn. The piece should erase any doubt about the need for a national debate on Iraq.

title: Struggling Poles Have Little to Cheer Besides Pope
description: As Henryk Banak loitered moodily next to his tractor, scowling off and on at the distant towers of a grain elevator, nothing seemed to soothe his ill temper.

title: Bullish Analyst Of Tech Stocks Quits Salomon
description: Jack Grubman, the beleaguered telecommunications analyst who was once among the most powerful figures on Wall Street, resigned from Salomon Smith Barney yesterday by what the firm described as ''mutual agreement.''

title: Larry Rivers, Artist With an Edge, Dies at 78
description: Larry Rivers, the irreverent proto-Pop painter and sculptor, jazz saxophonist, writer, poet, teacher and sometime actor and filmmaker, whose partly self-mocking bad-boy persona encapsulated the spirit of a restless era that shook up American art, died on Wednesday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Percy Sutton's Company Loses 'It's Showtime at the Apollo'
description: A company controlled by Percy Sutton, the former Manhattan borough president, has lost the right to produce ''It's Showtime at the Apollo,'' a weekly televised amateur talent show that was at the center of a legal battle over the management of the landmark Harlem theater, Apollo officials said yesterday.

title: With Low-Key Race, McCall Is Now Seen Leading Cuomo
description: H. Carl McCall has become a strong front-runner in the race for the Democratic nomination for governor, according to several Democratic Party strategists and a major poll released today, even though Andrew M. Cuomo has waged an aggressive campaign.

title: PATENT OFFICE IS REVIEWING CHIRON CANCER TREATMENT
description: The Chiron Corporation's patent for a breast cancer treatment is being reviewed by the Patent and Trademark Office as the company and Genentech Inc. fight over the patent in court. The patent office said it was reviewing whether Chiron was the first to invent the treatment; the University of Pennsylvania challenged the patent. Chiron's patent can be revoked if the patent office determines that the university came up with the idea first. Chiron sued Genentech for patent infringement in 2000, saying Genentech's Herceptin drug uses Chiron's invention. Genentech is the exclusive licensee of the university's technology and says the Chiron patent is not valid.

title: Rival Parties Join in Bid to Defeat Musharraf
description: Pakistan's two largest political parties announced tonight that rather than compete with each other in parliamentary elections they would instead join to focus on defeating a coalition of small parties backing the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

title: Eleanor McCollum, 93, Texas Fund-Raiser
description: Eleanor Searle Whitney McCollum, a singer and a philanthropist in the fields of medicine, music and religion, died Aug. 12 at her home in Houston. She was 93.

title: 3 Women Do Their Own Heavy Lifting
description: When Charlie Kate dislikes you, she doesn't fool around. She despises her sleazy, womanizing son-in-law so much, for instance, that she delivers her daughter's baby on the porch. Having vowed never to set foot inside the house as long as the son-in-law is alive, she's not making an exception now.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about churches that accept donations by credit card and other electronic means included an erroneous reference to church policy from an official of the Southern Baptist Convention. The convention's executive committee said it had no official position on electronic donations. It has not barred such donations at member churches, nor does it have the authority to do so.

title: Seeing Beauty In Rocks
description: The Chinese look at unusual, highly textured hunks of stone the way Westerners gaze at billowing white clouds in a summer sky: as sources of inspiration and fantasy. For those with imagination, rocks can embody animals, people, mythological dragons, craggy mountains, just about anything.

title: Altitude-Training Room Aids Khannouchi
description: The town of Ossining in Westchester County sits from 6 to 200 feet above sea level. Khalid Khannouchi's bedroom in Ossining, or at least the air in it, is 12,000 feet above sea level.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: U.S. APOLOGY The United States has apologized to Italy after three American military helicopters swooped low over a crowded Italian beach on Tuesday, sending beach furniture flying and injuring five people. The two nations will jointly investigate the incident. The incident, in the southeastern town of Barletta, touched off Italian memories of a 1998 incident, in which a low-flying Marine jet sliced the cables of a ski gondola on an Italian mountainside, killing 20 people.    (AP)

title: 36 Hours | Prince Edward Island
description: FOR decades, tiny Prince Edward Island (population 138,000) has been a recreational haven for Canadians. But why should Canadians have all the fun? Prince Edward Island has all the charm of New England without Cape Cod's long lines and high prices. Since the Confederation Bridge opened in 1997, linking Borden-Carleton on the island with Cape Jourimain on the New Brunswick mainland, tourists have been able to visit without worrying about ferry schedules. Prince Edward Island is a land of undeniable yet simple charms, most of which are maritime because you are never more than 10 miles from salt water. The Malpeque oysters are famous, and thanks to the flow of the Gulf Stream the island's beaches are far more swimmable than those in northern New England. And while public signs will help refresh your high school French, English is spoken everywhere. The strong United States dollar (worth $1.56 Canadian at current exchange rates) is almost universally accepted. JAMES LEDBETTER

title: Cots Can't Solve a Homeless Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Says Lag in Aid Has Stymied Afghans
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld expressed frustration today at the slow pace of building viable government institutions in Afghanistan, largely blaming other nations for a lag in international donations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Immigration Scheme Reported
description: The Suffolk County district attorney yesterday announced the breakup of an immigration scheme to obtain green cards for permanent residency through false marriages. The district attorney, Thomas J. Spota, said more arrests might come. The ring was discovered when a county clerk noticed that the same American woman had married nearly a dozen immigrant men. Mr. Spota said the grooms, most of them from Nigeria, Trinidad, Grenada and Guyana, paid about $4,000 each. Among those arrested were William Baptiste, 63, of Brooklyn, who was accused of recruiting immigrant men, and Sheri Rudd, 36, also of Brooklyn, who was accused of recruiting American women. Also involved, Mr. Spota said, was a former Hempstead village justice, Lawrence J. Goldstein, who is expected to surrender to federal authorities in Islip. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: So He's Famous. Give Him a Break, if Not a Free Ride.
description: ASH WEDNESDAY

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Court Bars Priest's Suit
description: The state's highest court ruled that a defrocked Episcopal priest could not sue the church in slander, overturning a lower court's ruling. The unanimous decision, citing the First Amendment, ruled that the courts may not interpret internal disciplinary procedures or canon law. James Hiles, a priest at the Church of our Savior in Milton, was suspended in 1996 after a parishioner, Linda Hastie, claimed she had a sexual relationship with him from 1970 to 1975. Mr. Hiles sued in 1996, claiming the publicity had damaged his reputation. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Red Zone Is Where Becht Adds a Lift
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 15  The other tight end in town is getting all the attention, understandable for a first-round draft pick whose new teammates have called him the potential savior of the offense.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charges Involving Sex At Cathedral
description: A man and a woman having sex in a side entrance to St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon were arrested and charged with public lewdness, and a third person was arrested as he was recording them, the police said. Brian Florence, 37, of Quantico, Va., and Loretta Lynn Harper, 35, of Alexandria, Va., were having sex while Paul Mercurio, 42, of East 87th Street, held a phone nearby, the police said. An anonymous police official told the Associated Press that Mr. Mercurio had been connected by cellphone with ''The Opie and Anthony Show'' on WNEW-FM. A spokesman for the station's parent company declined to comment early today. The incident occurred around 4:45 p.m. Mr. Mercurio was charged with acting in concert. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on June 27 about the writer's search for radiation detection devices misstated the usefulness of potassium iodide in an emergency. While the drug could offer protection after an accident at a nuclear power plant, by blocking the thyroid's absorption of radioactive iodine isotopes, experts say it would probably not be helpful in a terrorist attack involving a crude radiological weapon -- a ''dirty bomb'' -- because such a weapon would most likely rely on other radioactive material. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Sports of The Times; Playing at Hazeltine Is a Unique Experience
description: THE nature of golf is nature itself heat, chill, sun, wind, rain, thunder and lightning, creeks and ponds, trees, even the type of grass in the rough.

title: U.S., Protesting Rights Leader's Sentence, Halts New Aid to Egypt
description: President Bush has warned President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that the United States will not deliver any new aid to Egypt in protest against the prosecution of a leading human rights activist, the White House said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ex-Terror Suspect Sentenced In Fraud
description: A man who came under intense government scrutiny after he was arrested with a box cutter a day after the Sept. 11 terror attack was sentenced yesterday for conspiracy to commit credit card fraud. The man, Syed Gul Mohammed Shah, was sentenced to one year and one day in prison. An Indian national, he faces deportation after completing his sentence. He was arrested with another man, Mohammed Jaweed Azmath, after they were found on a train carrying box cutters and about $5,000 in cash. Both men were cleared of terrorist links, but they both pleaded guilty in a credit card fraud scheme. A federal judge ordered Mr. Shah to pay restitution of about $415,000 in connection with the scheme. Mr. Azmath faces sentencing next month. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: How to Mark Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Dysfunction?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Mystery Writer

title: In Stamford, Order for a Courthouse Is Finally Filled
description: A generation has passed since state officials first started talking about an urgent need to build a new courthouse in Stamford. For the better part of two decades, judges, lawyers and court employees have complained about the dilapidated court buildings on Hoyt Street -- the overcrowding, the leaky roofs, the stench from sewage backups in the basements.

title: Better Animal Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: At Russian River, Gay Campers Find They Are Not Alone
description: THIS is the sixth summer that Joe Selph and Marty Bracciotti have gone camping together. Over the years they have made the rounds of the traditional spots -- the Grand Canyon, Yosemite, Bryce Canyon -- pitching a tent, cooking outdoors, hiking mountain trails. But the two men have decided that Fife's, a 15-acre camping resort in the lower Russian River Valley, a 90-minute drive north of San Francisco, is probably more their kind of place.

title: Ex-Executive Convicted of Fraud
description: The former chief financial officer of Media Vision Technology, Steven J. Allan, was convicted today of fraud for helping to inflate the company's 1993 financial results.

title: 25 Years Later, Elvis Rolls On
description: In death as in life, Elvis Presley has something for everybody. Twenty-five years after he died of a drug overdose in his bathroom at Graceland, on Aug. 16, 1977, he is still a charismatic figure, as widely recognized as a president or a Coca-Cola logo. And he is still ripe for admiration and exploitation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Equipment Layoffs
description: Fujitsu Ltd. will eliminate 2,100 jobs at four locations in Japan and consider shutting one factory as it adjusts to the slump in demand for telecommunications equipment. Fujitsu, Japan's largest maker of business computers, will offer early retirement packages to the affected employees, who make up 1.2 percent of the company's work force. Last year, Fujitsu cut 17,000 jobs, mostly overseas. The latest round of layoffs will hit factories that make printed circuit boards used in communications equipment. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Poles Greet Pope in Cracow on His 9th Visit to Homeland
description: Poles welcomed Pope John Paul II on his ninth visit to his homeland today against a backdrop of continuing speculation that because of ill health this might be his last trip abroad, and continuing denials by the Vatican.

title: For Harlem Little Leaguers, the Call Is 'Play Ball!'
description: After 30 hours of discussion over two days, Little League officials announced this evening that they had exonerated a team from Harlem of charges that three of its players were ineligible and thus cleared the way for the team to play in the Little League World Series.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Sticker Shock Over Court Project
description: A legislative committee has balked at appropriating an additional $1 million for the new home of the State Supreme Court. The state is converting an office building in the French Quarter of New Orleans, and the cost of the project had already risen to $40 million, from $30 million. Work on the project has gone on intermittently since 1981. Court officials said the additional money would come from a surplus in the court's budget and would cover items cut from previous plans.

title: DDB Corbett Gets Jobs at Novartis
description: Novartis said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with DDB Corbett, the health care unit of the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, by selecting the agency to handle advertising for its over-the-counter cold remedies TheraFlu and Triaminic from its Novartis consumer health unit. Spending was estimated at $20 million.

title: The Only Flag the Mets Can Raise Is a White One
description: Vance Wilson stepped out of the Mets' dugout at five minutes past noon yesterday, wiped his wet brow with the wrist band on his right arm and slid his palm across the dirt. Wilson, catching in place of the injured Mike Piazza, came out to play catch before the Mets took the field and he already looked spent.

title: Economic Havoc From European Floods
description: Insurers and analysts have already begun to tally the economic impact of the rains and flooding in Central Europe, even as the floodwaters continue to surge downstream and burst the banks of rivers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You bet my players noticed those new uniforms -- of course they saw what was going on. I told them, 'Not yet.' And now I'm going to go tell them to celebrate this joyous news.''

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Spy Kids 2: Island of Lost Dreams

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FEDERAL SIGNAL, Oak Brook, Ill., a maker of vehicles and equipment, said it was buying Wittke, Calgary, Alberta, and Leach, Oshkosh, Wis., both makers of waste-hauling vehicles, for at least $79.4 million.

title: China Prosecutes a Banker As Loan Scandals Continue
description: The Chinese government announced today that it would bring corruption charges against a former top banker, Zhu Xiaohua. He becomes the most prominent corporate leader to face charges of criminal malfeasance in China since the country began its move toward a market-based economy two decades ago.

title: New Video Releases
description: Birthday Girl

title: Antiterror Chief Quits F.B.I., Which Gets New Deputy
description: The F.B.I.'s counterterrorism chief, who has overseen the investigations of the Sept. 11 terror attacks and last year's deadly anthrax mailings, has decided to retire, with no replacement yet chosen, the bureau said today.

title: AMTRAK SIDELINES MORE LOCOMOTIVES BECAUSE OF DEFECT
description: Amtrak's equipment problems grew today to include locomotives for slower trains that had not been affected by its suspension of the high-speed Acela Express service this week, and the railroad said the few Acela trains it had previously found to be crack-free were damaged, too.

title: Bush vs. Women
description: The central moral struggle of the 19th century concerned slavery, and that of the 20th pitted democracy against Nazism, Communism and other despotic isms. Our own pre-eminent moral challenge will be to ease the brutality that kills and maims girls and women across much of Africa and Asia.

title: Experts Expect Rapid Rise In West Nile Virus Cases
description: The number of cases of West Nile fever is expected to rise sharply in the next week and could eventually reach 1,000, federal health officials said yesterday. If the current epidemic reflects experience, about 10 percent of the cases will be fatal.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trizec Names Chief
description: One of North America's biggest real estate investment trusts, Trizec Properties Inc., named Timothy H. Callahan as president and chief executive, replacing Christopher Mackenzie, left. Trizec, which is controlled by the Canadian entrepreneur Peter Munk, and manages the Sears Tower in Chicago, said Mr. Mackenzie had left ''to pursue other interests.'' Mr. Callahan was previously chief executive of Equity Office Properties Trust, based in Chicago. Trizec also named Casey Wold as chief operating officer, a new position. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: An Arafat Aide Blames Hamas for Thwarting Efforts to Form a Palestinian Unity Platform
description: A senior lieutenant to Yasir Arafat said today that the militant Hamas organization had blocked all efforts in recent days to forge a unified Palestinian stand on suicide attacks and statehood.

title: Measuring Downtown's Future
description: In the 1950's, every city planning commission had its ''vision for the year 2020.'' The frontispieces of urban plans across America showed towers, beautiful and ethereal, rising from the city. Ten years later, these images were sarcastically called ''perfect vision'' plans. The reality they became -- the urban renewal projects of the 50's and 60's -- forcefully discredited the old Cities of the Future. Now, as we consider the future of the World Trade Center site, we are confronted, once again, with perfect-vision plans. One irony is that they are intended to replace what was itself one of the last urban renewal projects of the 1960's.

title: Despite Victory, Jets Have Questions
description: The Jets staged a magnificent goal-line stand against Jerome Bettis and the Steelers last week, and they are piling up points like so many Christmas presents under a tree.

title: Cots Can't Solve a Homeless Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Add Offensive Tackle To Giants' Shopping List
description: The Giants send at least one scout to every preseason game in the National Football League, and often their work is long-range stuff, a look ahead to the 2003 season. But this month the Giants almost certainly have an all-points bulletin out for an offensive tackle, and their scouts will be scouring fields for someone who can be acquired in a trade or claimed on waivers before the start of the regular season.

title: Cots Can't Solve a Homeless Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Chaffee Whitaker, 73, Tennis Player
description: Nancy Chaffee Whitaker, a leading tennis player in the 1950's who won three consecutive national indoor championships, died Sunday in Coronado, Calif. She was 73 and lived in Indian Wells, Calif.

title: Love, Italian Style, but, Oh, Such Complications
description: One of Italy's highest-grossing films for 2000, Gabriele Muccino's ''Last Kiss,'' was promoted there as ''the story of all love stories.'' The picture does do its best to be inclusive: it interweaves three different tales of three different generations trapped in three different situations -- which means, of course, that it can be marketed to three different demographics. Thus are nations united.

title: Tuxedo Park Opens the Gates, Just a Bit
description: THERE used to be a long list of dreamy, secluded places that immediately conjured up romantic visions of old money and big houses: Newport, Bar Harbor, Hot Springs, Tuxedo Park.

title: Poetical Flesh and Blood Proves a Strong Tonic
description: For some readers of ''Possession,'' A. S. Byatt's Booker Prize-winning 1990 novel, the long stretches of mock-Victorian poetry were the high points; for others, Ms. Byatt's virtuoso parodies of Robert Browning, Christina Rossetti and Emily Dickinson were there to be skipped over, since they slowed down enjoyment of her teasingly suspenseful mlange of historical sleuthing, academic intrigue and breathless, old-fashioned romance. The new film adaptation of ''Possession,'' directed by Neil LaBute, is likely to appeal to the second group of readers, since Mr. LaBute has wisely kept on-screen recitation to a minimum and completely omitted reference to ''Ask to Embla,'' the mythopoetic magnum opus that functions in the novel as a kind of Rosetta stone of secret, literary love.

title: Ewing Agrees to Buyout As Retirement Looms
description: Patrick Ewing moved closer to retirement yesterday when he accepted a buyout from the Orlando Magic. Ewing, who received the majority of the about $2 million left on his two-year contract, has not decided whether he will try to play an 18th N.B.A. season, the Magic said.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: How to Say Lemur and Quidditch in 11 Languages
description: THE screen saver photograph on Eleanor Sterling's computer is not of children or pets but an aerial view of a deserted, heavily forested island off the coast of northeast Madagascar.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Conviction In Home Invasion
description: A Westchester County jury convicted Michael Williams, 39, of the Bronx, of second-degree murder yesterday for his role in the fatal shooting of a clothing store owner, Sary Igbara, during a robbery at Mr. Igbara's home in Tarrytown in April 2001. Prosecutors said that Mr. Williams was the mastermind, while two other men posed as telephone repairmen to enter Mr. Igbara's home. The robbers fled with more than $7,000 but were later arrested. The two other men pleaded guilty to murder charges earlier this year. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: YUM BRANDS RAISES PROFIT FORECAST FOR THIRD QUARTER
description: Yum Brands Inc., owner of KFC and Pizza Hut fast-food restaurants, said yesterday that it was increasing its third-quarter profit forecast because of rising sales at its overseas restaurants and at its Taco Bell chain. Profit excluding some costs will rise to the high end of its estimates of 45 to 47 cents a share in the quarter ending Sept. 7, Yum Brands said. The company earned $124 million, or 41 cents, in the period last year. Yum Brands, which in May changed its name from Tricon Global Restaurants, said sales at Taco Bell restaurants open at least a year rose 10 percent in the four weeks ended Aug. 10. International sales have climbed 13 percent this quarter.

title: Dark Days For Ethics Of All Stripes
description: EVERY now and then, we get to see public officials wrestling with moral conundrums. This is one of those times, and it is a reminder of how political ethics can amount sometimes to an oxymoron. (Some would say the same of journalistic ethics, but let them get their own column.)

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Bush Appeals for His Domestic Security Plan Over Democrats'
description: President Bush placed himself against the backdrop of one of the United States' most famous monuments today to press for Senate approval of a new Department of Homeland Security, even as Senator Tom Daschle, the Democrat from South Dakota who has stood in the way of the president's version of the plan, sat right up in front.

title: Fast Train to Nowhere
description: David Gunn, the man credited with turning around the New York City subway system in the 1980's, has found an equally daunting challenge. Amtrak, which he has led since May, seems to have cornered the market on self-inflicted debacles this year. Just as passenger rail traffic was soaring in the wake of the Sept. 11 airliner hijackings, Amtrak suffered two nasty derailments and the sidelining of its brand-new fleet of high-speed trains. The setbacks, coming at a time when the railroad's future hinges on an upcoming budget showdown in Congress, are serious, and sorely test the patience of even the most fervent supporters of rail travel. But it would be a mistake for the country to give up on the development of a smoothly running passenger rail system to relieve transportation congestion on the East and West Coasts.

title: Gold-Standard Endorsement
description: For the first time in their long, parallel careers, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is featured in a campaign advertisement for Gov. George E. Pataki. This 30-second advertisement began to be broadcast statewide yesterday.

title: D.J. Sutherland, 71, Chief of Buyout Firm
description: Donald J. Sutherland, the founder and chief executive of Quincy Partners of Glen Head, N.Y., one of the first leveraged buyout firms, died on Sunday at his home in Glen Head. He was 71.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bioscrypt Excels In Fingerprint Technology Tests
description: Bioscrypt said yesterday that it had won 19 of 24 categories in a test of speed and accuracy of fingerprint identification technologies sponsored by the United States National Biometric Test Center and two university laboratories. Bioscrypt, based in Toronto, said that it finished second among the 31 entrants in the other five categories. The results were reported on Wednesday at the International Conference on Pattern Recognition in Quebec. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: RWANDA: GENOCIDE SUSPECT A senior Rwandan military commander was transferred to the international criminal tribunal in Tanzania after his arrest in Angola. The suspect, Augustin Bizimungu, led the Rwandan Army in 1994, when Hutu extremists killed an estimated 800,000 Tutsis and Hutu moderates. He faces 10 counts of genocide and crimes against humanity including rape and extermination.    (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Loss At Shipping Venture
description: Shares of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company fell 7 percent, after a venture jointly owned by P.&O. and Koninklijke Nedlloyd of the Netherlands, reported a second-quarter loss and said it expected to lose money for the entire year. The venture, P&O Nedlloyd, reported a pretax loss of $61 million, in contrast to a pretax profit of $32 million a year earlier. The company said a 13 percent rise in shipping volumes in the second quarter was not enough to offset a 15 percent decline in rates. ''For the market as a whole there is continuing pressure from increasing supply,'' the company said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Internet Bumbling In the Ivy League
description: To the Editor:

title: An Evening With a Scent From the Past
description: One of the indisputable charms of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo is the way this all-male troupe plunges the viewer back into the glory days of ballet. The dear old stars would be left in the dust if forced to compete technically with the dancers of today. But they had an allure that is largely missing now. And the Trocks, as they are affectionately known, brought back that perfume on Wednesday night in the company's second program at the Joyce Theater.

title: Cardinal Egan Defends Record In Abuse Cases
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan yesterday defended his handling of priest sexual abuse cases while he was bishop of Bridgeport and said his leadership of the New York archdiocese during the past seven months of crisis was not getting the credit it deserved.

title: Prague Floodwaters Drain Into Elbe
description: Prague emerged sodden and paralyzed today as the worst floods in its recorded history drained from buildings and poured down the Vltava River and into the Elbe.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: IOMEGA INTRODUCES REMOVABLE STORAGE DRIVE The Iomega Corporation, a maker of portable data storage devices, announced yesterday the availability of its new Zip removable storage drive. The third generation of the company's Zip drive can hold 750 megabytes of data, triple the capacity of the previous Zip drive, with double the maximum data transfer rate, the company said. The Zip 750 megabyte drive is available with a USB 2.0 interface; this fall, Iomega said, it plans to release a FireWire version of the drive. As a method for backing up and transferring data between computers, Iomega's Zip product competes with CD burners, which typically can save 700 megabytes of data on a CD.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: The Fabric Of the Past

title: Phelps and Vendt Break World Record
description: Just before Michael Phelps and Erik Vendt went out to compete in the 400-meter individual medley final at the National Swimming Championships last night, Vendt said to Phelps, ''Let's give the crowd a good show.''

title: The Leisure Class in Rarely Heard Rossini
description: With its blocky hotels and beaches lined with deck chairs, the Adriatic coast here is Italy's answer to the Jersey shore. Inland, it's a different story: narrow streets, a beautiful small 19th-century theater and a two-week festival devoted to the town's most famous son, Gioachino Rossini.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York City's increasing hostility to smoking referred incompletely to the situation at McSorley's Old Ale House, a smoker-friendly redoubt in the East Village. While it indeed forgoes ashtrays in favor of the sawdust on the floor, souvenir ashtrays are for sale. (The one shown in the picture was being used by a waiter.)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: BarnesandNoble.com Receives A Delisting Warning
description: BarnesandNoble.com said it had received a delisting warning from the Nasdaq on Aug. 6, after 30 days during which its stock traded below $1. According to a filing by the company on Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, ''the delisting of the company's common stock would have a significant adverse effect on the stock's liquidity.'' As a so-called national market Nasdaq company, BarnesandNoble.com will have a 90-day grace period, during which it can avoid delisting if its stock closes above $1 on any day. If the stock does not reach that level, the company will be granted a hearing, and it can appeal the delisting. Marie Toulantis, the company's chief executive, said: ''Business is on track, but the market's a disaster. We just have to keep focusing on the business, and, hopefully, the market will follow.'' Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Mark Battista was named senior partner and management director, overseeing the ThermaSilk account, at the New York office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. He had been vice president and account director for the Pizza Hut account at the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: BANK DROPS SALE OF UNIT The fourth-biggest German bank, Commerzbank, has decided not to sell the Jupiter International Group, its British asset management unit, because it could not get the price it wanted. It now intends to keep Jupiter within the Commerzbank Group for the long term, the bank said. Commerzbank reaffirmed its plans to sell Montgomery Asset Management, which is based in San Francisco.

title: Accounts
description: * Sean John Clothing, New York, to Blue Flame Marketing and Advertising, New York, a division of Bad Boy Entertainment, as its first agency of record. Spending was estimated at less than $5 million. Sean Combs leads both Sean John and Blue Flame.

title: Mississippi Floods Drain Life From River Towns
description: The only sound in this flat green settlement on the Mississippi River is the whisper of leaves. Just off the Grande Rue, at a shrine beside the abandoned rectory of the gothic brick Immaculate Conception Church, visitors press a green button on a wall to look inside. An automated door swings open to reveal a view of the Liberty Bell of the West. No one is in there.

title: Low-Cost Airlines Push Forward As Their Larger Rivals Cut Back
description: As full-service airlines cut flights in coming months, they will create the kind of opportunity that in the past has allowed low-cost carriers to steal passengers.

title: Mayor's Style Is Tested in Sending Homeless to Old Jail
description: The most crucial decisions that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg makes -- from policies to appointments -- he does in consultation with a few aides, and usually with little regard to politics or public relations. He often appears to believe that the best answer to a problem is anything that has not been tried before.

title: Sports of The Times; After Long Nights, A Look to the Future
description: THERE'S not a lot that makes me toss and turn at night, but the last 48 hours have been harrowing. This business about Harlem Little League has been an intense, emotional roller coaster ride.

title: Jamal Lewis Returns to a Team That Has Lost Its Swagger
description: Jamal Lewis ran out of the tunnel at Ravens Stadium tonight and did not stop until a sea of familiar purple jerseys surrounded him. Lewis, the Baltimore Ravens' running back with a surgically repaired left knee, then jogged to the sideline to wait for his first carry in a game since Super Bowl XXXV in January 2000.

title: Pool Play: Swimming With Sharks
description: THERE are many things to do in a pool, and the least of these may be swimming. How about floating on a soft, foam-cushioned two-cup-holder chair while watching a couple of realistic-looking sharks race to the end of the pool? Or paddling through chlorinated waters armed with two water pistols? Or a game of serious basketball where both ball and players get slam-dunked?

title: Wall St. Firms at Risk of Credit-Rating Cuts
description: Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and J. P. Morgan Chase, suffering from slumping investment banking revenue, may have their credit ratings lowered by Standard & Poor's.

title: After the Storm, Funk and Furyk Shine
description: In the year's first three major championships, Jim Furyk played poorly, while Fred Funk did not play at all.

title: Ready for My Backup
description: Twisting, stretching and the most masterful use of mirrors still leave blind spots for the driver backing up. So why not a video monitor putting the rear view up front? Nissan has introduced the first such system, but it's still a luxury item, part of an $8,000 package of extras in the Infiniti Q45, a $50,000 car.

title: Mind the Gap
description: How much has Japan's economy shrunk since its bubble burst? It's a trick question; Japan's economy hasn't shrunk. It had only two down years over the past decade, and on average it grew 1 percent per year.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Genuity Gets Extension To Renegotiate Credit Line
description: Genuity, a seller of high-speed Internet access that defaulted last month on $3 billion in loans, says lenders have given it 30 more days to renegotiate the credit line. As part of the ''standstill'' agreement, the second since July 29, Genuity will pay $50 million, according to a statement. The company also said it would no longer finance Integra, a manager of data for corporate Web sites that is 93 percent owned by Genuity. Last month, Verizon Communications chose not to buy a controlling stake in Genuity, causing a default under the company's credit agreement. The new accord gives Genuity time to renegotiate repayment of the loans. Genuity, based in Woburn, Mass., has drawn down $1.87 billion of a $2 billion credit line from banks, as well as a $1.15 billion loan from Verizon, a spokeswoman, Susan Kraus, said. Verizon had made $2 billion available, but it said last month that it would not extend the remaining $850 million, Ms. Kraus said. On July 29, Genuity said it had been given two weeks to renegotiate its credit line. Under that agreement, Genuity paid $100 million.

title: Watching You Watch Them
description: Danny had not been to the Bronx Zoo since he was a boy. He remembered riding camels and elephants and becoming nauseated. He remembered refusing to feed the animals at the Children's Zoo, even though that was allowed. He figured 10 fingers were better than 9.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Iomega Introduces Removable Storage Drive
description: The Iomega Corporation, a maker of portable data storage devices, announced yesterday the availability of its new Zip removable storage drive. The third generation of the company's Zip drive can hold 750 megabytes of data, triple the capacity of the previous Zip drive, with double the maximum data transfer rate, the company said. The Zip 750 megabyte drive is available with a USB 2.0 interface; this fall, Iomega said, it plans to release a FireWire version of the drive. As a method for backing up and transferring data between computers, Iomega's Zip product competes with CD burners, which typically can save 700 megabytes of data on a CD. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: ALPHARMA SAYS F.D.A. IS REQUIRING CHANGES AT A PLANT
description: Alpharma, which makes nasal sprays, bacitracin antibiotic and cold medicines, said yesterday that it would spend about $30 million to make its largest factory meet federal standards. Alpharma will present its plan to the Food and Drug Administration next month. The agency has demanded that the plant, in Baltimore, be improved to meet guidelines, the company said. The improvements will be in place within three years, Alpharma said. The F.D.A. inspected the plant in September and July, the company said. Stock in Alpharma, based in Fort Lee, N.J., fell $1.83, or 17 percent, to $9.01 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Unemployment Rate Drops
description: Fewer people than usual were looking for jobs in July, which led to a drop in the unemployment rate in New York City, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. The drop is due to the way unemployment is measured. Excluded from the measure are people who are not working but not actively looking for work. The smaller number of job seekers led to a drop in the unemployment rate to 7.7 percent from 8 percent in June, after adjustment for seasonal factors. Typically, there is a surge in unemployment in July as young people out of school seek work, but bad economic news may have discouraged some potential job seekers, said James P. Brown, an analyst with the Labor Department. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Records Show Judge's Qualms Over F.B.I. Acts
description: Newly released court documents show that a federal judge in Manhattan briefly considered appointing a special prosecutor to investigate how the F.B.I. had obtained a confession from an innocent Egyptian student detained in connection with the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: FOREST AND LUNDBECK WIN APPROVAL FOR ANTIDEPRESSANT
description: Forest Laboratories and H. Lundbeck A.S. said yesterday that they had won federal approval for the antidepressant Lexapro, the successor to their blockbuster Celexa. Forest licenses the rights to both drugs in the United States from Lundbeck, based in Denmark, and said Lexapro would be available in the United States by Sept. 5. Sales of Celexa, Forest's top-selling product, are more than $1 billion a year in the United States. Forest said its sales representatives would no longer promote Celexa once Lexapro was introduced. Stock in Forest, based in New York, rose $3.74, or 5.4 percent, to $73.24. Lundbeck shares rose 6 kroner, to 173.5, in Copenhagen. (Bloomberg News)

title: Backward Runs French. Reels the Mind.
description: Those who have studied French but haven't been in France for a while may find themselves confused when they overhear conversations that sound familiar but remain largely incomprehensible. Gradually they may realize, or some kind soul may explain, that what they are hearing is a popular slang called Verlan in which standard French spellings or syllables are reversed or recombined, or both.

title: The Man Who Wrote the Book on Spies
description: When James Bond flies into Istanbul in ''From Russia With Love'' to collect a Russian encryption machine along with an alluring Soviet defector, he is reading Eric Ambler's 1939 spy novel, ''A Coffin for Dimitrios.'' It is an inside joke for Bond's creator, Ian Fleming, since Ambler's book also involved skulduggery in Istanbul. The joke even takes on an edge when Bond later returns to the novel but can't keep his eyes open.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a rally by New York City police officers and firefighters demanding higher raises in their union contracts misstated a word in the name of the firefighters union. It is the Uniformed Firefighters Association, not United.

title: MEADWESTVACO NAMED IN 500 ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: The MeadWestvaco Corporation, the paper company formed by the combination of the Mead Corporation and the Westvaco Corporation, said it had been named in 500 asbestos-related complaints, setting off a 20 percent decline in its share price. MeadWestvaco once made auto-transmission friction paper that used asbestos. Most of the claims, it said, were filed in Illinois, Mississippi and West Virginia. MeadWestvaco, based in Stamford, Conn., said the claims would not affect its finances and it had substantial insurance coverage. Each case typically has other defendants, and there are about 6,000 plaintiffs in all, MeadWestvaco said. Its stock fell $5.11, to $20.95 a share.

title: Zimbabwe Starts Arresting White Farmers Defying Eviction
description: After a week of tough talk and stern warnings, the government of Zimbabwe has begun to crack down on the hundreds of white farmers who have defied an official eviction order that requires them to abandon their properties.

title: Amber Alert's Dangers
description: Another kidnapping case was closed this week with a happy ending. One-month-old Nancy Chavez, snatched on Tuesday from the family minivan at a Wal-Mart in Texas, was recovered unharmed barely 24 hours later. Her alleged abductor was arrested shortly thereafter. The news was not only a huge relief for the infant's parents but also a huge victory for the ''Amber alert'' concept, a system being used in some states to track missing children.

title: Exploring the Long Ordeal Of Hurricane Carter in Jail
description: I had never heard of Shiek Mahmud-Bey. When I looked him up, I found that he had played, among other things, a drug dealer in Sidney Lumet's ''Night Falls on Manhattan,'' a private eye's sidekick in a television movie based on the series ''Spenser: For Hire'' and the voice of a cockroach in the MTV movie ''Joe's Apartment.''

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: BANKER'S PROFIT FALLS Julius Baer Holding of Switzerland reported a 14 percent drop in first-half profit, and said it would cut costs, including layoffs of several hundred of its 2,300 employees. Baer, the largest publicly traded Swiss bank, made the announcement after its profit fell to $290 million in the first six months of this year. The cutbacks come on top of a 6 percent staff reduction over the last year at the 112-year-old family-controlled Zurich bank. The bank caters to wealthy clients, those worth at least a million Swiss francs ($670,000).

title: Record Labels Try to Force Internet Servers to Block Music Site
description: Testing out a tactic to combat online piracy, a group of record companies asked a judge yesterday to order four major Internet service providers to block Americans from viewing a China-based Web site that offers thousands of copyrighted songs free of charge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUBRY, JULES WEBER
description: AUBRY-Jules Weber, 90. Of North Branford, CT., formerly of New York, on Wednesday, August 14 after a brief hospitalization in New Haven, CT. After graduating from The Horace Mann School, he joined the family firm of Jules Weber Inc., from which he eventually retired as CEO. During 22 years in the military, he served as Major, K Company, 7th Regiment, N.Y. National Guard, and as Lieutenant Colonel, U.S. Army, Counter Intelligence, in the Pacific Theatre, World War II. Well known as philatelist, avid hunter, fisherman and bridge player, he was also an enthusiastic world traveller. He is survived by his wife, nee Julia Dyckman Andrus; two daughters, Lise Aubry of Damariscotta, ME., and Simone Aubry of Sudbury, MAdaughters of the late Ellen Jacobsen-and a brother, Paul Aubry of Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his step children, Margaret and Lance Minor of Darien, CT; Frederick Moon of San Francisco; Carol and Patrick Cardon of Pontlevoy, France; 9 stepgrandchildren and 9 step great grandsons. A memorial service will be held at the North Branford Congregational Church, 1680 Foxon Road, North Branford, CT., on Tuesday, August 20, at 2 o'clock. Contributions may be made to favorite charities in lieu of flowers.

title: PLANAR CUTTING 55 JOBS IN OREGON AND WISCONSIN
description: Planar Systems Inc., which makes flat-panel displays for computers, said it was cutting 55 jobs in Oregon and Wisconsin to save money. Thirty-five of the jobs are at Planar's Hillsboro, Ore., plant, which will be closed within the next 12 months. The other 20 positions are in its photonics business in Beaverton, Ore., and Lake Mills, Wis. Planar is consolidating production of its electroluminescent display panels into a single factory in Espoo, Finland.

Devoted husband for 22 years of Julie Gilbert Daniel and sonin-law of Henry Goldsmith & the late Janet Fox Goldsmith, he was a celebrated Acoustician, active in NABET for many years. His family deeply mourns his passing. Good night, sweet Francis, rest well.

title: Post Office Plans Tests For Anthrax In New Jersey
description: The Postal Service, concerned about the disclosure this week that anthrax spores had been found on Aug. 8 in a mailbox in Princeton, N.J., plan to conduct anthrax testing this weekend at two large New Jersey mail-sorting centers that may have handled mail from the letter box.

title: Texas Executes a Foreigner
description: An international treaty, signed and ratified by the United States, guarantees everyone arrested by a foreign government the right to seek help from the consular post of his own country. Yet Javier Surez Medina, a Mexican national who killed an undercover policeman during a drug deal in 1988, was never told of this right -- even though, Mexican officials say, he was carrying a green card. The officials say Mexico's consular office was repeatedly told that Mr. Surez was not Mexican.

title: After a Busy Day, Harlem Is Ready
description: In the long and storied history of baseball, there is no record of a manager or a coach saying he was happy with a team's off-day practice. Morris McWilliams, who manages the Harlem all-stars, kept the streak intact today as he prepared them for their first game in the Little League World Series on Saturday.

title: After Telephone Courtship, A First Date Ends in Death
description: Theirs was a romance born on the Internet and nourished through countless telephone conversations that ran late into the night. Though they had never met face to face, Nonie Drummond, 14, and Spencer Lee King, 17, seemed to have plenty in common: a zeal for MTV, a weakness for junk food and, more than anything, an aching hunger to escape the loneliness and boredom that marked their teenage lives. One day, Nonie boasted to friends, she and the teenager with the long, dirty-blond hair would be married amid the apple and oak trees on her grandfather's 140-acre farm.

title: 'The Egg Code'
description: It had been years since a man had touched her like that. Strong hands molded her body, her hips and soft shoulders, reminding Kay of dear Macheath Tree, dead these twenty-one years. The past two decades had been hard on the woman. All she wanted now was a respectable end, maybe a nice luncheon, a kind word from the vice president. The folks from Georgetown could even send down an assistant chair to deliver a few unfelt sentiments. Today we honor . . . the usual bullshit. She'd heard it all before, starting at Harvard, where the youngsters from Biological Sciences had worked hard to destroy her husband's program (and what an entire department couldn't accomplish with all its collective ill will, a shattered glass stamen managed quite nicely in the spring of '68).

title: 'The Banana Sculptor, The Purple Lady, and the All-Night Swimmer'
description: As a youngster in Queens, New York, Doug Fishbone assumed he would grow up to be a doctor "because that was in the rhythm of the household and my father was a surgeon." One night, back when M*A*S*H was a hit television show, he was awakened by a bad dream: "I was performing surgery and I killed the patient." After he graduated from Amherst, where he was a music major, his substitute-career thought was to be "a wheeler-dealer business type." He spent some time in Israel selling a stretch fabric made of acetate and spandex, called Slinky. "I'm an easy-going guy, not a real grab-'em-by-the-lapel salesman, so I operated at a net loss," Fishbone, age thirty-two, says.

title: FOSTER WHEELER OBTAINS FINANCING TO PAY DOWN DEBT
description: Foster Wheeler Ltd., a builder of refineries and power plants, said it obtained financing agreements that increase its liquidity by $82 million and give it more time to pay down debt. Its shares rose 22 percent. As part of the agreements, $904 million of Foster Wheeler's $1.1 billion in debt has been reclassified as long-term debt. Previously, the debt was classified as current, meaning lenders had the right to demand payment at any time. The financing allows Foster Wheeler to keep operating while looking for further sources of cash. Foster Wheeler is run from Clinton, N.J., and is based in Bermuda.

description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants to shove two major changes in the city's charter onto this November's ballot. There's no reason for this sense of urgency. New York has plenty of other problems that are far more pressing than changing the charter.

description: A federal monitor for the troubled Police Department in this Orange County town has found that ''significant progress'' was made in the past six months to turn around a force accused last year of harassing women and intimidating its critics.

title: West Nile Case in Queens Shows Virus Is Enduring
description: A day after announcing that an 84-year-old Queens man had become the first New York City resident to test positive this year for West Nile virus, city officials said yesterday that there was no reason to panic but urged the public to take precautions against mosquitoes.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Planning Shuttle Flights
description: Repairs of small fuel-line cracks have been completed on the space shuttle Atlantis, and NASA managers have ordered it to be readied for flight, probably in early October, a space agency official said. The shuttle fleet has been grounded since June because of cracks in metal liners in fuel pipes. Warren E. Leary (NYT)

title: PANEL FORMED TO NEGOTIATE US AIRWAYS' DEBT PAYMENT
description: A 13-member panel of creditors of the US Airways Group was named by a Justice Department official to negotiate repayment terms of billions in debts as the bankrupt airline reorganizes. Thepanel will negotiate on creditors' behalf as the airline restructures its operations and sheds debt. US Airways filed for protection under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings on Sunday. The members are Airbus North America Holdings Inc., the Airline Pilots Association, Charles E. Smith Commercial Realty, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, First Union National Bank, the J. P. Morgan Trust Company, LSG Sky Chefs, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, Rolls- Royce North America Inc., the State Street Bank and Trust Company, the Wilmington Trust Company, Honeywell International Inc. and the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers.

description: An Indian government delegation began a series of meetings with separatist leaders in the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir, delivering an invitation for talks from Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee. A prominent Kashmiri separatist leader, Syed Shabir Ahmed Shah, welcomed the invitation, but said the Indian government must first release political prisoners, rescind security laws and halt rights violations first. David Rohde (NYT)

description: Stocks were mixed yesterday but the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index still managed to finish higher for the fourth consecutive week.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: ECONOMIC RECOVERY Taiwan said its economy grew a surprisingly strong 4 percent in the second quarter as the recovery from recession accelerated. The rise, the largest in seven quarters, more than doubled the official estimate and prompted the government to raise its forecast for the full year. Nevertheless, officials were restrained in their optimism. "The U.S. economy is still adjusting," said Lin Chuan, head of the government's statistics office. "The world economy still faces many challenges. Hence, we must be conservative about the economic outlook." (Reuters)

title: New Child Welfare Head In Florida Is Drawing Fire
description: Gov. Jeb Bush's appointee to head Florida's troubled child welfare agency is not even on the job yet and already the appointee, a former Oklahoma social services administrator and founder of a conservative Christian group, has come under fire.

title: 'By the Hand of Mormon'
description: It is both fitting and ironic that at a small crossroads in the town of Palmyra, New York, four churches occupy the four corner lots of the intersection. Fitting, because the four contiguous meeting houses with their four steeples that intermingle on the skyline aptly symbolize the hurly-burly of religious sects vigorously competing for new proselytes, as Joseph Smith described the Palmyra area at the time of the Second Great Awakening. Ironic, because the embarrassment of denominational riches suggested by the intersection was not enough to provide a spiritual home for 14-year-old Joseph Smith himself. His youthful quest for a "true church" to join led him to a momentous encounter with heavenly beings in which he learned that no church in Palmyra—or anywhere else—was the true church of God.

title: A Club, the Mob, a Hit and a Miss, All on the Moon
description: ''You saw me standing alone,'' bounces the hip-hop version of ''Blue Moon'' heard over the opening credits of the sleepwalker sci-fi comedy ''The Adventures of Pluto Nash.'' The lyric may be more appropriate than anyone had expected; it may refer to the number of people in theaters where this numb rehash is playing. Apparently, setting this picture on the moon wasn't enough to help it escape the crushing gravitational pull of a bad script.

title: Serena to Buy Back Shares
description: Serena Software, a manager of software installations for businesses, said it would buy back as many as one million shares of its common stock, and its shares rose 40 percent. The shares rose $4.08, to $14.25. The stock had declined 53 percent this year. Serena will use some of the reacquired shares for its employee stock programs, the company, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., said late Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: W.T.O. Deputies Named

Mr. Supachai named Rufus Yerxa, a former United States trade envoy, and Roderick Abbott, head of the European Union trade delegation from 1996 to 2000. The others were two diplomats, Kipkorir Aly Azad Rana of Kenya and Francisco Thompson-Flores of Brazil. title: DYNEGY STAVES OFF BANKRUPTCY WITH SALE OF PIPELINE
description: Dynegy Inc. completed the $928 million sale of a natural gas pipeline to MidAmerican Energy Holdings, two days after it said a delay in the transaction might force it to seek bankruptcy protection. MidAmerican, part of Berkshire Hathaway, paid $928 million in cash and assumed $950 million in debt. Dynegy said Wednesday that a delay in the sale of the 16,600-mile Northern Natural Gas interstate pipeline might force it to seek court protection from creditors. The Federal Trade Commission approved the transaction, Dynegy said. ''Completion of this transaction solidifies our liquidity and our ability to meet our commitments and obligations,'' a Dynegy spokesman, John Sousa, said.
