title: The Waco Road to Baghdad
description: George W. Bush tossed the nation's press a softball and they hit it out of the park. There was not a single good review, not even from his minions at The Wall Street Journal editorial page, for the White House's feel-good-about-your-401(k) jamboree at Waco. It was a ''forum,'' the critics suggested, in the sense that the Politburo was a ''legislature.'' Only Mr. Bush, who is on record as having loved ''Cats,'' pronounced the event a ''great show.''

title: Mirth, Melancholy And Moderation, All Set in Motion
description: Mirth is fun. But there are times when melancholy can provide its own sweet pleasure. There's also something to be said for moderation. That was the lesson on Wednesday night when ''L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato'' was presented at the New York State Theater as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Holder Sues Disney Over Another Suit
description: The Walt Disney Company is being sued by a shareholder who says the company's delay in disclosing another lawsuit led to a steep decline in its stock price.

title: Mets' All-Time Team Includes Strawberry
description: It is not every day that a baseball club introduces its all-time team, and a prison inmate is included on it.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Governor's Cancer Treatment
description: Gov. Bill Owens had a cancerous mole removed from his face this week. A statement from his office said the cancer was basal cell carcinoma. The governor's doctor declared him ''100 percent cured.'' Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: On Iraq, Bush's Forces Are Split
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Budget Cuts
description: Gov. Kenny Guinn has asked state agencies to prepare to cut their budgets by 3 percent because of a deficit expected to be $140 million. The governor, a Republican, has said that he will ask the Legislature to use $100 million from the state's ''rainy day'' fund to cover most of the budget deficit, but that the rest must come from cutbacks.

title: No Reason They Can't Be Medieval, Too
description: The Locrian Chamber Players' guiding principle is that their programs include only works composed in the last decade. But at their concert on Thursday evening at Riverside Church, the musicians showed that there are ways around that restriction.

title: Two to Admit Harboring Murder Suspect
description: A Brooklyn couple will plead guilty next week to charges that they aided James C. Kopp, the abortion opponent who faces trial in the 1998 slaying of a Buffalo doctor, their lawyers said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Rejecting Video Games-Massacre Link
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, affirmed the dismissal of a lawsuit that tried to hold makers of video games and a movie liable for a 1997 school shooting in West Paducah, Ky. Michael Carneal, then 14, played video games and watched the movie ''Basketball Diaries'' before killing three fellow students and wounding five others. The court held that the defendants could not have foreseen this ''idiosyncratic'' reaction to their products, which are, moreover, protected by the First Amendment. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTON, THEODORE R., JR.
description: PATTON-Theodore R., Jr. On August 16, 2002 of New Hyde Park and Hampton Bays, NY. Beloved husband of Diane for 39 years. Loving father of Claudia Dudek and her husband Stanley, Claire Patton and Heather Patton. Daer grandfather of Teddy and Edna Dudek. Mr. Patton was a graduate of the Admiral Farragut Academy and Lycoming College. He was a proud member of the U.S. Marine Corps, Tenth Special Basic Class and retired as a Major. Mr. Patton was a long time stockbroker with Prudential Bache and Fahnestock and Company. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave., at 12th Street, Garden City, NY, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9. Religious service 10 AM Monday at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City. In lieu of flowers donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NY, NY, appreciated.

title: On Iraq, Bush's Forces Are Split
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Co. Results Certified
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accepted The New York Times Company's certifications of its financial statements. The Times Company was among more than 700 companies whose chief executives and chief financial officers were required by the commission to certify their statements by Wednesday. A list of companies that have filed sworn statements with the S.E.C. is online: www.sec.gov.

title: Trade Center Leaseholder Braces for Battle; Proposed Land Swap and Changed Development Plans Imperil Silverstein
description: Larry A. Silverstein, a perpetually optimistic real estate developer, thought the hard part was over a year ago when he fulfilled his long-held dream to take control of the sprawling World Trade Center complex in Lower Manhattan.

title: Holy Cow a Myth? An Indian Finds The Kick Is Real
description: ''Holy Cow: Beef in Indian Dietary Traditions,'' is a dry work of historiography buttressed by a 24-page bibliography and hundreds of footnotes citing ancient Sanskrit texts. It's the sort of book, in other words, that typically is read by a handful of specialists and winds up forgotten on a library shelf.

title: Another Drop in Stock Sharpens Concern for Vivendi's Future
description: Investors pummeled the stock of Vivendi Universal to a record low today, hastening the end of a brief management honeymoon and arousing renewed political concern in France about the future of the company.

title: U.S. Quietly Chides German For His Dissension on Iraq
description: The United States has expressed official displeasure with statements by Chancellor Gerhard Schrder that ruled out German participation in an American-led war on Iraq, which he described as ''an adventure,'' officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 7 about New York City residents who were enjoying a break in the heat wave referred incorrectly to a structure in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, near a spot where teenagers were playing on steps. It is the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument, a Doric column, not an obelisk.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Early Vote Rejected
description: India's independent election commission rejected an attempt by members of the country's ruling Hindu nationalist political party to hold early elections in the pivotal electoral battleground state of Gujarat. The commission ruled that tensions from religious rioting in which more than 1,000 Gujarat Muslims died this spring made an early vote inappropriate. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Police Raises Will Fall Short Of Demands, Bloomberg Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he expected the city's 24,000 police officers to get a 14 percent raise over two years, less than what city teachers recently won and far less than the 21.9 percent the police union has sought in a protracted contract dispute.

title: Ruling Favors Plan to Build Times Tower
description: A state judge refused yesterday to block the state from condemning 11 properties on Eighth Avenue near Times Square, clearing the way for the construction of a new 52-story headquarters for The New York Times Company.

title: Steven Yokich, 66, Dies; Headed Auto Workers Union
description: Steven P. Yokich, the recently retired president of the United Automobile Workers whose salty language and zeal for confrontation accompanied a keen understanding of the automobile industry, died here today. He was 66.

title: Bush Considers New Measures In a Bid to Boost the Economy
description: President Bush said today that he was considering a package of new steps to aid the economy and investors, illustrating the growing concern at the White House about the stock markets' fall and the possibility of another recession.

title: Mediator Joins Stalled Talks By Boeing Co. And Its Unions
description: The Boeing Company and the machinists union that represents 25,000 of its workers said yesterday that they had brought a federal mediator into their negotiations after the talks bogged down over pensions and the use of overseas contractors.

title: With Solid Putting, Funk Has the Lead In Interrupted Play
description: There was no doubt that Fred Funk basked in the limelight today. He smiled and waved at the gallery like a campaigning politician, tipping his cap more times than some players do in a year. He hit terrific shots, avoiding the dangers at Hazeltine National Golf Club with precise play, smart course management and rock-solid putting.

title: INSIDE
description: Clues on Lost Spacecraft

title: A Washington Must: Embassies With lan
description: Everywhere you turn on Washington's fashionable Embassy Row, a new palace-size building is under construction, a testament to the frenzied competition of other nations to gain attention in the capital of the last remaining superpower.

title: Corrections
description: The Think Tank column in Arts & Ideas on July 27 about the ramifications of investigating a devastating attack on the United States -- in this case, the one in 1941 at Pearl Harbor -- misidentified the four people who served with Justice Owen J. Roberts, the chairman, on a commission appointed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. They were Adm. William H. Standley, Rear Adm. Joseph M. Reeves, Maj. Gen. Frank R. McCoy and Brig. Gen. Joseph T. McNarney. The men listed in the article -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson; Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox; Adm. Harold Stark, chief of naval operations; and Gen. George C. Marshall, the Army chief of staff -- while closely involved in the formation and proceedings of the panel, were not on it. (The essayist's reference to the involvement of ''potentially culpable officials'' with the investigation was an allusion to these last four, not to the actual members of the commission.)

title: Amtrak Halts 20% of Its Runs In the Northeast
description: Amtrak canceled more than a fifth of its trains in the Northeast today, leaving 10,000 passengers crowded into slower trains or scrambling for other transportation, in a safety move that spread confusion and dismay among riders who are already accustomed to bad news.

title: Talks Continue on Jail as Homeless Shelter
description: New York City officials met for five hours yesterday with advocates for the homeless and a special master assigned by the courts, trying to avoid further legal action over the city's decision to start using a vacant jail this week as temporary shelter for homeless people and their families. But the talks, which were expected to continue through the weekend, did not appear to be close to a resolution.

title: Federal Order Activates L.I. Power Line
description: Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham yesterday declared a power emergency on Long Island and ordered the activation of a new electrical transmission line that runs underneath the Long Island Sound despite the objections of several Connecticut lawmakers and environmental groups.

title: Israel Begins Vaccinating Health Workers for Smallpox
description: With concerns mounting that an American attack on Iraq could provoke some form of retaliatory strike against Israel, the Health Ministry has begun vaccinating about 1,500 health workers against smallpox, a spokesman said today.

title: New Trains, Old Tracks: Bad News
description: To the Editor:

title: President Urges Sides to Continue Talks
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 16  President Bush said today that he would be "furious" if major league baseball players decided to strike, but he gave no indication of whether he would intervene.

title: Judge Calls for Review of Inmate's Harassment Claims
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has directed government officials to investigate complaints that a Qatari graduate student arrested in the Sept. 11 investigation was harassed and taunted by jail guards and treated like a terrorist, even though he was charged only in a credit card fraud.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Smelter Stake Acquired
description: The British-Dutch steel maker Corus Group has agreed to sell its 20 percent stake in the Aluminerie Alouette aluminum smelter at Sept Iles, Quebec, to Alcan of Montreal for $165 million. Corus put all its aluminum assets up for sale earlier this year as part of a drive to focus on making steel. The company, based in London, said it aimed to sell its remaining aluminum businesses, including two smelters and several processing plants, by the end of this year. Alcan will own 40 percent of the Alouette smelter, which has a capacity of 243,000 metric tons a year. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Time and Success Mellow Piniella
description: When Lou Piniella -- ''Sweet Lou'' to Yankee fans -- was named manager of the Yankees in 1986, at age 42 just a year and a half removed from his playing career and with no managerial experience, he thought he was in a great situation, especially since he was on good terms with the owner, George Steinbrenner.

title: Robert F. Borkenstein, 89, Inventor of the Breathalyzer
description: Robert F. Borkenstein, who revolutionized enforcement of drunken driving laws by inventing the Breathalyzer to measure alcohol in the blood, died last Saturday at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 89.

title: On Iraq, Bush's Forces Are Split
description: To the Editor:

title: Floods Keep Rising in Dresden and Now Spill Northward
description: As the Elbe River reached a record high level here today, about 30,000 residents were evacuated from their homes while volunteers stepped up efforts to protect centuries-old palaces and museums. But fears are mounting over the devastation that the river may still cause as it plows through northern Germany toward the North Sea.

title: For Venezuela, A Move Revives To Oust Chvez
description: The wide streets and white-washed houses in this city's affluent east end are deceptively calm, with tropical birds and lush mango trees providing a country feel just minutes from the chaotic downtown.

title: Rethinking the Lessons of Journalism School
description: In the last century, professional education for law, business and medicine has undergone a transformation. Before the New Deal, for example, legal scholars at Yale and Harvard integrated analysis of economics and finance into the teaching of law (and then designed the first effective regulation of our market economy). After World War II, leading business schools began offering the M.B.A. degree to give their students a broader education in management and economics. Medical schools also moved on from trade-school models and began to engage with fields like ethics.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: EARLY VOTE REJECTED India's independent election commission rejected an attempt by members of the country's ruling Hindu nationalist political party to hold early elections in the pivotal electoral battleground state of Gujarat. The commission ruled that tensions from religious rioting in which more than 1,000 Gujarat Muslims died this spring made an early vote inappropriate. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Jack Grubman's Last Deal
description: Critics of Jack Grubman's last deal, his $32 million severance package, are missing the big picture. Sure, most of the companies whose stock the fabled Wall Street telecom analyst bullishly plugged have gone bankrupt. But look at it this way: While investors lost $2 trillion in the implosion of the sector, his employer, Citigroup, made $1 billion in fees from the feverish dealmaking he helped arrange. It is no wonder the financial giant felt moved to show its appreciation, even as it forced him out.

title: Little League Confident In How It Enforces Rules
description: The first games of the 56th Little League World Series were played today, minutes after a team of Harlem all-stars was welcomed during the opening ceremony with applause that was cordial, if unemotional. Little League Baseball, for the second time in a year, was attempting to move on after a discomforting investigation into the eligibility of players in its showcase event.

title: Reward Miles Are Piling Up; Fliers May Face Future Squeeze
description: Americans are accumulating and cashing in frequent-flier miles at a record pace, scrambling for upgrades and free flights even as a dearth of paying customers has left the airlines losing billions of dollars.

title: Coke Classic Is Set to Get A New Look
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would give the packaging of its flagship Coke Classic brand a makeover early next year.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: NEW ROLE FOR SENATOR Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, is considering a new position when he retires in January: the district attorney on the NBC show "Law and Order." Mr. Thompson is negotiating with Universal Television to appear regularly during the show's 13th season, which is now in production, a person close to the talks said. Mr. Thompson, who has acted in nearly 20 films, would replace Dianne Wiest, who has played the role for the past two seasons.

title: With Deadline in Play, The Fans Feel Squeezed
description: Robert Menje leaned against a blue garage door at Shea Stadium yesterday and held up an autographed baseball so he could examine the precise signatures in ballpoint pen. Old-timers like Jerry Koosman, he said, had much better penmanship than today's players.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: From Maid to Rio Governor, and Still Fighting
description: JUST before Benedita da Silva was sworn in as the new governor of the State of Rio de Janeiro a few months ago, a political rival accused her of being excessively fond of the luxuries of office. As Brazil's first black woman governor, he argued, she had an obligation to remain true to her origins in the slums here and shun all pomp and privilege.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVERS, LARRY
description: RIVERS-Larry. The Board of Governors of The National Arts Club expresses it profound sorrow at the passing of valued member Larry Rivers. We will treasure the memory of his frequent visits to our historic clubhouse and the performances there with his band. He was a wonderful, supportive friend and contributor. We offer our sympathy and condolences to all his family. Aldon James, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Suspensions By Regulator
description: The Financial Supervisory Service has suspended two staff members of Korean brokerage firms for using their reports to manipulate share prices. One of them, identified only by the common Korean surname Lee, conducted business through an account opened by a relative, according to Yonhap, the semiofficial South Korean news agency. At the same time, the Financial Supervisory Service denied any bias against foreign brokerage firms in response to criticism of its decision this week to reprimand two foreign firms, UBS Warburg and Merrill Lynch, for favoring privileged clients by providing copies of reports in advance of their general release. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: So What's the Great Divide? Tax Rates and Thresholds
description: In the beginning, the players wanted no part of the luxury tax on payrolls that the clubs are demanding. But the union eventually relented and last week made a proposal that embraced a different structure from the clubs' proposal on what has now emerged as the key issue in the talks.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the London Journal article, about a dispute over the creation of an eruv, a symbolic boundary within which observant Jews are exempt from some Sabbath prohibitions, referred incorrectly to a child shown with Millie Samson, a supporter of the eruv. The child, Aryea, is one of Mrs. Samson's sons, not her daughter.

title: Lawsuits and Regulators Shadow Big Lender's Future
description: Household International has dodged the problems that have felled many other lenders to people with poor credit and low incomes. Now, though, a set of challenges will test its battle-hardened management.

title: I.N.S. Chief Stepping Down, Latest to Do So At Justice Dept.
description: James W. Ziglar, the commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said today that he would resign by the end of the year, concluding an embattled tenure at an agency that has suffered sharp criticism since the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLINGTON, DEAN R.
description: WELLINGTON - Dean R. Loving husband of Laura J. and cherished son of Norma Welligton Koster and Cary L. Wellington and loving step son of Bernie Koster. Passed away on Thursday, August 15, 2002. He leaves behind the legacy of four wonderful children, nine devoted brothers and sisters and lessons of tremendous courage, quiet strength, and an abundance of love. He will be greatly missed. Donations may be made to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation, 386 Park Ave So, 17 Flr, NY, NY 10016. Funeral Services Sunday August 18, 12:30PM, at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Ave, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: 'After the Quake'
description: UFO IN KUSHIRO

title: Bush Looks at Moves To Benefit Investors
description: With concern growing at the White House about the stock markets' fall and the possibility of another recession, President Bush said that he was considering new steps to aid the economy and investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBORD, SALLY
description: WEISBORD-Sally. On August 16, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Wallace Weisbord. Devoted & cherished mother of Ellen and Judi. Adoring and adored grandmother of Wendi. Loving mother-in-law of Howard and Robert. Much loved sister of Anna, Al, Charlie, Ethel and the late Molly & Lillie. Treasured aunt, dear in-law, wonderful friend. Her absence leaves a huge hole.

title: Primary in New Assembly District Draws Disparate Candidates
description: On any given recent weekend, it has been difficult to ignore the distinct sights and sounds of politics amid the street fairs, block parties and parades in the University Heights section of the Bronx.

title: You Faces Endurance Questions at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16  No one will question You's heart, not after she won by a nose over Carson Hollow at Saratoga Race Course last month in the Grade I Test, one of the great races in recent memory.

title: New Trains, Old Tracks: Bad News
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILIGMAN, SHIRLEY. (SPERANS)
description: HEILIGMAN-Shirley. (Sperans). Dear friend, beloved wife of our best man, Dr. Sol Heiligman, a beautiful, courageous lady who taught us all how to enjoy the bright side of life. We will miss the warmth of her smile and remember her with love. With deepest sympathy to her sons Andy and Tom and her sister Phyllis and their families. Eugene and Emily Grant

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ALGERIA: FUNDAMENTALISTS SAID TO KILL 26 Twenty-six people were killed, reportedly by Islamic insurgents, in a western hamlet, the official APS news agency said. Citing security sources, the agency reported that the victims were members of three families in Bokaat Laakakcha in the region of Chlef, 155 miles west of Algiers. The killings were the latest in what has proved a bloody summer. A marketplace bombing on July 5 in Larba, south of Algiers, left 35 people dead. About 170 were killed in July alone, according to an unofficial count by the press. (Reuters)

title: A Different Mets' Lineup Has the Same Poor Results
description: The Mets opened a seven-day stretch last night in which they play three games apiece with the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Francisco Giants, the first- and second-place teams in the wild-card race. This should be a time of opportunity for the Mets, but four of the nine players in their lineup last night began the season with Class AAA Norfolk.

title: S.E.C. ASKS WILLIAMS FOR MORE ENERGY TRADING DATA
description: The Williams Companies, under investigation for possible sham energy transactions, was asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission for more information on cash reserves and sales in its energy trading. The commission told the company June 24 to disclose how much it sets aside to cover energy trades and how it determines the amount, Williams said in a filing. The S.E.C. also requested data on trading profit in California and other Western markets. The company expects to give the S.E.C. the information it requested in a few weeks, a spokeswoman, Paula Hall-Collins, said.

title: Ex-Farrakhan Aide Fails in Primary Bid
description: Conrad Muhammad, the former representative of the Nation of Islam in New York, has failed to qualify for a position on the ballot for the Democratic nomination for the Congressional seat held by Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, the city's Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: Government Ordered to Justify Jailing of a Captured American
description: A federal judge ordered United States attorneys today to turn over documents supporting their argument that an American-born man caught on an Afghan battlefield should remain jailed without charges and access to a lawyer.

title: Catchings's 29 Help Fever Rout Liberty
description: If the Liberty was looking for an auspicious beginning to its W.N.B.A. playoff run, last night's effort against the Indiana Fever was not it.

title: On Iraq, Bush's Forces Are Split
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pay Raise for Police
description: To the Editor:

title: On Iraq, Bush's Forces Are Split
description: To the Editor:

title: Jesse Brown, 58, Ex-Marine Who Headed Veterans Dept.
description: Jesse Brown, a secretary of veterans affairs under President Bill Clinton who helped expand veterans benefits to cover post-traumatic stress disorder, exposure to Agent Orange and illnesses related to the Persian Gulf war, died on Thursday at his home in Warrenton, Va. He was 58.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRW, Cleveland, the maker of products for the military, is the leader of a team that the Pentagon said was awarded a contract worth as much as $868.7 million to take over a missile defense program that has been reorganized because of delays and probable cost increases.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the At the Movies column of Weekend yesterday about the actress Jennifer Ehle, a star of the new film ''Possession,'' misstated the given name of the novelist who is her father. He is John Ehle, not Richard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPSER, ELEANOR BEYER
description: ZIPSER-Eleanor Beyer, 86. Of Lauderhill, FL and Beechhurst, NY, died on August 16th, 2002. An attorney who practiced in NYC for many years, a pioneer in her time. Adored wife and partner of Herman B. Zipser, beloved mother of Myra Z. Korman & Marcia Z. Hefter. Mother-inlaw of Jack C. Korman and Robert J. Hefter. Grandmother of Jason Hefter and Michele Hefter Seitles, and her husband Victor Seitles, great-grandmother of Madeline. Services on Sunday, August 18th, at noon, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (at 76th Road), Forest Hills. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, or to the Hospice Care Network

title: New Search At Merrill Is Reported
description: Criminal investigators looking into Martha Stewart's sale of ImClone Systems stock gathered more evidence from her stockbroker's office at Merrill Lynch late Thursday, people inside the firm said.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Pop and Jazz Guide of Weekend yesterday about the Ahmad Jamal Trio misstated the telephone number for Iridium in Manhattan, where the group is playing through tomorrow. It is (212) 582-2121.

title: Beliefs; Among struggles with boundaries are those facing Godless Americans and advocates of 'polyamory.'
description: It's August, and stories like these traditionally appear in August.

title: U.S. Bans a Method To Avoid Estate Tax With Life Insurance
description: The Treasury Department banned a technique yesterday that thousands of the wealthiest Americans have used to escape billions of dollars in gift and estate taxes. The technique involves buying expensive life insurance that will be passed on to heirs, but declaring a far lower price on gift-tax returns.

title: On Iraq, Bush's Forces Are Split
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition
description: The German government moved to let the utility E.ON complete its disputed acquisition of Ruhrgas, saying it would hold a new hearing into the $10.5 billion deal on Sept. 5. The merger, of Germany's biggest natural gas distributor and its largest utility, was approved by the Economics Ministry on July 5, but has been frozen since July 13 by a Dsseldorf court because of possible procedural errors. Lawyers representing E.ON's rivals, which say the takeover would stifle competition, said they would press ahead with their case regardless of the new hearing. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: A Delay for McCartney
description: Paul McCartney, one of five performers selected to receive a Kennedy Center Honor in Washington this year, will be unable to attend the presentation in December, center officials announced yesterday. The reason was ''an inescapable personal obligation,'' they said.

title: Nasdaq Decides to Quit Its Joint Trading Venture in Japan
description: Plagued by the slump in stocks here and by a host of regulatory and market frustrations, Nasdaq said today that it would pull out of Nasdaq Japan, its joint venture stock market here, on Oct. 15.

title: Missing Spacecraft May Have Broken Apart
description: A missing spacecraft designed to study comets may have broken up during a rocket firing intended to send it deep into space, mission officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKIN, BERTHA
description: MARKIN-Bertha. On August 15, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Steven & Gary, and motherin-law of Caryn and Juliette. Adoring grandmother of Rayna, Emmet, Seth, Jeffrey, Phillip and Jack. Dear sister of Mervyn and Benny and the late Harry. Funeral service Sunday, 11:00 A.M. at the Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: The Man Who Wrote the Book on Spies
description: When James Bond flies into Istanbul in "From Russia With Love" to collect a Russian encryption machine along with an alluring Soviet defector

title: Golisano Attacks Pataki on Conservative Issues
description: The muted primary contest between Gov. George E. Pataki and Tom Golisano flared yesterday, as Mr. Golisano launched an advertising barrage against the governor and the Pataki camp accused him of lying.

title: A Dangerous Journey
description: Every year, tens of thousands of desperate illegal migrants from West and Central Africa cross the world's greatest desert to seek work in North Africa, Europe or the Upper West Side. Some don't even know there is a desert to cross until they reach the Sahara's edge, in Agadez, in northern Niger.

title: As Disney Loses Steam, Insider Loses Patience
description: THERE are few things Stanley P. Gold seems uncomfortable talking about. But on Thursday morning, over breakfast at his stately home not far from Rodeo Drive, he fidgeted when pressed to explain his dissatisfaction with Michael D. Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company.

title: 2 iPods and a Microphone
description: IF celebrities and their offspring can be D.J.'s, why can't everyone? That's the inspiration behind the ''open deck'' night held every Tuesday at APT, a lounge in the meatpacking district, in the far West Village. A sort of ''open mic'' for the CD-burner generation, there are no turntables. Instead, D.J.'s work two iPods attached to a mixer to fit their songs into a seven-minute set. (APT management says that's the threshold before customers run for the door.)

title: Peace Lobby
description: Effective immediately, the State, Justice, Treasury and Interior departments will be superceded by the Super Agency for All-American Style. As we all know, President Bush's restructuring of federal agencies is largely cosmetic. Therefore, we may as well let makeup artists and other professional image consultants take over the job. (See policy memos: ''Domestic Security -It's About the Eyes,'' ''Dull Lips Sink Ships,'' et al.)

title: A New Home and a Mission for Fine Art: To Help Children Heal
description: WHEN construction of the Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla is completed next year, visitors may think they've taken a wrong turn. With a walk-through aquarium in the lobby, a miniature golf course outside and artistic creations throughout the hospital, the Maria Fareri won't look anything like the antiseptic children's wards of old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARF, HERBERT L.
description: SCHARF-Herbert L., 77. Attorney, died August 6, after a four year battle with cancer. He served in the Navy and graduated from JHU and Harvard Law School. He is survived by his wife Loulou, 2 children, and 7 grandchildren. Receiving at home.

title: Follow the Herd? Not Her
description: I GREW up in New Jersey, but in 1973 I got a job with I.B.M. and lived in upstate New York and then Vermont. I came to Idaho for my current job, and it's where I feel most at home.

title: Way Up High, Soaring, Floating, Diving, Dancing
description: AN abandoned grain elevator rises high above the docks of Red Hook, Brooklyn. With 54 joined silos, it looks like a pack of gigantic cement ladyfingers. During its heyday, from the 1920's through the 50's, bulk grain was weighed, cleaned and dried there by laborers who lived in the neighborhood.

title: Whatever Lola Wants
description: Last March, during the Paris ready-to-wear shows, some of the most influential fashion editors on the planet converged on the Oscar Wilde Room at L'Htel. Save for a showy mural of a peacock and period-piece objets de clutter, the tiny room lacks the wit and flamboyance of its most famous resident and is best known as the inspiration for Wilde's spurious final quip about the wallpaper, ''One or the other of us has to go.''

title: Hooked on Bass Fishing at an Early Age
description: Jay Yelas was so highly focused as a youth growing up in Santa Barbara, Calif., that by the time he was 16 he knew exactly what he wanted to do for a living. This might have led his parents, Joe and Kim, to rejoice, but for the fact that their son's stated ambition was to fish for bass. description: FENSTERMACHER - Charles A. Died at home in Los Alamos, NM, on July 28. He was born March 31, 1928, in Scranton, PA. His parents were Robert George and Mae Richards Fenstermacher. He earned a BS from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science in 1950, then an AB in physics from Swarthmore College, and went on to earn a Master's and Ph.D. from Yale University in 1957. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He joined Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory in 1957 where he did significant work in nuclear physics, laser science and fusion research. title: Fighting the Wrong Budget War
description: Like some of America's biggest corporations, the United States government has been forced to revise its ledger recently. The results, which show that the 10-year $5.6 trillion surplus foreseen two years ago has mostly disappeared, has propelled President Bush into a budgetary conversion. He is suddenly a scourge of wasteful federal spending. Indeed, he refused last week to spend a minuscule $5 billion appropriated by Congress for a grab bag of ''emergency'' items, angering lawmakers from both parties. ''If Congress will not show spending restraint, I will enforce spending restraint,'' he said yesterday. Mr. Bush is not wrong to be concerned about Congressional wastefulness or the long-term budgetary outlook. But he is wrong about priorities.

Every year, tens of thousands of desperate illegal migrants from West and Central Africa cross the world's greatest desert to seek work in North Africa, Europe or the Upper West Side. Some don't even know there is a desert to cross until they reach the Sahara's edge, in Agadez, in northern Niger.

title: Going, Literally, With the Flow
description: Yoga enthusiasts thirsty for a new exercise-fusion cocktail can now sample Yogic Arts, the latest mix-and-match workout. Developed by Duncan Wong, a yoga master and martial-arts practitioner, the concept blends the fluidity of Vinyasa yoga, in which one pose flows into the next, with the strength building and conditioning of joints found in the martial arts. An hourlong class, starting in September at Equinox Fitness Clubs, (212) 780-9300, includes stretches, squats, lunges and kicks to lengthen and strengthen muscles and tendons. The routine is meant to complement an exercise regime, rather than to replace it. Although the two disciplines may seem at cross-purposes (martial arts are often associated with self-defense, while yoga focuses on finding one's own peace), the goals of Yogic Arts are in the end not contradictory. ''Vinyasa yoga is primarily an upper-body workout, and martial arts are mostly a lower-body workout,'' Mr. Wong said. ''Together they make for total body conditioning.'' JENNIFER LAING

title: The Chic Of Araby
description: In early June 1853, the English adventuress Jane Digby left the city of Damascus to set out on what she later called ''the greatest adventure, probably, of all my journeys.'' She wore an aba, or cloak, over a djellaba, and a square white kaffiyeh, or scarf, folded into a triangle and fixed on her head with strands of colored silk. On her feet, she wore lemon yellow kid ankle boots with pointed toes. Her guide, Medjuel el Mezrab, a Bedouin sheik, wore what he usually wore, which is to say, a scarlet cloak over a striped djellaba, a bright silk kaffiyeh and red leather boots with upturned toes. He had tied several silk scarves in a wide sash around his waist, which served as a holster for his knives and pistols, and around his neck hung a sword on a silk cord. He wore his final accessory, a hooded hawk, on his wrist.

title: On Edge
description: As I remember from my own early adolescence, being called a ''fag'' rarely referred to a sexual act or orientation. It meant you were perceived to be a traitor to the communal unity. Interest in the creative arts automatically made you a deviant, but involvement in any extracurricular activity (other than a few select sports) made you suspect, and a trip to the library revealed you to be a true pervert. It didn't stop me too much. I was already too eccentric to care. But I often wonder how many of my straight peers remained in a cycle of mediocrity because being called a fag seemed worse than a life without interests. Parents should consider this when they wonder why their children may not have any interests beyond hanging out in malls and parking lots. Those kids might be too terrified of the ''F'' word to do otherwise.

But it's hard to turn your back on a good crime scene, and Phillips returns, in THE WALKAWAY (Ballantine, $22), to catch up with the action 10 years later at the Sweet Cage strip club and its sister clip joint, the Tease-o-Rama, now sanitized and equipped with high-tech sound systems. Sidney McCallum, the current owner, admits that ''he missed the sleazeball atmosphere of the clubs before he cleaned them up.'' But Sidney is a sentimentalist, the kind of chump who keeps his old, shopworn dancers on the books and puts up a big finder's fee when his stepfather, Gunther Fahnstiel, a retired cop, slips out of his nursing home to wander the streets on an urgent errand he can't quite remember.

title: Need a New Show? Just Dip Into Television's Past

title: Hungarian Grand Prix Tests Mettle of Drivers
description: BUDAPEST, Aug. 17 — They are thrown about like rags in a clothes dryer as their knees and elbows strike the cell walls, their heads weigh up to five times their usual weight and the temperature around them rises to over 120 degrees.

description: Are the top chess-playing computers pulling their punches against one another and saving their real strengths for matches with humans? It certainly looks that way.

title: Lust in the Gallery, Larceny in the Heart
description: IT'S easy. I lift it off the wall, hide it under my arm and carry it off. ''Rocky Mountain Goat,'' a painting by Albert Bierstadt: the animal, silky white, perches on a crag, and the vastness of the American West falls away at its feet. Or a tiny van Gogh, ''Sprig of Flowering Almond in a Glass'': a blooming branch in a jar, the ephemeral pastels of flower and glass slashed by a bright red jagged line painted on the background wall.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; All Things in Their Boxes
description: ''Yesterday I was trying to fit Hedy Lamarr into Dante Gabriel Rossetti's pre-Raphaelite garden, without success. She was more at-one today with the night sky of the Planetarium,'' Joseph Cornell (1903-72) wrote in a diary entry, offering a peek at the thought process of the artist who put everything in a box. Astronomical charts, toys, clay pipes, birds, mirrors, images of ballerinas, movie stars and Medici princes all recur in his exquisitely composed shadow boxes that preserve and compress disparate worlds and memories. In the preface to her illuminating and poignant monograph JOSEPH CORNELL: Master of Dreams (Abrams, $45), Diane Waldman recounts spending the bulk of 1964 in the kitchen of Cornell's house in Queens, where he lived with his mother and invalid brother, trying to pin down information from an artist prone to drifting off in reveries. She even smuggled in a screwdriver to open his boxes in search of dates when he left the room. From the vantage point of the friendship that developed between them and her research, Waldman -- whose first museum exhibition and first book were devoted to Cornell -- interprets with a light hand the imagery of his boxes inspired by Renaissance and Dutch masters, unattainable women, Surrealism, his lost youth, Christian Science and chimney sweeps (believed to bring good luck if met by chance) without lapsing into psychoanalyzing the recluse who rarely left his childhood home on Utopia Parkway. ''What better place,'' Waldman writes in the conclusion, ''for a man with so many dreams.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Praise the Lord And Hook Up the Sewers
description: There were no vows of silence when 16 Benedictine monks trooped single-file into a Morris Township council meeting. Nor was there a sign of jollity or a drop of the milk of human kindness. Not even a smile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, MIRIAM CHIL SON
description: ROTHSTEIN - Miriam Chil son. Died at age 91, on August 14, 2002. She would've turned 92 on September 21. Mother-in-law to Harvey Cammer and the late Aaron Tucker. Loving grandmother to Nancy Ellin, David Tucker, Debra Cammer, Andrew Cammer and Hillary Cammer. The very proud greatgrandmother to six greatgrandchildren known to them as ''GiGi'', Alec Ellin, Jessi Ellin, Tabitha Ellin, Jami Tucker, Halle Tucker and Payton Cammer. Sister to ten brothers and sisters, survived by George Fink. Miriam was an active and devoted member for many years of the United Order True Sisters Organization, having been appointed President in both New York and Florida Chapters several times. Animal habitat is vanishing at a steady pace -- about the pace of a bulldozer -- and the dumb creatures don't always pay attention to traffic when they're searching for unspoiled real estate between the developments and the golf courses.

title: The Opera Singer
description: The stereotype of an operatic tenor is a bearded Italian in a plus-size tuxedo, not a dapper Greek with coiffed hair. But the tenor Mario Frangoulis is a different type. Mr. Frangoulis, whose first album, ''Sometimes I Dream,'' is to be released in September, breaks from tradition, musically and sartorially, mixing arias with pop ballads and hobnobbing with the likes of Donna Karan and Valentino. Onstage, Mr. Frangoulis favors a textured silk Valentino tuxedo, a gift from the designer. During auditions, he sticks to his lucky Donna Karan jacket, a light-colored Ralph Lauren shirt (which he believes masks perspiration under the stage lights) and Prada Sport shoes. But in off-hours, he prefers this high-contrast, tough-guy look: a DKNY black leather sport jacket ($495), black jeans by Ted Baker (about $125 at Bloomingdale's), a form-fitting white Calvin Klein T-shirt ($23 at Bloomingdale's) and steel blue suede DKNY motorcycle boots ($185). ''There are so many opera singers who are formal or puritan -- I think that's wrong,'' Mr. Frangoulis said. ''I'm a classical opera singer with pop appeal.'' Despite the boots and tight T-shirt, Mr. Frangoulis draws the line at doing dance moves while he sings: ''I'm not Ricky Martin.'' ELIZABETH HAYT

title: Corduroy Slims Down
description: The summer's pastel baby-wale corduroy shorts and minis have changed into a more rugged incarnation for the fall: Western-cut fine-wale corduroy jeans in a spectrum of earth tones. Old Navy has low-rise cowboy cords in putty, camel, blue and salt white ($26.50), while Banana Republic offers a version with wide waistband detailing ($68). Higher-end models by Cynthia Steffe ($252), Dolce & Gabbana ($195) and Crystal ($176) sport chic tweaks like whipstitching and pocket embroidery (all at Saks Fifth Avenue). Molly Sky cords by Mavi ($52 at www.shopbop.com) flare out to prairie bell-bottom effect. Silver Jeans adds a bit of stretch to deeply dyed corduroy in cranberry, indigo and ice blue for an even curvier fit ($57 at Macy's). American Eagle Outfitters puts both sandblast and whisker washes on slim cords in ivory, tobacco and mulberry ($38 at www.ae.com). And Tocca makes waffle cord pants in bright blue or black ($185 at Bloomingdale's), adding an unexpected texture to the wales of August.

title: Contemplating 1905 With Shostakovich
description: It's hard, while reading Martin Amis's ''Koba the Dread,'' a quirky yet cogent indictment of Stalin (and Lenin) for fathomless crimes against humanity, to contemplate celebrations of Soviet history, even those perhaps intended ironically. Shostakovich's Symphony No. 11 (''The Year 1905'') at least deals with prehistory, from a time when the boot of repression was on an altogether different foot. Contemplation is warmly encouraged in any case by a superb new recording of the work, with Shostakovich's great friend Mstislav Rostropovich conducting the London Symphony on the orchestra's own label, LSO Live (www.lso.co.uk).

title: The Passions, Drawn to a Bachian Model
description: ON Thursday, Robert Spano will again conduct the Boston Symphony in Osvaldo Golijov's ''Pasin Segn San Marcos,'' at the Tanglewood Festival in Lenox, Mass. This is music that springs straight from Latin American culture in its lively pulses, hot and earthy choral chants, sensuous vocal nocturnes, bright fanfares and, altogether, its expression of suffering and death in terms of carnival -- of exuberance and joy in the ability of the living to protest and pray on behalf of the departed. Understandably, the work created a sensation when the orchestra first presented it, in Boston in March 2001, and it undoubtedly will again.

You remember that the coaches have told you not to let the quarterback get outside, then you get yelled at if you do not duck back underneath when the quarterback steps up in the pocket.

title: The Collaborator
description: M. lives in a one-bedroom apartment on the main street of an Israeli town. Square, graceless apartment blocks covered in exhaust-stained stucco, their windows shuttered against the Levantine sun, stand above a supermarket, a hamburger joint and a booth selling lottery tickets, all buffeted by the growls of buses. It is a place whose only character is that it is indistinguishable from dozens of other Israeli main streets built in haste. As a setting for an espionage story, it belongs not to an airport thriller but to a Graham Greene tale, one in which a decent man makes one apparently sensible choice and finds himself in a grim labyrinth. M. is that man.

title: A Fan of Pompeii
description: To the Editor: If Robert S. Miller (''State of Pompeii,'' Letters on Travel, July 7) was disappointed by his visit to Pompeii, I certainly do not share his feelings. Indeed, if it hadn't been for Maureen B. Fant's article ''Going Back in Time, Briefly,'' (June 16), I would not have seen Pompeii at all. I am an airline employee and had to accompany my son's friend to Rome to meet him there. I would have spent one night in Rome and left but for kismet in the form of Ms. Fant's article. I navigated the train maze to Pompeii and thoroughly enjoyed it.

title: August 11-17: NATIONAL; HEAVY WEATHER

That sent airline stocks plummeting and raised more questions about the government's post-Sept. 11 airline bailout package, since federal officials said they would support US Airways even through bankruptcy with the promise of a $900 million loan guarantee. Then American Airlines, the world's largest carrier, said it was laying off 7,000 workers and cutting back its operations. The final rough patch came when United Airlines also said it could seek bankruptcy protection. Edward Wong

title: August 11-17: NATIONAL; A SCIENTIST CRIES FOUL
description: Dr. Steven J. Hatfill, a biological weapons expert, angrily denied that he was involved in the anthrax mailings that killed five people last year. Because of his background in biochemistry, Dr. Hatfill is among a group of scientists and other people whom federal law-enforcement officials are focusing on. Federal agents have twice searched his apartment in Maryland. But Dr. Hatfill has accused the Federal Bureau of Investigation of smearing his reputation with a series of accusations leaked to the news media, which he said were intended to make him the fall guy for a crime the F.B.I. cannot solve. Eric Schmitt

title: Armey May Be Leaving, But Isn't Going Quietly
description: Even though he decided not to run for the House of Representatives again, Dick Armey hardly has a retiring personality. So as he travels the country to help Republicans in his last political roundup, Mr. Armey has been making headlines that make him sound like the opposition to President Bush, even as he says, ''I love him dearly.''

title: August 11-17: NATIONAL; CARDINAL'S DEPOSITION RELEASED
description: Cardinal Bernard F. Law acknowledged in a videotaped deposition that the Archdiocese of Boston had allowed priests believed to have abused children to return to parish ministry, and that church officials never told parishioners about the priests' background. The deposition was taken in a civil suit accusing the cardinal of negligence in the case of the Rev. Paul R. Shanley, who is accused of molesting at least four boys while he was pastor at a suburban church. Cardinal Law also acknowledged in the deposition that he promoted Father Shanley to pastor of the church in 1985 without checking archdiocesan records, which would have revealed complaints against the priest dating back to 1966. Pam Belluck

title: OFFICERS SAY U.S. AIDED IRAQ IN WAR DESPITE USE OF GAS
description: A covert American program during the Reagan administration provided Iraq with critical battle planning assistance at a time when American intelligence agencies knew that Iraqi commanders would employ chemical weapons in waging the decisive battles of the Iran-Iraq war, according to senior military officers with direct knowledge of the program.

title: On a Bridge to America, Vows Stronger Than the Rio Grande
description: The three northbound lanes on the bridge from Mexico are choked with traffic as customs agents on the Texas side slowly examine each driver's paperwork. The air is boiling, and filled with muffler exhaust. An alarm clangs noisily in the distance.

title: Zo Arnold, Paul White
description: Zo Ryder Arnold and Paul Steely White were married yesterday at the farm of Robbi Bannen and Ted E. Fisher, friends of the couple, in Stockholm, Wis. Steven G. Schultz, commissioner of Pepin County Family Court in Durand, Wis., officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, LYSBET LEFFERTS
description: BARTLETT-Lysbet Lefferts. The Order of Colonial Lords of Manors in America records with deep sorrow the death of Lysbet Lefferts Bartlett (Mrs. Philip Golden Bartlett), a long-time Board member, and extends our deepest sympathy to Phyllis Bartlett and Sarah Jones, and the rest of her family. Timothy Field Beard, Pres. Joseph Kerr Pistell, Secy.

title: Carrie Gardner, Robert Roensch
description: Carrie Rice Gardner, the daughter of Char and Robert Gardner of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Robert Gregory Roensch, a son of Claudia and Robert A. Roensch of Pepperell, Mass. The Rev. William M. Krulak, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Moving Up in Class
description: Rail Europe is offering a free upgrade from second (standard) class to first class on the high-speed Eurostar train linking London with Paris or Brussels. Travel must be completed by Sept. 30, with purchase in North America by Sept. 13. Standard-class fare is $199 one way on either route; by comparison, first-class fares are $219 or $279, depending on flexibility. The free-upgrade fares are not refundable or exchangeable. First-class passengers get bigger seats (which recline), a meal, beverages and newspapers. Travel times are 3 hours between London and Paris, 2 hours 40 minutes London-Brussels. Information: (800) 387-6782 or www.raileurope.com.

title: Fraternal Order
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER TRESPASSING
description: A Princeton University admissions officer who gained access to Yale University's computer system will not be fired, but has been shifted to Princeton's communications office. Stephen LeMenager, formerly director of admissions and an associate dean, is said to have entered Yale's system to check its list of accepted students. Princeton's president, Shirley Tilghman, said other admissions staff face disciplinary action. Jeremy Pearce

title: Nakia St. Pierre, Jean-Marc DuBois
description: Nakia Catherine St. Pierre, a daughter of the late Jacqueline and Emmanuel St. Pierre, who lived in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, was married yesterday to Jean-Marc DuBois, a son of Katy Camille DuBois and Gerard DuBois of Port-au-Prince. The Rev. Nigel J. Massey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Dancing Barefoot
description: Patti Smith, the fabulously disheveled singer and poet, ruled the 1970's New York punk scene. Thirty years later, her old downtown stomping grounds are meccas of fashion inspiration.

title: Betsy Biern, Theodore Booth
description: Charlotte Elizabeth Biern, a daughter of Mary Catherine Biern of Annapolis, Md., and the late Dr. Robert Biern, was married yesterday evening to Theodore Viel Booth, a son of Patricia Booth of Denver and the late Charles Booth. The Rev. John Price, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in McDowell Hall at St. John's College in Annapolis.

title: Touching The High Points
description: The vastly popular White Liquid Shimmer, the first product in the merchandise line of the makeup artist Kevyn Aucoin to be released since his death last spring, is the cosmetic world's equivalent of a tiny spotlight in a bottle.

title: On Wall Street After Dark, A New Bohemia Beckons
description: AT 1 a.m. on a recent Saturday, the area around ground zero in Lower Manhattan appeared deserted except for a crew from Con Edison. But on a side street, among the vacancy signs and garbage bags, throngs of young people dressed in retro rock T-shirts crowded the entrance to the John Street Bar and Grill.

title: Good Impression
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Impressionist Visions'' (July 7), the author, Dana Micucci, did well to get to Ornans, France, without a car. But others might not want to depend on a kindly family to show them some of the beautiful spots on the Jura plateau where Courbet also worked.

title: Television Close-Ups Hurt Harlem Team's Image
description: The intense scrutiny of the Harlem Little League team ("When Home Is Here, and There, and There," Aug. 16) failed to note how the electronic media contribute to our perception of the team's achievements.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Fairness, by Ferdinand Mount. (Carroll & Graf, $13.) Filled with eccentric characters and fond echoes of Anthony Powell's fiction, this British novel tells of the life and times of a rather passive civil servant, and how the aftershocks of a summer spent as a male nanny in Normandy are felt throughout his adult life. Last year our reviewer, Michael Gorra, admired the tale's ''incidental pleasures'' more than its plot. '' 'Fairness' doesn't succeed at everything it tries,'' he wrote, ''but at moments . . . reading Ferdinand Mount is as much fun as pink gin.''

title: Pilgrims' Progress
description: Pilgrims make arduous journeys for religious and other exalted reasons, sometimes even lugging along suitcases that have no wheels. They travel to destinations where they can, say, worship at the shrine of saints and holy dignitaries (the Vanity Fair Oscar party), seek advice from a guru (Dr. Patricia Wexler, the Queen of Botox), acquire meaningful artifacts (the Parisian boutique Colette), attain spiritual cleansing while networking (the Betty Ford Center) or do penance for sins (a week at the Golden Door spa to atone for gaining two pounds). Fortunately for us, these pilgrims often write home, telling of their adventures. Here are a few of the postcards from pilgrims over the centuries.

title: A Star Analyst Exits Loudly. Others Hide Backstage.
description: JACK B. GRUBMAN, the former star telecommunications analyst who resigned on Thursday from Salomon Smith Barney, wants your sympathy.

title: An Intern Protests
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/Fort Lee, N.J.; New Life Across Hudson
description: FOR many people, moving to Manhattan is the adventure of a lifetime. Even if they stay only a few years, it becomes part of their personal lore.

title: If We Truly Value the Family . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Julie Gold, Adam Smith
description: Julie Elizabeth Gold, a daughter of Ellen S. Gold and Dr. Michael S. Gold of Rockville, Md., is to be married today to Adam Michael Smith, the son of Katharine Smith and Dr. Coleman I. Smith of Minneapolis. Rabbi Susan Shankman is to officiate at the Westin Embassy Row Hotel in Washington.

title: August 11-17: NATIONAL; CHILD-SMUGGLING RING SMASHED
description: Federal authorities have broken up a major child-smuggling ring that preyed on immigrants living illegally in the United States who were desperate to be reunited with the children. Since 1994, the network brought in hundreds of children from El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras, at a cost of $5,000 to $7,000 per child, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said.

title: Afghan Defense Chief Acts To Counter Talk of a Rift
description: Under growing pressure from the United States to heal damaging political rifts in Kabul, the new Afghan government put its military strongman on display at a news conference today to deny vehemently that he has been locked in a power struggle with the country's American-backed president, Hamid Karzai.

title: Junior Gets a Spanking
description: Oedipus, Shmoedipus.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIDES, RUTH
description: WIDES-Ruth, August 10, 2001. Remembered always for her love, beauty and sage counsel. She is missed

title: Helsinki
description: Finland, and Helsinki in particular, has been a cultural and political fulcrum upon which East and West have seesawed for centuries. But the strong influence that Moscow exerted over the country ended with the collapse of the Soviet Union, paving the way for a truly independent Finland. The country has gone its own eclectic way ever since.

title: POSTINGS: A $1.5 Million Renovation, With Paint; 1871 Building Is Wearing New Coats
description: New coats of paint -- 150 gallons of a two-part epoxy durable enough for ships -- gleam a rich, creamy white in a patch of sunlight against Gilsey House, an eight-story co-op with commercial space on the ground floor at 1200 Broadway at 29th Street.

title: Word for Word/The Clancy Effect; Quick! Man the F56 Kryton Hydro Thermal-Sensitive Torpedoes!
description: NO doubt about it: Tom Clancy is a phenomenon. His military and espionage thrillers are routinely introduced with first printings of two million copies and shoot to the top of best-seller lists. Last year, according to Forbes magazine, Mr. Clancy earned $47.8 million.

title: Songs That Emanate From a Raw Nerve
description: Conor Oberst, who leads Bright Eyes, obsesses about a lot of things: love, salvation, music, the future, truth. In his songs, he's like a raw nerve, jolted by every sensation and often in pain; his voice quivers with urgency.

title: For Once He Says, 'Don't Take My Advice'
description: BILL O'REILLY, the conservative, in-your-face host of ''The O'Reilly Factor'' on the Fox News Channel, usually has all the answers. That is, in fact, part of what draws viewers to his talk show, the one to beat on weeknights at 8 on cable.

title: Modern Mikado
description: EMPEROR OF JAPAN

title: Deck the Malls
description: RETURN with us now to the thrilling days of yesteryear. For three decades, this sprawl of a building just west of the Garden State Plaza was Chan's Waikiki, a faux-Hawaiian palace that served neon cocktails with paper umbrellas and was retro even before it opened. Then, for a time in the late 90's, it was R. J. Gator's, the northern outpost of a Florida chain (its namesake dish was ''alligator nibbles'') that made only the faintest impression on Bergen County's dining consciousness before vanishing without a trace.

title: Leora Horwitz, Derek Kaufman
description: Dr. Leora Idit Horwitz, the daughter of Dr. Rena Horwitz and Dr. Jonathan Horwitz of Great Neck, N.Y., is to be married today to Derek Ellison Kaufman, a son of Arline Kaufman and Dr. Barry Kaufman of Wilmette, Ill. Rabbi Harold Kudan is to officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Few Records Were Set, but U.S. Meet Shows Depth
description: Two world records and three American records were set at the summer national championships, which concluded here today. Yet those achievements pale when compared with the combined seven world records set at the European Championships and the Commonwealth Games. Despite the disparity, officials assert that American swimming remains as competitive as ever.

title: Star Turns
description: The idea of Southern California as a place of reinvention is so commonplace that it's almost a clich. But in the field of domestic architecture, it's a fact. Throughout the 20th century, architects there freely borrowed from history to create a glamorous Disneyland of house styles: Tudor Land on this lot; Cape Cod Land down the block; Regency Moderne Land next door. (True, the region was also where pioneering Modernists like Wright, Schindler and Neutra built some of their most notable works, but that's another story.) I lived in Los Angeles for five and a half years, and never tired of improbable sights like that of a Federal-style clapboard cottage that looked as if it had been airlifted, rose-covered fence and all, from New England to Beverly Hills. In architecture, as in the movies, Hollywood was where dreams came true.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAYER, STEVEN J.
description: DRAYER-Steven J. It's three years since you left us. You are always in our memories and our love. Dad, Michelle, Joe, Emily Billy, Caroline

title: Corrections
description: Captions today in Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, refer incompletely to five vintage Norman Parkinson photographs of models in designer clothes in exotic settings. The picture on Page 47 shows a dress from Fortnum & Mason and an Ascher scarf, and was taken in Greece in 1963; on Page 50, Spectator Sports bloomer suit and Jaeger sandals, Ireland, 1951; on Page 54, Aquascutum coat, South Africa, 1951; on Page 58, Spectator Sports sundress, Howick Falls, South Africa, 1951; and on Page 167, Jaeger coat, India, 1956.

title: Americans Stay Home, and Europe Feels a Pinch
description: They gather in sneakered gaggles at Buckingham Palace. They swelter in art-hungry lines at the Uffizi in Florence. With their cameras and guidebooks, the foreign tourists rubberneck the Eiffel Tower in Paris.

title: State Approves Siting Of New Power Plant
description: A state siting board voted unanimously last week to approve a privately owned, 580-megawatt power plant in Yaphank despite a controversy over the cost and impact of tying the new plant into Long Island's electric transmission system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, ROBERT ALAN
description: BENJAMIN-Robert Alan. Beloved husband of Jean, of Raleigh, NC, formerly of Tuxedo Park, NY, passed away on Monday, August 12, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife Jean; daughters Penny Pesaturo and husband Michael, and Robin Durr and husband Bill; granddaughter Morgan Holly; brother Donald Benjamin and wife Anne; his nephew Scott and wife Cindy; and niece Cindy Benjamin. There will be a private service at the home on August 14 at 2 PM; guests will be received at the home at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Duke University Medical Center, PO Box 90581, Durham, NC 27708, in memory of Robert Benjamin for Parkinson's Research.

title: Calling The Shots
description: I don't know how I first learned of Eve Arnold. She was one of those bold American female photographers, like Margaret Bourke-White and Lee Miller, whom ambitious young women of a certain milieu just knew about. Arnold was an early member of Magnum, the elite picture agency founded by Robert Capa and his friend Henri Cartier-Bresson back in the 50's. She is known for her arresting images of struggling women in the third world, of Malcolm X and Joseph McCarthy at the height of their power, of Marilyn Monroe and Clark Gable wrestling horses on the set of ''The Misfits.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: Tommy Tune Honored

title: The Nation: Pressed for Success; When the Going Gets Tough, the Tough Put On Suits
description: BACK in the heady days when the Dow hovered at 10,000 and investors careered on the Nasdaq with the adrenaline thrill of riders on the Coney Island Cyclone, the time-tested boundaries between the public and private selves in business got weirdly blurred. People began to conflate what the sociologist Erving Goffman labeled the ''backstage'' and ''outside regions'' in the theater of the self. They moved the unconstrained self to center stage -- to the office, the boardroom, the interview.

title: Corrections
description: Captions today in Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, refer incompletely to five vintage Norman Parkinson photographs of models in designer clothes in exotic settings.
