title: Citing Cost, Judge Rejects Death Penalty
description: A judge in a small, poor Ohio county told prosecutors there this month that they could not seek the death penalty in the murder of a college student because the county's share of the defense costs would be too great.

title: War Emblem to Stay on West Coast
description: Richard Mulhall, the racing manager for the Thoroughbred Corporation, announced yesterday that War Emblem would bypass the Travers Stakes for 3-year-olds at Saratoga on Saturday and start against older horses in the Pacific Classic at Del Mar on Sunday.

title: In Last Strike Year, Winning but Losing
description: On second thought, maybe it's no surprise that the Montreal Expos have had a relatively good season. Maybe the surprise is that they are not doing even better. This, after all, could be a strike-interrupted season, and history tells us that the Expos are a terrific strike-season team.

title: Jessica Gibson, Robert Rosen
description: Jessica Law Gibson, a daughter of Arlene J. Gibson and Charles D. Gibson of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' vacation home in Park City, Utah, to Robert Alexander Rosen, the son of Andrea and Michael I. Rosen, also of New York. Virginia Hill Worden, a Universal Life minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: JOSEPH CORNELL

title: Rachel Hershberg, Neil Malhotra
description: Rachel Elisabeth Hershberg, the daughter of Karen and David S. Hershberg of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Neil Rainer Malhotra, the son of Dr. Heide Malhotra and Mohan Malhotra of Oakton, Va. The Rev. Samuel Morgen, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Yale Club in New York.

title: Before Robeson
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprise! Your Garden Just Got a Makeover
description: JO GOODALE, an attractive blond secretary in her early 30's, had a weedy precipice of a yard that hung from the back of her modest brick home in Hampshire, England. She hated it. She wanted to give her husband, Ian, a real garden, and so she called in the troops of ''Ground Force,'' Britain's hottest garden-makeover show.

title: Investing; Risks Are Rising in Bonds, Too
description: INVESTORS who have sought a refuge from stocks by pouring money into bond funds may need to prepare for a storm, say some bond managers, who worry about the prospects for intermediate and long-term bonds.

title: INVESTING WITH/Adam I. Friedman and Daniel J. DeMonica; Armada Small Cap Value Fund
description: THE accounting scandals troubling corporate America make smaller, simpler companies look better than ever, say Adam I. Friedman and Daniel J. DeMonica, who run the $900 million Armada Small Cap Value fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILIGMAN, SHIRLEY (NEE SPERANS)
description: HEILIGMAN-Shirley (nee Sperans), 75, on August 13, after a long heroic battle with cancer. Her warmth and enthusiasm will be remembered by a myriad of loyal friends. She was a devoted and beloved wife of Sol. Adoring mother of Andy & Tom, Randy & Nan. Grandmother of Michael and Zachary. Precious to her sister Phyllis Halpern. Adored by her nieces and nephews. Funeral services were held on Friday, August 16th at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to Community Access or Mary Mount Manhattan College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSLOW, KIRK ALAN
description: WINSLOW-Kirk Alan, after living with HIV/AIDS since 1987, Kirk died on Saturday, August 10, 2002. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to organizations directly involved with curing HIV/AIDS. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIDDLETON, HENRY BENTIVOGLIO
description: MIDDLETON-Henry Bentivoglio. On August 17, 2002, at age 78. Direct descendant in the male line from Arthur Middleton, signer of the Declaration of Independence. Beloved husband of Payne Whitney Middleton. Loving father of Laurinda Oswald, Alison de Peverelli and the late Julia Serena. Grandfather of four. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association of NYC, or the Julia Serena Fund of the American Museum of Natural History, NYC.

title: Two Railroads, One Company and a Need for Money
description: Until the last few days, the consensus on Amtrak was that it was two railroads: a sprawling long-distance system doomed to carry tourists at a loss, and a bustling Northeast Corridor line that could meet its costs, or even make a profit, competing with the airlines for business travelers.

title: An Ego Trip
description: It's pre-Jubilee week in London, and the air is humming and drumming. Lucian Freud's warts-and-all portrait of Her Majesty is sparking contentious debate -- one newspaper harrumphs that the Queen looks like a pug. But Freud -- one of the great realist painters of all times -- never shirks from the truthfulness of lines and wrinkles, even royal ones.

title: A March Protests Wages and Firings
description: Politicians joined janitors on a two-day march through the heat and two states last week, protesting what they said were unfair wages and the intimidation of workers who complained.

title: REOPENING RECORDS
description: Governor McGreevey last week issued an executive order to ease restrictions that he had earlier placed on the Open Public Records Act, which took effect last month. Citing dangers from terrorist groups, the governor had issued an order placing curbs on releasing information that included state officials' home addresses, pipeline registrations, bridge surveys and locations of farms and historic sites. After complaints from the New Jersey Press Association and open-government groups, the new order reduced the number of secrecy categories from about 580 to 75. Jeremy Pearce

title: Introduction
description: Some called it satire and others called it sad, but our letter writers found Lynn Hirschberg's insider look at the packaging of a new pop-music star anything but boring. Some readers did suggest, however, that the package might turn out to be empty.

title: Karen Vanbergeijk, David D'Adamo
description: Karen Desiree Vanbergeijk and Dr. David Raleigh D'Adamo were married on Wednesday by the Rev. David Krueger, a Lutheran minister, at the Ka Hali'a Aloha Chapel in Kahana, Hawaii, on the island of Maui.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Sports of The Times; The Right Thing to Do With the Ryder Cup
description: IN any other Ryder Cup year, the two captain's choices completing the United States team would be announced here tomorrow after the completion of the 84th P.G.A. Championship at Hazeltine National. But ever since Sept. 11, this has been a different Ryder Cup year.

title: Gas-Electric Cars Gain Tax Benefits
description: Owning a hybrid gasoline-electric car has some well-publicized advantages. Fuel efficiency is one. A cleaner-burning engine is another. And now there are tax benefits.

title: How to Speak to a Nation's Suffering
description: It is said that the greatest works of art achieve universality through a paradoxical specificity -- that Hamlet becomes more Everyman the more he is made the Prince of Denmark. However that applies to other works of art, it is certainly true of one masterpiece, the Gettysburg Address, which will be read aloud twice, by politicians of both parties, on the anniversary of the attack on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Adventure Trips For Women Only
description: ON a hot sunny weekend in June, 81 women -- a dozen of them aged 60 or older -- piled into paddle boats for a weekend of whitewater rafting on the South Fork of the American River in northern California. Traveling with Mariah Wilderness Expeditions of Point Richmond, Calif., the assortment of novice and experienced rafters shot rapids during the day and spent evenings line dancing, singing and wine-tasting around the campfire. As described by Donna Hunter, the company's founder, it was a larger version held each June of trips taking place across North America and around the world: adventure tours for women only.

title: A Network In Its Youth: Striving To Be Casual
description: Watch Candice Bergen as she zips into a spacesuit at NASA with a shuttle commander or strolls through Spanish Harlem with a street artist. Catch Isaac Mizrahi washing his dog with Natalie Portman, playing Ping-Pong with Janeane Garofalo, even creating his own designer doughnut. Or just settle in with Oprah Winfrey as she takes off her shoes and walks into the audience to chat with viewers after her regular syndicated talk show.

title: LOCAL VOTES ON ARENA
description: Four Essex County municipalities -- Fairfield, Roseland, Verona and Cedar Grove -- will place nonbinding referendums on the Nov. 5 ballot that will let residents indicate whether they support using county tax dollars to help build a $355 million arena in Newark. Governor McGreevey and the YankeeNets, owners of the Devils and Nets, reached an agreement on $185 million in publicly financed bonds earlier this year to build an arena for those teams, but the State Legislature has yet to approve the plan. John Holl

title: Private Sector; Pitt's Rules: Lawyers Out, Bartenders In
description: Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was an architect of the new rule requiring executives of large companies to personally certify their financial results. But two days before the deadline for the first batch of such certifications last week, Mr. Pitt couldn't keep his own numbers straight.

title: A Hunka Hunka Burning Elvis Imitators
description: THE last time Maddy and Wally Schilo saw Elvis Presley in person was in the early 1970's at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum. The King of Rock 'n' Roll was dressed in black that night. ''He was our first hero,'' said Mrs. Schilo, 60, recalling that she was 13 when she first saw Elvis on television on ''The Ed Sullivan Show.'' Later she watched him perform live in Las Vegas and at Madison Square Garden. ''Elvis truly was the King,'' she said.

title: Always an Activist
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Gun Law Reviews, Gun Owners Worry About Rights
description: JOE CANGELOSI'S office desk is littered with a few thumbtacks, extra pens and some loose change. Mingled with the mundane items, though, are a handful of .22-caliber bullets, three .38 slugs and a shotgun shell.

title: When Home Is a Castle And the Big House, Too
description: ON August evenings, the limestone canyons of Park Avenue and the white-glove streets of the East 70's are quiet, abandoned by the well-to-do for breezier destinations.

title: Those Twins Return in a Not Quite Identical Comedy
description: THE score was one of Rodgers and Hart's finest, bursting with melody and wit. George Abbott wrote a ribald, fast-paced book and filled it with topical jokes. George Balanchine added dances for the courtesans and clowns. And in 1938, when ''The Boys From Syracuse'' opened on Broadway, its frothy, winking entertainment was all anyone asked of a musical.

title: BackTalk; A Brother Finds Family Comfort in Turbulent Waters
description: I have taken up surfing at age 48. I am acting strange in grocery stores, stopping at the magazine rack to peruse Longboard Magazine. It is a surf magazine designed for the boomers who ride the longer, slower boards, filled with pictures that make surfing look languid and relaxing, as if it were as simple as plunking down in an easy chair. The pictures in the magazines directed at younger surfers capture its wild, dangerous and sexy side -- Dionysus whirling down a six-foot face of water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFFER, DR. RAYMOND LOUIS
description: PFEIFFER - Dr. Raymond Louis, 101. Leading ophthalmologist, scientist, medical author, teacher and father departed on June 1, 2002 in New Canaan, Connecticut. He was born on May 16, 1901, in Lancaster, Ohio, to William Fredrick Pfeiffer and Louise Katherine Metzger Pfeiffer. In 1924 he earned a B.S. from Wittenberg College and in 1928 an M.D. from Ohio State University. Following his residency in Columbus in 1929 and a year of study in Berlin, Germany, he joined the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center Institute of Ophthalmology in New York in 1930. What followed was a distinguished career as an ophthalmologist in private practice, an associate professorship at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and publication of numerous original medical writings and discoveries. Throughout his years of practice, Dr. Pfeiffer donated medical care to those in need. He was awarded honorary degrees from Wittenberg College, Ohio State University and Columbia University. Dr. Pfeiffer was married in 1935 to Gertrude Bard Smith who predeceased him in 1993. He was predeceased by his daughter Nancy Pfeiffer Welch and is deeply missed by his surviving children Robert William Pfeiffer of Severna Park, MD, Jean Pfeiffer Tate of Pine Plains, N.Y., and Raymond Smith Pfeiffer of Bay City, MI. He is survived by 8 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. Upon retirement in 1969 he moved from Riverdale, N.Y. to New Canaan, CT., where he resided during the winter months. Summers were spent on Hickory Island on the St. Lawrence River. Dr. Pfeiffer's interests included tennis, fishing, duck hunting, and fine wood-working. He was an active member of the Rotary Club of New Canaan. Those who worked with him over the years had the highest trust and respect for him. His integrity was impeccable. He will be missed.

title: Marion Eakin, Michael Meola
description: Dr. Marion Charlotte Eakin and Michael Nicholas Meola were married yesterday in a nondenominational ceremony at Treasure Island, near Parry Sound, Ontario. The Rev. Aileen Rice, a minister of the United Church of Canada, officiated.

title: Executive Life; Plumping a Career By Writing a Book
description: NOBODY will say Michael P. Cangemi's book is a page turner after reading its opening sentence.

title: Ears Open, Mouth Shut
description: I am an ophthalmologist. Recently a patient mentioned that he was grateful to have his eyesight back after surgery because now he could return to work. He said he sells ''misplaced'' electronics supplied by two ''distributors,'' i.e., thieves, at a local flea market to customers who don't ask why they are so cheap. I want to tell the police about this guy and his associates, but am I bound by patient-doctor confidentiality? Dr. Susan M. Malinowski, Birmingham, Mich.

title: Dysfunction for Dollars
description: Pat Jordan's suggestion that Dave Pelzer invented or embellished his story for financial gain is a grave one (July 28). Aside from some gratuitous comments on Pelzer's publishing history and personality and, of course, his brother Stephen's statements, the only support for an attack on Pelzer's veracity is a claim that Pelzer's descriptions of the abuse are too vivid. What basis is there for the counterintuitive position that specific, detailed memories are less rather than more credible? Horrific child abuse is far outside the frame of reference of most people. Sadly, the fact that it is intrinsically hard to believe does not mean it did not, and does not, happen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARUCCI, CLARA T.
description: CARUCCI-Clara T. 85, of Great Neck, NY, on Thursday, August 15. Clara was a Friend of, and most recently honored by, Maynooth College, County Kildare, Eire. She served as a Board Member of the National Center for Disabilities Services, Albertson, NY, since 1962, and served as a Trustee of St. Mary's Children and Family Services, Syosset, NY. She also served as the President of the Nassau County Easter Seals Society for five years. She was a lover of the arts and an avid traveler. She enjoyed whitewater rafting and, at age 84, took up ballooning. She became a loved and respected mentor to many younger people. She is lovingly known to her family as ''F.O.L.'' Clara married her late husband, Joseph P. Carucci, in 1939. She is survived by sons Walter and Mitchell, and grandchildren Joseph Edward and Grace Carter. Mass will be held on Monday, August 19, at 9:45 AM, at St. Aloysius Church, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Mary's Children and Family Services, 525 Convent Rd, Syosset, NY 11791.

title: The Silk Route
description: My mother's qipao was made of red silk that shone like a ribbon, soft to the touch, heavy in my arms. It fit every curve of her tiny frame; it made a woman out of her. She had worn it on her wedding night. As a little girl, I used to play dress-up in it. By the time I was 12, raised on milk and cheeseburgers in America, I had outgrown it.

title: The Last Temptation Of Christian
description: Christian Dior was 13 when he visited his first fortune-teller. ''You will suffer poverty,'' she told him. ''But women are lucky for you, and through them you will achieve success. You will make a great deal of money out of them, and you will have to travel widely.''

title: When Shelter Feels Like a Prison
description: During my early childhood I lived in four or five different homeless shelters in New York City. It's a good thing my mother found employment when she did; otherwise I, too, might have been like one of the homeless children in the city today, left without even a shelter to live in because of overcrowding. Last week some of these children were sent to an unused jail in the Bronx -- and then removed when lead paint was found there -- because the city could find nowhere else for them to live.

title: Bubbles In Paradise
description: Pierre Cardin is a branding visionary. For more than 30 years he has been putting his stamp on everything and the kitchen sink -- luggage, linens, sardines, calculators, airplanes, cigarettes, hair dryers, pots and pans, cars, kitchens, liquor, campers, skis, floor coverings, mattresses, collapsible bicycles, bathrooms, wallpaper, chocolates, alarm clocks and ice buckets. Today, more than 800 products bearing his name are sold in more than 140 countries. The business brings in a reported $1 billion a year, and Cardin, who just turned 80, is still the captain of his ship, making every deal himself.

title: Environmental Hazards
description: In a couple of years the cry of ''fore'' may be heard over the old Bayonne city dump. Last week, plans were announced for what would be the first golf course in Hudson County. It will be called the Bayonne Golf Club, a rolling par 70, 6,800-yard golf course (shown here in an artist's rendering) enclosed by dunes and grass with panoramic views of Manhattan, the Statue of Liberty and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. The 125-acre site was once flat, but it's now rolling thanks to four million cubic yards of soil dredged from the harbor during shipping channel deepening projects. The developers, Empire Golf USA, say they need a million cubic yards more. Membership fees are expected to be hefty, but the club will also offer a daily rate for the public, and Bayonne residents will get a reduced rate. Environmental experts say the old dump is safely sealed but that the biggest challenge is keeping the pesticides and fertilizer used to maintain the course from being swept into the Hudson by rain. Margo Nash

title: Life Is a Contact Sport
description: The bananas are distributed first. Young women from the league office tote them on their hips in big wicker baskets. Then come the condoms, in smaller baskets. Given the sheer plenitude and the wicker, the enterprise almost has the feel of a summer-camp picnic. One banana and one condom for every young man in the hotel ballroom, 262 of them, the entire rookie draft class of the National Football League. Then the woman onstage, a grandmotherly dynamo named Sandra McDonald, commands the rookies to practice technique. The condom is a condom, and the banana is. . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAZIK, L. MARTIN ''LADI'', ESQ.
description: GAZIK-L. Martin ''Ladi'', Esq. 91, of Falls Church, VA, died August 4, 2002, after a fall at his home. A violinist and master chess player, he was a longtime employee of the Department of Commerce. He helped to create Liberia's first map in the early 1950's and supervised voter registration in the south after 1965. He oversaw planning and purchasing for the United States Pavilion a the 1964/65 World's Fair. Loving and devoted husband of Wilda O'Donnell Gazik, devoted brother of Paula Gazik Brown, affectionate stepfather of Stephen Meagher Bush and Margaret Bush Johns, Ph.D. Also survived by two nephews, Alan and Peter Brown and three step-grandchildren, Patricia Bush Gillham, Sara Johns Griffen and Kate Johns, AIA, their families and many dear friends. His body has been donated to science at Georgetown University Medical Center. A Memorial Mass will be held later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTON, THEODORE R., JR.
description: PATTON-Theodore R., Jr. On August 16, 2002 of New Hyde Park and Hampton Bays, NY. Beloved husband of Diane for 39 years. Loving father of Claudia Dudek and her husband Stanley, Claire Patton and Heather Patton. Daer grandfather of Teddy and Edna Dudek. Mr. Patton was a graduate of the Admiral Farragut Academy and Lycoming College. He was a proud member of the U.S. Marine Corps, Tenth Special Basic Class and retired as a Major. Mr. Patton was a long time stockbroker with Prudential Bache and Fahnestock and Company. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave., at 12th Street, Garden City, NY, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9. Religious service 10 AM Monday at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City. In lieu of flowers donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NY, NY, appreciated.

title: The Empire Has New Clothes
description: Giorgio Armani dropped in on Russia's capital in June for a six-day visit, the first in his long career, and came away impressed by the city's potential. ''Looking around, you can see that Moscow is seeking an identity,'' he said. ''You can see that there's this willingness to come to life quickly -- to catch up with life very quickly.''

title: U.M.D.N.J. RESIGNATIONS
description: In what appears to be a shake-up at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, three high-ranking administrators resigned within days after Governor McGreevey appointed a new chairman of the school's board of trustees. James Archibald, senior vice president for administration and finance and one of only two senior vice presidents at the medical school; as well as John Ekarius, vice president for government and public affairs; and Louis Goetting, vice president for administration, 2 of the 13 vice presidents, submitted letters of resignation effective immediately, the university said last week. All three made between $150,000 and $200,000 a year. A week earlier, the governor appointed Harvey Holzbert as board chairman. In June, the state attorney general's office began reviewing hospital records because of possible irregularities in billing. Karen DeMasters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUBRY, JULES WEBER
description: AUBRY-Jules Weber, 90. Of North Branford, CT., formerly of New York, on Wednesday, August 14 after a brief hospitalization in New Haven, CT. After graduating from The Horace Mann School, he joined the family firm of Jules Weber Inc., from which he eventually retired as CEO. During 22 years in the military, he served as Major, K Company, 7th Regiment, N.Y. National Guard, and as Lieutenant Colonel, U.S. Army, Counter Intelligence, in the Pacific Theatre, World War II. Well known as philatelist, avid hunter, fisherman and bridge player, he was also an enthusiastic world traveller. He is survived by his wife, nee Julia Dyckman Andrus; two daughters, Lise Aubry of Damariscotta, ME., and Simone Aubry of Sudbury, MAdaughters of the late Ellen Jacobsen-and a brother, Paul Aubry of Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his step children, Margaret and Lance Minor of Darien, CT; Frederick Moon of San Francisco; Carol and Patrick Cardon of Pontlevoy, France; 9 stepgrandchildren and 9 step great grandsons. A memorial service will be held at the North Branford Congregational Church, 1680 Foxon Road, North Branford, CT., on Tuesday, August 20, at 2 o'clock. Contributions may be made to favorite charities in lieu of flowers.

And in a development that could prolong the transition and lead to damaging power struggles at the top, Jiang Zemin is now said to be angling to keep at least one of the three top jobs he now holds: president, party leader and chairman of the Central Military Commission.

title: ANTHRAX IN PRINCETON MAILBOX
description: A mailbox at Nassau and Bank Streets in Princeton near the entrance to Princeton University was removed by law enforcement officials last week after anthrax spores were found in it. The discovery was made during the inspection of all mailboxes that fed a postal processing center in Hamilton. Anthrax-tainted letters delivered to government offices in Washington last fall were processed at the Hamilton center, which remains closed. The state health department says there is no health risk to residents and that this was the only mailbox found with anthrax. Karen DeMasters

title: Newport Nights

Rosecliff was modeled after the Grand Trianon of Versailles for Theresa Fair Oelrichs, the daughter of James Grand Fair. Fair was a partner in the company that controlled mines in the area of present-day Nevada that became known as the Comstock Lode.

title: Fine China
description: First things first: the name. It's pronounced CHEE-na, like Sheena (of the Jungle), Gina (Lollobrigida), Tina (Sinatra). Not CHY-nuh, like the country on her birth certificate. Truth be told, China Machado -- 60's supermodel, the Western world's first non-Caucasian cover girl, survivor of the publishing debacle that was Lear's magazine -- invented her celebrated moniker by defiantly embracing the first two syllables of a very clearly remembered childhood slur. Chinita, little China girl, was what Buenos Aires's curbside Lotharios called her as she made her way across town to the nuns at the Convent of the Sacred Heart.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: BEING a landlord is always complicated. In George Stevens's provocative comedy THE TALK OF THE TOWN (1942), Nora Shelley (Jean Arthur) is fixing up the country house when an escaped convict and old friend (Cary Grant) turns up. Just as she's decided not to kill him with a baseball bat, the new tenant (Ronald Colman) arrives early and Grant hides in the attic. Soon Nora has signed on as the tenant's secretary-cook for the summer and Grant is posing as the gardener, who knows a little too much about legal theory and chess. The deception works until the tenant goes into town and orders borscht with an egg -- Sunday at noon on TCM.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Although she appeared on the cover of her first album, ''Horses,'' looking as if she'd just woken up in the back of a tour bus, Patti Smith, as the new androgyne on the scene, paid a great deal of attention to her clothes. Her entire look for the 1975 album -- from the defiantly tossed jacket over the shoulder,  la Sinatra, to the white shoes she wore in homage to Brian Jones -- was chosen for effect. As Smith herself wrote in ''Patti Smith Complete: Lyrics, Notes and Reflections'' (Anchor Books): ''The pursuit of style has always been a spirited part of the work process. Images that inform the work or the movement of the work. Baudelaire's cravat. June Christy's careless ponytail. A raincoat  la Camus. Bob Dylan's snap tab collar. Black capris like Ava Gardner. Discarded finery from rich heaps. Italian sunglasses. Green silk stockings. Ballet slippers. Boxer shoes. A sense of style.''

title: Deals and Discounts
description: WINE CRUISE -- Book by the end of this month, and Uniworld will discount up to $500 a couple on seven-night Fall Foliage and Wine trips on the Rhine and Mosel between Amsterdam and Basel on the 138-passenger River Princess. Prices start at $2,198 a person, based on double occupancy, and include air fare, all meals and guided shore excursions. There will be wine tastings and lectures, including one at Reichsburg Castle in Cochem, Germany, dinner at the Rdesheimer Schloss in Rdesheim, Germany, and a lunch and tasting at an Alsatian vineyard. Other stops include Cologne and Heidelberg. Space is limited; departures from Aug. 30 to Oct. 18. Information: (800) 733-7820 or www.uniworld.com.

title: A Pop Image Maker Ponders the Snapshot

The walls of his home in the hills above Brentwood, Calif., are dotted with originals by Diane Arbus, Robert Frank, Richard Avedon and Joel-Peter Witkin. He has sepia-tinged daguerreotypes from the Civil War and an impressive array of vintage stereographs.

title: August 11-17: NATIONAL; NOT SO FAST
description: Amtrak's premium train on its most popular route, the Acela Express from Boston to Washington, was pulled out of service after inspectors found cracks in a part that keeps the engines from fishtailing. The parts are being fixed or replaced, but following derailments in Florida and Maryland and a threat to shut down because of lack of money, the setback on the 150-mile-per-hour Acela was a blow to the struggling railroad. Amtrak lost about a quarter of its seats on the route, and had to borrow locomotives from suburban commuter lines to keep running. Matthew L. Wald

title: Soul Training
description: We teachers celebrate New Year's Day twice a year. We celebrate it first alongside everyone else, with paper hats and Champagne and ''Auld Lang Syne'' and mornings-after. But the first day of school is our second New Year's. It is our day to make resolutions, to look backward to former lapses and triumphs and to look ahead, usually with a mix of anxiety and hope, to the year to come. It is around this time of year, mid-August, that I, and I'll wager many other teachers, too, think back to our own great teachers. It is now that we vow to emulate them if we can. We pledge to do for our students what our own best teachers did for us.

An ingenious aluminum wall saved Prague's historic Old Town and its medieval Jewish cemetery, but across the roiling brown Vltava, the Baroque palaces of Kampa and Mala Strana were submerged. Whole swathes of countryside became vast brown reservoirs.

title: Helicopter Tours Over Western Alaska
description: The remote attractions of Western Alaska's countryside can now be easily experienced from the air. Helicopter tours of the Seward Peninsula and the Bering Strait are being offered in Nome. The excursion, operated by Bering Air, showcases the Sawtooth Mountains, tundra, lakes and streams, waterfalls and wildlife with return flights running parallel to the coastline along the Bering Sea. Each trip is designed around passengers' interests, the season and the weather. Time in the air is about an hour, with one or two stops to take pictures.

description: Emily Halpin had no luck finding a job this spring, so she joined the Peace Corps and will be packing her bags for Nicaragua next month.

Drawn by the thumping sounds of a drum-and-bass D.J. and a four-member Brazilian drum corps, some 500 people, most in their 20's and all in stages of undress, have begun to gyrate around the outdoor club's pool and on its white-wood bar. Those who aren't moving are taking in the view horizontally: some 20 sunbathing beds are scattered around, three feet off the sand, and more than a few are being used for more private displays of affection.

title: August 11-17: INTERNATIONAL; EUROPE UNDER WATER
description: Two weeks of steady rains unleashed their wrath on Central Europe as the worst floodwaters in recorded history etched ribbons of destruction through the Czech Republic, Austria and Germany and threatened to inundate Slovakia and Hungary by week's end. An ingenious aluminum wall saved Prague's historic Old Town and its medieval Jewish cemetery, but across the roiling brown Vltava, the Baroque palaces of Kampa and Mala Strana were submerged. Whole swathes of countryside became vast brown reservoirs.

title: Puttin' On Le Dog
description: When I was a boy, my first saint was a poodle -- my mother's white toy, Chippie. He was a great companion for a child of 3, better than all the other nonliving toys I had. He was always clean and professionally groomed in what I now know is called a sporting trim, with a scissored cap of hair on his head and a pompon on his tail. He was adventurous and liked to lead me out on innocent missions just beyond the yard of my parents' summer house. I must have been too well dressed (I was a first child) in clever, jaunty little outfits, with matching knit sweaters, as I was summarily rejected from the juvenile community. But Chippie didn't seem to care about my clothes and was content to play within the confines of our property. One day he was abducted and murdered by the neighborhood bully, a flat-faced boxer who liked to chew tennis balls and, apparently, poodles. The man who owned the boxer returned Chippie in a shoe box and asked that we spare his dog as perhaps our poodle was simply too irresistible. We buried Chippie. It was the first I'd heard of heaven, and I was glad poodles were welcome there. But thereafter my mother was careful to find more neutral clothes for me to wear, and I never allowed myself to consider walking down the street with a poodle again, though I have owned and shown many of them since.

title: August 11-17: INTERNATIONAL; U.S. REBUKES GERMAN
description: The United States has expressed official displeasure with statements by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, ruling out any German participation in an American-led war on Iraq, which he described as ''an adventure,'' officials said. The American ambassador, Daniel R. Coats, went to Mr. Schrder's office in Berlin to deliver the message that Washington was unhappy about Mr. Schrder's remarks, the officials said. It was a sharp contrast to the gratitude Washington expressed to Mr. Schrder for his immediate declaration, after Sept. 11, of ''unlimited solidarity'' with the United States.

title: Can Bookish Be Sexy? Yeah, Says Neil LaBute

Byatt's intricate literary romance, has a case of multiple-personality disorder. The film, which stars Gwyneth Paltrow and Aaron Eckhart as a pair of scholarly detectives, is in many respects a faithful distillation of Ms. Byatt's 1990 book. But it keeps being interrupted by a jarring, inimitable voice -- the voice of the provocative writer Neil LaBute.

title: Licensed To Grill
description: I wonder if the gifted but unknown illustrator -- and rabid anti-Steinbergian -- Luas Grebniets had a good cackle parodying his nemesis Saul Steinberg's most famous work. You will recall this work, a New Yorker cover, because reproductions of it hang in just about every apartment in this city. It pictures the Big Appler's world basically ending at the Hudson, with California in another solar system and Russia somewhere beyond California. Although Steinberg intended it as a satire of our provincialism, most people who say they like satire don't actually like being satirized, and so they embraced the illustration as emblematic of New York's pre-eminent, if not apotheotic, status in the world. Grebniets's mirror image looks at the globe as a Midwesterner does, picturing New York as quite a small little dot, though a noisy dot, one that, while believing itself the discoverer of all things fashionable, is frequently a dot woefully behind the American curve.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Contradictory Signals From Commercial Property
description: TWO powerful trends seem to be clashing in commercial real estate in New Jersey, market experts say. Corporate consolidations and layoffs have produced painfully high vacancy rates in many cities. Meanwhile, the market for sales of commercial properties as investment is remarkably healthy.

title: QUICK BITE/Belmar; By the Beach, a Club and a Club Sandwich
description: D'Jais, the Belmar bar and dance club, has been a Jersey Shore institution for young people since the 1950's, but some people are surprised to learn it also is an outdoor restaurant with excellent food. The casual restaurant, which has a roof over the tables, overlooks the ocean. The menu has been developed by Mary Fallon, who has cooked for the owner, Frank Sementa, for more than a decade. One appetizers popular with the after-beach crowd is Swamp Thing, a spinach and artichoke cheese dip served with grilled pita wedges ($6.95). A better-than-average guacamole ($5.95) also makes a great ''snackatizer'' as D'Jais calls it. Shrimp Jammers are breaded and stuffed with cheddar cheese and served with spicy roasted red pepper sauce ($10.95). Salads ($5.50 to $10.95) feature grilled tuna, traditional Caesar or a ''surf salad'' made with shrimp and Jersey tomatoes. Although you can spend more and get a very good steak dinner, the homemade pizza (starting at $6.95) and fajitas ($9.95 or $11.95) are popular, as is the crab cake sandwich ($9.95), which has two soft flavorful crab cakes on a sesame roll. A variety of styles of hamburgers ($6.95 to $8.95) rounds out the menu. Mr. Sementa, who played at the club in a local band during the 1970's, bought the establishment in 1979 and added the restaurant 12 years ago. He hopes to add more fresh seafood to the menu and eventually to remain open all year. Karen DeMasters

She segued into corporate communications. He started an Internet company, then sold it for $5.5 million -- not real money, just stock options, but the two looked deceptively similar back then. That has all changed. As recently as 2000, the ESPN empire carried only 12 games, and ABC only one. But in 2001, with the networks signing a new contract for an undisclosed sum, ESPN and ESPN2 agreed to show a combined 26 games, and ABC carried two.

title: Queer As Folk
description: At some point in most of her concerts, Christine Lavin goes looking for a man. A singer-songwriter prominent in the folk-music circuit for more than a decade, Lavin is a drolly impish performer with a flair for the theatrical. She affixes a miner's light on her head, steps offstage and roams around the audience in search of the best-looking man in the house. ''The interesting thing to me,'' she says, ''is that I'll be looking for a man, and I'll have the light on, and I'll see 20 women, and I'll see one man in the whole section.'' The audience for artists like Lavin, like that of folk music in general, is predominantly female and increasingly gay.

title: Required Reading

He is survived by his wife Charleen Greer Edge, his three children, Deborah, David, Steven Edge, and seven grandchildren. He grew up in New York City and attended Lincoln School. He graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School. He served during WWII in the Coast Guard as LTD JG as a navigator on the USS Spencer in the Atlantic, Mediterranean and the Pacific. He married Mary Kerr in 1947, lived in suburban Chicago. Practiced law as a partner of Arnstein-Lehr. An avid birder, dedicated to conversation, he served Hawk Mountain Sanctuary for over 50 years as a board member, secretary, president. Serivces will be held at The Church of the Holy Comforter, 222 Kenilworth Ave, Kenilworth, at 2 PM, Thursday, August 22nd. description: MOHR-Alfred C. 98, of West Caldwell, NJ, on July 22, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Martha (Koepell) Mohr. Private funeral services were at Funeral Service of New Jersey, Hillside, NJ. A former member of the Department of Germanic Languages and Literature at Yale University. Previous to this assignment he had served as dean of the Modern Language Department at the McBurney School for Boys in New York City. He was born in Vienna, Austria, and came with his parents to the United States at the age of two. Subsequently he attended the Morgan Preparatory School in Clinton, CT, where he was the president of his class and valedictorian. Mr. Mohr entered Yale on a Middlesex County, CT scholarship and graduated with a BA degree in 1926. While at Yale he was the Heel and Toe Race-Walking Champion and captain of the Yale chess team. He sang in the Battell Chapel Choir and and the glee club in which his specialty was the Swiss yodel which he taught and coached subsequent Yale Glee Club yodelers. In 1932 he received his Masters degree at Columbia University whereupon he entered the University of Berlin to continue his studies. During the Second World War, he served as Technical Specialist for the Aeronautical Division of the Chrysler Corporation's new Dodge Chicago plant, after which he went into business for himself as a Chrysler Corporation automobile dealer in Caldwell and Newark, NJ. description: CELLPHONE USE IN CARS DROPS, STUDY SAYS A New York law banning drivers from talking on cellphones without devices allowing hands-free use has cut use in half, according to a study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Before the state started issuing fines on Dec. 1, 2001, for violations, 2.3 percent of drivers in the state were observed using cellphones by the institute's researchers. After the ban, use fell to 1.1 percent. Researchers observed more than 37,000 automobiles in Albany, Binghamton, Kingston and Spring Valley. New York City was excluded largely because of a shortage of good observation sites, the institute said.   Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGIN, KENNETH S.
description: KNIGIN-Kenneth S. 73, died in his Manhattan home August 16th, 2002, of a heart attack. Son of the late Jack Knigin and Miriam Sheldon Knigin Leitman. Mr. Knigin, a former lawyer, was highly regarded as an international environmental consultant. A graduate of NY University and Brooklyn Law School, Mr. Knigin was active politically and held various positions including NYC Councilman and Parking Violations Commissioner under the Lindsey Administration. In addition to his many other accomplishments, Mr. Knigin was a 20 year on-air radio personality on the Long John Nebel Show, Special Counsel to Taiwan, part owner of the NY Franchise of the World Football League and organizer of the Kyle Rote Football League for Young Men in Brooklyn. He was the beloved husband of Jeanie Walls Henry Knigin. He was also the beloved brother of Karen Leitman. He is survived by two previous wives, Eunice Germansky Knigin and Pia Buggert Knigin, and his four children Marcia Wallace, Randy Little, Johanna Knigin and Alexandra Knigin. In every way, Mr. Knigin was loving, kind, and sensitive and will be especially missed by his black Labrador retriever, Casey. Funeral services will be at Frank E. Campell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Monday, August 19th at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks the contributions be made to your favorite charity or to Guiding Eyes for the Blind in Yorktown Heights, NY.

title: Compressed Data; 'Push' Technology Lives, but Now You Pay for It
description: It has been six years since Pointcast made ''push'' technology an industry buzzword and only a little more than two years since the company was shut and the concept largely disavowed. But if you thought push was dead and gone, think again. In the last few months, Infogate, the company that acquired the Pointcast technology, has signed up a string of media companies that see push as a way of generating subscription revenue.

title: Vivendi Is Said to Consider Selling Some Units
description: The board of Vivendi Universal may discuss the potential sale of several assets that have not yet been put on the block when it meets next month, people close to the company said today, including its remaining publishing businesses and the Universal music, film and television production operations the United States.

title: Five Officers Are Wounded By a Gunman In Mississippi
description: The acting police chief of this scruffy little corn and cotton town on the Mississippi River was shot in the neck on Saturday, and four other officers were wounded at dawn today when they rushed the house where the gunman had holed up. They and the quiet young man who is accused of doing the shooting survived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, BETTY M.
description: PATTERSON-Betty M. Of New York City and Southampton, at the Southampton Care Center on August 17, 2002, of heart failure after an extended illness. Survived by her husband Jere, her daughters Bettina Murray, Knight Meem and Dean Bauer; her son Jere Patterson Jr., and seven grandchildren. Mrs. Patterson was a longtime director of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House. She also served on the Boards of the YWCA of New York, the Knickerbocker Greys and the Yorkville Community Assocation and was President and for many years a Trustee of the Chapin-Brearley Exchange. A memorial service will be held at 5 PM, on Sunday, August 25, at St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton. A reception in New York City is planned for the early fall. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Grosvenor Neighborhood House or to the Southampton Care Center, would be appreciated.

title: A Day Later, the Veterans' Mistakes Irk Fassel the Most
description: What may gall Jim Fassel the most about the inept play of the Giants on Saturday is that on a team top-heavy with inexperienced newcomers, the veterans made many of the mistakes. If a third-team linebacker misses a block on a kick return, Fassel might rant, but he knows that the player will probably not make the team. When quarterback Kerry Collins and defensive tackle Keith Hamilton are guilty of mental gaffes, Fassel's exasperation peaks.

title: Ban on Drivers' Cellphones Cuts Use, Study Finds
description: ANew York law banning drivers from talking on cellphones without hands-free devices has cut the practice in half, according to a study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Before the state started issuing citations , for violations on Dec. 1, 2001, 2.3 percent of drivers were observed using cellphones by the institute's researchers. After the ban, usage fell to 1.1 percent.

title: The Right Menu For Foreign Policy
description: It could be the worst dustup over food in the Middle East since Cain offered God the fruit of the ground instead of meat. According to Israeli press reports, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was outraged that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel served a visiting Egyptian general just two sausages and a tomato instead of the huge meal the general expected. Mr. Mubarak responded to the insult by calling Mr. Sharon a ''fatso'' who ''eats an entire lamb for dinner,'' and last week Israel responded to that by condemning Mr. Mubarak for his ''personal'' attack on Mr. Sharon (who reportedly quipped that the general could have three sausages next time).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cellphone Use In Cars Drops, Study Says
description: A New York law banning drivers from talking on cellphones without devices allowing hands-free use has cut use in half, according to a study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Before the state started issuing fines on Dec. 1, 2001, for violations, 2.3 percent of drivers in the state were observed using cellphones by the institute's researchers. After the ban, use fell to 1.1 percent. Researchers observed more than 37,000 automobiles in Albany, Binghamton, Kingston and Spring Valley. New York City was excluded largely because of a shortage of good observation sites, the institute said. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Men Shot, One Dies
description: One man was killed by gunfire and another shot in the leg last night in front of a building in Brooklyn, the police said. The two men, who were not identified, were shot in front of 997 Fulton Street in Fort Greene about 9:30 p.m., according to the police. One of the men was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead about two hours later. The man who was hit in the leg was being treated at Kings County Hospital Center early today. Hospital officials did not respond a request for information on his condition. Investigators said the victims were shot by one or more assailants, who fled in a black Mazda. They were still being sought early today, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular Widens Rollover Plan
description: Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest provider of wireless telephone services, said yesterday that it would create a nationwide plan that allows customers to keep their unused monthly minutes. Customers who have not used their minutes in one month will have them rolled over into the next month for up to a year, said Cingular, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications. The offer is available for customers who select a Cingular plan costing $39.99 a month or more. A spokeswoman said that more than 50 percent of Cingular customers would be eligible to roll over their minutes. The plans will also include nationwide long distance at no extra cost. ''Rollover lets customers keep what they're paying for,'' said Virginia Vann, Cingular's chief marketing officer, in a statement. ''These plans bring a new value proposition to wireless customers. If they don't use their package minutes, they don't lose their package minutes.'' Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILMERDING, LUCIUS JR.
description: WILMERDING - Lucius Jr. Died at his summer home in Maine on August 13, at the age of 96. He was born in New York City January 23, 1906, the son of Lucius Wilmerding Sr. and Helen Cutting. He was educated at St. Paul's and the Evans School; AB Princeton, 1927; MA Queens College, Oxford, 1929. He taught English at Columbia 1929-31. He served on various commissions and administrations in New York City 1931-35. When he moved to Washington, D.C. in 1935 he worked for the Treasury Department until he joined the Navy. During WW II he served in London and at the Army & Navy College, Washington, DC. He rose to the rank of Lt. Commander. After the war he moved to Princeton where he was at the Institute for Advanced Studies 1945-48. He was a consultant to the Federal Reserve Board and was called to testify before Congress on various points ot constitutional Law. He was the author of several books dealing mainly with political economics or history. In later life he was private scholar and continued to research his fields of interest. He was married for 64 years to the late Jane Mather and is survived by his sister Helen Bastedo of Peterborough, NH; his four children: Lucius Wilmerding, III of Old Lyme, CT; Jan Wilmerding Binger of Plainfield, NH; Walter Wilmerding of Princeton, NJ; and Helen Cutting Milner of London, UK and Princeton, NJ; twelve grandchildren; and fourteen great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Princeton University Chapel Thursday, September 5th at 11:00 A.M.

title: AQUILA TO SELL PIPELINES FOR $265 MILLION
description: Aquila Inc., the energy company that is trying to raise $1 billion this year by shedding assets, agreed to sell two natural gas pipelines and its 50 percent stake in a third line for $265 million. The sale to the closely held Energy Transfer Company of Dallas includes Aquila's Southeast Texas and Mid-Continent pipeline systems and half of the Oasis Pipe Line Company. The cash transaction is expected to be completed in 60 to 90 days, Aquila said in a statement. Aquila has now agreed to sell $483 million in assets this year, its chief executive, Robert Green, said in the statement.

title: Experts Scaling Back Their Estimates of World Population Growth
description: Demography has never been an exact science. Ever since social thinkers began trying to predict the pace of population growth a century or two ago, the people being counted have been surprising the experts and confounding projections. Today, it is happening again as stunned demographers watch birthrates plunge in ways they never expected.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Ex-President In Limbo
description: A High Court judge postponed his ruling on whether former President Frederick Chiluba can be stripped of his immunity from prosecution. Mr. Chiluba, who stepped down in January, has been accused of presiding over widespread corruption during his 10 years in office, and two of his closest aides have been arrested on charges of stealing state funds or resources. The new president, Levy Mwanawasa, and the opposition-led Parliament have been pressing for Mr. Chiluba's immunity to be lifted as part of a broad anticorruption campaign. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Coping With Health Hazards When on the Go

On the flight, he took aspirin as a precaution against blood clots in his legs. His colleagues, traveling to the region for the first time, were immunized for hepatitis A and B.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Conciliatory Move Toward Separatists
description: In a surprising move, the government said it wanted to continue negotiations with separatist rebels in the resource-rich northern province of Aceh rather than declare a military emergency. The senior minister in charge of security, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, said the government expected rebels of the Free Aceh Movement to recognize a new law on special autonomy as a condition for talks. The government had promised for weeks that it would have a new policy on the conflict, and speculation had centered on tougher measures. The more conciliatory approach came after the visit of the retired American general Anthony C. Zinni, who urged both sides to pursue talks. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: DIAL CONSIDERS BUYING CONSUMER PRODUCTS BUSINESSES
description: The Dial Corporation, the maker of Dial soap and Purex detergent, said it would consider buying consumer products businesses, buying back shares and reducing debt after failing to find a buyer after a yearlong search. The board of Dial, which is based in Scottsdale, Ariz., says the company can compete better with industry giants like the Procter & Gamble Company as part of a larger business.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett To Make Low-Cost Computer
description: Hewlett-Packard, the world's second-largest computer maker, said yesterday that it would begin selling a $549 business computer that includes a low-cost Athlon processor from Advanced Micro Devices. The computer also features graphics chips from Nvidia Inc., Hewlett said in a statement. The Athlon processor used in the Compaq D315 is cheaper than comparable semiconductors from Intel. Dell Computer, a Hewlett rival, has gained customers after lowering prices. Computer makers are seeking to bolster sales as the economy cools and customers cut purchases, analysts have said. Shares of Hewlett, based in Palo Alto, Calif., fell 6 cents, to $15. They have fallen 18 percent since the company completed its $25.3 billion acquisition of Compaq Computer in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOURAUD, JACKSON S.
description: GOURAUD-Jackson S., Colonel Jackson S. Gouraud (ret.) died August 17, 2002. He was 83 years old. Jackson Gouraud was born on September 7, 1918 to Powers St. George Gouraud & Irma Schlesinger Hunt in New York City. He graduated from Townsend Harris and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. He also lectured at Yale University on nuclear proliferation. During W.W. II, Mr. Gouraud enlisted in the United States Army. He survived a plane crash in the jungles of British Guiana and later fought as a combat company Commander in the Battle of the Bulge. After the war, he served as Senior Officer for Sub-Sahara Africa. He retired from military service as a full Colonel. He was awarded the Legion of Merit, Purple Heart, Combat Infantry Badge and Bronze Star. He joined Pfizer Corp. in 1953, where he launched the Veterinary and Animal Health Division whose annual revenue now exceeds $3 billion. Col. Gouraud co-founded the first marketing consulting firm in the U.S. in 1960. Among his marketing achievements, included launching Valium for Roche, introducing split-run advertising and creating the science of persuasion. Gouraud joind the Department of Energy during the Carter administration as Deputy Under-Secretary. He was responsible for the commercialization of all alternative energy sources. He subsequently became Chairman and President of the Solar Energy Industries and Association. He took Energy Clinic Corporation public and was Chairman of Servamatic Systems, then the largest solar energy company. Col. Gouraud was the seventh generation to serve in the American military and was also a member of the Sons of the American Revolution. He was very proud of many of his ancestors including his greatgrandfather George Snow who co-founded the Herald Tribune with Horace Greeley. Gouraud's grandfather, George Edward Gouraud, received the Congressional Medal of Honor for heroism in the Civil War at the Battle of Honey Hill South Carolina. Jackson met Sheila M. McCowan in British Guiana in 1941. They were married on January 31, 1942. She preceeded him in death in October 1994. In 1996, he married Betty Upham Buffum, who survives him. He is also survived by his daughter Meg, son George, daughter-in-law Tracey and grandsons Michael Briley and Charles and Steven Gouraud. He will be buried in Arlington National Cemetery. Funeral arrangements are pending.

title: No Talks on Toughest Issue
description: When the union set a strike date last Friday, it left negotiators for the owners and the players 13 days to try to work out a new labor agreement. Now 10 days remain before the Aug. 30 deadline, and the two sides have not returned to their debate on the most difficult issue in the talks, a luxury tax on payrolls.

title: Qwest to Sell Yellow Pages For $7 Billion
description: Qwest Communications International, the debt-laden telephone company, agreed last night to sell its yellow pages directories business to a group of financiers for $7 billion in a move that would help it avert a bankruptcy filing.

title: An A-League Team Has 90 Minutes to Shine
description: In nearly every country, the allure of domestic cup competitions (like the storied F.A. Cup in England, the oldest in the world) is the prospect of the proverbial minnow knocking a rich cousin out of the tournament.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Jobless Rate Hits Record
description: Hong Kong's jobless rate rose to a seventh consecutive record in July, dimming hopes the economy will pull out of a slump this quarter. Unemployment rose to 7.8 percent, from 7.7 percent in June, seasonally adjusted, leaving 275,000 of Hong Kong's 3.5 million workers out of a job, the government said. Job seekers may not find relief soon, Antony Leung, the financial secretary, said. High unemployment ''will be endured for another two quarters,'' he said at a news conference. Government economists forecast that the jobless rate may rise further, he said, without giving a forecast. Consumers are spending less as they lose their jobs or expect to be laid off, cutting retail sales and prolonging a 44-month slide in consumer prices.

title: A New Generation Of Journalists
description: To the Editor:

title: Padres' Owner Ready to Sit For a Season
description: While players were setting a strike date last Friday, Yankees officials were meeting with Major League Baseball officials to express their concerns about the impact the clubs' collective bargaining goals would have on the Yankees.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Feature Blocks Pop-Up Ads
description: EarthLink added a feature yesterday that will let subscribers block pop-up ads on the Internet. Earthlink, an Internet provider based in Atlanta, claimed it was the first major Internet provider to make available free software that can prevent advertising windows from appearing above or below their main browser window. Subscribers can disable the software for Web sites they specify -- like sports sites, for instance, where pop-up windows sometimes contain editorial content. (The software does not work on Macintosh computers.) Users may also override the software if they want to view certain ads. EarthLink, which has 4.9 million subscribers, acquired the technology for this service, which is available on EarthLink.com, from FailSafe Technology Inc. EarthLink said it would include the feature in next year's release of its Internet software. Rob Kaiser, EarthLink's vice president for narrowband marketing, said the service would ''minimize the aggravation of unwanted, seemingly incessant pop-up ads.'' Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

description: FINKELSTEIN - Sally. Fe bruary 1, 1907 to August 19, 2002. Adored grandmother, great-grandmother. ''Sal.'' Her sense of humor and M&M's are with her always. title: Television Is Making League Little in Name Only
description: As a business, Little League Baseball is not enormous, considering its scope: 2.8 million baseball and softball players belong to 7,300 leagues in 104 countries.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Wins Contract From Boeing
description: I.B.M., the world's largest computer maker, has won a contract from Boeing for 66 servers to be used in a United States missile defense system. I.B.M.'s high-end p690 Regatta servers along with eServer workstations will be installed in the ground-based midcourse defense program, for which Boeing is the prime contractor, said Greg Lefelar, the eServer federal manager at I.B.M. The company will also maintain the servers for five years, he said. The Pentagon has said it plans to request about $48 billion in missile-defense research through 2007. Mr. Lefelar declined to give the value of the contract. I.B.M. typically sells Regatta servers for $800,000 to $2 million apiece. Shares of International Business Machines rose $3.14, or 4 percent, to $82.49 yesterday.

title: In Florence, Michelangelo Has His Moment; Three Exhibitions Explore How the Master Influenced Art and the Notion of Beauty
description: With the statue of David never without a crowd of worshipers at the Galleria dell'Accademia, it could be said that every year is a Michelangelo year in Florence. But thanks to three exhibitions here this summer, il Divino, as Michelangelo is known to Italian devotees, seems more present than ever. In spirit at least. In reality, taken together, the three shows display fewer than a score of drawings and only a handful of sculptures that are confidently attributed to him.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Singapore; Learning to Have Fun While Getting Things Done
description: Travelers know Singapore as the place in Southeast Asia to get things done, not to have fun. Yet as Singapore emerges from its worst recession since independence in 1965, there's something more than tropical humidity in the air. This port city is trying to recast itself as a lifestyle capital.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Edward Brodney, an artist who painted American soldiers in World War II, misstated the date of his death in some copies. It was Aug. 3, not this past Saturday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Cigarette-Tax Evasion Scheme
description: A police sting operation has led to the arrest of a woman on charges of possessing counterfeit cigarette-tax stamps made in Paraguay, prosecutors said yesterday. Such American government stamps are used to certify that taxes have been paid. The woman, Aleya Begum, 39, of Queens, signed for a package with more than 100,000 counterfeit tax stamps, the authorities said. At $1.50 each for city and state taxes, the stamps would be worth more than $300,000 in unpaid taxes. New York City's cigarette tax is the highest in the nation. Ms. Begum was charged with criminal possession of a forged instrument and tax violations. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Korean Bidder for SeoulBank Is Chosen Over U.S. Fund
description: The South Korean government said yesterday that it had selected Hana Bank as its preferred bidder for SeoulBank, which the government took over in the 1997-98 economic crisis and has been trying for years to resell. The designation gives Hana Bank, which bid $920 million, exclusive rights to negotiate a final purchase of SeoulBank.

title: Theater Feels a Boost, Uptown and Down
description: Doomsayers have good reason to be concerned about the health of the theater in New York City: a precipitous decline in advance ticket sales, the closing of a number of longtime hits, the expectation of a September doldrums when tourists head home, this year made worse by the 9/11 anniversary.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Cuomo Is Stuck With a Negative Impression
description: With little time left until the Sept. 10 primary in New York, Andrew M. Cuomo is in a quandary. Mr. Cuomo is trailing his rival for the Democratic nomination for governor, H. Carl McCall, and needs to do something to shake up the race. But he and his strategists have concluded that he cannot afford to go on the attack, because it would reinforce the negative impressions many voters already have of Mr. Cuomo.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CONSTRUCTION WORKER KILLED A construction worker was killed yesterday when a one-story concrete slab snapped its cable and crushed him, the authorities said. Police investigators said the death appeared to be an accident, and no criminal charges were filed. The worker, identified as Volodymr Bolehivskyy, 48, of Brooklyn, had been helping to position the slab on the side of a building at 1725 First Avenue, near 89th Street, about 11:30 a.m. He was pronounced dead on the way to the New York Weill Cornell Center. The site manager, Bovis Lend Lease, said Mr. Bolehivskyy had worked for a subcontractor, Pinnacle Industries, which did not respond to phone messages seeking comment.   Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: A Success Story Among Connecticut Cities
description: In a state of wealthy suburbs and floundering cities, census figures being released Tuesday are providing new detail on the one big city in the state bucking the trend.

description: Amtrak restored most of its Acela train service today, but with half of its high-speed fleet still in need of repairs, officials conceded it could be days before the system was fully operational again.

title: An Ethics Lesson for Business Schools
description: When Joseph Wharton established the nation's first business school at the University of Pennsylvania in 1881, he made business law one of five basic business school disciplines. More than a century later, the study of business law has given way to the study of business ethics.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about demands for governments' aid for former fighters in Central American civil wars mislabeled the country on Nicaragua's southern border. It is Costa Rica, not Panama.

title: City Compiles List of Dead And Missing From Sept. 11
description: The New York City medical examiner released a list yesterday of 2,819 people it said were killed or missing in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Oil Prices Near $30 a Barrel, a 15-Month High
description: The price of crude oil is closing in on $30 a barrel and rose to its highest level in 15 months yesterday. It has surged 50 percent this year and is already a drag on the weakening economic recovery in the United States, some economists say.

title: London Hotel Discount
description: Through the rest of the year, the St. James's Club, a five-star hotel at 7-8 Park Place in St. James's, London, has rates of $99 a person, in double occupancy, on Friday, Saturday or Sunday nights, plus tax. The 60-room hotel is on a cul-de-sac in the West End and has a fitness room. Information: (44-207) 629 7688 or www.stjamesclub.co.uk .

title: House Panel Raises Pressure On Ex-Chief Of ImClone
description: The government investigation into ImClone Systems took a more combative tone yesterday as a spokesman for the House Energy and Commerce Committee suggested that ImClone's former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, had not been truthful during an interview with committee investigators and raised the prospect of further criminal charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, ROBERT.

title: GIANT HELICOPTER CRASHES IN RUSSIA
description: A hulking Russian military helicopter, designed for 80 people but carrying at least 132, crash-landed in a minefield near the main military base in Chechnya on Monday, causing explosions that increased a death toll believed to be in the dozens, officials and news agencies reported. A number of soldiers apparently survived the crash only to activate mines on emerging from the wreckage.

title: The Right Message to Egypt
description: At a time when Washington has staked much of its credibility in the Middle East on demanding democratic change in the Palestinian Authority and Iraq, it can no longer remain indifferent to the persecution of democrats in Egypt, the Arab world's most populous country and its biggest recipient of American aid. The Bush administration's decision to freeze additional American assistance to Cairo to protest the treatment of Saad Eddin Ibrahim is a commendable step. Washington's freeze affects only new aid, not the $2 billion a year Egypt continues to receive for signing the 1979 Camp David peace agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLSTEIN, WILLIAM CHARLES
description: WALLSTEIN - William Charles, 88, died on August 16, 2002 after an illness of several months. Beloved father of Nancy W. Newkirk of Bethesda, MD, Richard S. Wallstein of London, England, and the late Michael W. Wallstein, father-in-law of Thomas and Philippa, grandfather of Jennifer and Christopher Newkirk and grandfather-in-law of Kennon S. He retired in 1974 from The West Chemical Company as Vice President and started a long and successful career as a volunteer corporate fundraiser for Channel 13 (WNETNY), The Morgan Library and the New York City Police Foundation. He served for many years as a Deacon of All Souls Unitarian Church of New York. A memorial service will be held on September 15 at 2 PM at All Souls, Lexington Ave. at 80 St., New York, NY. Memorial gifts to the New York City Police Foundation, 345 Park Ave., New York, New York 10154, would be appreciated.

description: Here in the poorest state in the former East Germany, supporters of the reformed Communist party, the Party of Democratic Socialism, feel more faceless than usual.

title: Moscow Journal; Russian Music Pirates Sail on Government Land
description: In an industrial corner of western Moscow, a sleek set of machines in an old printing plant stamp out thousands of compact discs around the clock. The plant owner, Oleg V. Gordiyiko, a stout, ruddy-faced former metals trader, gives tours with a look of pride.

title: Forget Nature. Even Eden Is Engineered.
description: Nearly 70 years ago, a Soviet geochemist, reflecting on his world, made a startling observation: through technology and sheer numbers, he wrote, people were becoming a geological force, shaping the planet's future just as rivers and earthquakes had shaped its past.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Two Green Berets Wounded
description: Two American Special Forces soldiers suffered gunshot wounds on Sunday during an intelligence-gathering mission in Oruzgan Province in the south, a military spokesman said. Col. Roger King said the men, who were not identified, suffered wounds in the calf and upper thigh, and were under medical care at Bagram while awaiting evacuation to Germany. Four Afghan men were detained in the incident, which occurred when the Green Berets were going to ''a specific location'' to check out intelligence information. American military operations in Oruzgam have focused on the hunt for Mullah Mohammed Omar, the fugitive Taliban leader, who is a native of the province. John F. Burns (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the relationship between Sumner M. Redstone, the chief executive of Viacom, and Mel Karmazin, the chief operating officer, misstated the title of Ivan Seidenberg, a Viacom board member. He is chief executive of Verizon Communications, not co-chief.

title: Robert A. Corrigan, President
description: Robert A. Corrigan, a national leader in the urban university and civic engagement movements, became the 12th president of San Francisco State University in September 1988, after serving nine years as chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Boston. At both universities, he has made university-community partnerships and the application of university expertise to community issues a campus hallmark. At San Francisco State, Corrigan heads a university with eight colleges, more than 200 degree programs and 27,000 students. SFSU is one of the 23 campuses in the California State University (CSU) system, the largest four-year public comprehensive university system in the nation.

description: A chart on Sunday with a front-page article about changes planned by the airline industry misstated the first-quarter domestic operating results and, for several carriers, the operating cost per seat-mile, the standard industry measure. A corrected excerpt appears today, on Page C4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGCOPE, EDWIN
description: LONGCOPE-Edwin. A preeminent maritime lawyer who handled several of the most significant marine disaster case of the 20th century, died in New York August 12, 2002 from complications following hip surgery, at the age of 92. Mr. Longcope was awarded the French Legion of Honor in 1969. Interment will be private & a gathering of remembrance will be held at his beloved University Club at a later time.

title: One Name Stays on Bronx Ballot; One Is Off
description: In a blow to the Bronx Democratic Party organization, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the candidate backed by the party for a State Senate seat be removed from the ballot because she did not meet the residency requirements.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamilton Township: Fire Chief Indicted
description: A fire chief has been indicted on charges of stealing more than $20,000 of fire equipment and selling it to another firehouse. The chief, Jay Davenport of the Mizpah Volunteer Fire Department, has been accused of selling new equipment to the Belcoville Volunteer Fire Department. He is also accused of misconduct in connection with the purchase of a new fire truck for his department by failing to reveal his $3,000 commission on the sale. The state attorney general's office said Chief Davenport was responsible for the purchase of new equipment for the department. If convicted, he faces up to 25 years in prison and a $315,000 fine. He could not be reached for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday about a project to film the rebuilding at the World Trade Center site with time-lapse photography reversed the identifications of its co-producers. David Solomon was at the right and Jim Whitaker at the left.

title: On an Altered Planet, New Diseases Emerge as Old Ones Re-emerge
description: As America faces its largest outbreak yet of illness caused by West Nile virus -- 251 cases so far this year, and as many as 1,000 expected -- inevitable questions arise. Why here? Why now? Until 1999, the disease had never even been detected in North America.

title: Icahn Extends XO Note Bid
description: The High River Limited Partnership of Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that it would extend until 5 p.m. today an offer to buy as much as $331 million in senior secured loans of XO Communications. The offer would have expired at 5 p.m. yesterday, a lawyer involved in the deal said.

title: Miscellany
description: * General Motors, Detroit, agreed to extend its five-year marketing partnership with the Women's National Basketball Association, New York. Terms of the new agreement and its length were not disclosed. The deal calls for G.M. to advertise during coverage of games on television as well as on WNBA.com.

title: Playoff Attendance Down in W.N.B.A.
description: The Liberty averaged 14,670 fans at Madison Square Garden during the regular season, second in the Women's National Basketball Association to the Washington Mystics.

title: MAYOR PROMISING BETTER RESPONSE TO CATASTROPHES
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg promised yesterday to make major changes in how the New York Police and Fire Departments handle future catastrophes, including improvements in technology and basic emergency procedures. At the plan's core is an ambitious goal: a profound change in the culture of the Police and Fire Departments, two agencies with a long history of rivalry.

title: Learning to Live With Logging and (Gasp!) Even Liking It
description: ''Bongo!'' Paul Elkan exclaimed as he cruised down a logging road in this dense central African forest, keeping one eye out for animal tracks and the other on oncoming traffic.
