title: Swashbuckling Satirist Takes the Stage With His Pen at the Ready
description: Newspaper cartoons sing, play guitar, dance, dream and throw punches -- with a little help from puppets, slides and a dozen voices from the same mouth -- in ''The Bizarro Bologna Show'' by the syndicated cartoonist Dan Piraro. This one-man show has more characters than all but a few of the scores of entrants in the New York International Fringe Festival, and more laughs than most.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: More White Farmers Arrested
description: The police are continuing to arrest white farmers who have defied a new government law that requires many of the country's 3,500 white farmers to turn over their property to the state. Since last week, when the police began enforcing the 10-day-old law, 193 farmers have been arrested, the chief police spokesman said. More than 100 have appeared in court, a spokesman for the Commercial Farmers Union said. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ENGLAND: INVENSYS SELLS DIVISION: Struggling to reduce a mountain of debt, Invensys, a British manufacturer of factory controls, said it had agreed to sell its sensor business, which is based in Shelby, N.C., to Honeywell International , based in Morristown, N.J., for a net $394 million. Invensys said the sale meant it had completed 60 percent of its $2.3 billion debt-reduction program. The company's shares rose 7.25 percent. Invensys is still trying to sell Rexnord, an engineering firm based in the United States.

title: Talk, and Debate, on Koran As Chapel Hill Classes Open
description: James Moeser, the chancellor of the University of North Carolina here, began his discussion by saying he hoped there would be disagreement in the room.

title: Turning Pro, an Ex-Caddie Carries Out a Dream
description: He was just a caddie, one of many at the Hudson National Golf Club here on Prickly Pear Hill. In this suburban setting, on a gentle summer's day, amid lush greenery and not far from the sparkling, sun-splashed Hudson, it was about as close to heaven as a golfer could get. Provided, that is, the golfer was not hacking all day from behind tree trunks or sunk in bunkers.

title: Israeli Troops Let Palestinian Police Re-enter Bethlehem
description: A convoy of Palestinian jeeps carrying about 100 armed police officers arrived in Bethlehem from Jericho today to begin a trial resumption of Palestinian authority there under an agreement with Israel reached Sunday.

title: Continental Airlines Adding Fees, Grounding Planes
description: Continental Airlines , the nation's fifth-largest carrier, continued an industry trend toward belt-tightening since Sept. 11 today by announcing new passenger fees, service cutbacks, aircraft groundings and other measures intended to save it $80 million for the rest of this year and $350 million in following years.

title: Scatchard Awarded A Two-Year Deal
description: Islanders center Dave Scatchard was awarded a two-year, $2.7 million contract by an arbitrator, according to the N.H.L. players association.

title: Defense Contractor in New Mexico Faces Weapons Charges After Seizure of Warheads
description: A Canadian businessman who owns a defense contracting company has been charged with weapons violations after officials seized thousands of warheads for shoulder-fired anti-tank missiles at his Roswell, N.M., company over the weekend.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Economic Growth Slow Again
description: Germany's economy continues to sputter, growing just 0.25 percent in the second quarter, according to a report released yesterday by the Bundesbank, the German central bank. The estimate, which analysts expected, means the German economy has stagnated for five consecutive quarters. The Bundesbank said the rising euro and the weakening of crucial export markets like the United States could choke off an expected rebound in exports. ''The quick appreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar since April has raised concern that the external impetus, which initiated the economic turnaround, may wane and seriously hurt the recovery,'' the report said. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Giants Run Sprints And Curse Every Yard
description: As soon as left guard Pat Crummey flinched at the line of scrimmage during practice this afternoon, a chorus of players began cursing loudly, badgering the third-team rookie. ''Crummey, that's crummy!'' one said with a predictable yell.

description: As a second deadline for top executives to swear that their companies' numbers are correct came and went, investors seemed in a mood to buy, but few market watchers would draw a direct link between these events.

description: Benjamin C. Thompson, an architect whose exuberant recreation of Faneuil Hall in Boston inspired festival marketplaces around the country and whose Design Research International stores have influenced home furnishings to this day, died on Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 84.

description: The four American teams that have made the greatest impact at the Little League World Series here are Louisville, Ky.; Fort Worth; Worcester, Mass.; and Harlem.

description: CAPLAN-Mark J. Remembering you on your birthday and always. With love, Mom and Dad

description: Jeff Corey, a character actor who was barred from his field in the 1950's because of past association with the Communist Party and then became a prominent Hollywood acting instructor, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 88 and lived in Malibu.

title: A Biblical Heroine Who Captivated a King
description: The fascination with Handel that was a central focus of last season's Great Performers schedule has extended into the Mostly Mozart season, which at this point is hardly a separate festival at all, but an extension of what Lincoln Center's programming department does throughout the year. Even the title of the Great Performers' minifestival, ''George Frideric Handel: Beyond the 'Messiah,' '' has been retained, almost as an assertion of Mostly Mozart's subsidiary nature, not to mention that the summer festival's title is now more of a marketing slogan than a description of the music on offer.

title: Multiple Bands On Parade, Not Afraid To Collide
description: If there were any budding Charles Iveses in or around Lincoln Center late Sunday afternoon, they had plenty of opportunity to stretch their maverick ears and imaginations. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Chief Faces Investors
description: At the annual general meeting of the Elan Corporation in Dublin, the chairman, Garo Armen, faced shareholders and analysts in person for the first time since the company's chief executive and vice chairman resigned last month. Their departures came after a wave of public concern about accounting practices at the company had sent its stock plummeting more than 90 percent. Mr. Armen said internal investigations found ''no signs of impropriety.'' He said he was optimistic about the drugs being developed by Elan, especially for Alzheimer's disease. He said he expected the search for a new chief executive to conclude in three to six months, and that he would not consider taking the position. In an interview, Mr. Armen said a biopharmaceutical company like Elan would be at its optimum size with product revenue of $300 million to $500 million; Elan generated about $1.2 billion in product revenue in 2001. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: President to Presidents
description: Ido believe my contemporaries are a unique generation of university presidents -- academic administrators with a social conscience. As I think back on it, it seems obvious why many of us, who as faculty or students were active in civil rights and the anti-war movement, made the natural progression from political action to university curricular reform. Rejecting the view that higher education should serve a predominantly elite population, we proceeded to overhaul what we perceived as an outmoded university curriculum as we struggled to open up the university to new ideas, new teaching strategies, and most of all to new populations. In my generation of young faculty, at least in the humanities and social sciences, there was a heightened commitment to the values of equity, justice and diversity and a tremendous concern for reforming the very institution that had given those of us who were not from wealthy families our edge -- the university. Our efforts at reform coincided with the articulation of an urban university agenda which a number of AASCU institutions embraced. Those campuses were invariably led, as I recall, by presidents and chancellors who saw an urban commitment as fundamental to an expanded sense of institutional mission. As successful as our generation may have been in challenging established institutional values and educational orthodoxy across the spectrum of American higher education, it seems clear in retrospect that we were quite unsuccessful in articulating a new value system to support the curricula reforms we helped to initiate. Not until very recently has higher education taken on the daunting task of identifying and institutionalizing a new set of civic and moral values to replace those that my generation helped to discard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDGE, PETER
description: EDGE-Peter, 89. Died peacefully at home on August 16th. His parents were Charles Noel Edge & Rosalie Barrow Edge. He was predeceased by his first wife of 30 years, Mary Kerr Edge. He is survived by his wife Charleen Greer Edge, his three children, Deborah, David, Steven Edge, and seven grandchildren. He grew up in New York City and attended Lincoln School. He graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School. He served during WWII in the Coast Guard as LTD JG as a navigator on the USS Spencer in the Atlantic, Mediterranean and the Pacific. He married Mary Kerr in 1947, lived in suburban Chicago. Practiced law as a partner of Arnstein-Lehr. An avid birder, dedicated to conversation, he served Hawk Mountain Sanctuary for over 50 years as a board member, secretary, president. Services will be held at The Church of the Holy Comforter, 222 Kenilworth Ave, Kenilworth, at 2 PM, Thursday, August 22nd. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, 1700 Hawk Mountain Road, Kempton, PA 19529-9379. For more information Hanekamp Funeral Home, 847-272-3890.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Qantas Workers Strike
description: Flights on Qantas Airways were delayed as a 24-hour strike by as many as 6,000 workers forced the airline to change yesterday's schedule. A rival, Virgin Blue Airlines, added flights because of the disruption. Check-in, catering, operations, engineering and maintenance workers, who are members of the Australian Services Union, struck for the second time this month in a dispute with Qantas, Australia's largest airline, over wage increases and job security. Qantas, which will report second-half earnings tomorrow, is trying to cut costs to compete better with discount rivals like Virgin Blue. Labor has accounted for about a quarter of total expenses at Qantas in recent years.

The S.E.C., in a letter the company received Saturday, requested information going back to Sept. 1 about accounting for Wednesday's recall and trading of CryoLife shares, the company said. The inquiry follows a Food and Drug Administration order to recall all tissue processed since Oct. 3 because the company could not ensure that the products were free of bacteria and fungus. CryoLife, based in Kennesaw, Ga., said the F.D.A.'s order does not affect its implantable heart valve business. CryoLife shares were halted before yesterday's announcement.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP: FIRE CHIEF INDICTED A fire chief has been indicted on charges of stealing more than $20,000 of fire equipment and selling it to another firehouse. The chief, Jay Davenport of the Mizpah Volunteer Fire Department, has been accused of selling new equipment to the Belcoville Volunteer Fire Department. He is also accused of misconduct in connection with the purchase of a new fire truck for his department by failing to reveal his $3,000 commission on the sale. The state attorney general's office said Chief Davenport was responsible for the purchase of new equipment for the department. If convicted, he faces up to 25 years in prison and a $315,000 fine. He could not be reached for comment.   Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Howell: 15,000 Left Without Power Briefly
description: An electrical fire left nearly 15,000 residents without power yesterday. The power failure lasted for less than an hour and no injuries were reported from the fire, which broke out at a transformer in a substation. The power failure affected Howell, Lakewood and other towns in central New Jersey, said Scott Surgeoner, spokesman for First Energy, which owns the area utility, Jersey Central Power and Light. It was at least 90 degrees yesterday in central New Jersey, and demand for power was high. ''Right now, we are able to serve the load and we hope to be able to continue that,'' Mr. Surgeoner said.

description: GUADAGNO-Maestro Anton, died on August 16, 2002, in Vienna, Austria, having conducted a performance of ''Otello'' at the opera festival in St. Margarethen, Austria the prior day. Maestro was artistic director and principal conductor of the Palm Beach Opera for over eighteen years. He was a principal conductor of the Vienna State Opera for thirty seasons and also conducted extensively at the Metropolitan Opera, the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden, the Paris Opera and in Tokyo. The Board of Directors, the management, staff, patrons and devoted audience of Palm Beach Opera express their deepest sympathy to his wife, Dolores, and his son, Steven, at the loss of not just a veritable giant in the international opera world but, even more, a warm, devoted and intensively caring husband, father and friend. His musical legacy is secure with Palm Beach Opera and is already the inspiration that will be the guiding principle in forging ahead in memory of its beloved Maestro. His constant example of excellence will be the benchmark for the continuity of Palm Beach Opera. Funeral services will be in New York at a time yet to be determined.

title: MALDEN MILLS IS EMERGING FROM BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Malden Mills Industries, the maker of the Polartec fabrics used in cold-weather clothing, said yesterday that it planned to emerge from bankruptcy protection and repay creditors in full. Malden Mills filed a reorganization plan with the Bankruptcy Court in Worcester, Mass., that will pay all of the company's creditors, including the GE Capital unit of General Electric, in full over time, a spokesman, David Costello, said. He did not provide any details. The closely held Malden Mills, which is based in Lawrence, Mass., drew national attention in 1995 when the chief executive, Aaron Feuerstein, paid employees while he rebuilt the family business after a fire. The debt from rebuilding helped force Malden into bankruptcy. GE Capital was the lead agent for a group of creditors that provided about $140 million in bankruptcy financing, Mr. Costello said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Celebrity Convict Put To Work
description: Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire author and politician jailed on a perjury conviction, started a new job in a theater under a work-release program after serving one year of a four-year sentence. Lord Archer, who once starred in a West End play, arrived at the Theater Royal in Lincoln to start the job, which was described only as ''behind the scenes.'' He was found guilty of lying and forgery to conceal a sexual encounter with a prostitute. Under the work-release program, he must return each evening to the North Sea Camp open prison near Boston, Lincolnshire. While he will be paid an undisclosed amount for his work, the income is not seen as critical: he recently signed a new book deal reportedly worth $15 million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Error Noted In Color Capabilities
description: Palm said yesterday that it had misrepresented the color capabilities of its m130 hand-held computer, which was put on the market in March. At the time, Palm said the computer's screen was capable of displaying 65,536 color combinations. In reality, it displays 58,621 such combinations, an 11 percent difference. The company said it realized the error when participants on a Palm enthusiast Web site started questioning the company's initial claim. The company issued an apology yesterday on its Web site, and said it planned to modify its marketing materials, but the company said it was not intending to offer refunds on the m130. Palm's admission of the discrepancy was first reported in Wired News, an online publication that focuses on technology news.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: CINGULAR WIDENS ROLLOVER PLAN Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest provider of wireless telephone services, said yesterday that it would create a nationwide plan that allows customers to keep their unused monthly minutes. Customers who have not used their minutes in one month will have them rolled over into the next month for up to a year, said Cingular, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications . The offer is available for customers who select a Cingular plan costing $39.99 a month or more. A spokeswoman said that more than 50 percent of Cingular customers would be eligible to roll over their minutes. The plans will also include nationwide long distance at no extra cost. "Rollover lets customers keep what they're paying for," said Virginia Vann, Cingular's chief marketing officer, in a statement. "These plans bring a new value proposition to wireless customers. If they don't use their package minutes, they don't lose their package minutes." Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: JOBLESS RATE HITS RECORD Hong Kong's jobless rate rose to a seventh consecutive record in July, dimming hopes the economy will pull out of a slump this quarter. Unemployment rose to 7.8 percent, from 7.7 percent in June, seasonally adjusted, leaving 275,000 of Hong Kong's 3.5 million workers out of a job, the government said. Job seekers may not find relief soon, Antony Leung, the financial secretary, said. High unemployment "will be endured for another two quarters," he said at a news conference. Government economists forecast that the jobless rate may rise further, he said, without giving a forecast. Consumers are spending less as they lose their jobs or expect to be laid off, cutting retail sales and prolonging a 44-month slide in consumer prices. (Bloomberg News)

description: Pilots at Southwest Airlines overwhelmingly approved a contract extension yesterday in a surprise move that went against union leaders' last-minute recommendation that they reject the proposal.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Dobson Communications Faces Delisting
description: The Dobson Communications Corporation said yesterday that its stock might be delisted from Nasdaq because its shares do not meet a $3 minimum bid requirement. The company said it was told by Nasdaq that its Class A common shares did not comply with the minimum bid price for continued listing. Dobson has until Thursday to decide whether to appeal the notice, a company spokesman, Warren Henry, said. If Dobson asks for a review, shares will continue to trade until the appeal is decided. Shares of Dobson, based in Oklahoma City, fell 19 cents, or 31 percent, to 42 cents. They have fallen 95 percent this year. Dobson, which is partly owned by AT&T Wireless Services, the third-largest United States mobile telephone company, provides wireless service primarily in rural areas and small cities in 17 states.

title: A Slow Bass Joins a Piano In Quiet Tumult
description: Since he emerged more than 40 years ago, the bassist Charlie Haden has excelled in plain-spoken lyricism. In a solo break he'll play his thick, rounded notes in a slow, scale-based procession; what he's doing will seem ingenuous, almost nave, until at a certain point its beauty clicks in. The moving line is often backed by a drone note -- he loves playing his open bottom string -- and the sound recalls the slow, deliberate movement of notes, as well as the bottom-end drone, in white Appalachian gospel music. There is a strong, rousing dose of anti-technique in it, the human touch.

title: Mining Company Withdraws From Zambian Copper Project
description: Anglo American P.L.C., the global mining conglomerate with operations across Africa, said today that it had completed its withdrawal from the Zambian copper industry, closing the books on a failed investment that in little more than two years will have cost the company about $358 million.

title: Harvest The Whales
description: Whale-watching trips off Massachusetts are said to have begun only in 1975, with a pod of elementary school kids taking a boat from Provincetown, but now whale-watching is a $100 million industry in New England. And it's easy to see why: 35-foot humpbacks roll and splash so playfully around the boats that you just want to reach out and hug one.

title: Rumsfeld Says Criticism Won't Determine Policy on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the Bush administration will not necessarily be influenced by criticism in deciding what to do about Iraq, a country that he said clearly tolerates the presence of terrorists.

title: Exxon Loses Court Ruling
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation must pay 54 Texas gasoline-station owners almost $10 million for breach of contract after losing a federal appeals court ruling.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: BLUMENTHAL TO PERSIST IN SCHOOL ACTION Despite being rebuffed by the State Supreme Court, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said he would continue to go after public money from the failed Village Academy charter school. "We are continuing as aggressively as possible to pursue recovery against Village Academy and Robin Barnes," Mr. Blumenthal said. Earlier this month, the high court ruled that Mr. Blumenthal did not have jurisdiction to sue Robin Barnes, the charter school's former president. The school got $1.2 million in state aid. But Mr. Blumenthal said he would pursue a separate 2000 lawsuit against the school's trustees filed on behalf of the State Department of Education. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, ROSLYN
description: ALEXANDER-Roslyn. Educator and librarian, a lady of many talents and graces, passed away on 13 August 2002. Beloved wife of Albert, devoted and much loved mother of Nancy, Howard and Chun Nan, adored and adoring grandmother of Li, Katharyn, Alexandra and Victoria.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Caroline Bishop was named vice president and account director at Mullen, Wenham, Mass. She had most recently been director for client services at the Boston office of the Leo Burnett Technology Group, a unit of Leo Burnett USA, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group. Mullen is part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Woods Ahead and Behind, Beem Held On
description: The P.G.A. Championship was special, because both Rich Beem and Tiger Woods played spectacularly enough to win it.

title: Carmichael Lynch Gets Account
description: The Tractor Supply Company , which operates retail farm and ranch supply stores, said yesterday that it had selected Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies , to handle its account. Spending was estimated at more than $20 million.

title: AstraZeneca Casts Doubts On New Drug
description: The drug company AstraZeneca said today that a crucial trial had found that its new cancer drug, Iressa, did not help patients live longer when used with chemotherapy drugs.

title: Bronx Is Up, And Harlem Is Where?
description: MERCIFULLY, the eligibility dispute over the Little League baseball players from Harlem didn't last long. Officials satisfied themselves that all the youngsters met the standards for living within a district's boundaries and so deserved to represent Harlem in the Little League World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, ALFRED C.
description: MOHR-Alfred C. 98, of West Caldwell, NJ, on July 22, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Martha (Koepell) Mohr. Private funeral services were at Funeral Service of New Jersey, Hillside, NJ. A former member of the Department of Germanic Languages and Literature at Yale University. Previous to this assignment he had served as dean of the Modern Language Department at the McBurney School for Boys in New York City. He was born in Vienna, Austria, and came with his parents to the United States at the age of two. Subsequently he attended the Morgan Preparatory School in Clinton, CT, where he was the president of his class and valedictorian. Mr. Mohr entered Yale on a Middlesex County, CT scholarship and graduated with a BA degree in 1926. While at Yale he was the Heel and Toe Race-Walking Champion and captain of the Yale chess team. He sang in the Battell Chapel Choir and and the glee club in which his specialty was the Swiss yodel which he taught and coached subsequent Yale Glee Club yodelers. In 1932 he received his Masters degree at Columbia University whereupon he entered the University of Berlin to continue his studies. During the Second World War, he served as Technical Specialist for the Aeronautical Division of the Chrysler Corporation's new Dodge Chicago plant, after which he went into business for himself as a Chrysler Corporation automobile dealer in Caldwell and Newark, NJ. Before retiring, he had been a member of the Modern Language Association of America, a founding member and officer of the #

title: City Is Told To Rethink Shelter at Jail
description: A judge yesterday told the city to come up with a plan to vacate a former jail in the Bronx that has been used to house homeless families, but allowed the temporary shelter to remain open while that plan is being developed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIGELMAN, JESSICA
description: SPIGELMAN-Jessica. Age 38. Fought bravely for two months after a heart transplant. She was the beloved daughter of the late Sondra Spigelman and is survived by her father and stepmother, David & Nancy, her brothers Andrew and Fred, and sister Samantha. Services will be held at the Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapels, Inc., 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, 718-853-4000.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY IS BUYING CTB FOR $140 MILLION
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment company headed by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, agreed to acquire the farm-equipment maker CTB International Corporation for $140 million in cash, plus the assumption of $40 million in debt. Shareholders of CTB, which is based in Milford, Ind., will receive $12.75 a share, 13 percent less than Friday's closing price. CTB's 1,300 workers design and make equipment used to feed and house chickens and hogs, gather eggs and store grain.

title: Wilpon to Get a New Title, But It's the Same Old Mets
description: Fred Wilpon will lose the prefix from his co-owner title and become the sole man in charge of the Mets' organization within the next month. Last week's agreement to buy out Nelson Doubleday's half of the team assured that. But while Wilpon took steps to gain full control, the Mets were throwing away their season.

title: Unproductive Medicare Bashing
description: Medicare, the venerable health care program for the elderly, is under attack again. Congress's failure to provide prescription drugs for older people can be attributed partly to Republican refusal to consider making the benefit part of Medicare, which many said should be ''reformed'' before it is expanded. Then last week President Bush engaged in more Medicare bashing, describing the Great Society program as ''old,'' ''stale,'' ''tired'' and in need of radical surgery.

title: POWER DISRUPTION AT PLANT AFFECTS ROHM & HAAS PROFIT
description: The Rohm & Haas Company, which makes chemicals, said yesterday that second-half profit may be as much as 5 cents a share lower than analysts expect after a power disruption at a Texas plant cut shipments of a material used in paint, floor polish and textiles. Rohm & Haas was able to generate only 85 percent of its average monthly output of methyl methacrylate because of the loss of power at its Deer Park, Tex., chemical plant, the company said. The company was expected to earn 96 cents in the second half of the year, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.

title: Advertising; Newspaper ads are down again, causing worries that the slump is not ending after 18 months.
description: JUST a month ago, the newspaper industry was somewhat optimistic about the near future after a mildly encouraging ad-page performance in the second quarter. But now it is having second thoughts.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Medicare Formula Disputed
description: Gov. Tom Vilsack is challenging the formula for allocating Medicare financing because medical professionals in the state receive the least amount of Medicare reimbursement in the nation for the services provided. The governor said Iowa hospitals and clinics find it hard to recruit and retain quality personnel because the same services get higher compensation in other states. He has asked Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of Health and Human Services, to end the disparity. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: More Mature Whitmore Rewards Liberty's Faith
description: Tamika Whitmore of the Liberty has changed.

title: War-Making and Bumper Stickers
description: To the Editor:

title: Small-Picture Approach to a Big Problem: Poverty
description: Though rich countries may be able to rescue middle-class economies like those of Uruguay and Brazil from crises simply by lending them billions of dollars, attacking the problems of the poorest countries is not so easy. Putting aside old, one-size-fits-all approaches to development, a new school of thought emphasizes more specific grass-roots solutions.

title: Corrections
description: Amap yesterday with an article about demands for governments' aid for former fighters in Central American civil wars mislabeled the country on Nicaragua's southern border. It is Costa Rica, not Panama.

title: Market Place; To Many, Vivendi Headquarters Is Still Sending Mixed Signals
description: When Jean-Ren Fourtou took the helm of Vivendi Universal last month, he was quick to criticize the way his predecessor, Jean-Marie Messier, communicated with investors. But Mr. Fourtou appears to be having just as much trouble communicating Vivendi's strategy.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: ERROR NOTED IN COLOR CAPABILITIES Palm said yesterday that it had misrepresented the color capabilities of its m130 hand-held computer, which was put on the market in March. At the time, Palm said the computer's screen was capable of displaying 65,536 color combinations. In reality, it displays 58,621 such combinations, an 11 percent difference. The company said it realized the error when participants on a Palm enthusiast Web site started questioning the company's initial claim. The company issued an apology yesterday on its Web site, and said it planned to modify its marketing materials, but the company said it was not intending to offer refunds on the m130. Palm's admission of the discrepancy was first reported in Wired News, an online publication that focuses on technology news.

title: Carmichael Lynch Gets Account
description: The Tractor Supply Company, which operates retail farm and ranch supply stores, said yesterday that it had selected Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its account. Spending was estimated at more than $20 million.

title: Gay Couples' Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Torrid Hitting By Williams Is Taking A Day Off
description: With tongue in cheek, someone asked Jason Giambi if today's off day would have a negative effect on his teammate Bernie Williams. The Yankees rested before opening a series with Anaheim at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night. Williams paced a 5-1 trip with 17 hits in 29 at-bats to raise his batting average to .340.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, NELLIE (NEE LEVI)
description: LOEB-Nellie (nee Levi). Peacefully on August 11, 2002 in Washington Heights, N.Y. Born in Neuhof, Germany, April 19, 1905. Beloved wife of the late Max, her husband of 45 years; sister of the late Jennie Kahn and the late Meita Levi. she is survived by her brother Leo and her nieces Ruth and Marion. We will miss her elegant style, her love of the arts, and her independence of spirit. May she be remembered in peace.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: IOWA: FREEDOM SHORT-LIVED Members of an animal-rights group cut fences and broke open pens at an Iowa mink farm on Sunday, releasing hundreds of the cat-sized animals, which are prized for their fur. Becky Demuth, who owns the farm with her husband, Nick, said about 1,200 mink escaped. Half were recovered, Mrs. Demuth said, while others were run over by vehicles or killed by dogs. "Those that are recovered are in high stress," she said. "They're not used to running free." A spokesman for the Animal Liberation Front, David Barbarash, said he received an anonymous e-mail message in which members of the group took responsibility for the attack. (AP)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: MORE WHITE FARMERS ARRESTED The police are continuing to arrest white farmers who have defied a new government law that requires many of the country's 3,500 white farmers to turn over their property to the state. Since last week, when the police began enforcing the 10-day-old law, 193 farmers have been arrested, the chief police spokesman said. More than 100 have appeared in court, a spokesman for the Commercial Farmers Union said. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Harvey Kapnick, 77, Former Chairman At Arthur Andersen
description: Harvey E. Kapnick, a former chairman and chief executive of Arthur Andersen who in the 1970's raised concerns about conflicts of interest between the accounting and consulting arms of the firm, died last Friday. He was 77 and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Construction Worker Killed
description: A construction worker was killed yesterday when a one-story concrete slab snapped its cable and crushed him, the authorities said. Police investigators said the death appeared to be an accident, and no criminal charges were filed. The worker, identified as Volodymr Bolehivskyy, 48, of Brooklyn, had been helping to position the slab on the side of a building at 1725 First Avenue, near 89th Street, about 11:30 a.m. He was pronounced dead on the way to the New York Weill Cornell Center. The site manager, Bovis Lend Lease, said Mr. Bolehivskyy had worked for a subcontractor, Pinnacle Industries, which did not respond to phone messages seeking comment. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; 'Let's Roll' Demeans Real Heroes
description: UP to now, the most annoying thing ever to emanate from Florida State has been the tomahawk chop, a patronizing parody of alleged American Indian war cries, with accompanying chopping motions.

title: From Montreal to Rio to Johannesburg: 15 Years of Environmental Accords
description: Dozens of international accords aimed at protecting the environment have been enacted in recent decades. Some are fine-tuned, like an agreement adopted last year to save albatrosses and petrels. Others are as broad as the atmosphere, including treaties that ban ozone-destroying chemicals.

title: Ford Stresses Business, but Disappoints Environmentalists
description: After a delay of almost four months, Ford Motor will release its third annual corporate citizenship report today.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: TWO GREEN BERETS WOUNDED Two American Special Forces soldiers suffered gunshot wounds on Sunday during an intelligence-gathering mission in Oruzgan Province in the south, a military spokesman said. Col. Roger King said the men, who were not identified, suffered wounds in the calf and upper thigh, and were under medical care at Bagram while awaiting evacuation to Germany. Four Afghan men were detained in the incident, which occurred when the Green Berets were going to "a specific location" to check out intelligence information. American military operations in Oruzgam have focused on the hunt for Mullah Mohammed Omar, the fugitive Taliban leader, who is a native of the province. John F. Burns (NYT)

title: Fixing the Fire Department
description: A consulting firm report released yesterday on the performance of the New York Fire and Police Departments on Sept. 11 focused mainly on problems that have been clear for a long time -- hostile relations between the departments, and a fire department with insufficient resources and an inefficient command structure. The terrible losses of Sept. 11, combined with the authority of the McKinsey & Company report, may be enough to spur real change.

title: Fairness for Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Recommended Changes in Procedure
description: Following are some top recommendations of McKinsey & Company for changes in city emergency procedures. The complete reports are available at www.nyc.gov.

title: Brakettes Win Title, but Can't Say They Beat the Best
description: The Women's Major Fast Pitch National Softball Tournament concluded here tonight, with the host Brakettes edging the California Hurricanes, 1-0, to win their 24th national title. But the tournament was bedeviled by a scheduling conflict that left the game's 17 best players in San Diego preparing for an international tournament in Japan that begins next week.

title: Aversion to U.S. Airports Is Rooted in Stress Factor
description: IN 20 years of business travel, Kathy Ewing has racked up 1.8 million frequent-flier miles on Delta Air Lines alone. That makes her, by anyone's definition, a frequent flier, one of those who form the backbone of the airline market. So anyone wondering about the long-term outlook for airlines would do well to consider her current travel patterns.

title: Fall Hits the Stores, and So Do the Shoppers
description: Helen Schifter, the Upper East Side socialite, is trying to snag some Juicy Couture. ''You know,'' she said helpfully, ''those cashmere sweats and jackets that cost $200? Adorable. I've already been to Scoop, Bergdorf Goodman and Barneys, and I can't find them anywere.'' What Ms. Schifter has found, so far, are two Prada satin skirts, a pair of $495 custom Michael Kors jeans and a rainbow-bright Louis Vuitton sweater evocative of Ali MacGraw in ''Love Story.'' The matching long scarf is extra. ''Unfortunately,'' she said.

title: Power House
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: People Smugglers Charged In Deaths
description: Federal prosecutors filed charges against 11 accused smugglers who left 14 Mexicans to die in the Arizona desert last year. The organized-crime indictments against seven men and four women followed a raid and arrests in the Mexican border town of Nogales. Mexican officials said the group abandoned 25 migrants on May 23, 2001, near Yuma, Ariz. Only 11 survived. The 14 deaths were the most ever recorded in a single border crossing in Arizona. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, WILLIAM L. (BILLY)
description: LIVINGSTON-William L. (Billy), artist-producer. Died 17 August, 2002, after a long illness. Beloved friend of Joel Key Rice. He is also survived by his brother, Dr. Carver Van Wyke Livingston of Scottsdale, Ariz., 3 nephews and a niece. A gift of remembrance may be made to: Livingston Rice Memorial Fund, St. Bartholemew's Church, 109 East 50 Street, NY, NY 10022. A gala memorial celebrating his life will be announced at a future date.

title: Fears That Lending to Brazil May Dry Up
description: Nearly two weeks after the Bush administration threw its support behind a $30 billion loan to rescue the Brazilian government from financial collapse, American officials and the International Monetary Fund are worried about whether big international banks will keep lending to Brazilian private industry.

title: Campaigning About A-Plants, But Without Actual Power
description: Both candidates for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in New York are trolling for votes by saying that they want the Indian Point nuclear reactors closed. The Republican incumbent, in a shift, refuses to rule out the idea.

title: 1-2 Combo Makes TV Debut
description: H. Carl McCall, who is campaigning for the Democratic nomination for governor, and Dennis Mehiel, who is seeking the nomination for lieutenant governor, combine forces for the first time in this 30-second television commercial, which went on the air statewide yesterday. The spot comes one week after Charlie King, Mr. Mehiel's opponent, took issue with the merged finances of the campaigns of Mr. Mehiel and Mr. McCall, calling the arrangement a violation of the spirit of campaign finance laws on the grounds that by sharing expenses, Mr. Mehiel essentially donates money to Mr. McCall above the legal limit. Yesterday, Mr. King attacked the joint ad, saying that things ''had gone too far.'' But Mr. McCall and Mr. Mehiel said they had split both face time and the cost of the spot evenly.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Pregnant Woman Strangled
description: A 28-year-old woman who was eight months pregnant was found strangled on Sunday in a Bronx hotel she had been referred to by the city's Department of Homeless Services, the authorities said yesterday. The police have not determined a motive. The woman, Claire Cooper-Tognolli, was found in her room at the Park Overlook Hotel, 1938 Webster Avenue in Tremont, shortly before midnight with a telephone cord wrapped around her neck, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Bush Team Is Campaigning to Muster Opposition in Africa to Mugabe's Rule
description: The Bush administration said today that it was working to foster opposition to President Robert Mugabe in Zimbabwe, calling his rule illegitimate and irrational.

title: The Latest Essential for College Applicants: A Summer Already Spent on Campus
description: Some might call them classic overachievers, making every minute count to improve their college applications. But for many high school students, spending a month or two on campus is more than a striver's summer camp. It is a chance to get a glimpse of campus life, both academically and socially, and it is no longer an extra but something that some colleges expect -- like Advanced Placement courses taken during the school year.

title: Strike at Animal Disease Center Prompts Concerns for Safety
description: The first strike ever at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, the high-security laboratory off Long Island that conducts research on dangerous infectious animal diseases, has raised concerns among striking union members, workers still on the island and government officials about the center's ability to function safely and effectively.

title: Soham Journal; Girls' Killing Melts British Reserve
description: In this land once known for veiled emotion, people have come to show their grief in public with flowers and tears, a release displayed when millions mourned Diana, Princess of Wales, in public five years ago.

title: Chatty Owners Too Loud for Selig
description: They are lining up at the entrance to Bud Selig's woodshed -- George Steinbrenner, Tom Hicks, John Moores. More owners are destined to join them. They simply can't restrain themselves from speaking out, and when they do, they risk incurring $1 million fines, the designated penalty for violating the commissioner's rule stipulating silence on labor matters.

title: Panel Urges Caution in Producing Gene-Altered Animals
description: Although there is no evidence that cows, sheep and other animals reproduced through cloning are unsafe to eat, more caution is needed on animals engineered to contain genes from other species, a panel of scientists said today.

title: Agency Approves Trial of Interferon to Treat West Nile Virus
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it had approved a national trial of a drug to determine whether it could become the first specific therapy against the West Nile virus.

title: Debt Rating Of Malaysia Is Upgraded
description: The rehabilitation of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia on the international financial stage appears to be all but complete.

title: Worldly Style Paints the Town House Red
description: ROUGE, the town house restaurant that opened in March on the Upper East Side, presents an inviting face. It has a well-known chef, David Ruggerio, who made his early reputation cooking at high-end French restaurants like La Caravelle, Maxim's and Le Chantilly. It has a lovely parlor dining room with a high ceiling, marigold and cranberry walls etched with stylized fleurs-de-lis, a fireplace and big windows overlooking East 62nd Street.

title: Harlem Reaches The Quarterfinals Behind 3 Homers
description: When the Harlem all-stars played Aptos, Calif., in the Little League World Series today, there was no mystery: for each team, it was win or go home.

title: Murder and the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Injured Giants Try to Stay Current
description: If Tim Carter ran the way he did before the Giants drafted him in April, he would have caught the spiraling throw Jesse Palmer hurled into the right corner of the end zone today. But there was no speedy burst from Carter, no explosive movement to separate himself from the two defenders in the Giants' practice, and the ball bounced and rolled to a stop.

title: Critic's Notebook; In Salzburg, Striking Sets For Staples
description: Last month at the opening ceremony of this summer's Salzburg Festival, the new artistic director, Peter Ruzicka, declared that he had no intention of becoming a ''taste pope,'' ''moral apostle'' or the ''principal person of the festival.''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: ILL-GOTTEN GAINS RETURNED TO PERU Switzerland said it had transferred to Peru nearly $78 million after determining that it came from illegal commissions on arms deals paid to Peru's former spy chief Vladimiro Montesinos, left, who was sentenced in Peru last month to nine years in prison after being convicted of corruption. Mr. Montesinos, who was seen as the main power broker during the presidency of Alberto K. Fujimori, who resigned in disgrace in 2000 and fled to Japan, still faces charges including money-laundering, blackmail, drug running and heading a paramilitary hit squad.

description: To the Editor:

title: Richard I. Queen, 51, Hostage Freed Early by Iranians in '80
description: Richard I. Queen, an American diplomat among those taken hostage by Iranian militants in 1979, who was released early when he developed multiple sclerosis, died on Aug. 14 at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 51.

title: Report Cites Danger In Off-Road Vehicle
description: Four-wheel all-terrain vehicles are just as dangerous as the three-wheel versions that the federal government banned in the late 1980's, according to a report from a coalition of consumer and environmental groups.

title: School's Out for Summer? Not Anymore
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Leads Liberty Into Conference Finals
description: The Liberty was determined not to let Tamika Catchings prevail, and she didn't, and now the Liberty is on to the second round of the W.N.B.A. playoffs and another run at a league title.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What you're raised with, you grow to become.''

title: Accounts
description: * Supercuts, Minneapolis, a division of the Regis Corporation, to MediaCom, New York, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle media planning and buying for its account, with billings estimated at $15 million. Those duties had been at the San Francisco office of Universal McCann, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: CNN Now Says It Paid $30,000 For Its Videotapes of bin Laden
description: CNN said yesterday that it paid about $30,000 to people in Afghanistan for the videotapes of Osama bin Laden and operatives of Al Qaeda it has been showing this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Pope John Paul II's visit to Poland, where he alluded to abortion in his homily during a Mass on Sunday, referred incorrectly to the regulation of abortion in Poland. While it is legal in special cases including pregnancies resulting from rape, it is otherwise restricted.

title: Porsche Is Balking at U.S. Auditing Rule
description: Driving a Porsche may be a totem of success for high-level corporate executives from Beverly Hills to Bronxville. But Porsche is not about to be held to the same standards of accountability as its A-list American customers.

title: Weaker Dollar Has Yet to Spur a Boom in Exports
description: The nation's trade deficit has narrowed slightly from record highs, the Commerce Department said yesterday, but the falling value of the dollar has yet to spur a boom in exports that could jump-start the sputtering economic recovery.

title: The Lost Art of Penmanship
description: Is the handwritten word making a comeback? Some of the laptop-like ''tablet'' PC's being released this year allow users to write directly on the screen with a stylus -- employing their own longhand, not the modified alphabet required by previous recognition programs.

description: Former Enron Executive Expected to Take Plea Deal
