title: A Human Face on North Koreans' Plight
description: Sitting on the orange linoleum floor of her apartment, Kim Han Mee turned away from Cleo, her stuffed rabbit, distracted by a newspaper photo of her arrest.

title: Chatty Owners Too Loud for Selig
description: They are lining up at the entrance to Bud Selig's woodshed  George Steinbrenner, Tom Hicks, John Moores. More owners are destined to join them. They simply can't restrain themselves from speaking out, and when they do, they risk incurring $1 million fines, the designated penalty for violating the commissioner's rule stipulating silence on labor matters.

title: All Hail the Campus Kings
description: Several New York institutions rate highly on the various lists included in the new edition of The Princeton Review's ''Best 345 Colleges,'' which was published yesterday by Random House. The City University of New York-Brooklyn College, left, ranks No. 1 for its beautiful campus. Meanwhile, New York University is top-ranked as the place where the most ''students from different race/class backgrounds interact,'' and where ''nobody plays intramural sports.'' It was considered the school located in the greatest college town. It also ranked No. 2 for ''great college theater.''

title: Neighbor of California Girl Convicted of Murder
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 21  A neighbor of a 7-year-old girl who disappeared from her suburban bedroom here in February was found guilty today of her abduction and murder, the first in a string of such crimes to capture public attention this year.

title: Teaching Islam: A Controversy
description: To the Editor:

title: It's 1998 Again for Upbeat Testaverde
description: Vinny Testaverde knows he will probably never recreate those remarkable statistics of 1998, what he still calls ''that magical season,'' his first as a Jet.

title: Georgia Tire Plant Opens
description: Pirelli, one of Europe's leading tire companies, said yesterday that it had opened its first United States tire factory fitted with a robot system that cuts production time.

title: New Threats to Clean Water
description: The environmental community and the Bush administration are at odds again, this time over proposed changes in a key part of the Clean Water Act. The changes would give states greater leeway in deciding which waterways need to be cleaned and how rapidly to do the job. The administration says that such flexibility is necessary to make the act work. Environmentalists fear yet another rollback of existing protections.

title: Chilled Soup That Really Tingles
description: MANY Americans, born to chowders and raised on bisques, consider cold soup an oxymoron. Part of the problem may be cultural, but another part is simply culinary. Chances are good that if you have had a cold soup recently, you've had a bad one. And that's a shame. A well-designed cold soup is spare, elegant and witty -- a perfect dinner companion in summer's waning days.

title: Boy, 13, in Custody Fight Gets to Decide His Own Fate
description: A 13-year-old South Dakota boy at the center of a custody battle between his biological father and his late mother's male companion has been given the chance to choose with whom he will live.

title: Zones of Devastation From 9/11: Mapping the Victims by ZIP Code
description: Almost from the moment that the World Trade Center towers collapsed on Sept. 11, as people attempted to grasp the magnitude of the attack by tallying losses, they have tried to figure out which towns and neighborhoods were worst hit.

title: Martha Stewart Gives Panel Records in ImClone Inquiry
description: Martha Stewart delivered more than 1,000 pages of documents -- including e-mail messages from her laptop and telephone records -- yesterday afternoon to the Congressional committee investigating the sale of her ImClone Systems stock.

title: Fresh Food Spills Out in Front of City Hall (the Restaurant)
description: Henry Meer, the chef and owner of the Cub Room and City Hall, gets some of his summer produce directly from Beechnut Farm in Bridgehampton, N.Y., which is owned by his cousin Wilfred Heilbert. Mr. Meer travels there on weekends to help with the harvest, and now he has set up a small farm stand in front of City Hall, 131 Duane Street (Church Street).

title: Supplies for Needy Students
description: It could easily cost $250 to outfit a child for school with sneakers, binders and notebooks, consuming the pay of a parent who makes $8 an hour. With that in mind, New Jersey's largest food bank, the Community FoodBank in Hillside, has begun offering supplies for needy students in time for the first day of classes. The Kids in Need Resource Center, located at the food bank, is one of a dozen in the nation sponsored by the School, Home and Office Products Association. The center opened on Thursday and will run year round. The food bank will distribute pens, paper and art supplies through social service agencies and after-school programs in the Newark area. Julie Flaherty

title: Helicopter Crash Exposes Putin to Political Fallout
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 21  The catastrophic loss of a Russian military helicopter on Monday has exposed all that has gone wrong with Moscow's war in Chechnya and the potential political consequences of President Vladimir V. Putin's inability to end it.

title: Rolling Up a Little Bit of Heaven
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Judge Accused Of Green-Card Scheme
description: A retired Long Island judge has been accused of participating in sham marriages in a scheme to get immigrants green cards for permanent residency. The retired judge, Lawrence J. Goldstein, 77, pleaded not guilty on Monday to a charge of establishing a business to violate immigration laws. Mr. Goldstein is accused of conducting the weddings in his home in Hempstead and charging $75 for each one. His lawyer, Ronald J. Bekoff, said Mr. Goldstein ''lacked any criminal intent to obtain any criminal goals.'' Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: A Swaggering Hot Sauce With a Peppercorn Fuse
description: It looks both enticing and a tad lethal. San-J Cracked Pepper Sauce delivers on the first count and comes nicely close on the second, leaving the mouth aglow. Designed for steaks and barbecue, it is tamari-based and differs from similar condiments because it offers not just the typical blend of spice, sweet and sour, but also chewy texture from a thick component of cracked black and white peppercorns and minced red bell pepper. It is a bold foil for grilled or roasted beef or pork, superb to brush on potato cubes as they roast or eggplant as it grills. Added to a red wine vinaigrette, it will give swagger to a salad. A 12-ounce bottle is about $3 at many D'Agostino and Safeway markets.

title: Suit Attacks Plan to Change Blue Cross Status
description: A group of consumer and health care advocacy groups are suing to block the billion-dollar plan of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York state's largest health insurer, to turn itself from a nonprofit into a profit-making company, officials of the groups said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: New Conviction In '55 Killings
description: A 69-year-old man has been convicted a second time of murdering three boys in 1955. The previous conviction of the man, Kenneth Hansen, was overturned in 2000 by a state appellate court that ruled the jury should not have been told he had molested boys before the killing. Mr. Hansen, a stable hand, picked up the three boys who were hitchhiking, molested one and then killed them when they threatened to tell their parents. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Continental to Charge Low-Fare Fliers for 'Extra' Services
description: Continental Airlines, the nation's fifth-largest airline, said yesterday that it would start charging extra fees to its low-fare customers for certain services and make other cutbacks in an effort to stanch its losses.

title: The Deep-Fried Truth About Ipswich Clams; No matter the source of the harvest, the secret to a classic seaside meal may be the mud.
description: WAS it truly a potato chip entrepreneur named Lawrence Woodman -- known as Chubby -- who invented the Ipswich fried clam? And did it really happen near here, on Boston's North Shore, shortly before noon on a steamy July 3 in the year 1916? Most food-invention stories are apocryphal at best and downright self-promotional at worst, but this one may just have a grain of truth.

title: Bush's Mideast Sand Trap
description: Two weeks ago I was in New Delhi watching CNN, when on came President Bush talking about the need to deal with the threat from Iraq. I had no problem with what the president was saying. What bothered me, though, was that he was saying it in a golf shirt, standing on the tee with his golf clubs. Up to now Mr. Bush has conducted the war against terrorism with serious resolve. But he shows real contempt for the world, and a real lack of seriousness, when he says from the golf tee, as he did on another occasion: ''I call upon all nations to do everything they can to stop these terrorist killers. Thank you. Now watch this drive.''

title: Accounts
description: * Supercuts, Minneapolis, a division of the Regis Corporation, to MediaCom, New York, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle media planning and buying for its account, with billings estimated at $15 million. Those duties had been at the San Francisco office of Universal McCann, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Bush, Citing Fire Hazards, Wants Logging Rules Eased
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  President Bush will ask Congress to relax environmental laws so that the timber industry can accelerate cutting efforts across millions of acres of national forest land increasingly prone to devastating wildfires, senior administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIBERSON, ARTHUR
description: EIBERSON-Arthur. We will always miss you especially on Friday nights. The Friday Night Friends

title: Behind the Burger Mystique
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Promises Patience on Iraq
description: CRAWFORD, Tex. Aug. 21  President Bush took steps today to cool down speculation about United States action against Iraq, strongly suggesting that he was open to non-military ways to replace Saddam Hussein.

title: As Veterans Retire, New Principals Get Summer School
description: It was the middle of summer, a sweltering day, and one principal was overheard in the elevator genially grumbling that her brain was on vacation. She had just finished filling out a survey called ''What Is Your Professional Development I.Q.?''

title: U.N. Official, In Beijing, Tells of Worry Over Rights
description: Nearing the end of her five-year tenure, Mary Robinson, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, expressed her concern this week over ''new and worsening problems'' involving rights abuses in China -- and suggested that they were unlikely to be fully resolved until China underwent significant political reform.

title: New Jersey Bans Lawn Watering As a Lingering Drought Worsens
description: Revising New Jersey's drought restrictions for the third time in five months, the state's top environmental official today banned lawn watering and car washing statewide and directed businesses using large amounts of water to submit plans to cut use by as much as 50 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, MAX
description: WEINGARTEN - Max. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Max Weingarten, beloved father of Rita Plush. We extend our deepest condolences to Rita and family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Amtrak Finds More Cracks in Acelas and Juggles Locomotives
description: Amtrak faced growing problems yesterday in trying to restore high-speed Acela Express service along the busy Boston-New York-Washington corridor. It used conventional locomotives for four of its eight scheduled trains.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Pope John Paul II's visit to Poland, where he alluded to abortion in his homily during a Mass on Sunday, referred incorrectly to the regulation of abortion in Poland. While it is legal in special cases including pregnancies resulting from rape, it is otherwise restricted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, NATHAN M., MD
description: GREENSTEIN - Nathan M., MD. Died on August 19, 2002 at the age of 95. Resident of New Rochelle. Devoted father to Nancy Batterman, Dr. Robert M. and wife Arlene. Grandfather of Jennifer & David Carlson, Michael and Veronique, Debra and Christopher Graham, Suzanne, Daniel. Great grandfather to Seth and Isabelle. Brother to Naomi Shor, the late Jesse P. Survived by many nieces and nephews. Dr. Greenstein, a Pediatric Practitioner Bronx, New York, was the chief of Pediatrics for Jewish Mem. Hospital, Westchester Sq. and Pelham Hosp. Associate Professor Clinical Pediatrics at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He served in Navy Medical Corps as Lt. Commander in W.W. II. Dr. Greenstein attended CCNY, NYU Medical College. Awarded the All American CCNY Water Polo Team. Graveside service will be on Thursday, Aug. 22 at Mt. Zion Cemetery.

title: Fresh Food Spills Out in Front of City Hall (the Restaurant)
description: Henry Meer, left, the chef and owner of the Cub Room and City Hall, gets some of his summer produce directly from Beechnut Farm in Bridgehampton, N.Y., which is owned by his cousin Wilfred Heilbert. Mr. Meer travels there on weekends to help with the harvest, and now he has set up a small farm stand in front of City Hall, 131 Duane Street (Church Street).

title: Revisiting School Vouchers and Deportation
description: Q. Re "Supreme Court, 5-4, Upholds Voucher System That Pays Religious Schools' Tuition" (June 28), Please reveal the religious preference of the nine justices. I believe the majority is Roman Catholic whose schools stand to garner the lion's share of the government largess? Right or wrong?

title: Walking a Cyberspace Beat
description: With computer and network security a growing global concern, the online division of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., will begin an online graduate certificate program in cybersecurity next month. Students who are enrolled in the institute's four-course program will learn how to authenticate users, provide confidentiality and defend against security attacks while earning credits toward a master's degree in computer science. MANU MALEK, founder and editor in chief of the Journal of Network and Systems Management, will direct the program. It will go online Sept. 19 with its first course, ''E-Business Security and Information Assurance.'' Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Big Server Can't Slow Davenport's Comeback
description: Iroda Tulyaganova has won three tournaments in her three years on the women's pro tennis circuit, but her claim to fame may have been a 119-mile-an-hour serve she hit during a three-set loss to Serena Williams in Miami in March 2001.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Growth Forecast Stands
description: Jeon Yun Churl, South Korea's finance minister, said that he would not lower his forecast of 6 percent economic growth this year, even though ''instability in the United States and South America'' could have an effect. His confidence was reflected on the Korea Stock Exchange, which rose nearly 3 percent, to 736.70, its highest level in nearly a month. Among the gainers were Samsung Electronics and Hynix Semiconductor, buoyed by reports that memory chips might recover from their current downturn. Daewoo Electronics, meanwhile, said it would liquidate noncore assets, including its audio and computer monitor units, and merge with a subsidiary, Daewoo Electric Motor Industries. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Bush Foe and a Clinton One Are Ousted in Primaries
description: While neither Democrat Denise Majette, nor Republican Representative John Linder is a household name, they both scored impressive victories over better-known rivals in the Georgia primary on Tuesday.

title: Weight, a Measured Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke Repays $700,000 in Grant Money and Reports a Swindle
description: Duke University is repaying the federal government nearly $700,000 in grant money that it says was misspent by two former employees who have been accused of swindling one of the nation's most prominent researchers on aging after he was hospitalized for depression.

title: Mother Is Jailed After Children Are Sunburned
description: An Ohio woman has been jailed for allowing her three children to get severely sunburned at a county fair.

title: A One-Home Stand Against a Florida Golf Resort
description: Clarence Moore has placed aluminum pie plates on the bed to catch the rainwater that leaks into his house here, and he has applied masking tape to the place where the living room wall meets the ceiling. He turns on the 24-inch electric fan set between the portraits of his wife, Savannah, who died in 2001, and Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, MARGERY PEPPERRELL
description: STODDARD-Margery Pepperrell. August 20, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Francis R. Stoddard and the late Eleanor Wipple. Loving sister of Dudley W. Stoddard of New York City & Frances S. Dunn of Albany, Georgia. Devoted aunt of Lucy H. Hanafourde of Miami, FL., Sherburne W. Dunn of Olathe, KS., Townsend H. Dunn of Wayne, PA., Abigail A. Dunn of Old Hickery, TN., Katherine D. Gray of Scottsdale, AZ. and Deborah S. Moulton of Southampton, N.Y. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. She was a member of the National Society of Colonial Dames, The Huguenot Society and Daughters of Cincinnati. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Wednesday, August 21, 7-9PM. Interment to take place Thursday, August 22nd, 1 P.M., at the Memorial Cemetery of Saint John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Bible Society.

title: Sampras Goes Meekly Into the Night
description: Like so many other sigh-filled days and nights of the past two years, this one ended for Pete Sampras earlier than he expected as he walked off the court once again searching for his gilded game.

title: Herbert B. Max -- Lawyer, 71
description: Herbert B. Max, a retired lawyer and financier who wrote a book on private equity investing, died Aug. 4 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 71.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Nutley: Swim Club Accused Of Bias
description: A New Jersey swim club has been accused of turning away racial and ethnic minorities invited to the club by its members. Four complaints have been filed against the club, Le Terrace Swim Club in Nutley, and its owner, Patrick Nardone, according to the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights. In one complaint, a club member, Annmarie Giordano, said Mr. Nardone questioned her on the guests for her daughter's birthday party. When she identified the guests' race, Ms. Giordano said she was told her guests conflicted with club policy and her membership was canceled. The club's lawyer, George G. Frino, denied the allegations and said the club had a diverse atmosphere. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Exclusive Guest List For Milosevic
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, celebrated his 61st birthday yesterday in a United Nations prison near The Hague with his wife and a handful of fellow war crimes suspects with whom he is allowed to mingle. Others are off limits to him to avoid collusion. His trial is scheduled to resume on Monday after a brief summer recess. A cardiologist's report is also expected soon and may determine if Mr. Milosevic's heart condition and high blood pressure will require changing the current schedule of daily court hearings. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, ARTHUR
description: WIENER-Arthur. Died August 20, 2002 at age 99.5. Loving husband of Ruth Wiener. Beloved father and grandfather of Patricia Marx and Tara Marx. Highly esteemed member of the business community and respected neighbor. His warmth, wisdom and giving nature will be forever implanted in our hearts. We will miss you dearly. Graveside services on Thursday 1:30PM, Knollwood Cemetery, corner of Cooper and Cypress Aves, Ridgewood, NY.

title: Trysts and Battles With Long Sleek Lines
description: Alonzo King could not have thought of a better name than Lines for his company. Much has been made of the ways in which Mr. King's choreography defies the traditions of classical ballet. But his dances have long seemed to be more about long, sleek body lines and sculptured shapes than any one style or technique. And the four new and recent works presented by Alonzo King's Lines Ballet on Sunday at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshires here reinforced that impression.

title: DUKE CUTS PROFIT AFTER REVIEW OF ENERGY TRADING
description: The Duke Energy Corporation reduced profit at its energy-trading unit by 8 percent in the second quarter after a review of energy transactions requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Earnings before interest and taxes were cut by $17 million at Duke Energy North America and by $2 million at other units after Duke, the second-biggest United States utility owner, revealed 89 so-called round-trip trades, Duke said in a regulatory filing. In round-trip trades, companies simultaneously buy and sell power or natural gas at the same price and quantity. The transactions have little use except to increase revenue or trading volumes. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., had earnings before interest and taxes of $1.05 billion, including $196 million at Duke Energy North America, its main trading unit.

title: Pioline Walks Off Court, Maybe for Good
description: By its third agonizing set, Cdric Pioline's first-round qualifying match for the United States Open yesterday had morphed into his most dreaded nightmare. For a few minutes, he stood with his hands on his hips, watching the planes ascending from La Guardia. For a game, he stopped swinging at his opponent's serves. After losing his own serve one last time, he launched a tennis ball several courts away.

title: Judge Orders Drug Company To Alter Ads
description: A federal judge has ordered the pharmaceuticals company GlaxoSmithKline to stop saying in its advertisements for Paxil, a top-selling antidepressant, that the drug is ''nonhabit-forming.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Jobless Level Rises
description: Mexico's unemployment rate rose in July to its highest level since January, signaling that the economy is slowing down as United States demand for Mexican goods falters. July's jobless rate climbed to 2.9 percent from 2.4 percent in June, higher than the 2.5 percent rate expected by Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Mexico City. According to seasonally adjusted figures, unemployment was 2.88 percent, an increase from 2.55 percent in June. The higher-than-expected unemployment suggests that Mexican manufacturers are not stepping up production and hiring workers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about water conditions in the metropolitan region misstated the level of drought declaration in effect for New York City. It is not a warning but a Stage 1 emergency -- one step higher, with more restrictions on water use. The article also misstated the standard unit of measurement for the flow in the Stony Brook River in New Jersey. The flow is one-tenth of the river's normal rate, which is 5.5 cubic feet per second, not per minute.

title: Cisco to Buy Data-Storage Networker
description: Cisco Systems, hoping to enter a growing new market at a time when several of its other businesses have stagnated, said today that it planned to buy Andiamo Systems, a maker of technology that connects corporations' server computers to their banks of stored data.

title: Dokic Says Williamses Intimidate Opponents
description: Once the draw for the United States Open is unveiled Wednesday, some women will begin hatching mental travel plans by the lay of the brackets.

title: The Art of Listening, to Lake Waters and to John Cage
description: Founded in 1938 as an alternative to Salzburg when Austria fell under the Nazi cloud, the Lucerne Festival is among Europe's oldest and most distinguished. It has the prestige to summon the major orchestras of Berlin, Chicago, Los Angeles, Amsterdam and St. Petersburg, all of which will be passing through before events close for the season on Sept. 15. But in the air here, too, is the dash of something fresh.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drug Center's Ex-Chief Is Indicted
description: The former head of Odyssey House, the drug treatment center, was indicted yesterday on conspiracy and tax charges in connection with an embezzlement scheme against his organization, federal officials announced. The man, Benjamin Walker Jr., the former president of Odyssey House, was charged with conspiring to defraud the Internal Revenue Service, conspiring to commit mail fraud, and subscribing false income tax returns, the Justice Department said. His indictment also claims he shared much of the $2.3 million that Odyssey's former director of operations, Aaron Lugo, admitted embezzling from the center in 1999 when he pleaded guilty to bid rigging, fraud and tax changes. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Chinese Trappings in an All-American Hideaway
description: THEY were singing ''Happy Birthday'' at M Shanghai Bistro & Den the other evening to a woman whose age, for the purposes of anecdote, is of no concern. The bartender clanged a gong as the restaurant's customers, seated along communal tables in the small dining room, clapped. A cake was presented: airy, with a chocolate filling and white icing. The woman cut it and handed out slices. Now there were cheers.

title: Airlines' Sales Force
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Tycoon Retreats
description: Tom.com Ltd., the media company of Li Ka-shing, the Hong Kong billionaire, said that it had abandoned plans to buy control of the city's second-largest commercial broadcaster after concluding that it was too expensive. Late Monday, Tom.com ended its effort to buy 32.75 percent of the broadcaster, Asia Television, for $37 million, and it conceded yesterday that it had been trying to buy an even larger stake. Liu Changle, a former Chinese military official, recently took control of Asia Television, which received Beijing's approval on Monday to begin transmitting in Guangdong Province, next to Hong Kong. Asia Television is already widely available in Guangdong because its signals are illegally retransmitted by local cable operators, who replace Asia Television's ads with their own. Asia Television still needs the approval of provincial officials to begin legal service in Guangdong. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENESEE & WYOMING, Greenwich, Conn., an owner of regional railroads in five countries, said it would buy the Utah Railway unit from Mueller Industries, Memphis, for $54 million.

title: Cool, When It Sizzles, And a Breeze to Make
description: EVEN with air-conditioning, a late- summer dinner in the midst of a heat wave can be excruciating to prepare and eat. It's not just that it's too hot to relish hot food, but it's also not a good idea to have people in the kitchen and to cook at the same time. Add a few bodies humming at 98.6 degrees to an oven set to 450 degrees, and a comfortable 75-degree kitchen pretty quickly becomes hellish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTER, CHARLES JUSTIN
description: CANTER-Charles Justin. On August 19, 2002. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Carol (Harvey) and Arthur (Judy). Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Adam, Jeffrey and Nicole. Devoted brother of Joan Berger. Services 12 noon today from Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Corrections
description: Articles in World Business yesterday and on Thursday about management changes at Varig, the Brazilian airline, misspelled the given name of its chief executive. He is Arnim Lore, not Arnin or Armin.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: PERELMAN MAY CONVERT STAKE TO CITIGROUP SHARES
description: The financier Ronald O. Perelman may convert his entire stake in Golden State Bancorp into Citigroup shares when Citigroup, the world's largest financial services company, completes its purchase of Golden State. Mr. Perelman, a Golden State director, owned 42.9 million shares as of April 12, or 31.6 percent of the company. Based on Monday's Citigroup closing price of $36.35, Mr. Perelman would receive 42 million shares. The holding would make Mr. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Inc., one of the largest shareholders of Citigroup. He would own more shares than the chairman, Sanford I. Weill, who owned 32.6 million shares as of Feb. 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARNAHAN, A. VERNON
description: CARNAHAN-A. Vernon. The Board of Governors and Members of The Circumnavigators Club records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed Past International President, A. Vernon Carnahan. Through the past decades, this beloved and treasured member has served our century-old organization as a longtime Member of our Board of Governors, as Chairman of various advisory committees, as President of our Foundation, and as International President from 1987 through 1988. Vern promoted the highest standards of our Club and epitomized our creed, ''through friendship to leave this world a little better than we found it.'' We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife and Circumnavigator, Betty, and to his entire family. Jeffrey Kelly Alfred Morasso, Jr International Presidents

title: Upstairs They All Wear Masks, Downstairs Wooden Boxes
description: If Robert Wilson tried to remake Fritz Lang's ''Metropolis'' using a child's video camera and costumes bought at a hardware store, the results might be something like ''Box Head Revolution,'' a resolutely avant-garde video feature that opens today at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater in the East Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LILLIAN
description: GOLDMAN-Lillian. On August 20, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sol Goldman. Loving mother of Allan Goldman, Diane Goldman Kemper, Amy Goldman and Jane Goldman. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie Pitel, Cindy Blotner, Robin Kemper, Steven Goldman, Tris Goldman, Sara Arno, Solina Lewis Goldman and Michael Lewis Goldman. Great grandmother of Justin, Samantha and Bennett Pitel and Sabrina and Melissa Blotner. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Wednesday 7-9 PM. Services Thursday, August 22, 2002, 10AM at Tempel Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: New Agent Could Help to Detect and Cure an Anthrax Attack
description: Anovel agent that could help detect an anthrax attack and also serve as an antidote to weaponized forms of the deadly bacteria has been developed by biologists at Rockefeller University.

title: Wagner Ties for the Lead in His Pro Debut
description: The 190-yard 10th is the signature hole of the Winged Foot Golf Club. At the Met Open today, it was the first hole in an official tournament as a professional for Johnson Wagner, the area's best amateur for the last year or so. He turned pro last Wednesday.

title: Judge Seeks Copy of Crash Tape
description: A federal judge ordered prosecutors today to provide her with a copy of the cockpit voice recording from United Airlines Flight 93, on which passengers tried to wrest control from hijackers on Sept. 11, so she could determine whether the tape could be used at the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui and possibly be released to the public.

title: Teaching Islam: A Controversy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Either too easy or too tough, the debt raters always have critics.
description: After the collapse of Enron, the nation's rating agencies were hauled before Congress and over the coals by many who claimed they failed to warn investors of problems at Enron and dozens of other businesses. Now the same agencies are being criticized for just the opposite -- that they are too quick to downgrade companies at the slightest hint of trouble, adding more turmoil to already volatile markets.

title: In San Francisco, Work and a Little R & R
description: Nearly everyone will tell you that their jobs are misunderstood and baseball writers are no exception. Because of the hours we keep, the yearlong schedule we follow and the deadlines we meet, baseball writers believe they are the foot soldiers of a sports department.

title: Iraqi Official Affirms Death Of Abu Nidal; Suicide Hinted
description: A senior Iraqi official confirmed today that Abu Nidal, the man responsible for a brutal trail of terrorism through 20 countries, had died in Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 Arrested In Store Robbery
description: Armed men sneaked through an employee entrance at a Gap store in Manhattan yesterday before it opened, bound several workers and made off with cash from the safe, the authorities said. The workers suffered minor injuries. Two people have been arrested, and two accomplices were being sought last night. The robbers entered the Gap on 122 Fifth Avenue, near 18th Street, around 7:45 a.m. and stole an undetermined amount of money, the police said. Officers arrested Sylvester Reddick, 20, whom they identified as a gunman, and Lelia Vann, 26, whom they said was a lookout, a few blocks away when they crashed their car into a utility pole. The second gunman and an additional accomplice remained at large, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Supplies for Needy Students
description: It could easily cost $250 to outfit a child for school with sneakers, binders and notebooks, consuming the pay of a parent who makes $8 an hour. With that in mind, New Jersey's largest food bank, the Community FoodBank in Hillside, has begun offering supplies for needy students in time for the first day of classes. The Kids in Need Resource Center, located at the food bank, is one of a dozen in the nation sponsored by the School, Home and Office Products Association. The center opened on Thursday and will run year round. The food bank will distribute pens, paper and art supplies through social service agencies and after-school programs in the Newark area.

title: Oil Futures Drop a Bit as Supplies Rise 2%
description: Supplies of crude oil increased last week for the first time in three weeks, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.

title: A Wine Cellar That Can Take To the Road
description: A wine carrier for all seasons, but especially for those bottles that might be going to a Labor Day weekend picnic next week, has been introduced by Built NY, a company in the financial district. It is a well-padded nylon sailcloth bag with a Velcro closure and a space for a cold pack to keep white wine chilled or red cool.

title: Judicial Hypocrisy
description: The Supreme Court's conservative justices say they practice judicial restraint and accuse their liberal colleagues of activism. But a conservative federal judge has just written a blistering book arguing that the court's conservatives are actually engaged in a huge power grab, under the banner of respect for the states, that seriously erodes the rights of ordinary Americans.

title: Lillian Goldman, 80, Yale Law School Donor and Advocate for Women's Education
description: Lillian Goldman, who made a major contribution to the reconstruction of the library at Yale Law School, in part because it was among the first law schools in America to admit women, died yesterday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 80.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Canada's Prime Minister Will Not Seek Fourth Term
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 21  Prime Minister Jean Chretien announced today that he would not seek a fourth term and would leave office in February 2004, rather than try to overcome an open revolt against his leadership in the governing Liberal Party.

title: That Orderly World of Appearances He Lives In? It's About to Explode
description: ''I hurt myself today, to see if I still feel,'' the first line of the Nine Inch Nails song ''Hurt,'' could also be the theme of the writer-director Mark Romanek's gripping but not wholly successful psychodrama ''One Hour Photo.'' Mr. Romanek made his name directing some of the most unforgettable music videos of the 1990's: he was the Martin Scorsese to the Nails' leader Trent Reznor's Robert De Niro, creating attention magnets like ''Closer'' and ''The Perfect Drug.'' The depth of feeling in the videos Mr. Romanek directed comes through his deployment of color and the suggestion of violence. He does much the same thing in ''Photo,'' which opens today in New York and Los Angeles. It's a smart piece of direction, and he does a sterling job in creating Sy Parrish, a man whose love of superficiality, of surfaces, proves to be his undoing.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: PREGNANT WOMAN STRANGLED

title: Killed by a Bear
description: A black bear invaded a vacation colony in the Catskills this week in broad daylight, grabbed a baby from her stroller and ran into the woods before screaming adults could frighten the bear into dropping the infant, who died from the trauma. The incident, on Monday, left the community in shock -- and observers wondering what to make of this extraordinary event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, ROBERT
description: SCHER-Robert. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle mourns the passing of the dear father of our esteemed Executive Vice President Ellen Gelboim. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Bertram S. Schwarz, Pres.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: TYCOON RETREATS Tom.com Ltd., the media company of Li Ka-shing, the Hong Kong billionaire, said that it had abandoned plans to buy control of the city's second-largest commercial broadcaster after concluding that it was too expensive. Late Monday, Tom.com ended its effort to buy 32.75 percent of the broadcaster, Asia Television, for $37 million, and it conceded yesterday that it had been trying to buy an even larger stake. Liu Changle, a former Chinese military official, recently took control of Asia Television, which received Beijing's approval on Monday to begin transmitting in Guangdong Province, next to Hong Kong. Asia Television is already widely available in Guangdong because its signals are illegally retransmitted by local cable operators, who replace Asia Television's ads with their own. Asia Television still needs the approval of provincial officials to begin legal service in Guangdong.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: FLOODS THREATEN MILLIONS More than 10 million people are under threat from potentially devastating floods in central China as a vast lake that acts as a buffer for the Yangtze River surged above danger levels, officials said. With torrential rain from a looming tropical storm forecast, tens of thousands of people were racing to shore up thousands of miles of embankments around Dongting Lake in Hunan Province. The area could be hit by floods as bad as those of 1998, when 4,000 people died, one official warned.

title: Rodriguez Still Wonders What Might Have Been
description: Alex Rodriguez was about to tee off with Raymond Floyd at the Seminole Golf Club in North Palm Beach, Fla., last January when Floyd suddenly abandoned any course etiquette, squealed and stopped him. There was a white-haired man with an orange sweater around his neck shuffling toward them and a rascally Floyd wanted to introduce him to Rodriguez.

title: Toxic Pesticide Risk Is Seen For Public School Children
description: Children who live in public housing, go to public schools and play in parks in cities across the state are being exposed to high levels of toxic pesticides, according to a report released yesterday by Attorney General Eliot Spitzer.

title: Coup De Crawford
description: The plotters are meeting down at the Ponderosa today.

title: REGIONAL MARKET: Manhattan; Price Swings 'Enormous' In Deals for Office Space
description: As many seekers of Manhattan office space have discovered lately, this is a good time for deal making. With demand still weak in many parts of the borough, landlords are continuing to offer everything from a few months of free rent to double commissions for brokers.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: DELL PLANS SALE OF UNBRANDED PC'S Dell Computer , the world's second-largest personal computer maker, plans to sell low-cost personal computers without the Dell brand name through small United States dealers in a bid to lift sales by distributing products through third parties. This week, Dell will begin selling the unbranded PC's starting at $499 without a monitor to dealers, often called white-box makers, said a Dell spokeswoman, Amy King. Many small businesses hire such dealers to run their computer systems, making it a $3 billion market annually, she said. White-box makers account for 40 percent of the domestic market for desktop PC's sold to companies with 99 employees or less, Ms. King said. Dell wants to generate $380 million in sales in this market in the next year, she said. Shares of Dell fell 42 cents, to $27.70.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular Will Cut Up To 3,000 Jobs
description: Cingular Wireless, the second-biggest United States mobile telephone company, will cut 2,500 to 3,000 jobs, or as much as 7.5 percent of its work force, and reorganize its sales force by industry rather than geographic region. More than one-third of the cuts will come from normal attrition and eliminating temporary positions, Cingular said in a statement. Cingular has about 40,000 employees, including 4,000 temporary workers, a spokesman, Clay Owen, said. Some are represented by the Communications Workers of America. Mr. Owen could not say how many of the jobs to be eliminated were held by union workers.

title: Squatters Get New Name: Residents
description: Ellen Kessler, 54, mother, professional, dog lover, cat lover, owner of a new digital camera she bought because she wanted a new toy, is a squatter.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Moscow Blast Kills One and Recalls '99 Bombings
description: An explosion tore through an apartment building in northeastern Moscow late Tuesday night, killing at least one person and evoking troubling memories of a series of deadly apartment bombings in Russia in 1999.

title: Sharing the Evidence on Iraq
description: The Bush administration has floated a succession of possible justifications for war with Iraq -- Saddam Hussein's purported links with international terrorism, Baghdad's membership in a worldwide ''axis of evil,'' Iraq's efforts to develop nuclear weapons. Few firm facts have been offered in support of any of these claims, but there have been frequent allusions to secret intelligence information that officials are unwilling to make public.

title: Swami Satchidananda, Woodstock's Guru, Dies at 87
description: Swami Satchidananda, the guru with the gigantic cottony beard who opened the Woodstock festival by calling music ''the celestial sound that controls the whole universe,'' died on Monday in Madras in South India. He was 87.

description: ILLINOIS: NEW CONVICTION IN '55 KILLINGS

title: Musharraf Redraws Pakistan's Constitution
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 21  Gen. Pervez Musharraf unilaterally redrew Pakistan's Constitution today, imposing 29 amendments that expand his control of the country he took over by coup in 1999  changes that undermine coming parliamentary elections meant to return the nation to democracy.

title: U.S. Delays Part of Law Giving Mayor School Control
description: The Justice Department has delayed approving an important piece of the new state law that gives Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg control of the New York City school system.

title: What a Chancellor Needs Most
description: Serving as head of the nation's largest school system is an education in itself. Of all the lessons I have learned in the last three years, the most important is this: Attendance matters. And for schools to achieve better attendance, parents will have to become more involved.

title: CENDANT TO CUT 300 HOTELS IN FRANCHISE SYSTEM
description: The Cendant Corporation, the biggest franchiser of hotels, said yesterday that it would increase the number of poorly performing hotels it planned to cut from its system in an effort to increase consumer satisfaction. Cendant will also cut 130 jobs, or 15 percent of the positions in its lodging division. Cendant, based in New York, owns the Days Inn, Howard Johnson and other hotel chains. It will shed as many as 300 hotels from its franchise system, or up to 40,000 rooms. Over all, the company has 547,303 rooms. Cendant does not own any of its hotels. Rather, it leases its brand names to hotel owners and operators for a fee in return for marketing services.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Tax Reduces Use Of Plastic Bags
description: A tax on the free plastic bags given away in supermarkets has cut the number of bags in use by 90 percent since it was introduced at the beginning of March, according to the government's environment department. Shoppers must pay 15 cents per bag, and the $3.4 million paid since March is to be spent on environmental and waste-management projects. The tax is expected to result in a billion fewer bags in circulation this year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Contamination Fears Lead To Evacuation
description: Officials in McAllen evacuated about 70 people from an office after two employees complained of itching sensations when they came into contact with a white powder that spilled out of a package. The two employees were given a decontamination bath at the scene and then taken to a hospital. The McAllen fire chief, Odilio Montes, said no contaminants were detected. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Article 2002082192375409819 -- No Title
Mets Find New Way To Keep Skid Alive
description: Mo Vaughn mishandled a cutoff throw tonight, a play that is practiced in the first weeks of spring training. The Mets also made a base-running blunder, again looking as if they were working out the kinks on the back fields of their training complex in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Medical License Suspended
description: State officials have suspended the medical license of a plastic surgeon who came to New Jersey a year ago after his license was revoked in New York. The surgeon, Angel Prado, 66, lost his New York State medical license in April 2001 for negligence, fraud and ''engaging in conduct which evidences moral unfitness.'' The announcement of Dr. Prado's suspension was made on Monday, a day after The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that he was practicing in New Jersey. Dr. Prado, who also holds a medical license in Florida, has denied any wrongdoing. A hearing on his suspension is scheduled for Sept. 11. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: MERRILL LYNCH NAMES LAWYER AS RESEARCH MONITOR
description: Merrill Lynch, the securities firm, yesterday named Mark Goldfus, a lawyer, to monitor research, filling a post it had agreed to in its $100 million settlement with the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. William Genco, an analyst who covers companies like Waste Management and Allied Waste Industries, will be chairman of the firm's new research recommendations committee, Merrill said. In May, Merrill settled with Mr. Spitzer, who had asserted that some of the firm's analysts had misled investors by providing tainted research.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: English-Only Measure
description: The executive of Brown County, which encompasses Green Bay, vetoed a resolution passed last month declaring English the official language of government. ''One has to ask, Why are we doing something which supporters say changes nothing when we know it hurts members of our community?'' said the executive, Nancy J. Nussbaum. The veto, Ms. Nussbaum's first in more than 14 years as an elected official, can be overridden by a vote of 18 of the 26 members of the board of supervisors, which passed the resolution on July 17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, HELEN H.
description: HARRINGTON-Helen H. On August 14, 2002. Beloved sister of Patricia Harrington and Virginia Harwood. Also survived by many nieces & nephews. Founder & former president of Law Marketing, a list compiling firm. A longtime resident of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. A memorial service will be held at Scotto Funeral Home, 106 1st Place (near Court St.), Bklyn., Saturday, August 24, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Alzheimers Association of NYC, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017, or the American Ballet Theater, 890 Broadway, NY, NY 10011.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Railroad Diplomacy
description: As part of North Korea's diplomatic offensive the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, rolled into Russia, crossing at Khasan in his 22-car armored train. In a smaller version of his cross-Russia rail trip last summer, Mr. Kim plans to visit three Russian cities in the Far East, ending with a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Vladivostok on Friday. North Korea is trying to improve relations with Russia, Japan and South Korea, and Russia hopes to be able to push rail and gas links through North Korea to South Korea. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Carter Burgess, Ex-Executive And Envoy, 85
description: Carter L. Burgess, who had served as president of Trans World Airlines, ambassador to Argentina and president of the Foreign Policy Association, among other posts, died on Sunday in Roanoke, Va., where he lived. He was 85 years old.

title: Connecting With Communities
description: The After-School Corporation, a New York City nonprofit organization, has won a $500,000 grant to help teachers in New York and six other urban areas understand and take advantage of the neighborhoods in which they teach. The money will be distributed among schools in Queens; Baltimore; Boston; Providence; Utica, N.Y.; Charlotte, N.C.; and Pinellas County, Fla. It will finance after-school programs that emphasize interaction between schools and their communities. Abby Goodnough

description: ''Multiple killings tend to be a masculine thing,'' Sherlock Holmes observes in ''Sherlock Holmes and the Secret of Making Whoopee.''

title: Soldiers Should Not Be Spying
description: Last week Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld announced his desire to expand the role of Special Operations forces in the war against Al Qaeda -- even in countries with which the United States is not at war, and without informing local governments first. But while it may be tempting to hawks in Washington, allowing the American military to undertake missions that have traditionally been the job of the Central Intelligence Agency would be a very bad idea.

title: Ginger, Coconut And A Bit of Witchcraft
description: Fatou Soumahoro, left, a baker at Fat Witch Bakery in the Chelsea Market, is from Ivory Coast, one of the world's leading chocolate producers. So she suggested that the bakery honor her native country by adding some exotic flavors, like black pepper, coconut and fresh ginger, and also coffee and peanut butter, to its dense brownies. The result is a line called the African Witch. And on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, from 1 to 4 p.m., Ms. Soumahoro and compatriots, in African dress, will hand out samples of the intriguing and subtly spiced African Witch brownies at the market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street). The brownies are $2.25 each at the bakery.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: JOBLESS LEVEL RISES Mexico's unemployment rate rose in July to its highest level since January, signaling that the economy is slowing down as United States demand for Mexican goods falters. July's jobless rate climbed to 2.9 percent from 2.4 percent in June, higher than the 2.5 percent rate expected by Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Mexico City. According to seasonally adjusted figures, unemployment was 2.88 percent, an increase from 2.55 percent in June. The higher-than-expected unemployment suggests that Mexican manufacturers are not stepping up production and hiring workers.   (Bloomberg News)

description: LAZAROW - Edythe. Of Hackensack, NJ on August 20th. Loving niece of Rita and Jack Naparstek, Rachel and Jacob Rosenblatt and Morris Weisberg. description: AMSTERDAM, Aug. 20 (Bloomberg News)  ABN Amro Holding said today that it was in exclusive talks to hire Electronic Data Systems to manage the computers at its wholesale bank.

title: China Extends Olive Branch to Chatham Square
description: When Colette Rossant and Veronica Leung, the partners in Dim Sum Go Go in Chinatown, went to Nanning in China last spring, they discovered an unusual dish, steamed pork topped with Chinese black olives, of all things. So they brought the recipe home, and they serve the dish for $15.95 in their restaurant, at 5 East Broadway (Chatham Square).

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: U.S. Clears Purchase Of Paypal
description: EBay's $1.5 billion purchase of the online payment service PayPal was cleared by antitrust regulators, eliminating a potential barrier to the transaction. The Justice Department ended its review without asking for more information, eBay, the largest online auctioneer, said yesterday. Some analysts had expected regulators to delay the sale while it sought more data. Shares of PayPal, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., rose $2.10 each, or 10 percent, to $23.10; eBay shares fell $1.45, to $60.41. PayPal's competitors include a smaller service operated by eBay. PayPal, which lets users make payments electronically from banks and credit cards, estimated last year that 71 percent of eBay auctions listed it as a payment option. The acquisition, announced July 8, needs approval from PayPal stockholders.

title: First Flakes
description: For those who keep a close eye on weather forecasts, the Steamboat Grand Resort Hotel in Steamboat Springs, Colo., has an Early Season Ski Deal with five nights for the price of four and 20 percent off lift tickets of three days or more. It must be booked by Oct. 4, and travel must be completed by Dec. 20. Rates from opening day of ski season, Nov. 27, are $125 to $145 a night for regular double rooms and $225 to $305 for one- and two-bedroom suites. Children 12 and under stay free in the same room with adults, and two kids ski free if one adult buys a five-day lift ticket. The 328-room hotel is in Mountain Village, near the gondola. There is a heated outdoor pool with access indoors. The ski resort has 142 trails and 20 lifts. Information: (877) 269-2628 or on the Web at www.steamboatgrand.com .

title: AOL in Deal To Regain All Of Large Unit
description: AOL Time Warner, AT&T and Comcast, three of the world's biggest media and communications companies, plan to announce a $9 billion deal today to unravel a complicated venture that has bedeviled them for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLSTEIN, WILLIAM CHARLES
description: WALLSTEIN - William Charles, 88, died on August 16, 2002 after an illness of several months. Beloved husband of 61 years of Eleanor Scholle, fahter of Nancy W. Newkirk, of Bethesda, MD, Richard S. Wallstein of London, England, and the late Michael W. Wallstein, father-in-law of Thomas and Philippa, grandfather of Jennifer and Christopher Newkirk and grandfather-in-law of Kennon S. Miller, and great grandfather of Eleanor and Henry Miller. Devoted brother of Robert and the late Leonard. Bill graduated from Yale University in 1936. He retired in 1974 from The West Chemical Company as Vice President and started a long and successful career as a volunteer corporate fundraiser for Channel 13 (WNET-NY), The Morgan Library and the New York City Police Foundation. He served for many years as a Deacon at All Souls Unitarian Church of New York. A memorial service will be held on September 15 at 2 PM at All Souls, Lexington Ave. at 80 St., New York, NY. Memorial gifts to the New York City Police Foundation, 345 Park Ave., New York, New York 10154, would be appreciated.

title: Teenager Is Killed Walking Along Tracks
description: A 17-year-old high school senior who was walking along railroad tracks with friends was killed Monday night after he was hit by a New Jersey Transit train that knocked him to the road below, where he was hit by a car, police and transit officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bomb Scare On Bridge
description: A bomb scare on the George Washington Bridge proved unfounded but caused huge traffic delays yesterday during the evening rush. The authorities said a man, whose identity could not be determined last night, jumped off the bridge about 4:45 p.m., and was pulled from the water by the New York City Police Harbor Patrol. The police then realized that a briefcase had been left next to a railing on the bridge, prompting fears that it might contain bomb. Before the briefcase was found to be harmless by the police bomb squad at about 6:35 p.m., traffic was blocked from entering the bridge in both directions for more than a hour. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Home Depot Earnings Increase 28%
description: Home Depot Inc. reported today that its second-quarter earnings rose 28 percent, more than forecast, as the company reduced expenses.

title: Martin Deutsch, 85, Dies; Discovered an Atom
description: Martin Deutsch, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology physicist who discovered the strange short-lived substance known as positronium, died on Friday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Bad Bank Loans Sold
description: The Union Bank of Taiwan agreed yesterday to sell nonperforming loans with a value of $138 million, in the largest negotiated sale yet of bad bank debts in Taiwan, which is trying to purge its banking system of problem loans. The buyer is a new joint venture in which Morgan Stanley holds 51 percent and Union Bank holds the rest. Most of the loans are secured, and the joint venture is paying 35 cents on the dollar for them. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

description: Five men were arrested in Bologna in northern Italy this week after their behavior inside a basilica aroused police officers' suspicions that they were plotting a terrorist attack, Italian law enforcement officials said today.

description: Brian Mullen, who played for the Rangers for four seasons, will replace Sal Messina as the team's radio analyst, MSG Networks announced yesterday.

title: Dick O'Connell, 87, Red Sox Executive Who Led a Revival
description: Dick O'Connell, the Red Sox executive who revived a floundering franchise and built Boston's pennant-winning teams of 1967 and 1975, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Lexington, Mass. He was 87.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Digital Media Player Software
description: RealNetworks began offering new digital media player software yesterday that plays music and video in all formats, including that of Microsoft, its main competitor. The software is available for $19.95 or as part of a monthly fee for one of RealNetworks' subscription services. The move continues a shift in the company's strategy, first signaled last month, when it said it would allow companies that use its software to broadcast programs over the Internet to use audio and video in a range of formats, including Microsoft's proprietary Windows Media. ''Sometimes just because your competitor wants you to do something doesn't mean you shouldn't do it,'' said Rob Glaser, chief executive of RealNetworks. ''We realized we were the only ones who could offer universal playback, and we thought consumers would really appreciate it.'' RealNetworks has come under increasing pressure from Microsoft, which gives away both its media player and server software as part of the Windows operating system. Microsoft is expected to introduce the latest version of its own digital media player software next month. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: UNOCAL TO BUY THE REMAINING STAKE OF PURE RESOURCES
description: The Unocal Corporation, a leading oil and gas exploration and production company, agreed yesterday to buy the shares of Pure Resources Inc. that it does not already own for $409 million in stock. Pure shareholders will receive 0.6527 share of Unocal stock for each share of Pure held, valued about $22.25 a share. Unocal, which already owns 65 percent of Pure, will issue about 12 million shares to complete the transaction. Unocal is based in El Segundo, Calif. Pure Resources is based in Midland, Tex.

description: The ZIP codes with the most victims from the World Trade Center attack turn out to be one in the Upper East Side of Manhattan and, per capita, Hoboken, N.J. Page B1.

title: Gay and Lesbian Enrollment Rises
description: New York City's only public school for gay and lesbian teenagers will more than triple its student population in 2003, using $3.2 million that the former Board of Education allocated at its final meeting on June 19. The school, run by a nonprofit group, the Hetrick-Martin Institute, since 1984, now enrolls 50 students and has a three-year waiting list. It will expand its space in an East Village building and enroll 170 students by September 2003, according to the school. Abby Goodnough

title: 2 Rotech Officers Leaving
description: Rotech Healthcare, a medical device maker that is reviewing allegations of accounting fraud by a contractor, said yesterday that its chief executive, Stephen Linehan, had resigned and that the contract of its chief operating officer, Scott Novell, would not be renewed. Shares of Rotech, based in Orlando, fell as much 29 percent after the news; they were down 8.9 percent at 4 p.m.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Loss For KPN
description: Royal KPN, the Dutch phone company, posted a record loss for the second quarter as it took about 9 billion euros ($8.8 billion) in write-downs on foreign mobile-phone units and licenses for faster wireless services. The company, based in Amsterdam, posted a net loss of 9.3 billion euros, compared with a loss of 499 million euros in the period a year earlier, the chief executive, Ad Scheepbouwer, said at a news conference. Excluding the write-downs, the loss was smaller than analysts had forecast, lifting KPN's shares. The company and rivals spent about $100 billion on licenses to provide faster Internet access on mobile phones, betting on growth prospects that have not materialized. KPN cut the value of its mobile permits in Germany and Belgium by 4.1 billion euros. Mr. Scheepbouwer ''is cleaning the slate,'' said Krijn Moens, a fund manager at Eureffect Stockbrokers who owns KPN shares. ''The fact that he wrote down the licenses shows he's realistic; furthermore, underlying numbers were good.''

title: U.S. Releases 1980's Files On Repression In Argentina
description: The State Department released thousands of classified documents today that are expected to shed light on a particularly grim chapter in Argentine history: the military government's violent repression of leftist insurgents 20 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAVITIAN, ARLENE M.
description: TAVITIAN-Arlene M. On August 16, 2002. Beloved wife of Aso. Dear sister of Doreen Amaral. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday, August 23, from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Ave at 73 St Saturday, 11AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Profit Down at WPP Group, And Chief Is Not Optimistic
description: Emphasizing a gloomy advertising climate, Sir Martin Sorrell, the chief executive at the world's largest agency company, the WPP Group in London, forecast a slow recovery yesterday and warned that WPP's operating profit margins might not match last year's.

title: A Recipe for a Run-In: More Bears, and More People in Their Path
description: A fatal mauling of a baby girl in the Catskills on Monday follows a spate of bear sightings in recent years that have concerned wildlife officials across the New York region and even spurred calls for the first bear hunt in New Jersey in three decades.

title: American Dream Is a Ghana Home; Mark of Immigrant Success To the Folks Back in Accra
description: When Ghanaians immigrate here, they quickly display the timeless yearning of new Americans for owning a house. What makes the Ghanaians different is that the house they yearn to own is in Ghana.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Defamed Man's Parents Win Suit
description: A Philadelphia jury awarded $40 million to the parents of a man falsely accused of raping and murdering a woman in 1995. The accusation was made by two lawyers, Samuel Malat and Fred Ambrose, who represented two men acquitted of that crime. The lawyers identified John Lambert, who later died of a drug overdose, as the killer. His parents sued the lawyers and three others for defamation. The murder remains unsolved. Adam Liptak (NYT)

description: FOIE GRAS is not a Zuni Cafe speciality. But lowly chicken livers? Now you're talking.

title: Americans Are Taking Care Not to Offend Afghan Hosts
description: The conversation at a little restaurant here began politely, as many do in Afghanistan when the subject is the Americans. A shopkeeper said he had never seen an American soldier but felt they had come to help. A cook said the Americans' presence was all that kept the country quiet.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Report Recommends Domain Operator
description: The group responsible for the Internet's address system has issued a preliminary report recommending that its board select the Internet Society to operate the .org domain. The Internet Society, a nonprofit international organization, is one of 11 groups that submitted bids to take over responsibility for .org from VeriSign Inc., which must give up control over the domain by the end of this year. The address group, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, said Monday that its selection of the Internet Society was based on recommendations from three independent teams that evaluated the applicants. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Ross Stores Posts 40% Jump in Profit
description: Second-quarter profit at Ross Stores Inc. rose 40 percent as it, a discount retailer, sold more clothing and home decorations, and opened stores, the company said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Head Of Police Charity Is Indicted
description: A Queens man who claimed to run a charitable fund for Police Department widows and children has been indicted on charges of conspiracy and fraud, the United States attorney for Manhattan, James B. Comey, left, announced yesterday. The man, Justin Patrick White of Long Island City, is accused of defrauding scores of businesses and individuals from 1999 through this year, obtaining more than $440,000 in donations, officials said. Mr. White, president of the Police Survivors Fund Inc., paid only $14,500 of what he collected to slain officers' families, according to the authorities. Paul Testaverde, a lawyer for Mr. White, said: ''My client is completely innocent. If necessary, he expects to go to trial and to be vindicated at trial.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRYCE, ERSKINE

title: White House Denies Texas Session Is About Iraq
description: The White House vigorously denied today that President Bush had summoned his senior military advisers to his ranch here to map out a potential effort to topple Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq, declaring that the sole purpose of a meeting to be held here Wednesday was to review military procurement, missile defense and Pentagon spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, MARJORIE
description: JACOBSON - Marjorie. On August 19, 2002. Beloved wife for 59 years of Leslie A. Jacobson. Devoted mother of Sue Berland and David Jacobson. Beloved motherin-law of Phuong Jacobson & Joseph Berland. Cherished grandmother of Leslie Meyers, Maxwell Meyers, & James Berland. Step-grandmother of Laura BerlandShane and Kenneth Berland. The love and concern of her family and many friends helped to sustain her through her last illness. Donations may be made to the Katonah Museum of Art, Katonah, NY.

title: Assessing the Future Of Vivendi, Some Expect A French Strategy
description: For Jean-Ren Fourtou, the chief executive of Vivendi Universal, deciding which businesses to sell to stave off a cash crisis could prove the easy part. More difficult, according to analysts and company insiders, is figuring out which to keep.

description: As the number of days to the players' strike deadline dwindled to a single digit, negotiators for players and owners continued to disagree over the effect the owners' economic proposals would have on player salaries.

title: HANOVER COMPRESSOR CHOOSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Hanover Compressor Company, which makes pipeline equipment, named Chad Deaton, formerly with Schlumberger Ltd., as chief executive yesterday after ousting two top officials this month amid a federal accounting investigation. Mr. Deaton, 49, will also be president of the company and a member of the board, Hanover said. Schlumberger, the world's largest oil field services company, owns 11 percent of Hanover, which is based in Houston. Hanover restated results for the last two years after disclosing in February that it had accounted improperly for revenue from a Nigerian natural gas plant that was not running and $12 million of gas pumps sold to a pipeline controlled by Enron.

title: A Culinary Giant Has Mixed Emotions About Retirement
description: In contrast to those who can now anticipate Jol Robuchon's return to the professional kitchen, food lovers who once trekked regularly to Crissier, near Lausanne, in Switzerland, to be fed by Frdy Girardet remain out of luck.

description: Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, will appear in South Florida with Gov. Jeb Bush on Sept. 9 -- the day before Mr. Bush's would-be challengers meet in the Democratic primary -- at a pro-Israel rally where international affairs will share a stage with domestic political concerns.

title: Just the Right Tang to Add to the Pleasure
description: ''RIGHT now, I'd like a really great goat cheese,'' Frank J. Prial said as we tasted the Beaujolais crus. We all nodded in accord. There is a reason for this. Goat cheese has just enough fat to ease the coarseness of a young Beaujolais but not enough to flatten it out. Goat cheese also has tang, which suits this juicy but fairly buttoned-up wine.

description: Three little words open the floodgates: ''Speaking of which. . . '' This is the unexceptional phrase that so modestly begins ''The Coast of Utopia,'' Tom Stoppard's engrossing and exasperating trilogy of plays at the Royal National Theater here about the intellectual forebears of the Russian Revolution.

description: Saks Inc., the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and regional department stores, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed as it cut costs and controlled inventory.

description: Palestinian police officers in spanking new uniforms took up positions in Bethlehem today, and residents swarmed into the late-summer sunshine during a trial pullback of feared Israeli patrols in this West Bank city and in Gaza.

description: Some associates of Bill Clinton and executives from CBS are involved in negotiations to make the former president the host of a daily afternoon talk show.

The rate is 7.8 percent, not 5.8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, FLORENCE
description: GREEN-Florence. On August 17, 2002, in Greensboro, N.C., at the age of 88. Remembered lovingly by her son, Ronald, and his wife, Susan; her grandchildren, Cynthia, Jonathan, and Anne; her grandson-in-law, Josh Jablons, and her great-grandchildren, Zachary, Jonah and Hannah Jablons. Florence will be remembered by many graduates of the Jewish Theological Seminary, where she dedicated most of her working life.

title: PROGRAM TO COVER PSYCHIATRIC HELP FOR 9/11 FAMILIES
description: The American Red Cross and the September 11th Fund said yesterday that they would underwrite the expense of extended mental health treatment for people directly affected by the terrorist attacks last year. The effort may be the most ambitious ever undertaken by charitable organizations to address the emotional needs of disaster victims.

title: Anti-Hussein Iraqis Briefly Seize Embassy in Berlin
description: An Iraqi opposition group seized control of Iraq's embassy here this afternoon and held the small staff hostage until the German police stormed the compound, freeing the captives and arresting five members of the group.

title: Bloomberg Vetoes Easing Of Council's Term Limits
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his veto power for the first time yesterday on a measure that would have revised term limits and given eight City Council members an extra two years in office.

title: Corrections

While McLeodUSA issued a qualified certification, citing the effects of bankruptcy reorganization and the hiring of new auditors, the company emerged from Chapter 11 in April. It is no longer in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Acoustic Duo With Memories Made of Loss
description: When Eyes Adrift took the stage at Joe's Pub on Monday night, it was hard not to feel nostalgic about the alternative-rock boom of the 1990's. Was there really a time when the guitarist in the T-shirt and sweat pants had a hit single and a major-label contract? Was it only a decade ago that the other guy, the bassist with the full beard and floppy hat, played in perhaps the most popular band on the planet?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOTI, SHERYL ANNE SUSAN
description: FOTI-Sheryl Anne Susan. Age 57 died peacefully at home in Cambridge, MA. on August 19, surrounded by her family after a courageous fight against lung cancer. Graduated 1966, University of Rochester, 1968 Columbia School of Social Work, from 1971 to 1974, she co-directed the Adolescent Day Service at McLean Hospital, then was a psychotherapist in Cambridge. Ms. Foti was a Trustee of old Sturbridge Village & an Overseer of the Gardner Museum. She is survived by her father, Andrew Foti, sisters, Linda and Melody Foti, brother Bert Foti and by her daughter Lisa FotiStraus, son Drew Straus, and husband Robert Straus. A ''remembrance'' will be held 4-7 PM, August 22 and 23 at her home in Cambridge; a memorial service, 10 A.M., August 29, First Church in Cambridge, Congregational.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Profit Up 66%
description: Helped by recent acquisitions in the United States, the Royal Bank of Canada reported a 66 percent rise in net earnings for the quarter ended July 31. Excluding special charges recorded last year, earnings grew 24 percent, to $722 million (Canadian), or $1.02 Canadian a share, slightly above analysts' estimates. The bank, which is Canada's largest financial institution, said it would raise its dividend for the second time this year. For the first nine months of fiscal 2002, operations in the United States made up 27 percent of total revenue, up from 18 percent in the period last year. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: An Obsessive Garbage Monitor Comes Clean
description: MICHAEL E. McMAHON, the ruddy Democratic councilman from Staten Island, talks trash with the best of them: with mayors, governors, his long-suffering spouse, whomever he can get to listen. Garbage is, pardon the expression, his bag. Never been on the receiving end of an impassioned monologue on cutting-edge urban sanitation capped off by a nostalgic ode to the recycling program presently under partial lockdown by the Bloomberg administration? Then you've never been shut in a room at City Hall with Mr. McMahon, the slightly obsessive chairman of the City Council's effervescent Sanitation and Solid Waste Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGIN, KENNETH S.
description: KNIGIN-Kenneth S., 73. Died in his Manhattan home on August 16th, 2002, of a heart attack. Son of the late Jack Knigin and Miriam Sheldon Knigin Leitman. Mr. Knigin, a former lawyer, was highly regarded as an international environmental consultant. A graduate of NY University and Brooklyn Law School, Mr. Knigin was active politically & held various positions including NYC Councilman and Parking Violations Commissioner under the Lindsay Administration. In addition to his many other accomplishments, Mr. Knigin was a 20 year on-air radio personality on the Long John Nebel Show, Special Counsel to Taiwan, part owner of the NY Franchise of the World Football League and organizer of the Kyle Rote Football League for Young Men in Brooklyn. He was the beloved husband of Jeanie Walls Henry Knigin. He was also the beloved brother of Karen Leitman. He is survived by two previous wives, Eunice Germansky Knigin and Pia Buggert Knigin, and his four children Marcia Wallace, Randy Little, Johanna Knigin and Alexandra Knigin. In every way, Mr. Knigin was loving, kind, and sensitive and will be especially missed by his black Labrador Retriever, Casey. Funeral services were held at Frank E. Campell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Monday, August 19th at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks the contributions be made to your favorite charity, or to Guiding Eyes for the Blind in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Dell Plans Sale Of Unbranded PC'S
description: Dell Computer, the world's second-largest personal computer maker, plans to sell low-cost personal computers without the Dell brand name through small United States dealers in a bid to lift sales by distributing products through third parties. This week, Dell will begin selling the unbranded PC's starting at $499 without a monitor to dealers, often called white-box makers, said a Dell spokeswoman, Amy King. Many small businesses hire such dealers to run their computer systems, making it a $3 billion market annually, she said. White-box makers account for 40 percent of the domestic market for desktop PC's sold to companies with 99 employees or less, Ms. King said. Dell wants to generate $380 million in sales in this market in the next year, she said. Shares of Dell fell 42 cents, to $27.70.

title: A Bridge Title Sets a Record In Montreal
description: An American star won a title here Monday night at the World Bridge Championships and established a record for the number of world championships won in different bridge categories. Jeff Meckstroth, playing with Becky Rogers, won the Mixed Pairs, thanks to a surge in the final session that was worth 70 percent. He has now won four different world titles: the Bermuda Bowl, the Olympiad Teams, the World Pairs and the Mixed Pairs.

Nobody knows, and nobody wants to say that the Yankees can get by comfortably without him.
