title: Heeere's Bill
description: The concept of a Bill Clinton talk show sounds not so much like a good idea or a bad idea as an inevitable idea. It's been a long time since the nation had to cope with a relatively young and extremely energetic ex-president, and unlike Theodore Roosevelt this one does not appear interested in big-game hunting or third parties. The traditional route along the highly profitable speakers' circuit seems to be boring him, and he is showing no signs of flinging himself into good works the way Jimmy Carter did. If Mr. Clinton is yearning for a meld -- a job in which he can express concern about the nation's problems while making oodles of money -- talk of TV talk was bound to follow.

title: Nordson Says Quarterly Profit Rose 28%
description: WESTLAKE, Ohio, Aug. 21 (Bloomberg News)  The Nordson Corporation , a maker of machinery that applies adhesives, said today that its fiscal third-quarter profit rose 28 percent as the company cut jobs and benefited from an accounting change.

title: Weekend for Indian Artists to Get Their Business Done
description: Before daybreak Saturday morning, collectors who had pulled all-nighters in the booths assigned to their favorite artists were sprawled out in lawn chairs or cots, holding their place in line at this year's Indian Market. Some had waited a day and a half.

title: SALLIE MAE SAYS IT DOES NOT WANT TO BUY GOLDEN STATE
description: Sallie Mae, the government-sponsored company that offers student loans, said it was not interested in buying Golden State Bancorp, whose shareholders vote Thursday on a planned $4.7 billion takeover by Citigroup. Sallie Mae was responding to inquiries, the company said in a statement. The company made an informal all-stock proposal to buy Golden State earlier this year that would be worth more than Citigroup's offer, which had an initial value of $5.8 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter. Shareholders representing a majority of Golden State stock outstanding must vote in favor of the takeover for Citigroup to win approval. The financier Ronald O. Perelman, who holds the largest block of Golden State shares and sits on the bank's board, has agreed to vote for Citigroup's takeover and oppose any competing bid.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: AXA Expects Rise In Income
description: Giving a boost to European insurers hit by the sour securities market and the recent flood damage in Central Europe, AXA, the French insurer, said yesterday that it expected operating income for the first half-year to rise 17 percent, to 1.02 billion euros. That is better than expected and was attributed to better-than-anticipated results at AXA's life insurance business and its property and casualty unit, the company said. But AXA said that net income dropped almost one-third in the period, to 840 million euros, as a result of the cost of the Sept. 11 attacks. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Anton Guadagno, Opera Conductor Internationally, 79
description: Anton Guadagno, the artistic director and principal conductor of the Palm Beach Opera in Florida, and a frequent guest conductor in European and American opera houses, died on Friday in Vienna. Mr. Guadagno, who had homes in Vienna, Palm Beach and New York, was 79 and had conducted Verdi's ''Otello'' at an opera festival in St. Margarethen, Austria, the previous day.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Explanation Of Losing Bid

A finance ministry official said SeoulBank, which is owned by the government, was not likely to make the $300 million in profits that Lone Star said it would share with the government in addition to more than $800 million that Lone Star offered as an initial payment. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: DoubleClick To Close San Mateo Office
description: The world's largest Internet marketing company, DoubleClick, is closing its San Mateo, Calif., office as it continues to cut costs to consolidate operations. The company, based in New York, has been closing the office, which has about 20 workers, for several weeks, a spokeswoman, Brenda Fields, said yesterday. DoubleClick had more than 2,300 workers at its peak and now has about 1,200 employees, she said. ''It's just across the board, as I'm sure a lot of other companies are doing,'' Ms. Fields said. ''We are obviously consolidating our operating expenses, and, of course, real estate is one of the things we can consolidate.'' DoubleClick shares rose 47 cents, to $6.47, in Nasdaq trading. They had fallen 47 percent this year. Cutting jobs and selling its European unit helped DoubleClick reduce costs by 44 percent in the second quarter.

The bases were loaded with two out in the 11th, and the Yankees trailed the Anaheim Angels by four runs. All White wanted was a simple grand slam off a 98-mile-an-hour fastball.

title: Editors' Note; Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume in September.

title: Owners Await Response As the Clock Ticks On
description: Major League Baseball's chief labor lawyer, faced with a strike deadline eight days away, indicated yesterday that he was eager to pick up the pace of negotiations for a new agreement with the players. But he may have his own employers to blame for what he sees as the union's foot-dragging approach to the contract talks.

title: Not Necessarily Office Furniture
description: Setting up a home office can be done on a budget, even if you want brand-name furniture. The CFR warehouse sells used chairs, desks and filing cabinets, all in excellent condition, at discounts of 60 percent to 80 percent. Among the brands offered are Steelcase, Haworth and Global. Leap chairs, above, from Steelcase are $350 to $500 (they are $700 to $1,200 new). A lateral file by Steelcase is $200 ( $600 new). And keep in mind that some worktables make handsome dining tables and some conference-room chairs would look fine anywhere. CFR is open weekdays; 48-02 48th Street, Woodside, Queens, www.cfrfurniture.com or (718) 472-2230. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAWER, MURRAY
description: PRAWER-Murray. The law firm of Heller, Jacobs & Kamlet, formerly known as Thurm & Heller, with deepest sorrow, mourn the loss of Murray Prawer, our former Partner and cherished friend. Everyone who had the privilege of knowing Muz, loved him: he was a man whose love of his family, devotion to colleagues and friends, and compassion towards all was a true inspiration and model for us to follow. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his loving wife, Lisa; his children, Noah, Ben and Emily; his mother, Lola; his sisters, Naomi and Renee; and to all of his family and friends, whose lives he touched in so many wonderful ways. We will share with you in honoring his memory in worship at Temple Beth Rashon, Wyckoff, NJ on Thursday, August 22, at noon

title: WORLD WRESTLING'S FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT DOWN 79%
description: World Wrestling Entertainment, the producer of the ''SmackDown'' professional wrestling matches on television, said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter profit fell 79 percent as pay-per-view revenue declined. Net income in the quarter that ended July 26 fell to $2.5 million, or 4 cents a share, from $12 million, or 16 cents, a year earlier, World Wrestling said. Revenue fell 2.8 percent, to $88.1 million from $90.7 million. Revenue from pay-per-view programs declined 24 percent in the quarter. The company said television-advertising revenue fell to $16.7 million from $19.5 million because ratings were lower than a year ago.

title: New U.S. Inquiry Set On Towers' Collapse
description: Standing next to mangled pieces of steel from the World Trade Center, federal officials announced that they were beginning a two-year, $23 million investigation into how and why the twin towers and a third skyscraper collapsed in raging fires on Sept. 11.

title: BUSH, CITING FIRES, WILL SEEK TO EASE LAWS ON LOGGING
description: President Bush will ask Congress to relax environmental laws so the timber industry can step up logging across millions of acres of national forest land increasingly prone to devastating wildfires, senior administration officials said today.

title: The Kids of Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: Coolly, Fehr Plays His Hand
description: In his 19 years as head of the baseball players' union, Donald Fehr has been called a lot of things, among them the most powerful figure in professional sports, the smartest person in baseball and the nation's most successful labor leader.

title: Lighting That Floats From Window to Wall, As Well It Should
description: ''I'm trying to integrate light into architecture,'' said Johanna Grawunder, a designer with offices in San Francisco and Milan. And so she has, transforming light into walls, screens and windows in ''SuperLuminal,'' an exhibition of 10 light sculptures that opens tomorrow at the Limn Gallery in San Francisco. In ''Cyber-Sexy,'' left, two sheets of transparent orange plastic are suspended from a stainless steel beam that holds a fluorescent tube. The piece can be shown on a wall, and used as a window of light. Ms. Grawunder has also suspended the floating light above her dining room table. ''Cyber-Sexy'' ($3,500) is 4 feet wide by 6 feet tall. The show runs through Oct. 5. at the gallery, 292 Townsend Street; (415) 977-1300.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Guns To Undergo Minor Repairs
description: The New York Police Department has ordered that the handguns carried by most officers be refurbished because of a small risk that they might jam. The minor modifications will be made to the 24,000 Glock Model 19 semiautomatic handguns during annual firearms training, the police said. The plans were first reported yesterday by The Daily News. The guns fail so rarely -- one in 450,000 firings -- that the department decided a recall was unnecessary. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Gliding Through Europe, Cloaked in Diffident Charm
description: BLOOD OF VICTORY

title: A Workhorse
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Racial-Profiling Case Settled
description: New Jersey officials have agreed to pay $250,000 to settle a lawsuit filed by three Pennsylvania men who said they had been singled out by state troopers because of their race. In February 2001 the state reached a $12.95 million settlement with four blacks and Hispanics whose vehicle was stopped and later shot at by state troopers in 1998. The new settlement, announced on Tuesday, involves men who were simply stopped. Thomas White, 71; Fred Hamiel, 43; and Tyrone Hamilton, 36, said that between 1997 and 1999 they were improperly stopped and searched by state troopers. Other lawsuits are pending.

title: A New Look at 'Save the Whales'
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Skating Scandal Spurs 5-Count Indictment
description: A federal grand jury in Manhattan issued a five-count indictment yesterday against Alimzhan Tokhtakhounov, who is accused of conspiring to fix the pairs figure skating and ice dancing events at the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Bag-Screening Bribery Case
description: Two men have been charged with trying to bribe federal airport security workers to speed baggage screening during a test of a new system at T. F. Green airport in Warwick. The authorities said the men, Darrall Loren Redburn, 38, of Weymouth, Mass., and Angelo M. Troisi, 59, of Peabody, Mass., approached baggage screeners in June and July, offering them money. The indictment said Mr. Redburn was associated with a company, Air Tag Inc., that was testing the feasibility of the screening system. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: From Rubble, Ingenuity Sprouts
description: INVENTIVE minds have been at work on the riches in New York's community gardens. At La Plaza Cultural on the Lower East Side, the stones of demolished buildings have become an amphitheater, and old bricks form meandering paths. After drought restrictions limited hydrant use this year, gardeners in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, built a rainwater collection system to keep their most precious plants alive. High school students working at the Lower East Side Park and Garden have invented a hot compost box that needs no turning and heats their greenhouse in winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESS, JEAN A.
description: BESS-Jean A. On August 20, 2002 of New York City and Phoenix, AZ. Beloved wife of 54 years to Jerome Bess. Devoted and loving mother of John H. Bess and Andrea Jean Hughes, and Joan Bess. Private funeral services were held. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to be made in Jean's name to the cancer charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Member Of Parliament Slain
description: A member of the lower house of Parliament was shot to death as he walked his dog in Moscow early yesterday. Vladimir I. Golovlev, of the new Liberal Russia party, was the latest victim in a series of killings of city, state and federal officials but the first member of Parliament killed since 1998. Mr. Golovlev, 45, was said to be under investigation for his role in the privatization program in the early 1990's, but a leader of Liberal Russia, Sergei N. Yushenkov, called the killing politically motivated. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Futuristic Design Also Makes Friends In the Office
description: If you cheered for the robots in old sci-fi thrillers like ''The Day the Earth Stood Still'' or ''Forbidden Planet,'' your computer may have found a new friend in Harman Multimedia's JBL Creature speakers.

title: Valentine Takes Blame, But Mets Keep Losing
description: Throughout the Mets' miserable season and their collapse over the past 10 days, their owner, Fred Wilpon, has maintained support for Manager Bobby Valentine and General Manager Steve Phillips and has said they would complete their contracts, which run through next season. Today, Valentine sounded a familiar theme, taking the heat for the Mets' problems and offering Wilpon the opportunity to change his mind.

title: Corrections
description: The ''36 Hours'' article in the Escapes section on Friday, about Prince Edward Island, misstated the source of the surrounding warm waters. It is the Gulf of St. Lawrence, not the Gulf Stream. A ''Getting There'' note misstated the travel time and method from Halifax, Nova Scotia. It is about three hours, not one, and it includes a ferry ride.

title: More Heat in Independence Party Race as Golisano and Pataki Trade Charges
description: The political battle between Gov. George E. Pataki and Tom Golisano ratcheted up a few notches yesterday, as a state court judge knocked one of Mr. Golisano's running mates off the ballot and Mr. Golisano asked the Manhattan district attorney to investigate Mr. Pataki's campaign for voter registration fraud.

title: 3 Postal Centers Tested in New Jersey
description: Three more postal centers in central New Jersey were tested yesterday for the presence of anthrax spores similar to those found this month in a street-corner mailbox in downtown Princeton.

title: Unfunny in the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: SERVICE SPENDING DIPS Spending on services fell in June from May as the World Cup soccer tournament ate into demand for theme parks and other entertainment. The government said that demand for services fell 0.3 percent, slightly better than economists had forecast. For the whole second quarter, though, demand for services rose, suggesting an expansion in the country's gross domestic product during the period. Consumer spending makes up nearly 60 percent of the economy, and has remained steady, despite falling wages and high unemployment. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A New Look at 'Save the Whales'
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberty Sees Mystics As Tough Challenge
description: Liberty Coach Richie Adubato said the W.N.B.A. playoff format ''did in'' the Charlotte Sting and the Houston Comets, and almost did in the Liberty.

title: 5 Who Attacked Iraqi Embassy Had Sought Asylum in Germany
description: The five men who seized the Iraqi Embassy in Berlin on Tuesday appeared in court today and were described as recent asylum seekers in Germany, while the top Iraqi diplomat here characterized them as ''gangsters, paid mercenaries, who were getting their orders from outside, on their cellphones.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENSEN HATCHERDOROTHY
description: CHRISTENSEN HATCHERDorothy, born September 12, 1924 in NYC; died August 17, 2002 in Palm Harbor, FL. Mother of Donna Christensen (Holt Smith) granmother of Erica Smith. Preceded in death by her husband Al Hatcher. She worked in NYC at Bonwit Tellers for 30 years in mens fashion; followed by many years in Chicago. Resident of Palm Harbor for the past 17 years. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the hospice of your choice.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Rap Festival Canceled
description: Citing fears of gang-related violence, officials on Tuesday abruptly canceled a rap festival scheduled for this weekend. The sold-out concert at the city-owned Sandcastle Stadium was to feature the rappers N.O.R.E., Styles and Khia, left. The festival's promoters, however, said they had yet to be notified in writing about the cancellation, and insisted that the show would go on. Stadium officials said they canceled the concert after receiving warnings from the police, both local and out of town, about the potential for gang violence. An appearance by N.O.R.E. was canceled last year after Atlantic City residents protested his appearance and the organizers failed to get the proper permits.

title: Where They Lived
description: What we wanted at first, of course, was the names and faces of the people who died at the World Trade Center. The task was not simply to quantify the loss but to give it a human identity. That hasn't changed in the months since. But new ways of analyzing information about the victims keep giving us new pictures of the tragedy that unfolded last Sept. 11, new ways to understand its effects. A good example is the recent effort to match victims to the ZIP codes they lived in, based on the New York City medical examiner's list of the dead, which was released on Monday.

title: In Blast Police Call Accident, Muscovites See Terrorist Hand
description: Yevgeny Ruchichnikov had just dozed off on Tuesday night when a powerful explosion tossed him out of bed in his first-floor apartment on Akademika Korolyova Street.

title: The N.B.A. regretfully cancels a Lorillard sponsorship.
description: THE National Basketball Association and the Lorillard Tobacco Company are blaming anti-tobacco activists for the decision to remove the cigarette maker's Youth Smoking Prevention Program as a sponsor of a popular youth basketball tournament.

title: A Method Becomes Clearer In a Methodical Investigation
description: Throughout the summer, politicians and others have expressed impatience with the Enron investigation, demanding to know why no one from the company had yet been charged with a crime -- particularly when executives involved in other corporate scandals were being led away in handcuffs.

title: Standing Tall Once Again, This Time In Real Bronze; At Brooklyn Cemetery, A Civil War Monument Gets a Makeover
description: Two years ago, when the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn embarked on an ambitious $250,000 renovation of a famous and priceless Civil War monument, the notion of New Yorkers' heroic sacrifice in a traumatic conflict seemed patriotic and honorable, but remote.

title: Don't Laugh. The Little Guy Can Shoot.
description: As digital photography sweeps the nation, one counterpart of the analog world still seems to be missing: the disposable digital camera. The Aiptek Mini PenCam is by no means a disposable, but with its no-flash point-and-shoot imaging, it feels like one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANITO, EUFELIA P. (EUFELIA PINGITORE, MD)
description: GRANITO-Eufelia P. (Eufelia Pingitore, MD) of Tenafly, NJ, August 20, 2002. Beloved wife of the late AR William ''Bill''. Devoted mother of William R. Dearest sister of Nicholas E. Pingitore, M.D. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ on Friday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30 AM Mt. Carmel Church, Tenafly, NJ. Cremation private. For directions www.barrettfuneralhome.net

title: World Briefing | Europe: Slovakia: Police Files To Be Opened
description: Parliament voted to add Slovakia to the growing list of former Communist countries that have opened their secret police files to the public. Under the law, a ''national remembrance'' institute will be set up and citizens will have access to files from 1939, when Slovakia became a puppet state of the Nazis, through 1989, when as part of Czechoslovakia it saw the end of 42 years of Communist rule. The institute will be a semi-judicial body that will also be able to prosecute those deemed responsible for ''crimes of fascism and Communism.'' Accusations of Communist and Nazi-era collaboration have dogged Slovak politics, and the bill's sponsors said they hoped the institute would enable the country, which became independent in 1993, to face up to its past. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: The Drive to War: Where Is Congress?
description: To the Editor:

title: AOL Revives Focus on Creating Original Content
description: The executives assuming control of the struggling America Online Internet service are reviving a strategy the company abandoned five years ago, emphasizing the creation of original, exclusive content, said people who have discussed the matter with AOL's new chairman, Jonathan F. Miller.

title: Rosy Glasses After a Sea Of Setbacks
description: IT may have looked like only a hole in the ceiling surrounded by soaked plaster, but Betsy Carter knows a metaphor when she sees one. ''It's too good to pass up, isn't it?'' she asked, eyeing it ruefully.

title: Plugging In a Laptop When Traveling Abroad
description: Q. My daughter is taking her laptop to study at the American University of Paris. What kind of adapter does she need so that she can plug it in overseas?

title: In Hoboken, They Knew They'd Lost More on 9/11
description: Third park bench in from the Hudson, John Morris stared across the water at the gap-toothed skyline of Lower Manhattan and considered the tendrils of grief stretching from ground zero to this still-stricken city.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accord On Fuel From Iranian Reactors
description: The government said it had signed an agreement with Iran guaranteeing the return of spent fuel from two nuclear reactors Russian engineers are building in the Iranian port of Bushehr. The atomic energy minister, Aleksandr Rumyuantsev, said the accord makes academic the complaints that Iran will use the plants to make nuclear weapons or so-called ''dirty'' radioactive bombs. The fuel ''will not fall into anybody's hands but Russia's,'' he told the military newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda. The United States has argued that the reactors, ostensibly being built to generate electricity, will aid Iran's secret nuclear arms programs. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: SHEFFIELD ENDS JOINT VENTURE WITH ELAN, A DRUG MAKER
description: Sheffield Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that it had agreed with the Elan Corporation, Ireland's biggest drug maker, to end their joint venture to make products that deliver drugs to the lungs. Sheffield, which is based in St. Louis, will get the rights to Elan's Updas drug-delivery system, and Elan, based in Dublin, will receive royalties on two of the venture's experimental products if they are brought to the market, Sheffield's chief executive, Thomas Fitzgerald, said. Sheffield now has the rights to the venture's Tempo inhaler and Premaire drug-delivery system.

title: Finding a Mover: The Human Factor
description: I'M happy to report that after a grueling four-month search that may have prompted at least one real estate agent to seek early retirement, I finally found a house to buy in California.

title: U.S. Excludes More Steel Imports From Protective Tariffs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  In a move that defused at least some of the anger among European and Japanese leaders over American barriers on imported steel, the Bush administration today exempted an additional 178 kinds of steel from the steep "safeguard" tariffs that it imposed in March.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: DOUBLECLICK TO CLOSE SAN MATEO OFFICE The world's largest Internet marketing company, DoubleClick, is closing its San Mateo, Calif., office as it continues to cut costs to consolidate operations. The company, based in New York, has been closing the office, which has about 20 workers, for several weeks, a spokeswoman, Brenda Fields, said yesterday. DoubleClick had more than 2,300 workers at its peak and now has about 1,200 employees, she said. "It's just across the board, as I'm sure a lot of other companies are doing," Ms. Fields said. "We are obviously consolidating our operating expenses, and, of course, real estate is one of the things we can consolidate." DoubleClick shares rose 47 cents, to $6.47, in Nasdaq trading. They had fallen 47 percent this year. Cutting jobs and selling its European unit helped DoubleClick reduce costs by 44 percent in the second quarter. (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about Claire Cooper-Tognolli, a homeless pregnant woman who was found strangled in a hotel in the Bronx, misstated her age. She was 20, not 28.

title: Expect a Call While Rafting? A Way to Keep Your Phone Dry
description: Cellphone users who feel that they must take their phones everywhere, even into the great outdoors, now have a way to keep them safe during those end-of-summer hiking or rafting trips. The Boxit 5.0 mobile phone case, manufactured in Finland by Moduleo Oy and distributed by MDX Industries of Newbury, Mass., is a watertight and shockproof plastic case that allows full use of the phone.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the growing popularity of salvaged wood in home design projects misstated the amount of chestnut flooring that one homeowner, Jessica Dubner, bought for $12,000 at Cornerstone, a supplier in Brooklyn. It was 1,100 square feet, not 11,000.

title: Some Newly Made Friends Are Now in Harlem's Way
description: Early this month, the members of the Harlem Little League all-stars and the team from the Jesse Burkett Little League from Worcester, Mass., became fast friends as they worked their way through their regional finals in Bristol, Conn.

title: Polls Suggest Torricelli Has An Even Race
description: Weeks before the average incumbent United States senator scurries into campaign mode, Robert G. Torricelli is all over New Jersey, in part, political analysts say, because recent poll numbers show him at best in a tie in his re-election bid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, M. ALEXANDER
description: BERGER - M. Alexander. Born in Buffalo, New York and lately of Manhattan and Hillsdale, N.Y. Died on August 20 at his home in New York City at the age of 56 after a prolonged and noble battle with cancer. He spent 25 years as VP/Senior Account Director with top US ad agencies including J. Walter Thompson, D'Arcy, McManus Masius, McCann-Erickson. He then moved into Hispanic media and worked with its Publicidad Siboney and Telemundo. He was co-founder and COO of Gems International TV. In 1994 he became founder and Managing Director of the Insight Works, Inc. which identifies strategic insights from video-based qualitative research. He is survived by his wife Aileen Robbins, his children Sasha James of San Diego, Calif, Alexander W. Berger of Orlando, FL. and his stepdaughter Ariel Friedman and his siblings Sue Berger of Los Angeles, Calif, Kelly Dowell of Port Angeles, WA. and Michael McClure, Kailua, HI. A memorial service will be held at Campbell's, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, on Sunday, August 25 at 3:30PM. In lieu of flowers, Alex requested that contributions be sent to the Trickle Up Program, 121 W. 27 St, Suite 504, NY, N.Y. 10001. Family and friends are encouraged to share memories of Alex on mem.com.

title: F.B.I. Alerted to Saudi Man By Photo on Computer Disc
description: The F.B.I. issued a worldwide alert for a 21-year-old Saudi man this week after examining a CD-ROM it received three months ago that contained an image of his passport and photographs of some of the Sept. 11 suicide hijackers, government officials said today.

title: Judge Casts Doubt on the Manhattan Prosecutor's Right to a Bronx Tax Case
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan might be facing a rare setback on a matter of jurisdiction. As early as next week, a state judge could deny his request to prosecute a car dealer based in the Bronx on charges of tax evasion.

title: Enron Executive May Forgo A $4 Million Partnership Fee
description: In negotiating a deal with prosecutors, the former Enron executive Michael J. Kopper appears to have given up money he paid to himself for managing a secretive partnership -- money that some of the other partners have been trying to get back.

title: EXXON MOBIL BUYS STAKE IN OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it bought a 25 percent stake in a pipeline system that would carry oil from a field in the Gulf of Mexico. The price was not disclosed. Exxon, which is based in Irving, Tex., bought a fourth of both the Proteus Pipeline Company and the Endymion Pipeline Company. Those companies plan to build a 420,000-barrel-a-day pipeline system to carry oil from the Thunder Horse field 150 miles offshore, southeast of New Orleans, Exxon said. The pipeline will be operated by BP, which is based in London.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 4 Sought In Bronx Girl's Death
description: Four men wanted for questioning in the fatal shooting of a 10-year-old Bronx girl are believed to be headed to Mexico, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. The girl, Malenny Mendez, was shot early Sunday when gunfire broke out after a christening party at St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church. The four men, believed to be members of a Mexican gang called the St. James Boys, were identified as Enrique Snchez, Cesar David Lucero Rosa, Angel Salgado Snchez and Alejandro Polinar Romano Solis. Mr. Kelly said they were thought to be driving a red 1992 Chevrolet Beretta, license number BRS-2842. Anyone with information is asked to call 1-800-577-TIPS (8477). Al Baker (NYT)

title: Senator Questions Finances of United Way
description: Responding to the scandal engulfing the metropolitan Washington United Way, Senator Charles E. Grassley, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, has made inquiries into the United Way's finances.

title: Nestl Reports 79% Increase In Profit During the First Half
description: Nestl, the world's largest food company, reported a 79 percent increase in profit today for the first half of 2002. Gains from asset sales and a partial spin-off of an eye-care products subsidiary offset charges for the falling value of some slower-growing businesses.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the increased scrutiny that companies are giving to the backgrounds of potential executives misstated the name of a firm that specializes in accounting, security and investigation. It is the Control Risks Group, not Controlled Risk.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Starbucks Expands Web Network Service
description: The Starbucks Corporation, in a venture with the T-Mobile International division of Deutsche Telekom and the Hewlett-Packard Company, added 700 high-speed wireless network service outlets yesterday in cities in New Jersey and Connecticut and in Atlanta, Boston, Denver, Philadelphia and Portland, Ore., as well as in three international test stores in London and Berlin, for a total of nearly 1,200 outlets. The service, available for those with laptop computers and hand-held devices, uses the Wi-Fi standard, and has been renamed T-Mobile HotSpot. The new locations join 500 outlets in the Seattle, San Francisco and New York regions and in three cities in Texas. The companies said they expected to add 800 more outlets by the end of the year. Hewlett-Packard will provide free software to make wireless connections easier, according to Bloomberg News. Starbucks has a revenue-sharing agreement with T-Mobile. Shares of Starbucks fell 18 cents, to $20.87. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LILLIAN
description: GOLDMAN-Lillian. On August 20, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sol Goldman. Loving mother of Allan Goldman, Diane Goldman Kemper, Amy Goldman and Jane Goldman. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie Pittel, Cindy Blotner, Robin Kemper, Steven Goldman, Tris Goldman, Sara Arno, Solina Lewis Goldman and Michael Lewis Goldman. Great grandmother of Justin, Samantha and Bennett Pittel and Sabrina and Melissa Blotner. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Wednesday 7-9 PM. Services Thursday, August 22, 2002, 10AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: A Confused Inquiry
description: Under pressure, and after a great deal of confusion among its own officials, the U.S. Justice Department has said it will continue its criminal investigation into a drug sting gone haywire in the Texas panhandle town of Tulia.

title: Wall Street Analyst
description: To the Editor:

title: A New City Hall for London Is Cause for Celebration, Not Brickbats
description: When Norman Foster's design for City Hall was unveiled in 1999, Londoners derided it as a ''search lamp,'' a ''fencing mask'' and a ''giant eye.'' But since last month, when Queen Elizabeth opened City Hall, located on the South Bank of the Thames opposite the Tower of London, the name-calling has for the most part stopped. Admiration for the building, top left, seems to have broken the spell cast on architecture in Britain in 1984 when Prince Charles described a proposed extension to the National Gallery as ''a monstrous carbuncle.''

title: Musharraf Redraws Constitution, Blocking Promise of Democracy
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf unilaterally redrew Pakistan's Constitution today, imposing 29 amendments that expand his control of the country he took over by coup in 1999 -- changes that undermine coming parliamentary elections meant to return the nation to democracy.

title: Friends Say Ex-Chief Despairs, Seeking Someone to Believe Him
description: A year after he resigned as chief executive of Enron, Jeffrey K. Skilling -- who once bragged that he was building the world's leading company -- is a portrait of despair.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Medical Patent Case Decided
description: Technology for a robotic-surgery system that was developed by I.B.M. and Intuitive Surgical was ruled to be protected by patent yesterday. After deliberating about 10 hours following a weeklong trial, jurors in Federal District court in Delaware decided that Computer Motion, a competitor, must pay $4.4 million for infringing on the patent. International Business Machines and Intuitive Surgical contended that Computer Motion's Zeus system for minimally invasive abdominal surgery copied technology used in Intuitive's da Vinci system. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRAH, JERE TIFFIN
description: FARRAH-Jere Tiffin. Age 57, died suddenly of a heart attack, August 18, 2002. Beloved son of Mrs. Jere T. Farrah Sr, uncle of Tiffin. Funeral held in South Carolina. Esteemed member of the staff at The Cathedral Church of St John the Divine where a memorial service is planned. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Wine Cruise
description: Book by the end of this month, and Uniworld will discount up to $500 a couple on seven-night Fall Foliage and Wine trips on the Rhine and Mosel between Amsterdam and Basel on the 138-passenger River Princess. Prices start at $2,198 a person, based on double occupancy, and include air fare, all meals and guided shore excursions. There will be wine tastings and lectures, including one at Reichsburg Castle in Cochem, Germany, dinner at the Rudesheimer Schloss in Rudesheim, Germany, and a lunch and tasting at an Alsatian vineyard. Other stops include Cologne and Heidelberg. Space is limited; departures from Aug. 30 to Oct. 18. Information: (800) 733-7820 or www.uniworld.com .

title: GLAXO WANTS TO PROHIBIT IMPORTS OF GENERIC ANTIBIOTIC
description: GlaxoSmithKline has asked a United States trade agency to block Novartis from importing to the United States a generic version of Glaxo's antibiotic Augmentin, saying Novartis subsidiaries are using a stolen production process. The request is part of Glaxo of Britain's effort to protect its $3-million-a-day United States Augmentin market. It follows a federal judge's ruling in May invalidating Glaxo's patents on the antibiotic, which generated more than $2 billion in sales worldwide last year. Glaxo's petition says that ''willful misappropriation of trade secrets'' by Novartis and its subsidiaries has damaged Glaxo. The petition was filed at the International Trade Commission, an independent federal agency that weighs the impact of imports on United States companies.

title: Faster Chips That March to Their Own Improvised Beat
description: THERE are no jazz riffs in the rhythms of electronic circuitry. Instead, all the operations of a microprocessor are governed by a metronomic central clock -- a crystal oscillator that beats out a single lockstep rhythm more relentlessly than Toscanini on a bad day.

title: Four-Way Race in Brooklyn For a Redrawn Senate District
description: In his 20 years in the City Council, Noach Dear was known not only as a bombastic wheeler-dealer who vied for the political leadership of Borough Park, Brooklyn, but also as a master fund-raiser who collected millions of dollars on behalf of Bill Clinton and Al Gore's presidential campaigns.

title: Water and Woe For the Czechs' Cultural Gems; Assessing the Damage Wrought by Historic Flood
description: His full white beard and flowing hair shining bright in the dim cellar, Jaroslav Krejci lifted his arms like an Old Testament prophet as he surveyed his sodden, mud-smeared, foul-smelling art studio.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Telekom Has Record Loss
description: Deutsche Telekom reported a record quarterly loss yesterday and said it was keeping ''all options open'' for disposing of its American cellular phone service, VoiceStream. Deutsche Telekom lost $2.04 billion in the second quarter. The company has explored a merger of the unit with AT&T Wireless and Cingular, but the talks have not progressed. The interim chief executive, Helmut Sihler, said he planned to cut the company's debt of $67 billion to about $50 billion by the end of the year. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: FORD IS REVIEWING EMPLOYEE POLICIES ON EVALUATIONS
description: The Ford Motor Company is reviewing policies, including pay and evaluations, for about 127,000 salaried employees worldwide as it tries to improve worker morale. The automaker wants to complete the review by next year's first quarter, a spokeswoman, Anne Marie Gattari, said. The chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., has said he wants to improve employee relations. Ford settled discrimination lawsuits last year arising from an evaluation system instituted under the watch of Jacques Nasser, the former chief executive.

title: U.S. Drops Objections to Officials Testifying in Milosevic Trial
description: The US State Department has agreed that Richard Holbrooke, the former US diplomat and architect of the Bosnia peace accords, and other former high-ranking US officials, may testify at the war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic, US and tribunal officials said on Thursday.

title: Hingis Overcomes Stevenson To Reach the Quarterfinals
description: Alexandra Stevenson stunned the tennis world three years ago by reaching the semifinals at Wimbledon as an 18-year-old qualifier, and, at No. 32 in the world, has her highest ranking on the women's Tour. But she would have seemed to have been out of her league in going up against Martina Hingis today in the second round of the Pilot Pen tournament. The 21-year-old Hingis has won 40 singles titles, including four Grand Slam events, while Stevenson has yet to win a title on the WTA Tour.

title: An Online Epic Pursues Geese Tagged for Satellite Tracking
description: Oscar perished in Iceland, possibly slain by a gyrfalcon, and Arnthor disappeared on the western coast of Greenland, probably shot.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Online Sales Grew Slightly In July
description: Online consumer retail sales grew at a slightly slower pace in July than they had in the first half of this year, comScore Media Metrix said this week. Spending on nontravel and nonauction goods totaled $3.1 billion, or 20 percent more than in July 2001, but it was off slightly from the 29 percent growth of the previous six months. Peter Daboll, the division president of Media Metrix, attributed the summer slowdown to ''market uncertainty.'' He pointed out that sales of some goods, like computer hardware, had grown at a faster rate than the overall market, with $927 million in sales in July, or 30 percent more than July 2001. Sales of online travel services also continued to grow. That category's July sales, $2.9 billion, were up 32 percent from July of last year, but that figure, too, was down from the 71 percent growth rate in the first half of 2002. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: Data Show Growing Trend Toward Permanent Layoffs
description: Permanent layoffs surged from 1999 through 2001, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday in releasing the results of a survey that is the government's most comprehensive assessment of how frequently workers are dismissed from their jobs.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Basking Ridge: AT&T Offers Local Service
description: AT&T began offering local telephone service yesterday to New Jersey consumers currently served by Verizon. AT&T was already providing local service to about 1.5 million residential customers in seven states. It decided to seek New Jersey customers in July after the Board of Public Utilities forced Verizon to lower rates it charges competitors who lease its lines. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: For the Doctor's Touch, Help in the Hand
description: WHEN nurses make rounds at the cardiovascular surgery unit of Miami Children's Hospital, there is one piece of medical equipment that is missing: the clipboard. Instead of writing information about the patients on pocket-size cards, nurses tap away on hand-held organizers.

title: McGreevey Calls Trade Center Land Swap Unlikely
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey said yesterday that it was ''relatively unlikely'' that the land under Kennedy and La Guardia Airports would be swapped for the site of the World Trade Center.

title: 3 Fed Bank Chiefs Hint That Another Rate Cut Isn't Needed
description: The presidents of three Federal Reserve regional banks said today in separate remarks that interest rates were low enough to keep consumers spending and fuel the economy's rebound, suggesting that Fed officials did not think that another cut in interest rates was needed to prevent growth from faltering.

title: State Democrats Drop Idea of 9/11 TV Ad
description: With an assurance from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that Democrats will not be shut out of the city's Sept. 11 anniversary ceremony, the state Democratic Party said yesterday that it had dropped its plan to commemorate the terrorist attack by broadcasting an advertisement with elected leaders reciting the Gettysburg Address.

title: LUFTHANSA'S RESULTS EXCEED ANALYSTS' FORECASTS
description: The German airline Lufthansa's first half-year operating profit jumped to 332 million euros ($325 million) from 105 million euros a year earlier, the company said yesterday. The result by far exceeded analysts' forecasts, based on a 4.7 percent rise of sales to 8.2 billion euros ($8.02 billion) until June 2002. Although Lufthansa still was not able to report net profits, net losses could be reduced by 37.2 percent, to 27 million euros ($26.4 million), compared with results a year earlier. The full-year forecast was increased to ''at least'' 500 million euros in operating profit, up from 400 million euros, the company said. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Washington Talk; George W.'s Worst Fear: A W-Shaped Recession
description: When the economy entered an unmistakable slump last year, economists quickly began a lively and jargon-filled debate about whether a recovery would be U-shaped (mild and slow) or V-shaped (sharp and quick).

title: Bernard Canavan -- Executive, 66
description: Bernard Canavan, 66, a former president of American Home Products, a major pharmaceutical and health care company, died on Aug. 10 at his home in Jupiter, Fla.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Celebrities Back Farmworkers
description: More than 40 entertainers signed a full-page advertisement that ran in Daily Variety and Hollywood Reporter urging Gov. Gray Davis to sign a bill that gives unionized farmworkers the right to binding arbitration on contracts. The signers included Warren Beatty, Robert Redford, Barbra Streisand, Jack Nicholson and Marlon Brando, Annette Bening, Sean Penn, Danny Glover, Martin Sheen, Robert Altman and Richard Dreyfuss. Mr. Davis faces pressures from the growers to veto the legislation and from the farm workers and other labor unions to sign it. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Genocide Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
description: Augustin Bizimungu, a former Rwandan military commander considered one of the architects of the 1994 killing frenzy, pleaded not guilty at the United Nations tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania. Mr. Bizimungu, who was chief of staff of the army, was arrested last week in Angola. He faces 10 counts of genocide and crimes against humanity after being accused of leading the killing of 800,000 people, mostly members of the Tutsi ethnic group. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Boston Priests Warn Cardinal Of False Abuse Accusations
description: A group of priests representing almost a third of the Roman Catholic priests in the Boston Archdiocese is concerned that some priests are being falsely accused of child sexual abuse and has asked Cardinal Bernard F. Law to ensure that they are given full legal rights when charges are made against them.

description: Radio City Entertainment and the union that represents the Rockettes reached an agreement yesterday that offers 41 veteran dancers buyouts of $30,000 to $120,000 and allows the traditional Christmas spectacular to go on without a strike.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Lightning's Legacy
description: Two large wildfires in northwest Colorado have burned a combined 30,000 acres and are expected to merge this week. The two, the Hinman fire and the Burn Ridge fire, are in the Mount Zirkel Wilderness Area in Routt National Forest and are among five sparked by lightning near Steamboat Springs. The others are the 5,100-acre Lost Lakes fire and the 4,400-acre Green Creek fire, both in the national forest. In the nearby White River National Forest, the Big Fish fire has burned 13,500 acres. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Boat Sunk By North Salvaged
description: South Korea has raised from the waters of the Yellow Sea its bullet-riddled patrol boat that was sunk in a gunbattle with North Korean forces on June 29. Dangling from iron cables linked to the bow and stern, the ship was a vivid reminder of the fierce battle that killed 5 South Korean sailors and apparently 13 North Koreans. The windshield of the cabin was shattered, part of the stern was missing and the body of the ship was riddled with bullet holes. South Korean warships were on alert during the salvage operation in waters claimed by both the North and South, but North Korea kept its promise not to interfere. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Tuneup Lets Mac Go Full Throttle
description: WHEN Apple unveiled its Mac OS X operating system a couple of years ago, the company's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, explained that it offered two important benefits. First, Mac OS X (pronounced ''ten'') rests on a superstable, industrial-strength foundation called Unix. Second, Mac OS X is so beautiful, ''you just want to lick it.''

description: ''This is part of the Constitution. I am hereby making it part of the Constitution.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Prosecutors Want To Ban Toy Guns
description: Prosecutors are weighing a new kind of gun control -- a ban on toy pistols. Realistic plastic handguns, made by toy manufacturers, have been used in several recent robberies in Mexico City, and Bernardo Btiz, the city's chief prosecutor, said he was studying how to limit or ban their sale. Mexico has strict laws against weapons possession but they cannot be applied to a thief carrying a toy. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Compensation For Muslim Families
description: The government has asked the families of nearly 500 Muslims missing since Hindu-Muslim violence convulsed Gujarat State earlier this year to apply for the same compensation -- $30,900 -- that was awarded to families of those killed. Human rights groups say that is an indication that the missing are dead. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Russia's Military Morass
description: It is still not clear whether Monday's deadly crash of a Russian helicopter in Chechnya resulted from mechanical failure or a rebel missile. But either way, it dramatizes two obstacles to President Vladimir Putin's goal of remaking Russia into a modern state. Moscow's increasingly dysfunctional military forces have resisted years of reform efforts, while the Chechen war bleeds Russia's morale and stains its reputation abroad. Mr. Putin should grasp this chance to transform Russia's military as boldly as he has its foreign policy, and find a negotiated solution to the Chechen conflict.

title: Neighbor Guilty of Murder Of Girl, 7, in San Diego
description: A neighbor of a 7-year-old who was taken from her suburban bedroom here and left dead by the side of a desert road was convicted today of her murder and kidnapping, the first of several such crimes to capture attention this year.

title: Not All Airlines Are Caught in the Global Downturn
description: As US Airways filed for bankruptcy protection and other industry giants announced cutbacks to cope with mounting losses this month, Singapore Airlines inaugurated a new service between Singapore and Las Vegas.

The term is banlieue, not banlieu. It refers to any suburb, not just to a suburb in which the government built high-rise housing after World War II.

description: PayPal, which lets people make payments over the Internet, said yesterday that it had reached a settlement with New York State to prevent residents from using its service to gamble online and that it would pay a $200,000 fine for handling such payments in the past.

title: Mexican Leader, Reneging, Bangs Door Shut on a Violent Era
description: Luis Echeverra, a former president of Mexico, has broken a pledge to testify about the killing of student protesters by government forces in the 1960's and 70's and has reverted to the stony silence he has kept for three decades.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Service Spending Dips
description: Spending on services fell in June from May as the World Cup soccer tournament ate into demand for theme parks and other entertainment. The government said that demand for services fell 0.3 percent, slightly better than economists had forecast. For the whole second quarter, though, demand for services rose, suggesting an expansion in the country's gross domestic product during the period. Consumer spending makes up nearly 60 percent of the economy, and has remained steady, despite falling wages and high unemployment. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: ''Liberty exists in proportion to wholesome restraint,'' Daniel Webster famously said. But soon, it may also exist off Exit 13A of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Challenge To Abortion Pill
description: Anti-abortion groups asked the Food and Drug Administration to halt sales of the abortion pill RU-486, saying the agency had violated its own rules by approving sale of the pill without ensuring that it was safe and effective. The groups -- the American Association of Pro-Life Obstetricians and Gynecologists, Concerned Women for America and the Christian Medical Association -- cited an agency report in April detailing complications from the drug, including one death. A spokesman for Danco Laboratories, which makes the pill, said, ''We fully stand behind the safety and efficacy'' of the drug.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Record Industry Presses Verizon
description: In a sign of the growing friction between major copyright holders and Internet service providers, the Recording Industry Association of America has asked a federal judge in Washington to order Verizon Communications to identify a customer accused of illegally copying hundreds of songs. Verizon has refused to comply with a subpoena issued under a process intended to allow copyright owners to get personal information quickly about people suspected of infringement. Internet providers are required by law to turn over such information when a copyright holder identifies infringing material on computers that they control. In this case, the material resides on the individual's personal computer. Verizon argues that the recording industry should be forced to file a lawsuit against the individual, rather than getting the information through the expedited method. Last week, the association asked a judge to order several major Internet providers to block a site in China that distributed thousands of unauthorized songs. That lawsuit was dropped yesterday because the site, Listen4Ever, is no longer operating, but record industry officials said the same approach to blocking a pirate site could be used in the future. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Shares Decline 76% at Storage Computer
description: Shares of the Storage Computer Corporation fell 76 percent today after a British court invalidated two of the company's patents involved in a dispute against its rival Hitachi Data Systems.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Falls
description: In a sign that Brazil's months-long economic slowdown might be bottoming out, the country's unemployment rate fell in July, for the second straight month, helped by job growth in construction and commerce. The government's statistics agency said the jobless rate in Brazil's six main cities fell to 8.2 percent in July, slightly lower than June's 8.3 percent rate. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Software Buyers Find Support Has Its Price
description: FOR 14 years, computer users who bought software by Dantz, a manufacturer of backup programs, received unlimited free technical support by phone or by e-mail. No longer. Earlier this year, Dantz began restricting its free assistance to just 30 days after purchase. Customers who buy an upgrade of a Dantz program get no free help at all. Depending on the product, both types of customers will have to pay either $39.95 or $69.95 per incident to talk to someone who can help solve their problem.

title: How to Make Yourself Reachable in 5 Places at Once
