title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Democrats Drop Plan For 9/11 TV Ad
description: With an assurance from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that Democrats will not be shut out of the city's Sept. 11 anniversary ceremony, the state Democratic Party said yesterday that it had dropped its plan to broadcast an advertisement with elected leaders reciting the Gettysburg Address. The plan had drawn controversy because Gov. George E. Pataki will read the address on Sept. 11 at the official city-organized ceremony. The plan was dropped after Mr. Bloomberg assured Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver that Democratic officials would be invited to read the names of the dead at the city ceremony. Randal C. Archibold

title: Wagner Has an Ugly Round But He's Still Sitting Pretty
description: Johnson Wagner was the only player to shoot under par in today's second round of the Met Open. But he was disgusted with the way he played in ideal conditions. That is because Wagner, who plays out of Hudson National, sets high standards.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: A Gesture To Japan
description: North Korean Red Cross officials have promised to allow visits home in October by some Japanese women who moved to North Korea with their ethnic Korean husbands. About 1,800 Japanese women moved to North Korea from 1959 through the early 1980's, and North Korea strictly controls visits home, not allowing any since 2000. The promise was made to Japanese Red Cross officials in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, in a meeting seen as clearing ground for talks on diplomatic normalization, which are to take place in Pyongyang next week. James Brooke (NYT)

title: A New Look at 'Save the Whales'
description: To the Editor:

title: Eduardo Chillida, Sculptor on a Grand Scale, Is Dead at 78
description: Eduardo Chillida, a Basque sculptor internationally celebrated for his graceful, monumental abstractions in steel, wrought iron, stone and concrete, died on Monday at his home near San Sebastin, Spain. He was 78.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLSTEIN, WILLIAM CHARLES
description: WALLSTEIN - William Charles, 88, died on August 16, 2002 after an illness of several months. Beloved husband of 61 years of Eleanor Scholle, fahter of Nancy W. Newkirk, of Bethesda, MD, Richard S. Wallstein of London, England, and the late Michael W. Wallstein, father-in-law of Thomas and Philippa, grandfather of Jennifer and Christopher Newkirk and grandfather-in-law of Kennon S. Miller, and great grandfather of Eleanor and Henry Miller. Devoted brother of Robert and the late Leonard. Bill graduated from Yale University in 1936. He retired in 1974 from The West Chemical Company as Vice President and started a long and successful career as a volunteer corporate fundraiser for Channel 13 (WNET-NY), The Morgan Library and the New York City Police Foundation. He served for many years as a Deacon at All Souls Unitarian Church of New York. A memorial service will be held on September 15 at 2 PM at All Souls, Lexington Ave. at 80 St., New York, NY. Memorial gifts to the New York City Police Foundation, 345 Park Ave., New York, New York 10154, would be appreciated.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Kidney Hunt
description: A suburban man in need of a kidney transplant placed an advertisement in newspapers searching for a kidney and has received nine responses. Robert Kornblum, 46, of Clayton, who has a hereditary kidney disease, will soon begin screening donors. He has only one partially functioning kidney and is often on dialysis. Even if the donors are not a match for him, he said, he hopes they will consider donating a kidney to one of the 53,000 others on transplant waiting lists. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Readers Share Software Mishaps
description: In my e-mail column last week, I posited that speech recognition would never achieve perfection. As evidence, I supplied a batch of funny "wordos" that my own dictation program has made over the years. Below, some of the best of your thoughtful and hilarious responses -- all, I'm guessing, typed on keyboards.

title: Footlights
description: 'Noises Off' to Close

title: Economic Scene; When the economy hits a turnaround, conspiracy theories abound.
description: ''PREDICTION is very difficult,'' Niels Bohr once remarked, ''especially about the future.'' Lately, predicting the economy's recent past has proved to be difficult, too. Actually, determining last quarter's or last year's growth in gross domestic product has always been difficult and subject to error and revisions.

title: A Parental Black Box For Young Drivers
description: LARRY SELDITZ flew missions in Vietnam, served as a test pilot for the Army and worked as chief operating officer for the Andy Granatelli auto racing organization. His current venture, selling black boxes to ambulance companies and police departments to monitor driving habits, is a natural extension of his experience with aircraft and fast driving.

title: Study Suggests Carbohydrates Are Attacked In Arthritis
description: Scientists may have discovered an important, unexpected clue in the long, elusive search for the cause of rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHER, NORMAN, M.D.
description: SHER-Norman, M.D. The Department of Psychiatry at Maimonides Medical Center is saddened to learn of the death of Norman Sher, M.D., one of the founding doctors of our community mental health center. Our condolences to his family. Marvin H. Lipkowitz, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWN, ALICE ROSEMARIE
description: DAWN-Alice Rosemarie, died August 20, 2002, at home, in the arms of her loving husband, David Aronson, and at peace, after a courageous struggle with cancer. In addition to her husband David, she is survived by her sister Carolyn of Walnut Creek, CA; her brother Robert of Fayetteville, NC; her stepson Daniel and his wife Dina, of Arlington, MA., her stepmother Helga of Southampton, NY and Boca Raton, FL; and her two stepbrothers, Peter Weiden of Brooklyn, NY and Michael Weiden of Bronxville, New York. She was predeceased by her parents David Dawn and Ida Mae Dawn. Born on June 19, 1940 in Brooklyn, NY, Alice moved to Westchester County, NY where she lived until graduating from Scarsdale High School. She then attended Connecticut College for Women where she received her Bachelor of Arts Degree, followed by her Master's Degree in teaching French from Columbia University. Alice touched many people in many different ways. A noted communicator and a student of languages, Alice taught French for four decades. She was on the faculty of Adelphi Academy, Brooklyn and Friends Central School in Philadelphia, PA. During her recovery from Hodgkins Disease in 1994, Alice helped co-found the New England Coalition for Cancer Survivorship (NECCS), serving as its first president. A tireless worker Alice recognized the need that other cancer survivors had for advocacy and education. She worked passionately to achieve legislative changes as well as to educate survivors, medical professionals and the general public. Alice was a warm, outgoing, loving person who fought injustice wherever she came across it. She was a woman of great integrity-honest, straightforward, and direct. She loved life, classical music, and her family. She also loved to laugh. Passionate recycler, she was a firm believer in natural organic products and a champion of the environment. A memorial service is pending. In lieu of flowers, donations in Alice's name may be sent to the NECCS, 6 Strathmore Road, Natick, MA 01760, or the Brigham and Women's Hospital Connors Center for Women's Health, 116 Huntington Ave., Boston, Massachusetts 02116.

title: Critic's Notebook; Updating 'Turandot,' Berio Style
description: That Puccini died at 66 in 1924 before composing the crucial final scene of ''Turandot'' is one of the great losses to opera. Even in its incomplete state ''Turandot'' may be his greatest achievement. That said, in an interesting program note for the Salzburg Festival's fascinating new production of ''Turandot,'' performed with a new ending composed last year by Luciano Berio, the writer Clemens Hslinger wonders whether even with more time Puccini would have managed to complete this scene satisfactorily.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about advertisements by Tom Golisano's campaign for governor, including a commercial contending that jobs have been lost under Gov. George E. Pataki, misstated the increase in the number of jobs in New York State since Mr. Pataki took office in January 1995. According to seasonally adjusted employment figures from the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, the measure used by most economists, the gain was 677,500 jobs, not 385,100.

title: Wait Till Next Year, YES Says
description: The head of the YES Network has given up hope of reaching a deal for its Yankees games to be carried by Cablevision before next year.

title: HSBC Buying Fifth-Largest Bank in Mexico for $1.1 Billion
description: HSBC Holdings said today that it had agreed to buy Mexico's fifth-largest banking group, Grupo Financiero Bital, for $1.14 billion, giving HSBC a strong presence in Latin America's healthiest economy.

title: The First Domino at Enron
description: Eight months into the Justice Department's investigation of the financial shenanigans that led to Enron's unexpected bankruptcy and triggered a crisis of confidence in financial markets, federal prosecutors have reeled in a big fish. Yesterday Michael Kopper, a former managing director of Enron's global finance unit, pleaded guilty to federal money-laundering and fraud charges. Mr. Kopper was responsible for setting up and running some of the notorious off-the-books partnerships that bore names like Chewco.

title: Democratic Demolition Derby
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forum discussions  from the governor's race in New York to the U.N. conference in Johannesburg.

title: City Hall Memo; Council Full Of Neophytes Gets Off To Slow Start
description: This was the year that a huge class of newcomers would bring a fresh sense of activism and urgency to the City Council, furiously passing laws and creating a true partnership with the mayor.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: RWANDA: GENOCIDE SUSPECT PLEADS NOT GUILTY Augustin Bizimungu, a former Rwandan military commander considered one of the architects of the 1994 killing frenzy, pleaded not guilty at the United Nations tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania. Mr. Bizimungu, who was chief of staff of the army, was arrested last week in Angola. He faces 10 counts of genocide and crimes against humanity after being accused of leading the killing of 800,000 people, mostly members of the Tutsi ethnic group.

title: U.S. Open Draw Poses A Problem for Hewitt
description: The United States Open draw did not do the defending men's champion, Lleyton Hewitt, any favors.

title: Hamas Members Held in Recent Bombings
description: Israeli security officials announced today that they had rounded up a group of Arab residents of East Jerusalem belonging to Hamas and said they were responsible for a string of terror attacks over the last four months, including the bombing at Hebrew University on July 31 that killed nine people, including five Americans.

title: US AIRWAYS TO ELIMINATE 200 FLIGHTS AND 31 PLANES
description: The US Airways Group, operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said it would eliminate about 200 flights, or 13 percent of its daily schedule, and take 31 aircraft out of service by the end of the year to lower costs. Most of the changes will occur in September, when the airline, which is based in Arlington, Va., grounds 19 planes and cuts 130 flights, its chief executive, David Siegel, told employees.

title: Israeli Smallpox Move
description: The Israeli security cabinet decided today to vaccinate 15,000 security, medical and rescue personnel against smallpox because of the possibility that Iraq might respond to any American attack with a biological strike on Israel.

title: Dressing Up The Laundry
description: Anyone who hauls laundry down the street to a laundromat will appreciate the new Washpack by BaZillion Bags. The ample laundry bag/backpack was designed by Dylan Lubetkin, a Manhattanite who understands the washday woes of urban dwellers. ''I live in a fourth-floor walk-up,'' Mr. Lubetkin said.

title: Mixed Reviews for Proposed Merger of Power Agencies
description: Operators of the nonprofit agency that supervises New York State's power markets and grid and a similar agency governing the grid in the six New England states announced yesterday that they planned to ask federal regulators to let them merge, in a move that would probably result in lower rates for New Yorkers.

title: In Shift, Program Is Turning Tenants Into Owners
description: Barbara Jean Robinson calls it her ''miracle house.''

title: McPeek Still Has a Shot In Travers With Repent
description: Don't tell Ken McPeek that this year's Travers Stakes barely lives up to its billing as the Mid-Summer Derby, or that this generation of 3-year-olds -- usually horse racing's pin-up division -- is an underwhelming bunch. All McPeek, a 40-year-old trainer, knows is that when he was trying to figure out where to run his colt Repent, the pull of the Spa's premier race was too powerful to resist.

title: Cellphones in School
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Announces New, Tougher Look Into Why the Towers Collapsed
description: Standing next to mangled pieces of steel from the World Trade Center that were mounted like dinosaur bones in a museum, federal officials announced today at a research campus here outside Washington that they were beginning a two-year, $23 million investigation into how and why the twin towers and a third skyscraper collapsed in raging fires on Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: AXA EXPECTS RISE IN INCOME Giving a boost to European insurers hit by the sour securities market and the recent flood damage in Central Europe, AXA, the French insurer, said yesterday that it expected operating income for the first half-year to rise 17 percent, to 1.02 billion euros. That is better than expected and was attributed to better-than-anticipated results at AXA's life insurance business and its property and casualty unit, the company said. But AXA said that net income dropped almost one-third in the period, to 840 million euros, as a result of the cost of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Recipe for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: New Tools Let a Palm Device Do Heavy Lifting on Its Own
description: The ability to write and revise Microsoft Office documents -- the lingua franca of business -- on a hand-held organizer has allowed organizers to pinch-hit for the laptop in many situations. Version 5 of Documents to Go, a program from DataViz that allows users to do just that on a Palm-based organizer, has arrived in two editions, Standard and Premium.

title: INSIDE
description: Running Hard in New Jersey

title: Shelter Units For Families Will Increase, Officials Say
description: When the city announced on Monday that it was immediately converting the Skyway Motel in Elmhurst, Queens, into a 49-room shelter for homeless families, angry neighbors argued that they had become unwilling victims in the battle against homelessness. The city, they argued, was looking for a quick fix to a court order to reduce the number of families sleeping at the Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx, and it was coming at their expense.

title: For the Homeless, a Face Behind the Bureaucracy
description: CAROL DAVID finally went on vacation last week, heading south to Busch Gardens in Williamsburg, Va., even though she's not a major fan of funnel cakes and she tends to get a little dizzy on roller coasters. It wasn't her first choice, but there were four good reasons for taking the trip: her three daughters -- ages 7, 9 and 11 -- and her son, 5.

title: Freidann Parker, 77, Colorado Ballet Head
description: Freidann Parker, a founder of the Colorado Ballet, died on Aug. 2 in Denver, where she lived. She was 77.

title: The Crash in Chechnya: Russia's Gaping Wound
description: The catastrophic loss of a Russian military helicopter on Monday has exposed all that has gone wrong with Moscow's war in Chechnya and the potential political consequences of President Vladimir V. Putin's inability to end it.

title: First Payments Announced From Federal 9/11 Victim Fund
description: Nearly a year after some 3,000 people died in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the federal government today announced the first awards to compensate the relatives of victims, offering 25 families a net average of $1.36 million  from a low of $300,000 to a high of $3 million.

title: Standing Up to Heels At Cond Nast
description: Cheap chic and Cond Nast have always been in conflict. A truth borne out when the lowly ash-veneer plywood floors in the company's canteen, designed by Frank Gehry, had to be ripped out in July. Apparently, the rough-and-ready material couldn't take the relentless beating of Jimmy Choo and Christian Louboutin heels as Cond Nast editrixes breezed through to get their taster-size portions of mango soup. The canteen reopened last week with new fashion-resistant off-white terrazzo, blue-flecked to complement the titanium walls. Frank Gehry's office had no comment.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIRECTV, a satellite television broadcaster and a unit of Hughes Electronics , El Segundo, Calif., sold its 3.1 percent stake in Thomson Multimedia, Paris, the consumer electronics maker, back to Thomson for about $215 million.

title: In Brazil, Gol Succeeds in the No-Frills Path
description: After a friendly preflight greeting in Portuguese, flight attendants for Gol, a domestic airline that hauls Brazilians across their vast country, announce: ''Hi, folks! Welcome to Gol, the really youngest fleet in Brazil.''

title: Letters
description: AWorkhorse

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Architect Finalists Chosen
description: The American Craft Museum has chosen four finalists to compete for the reconstruction of 2 Columbus Circle, the long-vacant marble building overlooking Central Park. They are Zaha Hadid of London, Smith-Miller & Hawkinson Architects of Manhattan, Toshiko Mori Architect of Manhattan, and Allied Works Architecture of Portland, Ore. The almost windowless structure, designed by Edward Durell Stone, was built 38 years ago as Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art. The craft museum plans to buy it from New York City and renovate it for its new home, more than tripling the space it now has at 40 West 53rd Street.

title: Argentine Junta Felt Safe From the U.S.
description: Leaders of the military dictatorship that took control of Argentina in 1976 believed that the Ford administration supported their crackdown on leftist insurgents and would not penalize them for rights abuses, newly declassified State Department documents show.

title: Spontaneous Abstraction Inspires Younger Players
description: Abstract improvisation bloomed from the late 1960's to the early 1980's among young musicians who worked in self-sustaining crews exploring different ways to intersect their various devices and sounds. Among them were a London group, spearheaded by Derek Bailey, and a New York group, of which John Zorn was a principal member.

title: Steer Clear of Trouble
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: An Architect Designs for Himself
description: For the design of his own weekend house, the architect Richard Gluckman cast a wide net, from Palladian villas to contemporary art.

title: Smoking and Venting
description: New York bartenders, waitresses and patrons sound off on the proposed ban on lighting up.

title: Building Up a Shimmer, Stroke by Careful Stroke
description: More than 100 years after its origination by the French painter Georges Seurat (1859-1891), neo-Impressionism has made it to Maine. Billed as the first show in the state's history ever devoted to the movement, ''Neo-Impressionism: Artists on the Edge'' is lighting up the Portland Museum of Art with the radiance so painstakingly achieved by its theory-laden practitioners.

title: Sears, Riding Wave of Nostalgia, Emphasizes Heritage in Campaign
description: A year after Sears departed from tradition by introducing a tongue-in-cheek advertising campaign, the struggling retailer is making a midcourse correction with heart-warming commercials that evoke the company's heritage.

title: Jakarta Journal; A TV Preacher to Satisfy the Taste for Islam Lite
description: Abdullah Gymnastiar, this nation's most popular Islamic preacher, possesses the boyish good looks and eternal smile that send Indonesian women scrambling for invitations to join his television audience. Men come, too.

title: Catskills Casino Plan Clears a Legal Hurdle
description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit yesterday challenging plans by Park Place Entertainment to build a $500 million casino in the Catskills with the St. Regis Mohawk tribe.

title: BUSH SCALES BACK TARIFFS ON STEEL
description: The Bush administration today excluded more than 178 imported steel products from steep tariffs it imposed in the spring, chipping away at an effort to protect the ailing United States steel industry.

title: Space, Inside and Out, That's Filled With Ideas About . . . Space
description: Space may or may not be the final frontier, but for a lot of avant-garde-minded folks, it's where the action is. This is not the kind of space that the Starship Enterprise set out to explore, however. Nor is it the 60's-style, zero-degree space that Minimalism opened up. The concept has metastasized into all kinds of what the professors call contested spaces: public versus private; cyberspace versus tactile space; inner space versus outer space; mental versus physical; aural versus visual. And so on.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: ROLLS PROFIT DOWN 45% Rolls-Royce , which supplies engines for Boeing and Airbus, reported a 45 percent decline in first-half pretax profit, as airlines deferred delivery of new planes after the Sept. 11 attacks. But the company said it had experienced strong orders recently, which would contribute to profit growth in 2003. For the six months ended June 30, pretax profit was 104 million ($158 million), in contrast to 190 million a year earlier. Sales shrank 9 percent, to 2.8 billion. Orders in the first half totaled 16.7 billion, more than the 14.6 billion logged in the first six months of 2001.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: ELIZABETH: PAROCHIAL SCHOOL TO CLOSE

title: There Are Realities to Be Gained From the Illusions of Preseason
description: There are reasons for the ''pre'' in preseason. Everyone reminds us that these are practice games full of players soon to be axed. Little can be gleaned that foretells the regular season.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Couple Are Charged by Jury In Drug Death of Their Son
description: A New Jersey couple whose 18-year-old son died of a heroin overdose last year have been indicted on manslaughter charges by a grand jury that said the parents had acted recklessly in his death.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 5 Arrested In Girl's Death
description: Five people were arrested yesterday in connection with the fatal shooting of a 10-year-old girl outside a Parkchester church, the authorities said. All are suspected members of a Mexican gang called the St. James Boys. Four others, including the suspected gunman, are believed to be heading to Mexico, the police said. The girl, Malenny Mendez, above, was caught in crossfire after a christening party at St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church. Of the five arrested yesterday, Jose Cortes, 20, and Flo Ortega, 16, were charged with criminal trespass for intruding on the party. Edgar Morales, 20, who investigators said handled the gun after the shooting, was charged with tampering with evidence. Jesus Martinez, 26, who investigators said hid the weapon, was charged with tampering with evidence. The fifth person, a 15-year-old girl whose name was not released, was charged with criminal possession of a weapon and tampering with evidence. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Replacing The Hollywood Bowl
description: A three-judge panel of the State Court of Appeal has unanimously ruled that the Hollywood Bowl can replace its landmark 73-year-old orchestra shell. The new $18 million version will be a smooth curvilinear shape, similar to the current shell when it was first installed in 1929 but larger at the footprint, according to the Los Angeles Philharmonic Association. Preservationists had argued that the famous white shell is historically essential to the Bowl, but previous renovations over the last 50 years have failed to remedy severe acoustical problems. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Turning Up Unexpectedly, Old Dad Is Far From Dear
description: The new French melodrama ''How I Killed My Father'' is as dry as summer cornmeal. Here, it's as if the director Anne Fontaine is trying to say that every nationality -- and generation -- needs its own austere and mechanical ''Ordinary People.'' It is just as grimly and pointedly plotted.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: To Catch A Thief

title: S.E.C. Approves Acquisition of Bcom3
description: The Bcom3 Group and the Publicis Groupe said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had approved the Publicis acquisition of Bcom3 for an estimated $3 billion.

title: Foreign Prisoners Becoming a Problem for Karzai
description: To hear the more than 50 foreign prisoners held in the basement of the Afghan intelligence ministry's detention center in Kabul tell their tales of innocence, the months they have spent under interrogation for links to the Taliban and Al Qaeda have been a nightmarish mistake.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profits Dip At Steel Maker
description: ThyssenKrupp, the German steel maker, posted its smallest quarterly decline in profit in at least a year and stuck to its full-year forecast. Net income in the third quarter fell to 202 million euros ($195.7 million), or 0.39 euro a share, from an adjusted 331 million euros, or 0.64 euro a share, in the year-earlier period, a ThyssenKrupp spokesman, Klaus Pepperhoff, said. Shares rose about 4 percent, to close at 13.95 euros. Like its rivals Arcelor and the Corus Group, the German company has raised prices from two-decade lows because of production cutbacks and higher demand. ''We expect the positive trend of the third quarter to continue in general in the fourth quarter,'' ThyssenKrupp said. ''The fiscal 2002 target of 400 million in adjusted earnings before taxes appears achievable.'' The company had backed away from previous forecasts five times since last year. ThyssenKrupp posted a third-quarter pretax profit of 121 million euros at its steel division after a loss of 68 million euros in the second half. The company, which is the largest maker of stainless steel used for forks and knives, has raised prices twice and plans two more increases, for October and January, it has said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas futures rose after reports of a slowdown in the growth of inventories. In New York, natural gas for August delivery rose 24.1 cents, or 7.4 percent, to $3.515 per million British thermal units.

title: Izawa and Goosen Redeem Themselves and Share Lead
description: After watching Retief Goosen and Toshi Izawa hit gorgeous shots at Sahalee Country Club today, it was hard to believe they were both miserable last weekend at the P.G.A. Championship.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The dollar rose against the yen on expectations that American markets will extend a four-week rally, increasing demand for the currency. In New York, the yen settled at 119.89, from 118.45 on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, ERWIN
description: LOWE-Erwin. On August 20, 2002; 90 years of age. Beloved husband of the late Lotte. Loving father of Roger (Ellen) and the late Steven (Elisheva). Cherished grandfather of Eric (Jennifer), Ariel (D'vora) and Susan. Great grandfather of Rafi, Tehila and Allison. Devoted brother of Gerda and Inge. Services 10 AM Sunday, August 25, 2002, from Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Putin Dresses Down Military For Crash That Killed 116
description: President Vladimir V. Putin sharply criticized his military commanders today, bluntly blaming dereliction of duty for the catastrophic crash of an overloaded transport helicopter on Monday near the main military base in Chechnya.

title: Primal Passions, Gruesomely Rendered
description: Not since the Japanese film ''Audition,'' in which a psychotically vengeful woman tortures her male victims with needles, has an art film demanded that the viewer have as strong a stomach as Kim Ki-Duk's brutal allegory, ''The Isle.'' The two most notorious scenes in the South Korean movie, which created a stir on the international film festival circuit, are both gory suicidal gestures involving fishhooks inserted into orifices.

title: Clinton Aide Heads to House, With Waves Preceding Him
description: Rahm Emanuel, the Clinton White House insider now running for Congress, has been turning on the charm with voters here, trying to put to rest a reputation for abrasiveness and ambition. While his potential constituents may be convinced, some of his future colleagues are not so sure.

title: Novartis Drug in Priority Review
description: Novartis said today that Gleevec, an anticancer drug, was receiving a priority review from the Food and Drug Administration in the United States to determine if it can be used by a wider range of sufferers.

title: Nuclear Material Secretly Flown From Serbia to Russia for Safety
description: More than 100 pounds of nuclear material considered at risk of being stolen or sold for use in producing nuclear weapons was secretly flown today from Serbia to Russia, where it will be processed for use in a commercial power plant, United States officials said.

title: New Video Releases
description: Return to Never Land

title: GOLDEN STATE SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE BID BY CITIGROUP
description: Golden State Bancorp said yesterday that shareholders had ap proved Citigroup's planned $4.7 billion takeover of the company, a leading savings and loan, in a move aimed at almost doubling the number of Citigroup branches in the United States. Shareholders of Golden State, based in San Francisco, voted 87.4 percent in favor of the purchase. Golden State did not disclose the number of shareholders who opposed the plan or who did not vote. Ronald O. Perelman, the largest shareholder, with about a 31 percent stake, was among those backing the plan. The two banks expect to complete the transaction by Sept. 30, pending approval from federal bank regulators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINES, WILLIAM L.
description: VINES-William L., 58. A regional sales representative for Mephisto shoes, died of cancer on August 16 in Rockville, MD. He maintained a home in New York City for more than 30 years. Bill was born in Brooklyn, NY, raised in Gales Ferry, CT, and graduated from Mitchell College, New London, CT. He later served in the U.S. Army Combat Infantry and received the Bronze Star Medal for meritorious actions, Vietnam Service Medal and several other commendations. Bill's successful career in the fashion and shoe industry led to Mephisto, an international shoe manufacturer, where he worked from 1990 until last May. Bill helped develop Mephisto into one of the most successful high-quality shoe brands in the US. He was recognized as a leader in the industry who inspired, mentored and developed many young sales associates. Survivors include his parents, Donald and Sally Vines of Seminole, FL, brothers Don of Rockville, MD, Jeff of Moraga, CA, Keith of San Francisco, CA, sister Sally Dugan of Larkspur, CA, six nephews, four nieces and numerous other relatives, beloved friends and devoted business associates. Memorial gifts may be made to: Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, National Processing Center, P.O. Box 96764, Washington, D.C. 20090-6764; and Montgomery Hospice, 1450 Research Boulevard, Suite 310, Rockville, MD. 20850-6101.

title: Accountants Gave to McCall After Getting State Contract
description: A small Philadelphia accounting firm donated at least $24,000 in campaign contributions to H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller who is running for governor, less than a year after winning a lucrative contract from the state, according to records filed with the State Board of Elections.

title: The Plays Are the Thing
description: It's a fine year for theater on DVD. In January Kultur began issuing the first of some 140 works from the Broadway Theater Archive by the likes of Arthur Miller, Tennessee Williams and Eugene O'Neill. Now from Ambrose Video, a New York distributor, come sets of Shakespeare and Beckett.

title: Pataki, in Move Foes Avoided, Uses Sept. 11 in a Campaign Ad
description: A day after New York State Democrats abandoned plans for a television advertisement commemorating Sept. 11, Gov. George E. Pataki became the first political figure who was prominent in the attack's aftermath to address it in a campaign commercial.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Accessories Resource Team, Charlotte, N.C., the association of decorative accessory makers and retailers, to the Coastal Group, New York, as its first agency of record.

title: In Plea Deal, Friend Talks Of Shooting By Nets Star
description: A friend of the former Nets basketball star Jayson Williams testified in court here today that he hid the bloody clothes that Mr. Williams wore during the fatal shooting of a limousine driver in February.

title: Bush Gives Limited Support to Candidate in California
description: DANA POINT, Calif. Aug. 23 - President Bush came to California today for a decidedly restrained day of campaigning of behalf of Bill Simon Jr., the embattled Republican gubernatorial candidate, in a lackluster demonstration of how far the White House believes that Mr. Simon's prospects of unseating Gov. Gray Davis have fallen.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Suit Against Foster-Parent Policy
description: The Arkansas affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union asked a judge to strike down a state policy prohibiting gay and lesbian couples from foster-parent programs. The A.C.L.U. contended that the Arkansas prohibition was rooted in prejudice against homosexuality and that the state had failed to provide evidence that foster parenting by gay or lesbian couples had an adverse effect on children. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LILLIAN
description: GOLDMAN-Lillian. Dearest Lillian, beloved matriarch of the Goldman family, thank you for loving us so selflessly, so completely, for so long. We have been blessed-and will continue to be so-by your warmth, wisdom, and wit; your strength, bravery, and resilience. You are our inspiration and our anchor and we are forever grateful. Love always, Allan, Dee Dee, Amy, Jane and grandchildren and great grandchildren

title: North Korea's Leader Whistle-Stops in Siberia
description: The end of the line for Russia's railway system, an iron road that extends 7,000 miles from the back door of Europe to the Sea of Japan, is here, at a lowered gate over a rusty railroad bridge that blocks access to the Korean peninsula. Just over the Tumen River, lost today in fog and rain, lies North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLOW, BLANCHE
description: BELLOW-Blanche, born July 31, 1904, in New York City, died August 21, 2002, in West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved mother of Anne Ross and the late Marilyn Lee. Survived by sister Rose Feuer. Cherished grandmother of Marlene Hummel, Janis Adler, and Jordan and Jami and the late Mitchell Lee. Dearest greatgrandmother of Phillip and Daryin Hummel, Michael Adler and Jared, Kelsey and Kelin Lee. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St., NYC, on Sunday, August 25, 11:15 AM.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Baby Fed Oxycontin
description: A mother has been arrested for feeding her 5-week-old son the powerful pain reliever OxyContin, the police said. The mother, Amatullah Davis, laced the infant's formula with the drug because the baby, Jabari Hines, was crying too much, the police said. The baby was taken to Connecticut Children's Medical Center on Tuesday with breathing difficulties. His condition was raised yesterday from fair to good. Ms. Davis was charged with assault, reckless endangerment and risk of injury to a minor and released on a $20,000 bond. She could not be reached for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Ewing: New Police Headquarters Planned
description: New Jersey plans to build new state police headquarters, including an emergency operations center, Gov. James E. McGreevey said yesterday. The $125 million project, which will have about 200,000 square feet of office space, is to be completed in September 2005. The headquarters will contain classrooms, dormitories, dining halls and a firing range. It is intended to centralize training programs and replace buildings that date to 1921. ''Training is the linchpin that will ensure that the New Jersey State Police continues to serve as a model for other state police agencies,'' said Superintendent Joseph J. Santiago, above.

title: Harlem's Mobile Fan Base
description: Carmen Gomez missed the bus to Williamsport on Sunday, missing the chance to see her sons Javier and Jorge play in the Little League World Series, so she got to the corner of 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard in Harlem more than an hour early today, just in case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHMER, HAROLD
description: SOHMER-Harold. Died on August 22nd, 2002. Devoted husband of Esther, cherished brother of Irene Kanfer and loving uncle of Abraham, Debbie, and Skyler. He will be greatly missed.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Trouble For Winnie Mandela
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela was found guilty of violating Parliament's code of conduct by failing to report additional income beyond her salary as a legislator. Ms. Madikizela-Mandela, the ex-wife of former President Nelson Mandela, is also on trial on charges of defrauding a bank. She said she had monthly expenses of $6,600 -- more than four times her salary as a member of Parliament -- and said she paid them with additional money from private donors. She will be reprimanded and lose 15 days of her pay. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: HAAS ADVANCES TO QUARTERFINALS
description: Top-seeded Tommy Haas did not flinch under the bright lights last night, pounding out a 4-6, 6-2, 6-1 victory over Agustin Calleri to advance to the quarterfinals of the TD Waterhouse Cup in Commack, N.Y.

title: A Talk Show For Bill Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Postpones a Trip To Florida Next Month
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel has decided to postpone a trip to Florida and California early next month, officials in his office said today. They said the decision had nothing to do with protests from Florida Democrats, who viewed the visit as a political favor to Gov. Jeb Bush, the president's brother.

title: Alfred Ligon Is Dead at 96; Owned Renowned Bookstore
description: Alfred Ligon, the owner of one of the nation's oldest black-owned bookstores, who rebuilt the business after it was burned to the ground in the Los Angeles riots of 1992, died on Aug. 10 at a hospital in Montebello, Calif. He was 96 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: SECRET COURT SAYS F.B.I. AIDES MISLED JUDGES IN 75 CASES
description: The nation's secret intelligence court has identified more than 75 cases in which it says it was misled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in documents in which the bureau attempted to justify its need for wiretaps and other electronic surveillance, according to the first of the court's rulings to be released publicly.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Red Cross Policy On Gays
description: The American Red Cross has adopted a policy that defines family in a ''broad and inclusive'' way to includes gay domestic partners. After receiving reports that the gay partners of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks were having trouble gaining assistance, the charity issued 16 criteria for determining a financially interdependent couple, trained volunteers to interview same-sex partners, and appointed an ombudsman to oversee their cases. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEITELBAUM, LEW
description: TEITELBAUM-Lew. My sweetheart, my soul mate, my beloved best friend. On our 38th wedding anniversary, 42 years of us. You were my life. My excellent strongman, I will miss you and love you forever. Your Sook

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRISAMT, ANITA
description: PRISAMT-Anita. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Int. Sr. Rabbi-Myron Fenster Steven Markowitz, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Chief Executive Arrested
description: The chief executive of a former Enron subsidiary in Britain, Wessex Water, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of accepting a bribe of close to 1 million ($1.5 million), Sally March, a spokeswoman for Wessex, said. The official, Colin Skellet, was being held at an Avon and Somerset police station for questioning. A police statement, which did not name Mr. Skellet, but referred to a senior Wessex Water official, linked the arrest to the $777 million purchase of Wessex Water in March by the YTL Corporation of Malaysia. The police also arrested a second person in connection with the suspected payment. That person, whose identity was not disclosed, has no direct connection with Wessex Water, the police said. The investigation is focused solely on the suspected bribe, the police continued, and ''there is no suspicion of general mismanagement within Wessex Water.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, LILLIAN (NEE MYERS)
description: ROSENFELD - Lillian (nee Myers), 92. Died August 22, 2002, of North Miami Beach, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel Rosenfeld, beloved mother of Alexander M. Rosenfeld and Marcia R. (Manning) Feinleib; loving grandmother of Richard (Katherine), Joel, and Steven (Rachel) Feinleib, and Jeffrey, Stephen, and Barbara Rosenfeld. Proud great grandmother of Laura, Leanna, and Max Feinleib. Sister of Helen Hecht of Invarrary, FL. Lillian was a remarkable woman and a model of successful aging. She was an avid bridge player, intructor, and life master; and a lifelong member of the United Order of True Sisters and past President of the Progress and Biscayne chapters. She will be deeply missed by her loving family and many friends. Funeral services will be held Sunday, August 25 at 10:30AM at the Menorah Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 20955 Biscayne Blvd, Aventura, FL. Interment will follow at Temple Beth El Cemetery, Davie, FL. Donations can be made to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: INSIDE
description: AOL Deals Scrutinized

title: The Sound of Home: An 8,690-Mile Echo
description: IT was almost like home. Samkhann Khoeun sat under a tent on the grassy banks of the Merrimack River watching young Cambodian women in traditional dress perform a classical folk dance on a stage about 20 feet away. ''When I moved to Lowell, I was so fascinated by the Merrimack,'' said Mr. Khoeun, a Cambodian native who has been living in the United States for nearly 18 years, first in Chicago and then, since 1995, in this former textile town 28 miles north of Boston.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The presence of Wylie Dufresne, the original chef at 71 Clinton Fresh Food, was so powerful that many people assumed he owned the place. He did not, though his father, Dewey, was a partner there. Both father and son left last year to create their own restaurant up the block at 50 Clinton Street, to be called WD50 and to open this fall.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Prices Falling
description: Consumer prices were 3.4 percent lower in July than a year earlier, compared with a drop of 3.3 percent in the 12 months through June. The deflation rate had been running at 2.4 percent earlier this year. A consulting firm rated Hong Kong the world's most expensive city in which to live this summer, with everything from apartment rents to movie prices higher than in Manhattan. But a stagnant economy and growing competition from the rest of China are pushing down some costs.

title: BANKNORTH AGREES TO BUY AMERICAN FINANCIAL
description: The Banknorth Group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy American Financial Holdings for $709.3 million in cash and stock, in a move that would quadruple Banknorth's size in Connecticut. Banknorth, which is based in Portland, Me., and already operates a $1 billion banking division in Connecticut, will pay shareholders of American Financial, based in New Britain, Conn., either $32 or 1.22 shares for each American Financial share held. The proposed cash amount is a 2 percent premium to American Financial's close of $31.24. Nasdaq halted trading of American Financial shares at 4:12 p.m.

title: Notes From Laredo; Tracing Clues Along the Border
description: It's night, and I'm tracking a group of 20 illegal immigrants through the thick and tangled brush of south Texas. About 30 miles to my left, the subdued orange glow of the closest city, Eagle Pass, gently illuminates the night sky. It's quiet out here. Besides the wind and the occasional yapping of coyotes, nothing stirs. The terrain lacks much in the way of topography.

title: Corrections
description: The picture caption with the Connections column in Arts & Ideas on Saturday, about the novelist Eric Ambler, misstated the subject of the film ''Topkapi'' and the Ambler novel ''The Light of Day,'' on which it was based. They were about thieves, not spies.

title: Everyman in Autumn, But Superman in Summer
description: IN the world of New York theater, Adam Weinstock, a high school drama teacher who is occasionally the co-producer of an Off Off Broadway show, is pretty much a nobody. But in Provincetown, Mass., he's Mr. Entertainment.

title: Umpire Laughs Off Steinbrenner's Remarks
description: Ria Cortesio hears the jeers and sexist comments all the time. They usually come from the stands, partly driven by beer. The fact that on one occasion they came from a man with power and money and wound up on national television made little difference to her. In fact, it may have been helpful.

title: Undercover Police Break Up Drag Race Near Jones Beach
description: They thought the coast was clear. It was after midnight, and the Wantagh and Ocean Parkways near Jones Beach were nearly empty. A pack of 75 cars had turned out for the drag races. Girls cheered, boys revved their engines, and the New York State Police watched it all in unmarked cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, FANNY
description: ROTH-Fanny. Loving mother of Irwin and Annette, cherished grandmother of Marilyn, Ilene, Michael, Sharon and Stephen. Adored greatgrandmother of Joshua, Lauren and Naomi. Devoted wife of 66 years to a late husband, Phil. Graveside services at 11AM, August 23 at Mt. Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Yao Displays Potential In First Game In the U.S.
description: The most widely publicized American debut of a Chinese athlete took place tonight at the Arena here in an exhibition game between the Chinese and United States national teams.

title: Residential Real Estate; Rents, Especially in Manhattan, Start to Inch Back Up Again
description: The downward lurch of residential rents that began about a year and a half ago in New York City appears to have been halted, according to many brokers and landlords; and some rents, especially in Manhattan, are beginning to inch back up.

title: Wagner Wins Met Open
description: Any doubts about Johnson Wagner's ability among golfers in the metropolitan area was erased this afternoon in the final round of the 87th Met Open.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTHMAN, JESSE
description: ROTHMAN-Jesse. Oct. 3, 1909-Aug. 23, 2001. Dearly beloved, we miss you more everyday. We miss you with every fiber of our being. We love you. Husband, father and grandfather. Your Grieving Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLITI, JULIA
description: POLITI-Julia. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the death of its devoted member Mrs. Julia Politi and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Peter Neustadter, Parmas

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: TWO DIE OF WEST NILE VIRUS

title: Save on the Whales
description: From Nov. 1 to April 15, 2003, the Outrigger Waikoloa Beach Resort on the Big Island of Hawaii will give one guest per room a whale-watching cruise with a stay of four nights or more (ask for it at the hotel). From Dec. 16, a whale sighting is guaranteed on the 90-minute naturalist-narrated cruises, or you can return the next day to try again. The 545-room resort is on the Kohala Coast, and the cruise starts at the resort's beach. It normally costs $59 for adults, $39 for children. Rates start at $189 a room, double. Information: (800) 688-7444 or www.outrigger.com .

title: 'Amy's Orgasm'
description: Directed by Julie Davis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENEMAN, JOHN
description: KOENEMAN-John. A true gentleman and born optimist, John took a genuine interest in people and had a rare gift for putting others at ease. In his three years working at the American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR), his personal charm, can-do attitude, and sometimes outrageous sense of humor won him many friends. John combined style and sophistication with enormous natural warmth. It was impossible not to like him, and he is very sorely missed. The staff of amfAR's Public Information Department

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES TO REDUCE ITS NUMBER OF BUILDINGS
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it would consolidate 5,000 of its staff members into 2 buildings from 11 by 2005, reducing annual costs by $6 million. As part of the consolidation, American's parent, the AMR Corporation, said it had sold its Centerport 2 site in Fort Worth, where American is based, for a $10 million gain. Last week, American said it would eliminate 7,000 jobs, or 5.6 percent of its work force, retire some planes and reduce capacity to help save at least $1.1 billion a year. American had a second-quarter loss of $465 million. American said it had cut 17 percent of its work force since early 2001.

title: S.E.C. Approves Acquisition of Bcom3
description: The Bcom3 Group and the Publicis Groupe said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had approved the Publicis acquisition of Bcom3 for an estimated $3 billion.

title: A Pluralist Exhibition In the Plural Borough
description: ''Queens International'' is not a glittering extravaganza like the Carnegie International or the Venice Biennale, showcasing the big reputations on the global art circuit. The 40 artists in this exhibition at the Queens Museum represent 12 countries on five continents, but what qualified each for inclusion was local residency: they are all from Queens, the most culturally diverse county in America, according to the last census, and the borough that many speculate could become the art world's next Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Women Reach The Quarterfinals
description: United States Coach Tracey Leone made six changes to her lineup, but the result was the same.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Government Attacks Militants
description: The military started bombing suspected hideouts of Muslim militants after they beheaded two Christians kidnapped with six other people earlier this week, officials said. The dead men, Filipino members of Jehovah's Witnesses, were killed by the Abu Sayyaf group, which has previously kidnapped and killed foreigners, including Americans. American-trained Filipino troops were sent to Jolo island in the southern Sulu archipelago to try to rescue the remaining hostages. Two Muslims among the eight people kidnapped were freed by the group but four women are still being held, officials said. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: U.S. Warning On New Move By Musharraf
description: The State Department warned today that Gen. Pervez Musharraf's redrawing of Pakistan's Constitution could hinder democracy in his country, and it called on him to ensure that Parliamentary elections this fall would be free and fair.

title: North Korean Leader Heartily Embraces His Russian Host
description: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia, Aug. 23  Ebulliently declaring himself "1,000 percent happy" with his Russian rail trip, North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, bouncily converted a handshake with Russia's President, Vladimir Putin, into a three-cheek Russian kiss as the two leaders met here today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Widens Exemptions On Foreign Steel Products

title: Pataki's Solemn Thank-You
description: Gov. George E. Pataki released this 30-second commercial for statewide broadcast yesterday. It is the first political commercial in the governor's race to address Sept. 11.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of The Arts on Wednesday about an interview with Tony Randall misstated his roles in the television show ''Mr. Peepers'' and the film ''Pillow Talk.'' He had supporting roles; he did not star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALZARINI, FRANK
description: BALZARINI-Frank. The Officers, Directors, Employees & Owners of Emigrant Savings Bank mourn the passing of Frank Balzarini, Senior Vice President, who served the Bank so well for 41 years. Frank fought his illness bravely for many years and always without complaint. We will miss him. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife, Carole, and his children, Michael Balzarini, Lori Breslow, Jennifer Balzarini, Donna Mazzella, Andrea Galfano and their spouses. Paul Milstein Howard P. Milstein Co-Chairmen, Emigrant Savings Bank

title: Belly Dancing as Solace For a Demure Arab Widow
description: One way (the crass Hollywood way) of looking at Raja Amari's sweetly upbeat film ''Satin Rouge'' might be to describe it as a Tunisian answer to ''Dirty Dancing.'' The story of a beautiful widowed seamstress from a proper family who rediscovers her sexuality through belly dancing has the same gung-ho vision of the swiveling body as a vehicle toward personal liberation as that sexy 80's hit, in which Patrick Swayze partnered Jennifer Grey into womanhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUKER, RABBI NORMAN
description: PAUKER-Rabbi Norman. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the brother of its esteemed member, Mrs. Anita Rothman, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: Cuomo and Running Mate Hit McCall Where It Hurts
description: Taking on H. Carl McCall on an issue Mr. McCall has sought to make his own, Andrew M. Cuomo and his running mate yesterday criticized him for what they called his failure to improve the academic performance of students while he was president of the New York City school board.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Parochial School To Close
description: The Archdiocese of Newark plans to close a nearly 75-year-old parochial school because of declining enrollment. The school, St. Hedwig Roman Catholic Elementary School, which opened in 1928, will not reopen this fall because only 55 children registered for the new school year, or slightly more than half the previous year's enrollment. Annual tuition was raised to $2,230 from $1,730 per student, the archdiocese said, but if the school had remained opened, it would have posted a deficit of at least $350,000. St. Hedwig's students will be placed in nearby Catholic schools, the archdiocese said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLDE, ERNEST J.
description: OLDE-Ernest J. A pioneer in the discount stock brokerage business and founder of Olde Discount Corporation, died on Sunday, August 4, 2002 from complications arising from cancer. Interment took place at a private ceremony held on August 7, 2002. Mr. Olde founded the predecessor to Olde Discount Corporation in 1971 and converted the company to a discount stock brokerage. He maintained ownership until December, 1999 when the business was sold to H & R Block. The company enjoyed great success in the 1990's when it established a nationwide network of 200 offices with the support of approximately 2,000 employees. Mr. Olde, who was a graduate of the University of Toledo, had many diverse interests including all forms of art and served as a patron to sculptors and painters. He also was an admirer of silk Asian rugs and developed particular expertise in Chinese carpets. Mr. Olde is survived by his wife Susan Anne Olde, his son E. Jacob Olde and daughters Erica Jane Olde and Christine Louise Kjos and her husband Eric Kjos and their children Michael and Stephen. Donations in memory of Mr. Olde may be made to the Essex Region Conservation Authority, at 519-776-5209.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, JEANNETTE
description: NEWMAN-Jeannette. In our hearts, still. Jeff, Charles and their Families

title: LIMITED BRANDS SAYS QUARTERLY EARNINGS ARE UP 16%
description: Limited Brands said yesterday that earnings rose 16 percent last quarter and that its second-half profit would match forecasts. Limited Brands, which owns the Limited, Express and Victoria's Secret stores, said its net income increased to $83.2 million, or 16 cents a share, from $71.6 million, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the second quarter, which ended Aug. 3, fell 3.6 percent, to $2.11 billion, reduced by the sale last year of the Lane Bryant chain. Limited said it kept inventory low, so it offered fewer price cuts, helping to widen profit margins. Limited, based in Columbus, Ohio, is forecast to earn 4 cents a share in the third quarter and 76 cents in the fourth, according to Thomson First Call.

title: Glaxo Sues Some Generic Rivals
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the British pharmaceutical company, said today that it had filed lawsuits against several generic drug makers, accusing them of using a stolen strain of bacteria to make versions of its antibiotic Augmentin.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Utility Files For Bankruptcy
description: Companhia Energtica do Maranho, owned by the PPL Corporation, has filed for bankruptcy, the first electric utility to do so since Brazil started liberalizing the sector in the 1990's. The National Electric Energy Agency intervened shortly after the utility, known as Cemar, filed bankruptcy proceedings late on Monday. The agency named Sinval Zaidan Gama acting chairman for at least 180 days so the company's financial problems do not interfere with electricity supplies to Cemar consumers. A court must decide, meanwhile, what to do with Cemar's $180 million in debt. PPL said in January that it would write off its investment in Cemar, worth about $300 million. It bought Cemar in 2000, but has suffered because of electricity rationing, a sharp devaluation of the Brazilian currency and an uncertain regulatory climate. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: HUTCHISON BUYS DRUG CHAIN The Asian billionaire Li Ka-shing, left, bought the Kruidvat Group, based in the Netherlands, for 1.3 billion euros ($1.26 billion), adding a drugstore chain to European assets that include mobile phone licenses and ports. Mr. Li's Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. , which posted a 17 percent drop in first-half profit yesterday, is buying the 1,900-store chain to lift the European expansion of its A. S. Watson drugstore and supermarket business, its managing director, Canning Fok, told a news conference. It may also help sell phone services, he said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sentence In Attempted Rapes
description: A man who admitted at least two sexual assaults on women in the bathrooms of fashionable bars was sentenced yesterday to 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 years in prison. The man, Eric Lewenstein, 27, is the son of a wealthy Manhattan physician and frequented restaurants popular with young singles. Midway through a sensational trial in June in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, he accepted a plea bargain to admit guilt in two attempted rapes. Both victims spoke at the sentencing, one calling Mr. Lewenstein's prison term ''pathetic'' in view of the brutality of his attacks. Mr. Lewenstein did not speak. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Inside Art
description: The Inside Art column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: Wells Continues to Stand the Test of Time
description: David Wells insists he is pitching on borrowed time. His back just might fail right there on the mound, he has suggested, ending his career with one excruciating snap.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Franciscan And Assault Charges
description: A Franciscan brother charged with sexually assaulting four Boston altar boys in the 1970's was ordered to remain in the state while his case was pending. The brother, Fidelis DeBerardinis, 75, pleaded not guilty last week to 11 counts against him, including rape of a child and indecent assault and battery on a child younger than 14. Prosecutors contend that Brother DeBerardinis molested four boys at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in the East Boston neighborhood at various times from 1968 to 1973. The Franciscan order posted his $10,000 bail last week. He will live on Cape Cod, at a home for retired Franciscans. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Suspension of Hostilities Over Diplomats' Tickets
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has clocked hours in San Juan, Santo Domingo and Jerusalem. He has sent a message to representatives of Taiwan, Cuba and the Palestinian Authority by excluding them from a Gracie Mansion reception. But the mayor may have achieved his biggest foreign policy coup so far -- at least in theory -- in negotiating an agreement with foreign governments for payment of some of their outstanding parking tickets.

description: LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD UNCLOAKED

title: United Way Chief Urges Clean Sweep in Washington Office
description: The head of the United Way of America, the umbrella organization for the nation's 1,400 United Way affiliates, called yesterday for the resignation or ouster of the head of the troubled United Way in the Washington area and his management team.

description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa's Reigning Pop And Its Upbeat Ambassador
description: Bongo Maffin, the South African band that finished its United States tour on Wednesday night at S.O.B.'s, has appointed itself the international ambassador of kwaito, South Africa's current reigning pop style.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Ciena Reports Net Loss For 3rd Quarter
description: As spending cutbacks continue at major telephone companies, Ciena, a leading supplier of networking equipment, said yesterday that it would have a net loss for the fiscal third quarter because of slumping sales. Company officials said sales dropped to $50 million from about $458 million -- a decline of nearly 90 percent to the lowest level since Ciena's initial public offering in 1997. ''In the face of the pronounced downturn in telecom spending, Ciena continues to strive for a balance between sustained, strategic investment that will drive future revenues and prudent cost management that will help return us to profitability,'' said Gary Smith, the company's chief executive. The loss for the quarter that ended July 31 was $160 million, or 42 cents a diluted share, in contrast to net income of $5.7 million, or 2 cents a diluted share, for the period a year earlier. Shares of Ciena, which is based in Linthicum, Md., fell 37 cents, or 8.2 percent, to $4.12. In May, Mr. Smith said, ''We cannot pretend to know when the telecommunications industry will recover.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Riverstone To Lay Off 30% Of Work Force
description: Riverstone Networks, a maker of Internet equipment whose shares have dropped 93 percent this year, said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 30 percent of its workers, or 143 people, as fiscal second-quarter sales plunge. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., expects the move to reduce expenses by $7 million a quarter. Riverstone currently has 477 employees, said a spokeswoman, Tracy Pina. Riverstone's sales have eroded as telephone and Internet companies spend less on equipment. The company said sales would be $10 million to $15 million in the quarter ending Aug. 31, down from the $55.3 million reported for the period a year earlier. The equipment maker forecast a net loss of 23 cents to 29 cents a diluted share for the quarter. Excluding $5 million in expenses to lay off employees and close plants, and amortization costs, it expects a loss of 18 cents to 24 cents. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, an estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected the company to have a loss of 11 cents.

title: Wipers That Know What to Do
description: When the raindrops fall, the wipers know. More and more windshield wipers have the good sense to turn themselves on when it rains. Rain-sensing wipers are now standard in almost every luxury car, including BMW, Cadillac, Lexus, Lincoln and Mercedes-Benz. As options, they are working their way onto mainstream cars like Toyotas and Chevrolets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ANNETTE S. (NEE SUMBERG)
description: KLEIN-Annette S. (nee Sumberg). Died on August 22. Dearly beloved sister of Mort (Fran) Sumberg and the late Ruth L. Sumberg. Loving aunt of Jeff and Debra Sumberg. Loving great-aunt of Lori Sumberg. Services are private by ''Wien & Wien''.

title: Amazon Forest Still Burning Despite the Good Intentions
description: By decree, the official burning season here in the Amazon is supposed to be severely limited in scope and not to start until Sept. 15. Yet the skies south of here are already thick with smoke as big landowners set the jungle ablaze to clear the way for cattle pasture and lucrative crops like soybeans.

title: Ad Citing Kashmir Stirs Fury in India
description: An advertisement run last week by Cadbury India, the local unit of the multinational candy and soft drink maker Cadbury Schweppes, has stirred up a national political controversy and obliged the company to issue a public apology.

title: J. P. MORGAN IS BUYING A RESEARCHER OF TRADING COSTS
description: J. P. Morgan Chase agreed yesterday to buy the Plexus Group, a closely held firm that provides research on trading costs and execution, as it seeks to increase services to pension funds and other institutional investors. J. P. Morgan did not disclose the terms of the purchase. J. P. Morgan also said it had created an alliance with Inalytics, based in Britain, which offers research like that of Plexus, which is based in Los Angeles.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: NIGERIA: GOVERNMENT OPPOSES STONING SENTENCE The government is "totally opposed" to an Islamic court's ruling that a single mother be stoned to death for having sex outside marriage and will aid the woman's appeal, Justice Minister Kanu Agabi said. On Monday, an Islamic court in the northern town of Funtua rejected Ms. Lawal's appeal against the stoning sentence. Nigeria is deeply divided about the application of Islamic law, which has been adopted by a dozen states in the mainly Muslim north. (AP)

title: Bookseller Falls Short Of Estimates
description: Barnes & Noble Inc., the book retailer, reported second-quarter earnings yesterday of $1.43 million and said profit for the year would be less than expected.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Anti-Harassment Law Fought
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union has filed a lawsuit on behalf of a Manhattan man arrested under New York State's anti-harassment law. The group, which filed its suit on Wednesday, argues that the law violates the First Amendment when enforced against speech that does not include personal threats. In April, Carlos Vives, 65, of Manhattan mailed eight pages of handwritten biblical references and newspaper clippings to Jane S. Hoffman, then a candidate for lieutenant governor. Mr. Vives was arrested, questioned and released. Gail Donoghue, a lawyer for the city, defended the arrest as part of a legitimate investigation. She noted that Ms. Hoffman is Jewish and that the materials included ''biblical references to Judaism, including a reference to death and killing.''

title: Searching For Love, Unwisely
description: Uma Thurman, left, stars as Debby, a lonely working-class New Jersey woman looking for love in all the wrong places in ''Hysterical Blindness,'' which will be on HBO Sunday night. The film, directed by Mira Nair (''Monsoon Wedding''), traces the bumpy emotional road traveled by two best friends, and in the process, immerses us in the daily lives of ordinary people. Co-starring with Ms. Thurman is Juliette Lewis as her bar-hopping pal, Beth. An added bonus comes from the appearance of Gena Rowlands as Debby's waitress mother and Ben Gazzara as her devoted, late-blooming beau.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Focus Enhancements Chip Accepted For Xbox
description: Focus Enhancements said Microsoft had accepted its FS454 semiconductor chip for use in the Xbox video game console. The share price jumped as much as 65 percent and ended the day up 37 cents, or 28 percent, at $1.70. Earlier the shares had reached $2.20. They have risen 27 percent in the last year. Focus Enhancements, which is based in Campbell, Calif., and Microsoft began working together in May 2001 to develop a low-cost video chip that would improve the look of Xbox video games on television screens and still fit into the existing game console design, Focus Enhancements said in a statement. The chip converts signals from the Xbox console for playback on standard and high-definition television sets, a Focus Enhancements spokesman, Steve Sheldon, said. The FS454 chip will help Microsoft cut costs for components and make the unprofitable Xbox system more competitive in the video game market. Analysts estimate that Microsoft, the world's largest software maker, is losing $50 to $150 on each Xbox console sold. Focus Enhancements expects to receive orders from Microsoft shortly, said Sean Leous, an outside spokesman for the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JOSEPH S.

Truly a gentleman, his elegance and grace touched many people. We will remember him especially for his generosity, love of life, music and writing, but most of all, his dedication to his family and fellows. Brigitte Lewis-Diederich Joseph S. Lewis III & Family

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 12 about a new railroad station that stands idle in Rensselaer, N.Y., near Albany, misstated the rank of the current station among the busiest nationwide. With 600,000 passengers last year, it was the 14th busiest, not the 10th.

title: Chechen Rebels in Limbo Vow Endless Resistance
description: The band of 60 fighters had stopped for the night beside a shallow river in the rugged mountains of southern Chechnya on July 27 when the full fury of Russian military force fell on them before dawn.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES REDUCES ITS HIGHEST FARES 25%
description: Southwest Airlines, the largest discount airline, reduced its highest one-way ticket price 25 percent yesterday, sharpening fare competition as larger rivals cut service to try to stem losses. The cut, to $299 from $399, applies even to tickets bought at the last minute, Southwest said. Southwest's highest fare is available on 36 percent of its routes and is paid by 1.3 percent of its passengers, the airline said. Southwest, based in Dallas, is one of the few major United States airlines to remain profitable since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks worsened a travel slump.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Hutchison Buys Drug Chain
description: The Asian billionaire Li Ka-shing, left, bought the Kruidvat Group, based in the Netherlands, for 1.3 billion euros ($1.26 billion), adding a drugstore chain to European assets that include mobile phone licenses and ports. Mr. Li's Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., which posted a 17 percent drop in first-half profit yesterday, is buying the 1,900-store chain to lift the European expansion of its A. S. Watson drugstore and supermarket business, its managing director, Canning Fok, told a news conference. It may also help sell phone services, he said.

title: From Zero Candidates to Two In Senate Primary in the Bronx
description: A State Senate district in the Bronx that started the day without any candidates on the Democratic primary ballot ended the day with two, after an appeals court restored the incumbent, Pedro Espada Jr., and the party organization backed the candidacy of the Rev. Ruben Diaz Sr., a city councilman.

Until then, beginning in September, residents will be restricted to two hours of lawn watering on designated days. Penalties will be doubled for violations, and large water users will have to pay a surcharge. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: A man who threatened to blow up a car filled with explosives near the Moscow headquarters of the Federal Security Service, formerly the K.G.B., was arrested after a standoff during which he demanded a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin. The man held what appeared to be a gun in his hand and said he had explosives strapped to him and had a bomb in his truck. After the police detained him, the gun was found to be a fake and the sacks in his truck turned out to be filled with cement. The man has been charged with terrorism. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Looking for Love, Finding Heartbreak

The opposite is true with Uma Thurman and Juliette Lewis in ''Hysterical Blindness.'' Beneath big hair, tight clothes and thick New Jersey accents, they bring enormous empathy to their roles in this small-scale, beautifully made character study about two best friends in their 20's.

title: What Is America's Commitment to Iraq?
description: The prospect of an American war against Iraq is generating growing opposition around the world. One way the administration could transform the debate is to lay out, in advance and in some detail, its vision for Iraq after Saddam Hussein. And to prove America's ability to implement such a vision, the administration must demonstrate a new resolve to secure and rebuild Afghanistan.

title: 36 Hours | Black Hills, S.D.
description: AS western South Dakota rises gradually toward Wyoming, its seemingly endless expanse of wheat fields is broken abruptly by the Black Hills, a tangled maze of topographical features where Indians of the Great Plains battled Army troops in the 1870's. Today, grain-harvesting combines and razor-straight highways east of the Black Hills give way to a broken and wooded landscape laced with serpentine roads through pine forests and granite passes. There is more wildlife here than there is in some of the country's most famous national parks, but the area has somehow been spared the throngs of recreational vehicles and cars that choke roads in and around better-known places. The Black Hills cover a sizable corner of South Dakota, so putting some mileage on the odometer is part of the journey. This is not a trip for serious foodies, however: the local cuisine tends to be more chicken-fried steak than pan-seared scallops, so adjust your culinary expectations accordingly. KARL CATES

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: No Anthrax Found At 2 Postal Centers
description: No anthrax spores have been found in samples collected Sunday at postal centers in Edison and Eatontown, the authorities said yesterday. Vito Cetta, a regional Postal Service official, said he hoped the findings would reassure postal workers and the public that they do not face risks from the anthrax found Aug. 8 in a mailbox in Princeton. The two centers are among five facilities that process mail from Princeton. Results of samples gathered at the three others are expected early next week. Robert Hanley (NYT)

description: The economy grew 6.3 percent in the second quarter, from April 1 through June 30, compared with the second quarter of last year, keeping pace with forecasts of more than 6 percent growth for the year, the Bank of Korea said yesterday. The bank said, however, that the economy grew only 1.4 percent from the first quarter, a rate that was somewhat less than expected. The economy was powered by exports of motor vehicles and electronic items, including semiconductors, despite fears of the impact of the downturn in the United States economy on exports. title: QUARTERLY PROFIT RISES TENFOLD AT WILLIAMS-SONOMA
description: Second-quarter earnings at Williams-Sonoma rose tenfold as the company sold more home furnishings at full price at its Williams-Sonoma and Pottery Barn stores, but the company cut forecasts of same-store sales growth, sending its shares down 6.2 percent. Net income in the period, which ended Aug. 4, rose to $14.1 million, or 12 cents a share, from $1.35 million, or 1 cent. Sales, including shipping fees, rose 16 percent, to $495.6 million. Catalog sales rose, while same-store sales remained unchanged. The chief executive, Dale W. Hilpert, has changed purchasing procedures and cut inventory since taking over in April 2001. Shares of Williams-Sonoma fell $1.65, to $25.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rolls Profit Down 45%
description: Rolls-Royce, which supplies engines for Boeing and Airbus, reported a 45 percent decline in first-half pretax profit, as airlines deferred delivery of new planes after the Sept. 11 attacks. But the company said it had experienced strong orders recently, which would contribute to profit growth in 2003. For the six months ended June 30, pretax profit was 104 million ($158 million), in contrast to 190 million a year earlier. Sales shrank 9 percent, to 2.8 billion. Orders in the first half totaled 16.7 billion, more than the 14.6 billion logged in the first six months of 2001.
