title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Globalstar Cuts Some Prices
description: Globalstar Telecommunications, an operator of a worldwide satellite telecommunications system that filed for bankruptcy protection in February, slashed rates for calls and handsets in an effort to gain business. Some high-volume satellite phone callers will be eligible for rates as low as 17 cents a minute for calls in the United States and the Caribbean. Globalstar's prices typically ranged from 79 cents to $1.60 a minute before the cut. The new prices range from 17 cents to a little over $1 a minute. Globalstar also cut the price of handsets 25 percent, to $599 from $799. The company says that more than over 80 percent of the world's land surface and essentially all ocean regions remain outside the range of cellular telephone networks. Costly satellite telephone service, however, has found relatively few customers and the companies providing it have suffered. ''These aggressive new price plans now open up our business to a vast new array of potential customers,'' Olof Lundberg, chief executive of Globalstar, said in a statement. ''Just as we saw only 10 years ago in the cellular industry, once a reliable, useful communications service like ours reaches a certain critical price point, it can rapidly move to a rate of dramatic growth and broad acceptance.''

title: Poor Defendants, Poor Lawyers

A defendant facing life in prison in New York State, the articles noted, can get a lawyer who is paid just $693, less than the cost of an average real estate closing.

title: Examining How the Towers Collapsed
description: The Bush administration kicked off a vital two-year investigation this week of the factors that caused the World Trade Center towers to collapse last Sept. 11. It is a necessary follow-up to the initial six-month inquiry into the structural collapse, which was hobbled by a lack of resources and legal authority. The only missing element now is subpoena power for the federal investigators so that they can compel testimony and the production of documents. The House has passed a bill granting that power, and the Senate needs to do likewise.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Novell Reports Profit As Sales Rise 13%
description: Novell, whose NetWare software competes with Microsoft's Windows operating system, posted a fiscal third-quarter profit of $9.9 million yesterday, bolstered by a 13 percent sales increase and lower expenses. Net income for the quarter ended July 31 was 3 cents a diluted share, in contrast to a net loss of $19.3 million, or 6 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $282.3 million from $249.1 million, and operating expenses declined 20 percent. Novell has been expanding into new products after losing market share to Microsoft in operating system software. Last month, Novell bought SilverStream Software to add programs used to run Web applications. Demand for Novell's programs was stronger than expected in Europe and remained sluggish in the United States, the chief financial officer, Ron Foster, said. ''In the software world, the continuing reports are that the information-technology marketplace isn't rebounding,'' Mr. Foster said. ''The consulting business globally and notably in the U.S. has still not completely leveled out.'' Novell shares, which have dropped 54 percent this year, climbed as high as $2.78 after the news was announced. But by the close of regular trading they had fallen 9 cents, to $2.09. Excluding purchased in-process research and development, Novell said it would have earned 4 cents a diluted share in the recent period. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, Novell had been expected to earn 2 cents, the average estimate of three analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Excluding certain items, fourth-quarter profit will be less than in the third quarter because of costs from the SilverStream purchase, Mr. Foster said. Sales will be about $10 million more than in the third quarter, the company said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew for the fifth straight month, thanks to strong shipments of electronics, automobiles and semiconductors. The country's surplus hit 752 billion yen ($6.3 billion) in July, 80.3 percent more than the same month a year ago. Exports over all grew 8.9 percent, but shipments to the United States dropped 1 percent. Imports grew for the first time in a year because of purchases of airplanes. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Stitching Together a Melody

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: GLOBALSTAR CUTS SOME PRICES Globalstar Telecommunications, an operator of a worldwide satellite telecommunications system that filed for bankruptcy protection in February, slashed rates for calls and handsets in an effort to gain business. Some high-volume satellite phone callers will be eligible for rates as low as 17 cents a minute for calls in the United States and the Caribbean. Globalstar's prices typically ranged from 79 cents to $1.60 a minute before the cut. The new prices range from 17 cents to a little over $1 a minute. Globalstar also cut the price of handsets 25 percent, to $599 from $799. The company says that more than over 80 percent of the world's land surface and essentially all ocean regions remain outside the range of cellular telephone networks. Costly satellite telephone service, however, has found relatively few customers and the companies providing it have suffered. "These aggressive new price plans now open up our business to a vast new array of potential customers," Olof Lundberg, chief executive of Globalstar, said in a statement. "Just as we saw only 10 years ago in the cellular industry, once a reliable, useful communications service like ours reaches a certain critical price point, it can rapidly move to a rate of dramatic growth and broad acceptance."

title: National Briefing | West: California: No-Talking Order Stands
description: The State Supreme Court declined to hear appeals of orders barring lawyers and witnesses in two criminal cases from talking to journalists. The appeals, filed by The Associated Press and two newspapers, said such orders were a growing trend in the state. ''Trial courts are imposing gag orders as a matter of routine,'' wrote Rachel Matteo-Boehm, a lawyer for the news groups, and said the judges had not provided adequate justification for the orders. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip-Making Equipment Sales Fell In June
description: Sales of equipment used to make semiconductors slumped for a 16th consecutive month in June, an industry group said. The decline was the smallest in percentage terms since March 2001. Global sales slid 18 percent, to $1.85 billion, in June from a year earlier, the Semiconductor Equipment Association of Japan said. Orders, which become sales about six months after they are received, have begun rising as chip makers decide to purchase more machines to prepare for a recovery in demand. Orders for chip-making equipment made in Japan rose 42 percent in June, the fourth consecutive monthly increase. Global equipment sales fell 64 percent, to $4.05 billion, in the first quarter from the period a year earlier. Orders fell 36 percent, to $4.15 billion, Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International said. Worldwide chip sales last year dropped 32 percent, to $154 billion, from $227 billion the previous year, according to Dataquest, the market research unit of Gartner Inc. Sales will probably rise 3.4 percent this year, Dataquest said.

title: A Rare Memoir Of a Massacre Returns Home
description: The French and Indian raid on Deerfield, Mass., on Feb. 29, 1704, was not the first attack on the fledgling village, founded in 1669, but it was the most devastating: in all, 56 people were killed; 112 men, women and children were taken prisoner; and half the town was torched. The event, known as the Deerfield Massacre, is considered a critical event in New England frontier history.

title: Bush Defends Logging Initiative as a Better Means of Management Against Forest Fires
description: Stepping through the blackened cinders left by one of the worst forest fires in Oregon's history, President Bush asserted today that his proposal to allow more logging in national forests would prevent catastrophic blazes and lift local economies.

title: Plantation Homes: With Torn Petticoats, They Wait to Rise Again
description: WHO: Terry Cobbs, a medical technician.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the artist Larry Rivers last Friday misstated the role of the writer Jack Kerouac in a 1959 film short, ''Pull My Daisy,'' which featured Mr. Rivers. Kerouac was the narrator; he did not appear in the film.

title: The Plays Are the Thing
description: It's a fine year for theater on DVD. In January Kultur began issuing the first of some 140 works from the Broadway Theater Archive by the likes of Arthur Miller, Tennessee Williams and Eugene O'Neill. Now from Ambrose Video, a New York distributor, come sets of Shakespeare and Beckett.

title: Mets Approach The Worst Kind Of Milestones
description: Six years ago Monday is the exact anniversary -- Mets Manager Dallas Green and his coaching staff walked across the field at Dodgers Stadium after a losing road trip and left for New York. Green was fired upon returning to Shea Stadium, and the Mets elevated their Class AAA manager, Bobby Valentine, to fill his position.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: FOCUS ENHANCEMENTS CHIP ACCEPTED FOR XBOX Focus Enhancements said Microsoft had accepted its FS454 semiconductor chip for use in the Xbox video game console. The share price jumped as much as 65 percent and ended the day up 37 cents, or 28 percent, at $1.70. Earlier the shares had reached $2.20. They have risen 27 percent in the last year. Focus Enhancements, which is based in Campbell, Calif., and Microsoft began working together in May 2001 to develop a low-cost video chip that would improve the look of Xbox video games on television screens and still fit into the existing game console design, Focus Enhancements said in a statement. The chip converts signals from the Xbox console for playback on standard and high-definition television sets, a Focus Enhancements spokesman, Steve Sheldon, said. The FS454 chip will help Microsoft cut costs for components and make the unprofitable Xbox system more competitive in the video game market. Analysts estimate that Microsoft, the world's largest software maker, is losing $50 to $150 on each Xbox console sold. Focus Enhancements expects to receive orders from Microsoft shortly, said Sean Leous, an outside spokesman for the company.

title: Teachers and Catholic Archdiocese Reach a Tentative Contract
description: The union representing teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in New York City and its suburbs announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract that calls for an 11 percent raise and improved retirement benefits.

title: Newcomers' Businesses Restore Old Towns to Life
description: There have been days lately when Mildred Johnson has had to park half a block from her storefront office. The reason, she said, is Kelly Laster.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 15 about a fine imposed on the campaign to re-elect Mayor Anthony A. Williams of Washington misidentified the court that ruled that his nominating petitions were fraudulent enough to justify barring him from the primary ballot. It was the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, not the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

description: CALIFORNIA: NO-TALKING ORDER STANDS

title: For 2 Stepsisters, 2 Choices on Homelessness
description: They are two stepsisters. Both are unmarried mothers on public assistance, both were raised in the same apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and both say they do not have enough money to pay rent. Yet only one of them is homeless.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you are in his way, look out. When he is by your side, there is nobody better. Nobody. Members of Congress are going to find both sides of him.''

title: Serbian Election Unlikely to End Rivalry Among Reformers
description: Serbs are expected to turn their backs on an extreme form of nationalism when they vote for president next month, but the election is unlikely to resolve a bitter power struggle among the reformers who toppled Slobodan Milosevic.

title: State's Largest Charter School Faces a Critical Year
description: The academic year is off to a rocky start at the Charter School for Science and Technology, the state's largest charter school. Earlier this month it announced that it was dropping its 9th- and 10th-grade programs for this year, forcing 122 students to scurry to find other schools. The beginning of classes has been delayed by nine school days, to Sept. 4, to give teachers and administrators more time. The science tables have not been installed for laboratory work. The job of principal remains unfilled.

title: Private Money Pads Packages Of Public University Leaders
description: Some of the country's highest-paid officials at public universities are being compensated at levels once considered the domain of their counterparts at private institutions, a survey published today by The Chronicle of Higher Education shows.

title: FOOT LOCKER POSTS A PROFIT FOR THE SECOND QUARTER
description: Foot Locker said yesterday that it had swung to a profit in its second quarter after divesting itself of some operations last year. Net income came to $31 million, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter ended Aug. 3, in contrast to a net loss of $14 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding items, the company, based in New York, earned $32 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with $28 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said that it expected to earn 28 to 30 cents a share in the third quarter, and that earnings for the year ending next February should be $1.12 to $1.14 a share.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK ONE, Chicago, said it was negotiating with Prime Group Realty Trust, Chicago, to buy the Dearborn Center, a 1.52-million-square-foot skyscraper under construction in downtown Chicago. Bank One has leased space there and plans to open a trading floor.

title: People
description: * Brad Epstein was named to the new post of executive creative director at the Lord Group, New York, and its parent, Spier New York. He had most recently been executive creative director at I-Traffic, New York, part of Agency.com. Bethany Chamberlain continues as president, chief executive and executive creative director at Spier.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Prisoner Is Caught After Escape
description: A man arrested on weapons charges escaped from a precinct station house yesterday and was rearrested a short while later, the police said. Afterward, Officer Edward Velasquez was suspended for his role in the incident; the police would not elaborate. The man, Omar A. Alihayphe, 26, was arrested on Wednesday and was being held at the 41st Precinct station at 1035 Longwood Avenue before being taken to court. He escaped at 12:35 p.m. yesterday and was rearrested at 2:15 p.m., the police said. More than 20 prisoners have escaped from police custody this year, prompting the department to review procedures and mete out harsher discipline to officers who fail to safeguard their prisoners. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Weekender | Red Hook, N.Y.
description: BROADWAY at Market Street in Red Hook looks like a poster for Main Street, U.S.A. Actually it is on a poster -- framed and on display in Billie's Family Restaurant a few steps away. The poster announced a 1986 conference that dealt with historic preservation, and Red Hook seems to have taken the concept to heart. The village center with its red-brick storefronts, 90 miles up the Hudson Valley from New York, still has the feel of a Norman Rockwell painting.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: BROTHER HELPS BROTHER ESCAPE A suspected Basque terrorist escaped from a high-security prison in Paris by switching places with his brother during a visit, prison officials said. The escape from Sante prison happened Saturday but was discovered only yesterday, they said. The man who escaped, Ismael Berasategui Escudero, is suspected of being a member of the Basque separatist movement E.T.A. "There is a natural physical resemblance between the two men," the prison director, Alain Jego, said. "It's hard to tell them part." (AP)

title: How About A Civilized Cab, Please, Driver
description: AMERICAN taxicabs can shock unsuspecting Londoners. Riding into Manhattan from Kennedy International Airport at rush hour, they're likely to find themselves cramped in the back seat, knees pressed against an ugly metal barrier, with seat belts buried under the seat cushions, air-conditioning too low or heat too high and bags crunched into the trunk.

title: Deep in the Night, When You Can Walk in Beauty
description: Hiking purists might disagree, but New York at night, very late at night, is a great setting for a long walk at a fast pace. In summer the heaviness of the daytime air can weigh down the bounce in anyone's step. But at night an unexpected breeze can inspire walkers to tread again on city sidewalks. Best traversed after midnight when they're mostly quiet, the streets become a wide open, well-lighted trail system, unfolding an urban version of awesome beauty.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: President's Foe Pursued
description: Federal prosecutors began an effort to strip Yulia Timoshenko, a top legislator and fierce critic of President Leonid D. Kuchma, of the immunity from criminal prosecution granted all members of Parliament. They asked Parliament to lift Ms. Timoshenko's immunity so they can arrest her on charges that include embezzling state funds. Among other crimes, Ms. Timoshenko is accused of taking $2.2 billion in government money when she ran the national electricity monopoly before winning election to Parliament in 1998. She has called the accusations a political vendetta. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Hingis Falls Apart After Leading Myskina
description: After winning the first-set tie breaker, Martina Hingis was one point away from a 5-1 lead in the second set last night before she unraveled under unrelenting pressure from Anastasia Myskina.

title: Peter Martin, Writer for The Financial Times, Dead at 54
description: Peter Martin, chief business columnist and associate editor of the Financial Times, has died at the age of 54 after a near two-year fight against cancer.

title: A Talk Show For Bill Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Prison: You Think They'll Just Talk It Over?
description: It could be a moment right out of an episode of HBO's ''Real Sports'': Jim Lampley interviewing a proud heavyweight champ who is sitting behind prison bars, stripped of his title after being convicted of rape. The boxer gives a couple of common-sense answers to questions: he refutes the contention that boxing is a sport. People play baseball, they don't play boxing, he asserts, and proclaims himself a gladiator. When asked about his guilt, he goes ballistic, and the interview is over.

title: Radio Station Cancels a Show After Complaints of Indecency
description: A popular afternoon radio show was canceled yesterday by WNEW-FM, hours after federal regulators ordered an investigation into complaints that the show's hosts broadcast a live eyewitness account of a couple having sex in the vestibule of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: FOSTER WHEELER TO BUILD POWER PLANT FOR PPL CORP.
description: Foster Wheeler said yesterday that it had received a $200 million contract to build a natural gas-fired power plant in eastern Pennsylvania for the PPL Corporation, the utility owner and energy trader. The plant, the Lower Mount Bethel project, will be in Bangor, Pa., about 20 miles northeast of Allentown. It will have a capacity of 600 megawatts and be capable of lighting about 480,000 homes. It is being financed by LMB Funding, which is owned by a subsidiary of PPL, and will begin operating at the end of next year, Foster Wheeler said.

title: Shortage Ends As City Lures New Teachers
description: After years of struggling to recruit enough certified teachers to fill even half of its classroom vacancies, New York City has attracted more than 8,000 qualified candidates for the fall, in effect ending what school officials called the most crippling teacher shortage in decades.

title: S.U.V. Haters Pitch a Curbside Battle
description: WITH people crowding the sidewalks and music from clubs and cars in the air, it was the kind of summer night in Greenwich Village when energy seems to emanate from the pavement. Joseph Edmonds, in a dark baseball cap and a white polo shirt, might have been looking for the right nightclub. Instead, he was studying the rows of parked cars.

title: Black Farmers Seek Settlements From Bias Suit
description: Black farmers with well-used tractors and a mule protested today outside the Department of Agriculture, asking for immediate settlement of their cases from a five-year-old lawsuit charging that the government had refused them loans because of their race.

Minuse & her husband Henry Stevenson, and William B. Minuse Jr. Devoted grandfather of James Minuse Stevenson & Robert Minuse Stevenson. Mr. Minuse was a retired engineer for the FAA at JFK Airport, a former Vestryman & for many years Senior warden of the Caroline Church. Reposing at the O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, 4839 Nesconset Hghwy (Route 347), Port Jefferson Sta. L.I. Visitation Friday 7-9 PM. Religious service Saturday 2 PM at the Caroline Church, Setauket. Interment Caroline Churchyard Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions would be appreciated to the Caroline Church, or the Three Village Historical Society.

title: Rough Start for Regulator in Japan
description: It has been an inauspicious beginning for Shokichi Takagi, the new commissioner of the Financial Services Agency. In the six weeks since he was promoted to the post at Japan's chief financial regulator, stock prices have tumbled to near 18-year lows, nonperforming loans have hit record highs and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has backed down on a crucial part of a banking reform effort.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Business Aid At Ground Zero
description: Two groups said they would offer about $15 million in grants and loans to small businesses seeking to remain in Lower Manhattan. The groups, Seedco, a nonprofit community aid group, and the Alliance for Downtown New York, said that businesses with 10 or fewer employees could apply for the aid if they were on or below Chambers Street. The grants have a maximum of $50,000 and the low-interest loans, $100,000. Information is available at (866) 473-3326. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Victims' Fund Announces First Awards
description: Nearly a year after 3,300 people were killed or injured in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the federal government yesterday announced the first awards to compensate the relatives of victims, offering 25 families an average of $1.36 million, from a low of $300,000 to a high of $3 million.

title: Garrett Holds Edge in No. 2 Quarterback Battle
description: Jason Garrett's voice is assuring when he speaks to Giants kicker Owen Pochman, like a jockey chatting steadily into the ear of a thoroughbred. Let's go out and get 3 points, Garrett says evenly, confidently.

title: Power Grab in Pakistan
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf's latest assault on Pakistan's democratic aspirations requires a strong rebuke from Washington. The Bush administration is understandably grateful to General Musharraf for breaking with the Taliban last year and supporting American military operations in Afghanistan. Yet any credible long-term strategy against terrorism must include consistent American support for democracy throughout the Islamic world.

title: Pinault To Sell Unit To Staples
description: Dispelling concerns over a possible liquidity squeeze, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, the French retailer, said today that it had agreed to sell the mail- order division of its Guilbert office- supplies unit to Staples of the United States for 825 million euros ($809 million).

title: British Aide Says Toppling Hussein Is Not a Goal for London
description: Reinstating United Nations weapons inspectors not the removal of Saddam Hussein -- is the centerpiece of Britain's policy toward Iraq, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said today.

title: G.M. Won't Buy Fiat Unit
description: General Motors, the world's largest automaker, said today that it was not interested in buying Fiat's car-finance unit, paving the way for some of Italy's biggest banks to purchase it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: SUNY Suspends Program In Israel
description: The State University of New York has suspended a longtime study program in Israel, citing concerns for the safety of the two remaining participants. The program, begun in the 1970's, averaged 40 students a year until recently. Heidi Weber, a SUNY spokeswoman, said the decision was prompted by a travel warning by the State Department after five Americans were killed in the July 31 bombing of a cafeteria at Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Last week, students were notified of SUNY's decision, which was first reported by The Jewish Week. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAIDAMAST, DANIEL
description: NAIDAMAST - Daniel, 80 years old, a Great Neck resident, passed away quietly in his sleep at the Nesconset Nursing Home on August 22, 2002 following a long illness. Professionally, Mr. Naidamast was Aerospace Engineer and worked for several companies in the metropolitan New York area including Kollsman Electronics and the Loral Corporation. It was at Loral where he was engaged in testing components for the radar warning receiver, which alerts F-15 fighter pilots to incoming surface-toair missiles. A 47 year resident of Great Neck, Mr. Naidamast was active with the Nassau County Council Boy Scouts of America for more than three and a half decades. He initially served as the Scoutmaster of Troop 446, which met at the Baker Hill School in Great Neck and later served as a Neighborhood Commissioner, responsible for working with adult leaders from numerous troops in the county area. He also was an elected member of the Sagamores, an honorary group of adult scout leaders. Mr. Naidamast was born and raised in the Bronx and graduated from Evander Childs High School. He later earned a Bachelor of Science in Engineering and a Masters in Business Administration from the City College of New York. Mr. Naidamast is survived by his wife Nille, his daughter Elion, his son Edward and four grandchildren, Adam, Samuel and David Austin and Ilana D'vorah Naidamast. Services Friday 12:30 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: MEN'S WEARHOUSE CUTS FORECAST FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
description: Men's Wearhouse lowered its earnings forecast yesterday for the third quarter and the year. Profit for the third quarter, which ends Nov. 2, will be 25 to 26 cents a share, less than the 37-cent average estimate from Thomson First Call, the company said. Men's Wearhouse expects profit of $1.30 to $1.32 for the full year, lower than $1.44, the average estimate of analysts. Men's Wearhouse, based in Houston, held its midyear sale in June instead of August this year, and that will cut third-quarter sales to about $315 million from an earlier estimate of $325 million, a spokeswoman said. The sale did not bring in the revenue expected, and August sales will not make up for the shortfall, she said. Shares of Men's Wearhouse fell $1.07, or 5.24 percent, to $19.35.

title: A Delicate Challenge for the 'Voice of Organization'
description: NO way does this petite, self-effacing person in the understated black pantsuit and matronly pearls match up with the sweeping, self-aggrandizing rsum that delineates her professional history. First she apologizes for her small, stuffy temporary office at sleek black Liberty Plaza. Then she explains that the sole poster taped to the wall is crooked because she's too short to reach it and straighten it out. Talk about counterintuitive come-ons.

title: Shared Memories and Tips As Fans Revisit Saratoga
description: For 20 years now, Marion Russell, Jack Farrell, Jim Purgerson and more than 15 other dedicated racing fans have come from Massachusetts and Kentucky, Connecticut and Illinois, and have taken up residence in the 10-room Brunswick Bed & Breakfast. The reason can be seen from the shaded porch where they spend most of their time: across Union Avenue is Saratoga Race Course, horse heaven.

title: Some Insurers Halt Coverage for Vans Linked to Rollovers
description: After deadly rollover crashes of 15-passenger vans that killed or injured young athletes, church choir members and summer campers, a growing number of colleges and churches are prohibiting or severely limiting the use of the vehicles, and some insurance companies are refusing to insure the vans as costly lawsuit settlements threaten to cut into their profits.

description: The verdict is in on the American debut of Yao Ming, the 7-foot-5 Chinese center who will enter the N.B.A. this fall.

title: Rangers Torment Mussina With Four Home Runs
description: Still trying. Still tinkering. Still tormented. Mike Mussina continues searching for the calm, competent formula that has made him one of the best pitchers in the American League for a decade. The formula has deserted Mussina this season, leaving him to figure out what has happened, causing him to tinker with pitches and making him a sometimes tormented soul.

description: BERER-Ethel. On August 22, 2002. Loving sister of Sonia Kessler. Dear aunt of David, Paula and Daniel. Cherished great-aunt of Aaron, Jonah, Jason, Jordan, Molly & Mina. description: The investigation into Salomon Smith Barney and Jack Grubman, its former star telecommunications analyst, escalated yesterday when AT&T said that it had received a subpoena from the New York attorney general for documents related to Salomon's selection in April 2000 as an underwriter for one of AT&T's largest stock offerings.

title: TENET PLANNING $1 BILLION IN CAPITAL PROJECTS
description: Tenet Healthcare said yesterday that it would spend $1 billion in the year ending in May 2003 on capital projects at its 115 hospitals. The projects include expanded emergency and medical services and the construction of a new hospital, the company said. Tenet said it was expanding its facilities to meet the needs of an aging population. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., spent $889 million in the previous fiscal year on capital projects and bought six hospitals. It plans to finance the projects from its internal cash flow and its lines of credit, a spokesman, Harry Anderson, said.

title: Politics in Moscow More Dagger Than Cloak
description: Americans like to call their politics a blood sport. They should come to Moscow, where to a worrisome degree that is more than just a metaphor.

title: Chinese Hold Their Breath as a Swollen Lake Recedes
description: Under incongruously blue skies, more than 100,000 troops and hundreds of thousands of villagers patrolled dikes around giant, swollen Dongting Lake in central China today as officials expressed cautious hope that they had averted any major disaster from the summer's most menacing flood.

title: A New Name for Newark Airport?
description: To the Editor:

title: Imperfect Pearls? What Would Jackie Say?
description: Spotlighted on the second page of Tiffany's baby-blue catalog -- in the past, a fantasy of quarter-million-dollar diamond brooches and million-dollar emerald necklaces -- is a small and simple pearl bracelet with a silver clasp.

title: Women Are Nurturing? How About Cruel, Especially to One Another
description: Phyllis Chesler is a feminist psychotherapist, author of several books about women and the founder of the Association for Women in Psychology. In her latest book, ''Woman's Inhumanity to Woman'' (Thunder's Mouth Press/Nation Books, 2002) she explores the often cruel relationships between women. Felicia R. Lee spoke with her.

title: Veterans' Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Injury and Concerns, Haas Reaches Semifinals
description: Nagged by a troublesome right arm and distracted by his parents' recovery from an accident, Tommy Haas has had a difficult week at the TD Waterhouse Cup. But he is still around to provide marquee wattage to a tournament that needs it.

title: Local United Way Leaders Worry About Fund-Raising
description: Local United Way organizations are calling for a swift resolution of investigations into their affiliate in Washington, D.C., fearing that it poses a threat to them as they gear up for their annual fund-raising campaigns.

title: DELAY IS SOUGHT IN EFFORT TO SELL HERSHEY FOOD
description: The attorney general of Pennsylvania, Mike Fisher, asked a state judge yesterday to prevent the Hershey Trust Company from making any sale of Hershey Foods until the authorities can decide whether court approval is necessary. Mr. Fisher filed a motion for a temporary restraining order with the Dauphin County Orphans' Court, which oversees charitable trusts. According to Mr. Fisher's Web site, he is also drafting legislation to make the trustees consider the impact of a sale on Hershey, Pa., where Hershey Foods is based. The trust said last month that it was putting Hershey Foods up for sale.

title: V.A. Suggests Halt to Kind of Knee Surgery
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs has issued an advisory to its doctors recommending that they not perform a common knee operation until it is reviewed by a panel of experts.

title: Money matters : In Australia, expats face a taxing time
description: When new residents in Australia begin paying taxes, they probably will find that their adopted country is not just distant but expensive.

title: The Secular Society Gets Religion
description: FROM the recent Supreme Court decision supporting vouchers for religious schools to a lower court objection to the phrase ''one nation under God'' in the pledge of allegiance to wrangling over cloning, stem-cell research, euthanasia and genetic engineering, religion has been re-entering the public arena in complex and unforeseen ways.

title: Frustration Mounts for Mets
description: DENVER, Aug. 23  The attendants to the visiting clubhouse at Coors Field quietly closed the door following the Mets' 10-4 loss to the Colorado Rockies, their 12th straight defeat.

title: Privacy Furor As Baby Death Goes Unsolved
description: Seeking leads in the gruesome killing of a newborn baby in May, the county attorney here has subpoenaed the names of hundreds of women who had pregnancy tests at a local Planned Parenthood clinic. The organization is fighting the subpoena in the Iowa Supreme Court.

title: At 100, Hitler's Filmmaker Sticks to Her Script
description: AS she celebrates her 100th birthday with friends and a new film, Leni Riefenstahl, Hitler's favorite mythmaker, is trying to sell her innocence to yet another generation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Contamination After Floods
description: The floods last weekcrippled Prague's sewage treatment plant, letting most of the capital's human waste flow directly into the Vltava River, which joins the Elbe and passes through Dresden and Hamburg and other German cities. Fearing more contamination, officials say they have detected small amounts of mercury in the river and are awaiting results of tests to see if the Spolana chemical factory at Neratovice leaked dioxin into the Elbe. The Czech police have begun a criminal investigation into the plant's handling of chemicals after one metric ton of poisonous chlorine gas escaped into the air when the plant was inundated. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Martha Graham Center Wins Rights to the Dances
description: A federal district court judge ruled yesterday that the Martha Graham Dance Company has the rights to virtually all of the choreographer's works. The decision is a sweeping victory for the center in its protracted battle with Ronald Protas, Graham's heir.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNER, MICHAEL
description: CONNER-Michael. On August 23, 2002, of Rego Park, NY. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Helaine and Monte Magid, Allan and Sheila Conner. Adored grandfather of Laura, Scott, Jennifer and Allison. Cherished great grandfather of David & Lyndsay. Services on Sunday at 12 Noon at Parkside Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT CLIMBS. The Canadian government said drought would reduce this year's harvest by a quarter, to a 28-year low. In Chicago, wheat for delivery in December, after the harvest, rose 8 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $3.59 a bushel.

title: A Monk and His Love: The Opposites Connect
description: Yin Mei has a striking visual sense and an authoritative way with social and literary themes. All that was in evidence in ''/Asunder,'' performed by Yin Mei Dance on Sunday evening at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here. But the stylish economy of her 1999 ''Empty Tradition/City of Peonies,'' also performed at the Pillow, was missing from ''/Asunder.''

title: Making Way For the Big Ships; Recovered Since 9/11, The New York Harbor Is Awash in Cruise Liners
description: New York's late sleepers will dream right through it. But this morning, as on most weekend days this month and next, four cruise ships are expected to dock within an hour of one another at piers along the Hudson River, depositing thousands of seafarers with sunburns, palm-tree-print shirts and rhinestone-encrusted flip-flops just off the West Side Highway.

title: GADZOOX NETWORKS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Hurt by waning sales, Gadzoox Networks Inc., a maker of products for data storage networks, said yesterday that it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The bankruptcy petition, filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of California, listed assets of about $10 million and liabilities of about $14 million. The company, which sells its hardware and software primarily to manufacturers like Hewlett-Packard, said it was exploring additional or replacement financing. Gadzoox, based in San Jose, Calif., also said it planned to relocate its headquarters within the same area.

title: A Guiding Force
description: There was this little girl with pigtails well, not so little at 11 years old and tall for her age -- who thought she was pretty cool. She had begun attending P.S. 146 in Astoria, Queens, and decided to skip school. Not for a day, not for two days, but probably forever. A week went by and her grandmother, who had taken the girl into her home after her alcoholic parents were unable to care for her, found out. She raised the roof with school authorities -- ''How come no one told me! -- but she was calm with her granddaughter.

title: U.S. and Russia Resolve Chicken Dispute
description: The United States and Russia resolved a dispute over chicken parts that had blocked American exporters from selling to their largest overseas market for six months, settling health concerns over the food product.

title: World Business Briefing | North America: Canada: Profit Outlook Changes
description: Citing a severe downturn in the business aircraft market, Bombardier Inc. said that it would fall short of its target of 10 percent profit growth for the current fiscal year. The company, which makes executive and regional jets and railroad equipment, is to report second-quarter earnings on Tuesday. It estimated that net earnings would be 70 cents a share for the three months to July 31, down from estimates of 89 cents. Bombardier said it would also take a write-down on used commercial aircraft stemming from US Airways' filing for bankruptcy protection this month. The company is based in Montreal. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Salary Doubles for Chief of P.&G.
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (Bloomberg News)  The Procter & Gamble Company , the largest United States maker of household goods, more than doubled the salary and bonus of its chief executive, A. G. Lafley, to $3.62 million as the stock led the Dow Jones industrial average last year.

title: Alexander Klein, 83; Wrote Spy Thriller
description: Alexander Klein, an author whose spy thriller ''The Counterfeit Traitor'' was made into a Hollywood movie in 1962, died at his home in Manhattan on Aug. 13. He was 83.

title: Golisano Set To Challenge Registrations Of Voters
description: The gubernatorial campaign of Tom Golisano pressed ahead yesterday with efforts to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki's bid to register thousands of new voters in order to win the Independence Party's ballot line in the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Sustaining the Planet
description: With the American president a conspicuous exception, leaders from nearly 100 nations will begin assembling next week in Johannesburg to address the future of life on this planet. At the heart of the conference is a formidable if now familiar challenge -- figuring out ways to bring economic well-being to billions of people now trapped in poverty without destroying the land, water, air and biodiversity required to sustain life itself.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Muslim attitudes toward the coming anniversary of Sept. 11 gave an incomplete context for a quotation by Talib Abdur-Rashid, imam of the Mosque of Islamic Brotherhood in Harlem. He was referring to terrorism in general, not exclusively to the attacks of Sept. 11, when he said of Muslim leaders: ''We haven't had a lot to say about it. Now we have a lot to say about it.'' And he acknowledged only that some Muslim leaders -- not many -- were less than forceful in condemning the attacks.

title: Georgia Moves Against Rebels And Accuses Russia of Airstrikes
description: Fighting flared on Russia's border with Georgia today, as Georgian forces moved to drive out Chechen fighters from a lawless region near Chechnya that has become a flash point between the countries.

title: Kmart Shift on Financing
description: The Kmart Corporation, the largest retailer to file for Chapter 11 protection from creditors, said today that its $2 billion bankruptcy credit line was enough, and it dropped a proposal for a $500 million increase. Last week, Kmart asked a federal bankruptcy judge in Chicago for permission to borrow another $500 million. Kmart said it needed the money to reassure suppliers as it went into the holiday season and losses mounted in a weak economy.

title: Cuomo Spends Night at a Homeless Shelter
description: At the end of a speech yesterday on his plan to reduce homelessness, Andrew M. Cuomo announced with a flourish that he was going to spend the night in a shelter in order to ''bring light to places that have been in darkness for too long.'' Hours later, he headed to Bedford-Stuyvesant, where he bedded down for the night in a private room with his running mate.

title: Two Venerable European Festivals, One That's Magical and One That's Not
description: In his first season as the artistic director of the Salzburg Festival in Austria, Peter Ruzicka, a composer and polymath, has the solid support of the festival's trustees. Things are different at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany, where Wolfgang Wagner, the composer's pugnacious grandson (who turns 83 next week), tenaciously clings to the directorship, waving his lifetime contract at all challengers, who have included a niece and a daughter, both estranged.

title: Cuomo in the Clinton Years
description: Andrew M. Cuomo began running these two similar television advertisements on his record as the secretary of housing under President Clinton. One, ''Real Results,'' will be broadcast upstate; ''Real Rsum'' will be broadcast in the New York City area.

title: Suburb's Residents Not Pacified by Charge in Student's Death
description: Residents of this Westchester County suburb expressed a modicum of relief today that someone was being brought to task in the case of a local teenager who died after a fistfight at a house party.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deported Family Can Appeal
description: An Afghan family that was deported to Germany from Britain, where it had sought refuge in a mosque, can appeal the government's decision, the High Court in London said. The court ordered a judicial review of the case to begin as soon as possible but did not grant the family the right to return to Britain while the appeal was heard. Farid Ahmadi, 33, his wife, Feriba, 24, and their two children fled Afghanistan and said the Taliban had persecuted them. The Home Office refused to grant asylum, arguing the family would first have to apply for protection in Germany, where they first sought sanctuary. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: On the Cover of the Book Review
description: JULY 14

title: Allenby Scorches Back Nine to Share the Lead
description: When Robert Allenby reached the 11th tee this afternoon, something clicked. From there, almost all of his shots were struck purely. Almost all of his putts found the hole. And almost every hole presented another birdie opportunity.

title: Torre Contends Rodriguez Has the Stuff of an M.V.P.
description: The Yankees have two strong candidates for the Most Valuable Player award in Alfonso Soriano and Jason Giambi and another possible candidate in Bernie Williams, but Manager Joe Torre stared across the field at Alex Rodriguez of the Texas Rangers last night and called him the best player in the American League this season.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Sells Rights
description: The troubled Irish drug maker, Elan, sold its marketing rights for a hypertension treatment, nifedipine ER, to Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. as part of its efforts to sell off $1.5 billion worth of assets by December 2003 to cover its debt. Financial terms were not disclosed. Elan will continue to manufacture the drug, the generic version of Bayer's Adalat CC product, for the Biovail Corporation, another distributor, to fulfill Federal Trade Commission competition regulations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: McTaco vs. Fried Crickets: A Duel in the Oaxaca Sun
description: The town square in this old city is a kind of sacred space. Beside a cathedral, under ancient shade trees, people sit for hours on cast-iron benches, passing time slowly, framed by stone arches glowing golden in the afternoon light.

title: Lawyer Urges Judge to Free Detained Muslim
description: The lawyer for an American Muslim who is being detained in a terrorism investigation told a federal judge here today that his client should be released because he had not been charged with a crime.

title: A New Name for Newark Airport?
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Requested From Global Crossing
description: Global Crossing said today that it had received a request for information from the New York attorney general, who is investigating whether securities firms improperly won investment banking business.

title: TIVO SHARES GAIN ON STRENGTH OF EARNINGS REPORT
description: Shares of TiVo Inc. rose 9.6 percent yesterday after the company, which makes devices that digitally record television shows, reported a narrower second-quarter loss. The shares rose 40 cents, to $4.57. The company's loss narrowed to $3.04 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with $34.5 million, or 82 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the quarter, which ended July 31, rose almost sixfold, to $23.9 million. The sales were helped by licensing fees related to MyCast, a digital-video recorder that Sony built using TiVo technology.

title: Payton Doubts Disappear in Colorado
description: DENVER, Aug. 23  Jay Payton received a phone call from Armando Benitez today and spoke with some former teammates, reliever Mark Guthrie and outfielder Tony Tarasco, before the Mets took the field. But the best sign that he is missed can be found in his mail.

title: Zeile Distances Himself From Valentine
description: DENVER, Aug. 23  Bobby Valentine's remarks in a radio interview Wednesday that he had not established enough disciples in the Mets' clubhouse this season caused some of his players to shake their heads. Today, though, one of the players who Valentine tabbed as a former disciple questioned the strength of his relationship with Valentine.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about a court appearance by a Nigerian woman convicted of having had sex out of wedlock misstated the date of the scene in some copies. She was shown on July 8, when the appeal of her sentence to death by stoning was postponed for a month -- not on Monday, when the appeal was rejected.

title: Sale to Wilpon Is Final
description: Fred Wilpon completed his purchase of Nelson Doubleday's half of the Mets yesterday, making him the sole owner of the team.

title: Friend of Nielsen
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Tuesday about a court appearance by a Nigerian woman convicted of having had sex out of wedlock misstated the date of the scene in some copies. She was shown on July 8, when the appeal of her sentence to death by stoning was postponed for a month  not on Monday, when the appeal was rejected.

title: Chinese Oil and Gas Company To Buy Into Australian Fields
description: CNOOC Ltd., a Chinese offshore oil and gas company, said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy a stake in a group of Australian gas fields for $320 million, and that it had stepped up output of Indonesian oil, two further signs of China's rapid expansion in East Asia's energy markets.

title: National Briefing | Religion: Bishops Make Last Appointment To Panel
description: The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops named the last appointee to the national review board formed in response to the clergy sexual abuse scandal: Justice Petra J. Maes of the New Mexico Supreme Court. The panel of 13 Catholic laypeople, headed by Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, will study the extent and causes of sexual abuse by priests and monitor the bishops' efforts to prevent abuse. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISCHOFF, ETTA (GUYER)
description: BISCHOFF-Etta (Guyer), 95. Died August 22, 2002. Cherished friend and beloved wife of Gilbert R. Bischoff for 66 years. Devoted mother of Sara Jane Bischoff and the late Alan Guyer Bischoff. Burial was at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Grubman Pleads Guilty in Crash That Hurt 16 at Club in Hamptons
description: What began more than a year ago outside a trendy Hamptons nightclub -- a crash that injured 16 people and sparked a tabloid tizzy over the driver, Elizabeth S. Grubman -- neared a conclusion today inside a spartan Suffolk County courthouse.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a debate in Cobb County, Ga., on the teaching of evolution referred incompletely to action by the school board on Thursday. The board tentatively approved a requirement for teachers to give equal weight to evolution and biblical interpretations about the origin of life. But the policy will not take effect until the board votes again on Monday; final adoption did not occur on Thursday.

title: Europeans May Hold Their Fire on U.S. Steel Tariffs
description: European Union officials hinted today that the union might put off retaliating against United States steel tariffs until next year, signaling that Washington may have bought itself some time by greatly narrowing the scope of the disputed tariffs.

title: Newark Approves Arena Financing Deal
description: Newark's City Council tonight approved a tentative deal with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that could help the city finance a proposed downtown sports arena without assistance from the State Legislature -- a hurdle that has blocked an arena for the last two years.

title: Back in America : Farewell to those lazy Augusts
description: NEW YORK  As summer nears its end, I can no longer delay my real re-entry into American life. I finished graduate school in May and now I am slowly on my way to becoming an average American worker  a terrifying prospect for one overwhelming reason: vacation days.

title: McAFEE BOARD BACKS PURCHASE BY NETWORK ASSOCIATES
description: Network Associates Inc. said yesterday that it had won support from McAfee.com's board to buy the remainder of the company's shares for about $224 million in cash and stock. McAfee shareholders had rejected a previous offer. Network Associates, which owns 75 percent of McAfee.com, won backing for its offer of 0.675 share and $8 in cash for each McAfee.com common share. That combination totals $18.46 a share, based on Network Associates' closing price of $15.50 on Thursday. McAfee.com, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., makes antiviral software. Network Associates, based in Santa Clara, Calif., first proposed a takeover in March. Its shares have lost more than half of their value since then, and Network Associates has increased the exchange rate on the offer four times.

title: A New Name for Newark Airport?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Project For Golf Course Stalls in Fight Over Landfill
description: When construction of the Ferry Point golf course started two summers ago, it was the culmination of nearly 15 years of civic dreaming. Not only would New York City have a championship golf course that it hoped would draw the likes of Tiger Woods, it would also clean up a glaring eyesore in an isolated corner of the Bronx.

title: Pataki Is Using Fiscal Tricks To Avoid Cuts, His Rivals Say
description: Gov. George E. Pataki rode into office eight years ago as a fiscal conservative, railing about the fiscal gimmicks and spendthrift policies of his Democratic predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LILLIAN
description: GOLDMAN-Lillian. Dearest Lillian, beloved matriarch of the Goldman family, thank you for loving us so selflessly, so completely, for so long. We have been blessed-and will continue to be so-by your warmth, wisdom, and wit; your strength, bravery, and resilience. You are our inspiration and our anchor and we are forever grateful. Love always, Allan, Dee Dee, Amy, Jane and grandchildren and great grandchildren

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: GAY ADOPTION VICTORY

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Halting Of Transplants
description: Liver transplants at The University of Massachusetts Memorial Medical Center in Worcester have been suspended since last week, when the director and founder of the program, Dr. Eliezer Katz, was fired. About 50 patients on the hospital's waiting list may be transferred to one of four hospitals in the Boston area if a liver becomes available. The hospital said Dr. Katz was fired because he would not cede control to a new program director. He is suing for wrongful termination. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: 9/11 Mental Care
description: To the Editor:

title: For Two Giants, Long Steps Back From Surgery
description: When the Giants opened training camp a month ago, center Dusty Zeigler stood on the side and watched the other offensive linemen work out, wearing a visor, idly spinning a football in his hands, waiting for his surgically repaired knee to heal. Now, 12 days from the start of the regular season, Zeigler's practice regimen has not changed and he will probably miss at least the first game of the regular season.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush's California, Limited

title: World Business Briefing | North America: Canada's Wheat Crop Down
description: Canada's wheat harvest this season will be the lowest in 28 years, and production of barley and canola will also be far below normal, Statistics Canada said. The agency ascribed the poor outlook to a combination of drought in western provinces and heavy grasshopper damage. Wheat production is estimated at 15.4 million metric tons, a drop of 25 percent. The canola crop is expected to shrink to 3.2 million metric tons, half the average of the last 10 years. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: YUGOSLAVIA: PRESIDENT TO SEEK SERBIAN POST President Vojislav Kostunica said he would run for the Serbian presidency in the election next month. The decision sets up a showdown between camps from the reformist movement that ousted Slobodan Milosevic in 2000  Mr. Kostunica's moderate nationalists, and pro-market liberals, whose candidate is Yugoslavia's deputy prime minister, Miroljub Labus. Mr. Kostunica has been president of the Yugoslav federation since a mass uprising forced out Mr. Milosevic in October 2000, but the federation is being remodeled into a looser union of its two republics, Serbia and Montenegro. (Reuters)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the At the Movies column of Weekend yesterday about Walter Hill's new film, ''Undisputed,'' misidentified the crime committed by the boxer played by Wesley Snipes. He was sentenced for killing his wife's lover, not for killing his wife.

title: 2 Workers Die at Construction Site When Elevator Plunges 19 Floors
description: Two workers were killed yesterday when a temporary elevator at an office tower being built at East 42nd Street and Madison Avenue plunged 19 stories to the street, catapulting one worker to the pavement as the other plummeted in the orange basket, officials said.

title: Queens School Declared Safe After Air Tests
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has decided to open a Queens school where teachers and parents have complained about air quality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIDELMAN, JOHN R.
description: FIDELMAN-John R., 62. Of Jackson Heights, N.Y. Beloved son of Dorothy and the late John Fidelman. John served in the Viet Nam war and graduated from Fordham University. He is also survived by his sisters Nancy Karr and Barbara Adler. A memorial service will be held at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Washington, PA.

title: Sorrow So Sweet: A Guilty Pleasure In Another's Woe
description: Kenneth Borovina, a 34-year-old carpenter from Dumont, N.J., has a lot to be stressed out about these days. His grandmother is in the assisted living wing of local nursing home, and her life savings have gone from $600,000 to $250,000 in the last year, decimated by the sagging stock market. But there's one thing that cheers him: news that yet another rogue chief executive is under investigation or, better still, arrest.

title: John Willett, Scholar and Translator of Brecht, Dies at 85
description: John Willett, an English author, translator and cultural historian and one of the world's leading authorities on Bertolt Brecht, died on Tuesday in London, where he lived. He was 85.

title: The Loyal Opposition
description: If candor counted for as much as courtesy, the author note under Brent Scowcroft's now famous op-ed in The Wall Street Journal last week, the one arguing against war with Iraq, might have said something like this: ''Mr. Scowcroft, the former national security adviser, now makes his living advising business clients, some of whom would be gravely inconvenienced by a war in the Middle East. And by the way, he thought Saddam Hussein was finished after the gulf war in 1991.''

title: A New Name for Newark Airport?
description: To the Editor:

title: Town President Is Convicted In Scheme to Steal $12 Million
description: A federal jury convicted the town president of Cicero and six other people today of stealing $12 million from the town, which for decades has been clouded by accusations of mob influence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, GAIL E. (DRYER)
description: GOLDBERG-Gail E. (Dryer). Beloved wife of the late Harvey. Survived by her children Seth, Stephanie, Danielle and loving friends. Service Sunday 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: PUSH FOR CHANGES AT AMTRAK IS SEEN IN SHAPING BUDGET
description: Amtrak's problem-plagued summer has reignited debate over the railroad, leading critics of the rail system to say it will enhance their efforts to hold down spending on Amtrak unless significant changes are made in how it operates.

title: Talent Runs Deep at Quarterback
description: This season there is an abundance of talented quaterbacks, bringing back memories of the quarterback class of 1983. In the 1983 N.F.L. Draft, the future hall of famers Jim Kelly, Dan Marino and John Elway all went in the first round as did quarterbacks Tony Eason, Todd Blackledge and Ken O'Brien. Although it will be tough to top a class with three hall of famers, here is a look at some of the nation's top quarterbacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCENROE, RICHARD G.
description: McENROE-Richard G. On August 22, 2002 of Rockville Centre, Long Island. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Sweeney). Dear father of Richard, Gregory (Margaret), Kevin (Jeannine), Gerard (Regina), and Daniel (Anna), Kimberly McEnroe (James H.) Woo & Maureen (John P.) Byrne. Loving grandfather of 11. Brother of Eugene, James, Thomas McEnroe and Patricia Sheridan. Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre 79PM Saturday, and 2-4 & 79PM Sunday. Funeral Mass at 10 AM Monday, at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment is in St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge Freezes Accounts Of Ex-Enron Executive

title: GERMANS LAY OUT EARLY QAEDA TIES TO 9/11 HIJACKERS
description: German investigators say they have evidence that Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks, and two accomplices trained at Qaeda camps in Afghanistan from late 1999 to early 2000. They have also established a clear link between Al Qaeda and a recent attack on a Tunisian synagogue, a top official said.

title: Safeguards for Nuclear Fuel
description: For years, some 100 pounds of weapons-grade uranium packed in shipping crates sat in a nuclear institute in Belgrade, tempting terrorists, criminal traffickers and rogue states. Just before dawn on Thursday that uranium was removed to a secure facility in Russia where it will be blended into civilian reactor fuel. American and Russian technical experts cooperated closely in taking it from the Vinca Institute, working with Yugoslav scientists and protected by heavily armed Serbian police and Yugoslav troops. Vitally important in itself, this extraction should become a prototype for future cooperative efforts to safeguard and dilute the tons of nuclear weapons fuel around the world still dangerously vulnerable to diversion or theft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAVENEY, PETER F.
description: KEAVENEY-Peter F., 50. An international banking officer with ABN AM RO Bank, died on August 23, 2002. He was a son of Margaret Kelly Keaveney and the late John Keaveney. Funeral will take place Wednesday. Visitation will be Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Costello - Greiner Funeral Home, Woodbridge New Jersey, 732-634-0264. Memorial donations may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 6th Ave, NYC 10013.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Judge Admits Erring
description: A federal district judge who wrote a letter to a colleague seeking leniency in the sentencing of a former F.B.I. agent convicted of racketeering has conceded that he violated the judicial code of conduct. The judge, Edward F. Harrington, asked Judge Joseph L. Tauro to consider the contributions the agent, John J. Connolly, had made in the battle against Boston gangsters. A jury convicted Mr. Connolly of racketeering and obstruction of justice in June. He faces up to eight years in prison when sentenced on Sept. 16. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Threat to retaliate on tariffs remains : U.S. retreat on steel fails to satisfy EU
description: PARIS:  The European Union refused Friday to withdraw its threat of retaliation over U.S. steel tariffs, saying that Washington's most recent list of exemptions was encouraging but insufficient.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: REVISION ON GROWTH The British economy grew slower than originally reported in the second quarter, the National Statistics Office said. Gross domestic product rose 0.6 percent in the quarter and 1.2 percent for the year, less than the 0.9 percent quarterly growth and 1.5 percent annual growth originally reported. The widely expected downward revision was mainly a result of an "unprecedented" decline in manufacturing output, the government said. In Karachi, American officials said they had reopened the American Consulate, which had been closed since a bomb attack on June 14 killed 12 Pakistanis. title: The Odds of That
description: The psychological study of coincidence may be newly fashionable, but it is not new. When I was a freshman at Harvard in 1960, I volunteered to be a subject in an experiment in B.F. Skinner's lab. I was placed in front of a box with two lights -- one red and one green -- and a button. I was told to watch the pattern of the green light flashing and to try to figure out how to make the red light flash by pushing the button. It took awhile, but I did figure out the relationship and was soon able to make the red light flash with some frequency. When the experiment ended, I was told that the button was not connected to the lights and that the lights flashed randomly. I had imposed my own explanatory pattern on randomness. Which, I was told, is the same thing pigeons do.

title: Editorial Notebook; Riding the Light in Wyoming
description: Sometimes I think the West is just a trick of the light. Especially in central Wyoming. Dawn breaks as if someone had flung open the barn doors, letting the sun out onto the prairie. After a run of bright colors, dusk lingers like a bruise. Everything is measured against the open range of the sky, and everything would be diminished by that scale if the level sun, at morning and evening, didn't have the trick of catching the world in its low beams. A herd of deer grazing by a head gate near sunset blends into the alfalfa behind it, until one doe peers over the embankment and her ears turn crimson with their own blood in the penetrating light. Sunrise picks out wires on a fence line that were once as tight as guitar strings but now run like tendrils from post to post. A derelict Econoline glistens in the tall grass, as venerable as a settler's buckboard. Wait long enough here, and the light will sooner or later give everything its due. It will make everything seem just right.

title: Angkor Wat
description: To the Editor: I can easily empathize with Ms. Rose's forebodings about actually setting foot in Angkor. I lived in Southeast Asia in the early 60's, when travel to Angkor was possible although not very convenient. I thought I wanted to see Angkor, and repeatedly made plans to do so, but they never panned out. Only in retrospect did I realize that my idealized picture of Angkor could never have been matched by the reality. I had been subconsciously sabotaging my own travel plans.

title: August 18-24: INTERNATIONAL; MUSHARREF FLEXES
description: Declaring ''I am hereby making it part of the constitution,'' Gen. Pervez Musharraf rewrote the Pakistani constitution, cementing his rule as president for another five years and institutionalizing the military's role in politics by allocating them seats on a new National Security Council. The 29 amendments unilaterally enacted by the general came two months before elections of a new national parliament, which will now be largely toothless. Political, human rights and legal groups called on the United States to restrain the general. Later in the week, President Bush called the general an important ally in the effort against terrorism. David Rohde

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: BORROWED FINERY: A Memoir, by Paula Fox. (Owl/Holt, $12.) According to this fragmentary account of her childhood, the author has repeatedly fictionalized her real life in both her children's books and her adult fiction. And it's not a very pretty story: her parents were cruelly feckless, and after her mother decreed she had to go, Fox was passed among relatives and friends in locales as varied as Long Island, Hollywood and Cuba. Her imagistic memoir, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2001, displays her ''intelligence and her exceptional eye,'' Thomas Mallon wrote here. ''Sharp observations and pieces of humor stick out from all the confusion and dread.'' Fox's recently reissued novel THE GOD OF NIGHTMARES (Norton, $13.95) follows the fortunes of a young woman who abandons her sheltered life on a rural horse farm to search for her aunt in the liberating, bohemian world of New Orleans in 1941. In 1990 our reviewer, Jill McCorkle, admired the tale's ''wonderfully rich'' prose.

Departing from the 80's-glam kiddie-kitsch look of past years, retailers are putting the personalized jean jackets and rhinestone name bracelets of past seasons on the back rack. Instead, designers are opting for safety in numbers that have already been tested -- by parents. Whether wearing Tod's loafers and an L. L. title: August 18-24: NATIONAL; FIGHTING ANTHRAX
description: A virus called gamma phage replicates inside the anthrax bacterium and breaks out with the help of enzyme called lysin. Scientists at Rockefeller University see the gamma phage lysin as a powerful weapon against anthrax. Injected into the bloodstream, lysin could serve as a therapy even against anthrax strains made resistant to antibiotics. The scientists have also made lysin the basis of a handheld sensor that detects whether anthrax spores are in the environment. Nicholas Wade

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITAN, RABBI KALMAN L.
description: LEVITAN-Rabbi Kalman L., 85. Of Dayton, OH and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, on August 22nd, 2002 in Dayton. He is survived by his adoring wife, Carol, loving children, Robin Wenig, David Levitan and Daniel Levitan, devoted stepchildren, Ellen Katz and Tom Philips, and seven wonderful grandchildren, Rebeka and Abe Levitan, Zibby and Teddy Schwarzman, Ashley, Carrie and Spencer Philips. He spent 30 years active duty in the U.S. Navy and U.S. Air Force, retiring with the rank of Colonel. He was a member of the Department of Defense Armed Forces Chaplains Board and served nine years as Senior Jewish Chaplain as advisor on Jewish activities to the Chief of Air Force Chaplains. He was Founder and first Chairman of the Miniature Book Society of America. He was an active teacher of Judaism. He received his BA from Yeshiva University, Master of Hebrew Letters from the Jewish Institute of Religion and Doctor of Divinity from Hebrew Union College. He did graduate study at Harvard Law School and Columbia University. Memorial service will be held Sunday, August 25th, at Temple Israel, Dayton. Donations may be sent to Hospice Care Center, 324 Wilmington Avenue, Dayton, OH. 45420.

title: The Right Way to Change a Regime
description: While there may be little evidence that Iraq has ties to Al Qaeda or to the attacks of Sept. 11, there is no question that its present government, under Saddam Hussein, is an outlaw regime, is in violation of United Nations Security Council resolutions, is embarked upon a program of developing weapons of mass destruction and is a threat to peace and stability, both in the Middle East and, because of the risk of proliferation of these weapons, in other parts of the globe. Peace-loving nations have a moral responsibility to fight against the development and proliferation of weapons of mass destruction by rogues like Saddam Hussein. We owe it to our children and grandchildren to do so, and leading that fight is, and must continue to be, an important foreign policy priority for America.

title: The West Nile Epidemic
description: The West Nile virus, first detected in New York only three years ago, has now spread more than halfway across the country and deep into the South. Thus far this year it has sickened more than 370 Americans in 20 states and the District of Columbia, killing at least 16 of them. It is the worst outbreak yet in this country, and the peak season for the disease is only just starting. Some experts predict that the number of cases could eventually reach 1,000, with as many as 100 fatalities. There seems little doubt that the disease, which flies on the wings of birds and mosquitoes, has become permanently established in this country. The public is wondering just how bad it will get.

title: QUICK BITE/Newark; Where Tony's Dad Bought the Cherry Vanilla
description: In a 1950's flashback on ''The Sopranos,'' Tony's dad says, ''I stopped at Nasto's; got you some cherry vanilla.'' Forty-plus years have passed since that sequence, and a seemingly equal amount of time has gone by since there have been any new episodes of the HBO drama. But Nasto's Olde World Ice Cream remains a constant, and you can still get cherry vanilla. Opened in 1939, Nasto's commands the corner of Jefferson and East Kinney in the Ironbound district of Newark. Though the shop itself -- with its white-fringed blue awnings -- is rather small, Nasto's takes up a sizeable chunk of the block. In the additional square footage, Nasto's manufactures ice cream and desserts, and parks its delivery trucks as ''purveyors to hotels, restaurants, caterers.'' Still, this is no conglomerate. It's a traditional family business, and not just because there' a gratuitous ''e'' in Olde World. The proof is in the pudding, or rather, in the ice cream. On the day I visited, 24 flavors were available, as well as 3 frozen yogurts, 4 sherbets and 6 Italian ices. I tried the chocolate peanut butter ($1.75 for a cone, $3.25 for a hand-packed pint, $7.25 a half-gallon) while my friend sampled the butter almond. O.K., I never met an ice cream I didn't like. But top quality homemade ice cream like this is a rare treat. And that was just for starters. Next we tried the chocolate and lemon varieties of Italian ice ($1.25 small, $1.50 medium, $1.75 large, $2.75 quart, $4 half gallon), which were terrific. Nasto's also offers ice cream cakes, shakes, sundaes, tortoni, spumoni, tartufo, prepacked ice cream and more. What more can I say? Summer's (still) here, and the time is right for ice cream in the streets. Jack Silbert

A tablespoon or two of arrowroot doesn't quite absorb all the lemon juice, but I prefer my blueberry pie a little runny, not glutinous and stiff with cornstarch like pies from the bakery. I enjoy the way a scoop of vanilla ice cream melts into the warm juice.

They took comfort from the annoucement of the sanctions, which though essentially symbolic, come as the administration is discussing the dispatch of a high-level State Department official to Pyongyang. title: Neologist
description: If you've ever heard yourself saying, ''He was, I don't know, squidgeral,'' or thought, ''I wish there were a word for 'needing more than two hands to operate,''' you are probably a closet neologist. Neologizing, the practice of coining new words, may seem to be an arcane, specialized activity, but it's everywhere -- and the skillful employment of neologism is what gives English much of its verve. Each word in English had to start with a person trying to express a thought. For most words, the neologizer (or neologizers -- new words, like teenage trends or the calculus, are likely to pop up at the same time in very different places) is anonymous, although there are some exceptions. The humorist Gelett Burgess coined the word blurb in 1907. Yester-year, which sounds ancient, was in fact coined in 1870 by Dante Gabriel Rossetti, who wanted to translate a French word for which he couldn't find a suitable English equivalent. Paul Lewis, a professor of English at Boston College, invented the word Frankenfood (''genetically modified food'') in a letter to The Times in 1992. New words are being invented every day, and some of them even make it into the dictionary.

Some scandals, like the priestly abuse of children, cause nausea. Others -- the big-money kind -- embitter. But just when the public must feel that it has sampled every vintage of deception, along comes the story of Princeton University's office of admission and its illicit visits to a Web site maintained by its counterparts at Yale to allow applicants to the freshman class to check whether they've been accepted. Would they look up to you as a model? They hate that you are monopolizing all the nonrenewable resources [oil]. And because you want to do that, you need to keep in power all your collaborators. Appointments should be for a term of no more than 14 years, with the judges eligible for reappointment if a future president and Senate so determine.

Since admitting that racial profiling was practiced by some State Police, the state has agreed to several settlements, including a $12.9 million payment, plus legal fees, to four minority men who were shot at by troopers after being stopped. Several other cases involving simple traffic stops are pending. Karen DeMasters

title: 'Edison's Eve'
description: He was sure it was to be his last trip. The philosopher Rene Descartes had been summoned by Queen Christina of Sweden, who wanted to know his views on love, hatred, and the passions of the soul; but although he was happy to correspond with the Queen, Descartes was loath to become part of her court. He felt, he said, that "thoughts as well as waters" would freeze over in Sweden and, since that winter was particularly harsh, he believed he would not survive the season. He even feared, he wrote to a friend, "a shipwreck which will cost me my life." But Christina's whim was his command. Filled with foreboding, he packed his bags, taking all of his manuscripts with him.

title: Obstruction Of Judges

Indeed, since the Supreme Court generally hears fewer than 100 cases a year, it falls to the nation's 94 district courts and 13 circuit courts of appeal to say what the law is in the vast majority of instances.

title: The Dixie Chicks Keep The Heat On Nashville
description: IN the early 1990's, the Dixie Chicks were a cowgirl revival troupe playing for tips on the Texas dance hall circuit. By the end of the decade, they were Nashville, and pop, superstars. Their albums ''Wide Open Spaces'' and ''Fly'' sold more than 10 million copies each. They won a clutch of Grammys. Their 2000 tour grossed more at the box office than those of Bruce Springsteen and Britney Spears. Most striking of all, the Dixie Chicks achieved success not by cleaving to the conservative dictates of the country music industry but by taking risks that could just as easily have been big mistakes.
