title: The Odds of That
description: I found Belkin's analysis of the case of the twin brothers who died in biking accidents within two hours of each other in Raahe, a small town in Finland, an example of swallowing without examination the conventional wisdom of statisticians. To say that the fact that the two men were brothers -- and twins at that -- is ''a superfluous fact'' is simply a way for statisticians who don't want to confront the facts to neatly dispose of the inconvenient ones. While it is true that ''riding bicycles along a busy highway in a snowstorm . . . greatly increases the probability that they would be hit by trucks,'' that does not answer the question of just how common it is in Raahe for bicyclists to be hit, and killed, by trucks in snowstorms. Has there ever been a case of even two unrelated bicyclists killed within two hours of each other in Raahe during a snowstorm? And where are the statistics showing the general probability of being hit and killed by a truck while riding a bicycle in a snowstorm?

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

Then his first wife (Anjelica Huston), who was believed to have died in the Holocaust, turns up. And to top it all off, the mistress announces that she's pregnant. How does he handle all of this? ''I do the best I can,'' he says philosophically. ''It's not that easy.'' In Mr. Silver's hands, Herman does seem as much victim as perpetrator. The film, based on an Isaac Bashevis Singer novel, is poignant, atmospheric, a drama with a wry sense of humor. Paul Mazursky directed -- Friday at noon and 8 p.m. on Oxygen.

description: REGENHARD-Christian Michael Otto, FF, Former Sgt. USMC, August 25, 1973-September 11, 2001 who remains missing at the WTC. Christian, today is your birthday. Our lives were destroyed with yours on 9/11. In your memory, we have established the Christian Regenhard Fund for Justice, Humanity and the Environment and The Skyscraper Safety Campaign to advocate for truth and justice regarding the WTC collapse and to demand responsibility and accountability from individuals responsible for this atrocity. Your honesty, integrity, passion and compassion inspire us to fight for reform as a legacy for you and the 3,000 WTC victims. Until we meet again, ''gracias a la Vida'' & ''Semper Fi.'' title: Most Wanted
description: The photos are everywhere. Gap-toothed faces with awkward squinty grins, school portraits of broadly beaming adolescents. They flash on the television screen; they populate the purgatory of cyberspace. Of course, each image is freighted by the space between the carefree moment of the snapshot and the nameless horror that may have occurred later. Occasionally -- and with depressing regularity in recent months -- one flares up in the national consciousness as a major news story, but the hundreds upon hundreds of others have names attached to them, too, and, honestly, John Walsh seems to know them all. Logan Tucker. Kiplyn Davis. Christopher Samples. Sabrena Beck. Erin Pospisil. He has the details: ages, the days and times of abduction, the backyard or mall parking lot where they were last seen. Most of all, he knows the drill on the suspects in each case: previous convictions, hair color, cigarette brand, the scars and last-seen-driving information. He's got them cold; he tolls them in a high-intensity monotone, like a machine gun spitting bullets.

title: In God They Trust, Sort Of

We plod from the lachrymose to the smutty via the obstetric, and never seem to get any nearer.'' He's right about the sins of the sex writer, but wrong to say that they are the worst to be found on the page. Read through the offerings of most religious publishers, and you'll suffer greater affliction. The spiritual journey of our time begins with the maudlin and ascends, through tortuous barings of the soul, to the falsely humble. The view from those peaks is foggy; the air is damp; the valleys echo with oracular pronouncement.

Our Thai host found me watching a woman with a pile of small cages, each holding a single small bird -- finches or sparrows, I guessed. It is a custom to release a bird at the temple, he said, and seeing me touched by this symbol of the soul longing to be free, paid the woman and gave me a cage to open. I slid the bars open and the bird flew out, perhaps to freedom, more likely to be caught another day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, DR. LOUIS
description: ROSENBERG - Dr. Louis. Longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY passed away peacefully on the morning of July 5, 2002 at the age of 83 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Born in Harlem, educated at City College, NYU, and the William Alanson White Institute, Lou was in private practice in Manhattan as a psychotherapist for almost 40 years as well as a teacher at both NYU and Fordham. Husband to Miriam (Mitzi) Silver for over 50 years, he is survived by their three children, Steve Rosenberg of Oakland, CA., Eve Martin of Clinton, NY, and Carrie Crockett of Peapack-Gladstone, NJ, and five grandchildren, Louise, Laura, Jesse, Clarissa, and Lucas. He was an inspiration for his unwavering curiosity about all things, strength in adversity, and sense of wonder and acceptance. He relished the outdoors, his close friends, and a good meal. Hiker, tennis player, singer, gardener, devotee of mushrooms and Shake speare, as well as teacher of many aspiring psychotherapists. Gifts in Lou's memory may be sent to the: Senior Director of Individual Giving, American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, New York, New York 10024-5192.

title: 'The Road to Verdun'
description: Surprise and speed, assets that military commanders have always been schooled to prize above virtually all others, were rarely at their disposal in the First World War. The Germans still hoped to enjoy them at Verdun, but first they had to put their faith in the lessons of mass warfare as they had learned them since 1914. Elaborate preparation, it seemed, was the key to victory. Falkenhayn might have hesitated to provide resources on a scale that met the large promises of his memo to the Kaiser or the specific needs that the Crown Prince discerned, yet what he authorized in the compromises hammered out immediately after Christmas 1915 was still a massive concentration of force. Indeed, it was the most massive yet gathered in a war that had already proved a deadlock of concentrated force.

title: Casein Dreams
description: Willem Elsschot's novel CHEESE (Granta, $14.95), first published in Dutch in 1933, is a surprisingly humane farce of ambition gone haywire and Edam gone bad. Translated now for the first time into English, it's also devilishly well timed. Frans Laarmans is a frumpy, middle-aged shipping clerk on the corporate road to nowhere who stumbles into a too-good-to-be-true cheese importing scheme, but he could just as easily be the starry-eyed creator of a doomed dot-com or the duped investor in a corrupt conglomerate. Misguided Frans, who doesn't even like cheese, is ripe for seduction -- he doesn't want to get rich as much as wants to finally get some respect. ''Thirty years of servility have naturally left their mark on me,'' he observes. So while he pompously hunts for the perfect typewriter and clever telex addresses for his business, which he calls the ''General Antwerp Feeding Products Association,'' 20 tons of red-robed Edam pile up in a nearby warehouse. With whiplash speed, his plans go bust as his hot commodity turns into a (pungent) albatross he can't unload. Elsschot, the pseudonym of a Belgian advertising agency executive named Alfons De Ridder, writes with the brisk efficiency and softhearted cynicism of a man who knows the indignities of office life from the inside. His hero's earnest buffoonery only makes the abrupt, embarassing combustion of his ''cheese dream'' all the more moving. When, defeated, Frans tells of trying to ''help my cheese wound heal,'' it's both absurdly funny and bitterly sad. Elsschot possesses the rare knack for making a reader laugh, squirm and sob, all at the same time. MARY ELIZABETH WILLIAMS

title: SCHOOL BONDS
description: The state's issuance of $8.6 billion in bonds for school construction without obtaining voter approval does not violate the New Jersey Constitution, the state Supreme Court ruled last week. The decision was a response to a suit filed by a group of citizens led by Bogota's mayor, Steve Lonegan. Although the state Constitution requires voter approval before the state can enter into debt by issuing bonds, the school construction bonds were legal because they were issued in response to an earlier Supreme Court ruling that schools in poor districts must be upgraded, the court said. In addition, the state is allowed to maintain a fund to finance schools, including construction costs, Chief Justice Deborah T. Poritz said in the opinion. The 30 poorest school districts in the state were to receive $6 billion of the bond money. Karen DeMasters

title: 'Blood of Victory'
description: On 24 November, 1940, the first light of dawn found the Bulgarian ore freighter Svistov pounding through the Black Sea swells, a long night's journey from Odessa and bound for Istanbul. The writer I. A. Serebin, sleepless as always, left his cabin and stood at the rail, searched the horizon for a sign of the Turkish coast, found only a blood red streak in the eastern sky. Like the old saying, he realized--red sky at morning, sailor take warning. But, a private smile for that. So many ways, he thought, to drown in autumn. The Svistov creaked and groaned, spray burst over the bow as she fought the sea. With cupped hands, Serebin lit a Sobranie cigarette, then watched the dark water churning past the hull until the wind drove him back to the cabin.

title: 'Centaur'
description: Until the Bolsheviks seized power in October of 1917, Russia for almost a thousand years enjoyed a degree of pluralism in the realm of literature and the arts. Even Kievan and tsarist Russia, under the spiritual hegemony of the Russian Orthodox Church, did not impose a uniform esthetics on its creative artists. While the form of religious icons was strictly prescribed, painters of genius such as Andrei Rublev and Theophanes the Greek could, nonetheless, infuse the icons and frescoes they painted with a personal vision of the Christian subjects they rendered. After the 1825 Decembrist uprising against autocracy was crushed, Aleksandr Pushkin was obliged to submit his manuscripts to Tsar Nikolai I for censoring, but Russias national poet was neither silenced nor consigned to penal servitude. While it is true that Fedor Dostoevskii was arrested for participation in the radical political activities of the Petrashevskii Circle and shipped off to prison and exile in Siberia for eight years, he was eventually allowed to return to Moscow to resume his work as writer and journalist. Even though the Russian Orthodox Church excommunicated Lev Tolstoi for his heterodox views on religion, he was not kept from publishing his writings in Russia or forced into exile abroad.

title: Holding On To Luke
description: I woke around midnight, threw up and went back to sleep. Nausea was nothing new. I had been throwing up constantly -- sometimes as often as 12 times a day -- throughout my pregnancy, but that night something felt different. If I had had to describe my symptoms right then, I would have resorted to the familiar vocabulary of illness -- I was dizzy, my heart was racing, I felt short of breath. I guess. The truth is, those words felt generic and crude, unequal to the task. What I felt was more elemental, as if my bodily organs -- mysterious, essential things I knew I had but couldn't feel -- had begun to malfunction in some subtle, unspeakable way. For the next few hours I lay on the bathroom floor throwing up, letting the tile cool my body as it shook uncontrollably after each episode, first freezing, then burning. A few hours later I got up, went into the bedroom and lay down next to my husband. I could tell from movement on the other side of the bed that he was awake.

title: Dishonesty in the Hunt for Terrorists
description: In 1978, when Congress passed the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, it built a wall between information collected for national security and for ordinary crime. The wall is critical because the act allows wiretapping and the search of espionage and terrorism suspects under more lenient standards than the Constitution permits in criminal prosecutions. If information collected under FISA flowed freely to criminal prosecutors, it would be a giant end run around the Fourth Amendment.

title: Why Not Put Off Till Tomorrow the Novel You Could Begin Today?

There is vague order to the everything else, but it scarcely matters. The thing I really don't want to do is start my fifth novel, and the rest of my life is little more than a series of stalling techniques to help me achieve my goal.

title: Patents; A new camera attachment for guns automatically photographs the target as the trigger is pulled.
description: WHEN Jack Ruby shot the man accused of assassinating President John F. Kennedy in 1963, the moment was captured on film. The picture shows Ruby's grim posture, his gun, Lee Harvey Oswald recoiling as the bullet strikes him, and the shocked reactions of the police escorting the prisoner. It's a rare photo -- an instant in history forever frozen because a news photographer happened to be taking Oswald's picture when the gun was fired.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: MASKED GUNMEN KILL MAN A Brooklyn man was seized by masked men at a Brooklyn apartment on Saturday and fatally shot in the street, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Ruel McKenzie, 35, was at a party in an apartment on Cornelia Street in Bushwick when two or three masked men burst in at 2:15 a.m. and took him outside, the police said. After an argument, Mr. McKenzie was shot in the arm and leg with two guns, the police said, and he died at 6:35 p.m. at Wyckoff Heights Medical Center. No arrests have been made. So far, no motive for the killing has been identified, the police said. Mr. McKenzie was a car salesman and the father of five children, the police said.   Al Baker (NYT)

The pairings by captain in the quarterfinal stage today are: Dhondy vs. Bep Vriend of the Netherlands, Veronique Bessis of France vs. Sabine Auken of Germany, Gianna Arrigoni of Italy vs. Kerri Sanborn of the United States and Lynn Baker vs. Judi Radin, both of the United States.

He was the founder of the Ashley Famous Agency and later became the Chairman of the Board and CEO of Warner Brothers, returning to New York to become the Vice Chairman of Warner Communications, Inc. The funeral will be held on Tuesday, August 27, at 11:30 AM, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, East 81st St and Madison Ave. The family will receive visitors at the Campbell Funeral Chapel Monday, August 26, from 4 to 8 PM. Mr. Ashley is survived by his wife Page Cuddy Ashley, his daughters Fran Curtis Dubin (Brian), Diane Ashley, Kim Balin, Ba-Nhi Sinclair (Jack), his grandchildren Michael Dubin and Lia Ashley, and his brother Alfred. Donations in his name may be made to the I Have a Dream Foundation/ Ashley Project in New York City.

title: Yankees Bang Out 19 Hits to End Mini-Slump
description: Now the Yankees head to Fenway the fun way -- hitting and scoring again and out of their little slump. After losing four of their previous seven games and scoring only seven runs in their previous three games, they bombarded the Texas Rangers yesterday with 19 hits in a 10-3 victory in front of 42,785 at hazy Yankee Stadium.

title: A Little Night Magic for the Past
description: Dancing in the Streets has produced site-specific programs in areas throughout New York City for 19 years. Many of the programs have been devoted to the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, and to Red Hook's vivid, checkered history. Joanna Haigood is the latest artist to respond to the neighborhood's haunting allure. And her ''Picture Red Hook,'' performed on Saturday night by her Zaccho Dance Theater, based in San Francisco, is a beauty.

title: Next Big Health Debate: How to Help Uninsured
description: Concerned that millions of workers are losing their health insurance coverage at a time when health costs are surging, employers and Congressional leaders say the next great health care debate will be over how to help the uninsured.

title: Washington Bends the Rules
description: ''Someone must have slandered Josef K., for one morning, without having done anything truly wrong, he was arrested.'' So begins ''The Trial,'' Franz Kafka's story of an ordinary man caught in a legal web where the more he struggles to find out what he did wrong, the more trapped he becomes. ''After all,'' says Kafka's narrator, ''K. lived in a state governed by law, there was universal peace, all statutes were in force.''

description: RANDELL-Joseph. 1/29/17-8/27/96. The brightest star-forever in our hearts. Eternally, Zeld

title: 16 Banks Pledge Continued Commitment to Brazil
description: Brazil's top economic officials persuaded 16 international banks yesterday to maintain their lending at current levels, a move that relieved some but hardly all the anxiety in that country's financial markets.

title: An Expansion Team Turns to a Rookie
description: For all of its humid sprawl, Houston is a place where anybody can hope to become anything. Its failures have been as spectacular as its successes (see Enron), but this is a city with a dreamer's heart, the home of the space program and the Astrodome, a suitor for the 2012 Summer Olympics. Left with a dry hole after the Oilers pulled out for Nashville, this petroleum capital again possesses a wildcatter's optimism for a professional football gusher.

title: More Get 9/11 Aid, but Distrust of U.S. Effort Lingers
description: Since overhauling its programs in late June to assist New Yorkers devastated by the Sept. 11 attack, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has granted more money to nearly as many people needing help with their mortgage or rent as it did in the previous nine months.

But after a meeting that lasted several hours, Saudi officials said their position was unchanged - that war was not acceptable and they would not cooperate in any military action.

description: You're packing for a business trip to a foreign city. Clothes? Check. Toothbrush? Check. The laptop? Check. The book?

description: Ask Krzysztof Olszewski how his pocket-size Polish bus manufacturer competes with Western European giants like Mercedes-Benz and Volvo, and he smiles winningly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE CATES, NELIA BARLETTA
description: de CATES-Nelia Barletta. After a long and valiant fight against cancer, Nelia Barletta de Cates succumbed in Paris, Saturday, August 24, 2002. Her life will be celebrated at an Anglican service in the American Cathedral, Paris, on Wednesday, August 28. Her husband was the late Jack M. Cates, a former American diplomat. Born in Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic, on December 21, 1932, of parents, Amadeo Barletta Barletta and Nelia Ricart de Barletta, Nelia Barletta de Cates spent her childhood in Havana, Cuba, where her father owned the newspaper El Mundo as well as other various interests. She was educated in Cuba, Argentina, and the United States where she received her diploma at Duchesne College in 1950. Nelia Barletta de Cates served her country as the Dominican Republic's Cultural Attache to the United Kingdom, 1975-85, and as Ambassador and Permanent Representative to the International Maritime Organization, 1985-94. She has maintained her home and residence in Santo Domingo and also has spent much time during years in Paris and London. Neila Barletta de Cates is survived by her children of a previous marriage, her son, Miguel Barletta, and her daughter, Nelia Anselin, and four grandchildren, all of the Dominican Republic.

title: ALKERMES, DRUG MAKER, CUTS ITS STAFF BY 23%
description: Alkermes, which makes long-acting drugs, laid off 122 people, or 23 percent of its staff, after federal regulators rejected a schizophrenia treatment last month that it had developed with Johnson & Johnson. Cutting its work force to 419 employees from 541 will save the company, based in Cambridge, Mass., $20 million to $25 million in fiscal 2003, before revamping expenses, and $40 million to $45 million in 2004, Alkermes said. The company said revenue would be lower than it expected after federal regulators in July rejected its Risperdal Consta medicine, a twice-a-month version of Johnson & Johnson's antipsychotic drug Risperdal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Richard L. Armitage's visit to Pakistan misstated his title in some copies and misstated the year of an election in Kashmir that was widely viewed as fraudulent. Mr. Armitage is deputy secretary of state, not assistant secretary. The election took place in 1987, not 1989.

title: National Briefing: Education
description: COMMUTER VISAS The Immigration and Naturalization Service will begin allowing thousands of part-time students who commute to United States colleges from Canada and Mexico to obtain visas. The new policy will allow students who attend classes part time to legally enroll in schools within 75 miles of the United States border. For years until Sept. 11, the immigration service did not enforce the ban on part-time students crossing the border.    Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: North Koreans' Protest Foiled
description: A small number of North Korean refugees tried to hold a protest at the gates of the foreign ministry but were quickly detained by the police. Three people held up a small banner saying ''No Freedom Means Death'' in Korean. Hundreds of thousands of North Koreans live illegally in China, fleeing hunger and repression. While they wish to be considered political refugees protected by international treaties, China says they are economic migrants who should be sent home if caught. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Another Exit for Stevenson
description: Alexandra Stevenson, playing well enough this year to earn a No. 31 seeding at the Open, capsized in the first round for the fourth straight year and for the fourth time this year in a major tournament.

title: Cleaning Coal-Fired Plants: The Debate Burns On
description: At one end of the St. Johns River Power Park generating station, operators in a control room watch the computerized dials and gauges of a $1.2 billion system that runs day and night, winter and summer. It grinds coal down to the consistency of talcum powder and blows it into twin furnaces that produce steam to power turbines that turn out 1,280 megawatts of electricity.

description: Computer Company Board Is Tripped Up on Disclosure

title: WILLIAMS ENERGY TO BUY OIL PIPELINE AND 4 TERMINALS
description: Williams Energy Partners agreed to buy a Midwest oil-product pipeline and four terminals for $110 million from the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, an oil refiner that is selling assets to trim debt. The 430-mile Northern Great Plains Products System includes a pipeline from a refinery in Mandan, N.D., to Minneapolis. The sale is expected to close in mid-October, Tesoro said.

description: The Bush administration has listed an obscure Muslim group fighting Chinese rule in the western province of Xinjiang as a terrorist organization, a visiting senior American official disclosed here tonight.

description: Nixon went to China. Gorbachev visited the Statue of Liberty. And last night, Bloomberg took in a little tennis at the United States Open.

description: It was Black Sunday for Americans at the world bridge championships here. In the round of 16 in the Rosenblum Cup for open teams, five United States groups were in contention, and only one survived.

title: US AIRWAYS ASKS BANKRUPTCY COURT TO VOID LABOR PACTS
description: The US Airways Group has asked the court presiding over its Chapter 11 bankruptcy case for permission to reject collective bargaining agreements that cover more than 18,500 of its employees. The agreements are with mechanics and fleet service employees represented by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, and with reservation agents and ticket counter workers represented by the Communications Workers of America, according to court papers obtained yesterday by Dow Jones Newswires. Unlike other employee groups, these groups have not ratified cost-reduction agreements. A hearing is scheduled for Sept. 10 before Judge Stephen S. Mitchell of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Alexandria, Va.

The assessment that removing Saddam Hussein is ''not an object of British foreign policy'' was made by a BBC interviewer, not by Mr. Straw.

title: Displeased With Team, Fassel Makes Moves
description: When another one of his linemen jumped offside in practice today, Giants Coach Jim Fassel had finally seen enough. He made his players run wind sprints from sideline to sideline, a punishment usually reserved for pimply-faced teenagers.

title: Jackson Hole Outgrows Its Tiny, Busy Airport
description: In the alpine splendor of the Teton range, where crickets flitter across the trails and fish splash around the Snake River, another, less natural, sound is never far away -- the mechanical buzz of airplanes ferrying people in and out of this enclave for the rich and famous.

title: Louisiana-Pacific to Lay Off Workers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 26 (Bloomberg News) — Louisiana-Pacific told Texas regulators that it would lay off 462 employees at a Texas lumber mill as part of an agreement to swap plants with a rival, Georgia-Pacific . Some, or all, of the workers, however, will be kept on under Georgia-Pacific, that company said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Just Say Oops
description: Seeking a deterrent to a national plague of drug addiction, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra suggested that the government might manufacture fake methamphetamine pills that make people vomit. ''I want the public health ministry to talk to psychiatrists and chemists on whether the government should produce drugs that give people headaches and nausea,'' he said. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Disputed Rap Concert Is Held
description: A rap concert that was canceled last week because of police fears of gang violence went ahead on Sunday night, but only a small fraction of the seats were sold. On Friday, a federal judge ruled that the concert could go on after the promoters agreed to hire 40 additional security guards. But three of the headline acts -- including N.O.R.E., Styles and Khia -- did not appear and only 200 people showed up at the 5,900-seat Sandcastle Stadium, which had a paid security staff of 70.. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Test on Bioweapons Expert Might Prove Short on Answers
description: The offer by Dr. Steven J. Hatfill, a biological weapons expert, to provide a blood sample to the F.B.I. could bear strongly on his guilt or innocence in the anthrax attacks last year, but any results might be hard to interpret because the bureau has not gathered base-line data of this sort from scientists who work regularly with the Ames strain of anthrax.

title: UNITED AIRLINES TO REAPPLY FOR LOAN GUARANTEE
description: John W. Creighton Jr., chief executive of UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that the company would resubmit an application to the federal government for a loan guarantee by Sept. 16. In his weekly telephone message to employees, Mr. Creighton said United would give union leaders proposals for concessions by the end of this week, in hopes that the company could achieve the cutback agreements necessary to bolster the application. Earlier this summer, United asked for a $1.8 billion loan guarantee on $2 billion in private loans. But a week and a half ago, the airline said it might have to declare bankruptcy because federal officials had told it they were reluctant to approve a loan guarantee because United had not shown it could get enough concessions to achieve a workable business plan. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Grief and Dread at Girls' Burial Site in Oregon
description: The bad news for the family of Miranda Gaddis came over the weekend, when her remains were identified by the local authorities. Sadly, though, in a summer filled with reports of missing girls across the country, that was not the end of it for the grieving family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONECKY, NATHAN ''NATE''
description: KONECKY-Nathan ''Nate''. Information technology pioneer. Long time resident of Collingswood, NJ and for the last three years Moorestown, NJ passed away August 26, 2002 after a battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 59 years old. Although Mr. Konecky was raised in New York City, he relocated to the Delaware Valley in 1963 and made it his home after he graduated with a BS in Mathematics from Clarkson University, Potsdam, NY. Nathan Konecky was a pioneer in the computer software and services business. After graduation he began his career working as a Programmer for Sperry Univac (Unisys). In 1968 he founded National System Analysts, Inc. (NSA) and was its CEO/President for all of its years in business. NSA provided systems analysis and programming services to the computer departments of major local companies. By the early 1980's NSA began to be known as ARMS, Inc. (ARMS). In 1996 ARMS was sold to IMI, a subsidiary of Olsen. But Nate was not finished. He carved out eight people from the sale of ARMS, added some family members and founded a new company, Acsis, Inc. (Acsis). It was his idea to run a small family business. But things didn't work out that simple. Acsis specializes in automated data collection and supply chain solutions that interface with SAP, the largest provider of integrated global computer systems. As a ''best of breed'' provider, Acsis has had tremendous success. Today, six years after its founding, Acsis employs 85 people and its software is installed at over 250 sites around the world. Nathan Konecky put together a fantastic management team and Acsis will continue to grow and flourish. Mr. Konecky was well known in the computer industry. He had been very active in ITAA (Information Technology Association of America) serving as the President of the Professional Services Sector for four years and serving on the organization's Board of Directors for eight years. Nathan has also been very active with his alma mater, Clarkson University. At Clarkson Nate had served on the School of Business Leadership Council for 12 years, had run ARMS U, a company run education program on campus, for six years, had been an Executive Lecturer and had supported the University with funding since graduating. In 1998 Nathan was awarded Clarkson's most prestigious alumni award, the Golden Knight. This award is presented to alumni who have distinguished themselves by service to their alma mater and have demonstrated outstanding career achievement, Mr. Konecky was also a 2001 finalist for Ernst & Young's Entrepreneur of the Year. Although Nathan's early background was in the technical disciplines, his forte had become leadership, sales and strategic vision. He is survived by his ''soul mate'', loving wife and life partner, Judith L. (Green Condon) Konecky. Other surviving family members include their children: Debbie and Vince Freeman, Aaron and Maureen Konecky, and Erika Wicker; their six grandchildren: David Meyers, Heather Denver, Sarah and Alexa Wicker, Shawna and Kaitlin Freeman and great-grandson Adam; their siblings: Sondra and Leon Einhorn, Stan and Rena Konecky and Michael and Cathy Graham; and the rest of their blood and extended family. Relatives, friends and business relationships are invited to call Thursday beginning at 10:30am at Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc. 2001 Berlin Rd. Cherry Hill, NJ where funeral services will begin at 11:00am. Interment will follow at Locustwood Memorial Park in Cherry Hill. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, that donations be made in Mr. Konecky's name for medical research in the disciplines of pancreatic cancer, cancer in general, diabetes, multiple sclerosis (MS) or any other worthy medical research group.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a debate in Cobb County, Ga., on the teaching of evolution referred incompletely to action by the school board on Thursday. The board tentatively approved a requirement for teachers to give equal weight to evolution and biblical interpretations about the origin of life. But the policy will not take effect until the board votes again; final adoption did not occur on Thursday. Because of an editing error, a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the date of the next vote. It is Sept. 26; it was not yesterday.

title: Critic's Notebook; Old Masters at Edinburgh, But Scarcely a Contemporary
description: The Festival Lecture, with Edinburgh University as host, is a recent and useful addition to the great basket of performances available here each August. It is a little mirror placed among the exuberantly varied selections of music, theater and dance, allowing everyone concerned -- creators, performers, producers, spectators -- to look at things from another angle and reflect.

title: Worries About West Nile Arrive as Spraying Begins
description: It seemed as if they had escaped that the mosquitoes had taken their business elsewhere, and that for Long Island, this was not going to be a West Nile summer. But with Labor Day less than a week away, the worries about the West Nile virus that preoccupied residents over the two previous summers were suddenly back today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FRANCES KOSTICK
description: COHEN - Frances Kostick. September 17, 1903-August 24, 2002, of Palm Beach, FL. Wife of the late Louis D. Cohen. Cherished mother of Marilyn C. Davimos, Arthur G. Cohen and the late Richard M. Cohen, mother-in-law to Karen B. Cohen and Richard Davimos, and remembered lovingly by 11 grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren. Frances was a kind, charming, and loving person who will be greatly missed by her family and many friends. There will be a private service for the family only.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: JERSEY CITY: HOSPITALS PLAN RADIO LINKS An emergency radio system will link all 85 acute-care hospitals in the state by the end of the year, as preparation for communicating in a disaster, officials announced yesterday. The hospitals are spending more than $1.5 million for 85 radios, and the state will spend more than $225,000 for 15 radios so its emergency workers and the governor can keep in touch with the hospitals, said the state commissioner of health and senior services, Dr. Clifton R. Lacy. Emergency communications were overwhelmed on Sept. 11.   (AP)

title: Forest Thinning Challenged as Tactic to Control Fires
description: Even as President Bush urges increased thinning of national forests, some scientists caution that there is little evidence to show that thinning will prevent fires at the catastrophic scales seen in the West this summer.

title: In the Ear and Off the Mark
description: How accurate are infrared thermometers that measure temperature through the ears? Accurate enough for a parent trying to decide whether a child has a fever, but not accurate enough for an emergency room physician in a situation that calls for getting it just right, according to a study published on Saturday in The Lancet.

title: Bloomberg News Apologizes To Top Singapore Officials
description: As an entrepreneur-turned-politician, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken pains to avoid being accused of conflicts of interest in the way he runs New York City. Now, the company that made him a billionaire is in trouble for accusing this city-state's politicians of conflicts of interest in the way they run business.

title: Tunnel Vision; Down by 3rd Rail, You Need 9 Lives
description: The search for the Fulton Street subway cat started the other day with a hopeful heart and a healthy dose of skepticism.

title: Krajicek and Ancic Default
description: Richard Krajicek of the Netherlands and Mario Ancic of Croatia defaulted yesterday. Krajicek injured a foot in the second set against Jiri Novak of the Czech Republic. Krajicek, the 1996 Wimbledon champion, was losing, 6-1, 5-4, when he defaulted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKIERNAN, MARGARET ''PEGGY'' (NEE FLATLEY)
description: MCKIERNAN - Margaret ''Peggy'' (nee Flatley). On August 25, 2002. Native to Carrabeg, Kilkelly, Co. Mayo, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Loving mother of Joan, Frank, and Kathleen. Adoring grandmother of Jean Marie, Frank, Ciaran, and Jeremy, and great grandmother of Gregg and Emily Elizabeth. Dear sister of Helen Cleary, Katie Conroy, and Nora Hennessey. Also a dear aunt to many nieces and nephews in the United States, England, and Ireland. Reposing Wednesday 2-4 PM & 7-9 PM at Riverdale - On - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 10:00 AM at St Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimers Association, would be deeply appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Denial On Airstrikes
description: Defense Minister Sergei B. Ivanov denied that Russian aircraft conducted strikes inside Georgia on Friday, as Georgia and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe asserted. The bombings, which Georgian officials said killed one person, brought an unusually sharp rebuke from the United States over the weekend. Fighting has flared recently along Georgia's border with Chechnya; Russia says Chechen rebels take refuge in Georgia. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Bodies in Water
description: Q. Why does a corpse float, when a living person must exert an effort to stay afloat?

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Barnhardt, Walker & Day, Concord, N.C., is expanding operations by adding public relations and event management services, to be led by Patrick Pearson, account executive. Mr. Pearson, who joined the agency in February, had been director for marketing at his own company, Clickitgolf.com, a golfing Web site.

title: Love, Friskiness and High-Heeled Shoes
description: Everything and almost nothing goes on simultaneously in ''Maria Vai Com as Outras'' (''Maria Who Follows the Others''), a funny and imaginative new work by the Brazilian modern-dance choreographer Regina Nejman, which was performed on Sunday afternoon at the University Settlement as part of the New York International Fringe Festival. Ms. Nejman creates the sense of men and women who live and experience emotions full throttle. There are only seven dancers, but they seem like an entire city population. The small, bare-bones studio performing space almost immediately feels like a crowded cityscape of bustling plazas and quieter beaches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMER, ROSLYN
description: HAMMER-Roslyn. Beloved wife of Irving. Devoted mother of Susan Neufeld (Stewart) and Edward Hammer (Cathy). Adored grandmother of Alex and Daniel Neufeld, Jenny, Brian and Glenn Hammer. Dear sister of Marlyn Smith. She will be missed by all who knew her. Services today, 1:15 PM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHLEY, TED
description: ASHLEY-Ted. Born August 3, 1922, died Saturday, August 24. He started his long entertainment career at age 15, as an office boy at the William Morris Agency. He was the founder of the Ashley Famous Agency and later became the Chairman of the Board and CEO of Warner Brothers, returning to New York to become the Vice Chairman of Warner Communications, Inc. The funeral will be held on Tuesday, August 27, at 11:30 AM, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, East 81st St and Madison Ave. The family will receive visitors at the Campbell Funeral Chapel Monday, August 26, from 4 to 8 PM. Mr. Ashley is survived by his wife Page Cuddy Ashley, his daughters Fran Curtis Dubin (Brian), Diane Ashley, Kim Balin, Ba-Nhi Sinclair (Jack), his grandchildren Michael Dubin and Lia Ashley, and his brother Alfred. Donations in his name may be made to the I Have a Dream Foundation/ Ashley Project in New York City.

title: National Briefing | Education: Keeping Freshmen On Campus
description: For the first time in its history, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is assigning every freshman to an on-campus dormitory. For the past 127 years freshmen have chosen where to live, either in fraternity or sorority houses or in dormitories. The policy comes five years after a freshman from outside Buffalo, Scott Krueger, died from consuming too much alcohol weeks after moving into a fraternity house. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: David Pogue
description: David Pogue has written the double-award-winning Desktop Critic column for Macworld magazine since 1991. With over 2.5 million books in print, Pogue is one of the world's bestselling how-to authors, having written or co-written six books in the "for Dummies" series (Macs, iMacs, iBooks, Magic, Opera, and Classical Music), along with the Computer Press Association award-winning "PalmPilot: The Ultimate Guide," several computer-humor books, and a technothriller, "Hard Drive."

title: 3 Postal Centers Free of Anthrax
description: No anthrax was found in three New Jersey postal centers tested last week for possible contamination by spores that were found on Aug. 8 in a Princeton mailbox, officials said yesterday.

description: A Detroit man who confessed to the rape and murder of a 16-year-old girl in 1984 was freed yesterday, after DNA evidence proved he did not commit the crime.

description: Long dismissed as a ragtag collection of outsiders, a psychosocial cult or worse, the Independence Party is suddenly poised to become a potent force in New York politics.

description: When Dr. J. Allan Hobson, 69, a Harvard psychiatrist and dream researcher, arrived for an interview, he had a notebook filled with his writings, photographs of his extended family and renderings of his summer house in Italy.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Karl Rove's California Dream
description: DANA POINT, Ca. -- Karl Rove, the president's chief political adviser, made a rare trip to the back of Air Force One to talk to reporters traveling with President Bush during a visit to California the other day. Among his many points and, more than likely, the main point he intended to circulate in giving what he specifically described as an on-the-record-briefing in the press cabin of the Boeing 747 was that California was not out of Republican reach in the 2004 presidential campaign, no matter the recent political and demographic trends in the nation's largest state.

title: 110 Wrongful Convictions, and Counting
description: Eddie Joe Lloyd has served 17 years of a life sentence for the rape and murder of a Detroit teenager, a crime he confessed to. At his sentencing, the judge said he regretted that Michigan had no death penalty. But yesterday the same judge freed Mr. Lloyd after prosecutors and defense lawyers submitted DNA evidence exonerating him. Mr. Lloyd is the 110th person nationwide to be freed based on DNA testing.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Seeking To Bar Mob Figure From Casinos
description: New Jersey gambling officials want the man reputed to be the leader of the Philadelphia mob, Joseph A. Ligambi, 63, barred from entering Atlantic City casinos. The Casino Control Commission will vote whether to put Mr. Ligambi's name on an exclusion list. Mr. Ligambi has 30 days to challenge the petition. Officials cited Mr. Ligambi's 30-year record, including a 1989 murder conviction, later overturned. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

description: Michael Chang walked off the grandstand court at the United States Open yesterday, then stopped in his tracks as the cheers grew into a roar, shaking his fist as he did a full turn.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Trial Resumes
description: Slobodan Milosevic was back in court yesterday after the monthlong summer recess of his war crimes trial. Looking rested and in his usual defiant mood, the former president of Yugoslavia cross-examined several witnesses who described atrocities in Kosovo. Prosecutors have until mid-September to call more witnesses and wrap up the Kosovo portion of the trial before moving on to charges related to the wars in Bosnia and Croatia. Cardiologists have presented a new report about Mr. Milosevic's heart condition, but Judge Richard May said the court was awaiting translation before dealing with the doctors' recommendations. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Emissaries to Eternity
description: To the Editor:

title: Has U.S. Made the Case for War?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. to Re-enter Building Long After Anthrax Shut It
description: Ten months after the first of the nation's series of anthrax attacks was discovered at the headquarters of American Media Inc. here, the F.B.I. said today that it would re-enter the building this week to search for new clues.

title: What They Don't Teach At J-School
description: YOU may have read that Columbia University's new president, Lee C. Bollinger, has suspended the search for a new dean of the university's Graduate School of Journalism. First, Mr. Bollinger said, the school must re-examine its mission in a world that is uncertain, rapidly evolving, globalizing, information-hungry, market-driven and so on and so forth.

title: Some Owners Doubt Players' Resolve to Strike
description: As negotiators worked to narrow their differences and merge their positions on key issues in baseball's labor dispute, people on the players' side and the owners' side began hearing an old story yesterday. Some owners, they said they had been told, do not think the players have the stomach to strike Friday.

title: Safin's Sister Not Awed by Open
description: Afew dozen fans in the low-rise metal stands on Court 9 were the only witnesses as the youngest member of the Safin family made her Grand Slam debut yesterday.

title: Safin Left Standing in Marathon Match
description: After one last stab at a volley, after four and a half hours of tortuous tennis, Nicolas Kiefer crumpled to the court. He willed himself to get up, but his legs would no longer respond to orders from his heart.

title: A Court Backs Open Hearings On Deportation
description: The federal appeals court in Cincinnati declared yesterday that the Bush administration acted unlawfully in holding hundreds of deportation hearings in secret based only on the government's assertion that the people involved may have links to terrorism.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a debate in Cobb County, Ga., on the teaching of evolution referred incompletely to action by the school board on Thursday. The board tentatively approved a requirement for teachers to give equal weight to evolution and biblical interpretations about the origin of life. But the policy will not take effect until the board votes again; final adoption did not occur on Thursday. Because of an editing error, a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the date of the next vote. It is Sept. 26; it was not yesterday.

title: Breaking Out Of the Bronx: A Look Back; A Pioneering Dancer Is the Last of His Breed
description: They started out as street kids. The dancing kept them mostly on the right side of the law.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose slightly against the dollar in moderate trading. With London markets closed, analysts said traders received little direction. In New York, the euro was 97.25 cents, up from 97.23 cents Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTRIAN, NICK
description: AUSTRIAN-Nick. Died far too young at 39. A beloved friend of Pauline, Alis and Jennifer. Devoted ''uncle'' to Max and Sam, and loving ''brother'' of John. We, the Alexanders and all of his NY friends including Vince, Marc and Ian, will miss him sorely.

title: Chancellor Adds 2 School Days, Cutting Teacher Training Time
description: In his first attempt at improving instruction for New York City schoolchildren, Chancellor Joel I. Klein has added two days to the coming school year, time that had been set aside for teacher training.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Disturbance At St. Patrick's
description: A man who tried to handcuff Archbishop Edward M. Egan during a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral last year pleaded guilty yesterday to disturbing the peace. The man, Timothy J. Byrne, 40, had originally been charged with unlawful imprisonment, disrupting a religious service and other charges. Under the plea agreement, he was released on the condition that he avoid the cathedral and the archbishop, who was not hurt in the incident. On New Year's Day 2001, the authorities said, Mr. Byrne, above, poised to receive holy communion, lunged suddenly at the archbishop and attempted to handcuff him. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Iran Legislators Vote to Give Women Equality in Divorce
description: Iran's reformist Parliament has approved a bill that would grant women a right to seek a divorce equal to that of men for the first time since the Islamic revolution in 1979.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Possible China Talks
description: President Chen Shui-bian called for talks with China to establish direct cross-strait shipping links and normalize trade with the mainland, The China Times reported. Taiwan should sign free-trade agreements with the United States and Japan to strengthen the economy, the paper said, citing remarks the president made at a weekend cabinet meeting. The island bars most direct transport links with the mainland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSDEN, HELEN (NEE SHIFFMAN)
description: COSDEN-Helen (nee Shiffman). With deepest sorrow, our family mourns the loss of our long-time friend. Norma and Sol Kugler

title: F.D.U. Has a Tough Act To Follow This Season
description: What can the Fairleigh Dickinson men's soccer team possibly do for an encore?

title: Pepsi says its pop music stars can reach minorities and the mainstream at the same time.
description: WHAT do the rapper Ludacris and the Colombian pop singer Shakira have in common? In addition to being nominated in multiple categories for statuettes at the MTV Video Music Awards ceremony on Thursday, the performers will be competing for a more relevant prize: the star of the program's hippest commercial.

title: RED ROBIN RESTAURANT CHAIN TO ADD 17 FRANCHISES
description: Red Robin Gourmet Burgers plans to add 17 restaurants in the next seven years to expand in Connecticut, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Michigan. One franchisee, Round Robin, based in Manchester, Conn., will open seven Red Robins in Connecticut and Massachusetts during the next seven years, the company said. Another franchisee, Unbridled Hospitality, based in Pittsburgh, an operator of family restaurants, will open five Red Robins in Pennsylvania during the next five years. Red Robin of Michigan, which runs nine Red Robins in Ohio and Michigan, will open five more in Michigan in five years. Red Robin is based in Greenwood Village, Colo.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: It's Not Size, but Color

title: Pope, for Health Reasons, Drops Idea of Philippine Trip
description: Pope John Paul II has decided not to make a trip to the Philippines in which he had previously expressed interest, and a Vatican official said late today that the primary reason was the pope's health.

title: Hudson's Bay Profit Down in Quarter
description: The Hudson's Bay Company, Canada's largest department store chain, said second-quarter earnings fell 65 percent after it cut prices at its Zellers discount chain.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRUKER DALTONICS INC., Billerica, Mass., a provider of technology for pharmaceutical companies, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 1 million shares of stock over the next 12 months. The company has about 54.9 million shares outstanding.

title: Salomon Gave A Big Helping Of New Stocks To WorldCom
description: Officers and directors of WorldCom received thousands of shares of hot initial public offerings from Salomon Smith Barney in the late 1990's, according to documents delivered late yesterday by the firm to a Congressional committee investigating the collapse of WorldCom.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NORTH KOREA: HELP SOUGHT ON U.S. TALKS The government asked Japan to help persuade the United States to renew talks with the Stalinist state, Japanese officials said. North Korean officials made the request in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, during the highest-level diplomatic talks with Japan in two years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Has U.S. Made the Case for War?
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 More Israeli Arabs Jailed; Tied to Palestinian Bombing
description: Israel announced today that seven Arabs with Israeli citizenship had been arrested for assisting a suicide bomber, further heightening apprehensions that Israeli Arabs were increasingly joining in the violent tactics of the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, JESSICA
description: WINTER-Jessica. 81, passed away on Sunday, August 25, 2002, following a short illness. Beloved wife and best friend of Martin E. Winter. Devoted aunt of Marvin and Diane Bernstein, Philip and Beverly Sklover, William and Sharon Friedheim, William and Oda Friedheim, Drs. Lee and Margarita Winter and Randy Winter. Great-aunt of David and Susan Bernstein, Alanna, Samuel and Joseph Sklover, Lisa Blaudoin and Gregory Friedheim. Sister-in-law of Joan and Eugene Winter and Anne Friedheim. Loving godmother to David and Jennifer Kouvant. Lifelong friend of Vivian Kouvant, Sylvia and Austin Fried and Regina Gelford. She had a long and distinguished career on Wall Street and recently retired after 20 years from the firm Ehrenkrantz, King and Nussbaum. Funeral services Wednesday, August 28, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 81st. St. and Madison Ave. Donations in honor of Jessica may be made to Variety-The Children's Charity.

title: Mets Came Apart As Pressure Mounted
description: After Timo Perez's game-winning ninth-inning home run Saturday night, a relieved Bobby Valentine sat behind his desk, a steak dinner awaiting him. The choice of meal would have been inappropriate during the Mets' 12-game losing streak. Valentine had twice mangled letter openers during the streak and nobody would have wanted him near a steak knife.

title: And in This Corner, Representing the Homeless . . .
description: STEVEN BANKS, a Legal Aid Society lawyer who represents the homeless, sits at the large kitchen table with his wife, a housing court judge whose hair is still damp from the shower. His 11-year-old daughter is slurping up Lucky Charms cereal, while his 14-year-old son, arms folded, is making wisecracks about his workaholic father.

title: The Rich, and the Rest
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Slovakia: Was The President Poisoned?
description: With President Rudolf Schuster hospitalized for a fourth day with intestinal problems, the police have opened an investigation into whether he was poisoned, the press reported. Mr. Schuster's son, Peter, said he suspected that his father may have been the victim of foul play. Doctors said Mr. Schuster had gall stones and an infection in his digestive tract, which could be linked to salmonella poisoning. So far, they have found no traces of poison. Slovakia will hold parliamentary elections next month and Mr. Schuster is expected to play a major role in selecting the next prime minister. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Kafelnikov Still Winning
description: Yevgeny Kafelnikov does not sound like the fourth-seeded player at the United States Open, especially when he talks about the next generation of Russian tennis players being ''as big as I was.''

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO SELL SPACECRAFT-PROPULSION UNIT
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the fifth-largest military contractor, agreed to sell its spacecraft-propulsion and fire-suppression businesses to GenCorp for about $90 million to focus on its main military businesses. The transaction, which will double the size of GenCorp's Aerojet-General unit, is expected to close in the fourth quarter, it said.

title: Emissaries to Eternity
description: To the Editor:

title: A Jubilant Barroom Toast: To Smoke-Free Air
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to extend New York's smoking ban to all offices, bars and restaurants -- even pool halls, bowling alleys and bingo parlors -- would not make the city the first to have such a law. California and dozens of towns and counties already have similar laws.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: HELICOPTER TOLL AT 117 The death toll in the crash last week of a military helicopter near the main Russian base in the southern republic of Chechnya rose to 117 as contradictory reports about the cause of the crash emerged. The official news agency Itar-Tass reported that an investigation had concluded that a rebel missile, possibly stolen from a Russian Army depot, had shot down the helicopter, which was carrying 147 people. It also reported that a suspect had been detained, but the federal deputy prosecutor general, Sergei N. Fridinksy, said later that no conclusion had been reached and that no one had been detained. Last week, President Vladimir V. Putin blamed commanders' dereliction of duty. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Judge Bans Basque Party, Linking It To Terrorists
description: A Spanish judge today banned a Basque political party accused of collaborating with the armed separatist group E.T.A. only hours before a special session of the Spanish Parliament demanded that the party, Batasuna, be outlawed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Executive Replaced
description: Nordea, the Nordic region's biggest bank, replaced its chief executive, Thorleif Krarup, with Lars Nordstroem, the head of consumer banking, after second-quarter profit slumped. Mr. Nordstroem said in an interview that he would speed up efforts to integrate Nordea's businesses. Mr. Krarup left after less than two years as chief executive. Nordea, based in Stockholm and the result of $19 billion worth of mergers over four years, will have to accelerate cost cuts after earnings fell 81 percent in the three months through June, investors said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Help Sought On U.S. Talks
description: The government asked Japan to help persuade the United States to renew talks with the Stalinist state, Japanese officials said. North Korean officials made the request in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, during the highest-level diplomatic talks with Japan in two years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: OIL INVESTMENT Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state-owned oil monopoly, will invest $4.25 billion over the next eight years to develop its offshore Ku-Maloob-Zaap oil field in the Bay of Campeche, the company announced. The project will increase production of heavy Maya crude from the oil field to 800,000 barrels a day from 263,000 by 2011. Pemex did not say how it would finance the project, which involves drilling 82 new wells and building 17 new platforms.

title: L.L. Bean Tries to Escape The Mail-Order Wilderness
description: In July, Chris McCormick, the new president of L. L. Bean, and several other company employees took a 160-mile bike ride to Washington County, Me., near the Canadian border. In the time-honored tradition of the venerable clothing and outdoor goods company, the excursion was more than fun and games: it was an exercise in product testing.

title: New York Waits For Decision By the U.S.O.C.
description: New York City's expensive campaign to become the host city for the 2012 Summer Olympics could advance today, or end quickly, when a United States Olympic Committee panel in Chicago chooses two finalists from a field of four to be the country's candidate.

title: Who Would Abduct a Child? Previous Cases Offer Clues
description: Child abduction by strangers, the experts continue to say, is not a growing menace. The number of cases -- 115 or so a year, according to the most recent federal statistics -- has remained steady. Yet, the crime has been prominent this summer because of a few startling cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ELLIOT
description: BERNSTEIN-Elliot. Of Stamford, CT, died Monday, August 26, 2002. Producer for CBS News ''Sunday Morning''; former Executive Producer ''CBS Morning News''; Producer for ''60 Minutes.'' Bernstein began his 46 year career in journalism at UPI, worked at ABC News, then came to CBS News in 1979. Bernstein was winner of a Peabody Award, an ABA Silver Gavel Award, an Overseas Press Club Award and an Emmy Award. He is survived by his wife Marcy; four children, Daniel, Rhea, Julie and Lisa; a granddaughter, Kemper, and his sister, Betty Seiden. Funeral at noon today at Greenwich Reform Synagogue, 257 Stanwich Rd, Greenwich, CT.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: STATE'S PROPERTY MANAGEMENT IS FAULTED The state sometimes fails to identify and market its surplus properties, according to a new report from the state auditors. The state's largest landholding agencies still are not sure how much property they control, the report states. Auditors Kevin Johnston and Robert Jaekle said the Office of Policy and Management, the Department of Public Works and the comptroller's office had developed a new computer system to track surplus properties. Clear criteria are still needed, the auditors said, to determine when a property is no longer needed. In one example from the report, the auditors found that the Department of Transportation "needlessly tied up" as much as $127 million because it left out as many as 3,300 parcels of unused real estate in past inventories. (AP)

title: CHENEY SAYS PERIL OF A NUCLEAR IRAQ JUSTIFIES ATTACK
description: Vice President Dick Cheney today presented the administration's most forceful and comprehensive rationale yet for attacking Iraq, warning that Saddam Hussein would ''fairly soon'' have nuclear weapons.

description: To the Editor:

title: Business Ethics 101
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE GROUND: Newark; A Gateway to New York Is Enjoying a Renaissance
description: Newark -- a 15-minute train ride from Manhattan -- is a leading gateway to New York. But this third-oldest major American city has been enjoying a renaissance, and there are several reasons to stay in town. Newark is aggressively fighting to eradicate its reputation for crime; in fact, crime has decreased more than 50 percent in the last six years.

title: Bush on Fire
description: Round up the usual suspects! George W. Bush's new ''Healthy Forests'' plan reads like a parody of his administration's standard operating procedure. You see, environmentalists cause forest fires, and those nice corporations will solve the problem if we get out of their way.

title: Patient Gets Role in Test For Doctors
description: Since 1998, all graduates of foreign medical schools seeking licenses in the United States have been required to pass a clinical skills test to determine whether they can effectively deal with patients.

title: An Aging Broadcaster in a Sleepy Southern Town
description: THE HEAVEN OF MERCURY

title: Even If the Hips Are Cocked, The Songs Are Family Style
description: When a character in a country song walks into a bar after a fight with his girlfriend and asks for ''the good stuff,'' it's usually easy to guess what happens next: drunkenness, adventures, regrets. But in ''The Good Stuff,'' the quiet centerpiece of Kenny Chesney's set tonight at the PNC Bank Arts Center here, the bartender pours the singer a glass of milk, talks about the romantic moments that are the real ''good stuff'' and sends him home to make up. It's a long way from the honky-tonk of yore.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: CICERO OFFICIALS MUST PAY A federal jury decided that Cicero's town president, Betty Loren-Maltese, and five others convicted of defrauding the Chicago suburb must forfeit millions of dollars in cash and property. The jury ruled that Ms. Loren-Maltese must forfeit up to $3.25 million and two pieces of property in Wisconsin. Two co-defendants, Michael Spano Sr. and John LaGiglio, were ordered to forfeit up to $4 million each and interests in the Wisconsin property. (AP)

title: National Briefing | Education: Commuter Visas
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service will begin allowing thousands of part-time students who commute to United States colleges from Canada and Mexico to obtain visas. The new policy will allow students who attend classes part time to legally enroll in schools within 75 miles of the United States border. For years until Sept. 11, the immigration service did not enforce the ban on part-time students crossing the border. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Amazon Changes Shipping Plan
description: Amazon.com yesterday cut by half the amount shoppers must spend to have merchandise shipped free as the company, the world's largest Internet retailer, seeks to lift sales and gain new customers. Shoppers who buy $25 or more of certain products can get free shipping under a test program, Amazon.com said in a statement. In June, Amazon reduced the minimum purchase required for free shipping to $49 from $99. The lowering of shipping costs is an attempt to turn browsers into buyers and persuade existing customers to order more, the company said. Amazon also expanded discounts in April, offering a 30 percent price reduction on any book with a publisher's list price of more than $15. It previously offered the discount on books of more than $20. ''It's probably a sign that they're having a good quarter,'' said Darren Chervitz, research director for Jacob Asset Management in New York. Customers who select free shipping must accept delivery schedules as much as five days longer than Amazon.com's regular services. Shares of Amazon fell 24 cents, to $14.93.

description: Chinese Group on Terror List

description: It's time to hear about Iraq from us feckless wimps.

title: Navigating the Drug Maze
description: ''The Essential Medication Guidebook to Healthy Aging,'' by Merck-Medco, edited by Dr. Les Paul and Dr. Becky Nagle, Ballantine Books, $18.95.

title: The New Battle of Chancellorsville; Development and Preservation Interests Clash at Civil War Sites
description: Here, where thousands fell in one of the greatest battles ever fought on American soil, a new confrontation is shaping up over the fate of the battlefield.

description: To the Editor:

title: Psychiatric Group to Investigate China, but Resists Penalties
description: The world's leading psychiatric association voted today to send a delegation of experts to China to look into charges that Chinese psychiatric hospitals are being used to silence political and religious dissidents.

title: Endorsements in Republican Primaries
description: Republicans are holding primaries next month for New York State legislative races in Staten Island and Suffolk County. Here are our endorsements, offered as always in the hope that the winner will breathe life into the political process in Albany.

title: Has U.S. Made the Case for War?
description: To the Editor:

title: To Rebuild Afghanistan
description: A country that has suffered as long and as cruelly as Afghanistan needs sustained international help to restore the rudiments of normal life. Two decades of economic and political breakdown helped make Afghanistan an outlaw base for global terrorism. Unless the promises of long-term reconstruction assistance that followed last year's military defeat of the Taliban are kept, anarchy could return.

title: Sports of The Times; Spotlight Won't Find Men's Draw
description: WELCOME, great players of the Earth, to the final Grand Slam of the tennis season, our Let's-Go-Yankees Open. Ladies, after you pass through the metal detectors, kindly give us your prediction for the night of Sept. 7: Venus or Serena? Gentlemen (with the exception of the four seeded Americans), please submit the primary reasons your matches merit attention in our all-Williams, all-the-time Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRKNER, IRWIN
description: BIRKNER-Irwin. Of NYC, died of cancer on August 25th, 2002. Beloved son of Dorothy and Daniel, brother of Melvin (all deceased). He is survived by cousins, close family members and many friends. Irwin will be remembered for his love of life, joyful spirit, kindness and compassion. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Has U.S. Made the Case for War?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Paper Court' Comes to Life Over Secret Tribunal's Ruling on Post-9/11 Police Powers
description: Almost no one has ever heard of this court before. It has never met to issue a ruling.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Riverside: Vandalism Linked To Ethnic Bias
description: Five men, all 19 and 20, have been arrested and accused of vandalizing the homes of Brazilian residents in what the authorities called bias crimes. It was not known why the vandals singled out Brazilians. According to the Burlington County prosecutor's office, the vandals struck three times about 4:30 a.m. Sunday. At one house, the vandals tossed a heavy lawn ornament, a concrete deer head, through a window, the authorities said. At another, they kicked the door and screamed at the sleeping residents to come outside. At the third, the authorities said, the vandals tossed a rock through a window. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Computer Associates Trips Up Directors on Disclosure
description: Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange and a leading official in setting the tone for corporate America, did not disclose his ownership of deferred stock as a board member of Computer Associates International.

title: William Warfield, 82, Dies; Baritone Known for 'Porgy'
description: William Warfield, the bass-baritone whose repertory included everything from theater works to Handel oratorios but who was best known for his portrayals of Porgy in Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess,'' died on Sunday in Chicago. He was 82 and lived in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, ALEXANDER
description: ABRAHAM-Alexander. 83, on August 25, 2002, at his home in Rye, NY. Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Harvard College 1940, former president of Abraham & Co. Inc., former vice chairman of Lehman Brothers Inc., ex-president of the 92nd St. YMHA, archeologist, philanthropist, and loving husband and father. Mr. Abraham is survived by his children Nancy and James, his grandchildren Lauren, Antonia and Karen, his daughter-in-law Andrea, and his son-in-law Arnold Moss. A memorial service is being planned. His children and his grandchildren ask that Mr. Abraham's many friends remember him for his integrity, his generosity, his intelligence and his kindness. Contributions in his memory may be made to the 92nd St. Y, the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, MA, and the Enterprise Foundation in New York City, NY.

title: West Coast by Rail
description: Book by Saturday and save $500 a person on two November departures of the 100-passenger American Orient Express, which takes riders on scenic rail journeys along the West Coast in cars from the 1940's and 50's. The seven-night trips, one way from Los Angeles to Seattle on Nov. 1 or 3, start at $2,390 a person, double occupancy, and include accommodations, wine tastings and lunch in the Napa Valley, a tour of Hearst Castle and other excursions, and most meals. The standard sleeping cabin has upper and lower beds, a sink and a toilet. Information: (800) 320-4206 or www.americanorientexpress.com .

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Health Agency Chief To Step Down
description: Gro Harlem Brundtland said she would not run for re-election next year as director general of the World Health Organization. Dr. Brundtland, a former prime minister of Norway, said she had made significant progress in the goals she set when elected in 1998, including anchoring health firmly in the international development agenda and reforming the organization, a United Nations agency. Dr. Brundtland, whose term expires next July, also said her age -- she would be 69 at the end of another five-year term -- was a factor in her decision. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Women Seek Choices When Fibroid Tumors Strike
description: Several years ago, Monique Brown, a writer and editor from Brooklyn, visited a physician, worried about her heavy periods and bleeding between menstruation. Her disorder was diagnosed as fibroids, she said, noncancerous tumors that can grow in the uterus.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Protest Against Drilling
description: A group of small-business owners asked the Bush administration not to allow drilling for oil in areas of southern Utah that have become tourist attractions for their scenic beauty. In a letter to the White House, the group said drilling would ''forever destroy the pristine landscapes'' that it called ''the bedrock for drawing significant revenue.'' The administration has proposed opening up more of the West to the energy industry, but the group said the potential value of the oil in the areas of Utah in question would be less than $1 billion annually, compared with the $4.25 billion that tourists annually spend there. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: End Of School Boycott
description: A one-week boycott of public schools in Marianna ended with a majority of the system's 1,800 pupils, 90 percent of whom are black, back in classes. Fewer than a third of the system's students attended school last week. The leaders of the boycott said they had succeeded in drawing attention to deteriorating educational facilities and what they described as unfair apportionment of the school board's seven seats, five of which are held by whites. A judge has scheduled a hearing on whether board policies discriminate against black candidates.

title: Some Signs of Gains In Spending on Ads
description: There were some encouraging signs for Madison Avenue yesterday as a forecaster predicted advertising spending this year would increase at a rate on the higher side of recent estimates and a company that tracks ad spending reported better-than-expected results.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Introduces 2 Servers
description: The Dell Computer Corporation introduced two servers and a storage device as part of its effort to diversify sales and aim at small and midsize businesses. Dell introduced the PowerEdge 2600, a $1,999 server that will replace the PowerEdge 2500, and the 600SC, an entry-level $699 unit that will replace the 500SC servers, said Russ Ray, senior manager for Dell servers. The company also introduced a new storage device, the $399 PowerVault 100T-Travan40, he said. Dell, based in Austin, Tex., is trying to diversify from less profitable PC's, which provided 80 percent of the company's revenue in the second quarter. Investors say making servers, fast computers that manage Web pages and printers, is more profitable. The new servers continue Dell's strategy of adding to lower-priced units features that are found on more expensive servers, Mr. Ray said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Terayon Shares Gain
description: The shares of Terayon Communications Systems, a large maker of cable modems, increased 40 percent after it said that Cox Communications would use its modems in Phoenix, the company's largest market. The stock rose 87 cents, to $3.03. Cox, the nation's fifth-largest cable television operator, said it would use Terayon's TJ 715 cable modems on its networks. ''Phoenix is a very competitive market for residential broadband services, and we must continue to stay one step ahead of the competition to maintain our leadership position,'' said Ike Wells, vice president for field operations at Cox's Phoenix system. ''The advanced features and capabilities of Terayon's TJ 715 cable modem give us a significant advantage over our competition.'' Terayon is based in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Rebels Propose Cease-Fire
description: The government and a rebel group appeared to inch closer to talks as leaders of the Lord's Resistance Army said they would observe a cease-fire if government soldiers did not attack their positions in northern Uganda. President Yoweri Museveni appointed negotiators last week in hopes of ending the 15-year war with the rebels. He invited them to peace talks, vowing to crush them within six months if they refuse. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNINO, GAETANO (AKA GUY MANNING)
description: MANNINO - Gaetano (aka Guy Manning), 69, son of the late Phil Mannino and the late Julia (nee Noto) died Saturday evening of a heart attack at home in New York City with his wife Angela (nee Van Heest) by his side. Guy is also survived by his sister Jean Asimakis and three nephews, Peter Asimakis, Frank Capriola and David Capriola, and five great-nephews, Shawn, Michael, David, Mario, and Angelo Capriola. Guy spent most of his adult life in showbusiness in Los Angeles and New York. The funeral will be Thursday at 9am from the Ippolito-Stellato Funeral Home, 425 Ridge Rd., Lyndhurst, NJ. Funeral Mass 10am St. Joseph's RC Church E. Rutherford. Entombment Holy Cross Chapel Mausoleum N. Arlington. Friends will be received Tuesday 7-9pm and Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 pm.

title: Ancient Ways, Harsh Terrain and Many Bugs

description: The esoteric pursuit of measuring who makes the fastest computer chips has turned nasty, with accusations of pressure, conflict of interest and deception.

title: Corrections

Bloomberg. Current law requires a six-foot space (not a physical barrier) between smoking and no-smoking sections. Mr. Bloomberg's proposal would ban all smoking in bars and restaurants. It would not allow separate, specially ventilated smoking areas.
