title: Front Row
description: In the cycle of Manhattan shopping life, there are about three or four days in mid-August when an unusual number of things are sold in rather small sizes. The period is not the official shopping week of the preternaturally thin. It is instead the point at which parents stock the closets of children returning to day jobs in September, which is to say, grade school.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about remarks by Foreign Secretary Jack Straw on the British government's Iraq policy misattributed a statement about that policy. The assessment that removing Saddam Hussein is "not an object of British foreign policy" was made by a BBC interviewer, not by Mr. Straw.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Meat Scandal
description: Japan's largest beef processor, Nippon Meat Packers, said three of its top executives would leave the company after some employees were found to have falsely labeled packages to gain state subsidies. The chairman and two vice chairmen will retire rather than receive honorary posts, as was originally announced. Their departures, however, will not halt a government investigation of the company's operations. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Reconstituted S.E.C. Tightens Rules on Insider Stock Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  The Securities and Exchange Commission responded today to the recent spate of corporate scandals by adopting a series of rules requiring executives to disclose both important company information and their own stock trades more quickly. The agency also put into effect a rule requiring top executives to regularly certify the accuracy of their companies' financial reports.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Airline Grounded
description: An Argentine regional airline, Dinar, suspended flights for an indefinite period after its owner said that a major bank was taking all of the company's fare revenue to pay off a small part of its $25 million debt. Dinar's chairman, Fayez Chaheb, whose charter company, American Falcon, took over Dinar a month ago by agreeing to take on its debt after it filed for bankruptcy, told the daily newspaper Clarin that the company's four daily flights would be grounded but that no immediate layoffs were planned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILEVSKY, FRED EFRAIM HESHEL
description: PILEVSKY - Fred Efraim Heshel. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a highly respected community leader, and extends condolences to his wife, Paula, his children, Philip (and Renee), a member of the Yeshiva College Board of Directors, Allen (and Shoshanna), and Sheila (and Jeff) Levine, and his grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Jay Schottenstein, Chairman YC Board of Directors

title: NASA Is Urged To Build Craft To Replace Ill-Fated One
description: All but writing off a comet-exploring spacecraft apparently destroyed in a rocket-firing accident this month, project managers suggested today that NASA build a duplicate craft to take up the mission.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: AMAZON CHANGES SHIPPING PLAN Amazon .com yesterday cut by half the amount shoppers must spend to have merchandise shipped free as the company, the world's largest Internet retailer, seeks to lift sales and gain new customers. Shoppers who buy $25 or more of certain products can get free shipping under a test program, Amazon.com said in a statement. In June, Amazon reduced the minimum purchase required for free shipping to $49 from $99. The lowering of shipping costs is an attempt to turn browsers into buyers and persuade existing customers to order more, the company said. Amazon also expanded discounts in April, offering a 30 percent price reduction on any book with a publisher's list price of more than $15. It previously offered the discount on books of more than $20. "It's probably a sign that they're having a good quarter," said Darren Chervitz, research director for Jacob Asset Management in New York. Customers who select free shipping must accept delivery schedules as much as five days longer than Amazon.com's regular services. Shares of Amazon fell 24 cents, to $14.93. (Bloomberg News)

title: Some in Argentina See Secession As the Answer to Economic Peril
description: For years this tidy city of 250,000 has prided itself on being ''the gateway to Patagonia.'' But these days it is also the center of an increasingly restive movement to detach this southernmost region of South America, rich in oil and minerals, from the economic disaster that is the rest of Argentina.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Helicopter Toll At 117
description: The death toll in the crash last week of a military helicopter near the main Russian base in the southern republic of Chechnya rose to 117 as contradictory reports about the cause of the crash emerged. The official news agency Itar-Tass reported that an investigation had concluded that a rebel missile, possibly stolen from a Russian Army depot, had shot down the helicopter, which was carrying 147 people. It also reported that a suspect had been detained, but the federal deputy prosecutor general, Sergei N. Fridinksy, said later that no conclusion had been reached and that no one had been detained. Last week, President Vladimir V. Putin blamed commanders' dereliction of duty. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Gas Pipeline Called Feasible
description: The Japan Petroleum Exploration Company, a joint venture of Japanese trading companies and oil field developers, said its plan to build a natural gas pipeline from Sakhalin to Tokyo was economically and technologically sound. The pipeline is expected to stretch more than 900 miles. Construction may begin in 2005. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: TRW Seen Near Deal To Sell Auto Unit For About $5 Billion
description: TRW Inc., the military contractor that recently agreed to be sold to Northrop Grumman for $7.8 billion, is close to a deal to sell its automotive-parts business to a group of financiers for about $5 billion, executives close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Analysts Retreating on Forecasts of Further Fed Rate Cuts
description: At the beginning of the month, economists at several top Wall Street firms predicted that the slower growth reflected in recent economic data and the shaky condition of financial markets would force Federal Reserve policymakers to cut their short-term interest rate benchmark, which is already at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent.

title: When the Flu Is Taken Lightly
description: The flu season is months away, but a vaccine expert from the Mayo Clinic is calling on doctors to start preparing a concerted effort to increase flu vaccinations, citing a study that found vaccinations cut deaths or hospitalizations from influenza by up to half among people older than 65.

description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Oil prices rose amid speculation that OPEC may not increase production when it meets next month. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 65 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $29.28 a barrel.

title: Accounting Rule Changes May Strain Small Companies Most
description: When members of Congress passed tougher corporate governance laws last month, imposing new reporting requirements on companies and overhauling the regulation of accountants, they were probably not thinking of companies like Regent Communications. They were worried about future Enrons, WorldComs and Adelphias.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWEDEN: EXECUTIVE REPLACED Nordea, the Nordic region's biggest bank, replaced its chief executive, Thorleif Krarup, with Lars Nordstroem, the head of consumer banking, after second-quarter profit slumped. Mr. Nordstroem said in an interview that he would speed up efforts to integrate Nordea's businesses. Mr. Krarup left after less than two years as chief executive. Nordea, based in Stockholm and the result of $19 billion worth of mergers over four years, will have to accelerate cost cuts after earnings fell 81 percent in the three months through June, investors said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: The Connections column in Arts & Ideas on Aug. 17 about the novelist Eric Ambler included a film credit for him erroneously. The screenplay for ''The Guns of Navarone,'' based on the novel of the same name by Alistair MacLean, was written by Carl Foreman, not by Ambler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSER, ABRAHAM
description: TESSER-Abraham. At 86, on August 26, 2002. Beloved husband of Toby (Turkel). Devoted father of Gary Charles and Steven Barry, Ph.D. Dear brother of Florence Tesser and Ruth Leventhal. Cherished uncle of many loving nieces and nephews. Mr. Tesser graduated City College after earning his CPA. He served in the U.S. Army and practiced public accounting for over 50 years. He was a 32nd Degree Freemason. He was respected and beloved by all, a dear, strong, gentle man who will be greatly missed.

description: A Congressional committee released copies of internal WorldCom e-mail messages yesterday that it says suggest that David Myers, the company's former controller, tried early this year to silence an executive who had questioned accounting practices at WorldCom.

description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and Gov. George E. Pataki urged Jews yesterday to be vigilant about security during the High Holy Days.

title: Broderbund Is Acquired
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 26 (Bloomberg News)  The Riverdeep Group , the Irish educational software maker, bought Broderbund , a software producer, for $57.2 million to expand its school and consumer business.

title: Quail Hawkins, 97, an Author Of a Range of Children's Books
description: Quail Hawkins, the author of gentle children's books like ''A Puppy for Keeps,'' and ''Mark, Mark, Shut the Door,'' both popular in the 1940's, died on Aug. 16 at the retirement home where she lived in Pacific Grove, Calif. She was 97.

title: Four Years of Federal Budget Deficits Are Expected
description: The Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the Federal government will be running big budget deficits through 2005, and those deficits do not reflect President Bush's proposal to make last year's tax cuts permanent.

title: Unabashed Wal-Mart Shopper Speaks
description: I'm almost embarrassed to admit I buy my clothes at Wal-Mart. Not because of the radioactive scorn attached to the company, the world's largest -- 2,600 stores, $219 billion a year in revenue, slayer of mom-and-pop operations everywhere -- or even because, golly, Ned, it looks as if I won't make the International Best-Dressed List now. I'm embarrassed because such an admission sounds like fashion editor jive.

description: Creditors for Enron filed suit yesterday against a former finance executive of the company, seeking the $12 million he agreed to turn over to the government as part of a plea deal.

title: State Dept. Says No Consensus Reached on Iraq Action
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  The State Department asserted today that President Bush had not decided on a military campaign against Iraq, and that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had not been enlisted to marshal international support for a military operation.

title: National Briefing: South
description: SMOKY MOUNTAINS SMOG STUDY Beginning today, a project will measure tailpipe emissions from vehicles in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, where smog has become an increasing problem. During the two-week study, financed by the American Lung Association, pollutants will be measured with infrared and ultraviolet light by a laser beam projected across the road. Tailpipe emissions contain nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons, precursors to ozone pollution and carbon monoxide. Researchers will look for about 50 possible pollutants. (AP)

title: Impostor's Stock Trade Roils Korea Market
description: A securities dealer bought $22 million worth of a company's shares over the Internet on Friday, using a stolen account number, sending shock waves through the Korean financial system.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: U.S. Helicopters Grounded
description: The United States command grounded its 70 Apache helicopters in South Korea while memorial services were held for two pilots killed when their Apache 64A crashed last Thursday in hilly terrain. Experts from the United States Army Safety Center at Fort Rucker, Alabama, are investigating that crash and one of an Apache 64D on Aug. 1 in which no one was injured. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: When on the Road Means on the Road
description: LAST Thursday, my wife and I flew to Phoenix on Continental Airlines, on round-trip tickets that cost $404 each. Because each of us last year flew over 25,000 miles on Continental, we qualify for when-available upgrades to first class.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Oil Investment
description: Petrleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state-owned oil monopoly, will invest $4.25 billion over the next eight years to develop its offshore Ku-Maloob-Zaap oil field in the Bay of Campeche, the company announced. The project will increase production of heavy Maya crude from the oil field to 800,000 barrels a day from 263,000 by 2011. Pemex did not say how it would finance the project, which involves drilling 82 new wells and building 17 new platforms.

title: Cutting the Cord
description: The hallowed college tradition of haggling with roommates over the phone bill and undelivered messages may soon be a thing of the past. An increasing number of students arriving on campus these days rely solely on cellphones for their gabfests. Young people, in school and at work, are breaking ingrained habits that date back to the 19th-century birth of AT&T. They think ''their'' phone number is as permanent as the one Social Security gives them, and belongs to them personally, not to a phone jack on a wall somewhere.

description: Fireworks, followed by a cloud of smoke above the court, capped the 35-minute opening night ceremony at Arthur Ashe Stadium last night, a trumpet-filled tribute to the heroes of Sept. 11.

title: Baseball's Labor Twist
description: As fans grope to understand why baseball's labor negotiations seem headed over the cliff once again, a big reason may rest in an unusually convoluted twist in the talks: the players' union is asking for precisely the opposite of what most unions ask for, while the club owners are seeking the opposite of what most businesses want.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: MUGABE OUSTS A DISSENTER Squeezing out one of the last voices of dissent in his cabinet, President Robert Mugabe dropped his finance minister, Simba Makoni, in a cabinet shuffle. Mr. Makoni, who had been enlisted to help rebuild the country's shattered economy, found himself increasingly isolated in recent months as the president hardened his stance toward Western donor nations and the International Monetary Fund. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Department Store Loss
description: KarstadtQuelle, the biggest owner of department stores in Germany, said its second-quarter loss widened and demand might not recover until next year. The company, which owns the Karstadt and Hertie department stores, had a pretax loss of 228 million euros ($221 million) in the quarter, compared with a loss of 69 million euros a year earlier. Full-year sales are expected to fall 3 percent, the company said. KarstadtQuelle generates about 90 percent of sales in Germany's $380 billion retail industry, which has not grown in 7 of the last 10 years.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: New Traffic 'Signal'
description: The state has updated a bloody black-and-white driver education film that had been the staple of safety classes since 1959. Maureen O'Connor, the director of the Department of Public Safety, said students in recent years had been distracted by the 1950's clothing and vehicles in the original version of the film, ''Signal 30.'' The new version includes real-life scenes of gruesome car accidents from across the state. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Pentagon May Extend Reservists' Duty
description: The Defense Department is notifying more than 14,000 reservists that they may be required to extend their duty, to serve up to two years instead of one, in a move seen as a contingency for possible action against Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl, 4, Killed In Hit-And-Run
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn girl was killed last night in Midwood by a hit-and-run driver when she ran into the street about 9 p.m., the police said. The girl, Tzitorah Gelb of East 29th Street, was declared dead at Kings County Hospital Center after being struck by a silver Lexus on East 29th Street between Avenues K and L. Investigators said that the driver, a woman of 50 who lives nearby, was being questioned, but that no charges had been filed. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Hewlett-Packard Drops Microsoft Works in Favor of WordPerfect
description: Microsoft, the world's biggest software group, on Monday suffered a blow to its most important business, when Hewlett-Packard, the world's largest personal computer company, selected a rival software package for its consumer PCs.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Suppliers Push Daewoo
description: Nearly 200 companies that supply components for Daewoo Motor said they would suspend deliveries beginning on Thursday unless the company began to pay them more than $300 million in accumulated debts. The parts suppliers, which have organized as the Association of Daewoo Motor Suppliers, warned that parts makers would go bankrupt unless the creditors who own the company guarantee that the parts companies would be paid. The impasse threatened a further delay in carrying out the agreement under which General Motors is to take over Daewoo Motor with an initial payment of $400 million.

title: Making Melodies Dance With a Basque Accordion
description: The smaller the accordion, the feistier the sound. That rule of thumb applies to the trikitixa, the two-row button accordion from the Basque region of Spain that Kepa Junkera played at Joe's Pub on Friday night. Like the accordions used in Irish and Cajun traditional music, the trikitixa puts a bite behind each reedy note, and Mr. Junkera uses that bite to make melodies dance.

title: JUDGE APPROVES XO BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: XO Communications, a telephone and Internet service company, won a bankruptcy judge's approval of a reorganization plan yesterday, clearing the way for the company to try to enforce an $800 million investment agreement with Forstmann Little & Company and Telfonos de Mexico. Forstmann Little and Telmex, Mexico's biggest telephone company, once planned to invest $400 million each in XO. They backed out in June, citing XO's deteriorating finances. XO, based in Reston, Va., sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June. The company is trying to enforce the agreement as part of a Chapter 11 reorganization plan. Judge Arthur Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved the plan at a hearing today.

He was a 32nd Degree Freemason. He was respected and beloved by all, a dear, strong, gentle man who will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDEN, ROGER, SR.

Former Foreign Exchange Broker for Tullett & Tokyo Forex Brokers. Former husband of June Gorden (nee White). He resided in Dingman's Ferry, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Dingman's Ferry Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Dingman's Ferry, PA. Services Thursday August 29, 3pm at Stroyan Funeral Home, 405 W Harford St, Milford, PA.

title: Europe, Next Year
description: Image Tours, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., will apply this year's price plus discounts to its 2003 European escorted tours for bookings made by Oct. 31. The 15-day Heart of Europe tour  with stops in Belgium, Italy, France, Germany, Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands  is $2,230 a person, double, for April departures, which is a $200 discount. A 16-day World War II Memorial tour visits battle sites (including Normandy), museums and memorials. Prices start at $2,770 a person, double occupancy, for May departures, a discount of $100. Prices include air fare from New York, Boston or Baltimore, accommodations, most meals, ground transportation and all taxes and tips. Information: (800) 964-3170 or www.imagetours.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUADAGNO, ANTON
description: GUADAGNO-Anton. Absolutely shocked and saddened at the news of the passing of my dear friend Anton Guadagno. My heart and prayers go out to you, Dolores, and your family for this great loss. My relationship with ''the Maestro'' goes far beyond our opera association. He was a great gentleman and a true friend. His passing leaves a very large, unfillable void. He was truly one of a kind. M. Mac Schwebel, President Palm Beach Opera

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHLEY, TED
description: ASHLEY-Ted. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts mourn the passing of Ted Ashley. A dear friend and thoughtful leader, Mr. Ashley served us as an esteemed member of the Board of Directors from 1981-1995, and as Director Emeritus since 1995. A true friend of the performing Arts, Mr. Ashley was a kind, warm, and hard working gentleman who generously gave of himself through his service to Lincoln Center. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Page, his four daughters, his two grandchildren, his brother Alfred Ashley and family. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him. Bruce Crawford, Chairman Reynold Levy, President Martin E. Segal and June Noble Larkin, Co-Chairs, Directors Emeriti Council Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

title: Market Place; HealthSouth Pulls Back Its Forecast, But Wall St. Questions Explanation
description: HealthSouth, the nation's biggest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, surprised investors yesterday by withdrawing its 2002 profit estimate and offering an explanation that some analysts said was incomplete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUGHRAN, JOHN B.
description: LOUGHRAN-John B. Of Bronxville and Big Indian, NY on August 26, 2002. Born August 27, 1916. Son of John T. Loughran (former Chief Judge, New York Court of Appeals) and Cornelia (Brodhead) of Kingston, NY. Survived by his wife Sara Ann Cruickshank Loughran, his sons John and Robert, his daughters Cornelia, Barbara, Marianne and Virginia and eleven grandchildren. A graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law School, he retired as a partner of the law firm Rogers & Wells. He served in Burma as a member of the Army Air Corps in WW II. A devout Roman Catholic, he was a member of the Knights of Malta and Knights of Columbus. The wake is Thursday, August 29, 5-8 PM at McGrath's Funeral Home, Bronxville. Funeral services Friday, August 30, 10 AM at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville. Burial in Kingston, NY at St. Mary's Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In your country club, your church and business, about 15 percent of the people are screwballs, lightweights and boobs and you would not want those people unrepresented in Congress.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Turkmenistan: Military Aid From U.S.
description: The United States plans to expand military cooperation with Turkmenistan, the commander of American forces in the region, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, said. General Franks, left, who is traveling through the region, met with the Central Asian country's autocratic president, Saparmarud Niyazov, and discussed aid to Afghanistan and efforts to combat terrorism, according to a statement by the American Embassy in the capital, Ashgabad. General Franks said the expanded cooperation could include training and equipment for Turkmenistan's military, border troops and police forces. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: RCN TO SELL PRINCETON CABLE SYSTEMS The RCN Corporation, the cable television, phone and Internet provider backed by Paul G. Allen, said it would sell its cable systems in Princeton, N.J., for $245 million. Spectrum Equity Investors, a private equity firm in Boston, and the cable entrepreneur Steve Simmons will buy the systems, which have about 80,000 subscribers, RCN executives said. Mr. Simmons said he would spend about $44 million to upgrade the networks to offer digital cable and high-speed Internet access. David C. McCourt, the chief executive of RCN, said, "Because the RCN business plan was founded on building our own network in major metropolitan markets and bundling phone, high-speed Internet and cable TV, central New Jersey's systems  which were built years ago by others  were not a core part of our strategy." Shares of RCN, which is based in Princeton, rose 12 cents, or 14 percent, to 97 cents; they have fallen more than 60 percent this year. (NYT)

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL BUYS U.S. UNIT OF AUSTRALIAN BANK
description: National Australia Bank said yesterday that it had sold the parent company of its HomeSide Lending unit to Washington Mutual Inc. for 2.3 billion Australian dollars ($1.3 billion), ending its foray in the United States banking market. The sale of SR Investment Inc., HomeSide's parent, comprises National Australia's $131 billion mortgage servicing rights portfolio in the United States. National Australia will report a loss of 104 million Australian dollars on the sale. National Australia sold most of its HomeSide business to Washington Mutual last year, excluding mortgage servicing rights to its home loan portfolio. Washington Mutual had the option to buy them at a later date.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Ship Pricing Conflict Widens
description: A delegation from the European Union said differences in the price of ships made in Korea from those made in Europe had widened since June 2001, the last time the delegations discussed the issue. The delegation said the Korean side had lowered its price by 10 percent. Europe says that South Korean shipbuilders receive government subsidies that more than compensate for losses they take in making ships and it might bring the issue to the World Trade Organization. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: US Airways Puts New Terms On Nonrefundable Tickets
description: US Airways said yesterday that it was imposing more stringent conditions on most of its nonrefundable tickets, including requiring passengers to buy another ticket if they miss their original flight and want to take a later one.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRECKIR, ROSE (GO, GO)
description: BRECKIR-Rose (Go-Go). It's been one year today. Always in our hearts. Judi

title: NORTEL NETWORKS TO CUT 7,000 MORE JOBS
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 7,000 more jobs by the end of the year and that its third-quarter revenue would miss its forecast because of a decline in spending on equipment by United States companies. Nortel, the big maker of telephone gear, will reduce its work force to 35,000, compared with a previous goal of 42,000 by the end of September, said a spokeswoman. Third-quarter sales will fall as much as 10 percent from the second quarter's $2.77 billion. Sales are falling because some operators like Global Crossing have sought bankruptcy protection while survivors including Sprint are cutting spending to preserve cash.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE DOWN Dutch consumer confidence reached a record low in August as consumers grew more reluctant to make major purchases, the government statistics bureau said. The August consumer confidence index, adjusted for seasonal swings, fell to minus 29 from minus 27 in July. (Bloomberg News)

title: Surgeons Are Warned About Heart Valves
description: Two weeks ago, the Food and Drug Administration ordered CryoLife Inc. of Kennesaw, Ga., a leading supplier of donated human tissue, to recall all tissue used in orthopedic surgery -- ligaments, tendons, cartilage and other soft tissue popular for repairing knees and joints. The agency said CryoLife could not assure that its tissues, taken from donated cadavers, were free from dangerous bacteria and fungi.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: DEFICIT FALLS Brazil's current account deficit shrank to $550 million in July from $2.04 billion a year ago, the central bank said. The bank lowered its forecast for this year's current account deficit, which measures a country's foreign transactions and is widely used as a barometer of the economy's vulnerability, to $17.03 billion from $19.6 billion. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A recipe last Wednesday for chicken salad with skordalia, with the Minimalist Entertains column, omitted the measure for extra virgin olive oil and an instruction on when to add black pepper. The oil measures one-quarter cup, and the pepper should go in with the chili powder or paprika. The recipe also omitted an instruction on what to do with the liquid squeezed from the bread; it should be reserved. A corrected recipe follows:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Gemstar Shares Drop After Warning
description: Shares of Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. fell as much as 11 percent yesterday after the maker of software to run on-screen television program guides said the Nasdaq Stock Market might delist its shares. Shares fell 57 cents, or 12.8 percent, to $3.91. The shares had fallen 84 percent this year through yesterday. Gemstar said yesterday that it might be delisted after failing to file its quarterly report, or 10-Q, for the second quarter with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, based in Pasadena, Calif., has requested a hearing on the proposed delisting. Two weeks ago, Gemstar said it would delay filing the 10-Q while the audit committee of its board reviewed the company's accounting. Gemstar in April disclosed that it had recorded more than $100 million in revenue for licensing fees it expected to collect from Scientific-Atlanta Inc., the maker of television set-top boxes that Gemstar had accused of patent infringement.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Thursday about the Democratic primary defeat of Representative Cynthia A. McKinney of Georgia and its aftermath included a name incorrectly among those of black politicians distancing themselves from her. Julian Bond, chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., points out that as head of a nonpartisan organization he does not participate in electoral politics.

description: Stocks fell today in light pre-holiday trading as the outlook for both the market and the economy continued to look uncertain.

description: FORMAN-Blanche. Beloved wife of the late William; loving mother of Ronald (Ann) and Gary; loving sister of Louis and Seymour; devoted grandmother of David, Eric and Steven. Dedicated teacher at P.S. 1 in Manhattan, P.S. 190 and P.S. 279 in Brooklyn. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, 11:30 AM, at I. J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Summons to War
description: With Republican mandarins cautioning the Bush administration about marching on Baghdad, Vice President Dick Cheney grabbed the microphone this week to make the case for war. We're glad the White House is talking at greater length and more specifically about Iraq, but Mr. Cheney failed to offer convincing answers to questions that give many Americans pause about using military force to oust Saddam Hussein. The White House has yet to meet the difficult burden of showing why Iraq's weapons programs, including its efforts to develop nuclear arms, require an American invasion.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: TV Azteca To Spin Off Phone Stake
description: TV Azteca, a leading broadcaster, will spin off its stake in Unefon, a mobile phone operator, to its shareholders, who will be asked to approve the move next month.

title: Stanton Is in Demand As Authority on Talks
description: Mike Stanton missed the daily prayer group again. Stanton was inundated by reporters as soon as he entered the cramped visiting clubhouse at Fenway Park today, so he passed the Bible off to a Yankee teammate and handled questions about the labor dispute.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Raises Urged For Police Officers
description: A group of City Council members urged Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday to sweeten raises for police officers and firefighters and pay for it with a new tax. Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference that the city could not offer larger raises because of a $5 billion budget deficit. Councilman Hiram Monserrate, above, distributed a letter endorsed by 20 members urging the mayor to take ''immediate action'' to consider a tax for fire and police pay. Citing what aides called a draft proposal, the mayor has said that police officers would be likely to get a 14 percent raise over two years, about two-thirds of the 21.9 percent the police union seeks. A state arbitration panel has not reached a final decision. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Saving Water, U.S. Farmers Are Worried They'll Parch
description: Ronnie Hopper grows cotton, and he has learned firsthand that water is precious. The water that he pumps from underground costs him five times as much as it used to, so he does his best not to waste a drop.

title: KitchenAid Selects Saatchi & Saatchi
description: KitchenAid, the appliance and kitchen-equipment maker owned by the Whirlpool Corporation, said yesterday that it had selected Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Advice for the Fans
description: Baseball fans, if you want to prevent a strike this summer and in summers to come, here's how you can help: Stop rooting against the players and start rooting against the owners. Your opinion matters more than you think.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Member Of Parliament Attacked
description: Two assailants seriously injured a member of Parliament and killed his aide in an attack outside the legislator's home in the southwestern republic of Karachayev-Cherkessia. Conflicting reports said the lawmaker, a well-known journalist named Magomet Tekeyev, was either severely beaten or shot several times; his aide was gunned down. The motive was unclear. Political figures are frequently targets of assassins; last week, an unidentified gunman in Moscow killed another member of Parliament, Vladimir Golovlyov. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: In Talk With Envoy, Bush Assails Hussein, but Saudis Are Firm in Opposing War
description: President Bush told Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States today that Saddam Hussein was ''a menace and a threat'' to both his Middle East neighbors and the United States. But after a meeting that lasted several hours, Saudi officials said their position was unchanged -- that war was not acceptable and they would not cooperate in any military action.

title: AMERCO SAYS S.E.C. INQUIRY INTO AUDITOR FIRING IS ROUTINE
description: Amerco, the owner of U-Haul International, said yesterday that it had been asked routine questions by the Securities and Exchange Commission about the firing of its auditor last month, and is not being investigated by the agency. The company said that it received a standard letter from the S.E.C. and responded to it after firing its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers. Without citing anyone as the source, The Financial Times reported yesterday that the S.E.C. was investigating the company, The company said it was current in its filings of financial information after two late filings in the last year.

title: UConn Making Jump to the Big Time
description: A victory over the Rutgers football team, the doormat of the Big East, may not seem like a reason to exult, but for Connecticut and its followers, its 20-19 victory last Sept. 29 in New Jersey was. It was the Huskies' first victory over a team from a major conference since they moved from Division I-AA to college football's top level, Division I-A, in 2000.

title: Fish Moves to Second Round
description: The last thing Mardy Fish needed was an addition to his list of close calls, a new entry on the annoying ticker of almosts, particularly at the United States Open.

title: For North Korean, It Seems Possible to Have a Hot Time in Siberia
description: As Kim Jong Il's armored railroad car rolled through this Doctor Zhivago landscape of dachas and birch trees during his second trip to Russia, government publicists back home in North Korea worked overtime to squelch suspicions that Mr. Kim, 60, their ''Dear Leader,'' was on another leisurely junket.

title: Tenants Suing Over Disparity In Rent Laws
description: Five tenants who say they are facing eviction because their landlords want their apartments for personal use sued Gov. George E. Pataki and a state housing agency in federal court yesterday, arguing that a city law allowing the evictions is unconstitutional.

title: Few Exercise New Right To Leave Failing Schools
description: The education act that President Bush championed during his campaign and signed into law last January gave 3.5 million children in failing public schools the right to choose a better school this September. But with few slots available and few parents applying, education officials say that only a small number of children will benefit from the law this year.

description: MANHATTAN: U.S. DEFENDS ACTION IN TERROR CASE

title: 65% Drop in Profit at Bombardier Is Tied to a Slump in Corporate Jet Orders
description: Bombardier Inc. of Montreal said today that a sudden slump in demand for corporate jets contributed to a 65 percent decline in its second-quarter earnings.

title: Fred Darrington, A Sculptor, 91, Inspired by Sand
description: Fred Darrington, who was to British sand castles what Sir Christopher Wren was to London churches, died Aug. 16 in his home in Esher, Surrey. He was 91.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Release Of Juror Names Is Urged
description: With jury selection in the fourth trial of Charles Schwarz scheduled to begin on Sept. 9, The New York Times petitioned the trial judge yesterday not to withhold the names of the jurors, as the judge did in the trial that ended in July. In its motion to Judge Reena Raggi, The Times argued that the appeals court had repeatedly ruled that jurors' names should be withheld only when their personal safety was at risk or there was a clear danger of jury tampering. Times lawyers argued that neither was the case with the trial of Mr. Schwarz, who is accused of violating Abner Louima's civil rights.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a pledge by 16 banks to continue lending to Brazil misstated the given name of the country's central bank president. He is Arminio Fraga, not Amilio.

title: Skakel Defense to Seek New Trial in '75 Murder at Sentencing Today
description: On the eve of his sentencing for the murder of Martha Moxley, lawyers for Michael C. Skakel have intensified their efforts to win him a new trial by accusing prosecutors of withholding a police sketch and other information that they say incriminate another suspect in the 27-year-old case.

title: Enron to Sell Major Units To Raise Cash For Settlements
description: The Enron Corporation announced detailed plans yesterday to sell a dozen major businesses by the end of the year, a big step toward generating the cash that the company needs to settle the more than $50 billion in claims against it.

description: TO remain the center of the universe -- which New York is, of course -- you need an infrastructure. For example: the National Tennis Center in Queens is built upon the skeletons of past extravaganzas when New York played host to the world.

title: Plan to Build a New Penn Station Is Moving Ahead, Officials Say
description: New York officials said yesterday that their plans to build a new Pennsylvania Station in the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue were back on track, even though they have yet to reach a deal with the Postal Service. They added that they were not concerned about Amtrak's summer of financial and technical problems.

title: New York Announces Details Of Greater 9/11 Business Aid
description: New York State and City gave details yesterday of their plans to increase aid to small businesses in Lower Manhattan that are suffering as a result of the terrorist attack last September.

description: A Brooklyn man was shot and killed by the police yesterday after he ran from officers, pulled out what was later identified as a fake pistol and pointed it at them, the authorities said.

description: Two powerful leaders of teachers' unions stood shoulder to shoulder with State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday and urged the state government to spend more money on schools, but both stopped short of endorsing him in his quest to become governor.

description: Gov. Jesse Ventura says he will help promote the state by going on overseas trade missions if he is succeeded in office by Tim Penney, the candidate of Mr. Ventura's Independence Party. Mr. Ventura has led trade missions to Japan, Canada, Mexico, Germany and China, and he is going to Cuba next month. He said Mr. Penney told him he wanted Mr. Ventura to continue such work.

title: White House Withholding Documents On Pardons
description: Bush administration officials said today that they were keeping secret more than 4,000 pages of Justice Department documents related to a flurry of last-minute pardons by President Bill Clinton to protect the right of all presidents to private deliberations.

title: GERON SHARES RALLY ON PATENT FOR CANCER TREATMENT
description: Shares of the Geron Corporation, a biotechnology company, rose 15 percent yesterday after it won a patent for technology to develop immune-system-based cancer therapies. Shares of Geron rose 59 cents, to close at $4.44, on Nasdaq. The patent covers Geron technology for stimulating the body's immune system to attack cancer cells by aiming at telomerase, a protein linked to cancer growth. The technology may be used to develop vaccines against a wide range of cancers, the company said. Geron is evaluating a telomerase vaccine in early studies in patients with prostate cancer, the company said. Geron, based in Menlo Park, Calif., is also developing drugs to block telomerase directly.

title: S.E.C. Pushes Companies To Disclose Data Faster
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, responding to recent corporate scandals, adopted rules today requiring executives to be faster in disclosing important company information and their own stock trades.

title: Wells and Yanks Keep Marching On, but to Where?
description: David Wells was apparently thinking more about Commissioner Bud Selig and the labor talks than about Nomar Garciaparra and Manny Ramirez three hours before the Yankees played the Red Sox tonight. Wells leaned back in a folding chair to ask Steve Karsay for an update on the negotiations and then predicted that Selig would soon become more immersed in the fragile discussions.

title: National Briefing | West: California: $1 Million Settlement In Slaying
description: The mother of Chad MacDonald, 17, who was beaten and killed by drug dealers in 1998 after working as a police informer in Orange County, will receive a $1 million legal settlement. City officials in Brea agreed on Monday to the settlement, the largest by a police department in Orange County history, about a month after a state appeals court reinstated a lawsuit by the family. The killing led to a law limiting the use of teenage informers. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Digitally Giving Time and Space the Silly Putty Treatment
description: The newest effort by the experimental director Michael Snow, ''*Corpus Callosum,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is simultaneously static and elastic. Though Mr. Snow credits a cast, he really uses his actors like action figures and deploys postproduction technology to stretch their forms and switch them around like pieces on a game board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGER, PER
description: ANGER-Per. 1913-2002. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum deeply mourns the passing of Per Anger. As second secretary at the Swedish legation in Budapest during World War II, Anger participated in efforts to rescue Hungarian Jews from arrest and deportation. As a key associate he worked alongside legendary hero and rescuer Raoul Wallenberg, and is credited with saving thousands of lives from 1944 until the end of the war in May 1945. Following the war, Anger continued his diplomatic career, serving as Swedish ambassador to Australia and Canada. In addition, he initiated efforts to search for Wallenberg, an issue that remained a driving focus of his life, and remained an active human rights advocate. In 1982 he was recognized by Yad Vashem as one of the Righteous Among the Nations, and was awarded the Hungarian Republic's Order of Merit in 1995. The Museum expresses its deepest condolences to his family and friends. Fred S. Zeidman, Chairman Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chair Sara J. Bloomfield, Director United States Holocaust Memorial Museum

title: From Playwright to Publishing Company Chief, Then Back Again
description: Thomas McCormack is the former chairman, chief executive and editorial director of St. Martin's Press. Mr. McCormack is also a playwright. He wrote his first play more than 30 years ago, and now he has written his second, a comic drama about what he knows best, the publishing business and, to use his words, ''what it takes'' to be a C.E.O., ''and what it takes away.''

title: Critic's Notebook; The Information Age Processes a Tragedy
description: In the introduction to a collection of essays on the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, the scholars Strobe Talbott and Nayan Chanda write that their working premise was ''that the unforgivable is not necessarily incomprehensible or inexplicable.''

title: National Briefing: Science And Health
description: NASA AND SINGER ARE 'N SYNC The 'N Sync singer Lance Bass won the endorsement of NASA and other space agencies in his bid to fly to the International Space Station this fall. Mr. Bass, 23, got the news while training at Johnson Space Center in Houston. All that remains in his way is a financial agreement with the Russian space program; both sides have been haggling over the deal. A round-trip ticket to the space station on a Russian spacecraft costs as much as $20 million. (AP)

title: U.N. Diplomat Seeks Miracle: Bring Together Rich and Poor
description: The big man in pinstripes walks into the convention center here and the diplomats take notice. The Japanese delegation asks for a few minutes of his time. South African officials whisper in his ear. In their offices nearby, senior American officials praise his leadership.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: President Visits Rebel Area
description: President Eduard A. Shevardnadze visited the Pankisi Gorge, a lawless region said to be home to dozens of Islamic militants and rebels fighting for independence in the Russian republic of Chechnya. His visit came as hundreds of Georgian police and interior troops set up checkpoints in the region in an effort to establish order, as Russia has long demanded. He also attended a memorial service for an elderly Georgian killed in an airstrike on Friday that Georgian officials said was carried out by Russia. The troops in Pankisi have yet to arrest any armed fighters, who appear to have fled in advance of the operation. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Abraham Expected To Play In Opener
description: The third-down defense, one of the few causes of concern for the Jets in an otherwise feel-good preseason, was given a boost today when Coach Herman Edwards said that John Abraham, the Pro Bowl defensive end, was expected to be ready for the season opener Sept. 8 at Buffalo.

title: Military Escorts Plane After Mix-Up
description: Two military fighter planes escorted a US Airways jetliner to Baltimore-Washington International Airport this morning after a miscommunication from the pilot led the authorities to suspect a security threat.

title: Agreement Is Reached On Steroid Testing
description: With players poised to strike after tomorrow night's games, negotiators in baseball's labor dispute reached agreement on a steroid-testing program yesterday, the first time the union agreed to any kind of random, unannounced testing for major league players.

title: PURCHASE OF JEFFERSON SMURFIT APPROACHES COMPLETION
description: The acquisition of the Jefferson Smurfit Group, an Irish box and paper manufacturer, by Madison Dearborn Partners of Chicago neared its final stages yesterday when the Irish High Court approved a motion to spin off Smurfit's holding in an American subsidiary to shareholders. Under the terms of the deal, shareholders will receive 2.15 euros in cash per Jefferson Smurfit share, as well as one share in the subsidiary, Smurfit Stone Container, for every 16 Jefferson Smurfit shares they hold. Madison Dearborn said it would declare its 3.8 billion euro ($3.7 billion) bid unconditional next Tuesday. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Study in Stamina and Pain: Safin Outlasts Kiefer
description: Under a thin veil of humidity, Nicolas Kiefer and Marat Safin were all but playing in front of a two-way mirror on the pit floor of Arthur Ashe Stadium yesterday, just contorted subjects in a study on mental stamina and pain thresholds.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: $1 MILLION SETTLEMENT IN SLAYING The mother of Chad MacDonald, 17, who was beaten and killed by drug dealers in 1998 after working as a police informer in Orange County, will receive a $1 million legal settlement. City officials in Brea agreed on Monday to the settlement, the largest by a police department in Orange County history, about a month after a state appeals court reinstated a lawsuit by the family. The killing led to a law limiting the use of teenage informers.

title: Newark Deal With Port Agency May Have More Benefits
description: The deal that might finally free Newark and the New Jersey Nets and Devils from their two-year struggle for state help in building a new arena here may also resolve some nagging problems for several other parties.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: RCN To Sell Princeton Cable Systems
description: The RCN Corporation, the cable television, phone and Internet provider backed by Paul G. Allen, said it would sell its cable systems in Princeton, N.J., for $245 million. Spectrum Equity Investors, a private equity firm in Boston, and the cable entrepreneur Steve Simmons will buy the systems, which have about 80,000 subscribers, RCN executives said. Mr. Simmons said he would spend about $44 million to upgrade the networks to offer digital cable and high-speed Internet access. David C. McCourt, the chief executive of RCN, said, ''Because the RCN business plan was founded on building our own network in major metropolitan markets and bundling phone, high-speed Internet and cable TV, central New Jersey's systems -- which were built years ago by others -- were not a core part of our strategy.'' Shares of RCN, which is based in Princeton, rose 12 cents, or 14 percent, to 97 cents; they have fallen more than 60 percent this year.

title: U.S. Charges 3 With Forcing Women to Work in Strip Clubs
description: Three Brooklyn residents were arrested today after a federal indictment accused them of bringing at least a dozen Russian women into the country and forcing them to dance in New Jersey strip clubs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Consumer Confidence Down
description: Dutch consumer confidence reached a record low in August as consumers grew more reluctant to make major purchases, the government statistics bureau said. The August consumer confidence index, adjusted for seasonal swings, fell to minus 29 from minus 27 in July.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Cheese Spread

title: Windmills On Their Minds; Battle Lines Drawn Over a Source of Power That Some Say Obstructs a Gorgeous View
description: A small but vocal band of preservationists is tilting at windmills here in this town of 1,270.

title: Wanted: University President/Religious Leader
description: When Yeshiva University's trustees voted in May to keep Norman Lamm on as president for another year, there was only one negative vote: Dr. Lamm's own.

title: Loving the Trumpet, but Beating a Union Drum
description: BILL MORIARITY was never ambitious. All he ever wanted, he says, was to play trumpet; if he had a job he was inclined to stay there until it ended.

title: Cart Collisions? Not When He's Directing Traffic
description: Can a supermarket checkout line be fun? At the Whole Foods market in Chelsea, waiting borders on entertainment.

title: Shop Till Eggs, Diapers, Toothpaste Drop
description: It looks like a 7-Eleven in a box.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Compensation Sought For Slave Labor
description: Ten Chinese men have filed a lawsuit in Tokyo demanding compensation for being held as slave laborers during World War II. The men, who are each seeking $167,000, sued the government and four Japanese companies, including the Sumitomo Coal Mining Company and Mitsubishi Materials. They said they were beaten and forced to work long hours at coal mines on Hokkaido between 1943 and 1944. The actions come after a landmark ruling in April awarded $1.39 million to 15 other Chinese men in a similar suit. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, PAULINE
description: TUCKER-Pauline. On August 27, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Tucker, loving mother of Karen Lefrak and Lynn Weiss. Cherished grandmother of Harrison, James, Eric, Jonathan and Jennifer. Services Wednesday, 10 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBSYS, REV. MSGR. ANTHONY
description: RUBSYS-Rev. Msgr. Anthony, entered eternal rest on August 27, 2002. 79 years. Professor Emeritus of Religious Studies at Manhattan College. Beloved brother of Matas and Stasys Rubsys and Apolonija Jacikeviliene, Terese Uksiene and Emilija Kucinskiene, all of Lithuania. Visitors may call on Thursday from 2-5 & 7-9pm at the Christian Brothers Center of Manhattan College, 4415 Post Rd, Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the chapel of the Christian Brothers Center, Friday, August 30, 2002 at 10am. Interment will take place in Lithuania.

description: WEST

title: Study and Help in Traumatic Loss
description: Researchers at Pace University, Teachers College of Columbia University and the State University of New York at Stony Brook are beginning to study ''sudden traumatic loss treatment'' by offering psychotherapy sessions to some of those who lost loved ones on Sept. 11. The study is financed by a $200,000 grant from the J. P. Morgan Chase Foundation. The treatment, which was developed for family and friends of car crash victims, differs from more traditional grief counseling, in part by aiming to teach survivors how to manage and control their feelings. Dr. Camille Wortman, a professor of psychology at SUNY-Stony Brook and one of the trauma specialists putting the program together, says that people who have lost loved ones in traumatic circumstances often suffer feelings of abandonment, betrayal or guilt. Research shows that surviviors can develop post-traumatic stress disorder, depression and physical problems.

title: S.E.C. Approves New Nasdaq Automated-Trading System
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  A costly lobbying and regulatory battle over the future of the nation's second-largest stock exchange drew to a close today, when the Securities and Exchange Commission approved Nasdaq's use of a new automated-trading system over the heated objections of its rivals.

title: Mets' Gonzalez Is in a Hurry to Stick
description: MIAMI, Aug. 27  Raul Gonzalez, the Mets' new outfielder, is unabashedly in the front row of those hoping that the major league players will not go on strike Friday.

title: Rumsfeld Says Allies Will Support U.S. on Iraq
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that America's allies would support the United States if President Bush decides to attack Iraq, saying ''leadership in the right direction finds followers and supporters.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHER, NORMAN, M.D.
description: SHER-Norman, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center was saddened to learn of the death of Dr. Norman Sher. Dr. Sher was a Psychiatrist associated with Maimonides Medical Center for over 35 years. He was Director of the Psychiatric Residency Training Program from 1974 through 1981. He served as President of the Medical Staff from 1978 through 1979 and remained involved in hospital affairs for many years after. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. S. Farber, M.D., Pres. H. Lehman, M.D., Pres. Elect. I. Mayer, M.D., Secy. W. Wexelman, M.D., Treas.

It is at times of loss that we are reminded of the ongoing ties of family love spanning generations. Lenore Simonoff and family

title: National Briefing | Washington: Tally For Charity
description: The country's 1,400 United Way organizations raised an estimated total of $5 billion last year, an increase of 6.8 percent over the amount collected in 2000, the United Way of America said. Without the $501 million of contributions to the Sept. 11 Fund, which is jointly administered by the United Way of New York and the New York Community Trust, however, the total was $4.5 billion, a 4.2 percent decline over the previous year. Adjusted for inflation, giving to the annual workplace campaign fell 1.8 percent to $3.95 billion, or somewhat less than the 2.3 percent decline in philanthropic giving over all. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, JESSICA
description: WINTER-Jessica. 81, passed away on Sunday, August 25, 2002, following a short illness. Beloved wife and best friend of Martin E. Winter. Devoted aunt of Marvin and Diane Bernstein, Philip and Beverly Sklover, William and Sharon Friedheim, William and Oda Friedheim, Drs. Lee and Margarita Winter and Randy Winter. Great-aunt of David and Susan Bernstein, Alanna, Samuel and Joseph Sklover, Lisa Blaudoin and Gregory Friedheim. Sister-in-law of Joan and Eugene Winter and Anne Friedheim. Loving godmother to David and Jennifer Kouvant. Lifelong friend of Vivian Kouvant, Sylvia and Austin Fried and Regina Gelford. She had a long and distinguished career on Wall Street and recently retired after 20 years from the firm Ehrenkrantz, King and Nussbaum. Funeral services Wednesday, August 28, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 81st. St. and Madison Ave. Donations in honor of Jessica may be made to Variety-The Children's Charity.

title: Mets Ease Pressure With 3rd Victory
description: Bobby Valentine noticed the players' smiles and heard the celebratory music. Winning tonight, for the third game in a row, made the Mets' clubhouse come alive again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, GERALD H.
description: KELLER-Gerald H. Died August 27 after a courageous battle with cancer. A devoted and caring husband of 48 years to Barbara, an understanding and supportive father to Judy and Robert, and a proud and loving grandfather to Samantha, Katie and Kendall. His strong presense and adventuresome spirit will be missed. The consummate adman. Services Friday, August 30, 11 AM at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

title: Philippoussis Is Out After Knee Gives Way
description: Mark Philippoussis was trembling courtside, worried again about his left knee, worried again about running out of time to explore the limits of his considerable talent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: China Air Stake
description: The Hong Kong arm of China's biggest investment company, Citic Pacific Ltd., plans to buy at least 25 percent of Air China as part of a plan to expand in the mainland, the managing director, Henry Fan, said. The company obtained a loan of 2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($256 million) to help finance the purchase, Mr. Fan said.

title: Voting Board Finds Fraud, But Rejects Complaint
description: After hearing reports of widespread irregularities in registering new voters to the Independence Party, the New York City Board of Elections took no action yesterday on complaints lodged by Tom Golisano, who is seeking the party's nomination for governor.

title: NATIONAL GYPSUM CREATES NEW FUND FOR ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: The National Gypsum Company has agreed to create a $347 million fund for potential injury claims by people exposed to asbestos in the company's building-materials products. National Gypsum, revamped in a 1993 bankruptcy proceeding and now a unit of the closely held Delcor, previously formed a $400 million trust for claims by those who contracted lung cancer and other diseases from asbestos. The new fund would cover people who did not have claims against National Gypsum as of 1993 because they were not ill. The plan is subject to the approval of claimants and a federal bankruptcy judge. In addition to the $347 million, the new National Gypsum fund will include $100 million left from the 1993 trust and $75 million in insurance. Until the 1970's, National Gypsum, based in Charlotte, N.C., made joint treatment compounds and plaster products that contained asbestos.

title: New York's Olympic Bid
description: Starting from somewhere deep in the back of the pack, New York City has made the cut to stay in the race to be host to the 2012 Summer Olympic Games. The United States Olympic Committee announced yesterday that it had eliminated Houston and Washington from the competition. New York will now vie with San Francisco to become the American entry in the international competition to hold the Games.

description: There are women whose last names are too famous to change when they marry, and others whose husbands have names too famous not to take.

description: New York and San Francisco advanced yesterday in their quests to play host to the 2012 Summer Olympics, winning selection as the United States' finalists in an international competition that will end in three years.

title: Study Finds Big Increase in Black Men as Inmates Since 1980
description: The number of black men in jail or prison has grown fivefold in the past 20 years, to the point where more black men are behind bars than are enrolled in colleges or universities, according to a study released yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Flirting Lawmakers
description: After a complaint from a reporter, state legislative leaders have issued a memorandum warning lawmakers against making ''flirtatious overtures'' toward reporters. The reporter, who was not named, complained about unidentified legislators' being ''too flirty'' or ''too clingy'' with female reporters and asking them out. Speaker Daniel W. McGee said the memorandum was a ''heads-up to all legislators to be careful and remember that they are in the public's eye, and must conduct themselves accordingly.''

title: John S. Wilson, Jazz Critic, Is Dead at 89
description: John S. Wilson, the first critic to write regularly about jazz and popular music in The New York Times, died yesterday at a nursing home in Princeton, N.J. He was 89 and lived in Princeton.

title: An American Abdication
description: At present there is much talk about the unparalleled strength of the United States on the world stage. Yet at this very moment the most powerful country in the world stands to forfeit much political capital, moral authority and international good will by dragging its feet on the next great global issue: the environment. Before long, the administration's apparent unwillingness to take a leadership role -- or, at the very least, to stop acting as a brake -- in fighting global environmental degradation will threaten the very basis of the American supremacy that many now seem to assume will last forever.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: TURKMENISTAN: MILITARY AID FROM U.S. The United States plans to expand military cooperation with Turkmenistan, the commander of American forces in the region, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, said. General Franks, left, who is traveling through the region, met with the Central Asian country's autocratic president, Saparmarud Niyazov, and discussed aid to Afghanistan and efforts to combat terrorism, according to a statement by the American Embassy in the capital, Ashgabad. General Franks said the expanded cooperation could include training and equipment for Turkmenistan's military, border troops and police forces. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEWDELL, FLORENCE
description: YEWDELL - Florence. Be loved wife of the late Carlton. Loving mother of Suellen and Thomas. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie and Michael. Service today 11A.M. at the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Man Missing Since 9/11 Alive
description: A sidewalk vendor from Newark who was listed as one of those missing after Sept. 11 has been found alive but suffering from amnesia in a Manhattan hospital. Page B1.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Plainview: Workers Paid In Union Dispute
description: The Marriott Corporation has agreed to pay $37,500 to five immigrants from El Salvador who asserted that a manager at a Residence Inn, a Marriott hotel, had fired them illegally because they wanted to organize a union. The National Labor Relations Board helped arrange the settlement after it filed a complaint charging that the hotel's manager had called the workers into his office on Oct. 1 and dismissed them. Under the settlement, Marriott must post large notices telling the hotel's employees that they have the right to form a union without fear of reprisal. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, JEANNE B.
description: MARSHALL-Jeanne B. On August 26, 2002. Age 77. Retired kindergarten teacher at P.S. 17 in Queens. Wife of the late Jack Zaretsky and the late Joseph Marshall. Survived by two sons, Jon and his wife Estelle, and Tom and his wife Kathy Keneally, two grandchildren, Michael, and Scott and his wife Randi. Memorial service at Riverside Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave, today, 1PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to P.S. 17 School Fund, 28-37 29 St., Long Island City, N.Y. 11102.

title: Getting a grip
description: John Vander Wal hollered across the clubhouse to Chris Widger last Thursday, asking if he had any "racquet grip" for him. Sorry, Widger replied. He had picked some up at a sporting goods store but had left it at home.

title: To Regulate Prostitution, Iran Ponders Brothels
description: She identifies herself as Susan. At 26 she is slender and graceful, and her long hair is pulled back, giving her face with its hazel eyes and round cheeks an air of innocence. She does not at all look like a prostitute.

title: Windows XP Update Is Set As a Part Of U.S. Deal
description: In an effort to comply with the terms of an antitrust consent decree agreement with the Justice Department, Microsoft said today that it planned to distribute its first major update to the Windows XP operating system some time in the next 10 days.

title: Hewlett Meets Expectations In First Post-Merger Results
description: Reporting its first quarterly results that included Compaq Computer, Hewlett-Packard matched Wall Street's earnings estimates yesterday but fell a bit short on revenues. The financial report also provided plenty of fuel for both sides in the continuing debate over whether the merger was a good idea.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Connecticut; New England Icons Are Serving a Hidden Purpose
description: Hidden in plain sight in suburban towns throughout Connecticut, cellular phone antennas have been engineered into the good graces of once-hostile communities. Eager to avoid lengthy battles over the installation of unattractive towers, telecommunications companies prefer to hide antennas within or on existing structures, using what are known in the industry as ''stealthing'' techniques.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading yesterday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's attendance at the United States Open tennis tournament misidentified the Queens neighborhood where it is being held. The stadium is in Flushing Meadows, not Forest Hills.

title: Music Rivalry And Revelry Both Serving Irish Culture
description: Decades before traditional Irish music became a record-industry staple and reached international audiences, this country's musicians earned their stripes in rigorous recital competitions. Championships begin in the 32 Irish counties in the spring and are followed by contests in the four Irish provinces. In August a weekend of spirited competition and celebration takes over a small rural town, usually changing every two years. Known by its Irish name, Fleadh Cheoil na hEireann, the event is a euphoric toast to the healthy state of Irish music and, more important, an excuse for an astonishing party.

description: TALLY FOR CHARITY

title: New Yorker to Join Field Expedition
description: STEPHEN PESICK, a science teacher at Westlake Middle School in Thornwood, N.Y., will be one of eight teachers from around the country to lead an expedition this winter on the Channel Islands off California. As part of the Jason Project, a program that sends teachers and students into the field for hands-on science experiences, 25 students and more than a dozen scientists will spend two weeks studying and reporting on the region's elephant seals, sea lions and fragile kelp forest. Started in 1989 by ROBERT BALLARD, who discovered the wreckage of the Titanic, the Jason Project involves travel to an exotic location each year and broadcasts live via satellite and the Internet to millions of students worldwide. Mr. Pesick's students will be able to talk with the explorers through a satellite link. Julie Flaherty

title: Cuckoo in Carolina
description: The ruckus being raised by conservative Christians over the University of North Carolina's decision to ask incoming students to read a book about the Koran -- to stimulate a campus debate -- surely has to be one of the most embarrassing moments for America since Sept. 11.

title: Disease Control Center Bolsters Terror Response
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday that it has taken steps over the last year to prepare better for a bioterrorist attack.

description: WITT-Marcia H. 66, on August 27. Predeceased by her loving son David. Beloved wife of Bob, loving mother of Beth and Billie and son-in-law John, step-children Debbie, Richie and Russell, cherished grandmother of Ana, Aviv, Ashley, Tori, Keri and Ryan. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Service Thursday, 10am, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt 4 East, Paramus, NJ

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Deficit Falls
description: Brazil's current account deficit shrank to $550 million in July from $2.04 billion a year ago, the central bank said. The bank lowered its forecast for this year's current account deficit, which measures a country's foreign transactions and is widely used as a barometer of the economy's vulnerability, to $17.03 billion from $19.6 billion. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank Sells Shares
description: The Bank of China's Hong Kong unit said that it had sold $169 million in additional stock beyond the $2.5 billion it raised last month in its initial public offering. The extra stock sales left the Bank of China still owning 63.74 percent of the unit. BOC Hong Kong (Holdings) also said that its net profit declined 19 percent in the first half of this year, even though it reduced the amount of money it was setting aside for bad loans. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: States' Rights Fig Leaf
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer Profit Down
description: The Swiss industrial engineering group Sulzer said its first-half profit fell to $20.7 million, not counting one-time gains. The company, which has revamped, cut its forecast for sales and operating income in 2002 because of flat demand in crucial areas. Sulzer said its four core divisions were not expected to match last year's operating income of just under $79 million. The company now concentrates on turbo machinery, pumps, chemical processing and surface coatings. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELPHI CORP., Troy, Mich., the world's largest maker of auto parts, said it had won contracts from General Motors, Detroit, to provide components, including steering systems and satellite radios, for the 2003 models of Chevrolet's Cavalier, Silverado and Suburban. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Congressional Memo; Departing Lawmakers Cost Congress Some of Its Dazzle
description: No one knows which party will control the House or Senate after the November elections, but one result is in: already out are some of the more outrageous, outspoken and polarizing characters of Congress.

title: Losing Weighs on Piazza
description: Icould see Mike Piazza had been morose for much of last week, so when he and I happened to be exiting the field after batting practice before a game in San Francisco last week, I offered some helpful information. "Did you know there's an In-and-Out Burger in Fisherman's Wharf," I said, referring to the popular hamburger joint from Southern California whose T-shirts Piazza often wears in the clubhouse.

title: Ebbers Got Million Shares In Hot Deals
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chairman of WorldCom, received almost one million shares of stock in hot initial public offerings from Salomon Smith Barney over four years, according to documents released by a Congressional committee investigating the collapse of WorldCom.

title: Hewitt Still Annoyed With Tour
description: Three weeks after Lleyton Hewitt was fined by the ATP for refusing a required interview with the host broadcaster ESPN at the Cincinnati Masters Series, he was still irritated last night at how tour officials handled the episode, and he plans to bring that up during an appeals process.

title: Smoke and Spice: Peruvian Classics in the East Village
description: THERE was smoke in the air last week, thick, and that was all right. It was at Lima's Taste, which opened about four months ago on a quiet block in the East Village, serving slightly upscale versions of Peruvian classics: ceviche, papas rellenas, barbecued chicken, grilled steak. The vent fans in the kitchen, above the stove, couldn't keep up with the cooks.

title: Forecast for a Warmer World: Deluge and Drought
description: It has been a summer of extremes. Rains have deluged Europe and Asia, swamping cities and villages and killing some 2,000 people, while drought and heat have seared the American West and Eastern cities. What is going on?

title: Harvard Law School Bows to U.S. And Allows Military Recruiters
description: Harvard Law School will allow military recruiters back on its campus, bowing to pressure from the Department of Defense rather than risk losing $328 million of Harvard University's federal financing.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Food Stuff column last Wednesday about a farm stand outside the City Hall restaurant, at 131 Duane Street in TriBeCa, misspelled the surname of the owner of the farm that supplies the produce. He is Wilfred Heilbut, not Heilbert.

description: FIVE days a week and often on weekends, Robert Rosenthal cooks breakfast and dinner for his wife and two daughters. His wife, Carolyn Kremins, doesn't cook at all.

description: Enron shareholders announced yesterday that they had reached a tentative $40 million settlement with Andersen Worldwide, the umbrella group for overseas accounting firms affiliated with Arthur Andersen.

title: Is climate change aiding spread of disease?
description: PARIS  As floods rage in Central Europe and China and as drought plagues Africa and North America, it is getting harder to dismiss the scientists who claim that weather is becoming not only warmer but more extreme. Both of those trends, each in its own way, has ominous implications for the spread of infectious disease.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Lindt Sales Up
description: The Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Sprungli said its first-half sales rose 2.7 percent, to $423 million, but it posted a loss in the period because more than half of its annual sales typically occur during the year-end holiday season. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Long After 9/11, a Missing Man Turns Up in a Manhattan Hospital
description: Weeks, even months, after the World Trade Center attack, many families kept hoping that their loved ones had made it out alive. Perhaps, the thinking went, they had somehow escaped the buildings and made it to a hospital, but were so badly hurt that they could not communicate, or had amnesia.

title: Panel Rejects Effort to Add A Steel Tariff
description: A federal trade panel today rejected pleas by the steel industry to impose new tariffs on imports of cold-rolled steel, a move that brought sighs of relief around the world but angered many ailing American producers.

description: REMEMBER the waiflike Giulietta Masina, who played the long-suffering little assistant to Anthony Quinn's strongman in ''La Strada,'' by Fellini? He was blustery, powerful, impossible to ignore. She was intense, endearing, impossible to forget; like good Italian white wines. Quinn was like the reds, of course.

title: Foreign birds flourish as city faces crisis : Tokyoites feel the heat
description: TOKYO  Palm trees native to subtropical southern China are springing up in parts of Tokyo while flocks of parakeets native to southern India and Sri Lanka are flying over the city.

title: A Well-Chosen Plum Makes A Daisy Of a Tart
description: FOR most of the year, plums are like apples. They sit, shiny as plastic and just as hard, in neat rows on supermarket shelves, imported from distant regions with warm climates.
