His visit came as hundreds of Georgian police and interior troops set up checkpoints in the region in an effort to establish order, as Russia has long demanded. He also attended a memorial service for an elderly Georgian killed in an airstrike on Friday that Georgian officials said was carried out by Russia. The troops in Pankisi have yet to arrest any armed fighters, who appear to have fled in advance of the operation.

title: Carrara Journal; Come Back, Michelangelo, the Marble Needs You
description: There is so much marble in the mountains above this city in northern Tuscany that local sculptors whimsically fashioned a full-sized 1950's Cadillac from the gleaming white stone. The ersatz sedan sits idle in a workshop here that looks like a two-door garage, as if ready and waiting to be taken for a spin.

title: Budget Office Forecasts Shift From Surplus To Big Deficits
description: The Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the federal government would run big budget deficits through 2005, and those estimates do not include the impact of President Bush's proposals for higher military spending and his ideas for additional tax cuts.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: GEMSTAR SHARES DROP AFTER WARNING Shares of Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. fell as much as 11 percent yesterday after the maker of software to run on-screen television program guides said the Nasdaq Stock Market might delist its shares. Shares fell 57 cents, or 12.8 percent, to $3.91. The shares had fallen 84 percent this year through yesterday. Gemstar said yesterday that it might be delisted after failing to file its quarterly report, or 10-Q, for the second quarter with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, based in Pasadena, Calif., has requested a hearing on the proposed delisting. Two weeks ago, Gemstar said it would delay filing the 10-Q while the audit committee of its board reviewed the company's accounting. Gemstar in April disclosed that it had recorded more than $100 million in revenue for licensing fees it expected to collect from Scientific-Atlanta Inc., the maker of television set-top boxes that Gemstar had accused of patent infringement. (Bloomberg News)

title: After Showing Some Skin, Haas Shows His Mettle
description: Tommy Haas simply took the dare to bare. If Anna Kournikova could expose her tan hipbones in a low-ride skirt, if Serena Williams could pack her dangerous curves in a Lycra cat suit, Haas saw no reason he could not follow the skin-is-in trend at the United States Open by showing a little . . . biceps.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of the World Trade Center dead or missing issued by the New York City medical examiner and published in late editions on Aug. 20 misspelled a victim's given name. He was Michael McCabe, not Micheal. It also gave erroneous middle initials for a victim. He was Stephen J. Fiorelli Sr., not S. R. And it omitted the names of two victims who died of injuries later. They were Randy Drake, who died on Sept. 22, and David Bernard, who died on Dec. 11.

title: Scientists say people have significantly altered atmosphere : The search to soften man's impact
description: NEW YORK  Nearly 70 years ago, a Soviet geochemist, reflecting on his world, made a startling observation: Through technology and sheer numbers, he wrote, people were becoming a geological force, shaping the planet's future just as rivers and earthquakes had shaped its past.

title: A Suburban Seattle Project, Begun in the Dot-Com Boom, Stalls Out
description: The complementary towers intended to dominate this city's skyline are little more than a partly completed office building core and a six-story hotel superstructure. They stand on a slab of concrete spread over two city blocks meant to undergird retail stores set atop a five-story subterranean parking garage. And for now the construction work on Lincoln Square, this $350 million project, is done.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYNER, GABY A.
description: DYNER-Gaby A. On August 26, 2002. Beloved wife of the late George. Devoted mother of the late Elizabeth Pilzer and mother-in-law of Herbert R. Pilzer. Formidable grandmother of Lynn Sobel and her husband Eric and Neal Pilzer and his wife Anita. Wonderful great grandmother of Anna and Peter Sobel and Lauren and Julia Pilzer. Graveside service Friday 12:00 pm Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.

title: World Banker Assails Indonesia's Corruption
description: In unusually blunt remarks, the World Bank's chief representative in Indonesia said in a farewell speech here today that corruption was probably the country's most serious economic problem and that he did not expect much improvement in the problem any time soon.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Shipping Charge Extended
description: The Neptune Orient Lines, Nippon Yusen of Japan and other shipping lines are extending a peak season surcharge for carrying cargo to the United States from Asia by a month because demand is higher than they had expected. The 14 shipping companies in the Transpacific Stabilization Agreement, which represents about 90 percent of trade on those routes, will extend a surcharge of $300 per 40-foot container until the end of October, the group said.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Aug. 20, about sluggishness in the newspaper market, misstated the affiliation of John Morton, an industry analyst who commented. He is the president of Morton Research Inc. Although he works with Miles Groves, chief economist of the Barry Group, to produce a monthly analysis of the industry, he is not a partner in the group, a consulting company based in Bethesda, Md.

description: OKLAHOMA: LARGENT WINS PRIMARY

title: Tim Hortons, Up From Doughnuts
description: At 8:15 one recent Friday morning, the Starbucks on Yonge Street in midtown Toronto was almost deserted, with just a handful of customers in armchairs nursing grande lattes and reading the morning papers. Yet next door at Tim Hortons, patrons in straight-backed chairs sat with their coffees, iced cappuccinos and pastries, which were selling as fast as servers behind three cash registers and a sandwich bar could process the orders.

title: Chinese AIDS Activist Disappears
description: BEIJING, Aug. 28  China's most prominent AIDS activist has disappeared, apparently detained by China's security services, human rights groups and relatives said.

title: West Nile Cut Short The Love Of a Lifetime
description: They were two lives lived virtually as one, from a wedding day 56 years ago in Italy to the day Joseph Chiella died this month after falling ill with a mysterious sickness.

title: Planned Bill Would Spur U.S. Sale of Diesel Cars
description: Representative John D. Dingell plans to introduce a bill that would encourage the sale of diesel cars in the United States, a prospect strongly supported by the auto industry but opposed by environmental groups.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Union Carbide Case In Court
description: Two former employees of Union Carbide told a court that safety equipment that should have prevented a lethal leak at the company's Bhopal factory in 1984 was not working, and that tanks storing gas at the factory were filled above capacity. India's Central Bureau of Investigation is in court trying to have the charge in the case reduced to a ''rash and negligent act'' from ''culpable homicide,'' a move opposed by victims' groups who say it would allow the former chairman of Union Carbide, Warren Anderson, to avoid extradition to India. The leak killed at least 3,000 people. Amy Waldman (NYT)

description: MONTANA: FLIRTING LAWMAKERS

title: For a Man and a Long-Lost Peach, A Happy Ending (and It's Dessert)
description: As a boy in Bari, in the heel of Italy, Joe Doria ate peaches that he recalls as being special. ''They were called Percoca peaches and they were very, very juicy,'' said Mr. Doria, who is an owner of Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street).

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans to build housing, stores and offices on part of the Civil War battlefield in Chancellorsville, Va., referred incorrectly to Stephen Crane, whose novel ''The Red Badge of Courage'' depicts the fighting there. He did not witness the war; he was born in 1871, six years after it ended.

title: Baseball Commissioner And Consensus Builder
description: The acting commissioner was seething. Taking a break from a baseball owners meeting that had taken an unexpected turn, Bud Selig walked down the hotel corridor gesturing as if he had a machine gun and was mowing down everything in sight.

description: MILITANT ISLAM REACHES AMERICA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, ALEXANDER
description: ABRAHAM-Alexander. 83, on August 25, 2002, at his home in Rye, NY. Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Harvard College 1940, former president of Abraham & Co. Inc., former vice chairman of Lehman Brothers Inc., ex-president of the 92nd St. YMHA, archeologist, philanthropist, and loving husband and father. Mr. Abraham is survived by his children Nancy and James, his grandchildren Lauren, Antonia and Karen, his daughter-in-law Andrea, and his son-in-law Arnold Moss. A memorial service is being planned. His children and his grandchildren ask that Mr. Abraham's many friends remember him for his integrity, his generosity, his intelligence and his kindness. Contributions in his memory may be made to the 92nd St. Y, the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, MA, and the Enterprise Foundation in New York City, NY.

title: For Rosh Hashana, Untraditional Takeout
description: These dishes are not exactly out of grandma's kitchen: chicken livers zapped with jalapeo and served on a cactus paddle, chicken soup and matzo balls seasoned with cilantro (both above), salsa verde with salmon gefilte fish, brisket of beef glazed with smoky chipotle chilies (right) and prickly pear honey cake. Judy Schiff and Stephen Hoerz of Ready to Eat, a takeout place at 525 Hudson Street (West 10th Street), decided to tweak tradition. So they added Southwestern options to their regular menu for Rosh Hashana, which begins on the evening of Sept. 6. Dishes are $3.50 to $12.95 a serving either way. A complete meal is $26.95 a person with roast turkey breast with mole or gravy, $27.95 with brisket. Orders must be placed by Tuesday and picked up on Sept. 5 or 6; info@readytoeat.net or (212) 229-1013. Delivery is available.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENKRANTZ, MINNIE
description: BLUMENKRANTZ - Minnie. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Minnie Blumenkrantz. Beloved mother of Robert Blumenkrantz. We extend our deepest condolences to Robert and family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mobile Phone Sales Rebound Slightly
description: Sales of mobile phones, which had faltered recently, are rising again, according to a report released yesterday by the Gartner Group. The market research firm said mobile phone sales rose 0.8 percent in the second quarter, halting a 15-month slide, as manufacturers released new models and demand increased in Asia and Eastern Europe. Gartner analysts said the mobile telephone industry, which had global quarterly sales of 98.7 million units, now showed signs that it had stabilized and ''is positioned for stronger growth.'' Nokia retains its position as the world's largest maker of mobile telephone handsets, claiming a 35.6 percent market share. In the corresponding period last year, the Finnish giant had a 34.2 percent share of the market. Gartner analysts expect demand to stay high as 3-G data services become more broadly available and consumers replace older phones with models that have color screens and built-in cameras. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: U.S. Defends Action In Terror Case
description: Lawyers for the federal government filed papers last night defending the Bush administration's decision to place Jose Padilla, a former Chicago gang member accused of being an agent of the Al Queda terrorist group, in military custody. In a filing before Judge Michael B. Mukasey of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, prosecutors argued that Mr. Padilla, who is being held in a South Carolina Navy brig, is under the military jurisdiction ''by the established practice of the United States in times of war.'' Mr. Padilla, also known as Abdullah al-Muhajir, is accused of plotting to explode a radioactive dirty bomb in the United States. His lawyer, Andrew Patel, declined to comment last night, saying that he had not had time to digest the government petition, which was released shortly before 10 p.m. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Democrats in a Face-Off Before Facing Jeb Bush
description: It was almost too polite to qualify as a political debate, but the Democratic Party candidates seeking to take on Jeb Bush in the Florida race for governor took center stage this evening to lay out their views on a variety of campaign issues, including the environment and elder care.

title: Dreaming of Stadiums and Souvenirs
description: Daniel L. Doctoroff's eight-year quest to bring the Olympics to New York went from quixotic to quite possible yesterday.

title: Resilient Rubin Is Still Showing A Lot of Fight
description: Chanda Rubin stepped onto the Grandstand court yesterday without braces or bandages, only small scars on her left knee and right hand. But Rubin does not see them as reminders of untimely roadblocks in a career that could have been.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 13 about a lawsuit brought by several residents of East Windsor, N.J., against their homeowners association over a ban on political campaign signs on lawns and other matters, included the court papers' erroneous reference to the basis for the ban. It arose from a 1984 settlement of a lawsuit concerning real estate signs -- not a 1999 board resolution regulating signs, which applied only to common areas.

title: A Win for Open Trials
description: Declaring that ''democracies die behind closed doors,'' a federal appeals court in Cincinnati ruled on Monday that the government cannot hold secret deportation hearings for people suspected of ties to terrorism. The decision is the most powerful rebuke yet to the Bush administration's policy of flouting the Bill of Rights in the name of national security.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Sciences Plans To Cut 450 Jobs
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the third-largest United States computer services company, said this week that it would cut about 450 jobs in its group that manages computers for banks and insurers as demand in those industries slows. The move will reduce the staff of the division, based in Austin, Tex., by about 10 percent, a spokesman, Mike Dickerson, said. The company, whose customers include J. P. Morgan Chase, began cutting jobs June 1 and will finish Sept. 6, he said. The company cut 2,000 jobs last year to save money and recently asked its 66,000 workers to volunteer to take six months of leave with 20 percent of their pay.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Loading up on school supplies can cost a fortune  and leave parents with precious little cash for their back-to-school celebrations. Luckily, store shelves are full of interesting, reasonably priced wines to wrap up summer and welcome fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, LEAH
description: WEINBERG-Leah. On August 26, 2002. Beloved wife of Erwin. Loving mother of Sharon and Lauren. Dearest daughter of Florence Bluestein and dear sister of Carl Bluestein. Over 30 years of loving service, to the children that she taught and schools that she administered and a very active member of the Forest Hills Jewish Center for many years. Funeral service today, 10AM, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the Democratic primary defeat of Representative Cynthia A. McKinney of Georgia and its aftermath included a name incorrectly among those of black politicians distancing themselves from her. Julian Bond, chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., points out that as head of a nonpartisan organization he does not participate in electoral politics.

title: While Praising McCall, Hevesi Intensifies Efforts in Race for State Comptroller
description: Alan G. Hevesi stood before the congregation at the Unity Fellowship Church of Christ in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn last Sunday and spoke as much about the man he supports for governor as he did about his own race for New York State comptroller.

title: Capriati Rips Richard Williams
description: Jennifer Capriati spiced up the aftermath of her 6-0, 6-0 romp through her first-round match against the qualifier Bethanie Mattek by using her news conference to air a few opinions about Richard Williams, the father of Venus and Serena Williams.

title: Senate Report on Pre-9/11 Failures Tells of Bungling at F.B.I.
description: A new Senate report on intelligence failures before Sept. 11 has concluded that ignorance and ineptitude of F.B.I. supervisors and lawyers in Washington blocked field agents around the country from pursuing evidence that might have helped provide the bureau with what one of the authors of the report called a ''veritable blueprint for 9/11.''

title: A Kitchen Maverick Rethinks Soup
description: JUDY RODGERS often questions conventional practice. Even when she is making onion soup.

title: Sony to Offer PlayStation Games Online
description: The battle for dominance in the multibillion-dollar video game industry flared yesterday as Sony Computer Entertainment America announced that its PlayStation 2 game console, the market leader, can now play selected games over the Internet. Sony also kept an earlier promise that it would not charge a fee to play its popular games online.

title: German Prosecutors Charge 9/11 Suspect
description: German prosecutors today charged a Moroccan man with supporting members of the Hamburg cell of Al Qaeda suspected of planning and carrying out the Sept. 11 terror attacks on the United States.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Marc Blanchard was named an interactive director and creative director at Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners, New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas. He had been president and chief technology officer at Zendo Studios, San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERENS, MARY
description: BERENS-Mary. On August 27, 2002. She would have said she was 59. Beloved wife of Abe for 64 years, treasured mother of Sandy and Marcia; Susan and Alan; Bob and Arlene. Grandmother of Andy and Frances; Lisa and Andrew; Carolyn; Jennifer and Evan; Jeff and Kathy. Greatgrandmother of Connor, Alyssa, Gabriella and Emma. Sister of Phil and Lillian; Jules and Edith; Ida and Lou; Harry and Ida; Ben and Judy; Jeanette and Oscar. She will be missed dearly by hundreds of nieces, nephews and cousins. Services Thursday, August 29, 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY, followed by interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

title: Portable Labs for 28 Bronx Schools
description: The Bronx borough president's office is allocating about $1.5 million for portable science labs that are to be installed in 28 Bronx high schools six weeks from now. ''This is a huge boroughwide effort to raise scores in biology, physics and chemistry,'' said ARLENE MUKOKO, a spokeswoman for the borough president, ADOLFO CARRIN JR. About the size of the rolling typewriter stand found in many offices, the labs include components like a video microscope, a colorimeter to determine the intensity and hue of a color, a pocket personal computer and a printer. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Arthur Avenue: A Big Bite of Italy And Old New York
description: ARTHUR AVENUE in the Bronx cultivates the image of ''Cucina Paradiso,'' complete with a booming soundtrack by Dean Martin at his sappiest. It would be easy to write the neighborhood off as a culinary theme park, a Neapolitan Epcot Center staffed by stock characters. There's the vegetable vendor in the ''Arthur Avenue since 1936'' jacket; the cheese and salami sellers who cannot let a passer-by pass by without insisting, ''Taste this!''; the grandmas in flowered aprons watching over their displays of basil and eggplant under boughs of hot peppers hung up to dry.

title: Attendance Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: There Was Plenty of It, And It Was All Cuban
description: There is a strain of virtuosity among the best Cuban jazz players -- it's an ideal -- that renders the listener helpless. When Orlando (Maraca) Valle plays a flute solo, the only response is to laugh. As he led his band at S.O.B.'s on Monday night, he put one or two solos into each tune.

title: For Now, Giants Stand Pat With Their Kicking Game
description: The Giants tried out a parade of place-kickers and punters today, hoping to find an alternative to the injured kicker Owen Pochman and the inconsistent punter Rodney Williams.

title: Plan for Alexander Statue Too Great for Many Greeks
description: Alexander the Great was a megalomaniac. But not even he, based on what is known of his life, wanted the side of a mountain carved to depict his face.

title: Elegant Ices In Unexpected Flavors
description: Her name is Sun but she has a way with ice. Ines Sun, the owner of Wild Lily Tea Market in the East Village, is selling sophisticated snow cones in passion fruit, litchi and green tea flavors. She calls them shaved ices and they are tartly quenching, especially the fragrant litchi and the golden passion fruit. The green tea is quite a bit sweeter. The ices come in generous wide glass coupes, $3.50 for the litchi and passion fruit, $5 for the green tea. The market is at 545 East 12th Street; Ms. Sun also owns the Wild Lily Tea Room in Chelsea.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Chief Executive Buys Shares
description: The chief executive of Lucent Technologies, Patricia F. Russo, bought shares in the telephone-equipment maker for the first time since taking the job in January, adding to her stake as the stock traded near record lows. Ms. Russo bought 350,000 shares for $497,000 to $500,500, at $1.42 or $1.43 a share, on Aug. 16, Lucent said. That brought her Lucent holdings to 713,365 shares. The chairman, Henry B. Schacht, bought one million shares that day for $1.43 each. Mr. Schacht, who preceded Ms. Russo as chief executive, now owns 1,003,712 shares.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDFEIN, PAULINE R.
description: GOLDFEIN-Pauline R. It is now 19 long years since you left us. Your family and friends still miss you. Phil

title: 5 Advance in Europe
description: Manchester United avenged a 1-0 opening-leg defeat by beating Zalaegerszeg of Hungary, 5-0, to become one of five teams to qualify for the European Champions League yesterday.

title: Local Heroes
description: EACH summer we wait impatiently for the local tomatoes to arrive and this summer they have made us wait longer than usual. A peculiar spring fraught with horticultural havoc -- drought followed by heavy rains followed by unseasonal cold followed by heat -- made everything late, and the harvests small.

title: New York City Makes a Cut In Olympic Bid
description: New York and San Francisco advanced today in their quests to play host to the 2012 Summer Olympics, winning selection as the United States' finalists in an international competition that will end in three years.

title: I'm With Dick! Let's Make War!
description: I was dubious at first. But now I think Dick Cheney has it right.

title: U.S. TROOPS FOCUS ON BORDER'S CAVES TO SEEK BIN LADEN
description: After months of frustration, American commanders appear to have concluded that Osama bin Laden is probably still alive and moving between mountain hideouts somewhere on a 250-mile stretch of the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the earliest known meteor impact on Earth misstated the origin of the zircon crystals that were used to date the impact. They were formed by volcanic activity before the impact and then scoured out of the rock by giant tsunamis, or tidal waves, caused by the impact; they were not created by the force of the tsunamis.

title: Sparks' Leslie Puts Her Focus on a Title
description: Lisa Leslie, the star center of the Los Angeles Sparks, scored fewer points this season than last, and was unable to capture her second straight Most Valuable Player award.

title: The Cooking of Naples, Pure and Simple
description: THE perennial appeal of the little Italian restaurant may not reside among life's deepest mysteries, but many adventurous eaters regard the thought of a meal at yet another trattoria with the yawns ordinarily reserved for a night of Chinese takeout and reruns of ''Cheers.'' For such naysayers, I recommend a helping of meatballs from Il Gattopardo, a tiny, understated Neapolitan restaurant that opened last year on West 54th Street across from the permanent home of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Software Maker Sued
description: The Konami Corporation, which makes software for games, was sued by the Japan Professional Baseball Players Association, which accused it of using the likenesses of ballplayers without the league's authorization. Konami's game, ''Jikkyo Power Pro Baseball,'' includes characterizations and names of actual players. Konami said it had signed a licensing contract with the Professional Baseball Organization of Japan, the operators of the league and a co-defendant in the suit. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Serbs, Not NATO Strike, Killed Inmates, Hague Court Hears
description: Slobodan Milosevic seldom looks pleased at his war crimes trial, but he seemed briefly and positively content today as the court heard about one of his favorite subjects, the havoc and destruction caused by the NATO bombing of his country, Yugoslavia.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: BANK SELLS SHARES The Bank of China's Hong Kong unit said that it had sold $169 million in additional stock beyond the $2.5 billion it raised last month in its initial public offering. The extra stock sales left the Bank of China still owning 63.74 percent of the unit. BOC Hong Kong (Holdings) also said that its net profit declined 19 percent in the first half of this year, even though it reduced the amount of money it was setting aside for bad loans. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Many Marketers Will Forgo Ads During Sept. 11
description: Two weeks before the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a consensus seems to be emerging about advertising on that day: less will be more.

title: Butter Saves the Day
description: THIS is a recipe that may have you grappling with your conscience, one that uses butter for nothing more than its flavor and a silken-mouth feel to counter the dryness and mild flavor too often associated with chicken. To make it, you loosen the skin of any chicken part and tuck a bit of butter between skin and flesh, along with a large pinch -- or small handful -- of chopped herb. I began doing this with breasts, which need the most help, but it is killer with thighs, which are more moist and flavorful by nature.

title: One U.S. Bridge Title Assured, One Lost
description: Play on Monday in the world bridge championships guaranteed that the United States would capture one major team title but would not win another.

title: Singing About Frustration, Some Strain, No Self-Pity
description: Alone onstage with an acoustic guitar, Paul Westerberg was still every bit a rocker when he performed Monday night at Warsaw in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. His clothes were bright and motley, and he kept his tinted glasses on. In a voice that was bleary but pugnacious, he sang about frustrations both adolescent and adult, and when he played electric guitar, he let it blare. He had brought not a band, but a stageful of living-room furniture, an ironic setting for songs about being perpetually uncomfortable.

title: Australia Lowers Fees Involving Credit Cards
description: Australia's central bank ordered sweeping changes in the way credit card businesses operate today. The bank said the changes would lower costs and promote competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, ELSIE LINCOLN
description: ROSNER-Elsie Lincoln. August 6 in Manhattan, age 89. Journalist for Time, 1939, medical reporter MD 1957-78, news editor 1969-78, Medical World News 1979-84, Physicians' Weekly 1984-2001. Born Philadelphia. BA (1933) MS (entomology) University of Pennsylvania. Working with Dr. Philip Calvert, identified dragonfly ''Aeshna elsia Calvert''. Married to Albert Aaron Rosner, MD, psychoanalyst, died 1962. Survived by brother, Jerome Lincoln, Elkins Park, PA and his wife Ray; two sons, Jonathan Rosner, physicist, University of Chicago and his wife Joy, and Anthony Rosner, Brookline, MA, Director Foundation Chiropractic Education and Research, and his wife Ruth; three grandchildren: Hannah, Rachael, and Benjamin. Memorial service NY Academy Medicine, 1216 5th Ave., NYC, Noon September 29. Contributions to the organization of one's choice.

title: Memoirs Commemorate Lives Lost on 9/11
description: Kenny Marino, 40, married, with two small children, was a New York City firefighter, a member of Rescue 1, the elite team on hazardous duty all through Manhattan. At 6 foot 5, he was by all accounts ''a gentle giant.'' After Mr. Marino died on 9/11 with 10 other members of Rescue 1, all that was recovered was the front piece of his helmet, with his number, 767, and that of his unit.

title: Sums vs. Summarizing: SAT's Math-Verbal Gap
description: OVER the last decade, average SAT scores have risen, but more on the mathematics test than on the verbal. The College Board announced yesterday that math scores grew, from 501 in 1992 to 516 this year, and verbal scores rose, from 500 to 504.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: If Mies van der Rohe had designed bracelets, he would have shown them at D'Fly, a jewelry store in SoHo.

description: A generation of racially mixed Thais who grew up feeling like ugly ducklings have now all but taken over the local fashion and entertainment industries.

description: It was another random moment in men's tennis, and as a result, David Nalbandian will not be providing his home nation, Argentina, with a welcome distraction from its troubles at this Grand Slam event.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle To Publish Explanation Of Prices
description: The Oracle Corporation, the nation's third-largest software company and one of the largest sellers of enterprise programs, said yesterday that it would start publishing a detailed explanation of its prices. The announcement comes within months of a wave of reports critical of Oracle's pricing policies, including the prominent dispute over its sale of $95 million in software to the State of California. Called the Software Investment Guide, the document includes information on all of Oracle's products and services, including consulting and education. Jacqueline Woods, Oracle's vice president for global pricing and licensing strategy, said the program was in direct response to requests from customers for pricing and licensing information they can use for comparison in shopping. The guidelines will be available Monday on Oracle's Web site at www.oracle.com/corporate/pricing. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Ruling on Charities And Tax Exemption
description: The Internal Revenue Service does not have to make public its reasons for denying or revoking a charity's tax-exempt status, a federal judge has ruled.

title: Seeing by Starlight, More Precisely Than Ever
description: MARK MARLOW MEAD, a volunteer captain for a search and rescue team in Calaveras County, in Northern California, got the call on an August evening three summers ago.

title: An Arab-American's Act Is Off Jackie Mason Bill
description: The comedian Jackie Mason asked that an Arab-American comedian not appear with him at a club here this week, and the club complied by canceling the act, both major Chicago newspapers reported today.

title: Together, This Team Succeeds
description: Just before Amir Hadad and Aisam ul-Haq Qureshi emerged from the tunnel into the Grandstand court at the National Tennis Center, flanked by a half-dozen escorts, they peered out, looking unsure of what awaited them last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANCBAUM, HYMAN (CHAIM BEN SCHMUEL)
description: FLANCBAUM - Hyman (Chaim ben Schmuel). Born in Wachock, Poland, June 20, 1923, died August 27, 2002. A survivor of Nazi tyranny, he escaped from a German concentration camp in June 1944 and lived underground in the woods for more than 6 months. After liberation, he lived in the displaced persons camp of Bergen Belsen where he married Paula Lerman, and their first child was born. In 1949, they emigrated to America. His spirit will be remembered always by his devoted daughters and sons, Shirley and Henry Hackel, and Florence and Barry Sideroff, and by his adoring grandchildren, Joshua, Julie, Melissa and Marc. Funeral services will be held Thursday, May 29 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., at 11:45 AM.

title: Morris Heights Journal; Youths Find Hope in Jobs Academy
description: The unemployment rate in the Bronx was 9.2 percent in June, the highest of any borough in New York. If a softball team were to take the field in Melrose, Clason Point or Bedford Park, the odds would be that someone in the lineup did not have a job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBSYS, REV. MSGR. ANTHONY
description: RUBSYS-Rev. Msgr. Anthony, entered eternal rest on August 27, 2002. 79 years. Professor Emeritus of Religious Studies at Manhattan College. Beloved brother of Matas and Stasys Rubsys and Apolonija Jacikeviliene, Terese Uksiene and Emilija Kucinskiene, all of Lithuania. Visitors may call on Thursday from 2-5 & 7-9pm at the Christian Brothers Center of Manhattan College, 4415 Post Rd, Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the chapel of the Christian Brothers Center, Friday, August 30, 2002 at 10am. Interment will take place in Lithuania.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Deals On Car Insurance For Uninsured
description: Uninsured drivers may soon be able to buy car insurance without the usual surcharges imposed on drivers who have had a 30-day lapse in coverage, said Holly C. Bakke, the state banking and insurance commissioner. From Sept. 16 to Dec. 31, drivers can save $115 in buying a policy without collision coverage and an additional $39 on a policy with comprehensive and collision coverage. Higher fees for those with a conviction will also be waived, but those drivers must still pay surcharges assessed by the state. Mary Caffrey, an insurance department spokeswoman, said the plan would encourage younger drivers who have older cars and limited incomes to ''get legal.'' Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Iran's President Trying to Limit Power of Clergy
description: Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, said today that hard-line clerics had made it all but impossible for him to do his job and that he would propose legislation to adjust the balance of power so that he could pursue reforms.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: TRAIN FIRE AT PENN STATION

title: Licensing of Gas Stations Ignites Patronage Scandal in India
description: The Raj lives on.

title: Creditors to Control Marconi Under Accord to Forgive Debt
description: Marconi, a troubled maker of telecommunications equipment, said today that it had agreed to hand over almost complete control of the company to creditors in return for forgiveness of most of its debts.

title: Ballet Theater Fills Positions After Tumult
description: After several years of administrative and fiscal turmoil, American Ballet Theater announced several high-level appointments yesterday, including a new executive director and a chief financial officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, GERALD H.
description: KELLER-Gerald H. Died August 27 after a courageous battle with cancer. A devoted and caring husband of 48 years to Barbara, an understanding and supportive father to Judy and Robert, and a proud and loving grandfather to Samantha, Katie and Kendall. His strong presence and adventuresome spirit will be missed. The consummate adman. Services Friday, August 30, 11 AM at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Wine Gain For Brewer
description: Foster's, the beverage company in Australia with a global beer brand, is selling more wine than beer in dollar terms. The Foster's Group reported a 21 percent increase in profit, to $310 million in the year to July, and revenue of $2.8 billion, which is up 14.6 percent. Wine revenue ($1.1 billion) exceeded beer sales ($960 million) for the first time since the brewer turned seriously to wine five years ago. Foster's bought the Beringer Wine Estates two years ago for 2.9 billion Australian dollars. Wine sales increased 28 percent and beer sales just 1.7 percent in the period. John Shaw (NYT)

title: I.O.C. May Drop Popular Ballgames
description: The International Olympic Committee's program commission recommended yesterday that baseball, softball and modern pentathlon be eliminated from the Olympics. They would be replaced by golf and rugby.

title: CENDANT TO CUT PAY OF ITS CHAIRMAN
description: The Cendant Corporation, a hotel and real estate brokerage franchiser whose shares have not recovered from a 1998 accounting scandal, will cut the pay of its chairman and chief executive, Henry Silverman, by more than half and begin accounting for stock options as an operating expense. Mr. Silverman's 2002 pay will be about $15 million, down from $36 million in 2001, a spokesman, Elliot Bloom, said. He declined to comment on the reason for the changes. Cendant, which is based in New York, disclosed in 1998 that its predecessor, CUC International, had overstated revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYER, BEN F., M.D.
description: BRYER-Ben F., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and longtime friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his entire family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Pres. William G. Stein, M.D., V.P.. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secy. George Raptis, M.D., Treas.

title: Editors' Note; Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume in September.

title: A Call for War: Will the Country Respond?
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Attorney General Opens An Inquiry Into '99 Drug Sweep
description: Attorney General John Cornyn of Texas has opened an investigation into a 1999 drug sweep in which about 12 percent of the black population of Tulia, Tex., was arrested. The decision failed to appease civil rights lawyers, who describe the arrests in an undercover operation as atrocities and want the convictions overturned.

title: Professional-Looking Labels To Go With Those CD Mixes
description: As compact disc recorders continue to gain popularity, the party-mix cassette tape has given way to the party-mix CD. But now, instead of using a marker to scrawl the playlist on the discs you burn, you can quickly pull song title and artist information from the Internet, put it into a label template and print it out with the Neato CD/DVD Labeling System from Fellowes.

title: Frankfurt Ballet Director Says He'll Leave in 2004
description: William Forsythe, the American choreographer who has led the Frankfurt Ballet since 1984, announced this week that he would leave the company when his contract expired in 2004.

title: Paying for Tech Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Development and a Drought Cut Carolinas' Water Supply
description: A regional drought that is the worst on record is taking a heavy toll in the Carolinas, where some of the country's fastest-growing cities and suburbs are proving unexpectedly vulnerable to water shortages.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADING COMPANY INQUIRY Tokyo prosecutors are investigating whether Mitsui & Company , a Japanese trading company, bribed a government official in Mongolia to win aid contracts, according to local media reports. A Mitsui employee reportedly paid 1 million yen ($8,400) to the official to win a contract to supply 150 diesel generators that were financed by Japanese government aid. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: CHIEF OF PHILIP MORRIS ADDS TITLE OF CHAIRMAN
description: In a widely expected move, the Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that Louis C. Camilleri, the chief executive, had been elected chairman of its board. He was also elected chairman of Kraft Foods, a subsidiary of Philip Morris. Mr. Camilleri became the chief executive of Philip Morris in April and will keep that post while performing his duties as chairman. He replaces Geoffrey C. Bible, who was named chairman in 1995, on both boards. Mr. Bible is stepping down because he has reached the company's mandatory retirement age, Philip Morris officials said. William H. Webb, who has served as vice chairman and chief operating officer since August 2001, will also retire from both boards. Philip Morris's board also voted yesterday to raise the company's quarterly dividend to 64 cents a share from 58 cents. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: Barcelona Celebrates Its Own Architectural Visionary
description: Architectural discourse stirs deep passions here, and no arguments reach quite the depth of those surrounding the legacy of Catalan architect Antoni Gaud.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption last Thursday about an influx of designers, artists and weekend residents into Columbia County, N.Y., misspelled the given name of an architect who has done some innovative modern work in nearby Rhinebeck. He is Steven Holl, not Stephen.

title: Mets Revert To Form, Which Isn't Good
description: When the last out was made tonight, the Mets' season might have ended. But it was difficult to find anybody who believed it had.

title: Worried Saudis Pay Millions To Improve Image in the U.S.
description: The Saudi government has spent millions of dollars on well-connected lobbyists and national television advertisements since Sept. 11 in a drive to improve its image among Americans and is poised to spend more as the anniversary of the events approaches.

title: Buoyed by World's Focus on Terror, Spain Cracks Down in Basque Region
description: On a recent afternoon in this well-kept Basque town, police officers marched up to a hip-looking tavern, pulled out a court order, and announced that the place was being shut down. Within hours, the street outside the bar was a froth of speeches, chants and spiky hair.

title: The Science Of Suction Hits the Dirt
description: IF it ain't broke don't fix it.'' That's how most people feel about vacuum cleaners. They are taken out of the closet once a week, walked around and shoved back in, behind the raincoats. People tend to buy the same vacuum their mother had. According to Consumer Reports, uprights are traditionally for carpets and canisters for bare floors. But the September Consumer Reports evaluations showed that most machines in each category did well on all types of floors and that the average price fell to $175 today from $250 three years ago.

title: A Walk in the Boroughs
description: To the Editor:

title: Nasdaq Wins Battle at S.E.C. On New System For Trading
description: A costly lobbying and regulatory battle over the future of the Nasdaq stock market drew to a close today when, over the heated objections of rivals, the government approved its use of a new automated trading system.

title: Germans Issue First Indictment in the 9/11 Plot
description: German prosecutors brought charges yesterday against a Moroccan man accused of supporting members of the Hamburg cell suspected of helping to plan and carry out the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States.

title: An Indie Movie Is Outlasting The Blockbusters
description: A couple of years ago, a Hollywood agent gave the actress Nia Vardalos a tip to help her find work. He suggested that she change her name to Vardalez and market herself as a Puerto Rican.

title: Market Place; Salomon Memo Hints at Favor on New Stock Issues
description: While the huge allocations of shares in hot stock offerings to Bernard J. Ebbers, the former WorldCom chief executive, have dominated the news since Salomon Smith Barney responded to a Congressional subpoena on the matter earlier this week, equally noteworthy among the documents was an internal memorandum from two of the firm's top brokers.

title: A Call for War: Will the Country Respond?
description: To the Editor:

title: Native New Yorkers (The Original Kind); American Indians of Many Tribes Work to Preserve Identity in City
description: The city with the largest American Indian population, according to the 2000 Census, is not Phoenix. Not Los Angeles. It is New York City.

title: A Call for War: Will the Country Respond?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter Testifies in Milosevic Case, Fueling Debate on Witnesses
description: A BBC television reporter appeared today as a witness in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic, the former leader of Yugoslavia, fueling debate over whether journalists should testify to war crimes tribunals and, specifically, before the newly created permanent International Criminal Court.

title: Water for a Thirsty World
description: Water is a vital resource for sustaining human life, growing crops and running many industrial activities. It is disturbing that in many areas of the world the demand for fresh water is rising faster than the supply, leaving about a billion people without access to clean drinking water. Regional water shortages have raised the specter of armed conflict, forced relatively affluent societies to finance huge water projects and left some of the world's most impoverished nations in deepening misery.

title: Fine Terrain for Scorpions and Artists
description: WHETHER you are a scorpion, a fire ant or a human, the desert demands creativity of its inhabitants. This skin-searing stretch of the Mojave foothills, two and a half hours east of Los Angeles, is a landscape of extremes, marked by rock slides waiting to happen and the spiky yucca plants, called Joshua trees, that look like botanical sparklers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Production Halted
description: The Daewoo Motor Company has stopped making cars at its three Korean plants after its leading supplier stopped shipping parts ahead of a boycott planned for today by all 191 companies that make parts for its vehicles. The company said Korea Delphi Automotive System stopped shipments on Tuesday while demanding payments of almost $200 million. Daewoo, which is in the hands of creditors while awaiting the takeover of its Korean plants by a new company formed by General Motors, reportedly owes about $700 million for parts bought since it went into bankruptcy two years ago. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a nonprofit organization that is privately publishing memorial books about victims of the World Trade Center attack misstated its Web address and at one point misstated its name. The organization is the American Tribute Center, not Tribune; the site is www.tributecenter.org.

title: Flexible Camcoder Lets You Shoot, Edit and Play on DVD
description: With any of Hitachi's three newest digital camcorders, serious home-movie buffs can not only archive their lives on DVD but also edit them on the fly and watch the product anywhere.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: President's Choice Rejected
description: The National Assembly voted 151 to 112 against President Kim Dae Jung's choice of Chang Dae Whan, a former newspaper executive, as prime minister. In two days of grueling hearings, members grilled Mr. Chang, right, former president of a leading financial newspaper, on real estate dealings, loans and tax issues. The hearings were reminiscent of those in which Chang Sang, who would have been South Korea's first woman to become prime minister, was rejected last month amid questions about her real estate dealings and academic background. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Lack of Basics Threatens World's Poor
description: Delegates at the United Nations Summit on Sustainable Development today emphasized the importance of bringing water and sanitation to the millions around the world who struggle without those essential services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELTMAN, GERTRUDE S.
description: ELTMAN-Gertrude S. Beloved wife for 65 years of Alex. Adored mother of Harriet Chwatsky (Mort), Lois Eltman and George S. Eltman (Karen). Cherished grandmother of Amy Feinblatt (Rob), Lynn Siegel (Jory) and Clara Eltman. Greatgrandmother of Carly and Rachel Feinblatt. Services Friday, August 30, 10:00 AM at Guttermans, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

description: SEPTEMBER 11

description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Richard Gabe, senior vice president at Bernstein-Rein Advertising, Kansas City, Mo., was named executive director of a new unit, the Brand Relationship Group.

title: Senior U.S. Official Underscores Bush's Criticism of North Korea
description: A senior American official today vigorously defended President Bush's inclusion of North Korea as part of an ''axis of evil'' -- along with Iran and Iraq -- saying the term was ''more than a rhetorical flourish, it was factually correct.''

title: Before Sentencing, Judge Rejects a New Trial for Skakel
description: Michael C. Skakel was confronted by his past today in an emotional court hearing in which friends remembered his loyalty and generosity, and foes accused him of covering up a murder 27 years ago.

title: Editorial Notebook; Sondheim Finds a Home in Washington
description: Though I enjoyed living in Washington for a good chunk of my career as a journalist, I never thought of the capital as a cultural mecca. I witnessed some wonderful performances over the years at the Arena Stage, Wolf Trap and the Kennedy Center, and spent a memorable evening at the Reagan White House when Vladimir Horowitz gave a brilliant recital and Nancy Reagan accidentally toppled off the stage in the East Room. Yet once I resettled in New York a decade ago, my travels to Washington have been dictated by political and foreign policy developments, not the performing arts.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell after an OPEC official said the group would probably lift production quotas when it meets next month. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell 49 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $28.34 a barrel.

title: MOLSON SELECTS A CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Molson, Canada's biggest brewer, appointed a former Diageo executive, Brian Burden, as chief financial officer and executive vice president. Mr. Burden replaces Robert Coallier, who is moving to Brazil to run the company's Cervejarias Kaiser unit, acquired in March for $765 million, the company said. Mr. Burden has about 25 years of experience as a senior finance executive, including 15 years with Diageo, the world's largest liquor maker, which is based in London, Molson said.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telstra Profit Falls
description: Telstra, Australia's national telephone company, reported a 10 percent decline in net profit in the year to July, from $2.21 billion to $2 billion, despite a 2 percent increase in sales. Revenue from cellular phone services was up 10 percent in the period. The Australian government is expected to offer its 51 percent stake in Telstra for sale next year. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Train Fire At Penn Station
description: An engine fire on an Amtrak train in Pennsylvania Station last night caused extensive delays, but no injuries. The authorities said the fire broke out about 6:40 on a train that was unloading passengers from Chicago, and before it was put out at 8 p.m., service was halted on seven sets of tracks. Officials of New Jersey Transit reported 20-minute delays, and Amtrak said it had delays of 15 minutes to two hours on its Acela service to Washington and Boston and other service to Albany and Miami. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: The Wrong Shelter
description: The Bronx House of Detention for Men is not much farther than a long fly ball from Yankee Stadium. Fans seldom notice it. But you can stand in its shadow on a game night and listen to the roar that rises from the brilliant, bluish light of the stadium and rolls out over that particular corner of the South Bronx.

title: Epidemic That Wasn't
description: When scientists announced this month that a widely anticipated federal study of breast cancer had failed to find links to pollution or other environmental factors, attention was again focused on the prevalence of the disease on Long Island, where the study was based.

title: Viloria, a Hawaiian Flyweight, Gets Ready to Face Munoz
description: Brian Viloria skipped rope so fast, it sounded like the prairie wind. A little bit of showmanship does not hurt, Viloria said yesterday, especially when you are a flyweight. That is why Viloria (8-0), a 2000 Olympian, is working on his knockout potential. He has registered six in eight fights heading into his main event against Gabriel Munoz (29-11-1) tomorrow at Cipriani 42nd Street's black-tie event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, AARON
description: COHEN-Aaron, 93, of Long Beach, NY, an accountant, educator and the gentlest of men, passed away on August 26, 2002. Husband of the late Irene. Devoted father of Barbara Cohen. Dear brother-inlaw of Jules Gantman. Loving uncle of Lynne, Jane, Susan, Judy, Deborah, Leonard, Barnet, Sue, Barnet Louis, Phyllis, Annette, Mike, Bernard, Stephanie, Gladys, Robert, and many great-andgreat-great nieces and nephews.

title: Rx for a Big Move: Refills on the Web
description: ''WE need the pink stuff,'' said a hoarse voice from the other side of the screen door.

title: U.S. Weighs Flight Restrictions Near Sept. 11 Crash Sites
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  Federal aviation authorities said today that they were planning to restrict air travel on the first anniversary of the terror attacks around New York City, Washington and Somerset, Pennsylvania, where the fourth hijacked airliner crashed on Sept. 11.

title: The Little Bench That Could (It Has Higher Aspirations)
description: A new multipurpose furniture module called Squat is perfect for students or those who live in studio apartments. It was created by Stefane Barbeau and Duane Smith, Canadian product designers now based in Boston. Squat, above, a 40-inch-long bench of birch plywood with anodized aluminum legs that can hold books or magazines, can be stacked six high to make a roomy bookcase, top. Single units, 15 inches wide and 13 1/2 inches high, can also be used as a coffee table. The wood can be left unfinished, stained or painted to fit any color scheme or dcor. Each Squat bench is $50 from Vessel, (877) 805-1801, or www.vesselinc.com.

title: Don't Cry for Baseball Owners, or Players Either
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Correction Officers Rebuff Teamsters
description: Union organizers have abandoned efforts to persuade 26,000 New York State prison guards to join the International Brotherhood of Teamsters this year. Teamster organizers and several correction officers had sought to get more than 30 percent of the guards to sign cards saying that they wanted to leave their current union, the New York State Correctional Officers and Police Benevolent Association, and join the Teamsters. Jeff Farmer, the Teamsters' organizing director, wrote to the guards that the Teamsters' law enforcement division, the Benevolent Law Enforcement Union, had not ruled out trying to recruit them in the future. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: New Jersey Will Reverse Use Of Wetlands as Cranberry Bog
description: Reprising a dispute that led to tighter state government ethics rules, the McGreevey administration said today that it planned to rescind 2,000 permits that allowed an influential Republican and major Burlington County cranberry grower to expand his bogs retroactively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSER, ABRAHAM
description: TESSER-Abraham. At 86, on August 26, 2002. Beloved husband of Toby (Turkel). Devoted father of Gary Charles and Steven Barry, Ph.D. Dear brother of Florence Tesser and Ruth Leventhal. Cherished uncle of many loving nieces and nephews. Mr. Tesser graduated City College after earning his CPA. He served in the U.S. Army and practiced public accounting for over 50 years. He was a 32nd Degree Freemason. He was respected and beloved by all, a dear, strong, gentle man who will be greatly missed.

title: Struggling to Find Expert Help
description: Its great to have a Web site. On mine, I promote books, unload old gear, and ask questions.

title: Effect of Smallpox Vaccine May Be Longer, Study Says
description: Scientists at the University of North Carolina have reported additional evidence suggesting that immunity conferred by smallpox vaccine may last longer than had been thought, at least for some people. But they and other researchers cautioned that the findings, from laboratory blood tests, might not apply to people actually exposed to smallpox.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: HOMICIDE CHARGE UPHELD IN BHOPAL CASE A court declined to reduce charges against the former chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation for the 1984 gas leak in Bhopal, which killed thousands. The former chairman, Warren Anderson, is charged with culpable homicide and federal prosecutors had asked the court to reduce the charge to "hurt by negligence." Mr. Anderson's whereabouts are unknown and he has refused to appear in court in India since the case opened in 1992. The leak of methyl isocyanate gas from the Union Carbide plant in Bhopal killed 4,000 people on the night of Dec. 2, 1984, and since then the death toll has risen to 14,410 as those sickened by the gas died, the government says. (AP)

title: A Call for War: Will the Country Respond?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brilliant Opening Lead Almost Saved a U.S. Team
description: One United States team beat another, winning a major title by 100 imps at the world bridge championships here on Tuesday. Another title will go to Italy or Indonesia.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: SCHOOL DISTRICT BANS SODA SALES

title: Plea Deals Are Seen for 3 WorldCom Executives
description: Three executives from WorldCom, including the former controller who was arrested on fraud charges this month, have reached preliminary agreements to plead guilty to felonies and provide testimony against other participants in what prosecutors say was a huge accounting scheme, according to court records and people involved in the case.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Governor's Day In Court
description: Gov. Rick Perry reported for jury duty on Tuesday at Austin Municipal Court, where Stenson Hutcherson was facing charges of speeding. Mr. Perry was allowed to leave when Mr. Hutcherson, who was representing himself, exercised a peremptory challenge. ''Governors of Texas are known to be kind of strict on the law,'' said Mr. Hutcherson, the manager of a fast-food restaurant. The jury convicted Mr. Hutcherson.

title: Do You Know the Correct Time? And the Barometric Pressure?
description: Suunto, a maker of compasses and sports instruments based in Finland, has long called its complex watches ''wristop computers.'' And now, with its two newest models, Suunto is expanding its computing territory. Both the X6 and the X6HR can download the data they gather to any Windows-based PC.

title: Hello, Roommates
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Woman Sues Bars
description: The owners of two bars in Butte are being sued by a woman who was injured by a drunken driver who had been served alcohol at the bars. The injured woman, Shannon Isakson, a high school student at the time of the accident in 1997, has had operations on her face, and her lawyer said insurance coverage to pay for more had run out. The driver, Jody Weiss, then 42, pleaded guilty, paid a $200 fine and served 30 weekends in jail. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose on speculation that a sale of two-year notes prompted some investors to buy the currency to invest in the notes. In New York, the euro settled at 98.02 cents, down from 98.33 cents on Tuesday.

title: A Senator on McCall's Side
description: H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and candidate in the Democratic primary for governor, yesterday began a statewide broadcast of his first commercial featuring Senator Charles E. Schumer. The ad, which will be shown throughout the Labor Day weekend, is the second phase of Mr. Schumer's efforts to help Mr. McCall win the Democratic Party's nomination; his endorsement last month helped Mr. McCall's campaign gain momentum against Andrew M. Cuomo. Mr. Schumer is expected to help draw support for Mr. McCall from Jewish voters, who historically have made up about 20 percent of the turnout in New York State primaries.

title: Then Again, Is It a Tool or a Cellular Trap?
description: A FEW months ago, a friend who is otherwise as technologically well endowed as the next guy explained to me why he had no desire to own a cellphone.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Axel Springer Profit Rises
description: Axel Springer Verlag, the publisher of Germany's most widely read newspaper, Bild, said first-half profit soared as job cuts, other cost reductions and asset sales offset a 9.3 percent decline in advertising revenue. First-half net income rose to 72 million euros ($70.6 million), from 14 million euros a year earlier.

title: Saudi Censorship of Web Ranges Far Beyond Tenets of Islam, Study Finds
description: THE Saudi government is censoring public Internet access to a degree that goes significantly but haphazardly beyond its stated central goal of blocking sexually explicit content that violates the values of Islam, according to a recent study by Harvard Law School researchers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSHCOPF, BERTA RUTH
description: HERSHCOPF-Berta Ruth. A Celebration of her life at 2PM, Saturday, August 31, at the Zoo School at Central Park Zoo, 64 St. and 5th Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOW, GEORGE J.
description: SOLOW-George J. On August 27. Loving husband of Ethel. Wonderful father of Peter, Matty, and the late Tommy. Cherished father-inlaw of Patty. Best grandfather of Michael Russell, Jessica and Rebecca. Brother of Toby Gotthelf. Service Thursday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam.

title: A Call for War: Will the Country Respond?
description: To the Editor:

title: You Thought Picking the Pickets Would Be Easy . . .
description: SAYING you want a picket fence is like going to a seafood restaurant and saying you want fish. Pickets can be made of red or white rot-resistant cedar or vinyl. They can be flat or beveled, pointed, rounded or straight, three and a half feet high or higher. And there are custom designs.

title: The Mall Has Its Charms But Try Hangin' at the Web
description: You can be home yet still shop as if you were at an outlet mall. Overstock.com, a Web site organized along the lines of a group of stores, offers deep discounts on name-brand merchandise, furniture and garden pieces. This week the offerings include a 16-piece set of four Rio cream-color stoneware place settings with blue stripes (below) by Pfaltzgraff. The set was $199.99, but on this site, $54.99; a $250 DeLonghi microwave oven here was $89.99; $145 white down comforters were $49.99; and $299 teak garden lounges were $189.99. For many items there is a flat-rate delivery charge of $2.95 in the continental United States; www.overstock.com, or (800) 989-0135.

title: Verdict for Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation unit of the Dow Chemical Company is not responsible for the lung illness of an oil well worker, a state court jury has decided.

title: Strahan-Barber Feud Is a Thing of the Past
description: Michael Strahan was introduced as the Giants' best player from last season at the team's kickoff luncheon at the New York Sheraton today, and Tiki Barber was the first teammate to rise to his feet and lead an ovation. In accepting the award, Strahan smiled enormously and spoke about how much he liked playing with the young players who surround him.

title: Investigative Excesses in Iowa
description: After a dead infant's body was discovered in an Iowa recycling center in May, local investigators issued subpoenas for the names of women who had visited local hospitals and clinics for pregnancy tests in the previous nine months. Some complied, but a Planned Parenthood clinic in the town of Storm Lake is battling the subpoena, arguing that its clients have a right to confidentiality. The resulting legal battle is fraught with emotion and complications, but on balance the clinic is right to oppose such overly broad and intrusive efforts by investigators.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Fortis Profit Falls
description: Fortis, Belgium's biggest financial-services company, said second-quarter earnings declined 15 percent as investment gains dropped and it set aside more money for potential loan losses. Profit excluding one-time gains fell to 648.5 million euros ($636.6 million), from 760.1 million euros, a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL III, LUCIEN (TONY)
description: HILL III-Lucien (Tony), of Huntington, NY, on August 27, 2002. Devoted son of Marianne D. Hill and the late Lucien Hill. Loving partner of Marie F. Wemyss. Dear brother of John H. Hill. Lucien is survived also by his sister-in-law Renee A. Richards and his nephew James Lucien Hill. Lucien was caring and giving to all. He attended the East Woods School and The Peddie School. A graduate of Ithaca College, he worked briefly as a commercial fisherman before embarking on his career as a financial planner. In addition to other associations, he served as a governor of the Squadron A as a Legacy to his father. title: ICAHN WILL BUY $362 MILLION IN DEBT FROM XO HOLDERS
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that holders of $362 million in senior secured loans of XO Communications Inc. have accepted his offer to buy the debt of the bankrupt company, a telephone service provider. Mr. Icahn said the purchase would bring his ownership to $947 million of the $1 billion in face value of the bank debt. Controlling that debt would give Mr. Icahn a powerful voice in how XO, which was founded by Craig McCaw, will reorganize in bankruptcy, as companies in Chapter 11 are legally obligated to serve their creditors' interests. ''XO has put down an excellent fiber network; the revenue has increased every year,'' Mr. Icahn said. ''What happened was finally the bubble burst, but that doesn't mean the underlying assets were no good.'' XO, which is based in Reston, Va., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June after demand for phone services waned.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Trial Over Fatal Train Wreck Starts
description: Four years after 101 people died in the country's worst train wreck since World War II, three engineers went on trial on manslaughter charges. The men, who denied the charges, are accused of having failed to properly test and monitor one of the train's wheels, which was later deemed to have suffered ''material fatigue.'' The wheel caused the train to derail at a speed of roughly 124 miles an hour, injuring 105 in addition to the dead. The trial, which is taking place in the northwestern town of Celle, near the site of the accident, is expected to last months. If convicted, the men face from five years to life in prison.

title: An Architectural Showcase For High-Tech Jewelry
description: To sell jewelry, it helps to have a jewel box of a store. At D'Fly in SoHo, which sells rings, necklaces and pins to the Wallpaper magazine generation, the jewel box is glass and steel, with recycled rubber underfoot. The store (run by Jeff Shi, who once worked uptown at Harry Winston) takes jewelry to its high-tech limit, with diamond-and-stainless steel rings by Atelier Verstraeten of Belgium (some less than $300) and steel cable necklaces by Shiri Sherf of Germany (less than $500). Most pieces are being seen for the first time in this country. And many of the pieces are architectural: if Frank Lloyd Wright had designed rings or Mies van der Rohe had done bracelets, they would have shown their wares at D'Fly. The jewelry is displayed in glass boxes whose tops ascend and descend when a sales person aims a remote control. The showcases, designed by the German firm 3deluxe, are as beautifully detailed as any of the items inside. The 3deluxe team did the interior of the store as well, dressing it up with stretched nylon constructions called ''genetic structures,'' which look like a high-school science experiment or a bubblegum-blowing contest gone wrong. ''I thought we should have a store that echoes the product,'' Mr. Shi said. ''Most jewelry stores are too conservative.'' Cushions in a seating area, above left, are made of Tempur, a high-tech foam. D'Fly is at 47 Greene Street (Broome). FRED A. BERNSTEIN

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Governor's Malpractice Plan
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove urged lawmakers to limit noneconomic damages in medical malpractice cases to $250,000 for doctors who treat Medicaid patients and join a proposed state-run malpractice liability insurance plan. Damages would be limited to $500,000 for all other doctors and health providers. Governor Murgrove also urged lawmakers to stem the mass tort cases against drug makers by prohibiting out-of-state patients from suing in Mississippi courts.

title: Williams Out, Allen In, as Giant Punter

After releasing punter Rodney Williams today and signing Matt Allen to fill the position, they now have a punter who has never appeared in a regular-season game, to go along with a place-kicker who has never made a field goal in the regular season.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Rights Advocate Slain
description: Gunmen wielding AK-47 assault rifles have killed a human rights advocate who was investigating complaints of abuses among the Garifuna communities of blacks on the Caribbean coast. Jos Callejas, director of the Honduran Human Rights Committee, was shot on Monday night when he arrived at his home in the town of San Antonio. Andrs Pavn, the group's president, said he suspected that the killing had been committed by members of organized crime connected to cases Mr. Callejas was investigating. In recent years, Garifuna leaders have been under attack for their opposition to government plans to sell coastal land to foreign hotel and resort developers. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Out Among the Yuccas, the Anti-Los Angeles
description: THOUSANDS of sleek white windmills twirl along Interstate 10 at the San Gorgonio Pass. A turn there onto Route 62 leads to the high desert towns of Yucca Valley, Joshua Tree and Twentynine Palms. In Joshua Tree (population 8,200 give or take) the culture of Los Angeles seems far away. In August, when most things are closed because of the heat, you'll be lucky to find an evening meal. But the Country Kitchen is open from 6:30 a.m. until 3 p.m., serving the musicians, artists, writers, actors, filmmakers and furniture designers who have colonized converted Quonset huts, trailers and ramshackle ranch houses. (One part-time resident, Blake Simpson, makes travertine-and-brass tables sold at Troy in Manhattan, at 138 Greene Street.)

The agency has 10 employees and clients like American Express Publishing and Chelsea Piers. Whether it was Jesse Owens showing up Hitler at the 1936 Games in Berlin or Palestinian terrorists killing 11 Israelis in Munich in 1972 or the United States boycotting the Games in Moscow in 1980 after the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan, the Olympics have been inextricably and uncomfortably linked with bigger issues.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Vitesse Chief Is Buying Shares

Mr. Tomasetta has bought 200,000 shares since mid-August, some for as little as $1.18, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission. In December 1991, Vitesse sold its shares through a public offering for $1.50 each. At that time, Vitesse had quarterly revenue of about $10 million; it now has about $40 million of revenue each quarter. But revenue has fallen recently because of reduced capital spending among telephone companies. Last year, Mr. Tomasetta made about $14 million by selling the company's stock, the S.E.C. said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUAREZ, SHEILA D.
description: SUAREZ-Sheila D. Aged 74. Died on August 28, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Joseph A. Suarez, beloved sister of Joseph Dudley Devine, beloved mother of Randolph West, II and John Dudley West, beloved stepmother of Andrea Hill and Joseph Anthony Suarez, Jr. after a brief battle with cancer. Mrs. Suarez was born in Buffalo, NY to a prominent family of meat packers and manufacturers. She was educated at Park School, Buffalo and Colby Junior College in NH. After college she moved to Greenwich Village, working for Time Inc. She lived with her first husband John Lee West in Norwalk, CT then moving to NYC, Miami, Grand Bahama Island, and Litchfield, CT with her second husband Joseph Anthony Suarez. During her life, she was active in community and environmental preservation projects. She was a member of the Junior League. She raised funds for the James Weldon Johnson Community Center in Harlem, the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, and the Farmington School. Mrs. Suarez was past President of the Litchfield Garden Club 1991-1995, and current President of the Women's Forum of Litchfield. She was the representative for Zone II of the Garden Club of America at the annual Legislature Affairs Seminar in Washington, DC. She is survived by her brother, children, stepchildren, two nieces, a nephew, and eight grandchildren. Viewings will be held on Friday, August 30, 2002 from 35pm and 7-9pm at the Rowe Funeral Home on Route 202 in Litchfield, CT. Burial services will be held at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield at 11AM on Saturday, August 31, 2002. We love her dearly. We'll miss her spirit and her love for life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, WILLARD GARDINIER
description: HAMPTON-Willard Gardinier, age 95, died on May 20, 2002. He was born in Amsterdam, New York. He graduated from Union College in 1927 as an Electrical Engineer and was employed by the New York Telephone Company, where he became Executive Vice President and Director. He retired after 40 years and became Chairman of the Brooklyn Savings Bank. He also was a Director and Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Long Island Trust Company. After retiring again, he did private consulting in New York. Mr. Hampton was Chairman of The Commerce and Industry Association in Brooklyn and was active in numerous philanthropic and business organizations, including The 100 Year Association, The Construction Users Council, the Brooklyn Hospital, Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, Brooklyn Development Association, and the Helen Keller National Association for the Deaf-Blind. Mr. Hampton was awarded an honorary LLD by his Alma Mater in 1951. Mr. Hampton was married in 1935 to Grace Metzger, who died in 1946. In 1948, he married Renee Smith, who predeceased him in January 2001. He is survived by a sister, Mrs. Laura Markert of West Melbourne, Florida; a son by his first wife, Lawrence of Portugal (a second son, Elbert is predeceased); a daughter of Mrs. Hampton, Mrs. Robert C. Knowles of St. Michaels, Maryland; two sons of Mrs. Hampton, Sanford, the Assistant Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western Washington, of Anacortes, Washington, and Frederick, of Albuquerque, New Mexico. There are 14 grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. It is requested that donations be made to Helen Keller National Center, 111 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, NY 11050, to Delaware Hospice, 3515 Silverside Road, Wilmington, DE 19810 or to the American Red Cross. For info, call Chandler Funeral Home 302-478-7100

title: World Business Briefing: Australia
description: AUSTRALIA: WINE GAIN FOR BREWER Foster's, the beverage company in Australia with a global beer brand, is selling more wine than beer in dollar terms. The Foster's Group reported a 21 percent increase in profit, to $310 million in the year to July, and revenue of $2.8 billion, which is up 14.6 percent. Wine revenue ($1.1 billion) exceeded beer sales ($960 million) for the first time since the brewer turned seriously to wine five years ago.
