title: A Web Site That Puts Horror in Your Head
description: Somewhere buried in the rain-washed blue-black murk of ''fear dot com'' is a lean and nasty little horror film struggling to be born. In the movie that might have been, a Web site on the Internet has acquired a malevolent intelligence that beams demonic energy into those who visit it and stimulates their worst nightmares. Over the next two days, they are gripped by escalating terror and eventually die of fright. In the most effective of the movie's death scenes, a woman who is scared of cockroaches visits the site and soon begins envisioning swarms of the little critters taking over her apartment and invading her body. Gripped by panic, she leaps to her death.

title: Where Time Refuses to Budge
description: People often ask me if I was an Army brat. I wasn't, but I lived in so many different places as a child that I have never mentally settled on a hometown or a straight answer to the question, ''Where are you from?''

title: 4-bedroom house, Wilmington, Vt., $275,000
description: WHERE Wilmington, Vt.

title: From Boy Band To Broadway
description: It's not very often that a Broadway replacement has a bodyguard, but Joey Fatone isn't your average Broadway replacement. As the cuddly baritone in the enormously successful boy band 'N Sync, Mr. Fatone has already, at the tender age of 25, earned tens of millions of dollars, sold tens of millions of records, and probably fended off more smitten 12-year-old girls than he can count.

title: Cuomo's Not-Very-Secret Weapon
description: In the race for the Democratic nomination for governor, Andrew M. Cuomo has frequently been portrayed as the pariah of the state Democratic Party. But at least he is not Charlie King.

title: Race Is On for Seat of Ex-Councilman Guilty in Bribery Case
description: As former City Councilman Angel Rodriguez of Brooklyn pleaded guilty yesterday in a federal bribery case, the race to succeed him was already taking shape.

title: Mayor's Panel Said to Reject His Suggestions For City Charter
description: A committee appointed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to study broad changes suggested for the City Charter is set to reject the two proposals sought by the mayor, people involved with the committee's plans said yesterday. It is highly uncommon for a charter revision committee appointed by a mayor to decline outright to bring his proposals to ballot.

title: INSIDE
description: A Change for Stock Options

title: A Study of Lonely Souls, One of Them With a Gun
description: David Allyn is the kind of playwright who takes Chekhov's dictum about foreshadowing seriously. You know, the one that says if there's a gun in the room it had better go off eventually. As the second act of Mr. Allyn's play, ''Baptizing Adam,'' begins in the apartment of a young biology teacher, there's the gun, sitting on a coffee table for no good reason.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Floods Leave 14 Dead
description: Floodwaters began receding in northeastern Cambodia, leaving 14 people dead, but began rising in the south as high water levels moved down the Mekong River toward the Vietnam Delta. Officials said the floods, coupled with a severe drought, could cause severe food shortages for hundreds of thousands of people. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUICCIARINI, SOPHIE
description: SQUICCIARINI-Sophie. Age 93, long-loved by Angela (Joel), Mary (Joe), John (Rosalie) and Minnie (Dick). Deeply loved grandmother of nine, Gigi to eleven. Viewing at M.J. Smith Sons, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, Friday, August 30, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday, August 31, 9:15 AM, Holy Name Church, opposite funeral home.

title: 3 Justices Call for Reviewing Death Sentences for Juveniles
description: In an unusual dissent from an order declining to stay an execution, three justices of the United States Supreme Court urged the court on Wednesday to reconsider allowing juveniles to be sentenced to death.

title: KODAK CANCELS INTRODUCTION OF A HYBRID CAMERA
description: Eastman Kodak said yesterday that it had canceled the introduction of the Advantix Easy Share camera, designed to give consumers both a digital image and a film picture. Kodak, based in Rochester, said component costs and the price of digital still cameras prevented it from releasing the ''hybrid'' camera. Kodak said that it would like to offer the camera in the $200 range, but that it could not predict when that might happen. The Advantix Easy Share camera was to be introduced around Labor Day, with the full rollout by early 2003.

title: No Rain Check for Ticket Holders
description: When the rain stopped and matches started yesterday -- five hours after they were scheduled to begin -- the United States Tennis Association dodged having to give yesterday afternoon's ticket holders tickets to next year's United States Open.

title: To Some Owners, TV Money Comes First
description: Baseball strike or no strike, many sports and media experts say that the growing number of media companies that own teams has increased the economic gap between rich ball clubs and poor ones -- an issue that has been at the heart of baseball's labor negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Boldface Names column yesterday carried an incorrect byline. The writer was Joyce Wadler, not James Barron.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Says Windows Has Security Flaw
description: Microsoft said yesterday that all versions of the Windows operating system released since 1996 have a serious security flaw that could prevent users from being able to encrypt e-mail and use some Web sites. In a bulletin sent by e-mail, the company, the world's largest software maker, called the vulnerability ''critical,'' its most serious rating for flaws. The company encouraged users to download a software patch to correct the problem immediately. Microsoft is working to improve the security of its software after holes allowed worms and viruses to enter Microsoft programs, angering customers. Last January, Bill Gates, the company chairman, ordered workers to focus on security, and the company halted work on some products for two months to retrain engineers. The flaw could allow a hacker to delete so-called digital certificates from a user's system. These certificates are used to hold codes that let users encrypt and decrypt e-mails and view secure Web pages like electronic commerce sites. The hacker would not be able to steal the code.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSER, ABRAHAM
description: TESSER-Abraham. At 86, on August 26, 2002. Beloved husband of Toby (Turkel). Devoted father of Gary Charles and Steven Barry, Ph.D. Dear brother of Florence Tesser and Ruth Leventhal. Cherished uncle of many loving nieces and nephews. Mr. Tesser graduated City College after earning his CPA. He served in the U.S. Army and practiced public accounting for over 50 years. He was a 32nd Degree Freemason. He was respected and beloved by all, a dear, strong, gentle man who will be greatly missed.

title: In Crossing a Lake, A Watershed Moment
description: WHEN I first started going along with my boyfriend, Matt Elliott, to his family's cottage on Lake George, I noticed that everyone in the family had a particular way of crossing the lake. The mile-long crossing is not at the widest part of the lake -- it's at Silver Bay, an old Y.M.C.A. resort. But it's far enough to be a trip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, SHIRLEY ZIMMER MAN
description: PINCUS - Shirley Zimmer man, August 27, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Zimmerman and the late Max Pincus. Loving mother of Ellen and grandmother of Ian. Devoted sister and aunt of Janet and Amy, cherished stepmother through greatgreat-step-grandmother. Inspiring educator, caring friend. Forever in our hearts. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hadassah Women's Health, 50 West 58th St, New York, NY 10019.

title: Images That Shock but Don't Inform
description: With the first anniversary of last September's terrorist attacks fast approaching, television executives are promising sensitivity and restraint in their use of the horrific video images of that day's events: passenger jets exploding as they penetrate the twin towers of the World Trade Center; skyscrapers collapsing into monstrous, roiling clouds of mortal ash; shocked New Yorkers fleeing for their lives. Even so, a CNN executive told The Associated Press that television producers can't walk away from these images entirely.

title: Last-Minute Deal in Baseball Talks Prevents a Strike
description: For the first time in 30 years, Major League Baseball and its players reached agreement on a new labor contract on Friday a few hours short of another strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIERER, FREDA K.
description: ZIERER - Freda K., died peacefully after a long illness on August 26, 2002. Widow of Harry, mother of the late Peter, she is survived by her loving daughter Jane of NYC, brother Morris Kaminsky, and two granddaughters. A lady of beauty and elegance.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: MEDIA EXECUTIVE QUITS The British media company Granada said its chief executive, Stephen Morrison, would leave the company at the end of September. Mr. Morrison, 55, is a 28-year veteran of Granada and was one of the architects of its failed foray into digital television. Granada does not plan to name a replacement for him. Granada and Carlton Communications jointly own the Independent Television network in Britain. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Toyota and Chinese Carmaker in Venture
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation signed an agreement here today with China's largest automaker to begin large-scale production of a wide range of models, becoming the latest multinational to place a big bet on China's fast-growing car market.

title: Quality Films Brush Away The Fluff
description: THE summer is supposed to be the silly season for movies, isn't it? While Hollywood holds back most of its Oscar-worthy entries until the fall, popcorn is allowed to rule. At the same time, most of the independent and foreign films that have won acclaim on the festival circuit have also been held back.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar on new indications that the economic recovery in the United States was losing steam. In New York, the euro settled at 98.40 cents, up from 98.02 cents on Wednesday.

title: A Police Officer Who Collapsed on the Job Dies 5 Days Later
description: AQueens police officer died Wednesday night apparently of brain aneurysm that he suffered last week while chasing a man accused of threatening his former wife, the authorities said yesterday.

title: McGreevey Is Reported To Criticize Rebuilding
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey lashed out at officials from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation in a private meeting Wednesday night, saying they had ignored the concerns of families of New Jersey victims of the World Trade Center attack, according to people who attended the meeting.

title: France at Sea: Remembrance Of Glories Past
description: Fresh from Paris, the boat show to top all boat shows has anchored here at the Peabody Essex Museum. Titled ''Rendez-Vous With the Sea: The Glory of the French Maritime Tradition,'' it sets out more than 125 objects, besides paintings, drawings, sculptures, prints and posters: model sailboats and battleships, drydock equipment and nautical machinery, uniforms and maritime artifacts that show French seaworthiness from the 17th through the 20th centuries.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Death Sentence For Extramarital Sex
description: An Islamic court has sentenced a man and a woman to death for engaging in extramarital sex, according to officials in the state of Niger. The court convicted Ahmadu Ibrahim, 32, and Fatima Usman, his 30-year-old girlfriend, who have 30 days to appeal. Islamic courts in northern Nigeria have sentenced a woman to death by stoning for adultery and a man to death by stoning for rape. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Corkscrews Put a Stop To Tyranny of the Hose
description: WITH hoses, hope springs eternal. Surely there must be an alternative to the heavy rubber tube hoses that leak at one end, spurt at the other and need to be wrestled on and off a bulky reel cart that presents its own set of stubborn problems -- like leaky connectors and handles that get stuck more than they turn.

title: Risky Sex Education
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bumpy Ride in Washington
description: Mayor Anthony Williams of Washington covered his face with both hands this week in stunned disappointment upon hearing that his city had been ruled out as a host for the 2012 Summer Olympics. The photograph of his reaction became emblematic in Washington. For Mr. Williams this has been a summer of relentless disappointment and embarrassment. Initially considered a shoo-in for re-election, he is now fighting for his political life as a write-in candidate in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary because his petitions to get on the ballot were thrown out as forged. Mr. Williams is clearly adept at governing, but disastrous at politics. His re-election bid raises the question of whether that combination can earn him another term as mayor.

title: Kenyan Leader Fires His Deputy in Revolt
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 30  President Daniel arap Moi fired his vice president today in an attempt to quash a revolt within his ruling party among top aides who refuse to back the longtime Kenyan leader's handpicked successor.

title: Dixon Slips on Stair And Misses Game
description: Because of freakish injuries to her back and right knee, Tamecka Dixon, the Los Angeles Sparks' outstanding shooting guard, sat out last night's playoff game against the Liberty. The Sparks won anyway, 71-63, but Michael Cooper, their coach, remained furious at Madison Square Garden's security people.

title: Appeals Court Reduces Guard's Sentence
description: A federal appeals court this week reduced the sentence of a former Nassau County jail guard who had pleaded guilty to fatally beating an inmate in 1999.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Swedish Retailer In Harlem
description: H & M, the Swedish clothing retailer, is opening a store in Harlem next week, its fourth in Manhattan. The 19,000-square-foot store on 125th Street near Malcolm X Boulevard will be the first to open in the Harlem Center, a retail and office complex that will also include a Marshalls. Terry Pristin (NYT)

description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 30  The World Trade Organization gave the go-ahead to the European Union today to impose sanctions on United States products worth just over $4 billion in retaliation for a tax break for United States exporters that the Europeans and the trade group has branded as illegal.

description: WEINBERG-Leah. description: This was Matt Allen's first game as the Giants' punter tonight and it could have been his last, but each time he returned to the sideline he was greeted with enthusiasm. That's what we want, Giants Coach Jim Fassel said to him. That's what we want.

description: ALLEN-Doris, Ed.D. Dr. Allen was a beloved member of the JCC ''family,'' and we were indeed blessed to know her, a gentle and compassionate woman whose character, commitment, and leadership enriched all those whose lives she touched. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: New No-Frills Airline
description: A German travel company, TUI, said that it would start a scheduled no-frills airline in December based at Cologne-Bonn Airport using eight 737-700's chartered from Germania, a Berlin-based charter carrier. Named Hapag-Lloyd Express, after one of TUI's charter carriers, the airline will fly to German and other European cities, including Berlin, Munich, Barcelona, Milan and Paris. MyTravel Group, a British travel company, announced a similar discount operation earlier this month. Jane Levere (NYT)

title: 2 Kennedys Sent Pleas For Skakel
description: Throughout the trial of Michael C. Skakel, the Kennedy name shone over the case like a dazzling marquee. The news media portrayed the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley as yet another segment in the life of a disaster-prone family -- even though the Kennedys were largely absent from the proceedings.

title: Some Somber Moments at MTV Awards Show
description: This year's MTV Video Music Awards were moved to August rather than early September to avoid the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. But the show, telecast live last night from Radio City Music Hall, could not escape the sobering memories. It opened with Bruce Springsteen performing ''The Rising,'' a song about a rescuer killed in the fire, with a sing-along chorus that turns it into a ritual of memorial and resurrection.

title: China Expected to Sell Stakes To Foreign Companies
description: The Chinese government is likely to allow the sale of government stakes in publicly traded state-controlled enterprises to foreign companies, a senior regulator said here today, signaling what could be the next big step in China's movement toward a market economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDFIELD, WALTER
description: REDFIELD - Walter. The Board of Directors, staff, members and participants of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children/New York City extend their deepest sympathy to Douglas and Susan Redfield upon the passing of their father, Walter Redfield. Walter has been a member of AHRC/NYC and a member of its Board of Directors for decades, during which time he provided leadership as its President, as well as serving on the NYSARC Board of Governors. Walter chaired and served on numerous Agency committees. He was particularly known as an advocate of AHRC's Guardianship Program and as a mentor to the families who participated in it. Walter was always an unwavering beacon and he will be missed by all who knew him. Genevieve O'Neil, President Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director, AHRC

title: Chinese Group Planned Embassy Attacks, U.S. Aide Says
description: BEIJING, Aug. 30 — A little-known Muslim group from western China that Washington recently branded as terrorist had planned attacks on Western embassies in neighboring Kyrgyzstan, an American official asserted today.

title: A Top Palestinian Official Calls for End to Suicide Attacks
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 30  The senior Palestinian security official, who has been negotiating with Israel on a cease-fire, denounced suicide attacks in an interview with an Israeli daily as "murders for no reason" and said he was demanding that militant organizations abandon them.

title: Blunt Portrait Drawn of the U.S. Work Force in 2020
description: Demographic changes threaten to hamstring economic growth and widen inequality in incomes in the next several decades, according to a report being released today by a nonpartisan group of leaders from government, universities and the private sector.

description: There's not much to like about Dirty Vegas. Capitol Records released this British group's self-titled debut this year, and on Wednesday night the three members played a brief, uninspired set at the World in Midtown.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Liberate Technologies Shares Fall
description: Shares in Liberate Technologies, the interactive television software maker, fell 7.58 percent yesterday after the company said its results would be poorer than expected because of internal financial restructuring and lower spending among its cable and telecommunications customers. The company, based in San Carlos, Calif., now expects a pro forma loss before amortization and other charges for its fiscal first quarter of 12 cents to 19 cents a share instead of the loss of 6 cents to 8 cents it had forecast in its last earnings announcement. ''It is a difficult market,'' Mitchell Kertzman, Liberate's chief executive, said. ''You've seen enough of that from the cable firms, with weaker spending.'' Demand for Liberate's advanced television software has lagged as telecommunications companies retrench after their late-1990's spending spree. In a statement, Mr. Kertzman said that Liberate would be able to turn a profit, minus charges, in the second half of its current fiscal year. The company said it expected to have $240 million in cash and equivalents eventually. Liberate shares fell 16 cents, to $1.95. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Panel Advises Bloomberg To Sell Stock
description: The city's Conflicts of Interest Board yesterday urged Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to sell all of his stocks, along with his interests in a hedge fund, within 90 days because the holdings -- valued at possibly tens of millions of dollars or more -- violated a provision of the City Charter.

title: Simplifying Child Seats
description: All new cars and children's car seats will be required to incorporate a new attachment system, called Latch, under federal regulations that take effect on Sunday. But the system, whose name is an acronym for ''lower anchors and tethers for children,'' has already shown up in some new cars and car seats in the last few years.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Airline Deal
description: The China Southern Airlines Company and two regional Chinese carriers will pay 206.5 million yuan ($25 million) for 59 percent of the Sichuan Airlines Company to expand routes in China's western provinces. China Southern, the nation's biggest carrier, will pay 136.5 million yuan to buy 39 percent of Sichuan Airlines, while the Shandong Airlines Company and the Shanghai Airlines Company will each pay 35 million yuan for 10 percent each, Zheng Baoan, Shandong Airline's corporate secretary, said. The transaction is one of the last in the government's push to combine 30 airlines into fewer, more efficient groups.

title: Malaysia Deporting Indonesian and Philippine Workers
description: Anger toward Malaysia intensified today after reports of death and disease among Indonesians and Filipinos recently expelled in Malaysia's crackdown on thousands of migrant laborers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Other Victims Of War
description: A government official said there were six widows for every widower in Vietnam, a result of years of war, longer lifespans for women and a higher remarriage rate for men. He said there were 2.93 million widows and 470,000 widowers in a population of 79 million people. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Bishop Looking Into Claims Priests Protected Abuser
description: The Roman Catholic bishop of Bridgeport, Conn., is investigating claims that two of his priests kept secret that a priest accused of sexually abusing children was hiding on a Caribbean island.

title: Greenspan Says Fed Could Not Prevent Market Bubble
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today that he and his fellow architects of monetary policy could have done nothing to deflate the stock market bubble of a few years ago. In fact, he said, there was no way they could be sure it was coming.

title: Growth Up in Japan in Quarter, But Pace Already Seems to Fade
description: Japan's economy grew moderately in the April-June quarter, the first expansion in more than a year, thanks to rising exports and an increase in consumer spending, but the tepid figures suggest the country's mild recovery is already losing momentum.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''For the last 25 years or more, a period well into his adult life, the defendant has been living a lie about his guilt.''

title: Networks Scramble to Fill Schedules
description: Executives at the News Corporation's Fox broadcast network, which has rights to televise the baseball playoffs and the World Series, have been scrambling to make plans in preparation for a possible baseball strike. With the timing of the crucial fall season and hundreds of millions of dollars of prime-time advertising on the line, the effects of a strike could ripple far beyond the sports broadcasts.

title: Hofstra's Offense Takes the Night Off
description: In recent seasons, Hofstra's offense had always been there when its defense failed. It racked up points against the toughest opposition. It was the foundation on which Coach Joe Gardi built his program.

title: Skakel Given 20 Years to Life for 1975 Murder
description: After he tearfully insisted that he was innocent, Michael C. Skakel was sentenced today to a prison term of 20 years to life for murdering his friend and neighbor, Martha Moxley, in 1975 outside her family's home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Japanese Submarine Sunk At Pearl Harbor Is Found
description: Like someone who has found a van Gogh at a garage sale, a research team on a routine dive near Pearl Harbor has uncovered a Japanese midget submarine that provides physical proof that submarines tried to infiltrate the harbor before the air attack of Dec. 7, 1941.

title: Investment Losses and Floods Hit Reinsurers Hard
description: Profits at the world's biggest reinsurance companies have been all but wiped out by the poor performance of their investment portfolios, the companies reported today. Recent flooding in Central Europe will also lower their bottom line, they added.

title: As Bush Campaigns, Cheney Talks of Iraq
description: President Bush traveled to Oklahoma and Arkansas today to raise $1.1 million for Republican candidates, and he joined a back-to-school event to press his education agenda, even as his vice president was talking about whether the country needed to go to war.

title: FOOTSTAR LOWERS PROFIT OUTLOOK, AND SHARES DROP 15%
description: Footstar Inc., the shoe retailer, cut its third-quarter outlook yesterday after sales in stores open more than a year slid 5.1 percent this month. The company said it now expected third-quarter earnings of 55 to 60 cents a share, before special items, rather than the 90 cents to $1.10 it had predicted. In last year's third quarter, Footstar, based in West Nyack, N.Y., turned in earnings of $1.08 a share before items and reported a bottom-line loss of $2.20 a share. Footstar's estimate excludes unusual charges for items like restructuring and those related to the liquidation of operations in Ames Department Stores. Shares of Footstar fell $2.10, or 15.5 percent, to $11.45.

title: Sports of The Times; Steroid Plan Is Juiced Up And Artificial
description: SETTLEMENT or no settlement, baseball or no baseball, the entire sport, owners and players, deserves your scorn for sweeping the only collective bargaining issue that wasn't part of the millionaires' pie-cutting contest under the artificial turf.

title: Bankers Have Cushion Should Games Stop
description: Despite Major League Baseball's industrywide debt of more than $3 billion, several bankers said that reserve funds built into many of the outstanding loans provide a cushion against business lost to a possible players' strike.

title: Market Place; ChevronTexaco Gets Some Help From $30 Oil
description: Oil prices are hovering closer to $30 a barrel than they have in months, breathing some new life into the flagging share prices of large oil companies, and few could be more relieved than ChevronTexaco.

description: * Mike Fazende was named to the new post of executive creative director at the Johnson Group, Chattanooga, Tenn. He had been principal and creative director at Publicis in Mid America in Dallas, part of the American operations of the Publicis Groupe.

description: The following is the prepared text of a speech delivered Friday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, at a symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. This text was posted on the Federal Reserve's web site.

description: In the onetime manufacturing neighborhood around Dean and Pacific Streets in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, the conversion of old warehouses and factories to housing marches on, evidenced by two buildings that are being transformed into loftlike condominium apartments.

description: Boeing Declines to Resume Talks With Its Machinists

title: 36 Hours | Flagstaff, Ariz.
description: FLAGSTAFF defies the image of Arizona as a land of spindly cactuses and sun-baked desert. At an elevation of 7,000 feet, this historic pioneer town, surrounded by ponderosa pine forests beneath the towering San Francisco Peaks, has a climate more akin to Tahoe than Tucson, with an average daily high temperature of 73 degrees in September, and a chilly low of 41 degrees at night. A lively and wildly friendly college town, with its turn-of-the-century historic district on fabled Route 66 and a resonant American Indian heritage, Flagstaff offers a surprising range of cultural, culinary and recreational opportunities for a city of just over 50,000. DAVID KIRBY

title: Sparks Control the Inside and the Game
description: The Liberty got to the Women's National Basketball Association finals by beating teams into submission with a physical game and outscoring them in the low post.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Talks With North
description: Negotiators from the two Koreas called off a formal bargaining session in Seoul in favor of behind-the-scenes talks in hopes of coming to terms on conflicting demands. The South wants the North to agree to a timetable for opening North-South rail links; the North wants the South to ship more food aid for its starving people. The negotiators met as John R. Bolton, undersecretary of state for arms control, delivered a speech in Seoul excoriating the North for developing and exporting weapons of mass destruction. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: KEANSBURG: POLICE CHIEF MONITORED

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Friday about a decision by the Bush administration to exclude more than 178 imported steel products from steep tariffs misstated the amount of steel that is now free to enter the United States under normal trade rules. It is about 3.2 million tons, or one-quarter of the imports that were subject to the initial tariffs, not one-quarter of all imports, which would be about 8 million tons.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Car Crash Kills 2
description: A car careering out of control early yesterday struck and killed a pedestrian in Sheepshead Bay and then crashed into a bus shelter, killing the driver and critically injuring a man in the bus shelter, the authorities said. Investigators have not determined what caused the accident. The driver, identified as Bruce Stein, 53, was northbound on Nostrand Avenue shortly before 3 a.m. when he struck and killed Rigoalberto Mejias, 63, as he was crossing at Avenue W, the police said. The car then hit the bus shelter, injuring Thomas Louis-Jean, 20, the police said. Mr. Stein was pronounced dead at the scene. Mr. Louis-Jean was in critical condition at Kings County Hospital Center, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Candidate Expands Lead
description: A poll by a Chicago television station shows that Representative Rod R. Blagojevich, the Democratic nominee for governor, has expanded a lead over his Republican opponent, Attorney General Jim Ryan. The CBS 2/Survey USA poll of 652 likely voters showed that if the election were today, 55 percent would support Mr. Blagojevich, and 33 percent Mr. Ryan. The margin of error was 3.9 percentage points. Mr. Blagojevich's lead has grown steadily in four similar surveys since May, when it was 48 percent to 38 percent. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

description: AFTER several years of identity confusion, Eddie Bauer is revamping its clothing line and will introduce a $12 million marketing campaign next week to restore its image as a retailer of rugged outdoor wear.

title: Generations Divided
description: Everywhere you look this summer, there are fathers and sons working out their relationships on the big screen. In films like ''Austin Powers in Goldmember,'' ''Signs'' and ''How I Killed My Father,'' boys and men bicker, mourn, manipulate and reach out for the closeness they never had. Paul Newmans character in ''Road to Perdition'' sums it up: ''Sons are put on this earth to trouble their fathers.'' And vice versa, as these films (which are available either on video or in theaters now) illustrate. ANITA GATES

title: Battle Under the Firs: The RV's vs. the Tents
description: IN 1890, a group of guys loaded down with enough whiskey and bacon to slow the healthiest of hearts tried to cross the Olympic Mountains by foot and raft. The ultimate boys' camp-out, sponsored by a Seattle newspaper as a way to interest readers in land still largely unknown, quickly soured. The whiskey ran out in a few weeks, the bacon was gone shortly thereafter, and the rain never stopped, soaking the oilskins of the post-frontier campers.

description: Becky Morgan of Wales carded a nine-under-par 63 yesterday, the lowest round of her career, to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the State Farm Classic at the Rail Golf Course in Springfield, Ill.

description: Andrew M. Cuomo intensified his attacks against H. Carl McCall today in the third debate of the Democratic gubernatorial campaign, raising familiar complaints about Mr. McCall's performance as state comptroller but using stronger language than he has on the campaign trail.

description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Oil prices rose on speculation that any increase in production by OPEC would have little effect on supplies. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 58 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $28.92 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIES, JACQUES
description: MARGOLIES-Jacques. The New York Philharmonic notes with grief and sadness the death, on August 29, of Jacques Margolies, 85, a deeply valued member of the Philharmonic's violin section. Mr. Margolies, who received a Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York scholarship at age 13, originally joined the Orchestra in 1942, but left in 1946 to pursue a solo career. He returned to the Philharmonic in 1964, and was due to retire on October 1, 2002. Over the years he enjoyed an extremely varied career, including recitals in Europe and at Town Hall and Carnegie Hall; serving as concertmaster of Ballet Theatre Orchestra under Antal Dorati, Carnegie Pops, the orchestra of Jackie Gleason's ''The Honeymooners'' television series, and the ''My Fair Lady'' orchestra; playing in dance bands, in radio orchestras, including the NBC Symphony under Toscanini, and even for tea at the Plaza Hotel. He was a member of the Philharmonic on November 14, 1943, the history-making day when Leonard Bernstein took the podium to fill in for an ailing Bruno Walter. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ruth, his daughters Eva and Caryn, his granddaughter Rachel and to his entire family. Funeral services will be private. Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Exec. Dir.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Plant To Rise In China
description: The world's largest supplier of made-to-order computer chips, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, said that it had signed an agreement to become the island's first chip maker in China, after Taiwan loosened controls on mainland investing. Taiwan Semiconductor gave no details of the preliminary agreement, disclosed in a statement to the Taiwan stock exchange. Taiwan lifted its ban this year on chip makers investing in China after companies complained that global rivals were entering China. China's annual production is projected to reach 20 billion chips by 2005, 50 billion short of domestic demand.

description: IT'S around 7 on a Saturday evening, and you've made it to Duryea's, a small, open-air seafood restaurant tucked down a side street in Montauk, in time to snag one of the picnic tables overlooking the water. Your lobster dinner ordered, you open the bottle of wine you bought at the nearby liquor store, pour generously into a plastic cup, and watch the sun dip slowly over Fort Pond Bay as you wait for your number to be called.

title: Richard Lippold, Sculptor of Metal Abstractions, Dies at 87
description: Richard Lippold, a sculptor known for radiant, expansive abstractions in metal, died on Aug. 22 at a hospital in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Lattingtown, N.Y.

title: COURT REVERSES AWARD AGAINST AMERICAN STANDARD
description: American Standard, the maker of Trane air-conditioning systems, said yesterday that it had won reversal of a jury's $18 million award to a distributor who contended that its contracts with the company were severed illegally. A federal appeals court overturned the verdict for the distributor, Haynes Trane Service Agency, which contended that its contracts were canceled without adequate notice. American Standard ended the contracts in 1995, saying Haynes had committed fraud in a rebate program. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit said Haynes ''failed to present evidence of any damages incurred.'' The panel sent the case back to Federal District Court in Denver for a new trial.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Troubles Continue As Pullout Begins
description: Uganda and Zimbabwe, two of five outside countries drawn into Congo's civil war, began pulling out their troops this week, but the United Nations asked Uganda's military to maintain a presence in the troubled northeastern town of Bunia until a power vacuum in the region is filled. Heavy fighting between rival rebel factions continued in the town of Dungu, also in the northeast. Of the other nations that have had a presence in Congo, Namibia pulled out its relatively few troops last year, Angola maintains a small number of soldiers in the country and most of the remaining foreign fighters are from Rwanda, which struck a deal to remove its troops if the Congolese government cracks down on Rwandan rebels operating from inside Congo. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Novartis Buys Company
description: Europe's third-largest drug maker, Novartis, plans to buy the Lek Pharmaceutical and Chemical Company of Slovenia for 1.186 billion Swiss francs ($800 million) to bolster its generics business. Novartis, which is based in Basel, Switzerland, said it would acquire all of the capital stock of Lek for $407 a share, more than 73 percent above the average closing price of the company's Class A shares since the start of the year. The acquisition is subject to approval by the shareholders at a meeting scheduled for Sept. 27. The purchase bolsters Novartis's capacity to make cheaper versions of GlaxoSmithKline's antibiotic Augmentin.

The onslaught of terrorism and suicide bombings has given rise to a discourse of revenge, implemented by the government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and the country's mighty military force, replacing any discourse of reconciliation and peace.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Softbank Sells Stakes
description: The Softbank Corporation, trying to meet its debt payments and to expand its broadband business, sold part of its stakes in Yahoo and UTStarcom Inc. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Officer Dies After Collapse
description: A Queens police officer died Wednesday night, apparently of a brain aneurysm that he suffered last week while chasing a man accused of threatening his former wife, the authorities said yesterday. The officer, Disdale Enton, 34, of Elmont, N.Y., was removed from life-support equipment on Wednesday, the authorities said. He had been declared brain dead the day before, they said. Deputy Inspector John E. Essig of the 113th Precinct said it appeared that Officer Enton had suffered a brain aneurysm, but added that he had no known medical problems. An autopsy was performed but further testing was needed to determine the precise cause of death, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Bewitched and Bewildered By Her Passion for a Heel
description: You may have missed ''Mad Love,'' also known as ''Juana the Mad,'' when it played last fall as part of Lincoln Center's Spanish film series. But the writer and director Vicente Aranda's fact-based historical film of sexual obsession has one of the more unforgettable openings in film history as the elderly Joan, embers of devotion still ablaze in her eyes, talks about a memory of the man she loved who brought her to ruin. It is a remembrance that lingers with her after almost half a century: the smell of her lover's armpits. This fervid note sets the tone for ''Mad Love,'' an often watchable, though goofy and lurid, blast of a costume drama set in the late 15th century.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Intel to Expand Operations In India
description: Executives from the Intel Corporation, said yesterday that the company planned to infuse further investments to expand its chip design operations in India. Intel's chief executive, Craig Barrett, who was on a two-day visit to India, made the announcement after a meeting with India's minister for communications and information technology, Pramod Mahajan, in New Delhi. ''Craig Barrett announced that a design team was being set up to engage in high-end, 32-bit Intel architecture microprocessor design and development at its India development center in Bangalore,'' the company said. The Indian center designing and developing the high-end microprocessor will be Intel's third such site, after the United States and Israel. Intel, which has 900 employees in India, is expected to quadruple its staff in five years. Since chip design is a non-capital-intensive industry, smaller, independent chip design companies are being set up and are flourishing in the country. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Union Seeks New Rate Hearings
description: Verizon's union has charged that the company used flawed data to help persuade state regulators to grant it a rate increase. The union, the Communications Workers of America, yesterday filed a petition with the regulators, the New York Public Service Commission, requesting that the commission reopen hearings on a performance plan that was adopted in February. The commission approved a $1.85-a-month rate increase for Verizon based in part on the performance plan. The union argues that proposed workforce reductions at Verizon will worsen performance. But John J. Bonomo, a Verizon spokesman, said the most recent report by the state said Verizon was ''on track'' to meet or exceed its quality requirements. Jayson Blair (NYT)

The police said the group used a tour bus line to smuggle drugs into the country from Haiti, whose lack of effective police and border control has made it a favorite port of entry for Colombian smugglers. title: The Curse of Factory Farms
description: Factory farms have become the dominant method of raising meat in America. Agribusiness loves the apparent efficiency that comes with raising thousands of animals in a single large building where they are permanently confined in stalls or pens. Most of the human labor can be automated. It takes less land, because the animals live cheek by jowl their entire lives. And it allows the concentration of enormous stocks of animals in the hands of a few corporations whose goal is usually complete vertical integration -- the control of production from birth through butchering and packaging.

Reilly, the director of the Voice of America broadcast service, resigned abruptly yesterday after nine months of controversy, particularly over the announcement that he would close five overseas news bureaus. Kenneth Tomlinson, the new chairman of V.O.A.'s oversight board, announced that David Jackson, a former Time magazine foreign correspondent who has recently been a Pentagon consultant, will become director. title: When Architects Drew Instead of Building
description: Architecture is paradoxical. Of all the visual arts, it is at once the most public and the most insular. It is everywhere seen and used but remains opaque to most people, its history, vocabulary and technology fully intelligible only to professional initiates. It is also the most conservative, if only because it costs so much to produce. And yet, because it so directly affects how people live, it is the most far-reaching in its hopes for bettering the world.

title: As One Trip Ends, A Journey Begins
description: MIKE GOGGIN, 21, folded his 6-foot-3-inch frame into a 1990 Volkswagen Golf crammed with his worldly possessions -- a few pairs of khaki cargo pants, 50 or so faded T-shirts, a few pieces of computer equipment and about 100 DVD's, plus the all-important container of Downy Wrinkle Releaser. (''Who needs an iron?'' says Mr. Goggin.) He rolled back the sunroof (the car has no air-conditioning), lamented again the lack of music (the radio and tape deck had been stolen eight weeks earlier) and headed out of Denver in the final leg of his cross-country journey, from Boston to tiny Fort Lewis College in Durango, Colo.

title: Stocks End Down on Quiet Day of Trading
description: The stock market finished August and the summer on a sour note today and investors returning from vacation next week still face the same doubts that plagued them this summer. Is the economy getting weaker or bouncing back from a short downdraft? And are corporate earnings finally going to recover? The jury is still out on both those questions.

title: New Video Releases
description: Iris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, HODA JANE
description: KAPLAN-Hoda Jane. 57, of Brooklyn, died August 21, from injuries in a car accident. Sailor, scholar, lover of subways, she lived with integrity and a full heart. South Street Seaport volunteer, captain of The Sunnyside. She studied Greek at University of Chicago, worked for the MTA for 17 years, volunteered at a shelter for homeless women and a soup kitchen. Survived by her sister Laura Kaplan and her dear friend Jeff Megerdichian. Contributions may be made to The Seamen's Church Institute, 241 Water St., NYC 10038, a homeless women's shelter or other charity.

title: Collectors With a Weakness for the Ornery
description: Wasn't late-20th-century American art strange, with its insane variety, outlandish forms and outrageous ideas? I think so; that's why I love it. And I was reminded how strange it was when I visited an exhibition at the Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore College, where objects made 40 years ago felt every bit as resistant and hard to love as they must have the day they were made.

title: Thinking About War
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only. +++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for performances last Saturday night only.

title: Off With the Cellphone (Even if It Plays Beethoven)
description: THE New York Philharmonic was playing energetically, but the gentleman on the aisle in Row M of Avery Fisher Hall was bored. He wasn't that much of a gentleman, either, for he actually pulled out his cellphone and began talking. ''Hi, how are you?'' he announced in a Texas drawl. ''What's going on?''

title: Another Blow To Executives On Options
description: Corporations across the country have halted a longstanding practice of allowing executives and directors to exercise stock options without putting up their own money in transactions that are often worth millions of dollars.

title: White House Rejects Proposal to Restrict Foreign Planes on Sept. 11
description: A proposal by top security agencies to restrict travel by foreign airlines over the sites of the Sept. 11 attacks was rejected today by White House officials, who called the approach too sweeping and unfair to those airlines.

title: 8 Utilities In Brazil Could Go On the Block
description: A number of multinational energy companies, which were once thought to be crucial to the modernization of the power sector in Brazil, are putting their Brazilian assets up for sale and preparing to quit doing business in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, HAROLD
description: ALLEN-Harold. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Ex-Premier Enters Race
description: An election official in Lahore gave preliminary approval to a bid by former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to run in parliamentary elections scheduled for October. But the country's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has repeatedly said that Mr. Sharif is banned from running in the elections or returning from exile in Saudi Arabia and it was unclear whether he would be allowed to run. His application requires approval of senior election officials in Islamabad, the capital. General Musharraf says Mr. Sharif has signed an agreement not to take part in Pakistani politics. Local election officials in Sindh Province are expected to rule today on whether another exiled former prime minister, Benazir Bhutto, can run. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: * Quick-Step, Thomasville, N.C., a division of Unilin Dcor that sells glueless laminate flooring, to Trone Advertising, High Point, N.C., as its first American agency of record. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: I.R.S. Sues for Disclosure of Offshore Accounts
description: The Internal Revenue Service went to court today in an effort to force more than 40 companies, including AOL Time Warner, eBay and American Airlines, to surrender information on customers the agency suspects are hiding income in offshore accounts.

title: Report Says City Is Paying Too Much to Build Schools
description: A state panel investigating the long-embattled process of building and repairing New York City public schools reported yesterday that the cost of constructing a classroom in the city last year was three times the national average, in part because contractors routinely added what the panel called a 20 percent ''aggravation tax'' to their bids to ''offset the bureaucratic red tape.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Mysterious Tadpole Deaths
description: At least 200 dead tadpoles, some just sprouting legs, were found in Lemon County Lake Park in Cedar Lake, where fishing and paddle-boating have been temporarily suspended until the waters are declared safe. The state's Department of Environmental Management said it could find no obvious causes, like contamination or unusual pH levels. The investigation continues. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Rabinal Journal; A Dig in Guatemala Strips Bare a Time of Terror
description: The white line markers on the soccer field seem wrong, stretching lengthwise from goal to goal. So do the deep holes and piles of dirt scattered about. And inside that damp cold dirt lies something terrible.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Remains Found
description: Three coin-sized human bone fragments were found Wednesday night on the roof of a building near the World Trade Center site, the authorities said yesterday. It was unclear if the bones came from the same person. Construction workers found them shortly before 7 p.m. on the rooftop of 130 Liberty Street, on the southern edge of the excavation site. The fragments will be tested to determine if they match DNA samples provided by relatives of those killed Sept. 11. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Port Authority Extends Lease of a Renamed Newark Airport
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved the terms of a lease yesterday to extend its operation of Newark International Airport to 2065, and agreed to rename the airport Newark Liberty International in honor of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airport Planned
description: Hochtief, Germany's largest building company, and the property group IVG Holding will build and operate an airport for Berlin, state authorities said. Airport Berlin Brandenburg International, as it will be called, is a $2.9 billion project scheduled to open at the end of 2008 in Schnefeld, the site of East Germany's former airport. Berlin's airports in the Tegel and Tempelhof districts will then be closed. The new airport will have a passenger capacity of 20 million a year and can be expanded to 30 million. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Panel Turns Focus to Founder In Global Crossing Investigation
description: Gary Winnick, the billionaire chairman and founder of Global Crossing, may have helped oversee the company's aggressive use of swapping communications capacity on its fiber optic network with other companies, according to documents obtained by a Congressional committee.

title: Russian Defense Aide Says Missile Shot Down Helicopter
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30  Russia's defense minister, Sergei B. Ivanov, said today that a shoulder-fired missile shot down the military transport helicopter that crashed in Chechnya last week, but he angrily blamed Russian military commanders for the disaster and vowed to punish them.

title: When King Midget Ruled the Autobahn
description: IN a television commercial for the Cadillac Escalade EXT, a sport utility vehicle, two cars drive up to one empty parking space at exactly the same time. Who's entitled to it? They solve the problem by sharing the spot -- the Escalade parks, and the second car, a tiny roadster, drives up into its cavernous cargo area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, BEATRICE
description: GROSSMAN-Beatrice. I have lost a cherished, beautiful friend. To have touched her life somewhere along the line, is to have enriched one's own. Claire Vogelman

title: Improvement, Albeit Slight, Is Noted in Indian Point Safety
description: Federal regulators announced yesterday that the new owner of the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant has made improvements there significant enough to raise the plant's dismal safety rating, if only slightly.

title: Environmentalists vs. the Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: TALKS WITH NORTH Negotiators from the two Koreas called off a formal bargaining session in Seoul in favor of behind-the-scenes talks in hopes of coming to terms on conflicting demands. The South wants the North to agree to a timetable for opening North-South rail links; the North wants the South to ship more food aid for its starving people. The negotiators met as John R. Bolton, undersecretary of state for arms control, delivered a speech in Seoul excoriating the North for developing and exporting weapons of mass destruction. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKULA, BERNARD B.
description: PAKULA-Bernard B. The employees of ORB, Inc. mourn the loss of Bernard B. Pakula, father of Andrew S. Pakula, our CEO and Founder. Our deepest sympathy goes to Andrew and the entire Pakula family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERSH, MURRAY
description: KIERSH-Murray. On August 28, 2002. Beloved husband of Betty. Devoted father of Warren and Steve, and loving grandfather of Laura, Sandy, David, Sarah and Mark. Veteran of WWII and founder of Salisbury Sales Corp. He will be remembered and missed by all of those who loved him. Service today, August 30, at 10 AM, at Gutterman's, Woodbury.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 6 about a federal study based on Long Island that found no links between breast cancer and environmental factors like pollution misstated how breast cancer rates in Nassau County compared with the national average when the study began in the 1990's. The rates were 1.1 percent higher than the national average, not 30 percent higher.

title: Florida Man Sentenced for Holding A.T.M. Cash
description: A Florida carpenter who pleaded guilty in March to illegal possession of $4.9 million stolen from an A.T.M. company was sentenced today to seven years and one month in prison and fined $100,000.

title: Yankees Don't Like Being an Easy Target
description: Alex Rodriguez, the $25 million man, raised his eyebrows, shook his head and might have wanted to cross his fingers and toes when he revealed two weeks ago that he had not been verbally abused by fans as much this season as last season. Rodriguez could be the target for every fan's venom over today's strike date because he makes more money than any other player in baseball, but he has not had hundreds of bogus bills floating in his face.

title: The Curtain May Fall, But the Routine Goes On
description: The alarm clock rang at 6 this morning in a small, untidy office under the stands behind the right-center-field fence in Cinergy Field, the home of the Cincinnati Reds, a ballpark that is on its last legs in a sport in danger of stumbling to a halt.

title: Israel Says Gaza Family Was Killed By Mistake
description: It was after 11 p.m. on Wednesday, Sharif al-Hajeen recalled today, when Israeli tank shells crashed with deadly accuracy into the plot of fig trees and grapevines in the dunes south of Gaza City where his family works days and sleeps nights during the summer picking season.

title: Summoned by a Princess to Air Dirty Royal Laundry
description: The first thing you might expect from a film called ''The Biographer: The Secret Life of Princess Di'' would be Princess Di. Or, more accurately, Diana, Princess of Wales. But no.

title: Make Way for DVD
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOROD, BOB
description: BOROD-Bob. Of Martha's Vineyard, MA, August 25. Broadway production stage manager. Nieces, nephew, cousins, devoted friends in the theatre community survive. Service Sunday, September 1, 11 AM, Sugarman Sinai Chapel, 458 Hope St., Providence, RI. 401-331-8094. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares/EFA.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Last Task at Andersen: Turning Out the Lights
description: After 89 years, Arthur Andersen will cease to be an auditor of public companies tomorrow.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kursk-Like Problems On Other Subs
description: Investigators into the explosion and sinking of the nuclear submarine Kursk in August 2000 found that torpedos on some other Russian subs were leaking a hydrogen peroxide propellant in a manner similar to a leak believed to have caused the disaster, the government daily Rossiskaya Gazeta reported. In printed excerpts from the official inquiry into the accident, prosecutors stated that torpedoes on other submarines displayed leaky gaskets and evidence of corrosion. Investigators concluded last month that the Kursk sank after propellant leaked, and came in contact with kerosene and metal, touching off a blast. One hundred and eighteen people died in the accident. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Heaven and Earth at Violent Odds in an Indian Epic
description: The volcanic passions that rumble through ''Agni Varsha: The Fire and the Rain,'' a dense, colorful dramatization of a portion of the Indian epic ''Mahabharata,'' are literally earthshaking. In one scene, a vengeful demon explodes out of a hilltop. Late in the movie, a deity materializes and tempts a human character with an offer to turn back time.

title: Airlines Allowed to Stop Asking About Luggage
description: Thomas Flood, a Census Bureau statistician from Bowie, Md., had just finished answering the two familiar questions posed to airline travelers for 16 years when he learned that the inquiries about luggage were ending.

title: Jets Show Martin How Much He Means
description: When Curtis Martin learned this week that the Jets were about to give him a blockbuster contract extension, he went into the shower and began to cry, amazed that the Jets thought so much of him.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fewer Teaching Fellows Fail
description: Almost one of eight new teachers who took part in a fast-track training program this summer failed one or both of the exams required for certification, an improvement over the previous year, school officials said yesterday. Such teaching fellows are career-changers or recent college graduates who agreed to teach in some of the city's most troubled schools. About 250 of this year's fellows, or about 13 percent of nearly 2000, failed one or both of the tests, which they took earlier this month. Last year 21 percent of fellows failed one or both tests. About 150 of the fellows who failed this year's exams were told yesterday that they could stay on as uncertified teachers or as substitutes. They will have up to a year to pass the tests. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: McDonald's To Expand
description: The McDonald's Corporation said that it planned to invest $50 million to double the number of its restaurants in Ukraine by 2007 to meet growing demand. McDonald's said it planned to open 14 restaurants in Kiev, the Black Sea port of Odessa, and other large cities through 2003 and double its staff to 6,000 in five years. McDonald's has spent $76 million building 49 restaurants since opening its doors in Kiev in 1997.

title: Every Which Way to Paint
description: IT'S amazing how much you can learn about one medium over the course of viewing a few focused, often modest and seemingly unrelated museum exhibitions. Take the five shows, spread among four museums, that I visited on a sultry summer day here.

title: India Again Delays Process Of Selling 2 Big Oil Stakes
description: The opposition of a central cabinet member appears to be bogging down India's efforts to step up the pace of privatization.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Jail Term For H.I.V. Exposure
description: A 19-year-old Chicago college student attending SiTanka Huron University in Huron will serve four months in jail for having unprotected sex with a woman who did not know he has H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Judge Tim Dallas Tucker of Circuit Court in Madison also ordered the student, Nikko Briteramos, not to have unprotected intercourse unless he tells partners he has the virus. Mr. Briteramos must also perform 200 hours of community service. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Talks On Police Raises
description: A state board mediating the bitter contract dispute over raises for city police officers will resume deliberations next week in an effort to reach an agreement. Union officials said yesterday that they hoped the panel, the Public Employment Relations Board, would reject a proposal to give officers a 14 percent raise over two years. The union has sought a 21.9 percent raise for its membership, whose starting salary is $31,305. The last contract included two years in which the police received no pay increase. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCGRATH, MARNIE ELI ZABETH
description: McGRATH - Marnie Eli zabeth. 4/16/70-8/30/00. Beloved in life, beloved in memory.

title: For the Modern Artist's Muse, Love Is Not Enough
description: THE LIVES OF THE MUSES

title: State Dept. Is Holding a Seminar Next Week on Anti-U.S. Trends
description: The State Department will hold a conference next week on the spread of anti-American attitudes around the world, officials say.

title: Centuries Of Turkish Delights
description: One of the peculiar customs in the Americana field is the inclusion of Oriental carpets in sales of Colonial furniture, ceramics and silver. Such carpets are also displayed over tables and on floors in the Early American period rooms in places like the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Oriental carpets and American antiques go together like peas and carrots.

title: Expectations Are Different For Kickoff Classic Teams
description: Maryland is replacing a quarterback, starting its season without its star running back and hoping its all-American middle linebacker has recovered from back surgery. Believe it or not, the Terrapins may be in better shape than Notre Dame.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Big Girl's Birthday

title: WADDELL & REED AGREES TO BUY UNIT OF INVESTORS GROUP
description: Waddell & Reed Financial has agreed to buy Mackenzie Investment Management, the United States investment-management unit of Canada's biggest mutual fund company, Investors Group, for $74 million. Holders of Mackenzie, based in Boca Raton, Fla., will get a minimum of $10.8 million, or $4.50 a share, for their 14 percent stake, Waddell & Reed said. Waddell & Reed will also pay $30 million plus excess working capital, estimated to be about $33.2 million, by the end of the year. Waddell & Reed is based in Overland Park, Kan. Investors Group is based in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: Boeing Halts Negotiations With Union
description: With 25,000 machinists threatening to walk out, the Boeing Company yesterday rejected a request from the nation's top mediator to resume negotiations.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Aid For Bank Mergers
description: The Financial Services Agency, the nation's top financial regulator, said it would ask for a budget next year of 1 trillion yen ($8.5 billion) to help small banks merge. The plan includes tax breaks, lower fees and less paperwork to help banks merge computer systems and close branches. The government is also considering a temporary increase in deposit insurance coverage to reassure investors and savers about the stability of the banks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  UNGER, PETER
description: UNGER-Peter. Dearest daddy. August 30, 1952, 50 years. Lovingly remembered. Mario

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Revenue Forecast Reduced
description: UBS Warburg cut its 2002 and 2003 revenue growth forecasts for the global semiconductor and chip equipment industries yesterday, citing sluggish demand for personal computers and telecommunications equipment. UBS now expects 2002 chip revenue to fall as much as 2 percent or rise as much as 2 percent. It previously predicted sales would be unchanged or grow as much as 5 percent. It changed its forecast for chip equipment revenue to a drop of 20 percent to 25 percent from a decline of 15 percent to 20 percent. The chip market has yet to rebound from its worst year ever in 2001 as consumers hold off buying products. UBS also cut its forecast for 2003 worldwide chip sales growth to a range of 9 to 13 percent from 15 to 20 percent. The equipment growth forecast was reduced to 15 to 25 percent from 30 to 35 percent.

title: Thinking About War
description: To the Editor:

title: Jamaica Resort Discount
description: Book by Sept. 25, and save $900 off a six-day stay at any of three Couples resorts in Jamaica. The valid travel dates are Jan. 1 to Dec. 26, 2003. From Jan. 1 through April 11, for example, the rate is $1,980 a couple (regularly $2,880). The rates include all meals, drinks, snacks, water sports, scuba diving, golf, airport transfers, taxes and tips. Information: (800) 268-7537 or www.couples.com .

title: Destitution Seen For Palestinians
description: The senior United Nations official in the region today painted a devastating picture of the Palestinian economy under Israeli siege in which a large majority was ''scrambling to survive'' on less than $2 a day and despair was fueling ever greater extremism.

title: Striking a Deal
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Style: French Twist
description: Coming soon to a theatre near you: "Eight Women" -- a campy whodunit starring the best-dressed cast on the planet.

title: Liberty Needs Bounces, Or the Series Is Finished
description: Liberty Coach Richie Adubato was thinking aloud yesterday about the one that got away.

title: Juries Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Clintons and Cuomo, Apart at the Fair
description: For a time yesterday afternoon, it seemed as if everyone in central New York had shaken hands or posed for a picture with former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, or at least strained for a glimpse of them, at the State Fair in Syracuse.

title: This Time, a Tie Breaks the Deadlock
description: After the baseball players union trounced the owners in the last labor negotiating round, in the mid-1990's, the union was repeatedly warned that the players' soaring salaries were endangering their sport's health.

title: A Big Spending Race Is On For a Small Bloc of Voters
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Tom Golisano have spent more than $10 million between them in the last three weeks wooing the 200,000 members of the Independence Party in the race for governor. It is a stunning amount of money that underscores the strategic importance of that party's influence on November's election.

title: A City That's Down but Not Out
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: No Fun Allowed
description: The police arrested 17 young men and women for immoral behavior and listening to illegal music -- Western music or songs sung by a woman -- in a cabin in the Caspian Sea area near Bandar Anzali, the newspaper Keyhan reported. The daily reported that they had offered the police $175 to buy their release and that bribery was added to their charges. The mingling of sexes and partying is considered a crime in Iran. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the search for Osama bin Laden misstated the location of the Shah-i-Kot Valley, the site of the biggest American ground battle in the war to oust the Taliban. It is 100 miles south of Kabul, not southwest.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about views in the White House and Congress on the possibility of a military strike against Iraq misspelled the surname of the White House counsel in some copies. He is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez. The article also misstated Senator Robert C. Byrd's middle initial.

title: National Briefing | Washington: United Way Ouster Urged
description: The largest regional affiliate of the scandal-plagued United Way in the Washington area has called for removal of its chief executive and greater accountability. The Fairfax-Falls Church, Va., United Way is the fourth of the eight affiliates of the United Way of the National Capital Area to seek the resignation or ouster of Norman O. Taylor, whose management has been called into question by a federal investigation of the group. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: A Couch For Authors In Need of One
description: WRITERS who suffer in solitude also have a well-known antidote: the artists' colony. Whether its a cozy cabin in the woods or a rambling Victorian mansion on a hill, these legendary creative havens provide picnic-basket lunches, rarefied company and literary cocktail parties replete with sexual frisson and the latest publishing dish. Even if you don't produce many pages at a Yaddo or MacDowell, at least you can boast you've slept in the same bed as Sylvia Plath or Truman Capote or have met, say, Oscar Hijuelos.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Economic Growth
description: Hong Kong's economy unexpectedly grew in the second quarter as rising exports and tourism countered a drop in consumer spending caused by record unemployment. Gross domestic product rose 0.4 percent from the first quarter, seasonally adjusted, the government said. That followed a 0.2 percent pace in the previous quarter; economists had expected no growth. Rising exports and growing tourism from mainland China were not enough to end a five-quarter run of growth below 1 percent, as domestic spending fell and companies moved to China to cut costs. ''The near-term forecast for the domestic economy remains bleak,'' the government said in its report. ''Consumers may still be less willing to spend, while companies may continue to hold back on their investment plans.''

title: Expos Get 4 Years of New Life
description: The Montreal Expos live.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Investment Bank Cuts Back
description: Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, the investment banking unit of Allianz, will shut its foreign-exchange, government debt and equity trading business in Mexico and lay off 20 executives to reduce costs. The move is part of a strategy to scale back trading in markets like Latin America where the bank has had trouble competing with larger rivals, said Roberto Mena, a spokesman for Dresdner. The bank aims to build up underwriting and merger and acquisition work, he said. Allianz bought Dresdner Bank last year for $20 billion and is seeking to return it to profitability by next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economic Output Is Up
description: Canada's gross domestic product grew at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 4.3 percent in the second quarter, propelled by strong consumer demand for services, a recovery in business spending on machinery and equipment, and inventory replenishment, Statistics Canada said. Though the latest figure falls short of the 6.3 percent advance in the first quarter, it is further evidence that Canada's economy is outperforming that of the United States. Economists are divided whether the Bank of Canada will again raise its overnight lending rate at its policy review on Wednesday. The rate, currently at 2.75 percent, has been increased three times this year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Bhutto Thwarted In Election Bid
description: A local election official in southern Pakistan rejected an attempt by former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto to register for parliamentary elections scheduled for October. Ms. Bhutto's supporters immediately vowed to appeal the decision and accused the country's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, of pressuring the official into blocking her bid. A spokesman for Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan Peoples Party said her papers were rejected on the ground that she was convicted of absconding from the country while facing corruption charges in 1999. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about Saudi Arabia's efforts to improve its image in the United States referred incorrectly in some copies to Representative Hale Boggs of Louisiana, the father of Thomas Hale Boggs Jr., who founded a public relations company hired by Saudi Arabia. He served as the House majority leader, not speaker of the House.

title: Beliefs; Where was God? It is a question that might be asked every day -- or perhaps not at all.
description: Where was God on Sept. 11? That question is the title of a documentary to be shown on many PBS stations next week. It is the title of at least two of the torrent of religious books on the attacks and their aftermath -- and a theme in many others. Undoubtedly, it has been the title of thousands of sermons.

title: Long Islander Is Out
description: The unlikely run of Long Island's Bea Bielik ended inside Arthur Ashe Stadium yesterday when eighth-seeded Justine Henin figured out Bielik's mix of power and slice to win, 7-5, 6-1, in the third round.

title: A.F.C. Scouting Reports
description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)
