description: CANADA: ECONOMIC OUTPUT IS UP Canada's gross domestic product grew at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 4.3 percent in the second quarter, propelled by strong consumer demand for services, a recovery in business spending on machinery and equipment, and inventory replenishment, Statistics Canada said. Though the latest figure falls short of the 6.3 percent advance in the first quarter, it is further evidence that Canada's economy is outperforming that of the United States. Economists are divided whether the Bank of Canada will again raise its overnight lending rate at its policy review on Wednesday. The rate, currently at 2.75 percent, has been increased three times this year.

title: At Wrigley, Sky Is Blue And the Fans Are Not
description: The sun shined and the fans filed in as baseball backed away from the abyss today, forging a new labor agreement that saved the remainder of the 2002 season and even managed to keep every game on today's schedule intact, starting with this afternoon's Cubs-Cardinals contest at the sport's great old reliable, Wrigley Field.

title: Weak Spell for Shares Reaches the Five-Month Mark
description: The stock market finished August on a sour note yesterday, leaving investors facing the same doubts that have plagued them for months.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday about the MTV Video Music Awards misidentified the musicians performing with the singer Axl Rose, under the name Guns N' Roses. They were a new band, not a reunion of the original band from the 1980's.

title: Demographics in Queens District Heat Up Race for Newly Created Seat in State Senate
description: Politicians throughout New York often insist that their districts are among the city's most diverse. One place where that claim rings particularly true is in the redrawn 13th Senate District, in Corona and Elmhurst, Queens.

title: LAST-MINUTE DEAL IN BASEBALL TALKS PREVENTS A STRIKE
description: For the first time in 30 years, Major League Baseball and its players reached agreement on a new labor contract without a work stoppage yesterday, concluding the deal a few hours short of a strike.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Christian Video To Be Distributed
description: Evangelical Christians plan to mail a video about the life of Jesus to each of the state's 1.8 million households the state the week of Sept. 11. The special edition of the Warner Brothers film, produced by Campus Crusade for Christ, has an introduction by three New York firefighters who say Christian faith sustained them through their World Trade Center recovery work. Some local religious leaders expressed misgivings about the video's possible divisiveness on a day of national unity. The distribution coincides with major Jewish and Hindu holy days. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Henman Beats Norman, and Both Are Satisfied
description: Tim Henman and Dick Norman share a style of play, a tricky, booming serve and a tall, powerful presence, the kind that people once feared would dominate men's tennis. They took the Grandstand court together yesterday morning for a second-round match at the United States Open, where all comparisons promptly came to a screeching halt.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Life Sentences For Internet Cafe Fire
description: Two teen-age boys convicted of arson in a late-night fire that killed 25 in a crowded Internet cafe in June have been sentenced to life in prison. The boys, aided by a girl who received a 12-year sentence and a 13-year-old boy who was sent to juvenile detention, reportedly set the deadly fire in anger after being denied admission to the cafe, in Beijing's university district. The cafe was a firetrap and the disaster led police to shut down many unlicensed Internet cafes. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Dispute Over New Court Perils Widened Alliance
description: The struggle between the Bush administration and Europe over the new International Criminal Court is placing some candidate nations for both the European Union and NATO in a severe political bind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSER, ABRAHAM
description: TESSER-Abraham. At 86, on August 26, 2002. Beloved husband of Toby (Turkel). Devoted father of Gary Charles and Steven Barry, Ph.D. Dear brother of Florence Tesser and Ruth Leventhal. Cherished uncle of many loving nieces and nephews. Mr. Tesser graduated City College after earning his CPA. He served in the U.S. Army and practiced public accounting for over 50 years. He was a 32nd Degree Freemason. He was respected and beloved by all, a dear, strong, gentle man who will be greatly missed.

title: In Fight Over Women, Masters Gives Up Ads
description: Rejecting demands that it quickly add women as members, Augusta National Golf Club said yesterday that it would do without commercial sponsors for the 2003 Masters telecast because the sponsors could come under pressure from women's groups.

description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)

title: Professors Offer A Reality Check For Politicians
description: When Leonard Wantchekon set out to investigate what kind of campaign messages are most effective, he could have done the standard review of past political advertisements or interviewed candidates, consultants and voters. But Professor Wantchekon, who teaches politics at New York University and is an expert in game theory, wanted a more scientific approach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARESTY, GERALD AND WIFE JOSEPHINE (NEE RIZZO)
description: ARESTY-Gerald and wife Josephine (nee Rizzo). Of Harding Township, N.J. Died August 29 from injuries in a car accident. Loving parents of Jeffrey (and wife Patty), David (and wife Patti). Beloved grandparents. Gerald is survived by brothers Maurice (wife Sare), Joseph (wife Kitty), Jerome (wife Lorraine) and sisters Ann Camhi and Esther Granite. Josephine is survived by brothers Dr. John (wife Gloria) and Charles (wife Ruth). Gerald was a partner in Alfred Dunner, Inc. and Josephine was an accomplished sculptor. They were devoted supporters of the Morristown Memorial Hospital, The Scholarship Program at the University of Miami, United Jewish Appeal and Temple B'nai-Or. Services Sunday, 11AM, Temple B'nai-Or, 60 Overlook Road, Morristiwon, N.J. 07960. Contributions may be made to Temple B'nai-Or.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airlines Investigated
description: The Fair Trade Commission will look into whether the Japan Airlines Company and two other airlines violated Japan's monopoly law by cutting fares on a route also operated by an upstart carrier, the Skynet Asia Airways Company. JAL, the All Nippon Airways Company and the Japan Air System Company, the nation's three largest airlines, all plan to match Skynet's fares on flights from Haneda airport in Tokyo to Miyazaki, in southern Japan. JAL and Japan Air Systems plan to begin consolidating routes in October, the first step in their planned merger. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Kenya's Retiring Leader Fires Vice President Over Succession
description: President Daniel arap Moi fired his vice president today in an attempt to quash a revolt within his ruling party among top aides who refuse to back his handpicked successor.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Spat With Taiwan
description: A diplomatic row has flared over whether a senior Taiwanese labor official, Chen Chu, can travel to Thailand to attend the signing of a major labor agreement. Thailand first barred Ms. Chen because its ''one China'' policy recognizes only mainland China. Then when Taiwan threatened to scuttle the deal, Thailand offered a tourist visa without an invitation to the signing itself. Ms. Chen rejected the compromise. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: The First 'Afronaut' Plans a Mission Back Home
description: PERHAPS the most obvious question to ask Mark Shuttleworth is this: after making half a billion dollars from the Internet bubble at the age of 26 and, two years later, buying a $20 million ride in space to become what Nelson Mandela called the first ''Afronaut,'' what do you do for an encore?

title: Tax Cuts, Again
description: President Bush's summer idyll in Texas, which comes to a close this weekend, has been interrupted more than once by bad economic news. As a result, the White House says Mr. Bush may present yet another package of tax cuts when he returns to work after Labor Day. Some of the proposals are said to be based on ideas proposed at the stage-managed economic ''forum'' in Waco, including new tax incentives to encourage stock market investments and expanded tax breaks for investors who have suffered losses. Details are skimpy, but based on what officials are saying, it looks as if Mr. Bush's proposals would do little to help the economy while deepening federal deficits over the long term.

title: RAYTHEON TO REORGANIZE SEVERAL DIVISIONS AND CUT JOBS
description: The Raytheon Company, the military contractor, said yesterday that it would split its military and air-traffic work into seven businesses. Raytheon, which is based in Lexington, Mass., will eliminate jobs after the reorganization, a spokesman, David Polk, said. The company will not know the exact number of jobs affected for a month, he said. The businesses include integrated military systems, intelligence and information systems, missile systems, network systems, space and airborne systems, technical services and homeland security.

description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Worry, Yanks Will Keep Spending
description: George Steinbrenner was pacing on his horse farm in Ocala, Fla., yesterday when a new collective bargaining agreement that was about subduing the Yankees and reaching a mythic form of competitive balance was finally reached. Not surprisingly, Steinbrenner, one hand on his wallet and the other on his checkbook, did not want to discuss the agreement. Not yet.

title: Lesson Plans for Sept. 11 Offer a Study in Discord
description: The anniversary of Sept. 11 has set off the latest skirmish in the classroom culture wars.

title: West Nile Cases Are Reported Upstate and in Connecticut
description: Two men in their 70's, one in upstate New York and one in Old Greenwich, Conn., have been sickened by the West Nile virus, health officials announced yesterday.

title: German Unit Will Pull Out If U.S. Attacks
description: If the United States attacks Iraq, Germany will withdraw its specialized unit designed to respond to nuclear, chemical and biological warfare from Kuwait, the German defense minister said in an interview published today.

title: Some Somber Moments at MTV Awards
description: This year's MTV Video Music Awards were moved to August from early September to avoid the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. But the show, telecast live Thursday night from Radio City Music Hall, couldn't escape the sobering memories. It opened with Bruce Springsteen performing ''The Rising,'' a song about a rescuer killed in the fire, with a singalong chorus that turns it into a ritual of memorial and resurrection. Mr. Springsteen and his E Street Band, who were performing at the Museum of Natural History, played an hourlong set for the fans gathered in the rain.

Grandmother of Steven, Jeffrey and Colin Kaplan. Funeral service Sunday, 12:30PM at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Westchester Avenue, Rye, N.Y. title: This Time, Tie Breaks Deadlock
description: After the baseball players union trounced the owners in the last labor negotiating round, in the mid-1990's, the union was repeatedly warned that the players' soaring salaries were endangering their sport's health.

title: Breast Cancer Mythology on Long Island
description: The search for environmental causes for a supposed breast cancer epidemic on Long Island is beginning to look like a wild goose chase. The cornerstone study in a $30 million federal effort to unravel the contentious issue reported this month that it could find no link between breast cancer and the prime environmental suspects, such as DDT and PCB's. It identified only a modest link, possibly due to chance, to pollutants in car exhaust and cigarette smoke. More results are still to be published, and breast cancer activists are calling for yet more investigations into a wider array of chemicals. But the negative findings suggest it is time to rein in this fruitless quest. There may simply be no significant environmental cause of breast cancer on Long Island, or if there is, it may be undetectable.

title: BALL CORP. IS ACQUIRING GERMAN MAKER OF SODA CANS
description: The Ball Corporation, the maker of Ball jars, agreed yesterday to buy Schmalbach-Lubeca, a German maker of soda cans, for 900 million euros ($886 million) in cash. Ball, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., will also assume 300 million euros in liabilities. Schmalbach-Lubeca is being sold by its owners, Allianz, the German insurance company, and E.ON, the large German utility. Ball, originally a maker of home-canning jars, is expanding in Europe, where sales of soda cans are growing faster. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

But after Schiano left, Cubit found himself sitting in the living room with the Scarlet Knights' new offensive coordinator, and the tone of the discussion changed.

title: To Greenspan, 90's Bubble Was Beyond Reach of Fed
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, defended the central bank today against criticism that it had mishandled the rise and fall of the stock market and said that the Fed could not have prevented the bubble on Wall Street without damaging the economy.

title: Transplant May Have Led To West Nile In Man, 71
description: Federal and Florida health officials said last night that they were investigating the possibility that a 71-year-old man had developed West Nile fever from a recent organ transplant.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GEORGIA: QAEDA SUSPECT ARRESTED Government security forces sweeping through the Pankisi Gorge arrested a Moroccan man suspected of belonging to Al Qaeda, a spokesman for the State Security Ministry, Nika Laliashvili, said. The man, whom he did not identify, was detained on Thursday carrying a fake French passport, he said. About 1,000 security troops fanned out across the gorge this week trying to establish control over a lawless region considered a haven for dozens of Islamic militants and for Chechen rebels fighting Russian troops in Chechnya. Mr. Laliashvili said Georgia would ask other countries to cooperate in an investigation and would consider requests for extradition.

title: Viloria Earns 12-Round Decision
description: Before Brian Viloria could hit Javier Jaibo Lagos last night, he had to catch him. Viloria chased Lagos for 12 rounds and punched him enough to earn a 12-round decision and the North American Boxing Federation flyweight title at Cipriani in Midtown Manhattan.

description: MORTILLARO-Louis F. August 28, 2002. Veteran of World War II, retired Sargent Major. Served his country until 1985 from Fort Hamilton Base. He loved his country and served it well. He loved his family even more. Beloved husband to Anne, beloved father and father-inlaw to Lois, Gerard, Francine, Anthony and Alfred. His grandchildren Geoffrey, Alexandra, Isabella and Sofia loved him dearly and will miss him very much. He will be missed and greatly remembered for his kindness, good will and generosity. Mass Saturday, August 31, St. Mary Star of the Sea, Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, NY.

Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the sale of Mackenzie Investment Management, a unit of Investors Group of Canada, to Waddell & Reed Financial for $74 million misstated the terms of the deal. A payment of $30 million plus excess working capital, estimated to be about $33.2 million, is included in the $74 million figure; it is not extra. Also, shareholders of Mackenzie will receive $4.05 a share, not $4.50, for their 14 percent stake.

title: Kuerten Shows Signs Of a Healthy Recovery
description: Gustavo Kuerten's elastic backhand certainly looked familiar yesterday as he made surprisingly quick work of second-seeded Marat Safin at the United States Open. Kuerten's right hand looked less familiar. Before leaving his Brazilian hometown, Florianopolis, to come to New York, he decided to have a large, smiling sun tattooed on it.

title: A Newspaper Apologizes For Photos
description: The managing editor of The Philadelphia Daily News apologized yesterday for the newspaper's decision to publish 15 photographs of nonwhite suspects to illustrate a story on fugitives wanted for murder.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and the Quotation of the Day yesterday about the sentencing of Michael C. Skakel for the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley misspelled the surname of the Connecticut Superior Court judge who sentenced him. He is John F. Kavanewsky Jr., not Kavanewski.

description: Two major titles remained to be decided as the world championships were winding down here today.

title: No Worries for Chrebet: He Receives 7-Year Extension
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet spent much of tonight's 23-16 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles on the sideline with the rest of the starters, a visor on his head and much more money in his pocket. Chrebet jokes that it is as if someone has written a script of his life. Today it would have been called ''Wayne's Excellent Adventure.''

title: Bomb Scare Forces Evacuation Of Lobby at the Roosevelt Hotel
description: Police officers removed what looked like a pipe bomb from the lobby of the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday afternoon as frightened guests waited in their rooms above. Later, the police said that the device was a fake.

title: Airlines Must Inspect Boeing Fuel Pumps
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the nation's commercial airlines to check more than 1,400 planes manufactured by the Boeing Company to see if they are equipped with an improperly wired fuel pump that could cause an explosion in the rare event that fuel goes below minimal levels.

title: Candidate Responds To Criticism By Sharpton
description: Charlie King, who is running for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor, issued a statement yesterday responding sharply to criticism from the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: City Is Ordered Not to Use Jail As a Shelter
description: A Manhattan judge ordered the city yesterday to stop using a vacant Bronx jail as a temporary shelter for homeless families by Sept. 25.

title: Janusz Bardach, 83, Gulag Survivor and Leading Plastic Surgeon
description: Dr. Janusz Bardach, a plastic surgeon who improved techniques for treating cleft lip and cleft palate and who wrote an acclaimed account of his life in Soviet labor camps in the early 1940's, died on Aug. 16 in Iowa City, his home. He was 83.

description: Hundreds of people who say they were sexually abused by priests have sued the Roman Catholic Church this year, and advocates for victims and lawyers who represent the clergy say that in no case have the accusations been ruled downright false.

title: Party Assigns Itself Blame Over Inaction On Charter
description: Members of the Independence Party yesterday took the blame for a decision by a mayoral commission on charter reform not to pursue nonpartisan elections this November, an idea the party had strongly supported.

title: China Muslim Group Planned Terror, U.S. Says
description: A little-known Muslim group from western China that the United States recently branded as terrorist had planned attacks on Western embassies in neighboring Kyrgyzstan, an American official asserted today.

title: Six Arrested in Stock Manipulation Case
description: Two former principals of Walsh Manning Securities and a former officer at Stratton Oakmont were among six men arrested on Thursday on charges of manipulating shares of companies in a scheme that reportedly netted $30 million.

title: Pierce Leads U.S. Past Germany
description: Dirk Nowitzki's German national team gave the United States some tense moments and a taste of raw vulnerability last night in Indianapolis. But the United States team kept its dream alive with a 104-87 victory in the preliminary round of the World Basketball Championships.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Kidnapping Fans Tensions
description: Hundreds of heavily armed Macedonian police officers sealed off a valley between Tetovo and Gostivar where ethnic Albanian gunmen are believed to be holding five Macedonians hostage, fanning fears of renewed conflict in the former Yugoslav republic. Western powers, which brokered a peace deal last summer to end six months of ethnic fighting, appealed for an end to provocations ahead of elections to be held next month. The kidnappers are demanding the release of a group of demobilized ethnic Albanian guerrillas who were arrested this week and charged with murdering two Macedonian policemen. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Told to Trim Costs, New York Libraries Reduce Their Hours
description: Most public libraries in Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx, including the majestic central library at West 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, will be cutting back to a five-day week over the coming months in response to recent citywide budget cuts, library officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALF, ROBERT
description: HALF-Robert. Dad, when did all of the wonders become memories? I miss holding your hand and being an audience of one. Mom, Peg and the children know you are smiling down on us all. I love you and think of you always. Nan

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Representative Indicted
description: State Representative Ronald E. Davis has been indicted on 13 federal felony counts, including money laundering and fraud. Mr. Davis and a companion are charged with forging diplomatic passports for two Texas men for $100,000, the indictment says. It also charges that they made false statements to a bank in three loan applications. If convicted, Mr. Davis, a seven-term Republican, faces up to 30 years in prison and a $1 million fine, the United States attorney's office said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Russia Says Missile Downed Copter, but Faults Its Military
description: Russia's defense minister, Sergei B. Ivanov, said today that a surface-to-air missile shot down the military transport helicopter that crashed in a minefield in Chechnya last week, killing 118 people. But he also angrily found fault with Russian military commanders and vowed to punish them.

title: No Sympathy for a Sibling
description: Playing in her first Grand Slam tournament, Dinara Safina was quickly dismissed in the second round Wednesday by top-seeded Serena Williams, losing, 6-0, 6-1. But her older brother Marat Safin scoffed when asked if there was anything he had said to help ease the pain of her defeat.

title: A Senior Palestinian Official Urges End to Suicide Attacks
description: The senior Palestinian security official who has been negotiating with Israel on a cease-fire denounced suicide attacks in an interview published today in an Israeli newspaper as ''murders for no reason,'' and said he was demanding that militant organizations abandon them.

title: Baseball Comes to Its Senses
description: So there will be a World Series after all. In the end, baseball players and owners did the smart thing, reaching a contract agreement without a strike. Yesterday's tentative four-year deal testified to both sides' willingness to compromise. It also reflected a shared recognition that a strike could have been truly damaging to baseball's health. It took five years for attendance to climb back to pre-strike levels after the 234-day work stoppage that wiped out the 1994 playoffs and World Series. A strike now, with ordinary fans rapidly losing patience with owners and players alike, would have been much harder to recover from.

title: Consumers Praised, or Blamed, for Aiding Recovery
description: Though the economy took a pummeling in the second quarter, consumers struck a modest blow for the recovery at the beginning of the third. The Commerce Department reported yesterday that personal spending in July jumped 1 percent, to $7.35 trillion -- the biggest increase in nine months -- thanks largely to low interest rates.

title: Containing Owens Is Just One of the Giants' Concerns
description: Terrell Owens wears the kind of shoes favored by an offensive lineman, or maybe a lumberjack or a carpenter -- tall and thick shoes that extend above the ankles. His shoes look very heavy until he runs in them.

title: At a Showcase for Talent, the Regulars Give Way to Youth
description: Much of the classical music world has rolled up its summer tent and headed off for a few weeks' quiet before the start of the new season. But at Bargemusic the concerts go on, and hearing a recital there on Thursday evening -- a night when there were few offerings for a concertgoer to choose from -- a listener was struck by how far this floating concert hall has come since 1977, when Olga Bloom began presenting her chamber music series there.

title: Roddick Steady as Peers Get Knocked Around
description: Overzealous autograph seekers formed a mosh pit against the court wall in Louis Armstrong Stadium as they reached, elbowed and muscled past one another to get Andy Roddick's attention yesterday.

title: Truckmaker Set To Lay Off 500
description: Paccar, the maker of trucks, said this week that it would lay off as many as 500 workers at a Tennessee heavy-truck factory. It cited tougher federal emissions rules for a decline in demand.

title: Court Backs Effort to Take Senator Who Switched Parties Off Primary Ballot
description: Overturning a lower court's ruling, the New York Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the Bronx Democratic Party has the right to remove State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. from its primary ballot, but not for the reasons it had cited. The matter was sent back to a trial court and the party committee, once again throwing the election into confusion.

title: Nassau Budget Deficit Is Worse Than Had Been Predicted
description: Nassau County's financial outlook is worse than officials had previously thought, with a possible deficit of $268 million next year, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said today.

title: Educator Has Accomplishments and Enemies
description: The new top educator in the New York City school system, Diana Lam, is known for starting fast with an aggressive reform agenda, racking up quick and impressive gains in academic achievement, and moving on. This seems to have earned her as many enemies as friends.

title: Yankees Win, and Are Just Happy to Play
description: Most of the Yankees were privately confident they would play at the Skydome tonight. The players and the owners were too close on the issues, the thinking went, to risk the harm a strike would cause.

He served as the House majority leader, not speaker of the House.

title: New Jobs For Labor Unions
description: In today's economy, rare is the worker who will spend his entire career in the same job. People are likely to have many employers, perhaps even several careers. Yet the labor movement remains attached to a 20th-century notion of its role: protecting members' employment, wages and benefits through collective bargaining.

title: Flurry of Legislation Puts California Governor in the Hot Seat
description: The California Legislature hurtled toward adjournment this weekend in a flurry of lawmaking, forcing Gov. Gray Davis to decide whether to sign dozens of bills backed by liberal lobbies but sharply opposed by business interests.

title: Vivendi's Chief Is Said to Favor Bidding American Units Adieu
description: When Jean-Ren Fourtou, the chief executive of Vivendi Universal, meets with board members in a few weeks, he plans to outline a new strategy that calls for separating the American entertainment division from the rest of the company, a person close to the company said today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. The possibility that a tropical storm in the Atlantic would disrupt fuel production in the Gulf of Mexico sent prices higher. Natural gas for October delivery rose 4.6 cents, to $3.296 a British thermal unit.

title: GENELABS FORECASTS APPROVAL FOR LUPUS DRUG
description: Genelabs Technologies Inc. said it might get federal approval for its Prestara lupus medicine, setting off a rally that doubled the price of its stock yesterday. The Food and Drug Administration, which rejected the drug last year, told Genelabs on Wednesday that it might approve Prestara if a study showed it prevented bone damage associated with lupus, the company said late Thursday. Genelabs said it would start the research this year or next. Prestara would be the first product for Genelabs, a 17-year-old biotechnology company based in the San Francisco suburb of Redwood City, Calif. The company's stock rose $1.43, to $2.82 a share.

title: 3 1/2-Year Sentence for Malcolm X Grandson
description: Malcolm Shabazz, the 17-year-old grandson of Malcolm X, was sentenced Thursday to three and a half years in prison for his role in the beating and robbery of another teenager in Middletown, N.Y., in January. The sentence is 18 months longer than the term a judge had planned for Mr. Shabazz before he missed his original sentencing hearing earlier this month.

title: Despite Slump, Cities See Drop In Welfare Rolls
description: During the boom years of the late 1990's, when the 1996 welfare law was still sending public assistance rolls plummeting nationwide and more recipients were leaving for jobs than anyone had expected, critics of the law had one big warning: wait until the economy sours, the poor will come back.

description: To the Editor:

title: Last-Minute Deal in Baseball Talks Prevents a Strike
description: For the first time in 30 years, Major League Baseball and its players reached agreement on a new labor contract without a work stoppage yesterday, concluding the deal a few hours short of a strike.

title: The Party Should Be Over
description: Even in the peculiar land of New York State politics, the Independence Party is a weird institution. Its active members agree on virtually nothing except opening up the election process, and ending a system ''rigged to guarantee the re-election of the incumbents.'' It was more than a little strange, then, that when the party leaders got together to pick a gubernatorial candidate, most of them chose -- Gov. George Pataki.

title: Investors Withdrew Record Total From Stock Mutual Funds in July
description: Investors withdrew a record $52.6 billion from stock mutual funds in July and shifted a record $28.1 billion into bond funds, an industry report said.

title: Sports of The Times; A Whiff of Failure Is Still in the Air
description: In the Mets' clubhouse, the television was showing the Cubbies, ''the only game in the majors this afternoon,'' as Ernie Banks loves to enunciate.

title: No Headline
description: The Rev. Dr. Edwin Louis Cole, whose experience with an abusive father inspired him to build a worldwide Christian ministry that demanded sexual and social responsibility from men, died on Tuesday in Grapevine, Tex. He was 79 and lived in nearby Southlake.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Government To Move Against Basque Party
description: The government said it would ask the Supreme Court next week to outlaw Batasuna, the political party accused of collaborating with the armed Basque separatist group, ETA. ''The request will explain in legal terms what is already clear to all of Spanish society: that Batasuna is terrorism's projection into politics,'' Justice Minister Jos Maria Michavila told reporters. The party plans to appeal a three-year ban imposed this week by a Spanish judge. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: College Football Begins in Full, Rekindling Hopes
description: Once the X's and O's were dispensed with at a news conference at the Meadowlands on Thursday, Notre Dame Coach Tyrone Willingham and Maryland's Ralph Friedgen fended off questions about the human angles that elevate their game tonight above just another opening game to the college football season.

title: U.S. Is Not the Only Nation Resisting a Strong Pact at the Summit Meeting on Global Warming
description: The photograph appears in a full-page advertisement in The International Herald Tribune under the headline ''Put a Face on Global Warming and Forest Destruction.''

title: F.A.A. Orders Inspections of Boeing Fuel Pumps for Miswiring
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the nation's commercial airlines today to check more than 1,400 planes manufactured by the Boeing Company to see if they are equipped with an improperly wired fuel pump that could cause an explosion in the rare event that fuel goes below minimal levels.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: JOHANNESBURG SUMMIT : At Johannesburg talks, warnings of AIDS' toll on the future
description: JOHANNESBURG:  The head of the UN's drive against AIDS complained Friday that world leaders at the Johannesburg summit were not devoting sufficient attention to the pandemic, warning that sustainable development would be impossible without a concerted attack on the effects of the disease.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: BHUTTO THWARTED IN ELECTION BID A local election official in southern Pakistan rejected an attempt by former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto to register for parliamentary elections scheduled for October. Ms. Bhutto's supporters immediately vowed to appeal the decision and accused the country's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, of pressuring the official into blocking her bid. A spokesman for Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan Peoples Party said her papers were rejected on the ground that she was convicted of absconding from the country while facing corruption charges in 1999.

title: MIDWEST EXPRESS FLIGHT ATTENDANTS PLAN WORK ACTION
description: Flight attendants at Midwest Express Airlines said yesterday that they planned to hold one-day strikes or other disruptions after their union failed to reach agreement on a contract. The 425 flight attendants were allowed to walk off their jobs after a 30-day cooling-off deadline expired without the Association of Flight Attendants reaching an accord. There were no flight disruptions as of yesterday afternoon in Milwaukee, but the company expects a work stoppage at some point, a spokeswoman said. The airline, which is based in Oak Creek, Wis., plans to maintain service by using managers who have been certified as flight attendants. Passengers will be accommodated on other airlines if flights are halted, the company said.

title: INSIDE
description: It's Game Day, Nationwide, For College Football Teams

title: State Fines Mount Sinai $66,000 and Bans Live Liver Transplants Indefinitely
description: Citing serious problems with patient care that may have contributed to several deaths, the state has fined Mount Sinai Medical Center $66,000 and extended its suspension of the hospital's live liver donor program indefinitely.

title: Abducted California Boy Is Found Safe; Mother Is Being Held
description: A tip from an employee at a San Diego County camping area led to the recovery today of a 9-year-old boy who had been whisked away from his Palm Desert home on Wednesday by gunmen who attacked his father.

title: Washington Talk; Prickly Roots of 'Homeland Security'
description: When the home front becomes the war front, what do you call the office meant to protect the country?

title: Ford Abandons Venture in Making Electric Cars
description: In another sign of the auto industry's struggle to make money selling electric vehicles, the Ford Motor Company said today that it was giving up on Think, an electric-car venture in which it sank $123 million. Instead, Ford said it would invest in other forms of alternative fuel technology like hybrid-electric vehicles and hydrogen fuel cells.

title: Krajicek Out for Season
description: Richard Krajicek announced yesterday that he will miss the rest of the season because of a hairline fracture in his left heel. The injury forced him to retire from his first-round match against Jiri Novak of the Netherlands. Once again, the oft-injured Krajicek is on crutches and expected to undergo surgery.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and the Quotation of the Day yesterday about the sentencing of Michael C. Skakel for the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley misspelled the surname of the Connecticut Superior Court judge who sentenced him. He is John F. Kavanewsky Jr., not Kavanewski.

title: Failing to Beat the Heat
description: The bees came inside my house this summer and stayed, as if there would be water here, or relief from the endless sun. They huddled together against the window glass, a living hive, and not even Bruce Springsteen's ''The Rising'' displaced them, not even the slow drawl of ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' which I read out loud to my son on the couch beneath the beehive. The bees came and they lived with us, and they endured, as we did, the heat, the blinding stifle of dust outside, the premature exhaustion of the trees beyond the glass.

title: A Soothing Anthem For Everybody
description: Before Sept. 11, John M. Guillot had composed what seemed to many a song of no commercial value. After that day, however, his song, ''The World Anthem,'' seemed to many to be a soothing antidote, and it was recorded by a 48-voice chorus with the Prague Studio Symphony Orchestra.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The dollar gained ground on the euro on a positive report on manufacturing activity in Chicago. In New York, the euro settled at 98.17 cents, down from 98.40 cents on Thursday.

title: Trees Fall in Canada's Forests, but U.S. Isn't Buying
description: In this tiny lumber village in the Canadian Rockies, people are more likely to take their vacations in Las Vegas or Disney World, retire in Arizona, drive Chevrolets and live in mobile homes imported from the United States.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I had a feeling they weren't going to strike. But when millionaires get together with billionaires, who knows what could happen? In the long run, if there is a strike, it's the small guy that always suffers.''

title: U.S. Approves Water Plan in California, but Environmental Opposition Remains
description: With California facing a year-end federal deadline to reduce its dependence on Colorado River water, the Interior Department has given its go-ahead to a $1 billion, 50-year plan to store and pump water from beneath private land in the Mojave Desert.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: No Visa For Catholic Priest
description: The government has denied a visa to a Slovak Roman Catholic priest, Catholic officials said, in the latest sign of tensions with the Vatican over the church's activities in Russia. The priest, the Rev. Stanislav Krajniak, had worked in a parish in Yaroslavl, northeast of Moscow, for a year before his visa expired this month. In April Russia stripped visas from two other Catholic clergymen. The Russian Orthodox Church has been increasingly critical of the Catholic Church, accusing it of proselytizing among the Orthodox. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Stock Fraud Investigated
description: The police are looking for as many as 10 people in an Internet stock fraud in which a dealer with Daewoo Securities bought $22 million in shares in a high-technology company with a password stolen from Hyundai Investment Trust Management. The dealer, identified by his surname, Ahn, was seized Thursday at Inchon International Airport after being extradited from Thailand at the request of South Korean authorities. He had flown to Bangkok after placing the order last Friday in an effort to drive up the stock price of Delta Information and Communication, listed on the over-the-counter Kosdaq. The police said both Ahn and a brother faced fraud charges along with a number of others still at large. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: TRADE PANEL SAYS EUROPE CAN IMPOSE PENALTIES ON U.S.
description: The World Trade Organization, the international arbiter in global trade disputes, ruled today that the European Union can impose $4 billion in penalties on the United States because an American tax break that promotes exports is illegal.

title: Season Has Been Saved, But Mets Still Look Lost
description: Bobby Valentine typically has boundless energy, but external factors made him pull an all-nighter Thursday.

title: Notes From Beverly Shores; Yesterday's Futurism, Today's Environmentalism
description: On a very clear day, a visitor to the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore can look northwest across Lake Michigan and see yesterday and tomorrow. Thirty-five miles away, the skyscrapers of Chicago split the horizon. On a wooded Indiana dune far above a white sand beach stands the 69-year-old House of Tomorrow, once an international attraction and the talk of Chicago. Its neighbors are four other oddly assorted single-family houses in varying states of disrepair.

title: In Those Days, Too, Blood and Sex Could Make a Best Seller
description: In 1796, a 20-year-old Oxford University graduate named Matthew Lewis published ''The Monk,'' a Gothic shocker unlike anything English society had ever seen. The novel told a lurid tale of sex and murder involving a Roman Catholic priest: Ambrosio, the revered head of a Capuchin monastery in Madrid, rapes and stabs Antonia, a local beauty of noble descent, in the crypt of the convent next door. The macabre nature of his crime is conveyed in graphic detail. The priest drugs her with an opiate so powerful that she is presumed dead and carted off in a coffin to the crypt, where, as soon as she revives, he forces himself on her and then finishes her off with two dagger blows to the heart. In an earlier fit of lustful frenzy, he also strangles her mother.

title: Charles M. Lichenstein, 75, American Envoy at the U.N.
description: Charles M. Lichenstein, who as America's No. 2 envoy at the United Nations 20 years ago offered to wave ''a fond farewell'' to the world body if its members chose to leave the United States, died on Thursday in Washington. He was 75.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Ex-President Closer To Prosecution
description: Former President Frederick Chiluba lost his bid to have the High Court overturn a parliamentary vote that stripped him of his immunity from prosecution, but he immediately appealed the ruling to the Supreme Court and won a stay of the ruling. Mr. Chiluba, who stepped down in January after a decade in office, has been accused of presiding over a corrupt administration, and his successor, Levy Mwanawasa, has made Mr. Chiluba a focus of the new administration's anticorruption drive. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Political Memo; Cuomo's Status: From Pedigree to Underdog
description: In the beginning, Andrew M. Cuomo had the glitz, the money and the reputation for bold new ideas.

title: Health Insurers Still Struggling With a Service On the Internet
description: A venture by seven big health insurers to take control of electronic services that link them with patients and doctors has run into financial trouble, industry officials said, and most of the companies have written down all or most of their investment in the effort.
